description:
I still cannot believe we found an amazing Vietnamese sandwich shop with reasonable prices in SF. 

SS is cash only, tons of beverage options, and great at what they do.

Parking is challenging, and expect to dodge the pan handler gauntlet.
author: Mikey R.

description:
I'm not sure what all the hype is about. I ordered a Thit Roast Pork. It is very cheap (only $4), and they do pack the sandwich with lots of ingredients (mainly pickled vegetables), but the taste was very mediocre. The pork was bland, the pickled vegetables weren't pickled enough, and they use miracle whip which is rather disgusting. On the plus side, the bread is fresh and crispy. The pickled vegetables are likewise fresh and crunchy.

There are only 2 chairs near the window, so this is a more grab and go kind of place. The area doesn't seem like a place you want to hang around in though. The sandwiches are cold, so you don't have to eat it right there. I recommend getting one to go and eating it elsewhere. They also sell some small snacks like Phong Kee Gourmet peanuts, which I enjoyed more than the banh mi.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
Great sandwiches at $4-5/ea. Crunchy baguettes, flavorful fillings, fresh bright veggies. Really well executed sandwiches that are great portions, satisfying and delicious for SUPER reasonable prices (lol in SF, one of the most expensive cities in the world nonetheless). 

For the record, after I found this Banh Mi shop (I'm Vietnamese too, so trust me these are yummy) I took a friend from Sonoma here and she ended up doing a repeat visit less than 24 hours later. 

Getchu some!!
author: Oanh M.

description:
The state of this business and the quality of the product screams authenticity. Every time I'm in SF I make it a point to come by this place and pick up a bunch of sandwiches.

The place: The epitome of tiny hole-in-the-wall, maybe two seats. More like a grab-and-go place.

The price: $4-5 dollars a sandwich. Cash only.

The service: There's always been a line when I've been. There's usually one or two ladies assembling the sandwiches, one lady taking orders (this may vary). It was kind of hard to order a couple times I went, and they got my order wrong once because I'm not sure they are the greatest at English. But it's okay! Makes the experience even *more authentic*

The food: INCREDIBLE, best banh mihs I have EVER had. Each sandwich is stuffed to the brim. I am a huge fan of the special combination and the pork pate.

And for that, 5 stars!
author: Wendi K.

description:
To those who've never been or known about Saigon Sandwich, it seems unthinkable that a small, nondescript sandwich shop located in the Tenderloin would be as popular as it is with lines frequently out the door and down the street.  But once you go there and order one of their sandwiches, you'll understand why.

Saigon Sandwich is a link to a bygone era of San Francisco (hell, the Bay Area as a whole, you could say) -- A time when things were much cheaper and people supported local businesses and did so in person (i.e. didn't have their lunch/food couriered to their office via Caviar or DoorDash).

As the name implies, Vietnamese sandwiches are what they serve here.  For the unacquainted, "bánh mì" sandwiches are a staple of Vietnamese cuisine.  Bánh mì, AFAIK, refers to the bread, but has come to colloquially refer to the sandwich as a whole.  They are known for being cheap no matter where you get them.  

Here at Saigon Sandwich, there are just 3-4 kinds of sandwiches to choose from.  I chose roast pork on my visit.  The sandwich was ready in a few minutes.  I paid $4.  CHEAP.  What I especially like about this place is that, even though the lines get long, they seem to be very efficient and organized when it comes to processing orders.  One lady took down everyone's orders quickly while another lady prepped the sandwiches.  I also like how they wrap the parchment paper around your sandwich with a rubber band so it won't unwrap itself and make a mess.  How many other sandwich places / delis do that?

My sandwich was, to say the least, awesome.  On a roughly 6-8 inch baguette, there were plentiful servings of the aforementioned roast pork, plus carrots, cilantro, green peppers, onions, and a mystery sauce.  The sandwich was also spicy but not overwhelmingly so.  To have paid $4 for this, I was really happy and am not surprised that this place is so popular.

A few notes:

* Don't bother trying to eat-in.  There are only a few stools, and it's very small inside.

* It's located in the Tenderloin.  You will likely see a number of transients and vagrants nearby.  They probably won't accost you, as long as you ignore them.  If this makes you uncomfortable, take an Uber or Lyft.

* CASH ONLY.

SUPPORT SMALL BUSINESSES.

5 stars all the way
author: Michael F.

description:
Yikes...I'm gonna be one of those few people who will be giving this place less than 5 stars.

I walked to TL to try this banh mi spot. I've heard great things about their banh mi. How it's really good. How it tastes authentic yadda yadda yadda. Because of all the ravings, I had high hopes and high expectation of how authentic it will taste like. And, maybe that's partially why I'm not giving this a stellar review because my expectation was a wee bit high. And...I know how Vietnamese food tastes like.

Let's start by saying, this ain't authentic banh mi. But it was still good. I'd like to say it's a hybrid banh mi...between Vietnamese and Chinese. The bread wasn't the consistency that I'm used to from San Jose or L.A but it was decent. They put some sauce in the sandwich. It wasn't the typical mayo sauce. There was definitely some mayo sauce along with a brown sauce. I know other people like that brown sauce and some ask for extra sauce but honestly, that brown sauce kinda threw me off because it made the sandwich tastes different than the traditional banh mi. I thought it overpowered other ingredients in the banh mi.

Maybe, next time, I'll ask for less brown sauce and see how that'll turn out to be. This place is good but it's not as authentic as I thought it would be. But, I'd come back when I have a craving for banh mi.
author: Ngoc P.

description:
With 3,000+ reviews, there's not much of a need for me to justify going here. You won't find a better deal in SF! For $4, you get a filling banh mi sandwich that doesn't lack in meat nor veggies and it will remind you of Vietnam. Being from Missouri, I can't even find this good of a deal at any sandwich shop. So to find it here is a treat! 

Go and grab one of the Asian snacks or drinks too while you're there. It is a quick and easy stop for lunch or on the way home.

Don't expect to sit down as seating is limited to just a couple chairs and bring cash. And likewise with other restaurants in the area, please don't let the location hinder you from going. Walking in the daytime is fine. You may feel unsafe seeing the increase in homeless people, but keep to yourself and don't show off expensive jewelry and no one will bother you. The TL is full of great eats, especially Vietnamese, and deserves to be recognized for that.
author: Brandon S.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is delicious, cheap, and simple. 

We've ordered everything off the limited menu, which all follows a near-perfect formula: quality crunchy bread, marinated juicy roast meats, and surprisingly fresh vegetables. Saigon Sandwich isn't trying to change up the Banh Mi formula, they just execute it well. 

Note that if you head here for an early dinner, it's likely they will be out of the roast pork. Also, for people unfamiliar with SF, Saigon Sandwich is located in the infamous tenderloin, so be prepared for a pretty rough neighborhood.
author: Yuchen L.

description:
Fantastic banh mi restaurant in SF... probably one of the best in the city because the sandwich really is delicious and the price is what it's supposed to be (darn you fidi).

The baguette is so fresh and crunchy. It's on the smaller side of banh mi sandwich lengths I would say.... but hey, for $4 you can just get two. They also don't cut the sandwich in half for you... perhaps that is something you should request prior to them handing it to you (fastest service ever). Although, I did mention to the lady that I didn't want cilantro and also wanted to change my pate sandwich to combo: I got neither requests fulfilled LOL. Sooooo if you have special accommodations, make sure to really spell it for them since their English isn't that great. Plenty of standard banh mi toppings.... delicious sandwich. Would love to go back again. Also note that you pay after you receive tour sandwich. Cash onlyyyyyy.

Two chairs in the store for two lucky people to sit. Wouldn't really recommend sitting anywhere near here since there isn't a place to sit and not sure you would want to chill around the area anyways. WOULD recommend walking two blocks to Civic Center to sit on either the benches near the (new) playground or steps in front of Civic Center. If you walk past the first playground area, you may find some chairs with tables, depending on the time of day.
author: Cathy C.

description: My favourite banh mi place in the Bay Area - great value, super efficient and full of flavour. I recommend the roasted chicken and roasted pork. The fancy pork is processed pork so only choose that if you are looking for that texture. The place also offers a variety of traditional Vietnamese snacks and desserts. I'm never quite sure what dessert I'm trying but I haven't tried anything that I wouldn't have again.
author: Aileen C.

description:
Attention: Depending on the time you come, there might be a line. Sometimes the line goes out to the street.

If there is a Banh mi place for heaven on earth, this is it! In San Francisco. $4 Banh Mi (yes they have vegetarian tofu option), who can beat that price? Freshly made, with authenticity, loudness, and speed of every Asian woman standing in the kitchen.

Now I can't remember if it was CASH ONLY, but it's an Asian place. So just bring cash.

Don't forget to tell them not to give you a plastic bag. You'll get a $1 discount. Ok that was a lie, but you don't need a plastic bag when you're gonna devour the banh mi already wrapped in paper right away. #BANplastic #dontbeignorant #yourgrandkidsdidntasktodrowninplastic
author: Tim C.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is soooooo overhyped. I really do not understand the popularity. I'm guessing their biggest pro is how fast they are able to make the sandwiches after you order. Everyone is in and out real quick. They are also willing to customize your order how you like, just make sure you tell them clearly. Their customer service could be better though.

Its a decent quick meal for the value/price, but is it worth the almost 3k reviews? overhyped.

Tastewise, the bread is crunchy and could be softer. They give you plenty of veggies and meat, but after having their banh mi several times, I think I'm over it. They are usually way too salty for my liking. I end my meal feeling super thirsty or like I need to cleanse my palette somehow. To bypass the saltiness, I would recommend going for the vegetarian options or the fancy/steamed pork.

Of course everything is way better than the Lee's Sandwiches banh mi (down the street), so please don't ever choose Lee's for banh mi. It's practically inedible (Their other options are much better, like the different specialty vietnamese desserts/pastries, roasted chicken, vermicelli, waffle, etc)
author: Angela C.

description:
3.25/5
I've never met a banh mi I didn't like until I came here which was a huge surprise considering the ratings. Maybe I just got the wrong items? Maybe they had an off day? Maybe my taste buds had an off day? Either way I just wasn't feeling either sandwich I got (yeah that's right, I was so excited to try this place out I got two!)

Came on a weekday and there was no line at all. Bought two sandwiches and walked straight to the library. The shop is small and it's definitely a takeout kind of place. Got a combination and a roasted chicken. They didn't skimp on the fillings for either. The bread for both was that good type of slight stale on the inside but overall the bread was too soft (I did have a short walk but not long enough for the bread to go soggy). The flavors of the combination were just all that memorable. Usually I like getting the different meat textures and spices but this predominantly tasted of the sweetness from the carrots. The roasted chicken alone was fine though it's not amazing chicken either (at least it wasn't dry). 

Overall, I just don't get the hype. I'm glad I didn't wait in line for this at least.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Epitome of "hole in the wall," Saigon Sandwich totally delivers on high-quality food for a low price. At around 2pm, there was a constant stream of people walking in and out with wrapped banh mi sandwiches. It seemed like most of them were locals swinging by for their late lunch meals.

Tim M and I split the steam+roast pork and the special combination (each $5). Both were awesome! The special combination, which include pate, was slightly better, I suppose, but both were packed filled with their given proteins and the regular accoutrements.

One of the best banh mi I've had in a long time - dare I say "ever"!
author: Jess L.

description: This is the absolute best bahn mi in San Francisco.  It's a total hole-in-the-wall through and through, but they do fresh, tasty sandwiches at a tremendous value.  Dollar for dollar, you can't beat this deal of a meal that also delivers on taste.  I usually get the roasted chicken with all the fixings, including jalapeños, but the other options are all good too.  Cash only, but if you've only got a few singles left in your pocket, that's all you'll need!
author: Sel C.

description:
Tenderloin has an abundance of Vietnamese restaurants in-fact there are as many as 4 specialized Banh-Mi (sandwiches) restaurants. Saigon Sandwich and L&G Vietnamese Sandwich are two that are literally across from each other.

I decided to try Saigon Sandwich first as it had a 4.5 star rating with almost 3000 reviews. It is small shop that generally has a line out of the door. The good news is that it moves pretty fast. The menu is pretty limited with I think 6 different types of Banh-mi which includes steam pork, roast port, pork pate, roast chicken and the combination. Prices of most of the sandwiches are $4 with tax.

I generally get a couple of roast chickens which are enough for a full meal. The sandwiches are solid. The only complaint will be that the French roll is a little to crispy, but I like it. Not much else to say expect that Saigon Sandwich stands head and shoulder over all the other Banh-Mi restaurants in the hood. Generous 4.5 stars rounded up to 5 is how I'd rate this place.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I didn't have this fresh - I devoured it many hours later but it was still good. The bread was still crisp and not soggy after all that time. I got the special combination sandwich - it had cold cuts, Pate and a cooked meat along with the pickled carrots, cilantro and peppers. I thought the combination was pretty interesting... different than the regular cold cut sandwich. It erred on the sweeter side, perhaps because of the pate - the pate was definitely on the sweeter side and there was a super generous portion of it. The sandwich itself looks pretty small but it has a hefty weight to it. 

It's $5 for a sandwich and you they have it prepped and delivered in your hands in minutes. Great for a quick lunch. There wasn't a line when we went but there was a continuous stream of people trickling in. I would recommend if you don't mind the low health score rating!
author: Maggie W.

description:
Tasty AND cheap sammiches stuffed with a bunch of veggies and your choice of meat. This hole in the wall is ran by two ladies who are fast multitaskers! I got the fanci pork sandwich with their dessert drink and it came to a total of $7 :D

My sandwich had a nice crunchiness to it and the veggies were fresh with a hint of sweetness. I also loved their mayo based sauce which I believe ties all the flavors together. This tiny shop has two seats inside. I managed to grab one and devour my sandwich while I stared at people with a stuffed mouth. Will be back again to try the other meats!
author: Sui N.

description:
This was the first time I had been to Saigon Sandwich. If you did not happen to see the crowded line inside, you easily would have walked past, especially considering that it is in the Tenderloin.

The sandwiches are a steal at $4 (September 2018). They fill up the sandwiches with a good balance of protein and vegetables. I had the grilled pork banh mi. My only complaint here was that the sandwich had a bit too much sauce on it and hence the baguette was soaked through. Either they need to change the baguette or use a bit less sauce (perhaps they just used a bit too much on mine). And they did not have any containers for siracha to go, so they gave me some in a ziplock bag. Besides those 2 items, I will definitely be back. This place is great.

There's a small counter to eat at the window but don't count on being able to eat inside. Take it to-go and be on your merry way.
author: David D.

description:
CASH ONLY

Honest Banh Mi review here. The value that you get from this place is amazing - An assortment of Banh Mi ranging from $4-$5 in San Francisco? Sounds pretty unheard of, but at this local hole in the wall that is exactly what is being served. On the blackboard to the right when you enter is the many of different types of Banh Mi that you can order, ranging from the traditional combination Banh Mi to specialties such as Pate. In the back of the shop you can see all of the Vietnamese ladies hard at work, piling on loads of pickled radish and carrots and meat onto baguette rolls. The bread itself is not baked fresh - you can see them heating it up in a toaster oven in the back, and when you bite into the bread, it is a bit hard.

I ordered the Combination and the Pate Banh mi. Both were pretty good - the meat from the combination Banh mi was nice and flavorful, and the mousse from the Pate Banh mi was rich yet delicate. However, what makes this place special is their sauce that they slather onto the Banh mi. It's sweet and savory, and oozes out of the Banh mi when you bite into it. It's a tad bit too sweet and heavy for my taste, but it's still delicious. The bread as I mentioned before is a bit hard - and for those reasons I give this place a solid 4 out of 5 stars. However, this Banh Mi should be the people's choice in San Francisco, as it's cheap price and solid quality will definitely provide you with a delicious and satisfying meal.
author: Gregory T.

description:
4 stars for the banhmi and one more for the price and efficiency 1 making it a total of 5 stars  

A really small place where you can pick up banhmi's to go. They are delicious and super affordable - $4 for a pretty good size banhmi. I always get the tofu - that's their vegetarian one and my husband likes the roasted pork. They sometimes have a line but they are super efficient and I'm always out in under 10 minutes with my order.
author: Eshita S.

description:
Very authentic, cheap, and delicious! It's only $4, and they prepare it extremely quickly. There's not much seating, so we just grabbed it and ate elsewhere. 

Despite not eating it right away (we finally ate it around ~30 mins after), it was still crunchy! They give a lot of filling and it's flavored really well. My friend even said it was comparable to the Vietnamese sandwiches he had in Vietnam. 

No other place can compare with the price nor taste. I'd definitely come back, highly recommend.
author: Aileen J.

description:
The best bahn mi in the city, hands down. Pork for life. 

For the uninitiated, when there's a long line you stand in line until the woman asks for you order. She typically takes like ten orders at a time. Step into the store enough that she can take your order but then stay in line because payment doesn't happen until you actually get your sandwich. Add on drinks or other stuff from the front when you pay. Unless you have special requests a simple "2 pork" is all you need to say.
author: Katherine W.

description: $5 ba minh. Cash only. Best sandwich you'll eat. Well-balanced. Bright. Recommended by a friend who'd been going since she was a sprout in her Mama's belly. You'll feel like you've been let in on a wonderful secret. You will not regret a visit.
author: Sarah S.

description:
VEGETARIAN REVIEW

the tofu bahn mi is absolutely delicious!! the tofu, the sauce, the mayo, the cilantro, pickled carrots, the baguette, SO DELICIOUS. for $4, what A DEAL. never change.
author: Shruti D.

description:
What happened to the good old days when 1 Banh Mi was priced at $3 to $4? Just walk down Market Street of the financial district and almost every Banh Mi ranges from $7 to $8+. Now isn't that a scam? If that isn't then I don't know what is. 

Although you will be risking your safety to get here (not saying you should), it's a really great deal for $4 to $5 sandwiches and here's why. 

1. The Aunties are super quick to prep dozens of sandwiches for a constant line of customers. 

2. The Banh Mi is packed with a generous amount of meat and pate (for the combination special). 

3. Price is flat (cash only), no BS. 

4. Everything about this place has an authentic feel, the other hipster Banh Mi joints are just way too pretentious.

All I got to say to the Aunties is, stay true and loyal.
author: Victor Q.

description: Much cheaper than some of the other banh mi joints in the East Bay.  The beauty is in its simplicity and quality.  The pickled veggies were on point and I like that they offer different meat options.  The bread is toasted perfectly.  10/10 I'd come again if I'm in the area.
author: Jason L.

description:
Easily the best banh mi sandwich I've ever had and the cheapest! It was only 4 bucks!! Unheard of in the city. I decided to buy two and took them with me on the Caltrain. It's not a sit down type of place but my sandwiches were ready in easily 3 minutes. 

This place is truly a hole in the wall. I can definitely concur with other reviewers that the banh mi here is excellent. Their bread is fresh and literally was what made it so great. I got their fancy pork and roast pork. Both excellent. And for just 8 dollars!! Again this place is crazy amazing. 

Also they accept cash only so scrap up some dollars around the house and you'll be good!
author: Leonardo O.

description:
Visiting from out of town and was craving some CHEAP banh mi. And this place was close to where we were staying.

$4 for a sandwich ! I scoff at places that charge $8+ for one (and this is not in SF.) Both the chicken and roast pork I got were good. One is enough for lunch. 

This isn't in the best location, but it's good, fast, and cheap.

There isn't really any seating. If you're lucky you can get a seat at the window, but more of a grab and go place. Cash only I think?...
author: Mel N.

description:
$4!!!

For a sandwich?? In SF?? 

My mind is blown. And I thought they slumped on the meat and stuffed it with veggies, but I got a lot of chicken! 

I'm not the biggest fan of cilantro, but the sandwich just worked. The crunchy, hardy French bread with the sweet chicken and pickled veggies...it's a hunger cure. 

Possible one of the best bangs for you buck in SF. It's not the most appealing looking place, but it's a hidden gem amongst hipster brunch restaurants.

Only thing is that I'm not a fan of mayo, but what's a bahn mi without it? It's a good bite.
author: Lilian K.

description: Great place at a great value! I ordered online and picked it up in person. Lots of flavor and authenticity. This is my first time there but won't be my last!
author: Ron M.

description:
3.5 Stars

Good food. Quality bread. 
Not much variety though.
Would still definitely eat here again
author: Michael D.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is a good value. 
It's one of the best in the city, but it doesn't quite taste the same as my favorite SJ spots. I'm still happy with their sandwiches. They can take my money anytime.
author: Huey N.

description:
I went to both this place and L&G  Sandwich across the intersection and i must say that they are both good. This shop was operated by several ladies who were hustling.  Their "motor" was impressive and would grade out well if they were rushing the passer in Football or going for rebounds in basketball but I digress...

I got the grilled pork Banh mi. As I noted in the L&G review  I can't really say that one is clearly better than the other I would probably go to the one that had the smaller line. The price of the Banh Mi's are $4 a pop.
author: Rod M.

description:
What's the lowest health score you will ignore for an amazing authentic Bahn Mi?  For me, it's this place, and the score is displayed on the front door, can't miss it.  But there's a line out the door hiding the sign anyway, and that's what I'm looking for.
French roll just this side of stale, perfect in my opinion.  Still soft inside but kinda chewy crust.  With crunch.  The pork is tender, sauce delicious, the veggies are bright colors and nicely pickled, cilantro and peppers were fresh cut and beautiful green.  It's about twice what I can eat in one sitting, but I'll be craving the other half within an hour cause I want to taste more.  More of an intermission than leftovers.

AND I didn't know it was cash only.  I had $3 and a card and she said she'd take the $3 instead of $4.  As long as I remembered her, which she repeated three times.  It might have been a hex, but damn if I won't already tell everybody how good that bahn mi was.  It's not as if I could help but do so anyway.

By the way, no seating, just a counter and a huge kitchen.  Find yourself a green nook in the city and eat there.

I won't even tell you the score.  We'll see if I post an update to this review in about 24 hours :-)  Until then, run, don't walk, and get yourself a Sammie.
author: LakeLady A.

description:
Ahhh...

No. I do NOT know why people love this place. Other than it's a cheap eat in a damn expensive city. The food here sucks out loud! There's also only two spots to sit. If you miss out you listen to people gloat. 

I ordered the chicken and it's essentially sliced deli meat on crappy French bread, with waaay too much carrot. The only thing that dresses it up is the sauce. This is the sorriest excuse I've ever seen for a Banh Mi in my existence. 

If you're cash poor, I can see why people eat here. Otherwise avoid this place. I don't eat pork. I can't speak to the quality of that. But avoid the chicken AT ALL COSTS!!!
author: Lea S.

description:
I have nostalgia for this place. It was one of the first places I came to when I visited San Francisco in early 2016. Almost two years later, and it remains one of my favorite locations in the city. The ladies working there have warmed up to me (probably because I used to show up nearly 3 times a week for a few months), and $4.00 for a filling sandwich is a steal- not to mention the taste is better than any other spot I've tried.

AMBIANCE is quaint. It's a tiny shop- if you arrive after 10 am, you'll notice a line forming down the street. It's that popular. I learned to arrive between 8 and 9 am, where there is little to no line. There are a couple chairs to sit, but with everyone in line to get food, it's a cramped experience. Walk down Larkin and turn right on Turk to find a few spots to sit and enjoy your meal.

FOOD is always amazing. I get the roast pork banh mi, which is delicious. They really stuff the sandwiches with the meat, veggies, and sauce, so you always get the bang for your buck (take notes, Chipotle). There's lots of Vietnamese treats inside- I've tried a few and highly recommend them.

RATING is a favorite five. I adore this spot. If you are considering this spot on a list of things to do or try in the city, this should be #1 (make sure you get there early- they open at 7:00 am, so no excuses!).
author: Nicholas G.

description: Hands down the best banh mi I've ever had. Although the prices have climbed up a bit ($4.75 for the combo sandwich), this place is still incredibly affordable compared to other Vietnamese sandwich places (~$7 per sandwich). Definitely a hole in the wall kind of place but don't be mistaken, this place is the place to go! The sandwiches are STUFFED with meat and veggies, these ladies do not skimp. The pate is out of this world and the signature sauce that they drizzle on each sandwich is basically liquid gold. Packed with flavor and super satisfying. They also have a veggie option with tofu!
author: Annie N.

description:
Grew up in SF..this place was my go-to place.
Coming back to this place, reminds me of my childhood and how fast time went by. Some people that didn't grew up in SF may find this place to be overly hyped and would prefer a different place that sells different types of Vietnamese sandwiches, i.e. Banh Mi with grilled duck. But traditional VN sandwiches are usually very simple and the selections are always: pork, chicken, beef, or a vegetarian option. Banh Mi is actually street food and to attend a Banh Mi place that's too upscale is overrated. Saigon Sandwich has not changed and it has been over 29 years and despite the changes throughout the Bay Area and in the city, Saigon Sandwich is still the best place to go especially for all the SF natives.
author: N A.

description:
I relish a bomb ass (really good) banh mi. When it comes to this quintessential French inspired sandwich, I personally think that the bread is key. Unfortunately, the baguette from here was too hard and crumbly. We tried the highly revered special combination and the roast pork sandwiches. While each sandwich offered a wealth of delicious flavors in each bite, the disappointing quality of the baguette is unforgivable in my book.

If you want stellar banh mi, you'll need to drive all the way to east side San Jose...or fly all the way to Vietnam. For SF, I guess this place is solid, but we wouldn't come back. 

+ Cash only
author: Merica S.

description: No joke. Hands down best Banh Mi in town. Perfect balance of fresh baguette, pickled veggies, meat, white sauce, cilantro and green pepper. I plan on trying all 3-4 meat options. I had the roasted pork this first go and it was simply magical.
author: Alex B.

description: This place is BOMB. Nothing like an treacherous trip through the TL to make you appreciate this gem of a place. These are one of the best banh mis I've had. They make sure to cut out some filling of the baguette so you're eating even amount of bread to meat/veggies. There is a LOT of substance in these -- especially the delicious pate. For $4-5 (after tax!), you bet I'm coming back.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Last Saturday my boyfriend and I dropped by here again. And although I love this place and hate that I have to write this review, this time around eating here gave us BOTH really bad food poisoning/diarrhea that lasted longer than a day. How do I know it was them? We ONLY had Saigon sandwich for lunch/early dinner that day (since we loved it so much). That day I also saw that they had a sign up declaring their food safety rating was in the 70s, which fell under the category of "needs improvement." 

At first, I thought maybe it could be something I ate from the day before, but shortly after I showed symptoms so did my boyfriend. As good as it is, I honestly do not know if I would take the risk to eat here again...
author: Trinh D.

description:
Best banh mi in all of sf! Super cheap and made to order. A sandwich there will cost you 4 bucks and some chump change. 
Their pate is bomb and I love that they load up their sandwiches with it. What makes their banh mi bomb is their uniquely dense French bread. Their bread is different that other banh mis I've had before. Almost like a cross between a croissant and French baguette. It's perfect. They load each loaf with loads of meat and toast your sandwich minutes before serving. They also don't skimp on the amount of pickled veggies either. This place is winner in my book. Always worth digging into my couch to find enough change to get me a combo banh mi at Saigon Sandwich!
author: Michelle C.

description: Had to go see what was up with this place. It's a no frills vietnamese Bahn mi sandwich shop. there are 4 choices and we got 2 of them the pork and the chicken. Both were pretty good. tons of meat, but I would rather have more of the pickled carrots and daikon. Bread was good but not the best i've had. all the sandwiches are $4. They're not much for personality but they are FAST!
author: Vince L.

description:
Wow, this might be simultaneously the cheapest and also the best banh mi I've had in my life. At $4.00 for a roast pork banh mi, it doesn't get cheaper than this. While everything was good, I think the sauce is what made the banh mi truly stand out. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying the special combination banh mi.

It's important to note that this place is cash-only. Also, seating is very limited.
author: Daniel N.

description: Simply good! Best Vietnamese sandwich in town. I'd recommend the chicken for starters.
author: Jimmy T.

description:
This place is hella busy and crowded during rush hours. Lines are constantly running out the door

I only saw 2 workers: one toasting baguettes/making banh mi, and one working the register while pausing to help out with making banh mi. They were friendly and efficient but it can get frustrating; they ask everyone in line to yell out their orders and you find yourself a small corner to wait for your order and then pay (cash only, atm at liquor store next door to the left). But that's how they get the job done!

They offer cold drinks on the right hand side, but all basic American drinks. You can order a classic Vietnamese cafe sua đa. There's a limited selection of Vietnamese desserts at the front, but nothing savory like banh gio which I was looking for.

I got banh mi dac biet and banh mi thit nuong. I'm not a huge fan of their roast pork cut which was kind of dry and seasoning lacking that touch of Vietnamese sweetness. Would be better if more pickled carrots, pate, and butter was added since it was a bit dry.

The banh mi here have the same names as other places but the cuts, flavors, and types of meat are not as classic. This might suit some people but sometimes you just want the same ol' one. Affordable and convenient meal but would try other places-- hype not getting to me.
author: Vivian T.

description:
I've heard this place has super great Xiu Mai Banh Mi so I was really excited to try it out. It's located in a little hole in the wall store in SF and it's a really tiny store but the line gets pretty long. The parking is practically nonexistent, so be prepared to either get dropped off if someone drives you there or look around for parking. 

The line was out the door when I came and there was barely any room inside the store so you just have to squish to the side while waiting for your order. There were only 2 ladies working so it was a little slow, but I was fine with it. 

I finally got to eat the sandwich and I wouldn't say it was amazing. The bread was a little hard/stale and xiu mai wasn't extremely flavorful, but I do get why people enjoy the sandwich - the pickled veggies complemented the rest of the ingredients very well. I hope the next time I come back the bread is a little softer and the sandwich as a whole is better! 

Overall a 3.5 star experience, really.
author: Julie N.

description:
Hands down one of the best banh mi I've ever had, and it's hard to beat for only $4! This will definitely fill you up. I was a little surprised to see such high reviews for a banh mi restaurant, so I was skeptical at first at this "hole in the wall" place. I was greatly mistaken. The banh mi was made within a couple minutes, and it was extremely easy for a grab-and-go meal. My friends ordered the chicken, and I ordered the pork. Both were really good. You can't go wrong at this place! 

Taste: 4/5 
Bang for buck: 5/5
author: Lander L.

description: THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH PLACE FOR ROAST CHICKEN BANH MI!! What are you doing if you haven't had the roast chicken banh mi from here? Although the combo banh mi is good too, but the roast chicken is bomb!! Parking isn't hard to find but it's not in the safest neighborhood, so i suggest having one person buy the sandwiches and just sit in the far(there are very limited space inside as it is not a place where you order and enjoy your time getting there.) Definitely worth the trip for those roast chicken banh mi!!
author: Emily H.
John A.

description: Tiny little place with bomb ass sandwiches! Roast pork is what I normally get. So good! They usually have long lines but it goes by pretty fast
author: Jeannette C.

description:
So my friend heard about this place and it was supposed to be amazing, so she got a bunch of us to walk through the tenderloin to get here. At about $4 a sandwich, the place is a pretty good deal considering how expensive SF is and how large the portion of meat was inside of the sandwich.

I got a BBQ pork sandwich, and while they gave us a lot, and the pork was decent, it wasn't what I expected since it was a bit different than the Vietnamese sandwiches I was used to. Generally the banh mi uses a fattier type of pork for the BBQ pork, and here it looked like they mostly used lean pieces of pork. The flavors also tend to be more intense.

While it was still good, this healthier version doesn't quite encapsulate the essence of the BBQ pork Vietnamese sandwich in my opinion, and is more of a westernized version of the dish (even though the dish itself has western influences).

I also had the Che 3 Mau, which was in a cup and is a coconut milk dessert with mung bean, red beans, and tapioca pieces. That was okay, and isn't really a stand out item here. I would pass on that in the future.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Best banh mi I ever had, hands down.

Let's talk about location. We started walking from our hotel around 930am, very much locals walking around and some sketchy people here and there. The place is small, one mini table with one chair to sit if you decide to eat and people watch. This is definitely take out, the menu is on the wall. The items are written in Vietnamese but to the left of it is in English. We ordered Xiu Mai and Combo.

I am a mad woman when it comes to my Banh mi, I like extra pate and mayo/butter. Well this lady listened to me because she probably put a pound of pate on my sandwich, haha! She was very friendly and we paid cash. I didn't see a credit card machine, but I cannot confirm if it's cash only. 

Got back to our hotel and I felt like I was in heaven. The banh mi gods had blessed me with a good joint nearby our hotel. Although, it was too much pate, I did take some out. Pate was fatty and flavorful. Grilled Pork meat was ok. Cha Lua slices were thin, could've used more slices. Xiu mai was also good, it didn't have sauce. It's straight up crumbled meat. BREAD was crispy and soft in the inside. Each bite with everything combine, heaven. Gonna come back again tomorrow.
author: Cecilia H.

description:
Great sandwiches, not just because of price (most people rave about) but the flavor in the fillings are quite good.  The bread is awesome and that's what really sets this place a part from the rest.  Try any of the sandwiches (my fav is bbq pork)  all very good. Service Is friendly. 

Food 5
Service 4.5
Overall 5
author: Patrick C.

description:
Cheap! that's it!

for only $4.00 each, you have to be happy.
but to be honest with you, compares to the Banh Mis I've had in Virginia / DC Area, this place is far behind.
the baguette is too crunchy (lack chewiness) and the pork is little bit dry and not enough juice.

Cheap Hole in the Wall!
get the " Cha Lua (Vietnamese Pork Roll / Ham / they called it "fanci pork").
and Tofu.
go and try them, you have nothing to lose.
author: Rudy H.

description: Great banh mi for the price! I can't believe most places in the city are charging over $8 for banh mi these days! Sure they don't offer more interesting options like duck and all but if you're looking for a simple and good ol' banh mi, this is the place!
author: Claire S.

description: These are some straight up, no BS, great bang for your buck banh mi sandwiches!  For less than $4, they stuff your sandwich with the meat of your choice and plenty of pickled veggies. Cheap and delicious!
author: Sennett L.

description:
Due to the hype, I was really excited to check this place out. I ordered the combination special, which was $5 and included every thing. When I came home and unwrapped the sandwich, a small fly flew out. I kid you not, I was pretty shooked but that did not deter me enough to avoid eating the sandwich altogether. However, the combination special is way too liquidy and messy for my liking. Every time I held up the sandwich, a bit of patte, patte juice or the mayo filling would fall out. It kind of reminded me of questionable lunch meat that is slathered on your plate. I may have just ordered the wrong menu item so I haven't crossed this place off completely. My boyfriend ordered a different item and said his was not as messy in addition to the taste being fine. The ladies that work there are pretty nice and the food comes out quick. 

!!!CASH ONLY!!!
author: Linh N.

description:
Location aside...the sandwiches are awesome.  Located in quite a dodgey part of town, Saigon Sandwich is one of a number of sandwich shops in the neighborhood that serve delicious banh mi. 

Cash only, the queue moves fast.  The menu is fairly simple.  Get the roast pork, which is just very flavorful.  The combination has pork and pate, which is yummy too.  Canned drinks available for purchase in the stand up fridge. 

I sort of felt like it's one of those places where you better know what you want when it's your turn to order.  Because the regulars would get peeved along with the workers.  I don't think they took my name or gave me a number...but after shouting the order a few times, the other customers alerted me to the order.  It's such a small shop that I had to stand outside for the wait.  


Now the location is VERY undesirable.  The sidewalks are filthy, (and smells as if every inch was painted in aged urine).  I saw several used needles across the street where I parked, and several people just "hanging out").  

So...if you are a food adventurer, yeah come on into the "Loin"...there are some treasures.  But I've had my banh mi craves before and found them in less dangerous and smelly neighborhoods.   

Pricing is about $5-6 per cash only.  There's some metered parking along the street.  We took our sandwiches to a park to enjoy far from the Loin.  

Beware...if you have the peppers in the sandwiches...it really packs heat!
author: Monty W.

description: Probably the best Banh Mi I've had. I got the Roasted chicken. Must try when in San Francisco
author: Chris D.

description:
I've been here several times - legit sandwiches for sure.  Soft bread, lots of filling, and price reasonable for SF standards at $4 a pop. Yes, it's located in an iffy part of town - but I prefer great hole in the wall spots vs so many overrated places in nicer parts of town.  It's a small place, so taking the sandwiches to go are your best bet.  There's a small counter by the window that can maybe sit 2 to 3 people. 

Today, I saw this lady hustling her ass off to make sandwiches at lightning speed. She worked quick to keep up with the customers and still was so friendly. Extra props to her.
author: Laura C.

description:
Still out must stop when we are in the city. Best pate ever!  We even got our daughter in loving the banh mi here. $4.50 per sandwich cuz we ask for extra pâté to be added but it's a full meal and will keep you full for a few hours. 
Be ready with cash and know what you want, you order, stand aside with cash in hand. You will be called in a few minutes, pay and you're out. Simple and fast. No place to sit to eat. Quite simple but oh so good.
author: Ann N.

description:
Love coming here to get Vietnamese sandwiches.
When I was first introduced to Banh Mi, I would only order the Chicken. However, now my go to is the Combo. The price point for these sandwiches is also great. The system they have is very efficient as it is a small shop, but you get your sandwich(es) fairly quickly. One of the best in San Francisco!
author: Michelle C.

description: Easily the best little Vietnamese sandwich I ever had! So much juicy meat with tons of flavor, fresh crunchy bread yet soft in the middle, great handful of carrots and spread, all for $4! Craving one as I write. Definitely worth the trip if you're in the area!
author: Quyen T.

description:
Favorite place to get banh mi ever!

LOVEEE this place. It's a little hole in the wall that can get pretty busy during lunchtime but the ladies working make the sandwiches quickly. They are super generous with the portions here and are able to keep their prices low! My go to is the combination pork sandwich and I love how much pate they put in the sandwich and they definitely don't skimp out on meat and picked veggies. You can also get your veggies on the side if you want to stock up on sandwiches without getting the bread all soggy. 

They also offer plenty of snack, drink, and dessert selection so it's basically a one-stop shop!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
If you have some Asian blood in you (whether that means you grew up with Asian parents or you just self-identify as one) and especially if you are a Vietnamese kid, you have probably experienced the wonders of the banh ii Sandwich. For those of you who don't know (please tell me you do), a banh mii Sandwich is a sub comprised of some meat, carrots, sometimes daikon radish, cilantro, jalapeños, and a mayo spread. I wholeheartedly consider it Vietnamese fast food that people order for cheap on the go.

Growing up in Garden Grove, CA near Little Saigon, I've definitely had my fair share of Vietnamese sandwiches from a variety of average-above average places ranging from the generic Lee's Sandwiches (you'd consider this the Vietnamese version of McDonald's to the more niche hole in the wall shops like Banh Mi Che Cali (it is a chain but there's fewer compared to international Lee's). And in NorCal, I've actually found a good number of places. Shout out to Cam Hung in Downtown Oakland and Huon Lan Sandwich in East San Jose. But when I heard wind of a "legendary" Vietnamese sandwich shop in San Francisco by the name of Saigon Sandwich, I had to try it out.

Saigon Sandwich is located in Larkin St within the Tenderloin. To come here, I highly recommend just traveling via public transportation (either by foot, barting via Civic Center, or hopping on a Muni). Parking is trash here and traffic is horrendous. I'd also call in ahead of time to skip lines. And make sure you don't come right when they close like I did because they will RUN OUT OF BREAD. They close early (around 5:30), so this will probably be a lunch option.

The two things you should know about Saigon Sandwich is that 1. They're cash only and 2. They only have like four options. My girlfriend and I ended up getting the Pork Pate combo (shoutout to my friend for getting them). So how was it?

Imagine you take the holiness that is Ike's Dutch crunch bread and add it to the most amazing combination of fresh Banh Mi ingredients. You get Saigon Sandwich. For around $4.5, you get one of the most stuffing Vietnamese sandwiches I've had. Our Pork Pate sandwich was HUGE. Even though it looks small lengthwise, boy they packed a bunch of sliced meat and grounded meat. It tasted so delicious that I wanted to just keep licking my plate. But honestly, what make Saigon Sandwich the A++ experience was the bread itself. Even as leftover, toast it around 350 degrees F for 9 minutes and you will get a legendary crunch. OMG, it was soo good. Though many would beg to differ, I'd say Saigon Sandwich eclipses the subs I've had back at home. It's definitely on par with Oakland's Cam Hung.

Overall, Saigon Sandwiches is a must in the city if you want something delicious and cheap. Especially if you have never had banh mi in your life, do yourself a favor and go. I give this place an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this!" 

Eat well and prosper folks,
author: Bryan W.

description:
You really can't beat the price here. $5 lunch and completely full? Sold!

The bread is on a bit too much on the crunchy side for me though... wish it was softer.

There really isn't any seating here though so it's more of a to-go place. I personally like other banh mi places and wouldn't go out of the way for this.
author: Janet H.

description: For the price and value. You absolutely can't beat it. The portions are huge and the lady was quick at making the sandwich. I recommend the bbq one
author: Will L.

description:
Success! Venturing out into the Tenderloin for a delicious banh mi sandwich was not for nothing!

All their sandwiches are $3.75, but at checkout, the lady just asks for $4 flat. After reading reviews, the baguette was actually smaller than I expected - at around 6 inches (that's what she said?). At first, I thought this small sandwich wouldn't be enough for lunch, but I was gladly proven wrong. 

The sandwich is generously stuffed with roast pork and pate. It was the perfect amount for a meal - pushing me into an ever-so-slight food coma. The veggies, meats, and bread were all delicious and fresh. I hate to admit that I'm the type of person who always picks off pieces of bread because it just gets too to be too much. But here, the proportion of bread to meat was perfect that my bad habit wasn't even necessary!

Cash only.

Will be back soon when the banh mi craving calls again! Let's be real, that'll probably be next week.
author: Sally L.

description:
Do you like banh mi? If yes, you're going to love Saigon Sandwich. 

Value: excellent - $4 even, cash only. Size is hefty - I ate two my first time here and it was a bad idea. 

Taste: top of the line - they're churning out sandwiches so quickly all the ingredients are incredibly fresh. 

Service: it's okay. Brisk but effective, at Saigon's price taste and value they can pretty much do whatever they want and still have a lengthy wait. So I don't begrudge them this at all! Also the line moves quickly and the place is very shallow, so don't be put off if you see it stretching out the door and down the block. 

If you're in the Tenderloin and not a vegetarian this is about the best lunch I can recommend. 

Like all the best restaurants in SF the menu is extremely limited: chicken, pork, fancy pork or combo sandwich options. I think the chicken is best. 

If you want a side they also have packaged chips (not sure about price) and cups of tapioca desserts ($2). 

The 3k reviews don't lie. Check it out! (Especially if you happen to be on nearby jury duty. It's easily the best option)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
WOW love at first bite! Coming from South Bay where there are so many places to get banh mi's, Saigon Sandwich has to be one of my favorite spots for it now. I wish there was something like this place in South Bay :(

I have never tasted such a generous amount of meat in a banh mi before! AND I always finish a banh mi, always, but here I couldn't because it was that filling!! Man there was so much meat when I ordered the banh mi thit (roasted pork), I love it!! My BF ordered the cha lua and he loved how it was thick and meaty too!

For $4 a banh mi, that's pretty cheap considering how much meat and stuff you get in it and it being in SF. It's CASH ONLY, but there's no tax. I'll be back whenever I'm in the area!
author: Ellen C.

description:
Holy moly!! This place was amazing! If you have not yet tried this establishment you are a fool.  I have not had such a perfectly made banh mi sandwich to this date, until today.  The women there really know their craft, even though they crank out sandwiches faster than I can blink, you still get the feeling as if they are made with care.  Let's start with how good the buns are, picture a fresh roll toasted to perfection.  Then the meat, perfectly seasoned and proportioned to the other ingredients.  Then our fresh items, the cilantro carrots and jalapeños all taste as if they have been picked from the garden yesterday.  Lastly, the star of the show the secret sauce.  It is to die for, somehow it is dripping out of the sides and yet it still leaves you wanting more.  
Last but not least the best part about this sandwich is that they are 4 dollars! Yes, you heard right.  They are four dollars! Which if anyone knows San Francisco prices, that's basically free.
In all honesty, I was pleasantly surprised and will surely come back for this amazing sandwich!
author: Paulina C.

description: Ugh!  Don't know why this is highly rated. It was gross. The pork had more fat than meat. The rest didn't matter. Awful.
author: Cousin D.

description: Never tried banh mi sandwich until I was at Pride a couple years ago. I'm sure that an authentic traditional sandwich probably tastes different but I liked it. I also thought it is decently priced for a sandwich in Sf.
author: Maribel G.

description:
Ventured into the depths of the Tenderloin district and dodged some shady people to get into this hole in the wall.

Special combination Banh Mi Dac Biet sandwich was $4.75, which is quite pricey by LA standards, but came loaded with oodles of pate, pork roll, and roast pork garnished with perfectly vinegary julienned daikon and carrots, cilantro. The bread itself was quite substantial, but the design of the classic french roll made it difficult to eat a sandwich stuffed to the brim. With every bite, meat would slip out from one end, and the mayonnaise +pate mixture would ooze out from the other. It was quite a delicious predicament. For a meal under 5 dollars, this was a great bargain, and the taste was quite alright. I'm a bit partial to so. cal style banh mi where head cheese with large peppercorns are sprinkled into the mix and this combination banh mi didn't have that type of ham. The roast pork was something different from what I'm used to but it was tasty nonetheless.
author: Alvin S.

description:
If this is not the BEST Banh Mi in the city, I don't know what is!! 

Fortunately/unfortunately I work in the Loin, so I come here whenever I am in the mood for this Vietnamese speciality. This tiny joint is literally a hole in the wall. But they sure know how to make the tastiest Banh Mi you will ever put in your mouth. 

Oh the French bread is so chewy, the meat melt in your mouth, and the veggies are so fresh! You can smell it a mile away! The best part is that those sandwiches are only $3.75 each. No, I'm not kidding. And they are huge! I usually get the grilled pork with added pate for $4 and I can make two meals out of it. Seriously guys this is a dream in an expensive city like San Francisco! 

My only gripe is that they don't have Vietnamese coffee to go with my Banh Mi. Damnit my yuppie wannabe self is trying to get fancy again. Worry not because you have Lee's across the street and Philz Coffee just a block away. I usually get a mint mojito coffee from Philz to go with my Banh Mi. And that tiny cup of coffee is more expensive than the sandwich that's thicker than my arm. Oh well. 

My coworker told me it used to cost $1 when he started eating there 10-15 years ago. I'd say if they managed to only raise $2-3 in a decade then that's pretty impressive IMO. 

There you have it. The best Banh Mi in the city! What are you waiting for?!
author: Angela F. W.

description:
$5 Bahn Mi sandwiches? I'm in!! This place is walking distance from City Hall so if you are ever nearby, definitely stop by! It's a tiny shop with no seating but trust me when I say this it's worth the long wait in that cramped space. Come to think of it, I don't think I've ever seen the line start from  inside. I clearly understand why...you get an amazing deal for your buck.

The sandwich was sooo good. I've tried worse bahn mi for double the price. The portions are perfect and always leaves me not too hungry or too full. I'll admit the place didn't look like the most sanitary but the veggies were fresh and the meat was tender. I literally come here every week, and the quality is always consistent.

They have a variety of snacks and cold drinks as well. With all that lunch money you saved, pick up a snack and treat yourself!!! This place is awesome!!
author: Graciela T.

description:
As good as it gets in SF. Quick service, unbeatable prices, generous portions, and delicious sandwiches. Will definitely make it a point to stop by whenever I'm looking for a bite in the area. Vietnamese coffee is also offered here, but they don't hold back when it comes to the condensed milk, so be prepared for a sugar rush. 
Remember to bring cash!
author: Amy C.

description: The best Banh Mi I've ever had. Worth a wait in line. Go before the lunch rush. Cash only.
author: Chris S.

description: Neighborhood is a little sketchy, but this is hands down the best tasting tofu banh mi in SF AND the best deal!
author: Bianca P.

description: Although they received low score on cleanliness, their sandwhiches are the best. Their portions are generous. The flavors are amazing. Although they have been warned with a bad health inspection, try their food and check out their place before deciding not to come. Ive been to so many places that serve banh mi, all over california. This placw by far is the best
author: Mark C.

description: Top quality, no-frills Banh Mi for $4. Filled to the brim with the goods. They don't skimp. Massive sandwich, absolutely beautiful. Highly recommend.
author: Josh L.

description:
I've been going here for +10 years, or maybe longer to get my vietnamese sandwich, I can't believe I never wrote a review. 

When you tell them extra pate, they will add extra. When I crave for vietnamese sandwich, this is the spot I think of. Their combination is delish-goodness, the flavors of the meat is on the spot! Not too salty or dry, with the perfect amount of pickles  craving for one right now.

If you never tried the sandwich here, you need to get one, it's a MUST. Not like generic Bunmee or, whatever overpriced vietnamese sandwich place you could think of, it has to be from here. My fave is definitely the combination and roasted pork. 

Fyi, this place is cash only.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
I'm not sure why I haven't written a review yet. Prices are cheap compared to other places in the city. They're so cheap/reasonable that I always order two (2); one of them being a Tofu sandwich. Prices have increased since I first went but still cheap. Parking may be tough so try to bike or walk there. It's in the tenderloin but so far, that hasn't stopped me or the many other people who visit this place. It starts to gets busy around 11:45-1:50am. For sure it's really busy at noon so try to arrive earlier or call in.

I highly recommend going here.
author: M L.

description: Had the chicken banh mi and it was hands down the best sandwich I have ever eaten. The service was incredibly quick and the staff was very nice. Also it was so cheap!!! I went in expecting to enjoy it but this surpassed all of my expectations! I wouldn't recommend a large group coming because they have exactly 2 chairs but it's a great lunch spot!
author: Ashley M.

description:
A little hole in the wall shop owned by Vietnamese ladies.  Definitely the best banh mi in all of the Bay Area.  They fill the sandwiches to the brim and the prices are more than reasonable.  I stop by once a week and order Combo, Pork, and Tofu with extra pate.   They make their orders in less than 4 minutes after you order and are cash only.  True mom and pop sort of shop.  I will always come back for as long as I live in the city.  

They're perfect for catering, bringing to Dolores Park or any picnic setting. Not to mention the sandwiches have a long shelf life in the fridge.  I've ordered 4-6 sandos for myself and they were able to keep their same freshness for 7 days after ordering.
author: Peter N.

description: Been here three times now during my trip. The Banh mi is loaded when they make them leaving me really full. The Vietnamese coffee here is the best.
author: Vinh P.

description:
I was told about a very famous Bahn Mi sandwich shop in San Francisco. He did not remember the name but luckily it was easy to find as it had the most reviews. Luckily we were in the area shopping around and decided to head over there through uber for a late Lunner. The inside is super tiny. Tiny as in you basically just order and leave or eat outside, while walking. There was only 2 chairs inside, facing the window, which got pretty hot and sunny. Because we got there close to 4:45-5 there was no line. It's a very small hole in the wall kind of place that is authentic. 

The menu is small, simple and straight to the point. There is no description or picture so you are better off knowing what you want to order, because when I asked the lady questions she was very unpleasant and not helpful at all. I don't know if it's because there was a language barrier but she seemed like she wanted us to hurry and order or leave. FYI: CASH ONLY!

_Roast Pork ($4) Pork, pate, pickled veggies. We decided to share one since we were going to eat dinner soon after but after my gf had a few bites she wanted another one. It was so good! The bread was nicely toasted, soft on the inside and crisp on the outside, although I can see it being a bit more on the crisp/harder side. They added a good amount of pate, where you can just taste it. The pork was well cooked and they gave a food amount. I do think it could have been a bit more tender but still pretty good. I wish they added more veggies because the end of my sandwich had nothing, and once the veggies were gone it did not taste as good, and it needed something to counter act the richness from the pate and pork. I just wish the lady cut the sandwich a bit more evenly or in the middle, because one side was way smaller than the other. Only because we were sharing, otherwise would not have mattered. But no big deal.
_Roast Chicken ($4) Chicken, pate, pickled veggies. This time, since I got greedy on how good the pate and lack of veggies, I ordered extra veggies and pate. I may have made a mistake, because even though it was good it was way too rich and heavy. The chicken was good, but needed more seasoning/flavor and It was a tad bit dry. My gf and I bother preferred the pork over the chicken. Maybe it was also because the pate overwhelmed the flavor of the chicken. But it did taste better with extra veggies. I think it may have been $1 extra for the veggies and pate or $1 each. Either way still very cheap.

I would be a regular If I lived in SF. And for those visiting, I do recommend checking this place out at least once!
author: Vanessa M.

description:
This was a short walk from Brenda's and was also a place I wanted to try, so I went and got a banh mi to-go for later.

LOCATION + AMBIENCE
This is a hole in the wall spot. It is not a sit down restaurant, get your food and go. Inside the restaurant is tiny and the line usually goes out the door. You wouldn't want to stay around the area, it's a bad neighborhood, so get the sandwich and get the hell out. You will know why the Tenderloin has a bad rep after walking around. 

FOOD
I got the combo sandwich ($4.50) which includes all the various meat, carrots, jalapeños, and cilantro. The bread has a crunchy and hard texture, so it can be difficult eating on the go. They pack the sandwiches to the brim, so you will definitely been getting your money's worth. They're considered to be the best Banh mi shop in SF and I agree. Super flavorful and authentic Vietnamese sandwiches. 

SERVICE
Cash only. The workers work in rapid succession, so be ready to tell them what type of sandwich you want and don't expect any customer service. After they complete your sandwich, pay for it and take your leave.

CONCLUSION
Saigon Sandwiches is a delicious and authentic Banh Mi store. The prices are cheap and they don't skim on the meat or veggies. The workers work fast, so the line should move at a good pace even if it's a long line. If you're craving a banh mi in SF, head on over to Saigon Sandwiches, just be wary of your surroundings around here!
author: Vincent P.

description: So disappointed .. used to be really good sandwiches .. not no more. They use old bread now the one left over the day before to make sandwiches . Tasted awful.. not going back no more.
author: Lynnie V.

description:
One of the best banh mi I've had for the price! 

A lot of Yelpers have left great reviews of this place so I had to check this joint out for myself in the city. It's located a few blocks from Civic Center in Little Saigon. Stopped by around 2pm on a Sat with my parents just to see what all the hype was about, no line!

Pricewise, you can't go wrong here. All the sandwiches are $4, with some of the special combos being $4.75-cheaper than a Subway sandwich. I got the fancy pork sandwich and the roast pork sandwich, both $4 a pop.

They are pretty quick getting all the sandwiches made. Their bread, which everyone raves about is truly good. It's toasted crispy but not tough and hard. And they pack on the meat generously. However, I think what stood out was that they don't glop on the mayo like other places; while they put some on, they also put on more generously a sweet and sour tasting sauce that, with the pickled veg, cuts through all that fat of the meat and mayo.

I saved one roast pork sandwich for the next day, and it was still yummy! The bread wasn't too hard and was such a great lunch. 

And for $4, I basically got double the size of what I normally pay $6-7 for at Dinosaurs. While it's a little out of the way in the city, this place is definitely worth stopping by for a quick lunch togo. And 3 extra for the next couple meals!
author: Clarissa C.

description: This place used to be my favorite place to get a Vietnamese sandwich. I've been going there for sandwiches ever since the store opened. The staff used to be friendly. Today I went there and ordered a fancy pork sandwich. The long was so long and I waited 30 minutes for my sandwich. The Vietnamese lady who took the order was so darn rude. I was very disappointed with my sandwich. As I always finish eating the second half of the sandwich, I found a piece of thing in my sandwich. It looks like a piece of hair right on the fancy pork. So disgusting. I almost vomit. I would never go back to that place ever again. Such a disgusting place!!!!  I had a stomach ache after eating that gross sandwich. Be careful what you eat next time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I had a lunch break from work and was looking for a quick bite to eat.  As I walked around, I noticed a line snaking out of this place.  I always take that as a good sign, so I joined.  I'm a big banh mi fan, so this was a no brainer.  There were 3 middle aged Vietnamese woman working a semi-assembly line of sandwiches.  As you got closer to the counter, 1 of them would bark out "what you want?"  She would scribble your order, and then move on to the next person.  She would take about 3/4 orders at a time, then turn to help assemble the sandwiches.  It was the banh mi version of the soup nazi from Seinfeld.  When I asked for a receipt, she looked at me as if I asked for the wine list...

The sandwiches were good (and cheap).  The roast pork was excellent.
author: paul b.

description: It's a $4 sandwich that is ridiculously delicious. Only knocked off a star because the bread was a bit over toasted, i.e. hard... But that's fine because it was delicious. We got the roast pork, with carrots, cilantro, green peppers, jalapeños and onions with a house mayonnaise based sauce. Oh, and the place can only fit 3 people in it at a time, but the place was packed.... That's how you knew it was good.
author: Erica H.

description:
Came here for a quick bite to go before an SF Symphony Chamber concert. This is the second time I've come to Saigon Sandwich, and it was just as good as the first time! It's the only banh mi I've tried in the city, but it's some of the best I've had (in general, of other bahn mi's I've had elsewhere in my life). And on top of it all, it was super cheap, at $3.75 a bun. The shop is a small store front on the edges of Tenderloin, so it's a bit sketchy outside, but inside are a few Vietnamese ladies working furiously away at their banh mi craft.

- Roast Pork: yum! So much meat stuffed into the baguette, and the sauce is quite addictive. The only thing is that I'm not sure why they put huge slices of jalapeno (I'm pretty sure there's like a whole jalapeno pepper in each sandwich XD), but I learned the hard way (almost crying the first time I had Saigon Sandwich) to take most of the jalapenos out haha. 

Definitely a tasty, satisfying meal, and I'll be back soon!
author: Joanna C.

description:
Ordered the roasted pork banh mi. The insides were delicious. I am just giving 3 stars because the service could have been better and my bread was hard (I did eat it ~10mins after being made).

I would come back if I was in the area, but would not go out of my way for it.
author: Adan A.

description:
I'm an idiot. I've lived here for 12 fn years now and JUST had my 1st Saigon chicken bahn mi. $4 just rocked my world. I wanna go shout from the rooftops how fucking amazeballs that sandwich just was. 

Also, it was made like 3.1 seconds after I ordered it. I had to all, 'Durr, it's ready already? Durr?', at the lady. God I'm a dumbass.

Damn. What a waste of 12 years. !$!$#!@#%!%$!
author: Karen K.

description:
A delicious and filling sandwich that costs $3.75 is a tough bargain to beat. Unlike most banh mi joints I've been to, Saigon Sandwich jam packs their baguettes with freshly prepared ingredients. They come loaded with various meats and veggies, which include your typical carrots, daikon, and cilantro. I would have preferred that they added more jalapeños for an even spicier kick, but that's just personal preference.

On my first visit here, I ordered the fanci pork. I had no idea what it was at the time, but turns out it's kind of like a glorified Vietnamese ham. Note to self to try the thit cha pate (special combination) next time. That one additionally comes with both the roast pork and the pate, which I hear are both amazing.
author: Miko B.

description:
Sad to be giving this place three stars. I used to LOVE this place and would get excited just passing by it while driving. However, my most recent experience just disappointed me a lot. Just fyi, every sandwich has the same condiments and differs by  the filling. Bread is lightly toasted, spread with mayo and pate, filled with  your choice of protein, then topped with a generous amount of pickled carrots/onion, cilantro, and jalapeno slices. We got one each of the following, ranked in order of my favorite to least:

1. Roast pork - pork was a little too fatty - we had to spit out some pieces of fat. Flavorful but slightly over powered by five spice powder. Generous amount of meat. Flavor blended the best with the other ingredients in the sandwich. There was one extremely hot jalapeno slice in this one for some reasons, bf was dying after that bite.

2. Special combination - jumble of different Vietnamese "ham" and other sliced meats. Quite heavy on pate taste. Like a cold cut sandwich of the Vietnamese world. Wish the bread was toasted more since everything inside is cold.

3. Pork meatball - it's like a deconstructed shu mai with a shit ton of black pepper, then shoved between bread and called a sandwich. It's flavorful, but idk... It's really too much black pepper. 

4. Roast chicken - idk... Flavor profile primarily was soy sauce. It really just reminded me of soy sauce chicken sandwich. 

Meh, will not waste time looking for parking and venturing out here gripping onto my pepper spray for dear life.
author: Susanna C.

description:
Amazing. Extremely delicious banh mi. It's a tiny little hole in the wall shop, with only three people working to pump out banh mi, but the banh mi is great.

There was a small line heading out the door when I got there, but it wasn't too long, and I only waited about 5 minutes before ordering. The banh mi itself was extremely delicious. I had the special combination and it was great. The only gripe is that the bread itself was pretty hard to bite. There definitely could be improvement in that area but everything inside of the bun is great.

The best thing about this place is the prices. $4 for a regular banh mi, and $4.75 for the combination? Are you kidding me? The next time I come, I'll order in bulk.
author: Desmond C.

description:
Came by for a sandwich the other day and was quite impressed! Despite what appeared to be a chaotic line, the process was amazingly efficient! 

Sandwiches were made in a flash and they were huge! Bread was fresh too! :)

...do be careful of the fecal matter on the street and random wet spots on the street

Cash only!
author: Derek S.

description: Apparently pregnant women are not supposed to eat processed deli meats. This was sad news for me, a lover of turkey, pastrami, and roast beef sandos alike. So i was super happy today when my cousin suggested we pick up some of these! Real roasted meat inside!! I'll be honest, the 78 health food score freaked me out a little... yeah it doesn't look that clean, but it didn't look straight up dirty, so i took my chances. A lot of popular places in town have subpar scores anyway. I'm glad there's only 4 sandos to choose from, that made it easy. I forgot the deliciousness that is a simple Vietnamese sandwich! $4 for a full belly and i felt like i got some veggies in my diet today...carrots aplenty were still nice and crunchy. Considering a Big Mac now costs $5.59, i gotta say, $4 is a fantastic deal. The roast chicken was juicy and well seasoned, and the french bread still warm and soft. I had to take some of the peppers out of mine because my mouth was on fire after one bite, but other than that i can't believe it's been exactly a year since I've had such a sandwich. There was a bit of a line, but it went quickly. Seems like other people are onto this place. My cousin said his mom has been bringing home sandwiches from here for at least the last 15 years, his go-to spot. Wtf is Fanci Pork btw?!
author: Theresa C.

description:
When I was told that Saigon Sandwich had the best banh mi in SF I just didn't believe it - coming from San Jose, I've already known plently of banh mi places that I thought was already the best. After trying their sandwiches here - I can gladly say that it is definitely one of the best that I've had. 

They work fast here which is good because this place is a hole in a wall. It's super tiny inside so often the line goes out the door, but don't let that scare you because the line moves fast. I like getting the combo because it has everything in it and the chicken is super juicy too... but the one thing I like most about this place is that they PACK SO MUCH PATE IN THEIR SANDWICHES!!! I love pate - and their pate is on another level. I cannot get over how juicy and flavorful their sandwiches are. Everything works well with each other and the bread is fresh.

Please be aware that this place is cash only - and it's in the tenderloins so the area may be a little bit ghetto. If you're looking for the best vietnamese sandwich in the area- this is where you need to go.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I am back at Saigon Sandwich as my regular after flirting with some competitors. They are tops for the sheer amount of stuff they pile into the bun. "Quality AND Quantity" to quote a slogan on a diner t-shirt I own.

Two things to report about my mid-day Sunday visit. First, they ARE open on Sunday which is a relatively new phenomenon. Second, I was there when they refilled the mayo bin and watched like a hawk because certain authorities have suggested they put sugar in their mayo. I did not see it happen. On the other hand, the sandwich was a bit less sweet than I remember. This was a weekend crew and maybe a bit rough around the edges... but still deserving of four stars for Quality AND Quantity.
author: Otis M.

description: When I happen to be in the Tenderloin, I have to find my way over to Saigon Sandwich.  I think the Fanci Meat Combination vietnamese sandwich here is better than any of the viet sandwiches I've eaten in San Jose.   At $4.50 a piece, it has a generous heaping of pate, ham, cha lua & all the fixings.  Grab a couple to hoard for when you're hungry later on.  CASH ONLY.
author: Melanie N.

description:
Living in SoCal for over a decade has spoiled me when it comes to Asian food. I'm used to great banh mi on fresh baguettes for sub $3 prices. When I first moved to San Francisco, my coworkers raved about Saigon Sandwich but the price tag alone was a deterrent for me.

San Francisco has worn me down over the months, which have turned into years (celebrating 3 years next month)! And as a San Franciscan now, $4.00-$4.75 for a satisfying sandwich is a good deal. I called in advance to order 6 sandwiches: chicken, roast pork, meatball pork, and special combination and was able to skip the line to pick it up quickly.

When I handed these banh mi to my friends, they were so thankful for the delicious sandwiches I brought. For ~$26, I was able to feed 10 people for lunch.

Thanks to Saigon Sandwich!
author: Yi Z.

description:
$4 no frills banh mi. Cash only, no seating room, line moves quickly. 

Pro tip: Always know your order (it's not that hard, what kind of meat do you want in your banh mi?)
Pro tip #2: Have your cash out ($4/sandwich)
Pro tip #3: Accept sandwich, grab some napkins and go eat the deliciousness somewhere else. 

There will always be a line out the door because Saigon is one of the few places where you can get a cheap and delicious lunch during the week.
author: Arezou A.

description:
Almost 2400 reviews and 4.5 stars. What more do you need to see to know that this is one of the best places in SF? 

Simply put these taste AMAZING and they cost almost nothing. Bahn Mi are almost always cheap (unless you're at some hoity-toity overly-yuppie place), and this place is no exception.

What IS exceptional about this place is the flavor. I just don't think you can go wrong, and I can't wait to go back, either.

Somehow, when I went, there wasn't a line. I have to guess that with such a small place and so many fans, there must be. I know for sure that next time I'm in the neighborhood, I'm going to stock up on several for my fridge.

"But Chris!" you cry "these must be fresh! You can't denigrate them that way!"
Oh but I can. And I have. And I will again. Because you know what? I froze a couple last time. And then I microwaved them. And they were STILL the best bahn mi I've had in the city. Plus they're still fairly priced even in this day and age of painful price increases all around us. A true community star. 

Add this to the list of what I would consider San Francisco's finest, and certainly my favorite type of restaurant.
- Hole in the wall?
- Amazing food?
- Cheaper than it seems like it should be?
