My only suggestion would be that I'd like some of that nice brown sauce (hoisin?) you sometimes get. But then again that might overwhelm the flavor so...what do I know. I should leave the magic up to the best bahn mi place in the city.
author: Chris S.

description:
The best Vietnamese sandwiches in the city and you already know it. It's not a secret! 

I have been coming here when their sandwiches were about $3.00. I travel across the town to get their sandwiches. It's that good. I normally get meatballs but other flavors are great as well.

I was just there on last Saturday and the place was packed! Did not realize that they get a bunch of customers on the weekend!! I really hope the price stays as is for a long time since I've seen other places jacking up the price like crazy.

Pros: great and reasonably priced sandwiches.

Cons: it's a hole on the wall, not a restaurant. It doesn't bother me at all. Oh, there was a homeless man standing in the door way to get your change but that's not Saigon sandwich's fault.
author: S M.

description:
Absolutely incredible eating experience. Fast, affordable, fresh ingredients, and wonderful service! 
Thank you!!
author: Angie M.

description: As everyone has probably said by now - omg - the tuna is fresh!!  Lightly seared then full of interesting flavors and spices and texture and the bread is unbelievably crunchy while soft inside.  Yum!  Definitely will be back to try them all!
author: Carl A.

description:
Absolutely delicious! I've had this place bookmarked for about two years but never got to go here during any of my visits to sf. Finally got a chance this time around because we stayed right around the corner at a hotel nearby. We don't love the area of tenderloin but there's a lot of awesome bars, lounges and restaurants there still and Saigon Sandwich is one of them! 

I love my Vietnamese food and being born and raised into a Vietnamese family with an excellent mom for a cook, I'm extra particular about Vietnamese dishes. So when I say this sandwich place is good I mean this is one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had! And this is coming from a person who lives near and frequently visits little Saigon where there's a huge selection of Vietnamese sandwich spots around. 

The pate, vegetables and meat are fresh and is given in abundance.
author: elizabeth t.

description: Don't miss this place. While the area is a little sketchy, these sandwiches are definitely a hidden SF gem. The two ladies who work there are quick, friendly and efficient, and the sandwiches are such a great deal for what you get. When I went there, the sandwiches were $4 each. Like many of the other reviewers, I've been going to this place for years and their prices have undergone very minimal change. The sandwich remains the perfect combination of flavorful meat, pickled veggies, spicy jalapeño and crunchy bread. Simply cannot beat Saigon Sandwich.
author: Sydney J.

description: Really enjoyed this sandwich, the bread was very good and there were a lot of vegetables in the banh mi itself. Still, I think I prefer nearby Sing Sing Sandwich shop for their banh mi. This place was still very good and better than a lot of places we have in Los Angeles.
author: Jason W.

description: This is a tentative rating. I think I got the wrong item for my palate, so I'm willing to give Saigon Sandwich another try, but, damn, the pork "meatball" sandwich is gross. I don't even know why they call that mess meatballs.
author: Paulina F.

description: Please go here I know you hear that a lot about San Francisco but this is a really good place for the best bang mi.  I got mine with everything on and and asked for it to be a bit spicy and they did it.  Places closes early and gets packed during lunch hour.  It's not big place so expect it to look packed but the ladies are doing an awesome job with the food.
author: Arjun S.

description: Banh mi? More like the bomb mi! You get a big Vietnamese sandwich for 4 bucks. I had the combo and the steamed pork, roast pork, pate special. Cash only and only 2 seats to eat in but the taste and value cant be beat if you dont mind carry out. The combo was good but prefered the way the 2 styles of pork and the absolutely delicious pate complimented each other. They also have a good selection of imported snacks and drinks. I added on lobster flavored chips and a drink made from some sort of gourd.
author: Sean G.

description:
They offer packaged Vietnamese mochi from Mai's Bakery in Monterey Park.

$2.29 for 4 mochi. The black sesame and the red bean mochi were good. Thicker pounded rice exterior to filling ratio than for Japanese mochi, which is ok for me, but your mileage may vary.
author: Vena V.

description:
Cheap,Tasty Vietnamese Sandwiches. I'm not sure where else in San Francisco you can get lunch for under $5. I recommend the BBQ Pork -  my favorite and go to order. 

This is in the Tenderloin and you'll likely see some homeless and lots of litter in the surrounding area. Unfortunately, we drove here on a weekend and encountered some human feces where we parked. But if you're in the area, I would stop by for the price.
author: Kristy L.

description:
Cheap and good to-go sandwich shop.

No place to eat and the store is super small. Line is also long. But if u live at SF, it's a must-try-at-least-once sandwich place. Baguette was crunchy, but not chewy inside. 

I ordered pork and chicken bahn mi. Chicken was great except the sauces were uneven, so one part was too sweet and other was not sweet at all. Also some parts were super super spicy due to the pepper. Uneven taste was a minus


Pork was.. bad. It has that weird smell of pig. 

If I want good bahn mi though, i will just go to sunnyvale or san jose vietnamese town.
author: Chloe S.

description: Really quick, delicious, and cheap, grab and go place for Banh mi sandwiches. I recommend you grab the sandwich, walk down two blocks and sit down in front of city hall and enjoy the view and the sandwich. Theres not much room in the store itself and its really crowded and busy.
author: John O.

description:
I had the pork banh mi and it was good! The patte is good and pork was grilled just right. I bought it an hour or so before they closed so the bread was not super fresh. It was a tad hard actually so that's the only con I  have. 

It's cheap, $3.50 for a sandwich and it's good authentic vietnamese banh mi. It will definitely fill you up.  Finally found a place in sf that serves banh mi like orange county! I'd definitely come back
author: Caitlin P.

description:
Saigon Sandwich has the best and cheapest banh mi sandwiches in all of San Francisco. For $4 you get a nicely sized sandwich with the best bread, pickled vegetables, and meat fillings. This place is no frills, all deliciousness, and fantastic value.

I've been a few times and recommend the fanci meat sandwich with extra pate (+50 cents).
author: Amy G.

description: I got the BBQ Chicken bon mi, it was super good. I do wish that the sandwich had more spice to it. I would defiantly take my son here as he would be able to eat this with ease, but for myself I will keep going to the one in Richmond.
author: Jayme G.

description:
Tried the fancy pork sandwich. The bread was a bit hard on the edges, but otherwise fresh & crunchy. The pork was ok. The vegetables and the overly sweet sauce kept the sandwich moist.

The ladies behind the counter were efficient in filling the orders.
author: David W.

description: Tasty, extremely affordable, and unique. Cash only, small menu, few options. Over all could do w some improvement, but you can't beat the price!
author: Colby S.

description: Roast pork bahn mi is a classic. The bread is amazing here. I don't like too much sauce. Sometimes it's dripping with it which makes it gross   But it's still a classic sf treat
author: Fatty A.

description:
Big sandwich. 4 dollars. Bread a little too hard.

I ordered a roast pork banh mi. It was cash only but there's an ATM a block away. I would definitely go here often if I worked in the area.
author: Justin H.

description: Everything I love about banh mi's they have here. Dive spot. Fobby workers w thick accents. Limited menu. Quick service. Cheap. Good eats. Sandwiches are about $4 and filling. They don't skimp on the pate. My friend is a vegetarian and she got the tofu and loved it. I got the dac biet and also loved it. Very limited seating, and by that I mean two tiny chairs facing the window and street. If someone wants to open the drink cooler you'll most likely get hit. The bread is fluffy and not too crispy where it rips up the roof of your mouth but my bff said hers still got wrecked. Lol noob. If you are a delicate little flower like her then turn that shit upside down. Next time I'm in town I'm def coming back here. These sandwiches rival those in San Jose.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
Stumbled upon this tiny sandwich shop after a visit to the Asian Art Museum a few blocks away. This is a quick made to order and go spot with only a couple seats by the window to eat. They serve mostly bahn mi sandwiches and some tapioca desserts that are made from other local stores. My husband and I ordered the Roast Pork Bahn Mi. At $4 a sandwich, it was filling and really hit the spot. The meat was juicy and tender. The bread was nicely toasted and warm. The sandwich had the perfect amount of heat from the jalapeños. 
Would definitely return next time to try other sandwiches. The neighborhood on the other hand, is not the greatest.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Quick story. During the second giants championship parade I came here with a few people including one of my Vietnamese homies. So as I talk to everyone about this awesome place he "of course" knows about this place and says " yeah, it's pretty good but not the best" okay I figure he might be more informed than me on the subject. So we proceed to order and he orders in Vietnamese and turns to use and says that he order off the menu. Hey a collective "cool" was given. I respect it. I'll talk slang at the bbq spot to show off so I'm not one to judge. Sandwiches start getting made and I watch to see what it was that he ordered. Bruh.... It was roast pork. We all ate those bad boys up so in a way this spot got consigned by a native so after my 13 years of coming here it's been legitimized. Just kidding. It's always been...

The standard.  

Only thing is since I've been making this place got over the past decade they've taken advantage. 4 bucks a sandwich is where we're at these days and while still quite reasonable I long for the 1.75 days. In any case walk in as a person is walking out to now find the place empty. Walk right up and there was a lady I haven't seen before and she took my order and started the sandwiches. She was pleasant enough and the assembly line took shape. Lots of fresh carrots and jalapeños but didn't see many onions in the carrot mixture. Still too many stalks of cilantro wish they would just do the leaves. Me and my first world problems. Meatball always juicy and while that's it for my lady I go plus pate and for me it makes all the difference. The texture of the pate and meatball is slightly mushy but the crispness of the carrots and jalapeño as well as the crusty bread create a great mouthfeel. 

Added a bag of shrimp chips with wasabi for a little bit more crunch. 

One of the few places that still stocks green tea ginger ale so that's always something I look forward to. I'll keep coming back for my meatball pate.
author: Jamal F.

description:
The restaurant is really small and only had two spots to sit. Ordered at the counter and they only take cash. My friend recommended the combination sandwich that had pork, chicken, and patay, which was a great choice to try as a first sandwich cause I tried all the fillings. I liked the pork the most followed by the patay. 

The bread is toasted and quite yummy. The sandwich comes with plenty of filling and one was enough for lunch. Affordable and tasty sandwich that I'd love to have again. Next time I'll probably just only get the pork.
author: Edward W.

description:
One of the best sandwiches I have eaten. Great price, CASH ONLY, lines most times. Listen be ready, this is like a food cart in a hole in the wall. Walk in make eye contact, answer her question. What you want? Me: combo her: ok
Combo is pate, roasts pork, & sausage with all the stuff. 
Pricing has recently gone up but SO what's $4.75 for this monster of goodness cradled in bread!
author: JamiQuan J.

description: This place is great for the price. It was only about $3.50 for a Pork Banh Mi. The sandwich was really flavorful and the meat was cooked well. They added mayonnaise in it, which worked, but isn't authentic. This is probably the best banh mi I've tried in SF/East Bay area.
author: Jamie N.

description:
Be careful. Very rough part of town.
The sandwich is hard as a rock and it was okay. Not the best so i don't understand how this place got so many reviews and stars. Cash only and it's take out only.
author: Myle D.

description:
Still a bargain at $3.75 for a hefty, tasty, wonderful sandwich

Overall Thoughts

If you haven't been you should go, the end
author: Eddie W.

description: I've been to tons of other Vietnamese delis and this is by far my favorite. Their bánh mì is the cheapest in the city and ranges from $4-5 but it's some of the best I've had. Definitely try their special combo $5 sandwich if you can eat pork. They made my sandwich in under 2 minutes! In contrast it takes me 10 minutes to get a sandwich from Lee's across the street. If you need a quick bite for lunch and don't mind the stroll through the TL, this is your place.
author: Calvin H.

description:
Omg... Hands down the BEST banh mi I have ever tasted in my entire life! lol. Til this day, Bullet S. And I still drool about it.. It is the gold standard when it comes to banh mi ... lol. We both ordered the special combination and it was less than 10$ for both! The line can get long but it moved pretty fast while we were there during lunch time. 
The banh mi was packed with good stuff and some sort of magic sauce.  Lol. It can definitely get messy, but who cares!! Hahah Bullet S. Usually hates eating banh Mi because it can be hard to chew but he loveddddd it since it was soft and delicious!!! They're very generous with the ingredients.. And man.. Each bite was packed with flavor! Also, I usually eat hot Cheetos or some sort of chips with my banh ml. :) 
We will definitely come back if we're ever in SF again. Until then.. We will just drool, I mean dream about it... :)
author: Tram D.

description: This little place is amazing. Had to get a rush passport and looked around for something to eat close by the passport office. This small unassuming place was doing a brisk business and it's no surprise. They're cranking sandwiches out and they are delicious.
author: Jake H.

description:
Whenever my friends and I need to pick where to eat, we play this game in which I spam them with a list of nearby foods I find on Yelp. 

Saigon Sandwich was the winner this time! All the great reviews had me really excited, but the location did not because it's tucked away in the Tenderloin. My friends and I trekked through dirty, stinky streets with crazies and hobos just to get one of their delicious sandwiches.

Make sure to look for the blue awning with their name on it or you might miss their small store front. The place has 1 table and really only fits about 4 people. They have a cooler for drinks (water, Snapple, soda, canned coffee, etc). Craving shrimp chips or some Vietnamese sweets? They have plenty of those here too!

Their menu is very simple, which is good for those who can never seem to make up their minds. For sandwich meat options, you have roast chicken, roast pork, meat balls (xiu mai), and pork sausage (cha lua), each one being $3.75. They also have combinations of roast pork, pork sausage, and pate altogether, which was $4.50. 

My friend got chicken and I got the special combination. The sandwich was smaller than I expected (I grew up eating banh mi so I've had my fair share). But they sure did stuff it with a lot of meat and veggies! We brought them back to our hotel to enjoy and by that time, the sauce had made parts of the bread soggy. However, it was still a good banh mi.

Note: Cash only! *sad*
author: Cindy C.

description:
Flavor 100
Value 100
Location ehhhh

Best banh mi in the city. Very reasonable price ($4.50/sandwich) and tastes awesome. Come here for an easy lunch! Just don't expect any special treatment or customizations. This is a grab and go type of deal where the people making your sandwich don't speak the best English. (That's how you know it's legit)
author: Mira K.

description: The price is right. The quality is consistent. I've been buying sandwiches here for the past five years or so. I recalled when the sandwiches cost $3.25 each.  I've been a regular here whenever that was. The only painful part of getting the sandwiches is the waiting and parking, if you're driving.  I generally order at least 3-4 sandwiches and call in the order.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Still the best banh mi in the city.  Hole in the wall sandwich without all the frills. Big on taste that won't burn a hole in your wallet. 

You could spot first timers a mile away because they don't know the system so here's the system:

1. Place your order with one of the ladies
2. Step aside so they can take the next persons order 
3. Wait till your order is called
4. If your order is called, pay at the register and enjoy
author: Naty D.

description: Cheap, delicious, fast service. Only 2 chairs available to eat in, more of a buy and go place. Their sandwiches are good and don't feel as yeet hay (Chinese term) as other places. Good size for the price. The jalapeños go from super spicy with the seeds on to bearable without seeds, I guess depending on who's making the sandwiches.
author: Angelina W.

description: Really solid Banh mis. Incredible value with fresh ingredients.  So yummy. I might have to take another 4 hour flight to cure my banh mi cravings.
author: Nhu N.

description: I love this place. When I lived in the city this was a frequent spot for my sando fix. It's a no frills, hole in the wall, no dining area, and two ladies who make the sandwiches and take your order.  I always get the combo bahn mi. I crave this 24/7.  My hubby just did a job in the city and brought me back a sandwich; he's romantic like that, LOL. And whenever we visit we always make sure to stop by on our way home to get a roadie sandwich. It's that good.  The baguette is a little less crunchy and flaky than most places, but that doesn't bother me.  It has the best thick sliced head cheese (yeah, I'm gross like that, and I LOVE it), pate, bbq pork (they have a little sauce that's great and missing from most bahn mi I've had elsewhere), the slaw, jalapeños, cilantro, and a lil bit of mayo. It's heaven.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Best Banh Mi ever. No questions asked. Whats more awesome is that it's only $4. Where else can you get a $4 meal and be full from it?! The line can get long during lunch time but it goes by really quickly. Its cash only but there's a bank of america atm nearby. I always get the meatball + pate sandwich here and I thought that its the best combo. I tried the bbq pork + pate and I still prefer the former. 

Their banh mi comes with pickeled carrots, jalapeno, cilantro, onions, mayo and their sauce. I really like how flavorful their meatball is. When you bite into it, bursts of flavors just explodes in your mouth. And with the pate, its the perfect combo. The bread is also really crunchy. I noticed that they always heat up the bread in the oven right before making the actual sandwich. 

I also had their taro sago dessert and it was good too. Its not too sweet and the coconut milk that tops it ties it together really well. 

Too bad there are only two seats in the shop so basically you'd have to eat your sandwich somewhere else.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Saigon Sandwich has been my go-to banh mi spot ever since I worked in downtown San Francisco many years ago, and recent visits have reminded me why I love this place.  It's a small shop located on Larkin Street, and during peak hours the line can extend out the door.  There's a small seating area in case you want to eat in house, but I often order my sandwiches and take them to go.

Their banh mi is amazing, from their toasted French bread to their well-seasoned meat fillings.  My favorites are the sliced pork and the meatballs, and the pickled vegetables and jalapeños give it a nice kick.  The price is affordable, and I'm always impressed that I can get a filling lunch for under $5 in San Francisco.  The service is expedient, and despite long lines, you will be in and out in a jiffy.
author: Keith H.

description:
Fast, convenient, and cheap. The ladies here are not the friendliest, so if you want your bahn mi cut, tell them ahead of time or risk getting hit with an eye roll and an audible sigh of disapproval.

There's two chairs for seating by the window, but it's mostly to-go. In terms of quality, the bread is crispy-ish on the outside but kind of dry on the inside. In terms of meat, I prefer the roast pork over the combo or the meatball. I would not get the meatball again. Saigon Sandwich has fewer fillings than L&G Sandwich across the street. Personally, I would go to L&G, and they're also open later.
author: Eva W.

description:
Just wish the carrots were pickled longer tad bit too much mayo. Other then that. 
A
M
A
Z
I
N
G
author: Envy C.

description:
Expections were high with the yelp reviews!  We had the roast pork and pate sandwiches-
Bread was good- but everything else was meh... poorly balanced - too sweet - meat was too game-y...

Won't be returning.
author: Susan K.

description:
It REALLY doesn't get better than a flat price of $4 for an authentic Vietnamese sandwich in the city!! I'm so glad my boyfriend and I came before lunch because the line was out the door by the time we finished our sandwiches (trust me it did not take long) 

These hardworking women speak Cantonese and Vietnamese by the way :)
author: Debby L.

description: How have I not written a review for this place?! I've been coming here for more than 8 years and as an SF native this has to be my favorite bahn mi spot in the city. I have eaten at most of the bahn minspots in the city and this is the one. I even drive across the city 25 minutes just to eat here in Little Saigon and then go home. I've had so many good memories whether it's to go, eating there, bringing it to a picnic, or evening ordering 30 sandwiches for a dirty 30 party lol.
author: Jul C.

description: This is the best Bahn Mi that I have had in the city. Combine that with the fact that it costs $4 makes this little, unassuming sandwich shop the BEST LUNCH VALUE in San Francisco. The ladies working across the counter are also quick and efficient. I ordered seven sandwiches  and they had me out the door in less than 10 minutes!
author: Jon M.

description:
In the past, whenever I purchased sandwiches from Lee's, I always wondered if Saigon Sandwich was better. They are nearby each other and serve similar items.

-Prices are around the usual $3.75, but the combination sandwich is $4.25. I wouldn't say it's pricey since my usual banh mi place sells their combination sandwich for $5.88 (tax included). One of the things I like about Saigon Sandwich is how the tax is already included, so it makes paying easier. 

-When I received my sandwich, W O W. The sandwich first appears small and fat in width, but it's what's inside that matters. They put a lot of ingredients such as daikons, carrots, cilantro, pâté, and jalapeños. In the combination sandwich they even have this weird mixture with the mayonnaise, probably brown sauce from the meat(?). I've never seen or tasted this before in banh mi, but one of the ingredients was beef flank!

Although hours have passed by since I finished my combination sandwich, I still feel full! Definitely filled with quality ingredients and deliciousness. The next time I'm craving banh mi, I'll forsure stop by.
author: Erica K.

description:
Hearty, tasty, and inexpensive sandwich made quickly in the Tenderloin near where I work. I really like the carrots and cilantro they stuff into it.

They do not have seating so you have to take out.
author: Han K.

description:
The one benefit of being called to jury duty at the courthouse in the Civic Center is the proximity to Saigon Sandwich and other good eats.

I had not expected the line to move so quickly on my initial visit and when asked for my selection I blurted out that I wanted the pork meatball sandwich, something I don't usually order when eating a banh mi.  That sandwich was literally ready in less than 2 minutes from ordering.  I didn't even have time to put the change back in my wallet before the lady handed me the warm wrapped sandwich.  Don't let the line going out the door intimidate you.

The menu is pretty limited but the ingredients to make them really shine. The sandwich contained super fresh vegetables - some pickled, some raw.  There was the right mix of salty, spicy and sour.  The pork meat was juicy and well seasoned.  The sandwich was stuffed and had a good ratio of meat to veg.  The bread was perfect, crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.  

On a subsequent visit I order the special combination, a mix of ham, special pork and pate.  The sandwich was good and very, very filling. Despite the three meats I didn't find that any of them really stood out on their own.   While it was tasty, I preferred the pork meatball sandwich for the pronounced flavor of that meat.  

There are drinks, chips and some Vietnamese snacks for purchase.  There is no where to really sit and enjoy the food on site but  it's easy to walk a couple of blocks over to the Civic Center for a nice outdoor picnic.

This is a great, filling meal for less than $5, is relatively healthy and will not leave you in a food coma.
author: Melissa L.

description: I found this place on yelp, looking for a quick and good food to bring to my husband and his co workers who were working on a Saturday in the area. On a late Saturday afternoon, there was a line out the door when I got there and when I left. Cash only. The ladies working weren't the talkative type but were fast and efficient. We ordered the pork bahn mi...I didn't have any because I was trying to do low carb but they said it was tasty and all wanted to know where this place was and how I found this gem!
author: S C.

description: This place is has the best sandwiches. The roasted pork sandwich was amazing. The place is very small. No sit down places but well worth the sandwhich.
author: Crystal O.

description: Got the combination sandwich, and it was really delicious - an awesome mix of meat, pate, and pickled vegetables.  The bread was a little on the crunchy side, but the sandwich was still great.  At under $5 for a pretty big portion size, their banh mi is pretty tough to beat.
author: Simon L.

description:
Affordable banh mi here, end of story. Most of their sandwiches are under $4, which is a great price compared to a lot of banh mi places in the city, and an especially great price for a sandwich nowadays. Bummer that they don't accept cards. Cash-only is inconvenient, but for $4, I guess I can't complain too much.

On a weekday afternoon, I picked up a Thit - Roast Pork Sandwich, and a Thit Cha Pate - Special Combination w/ pate, roast pork, ham, both of which were topped with pickled carrots & daikon, jalapenos, and lots of cilantro. The French baguette was lightly toasted and crunchy. There was a good amount of meat and pate. I could distinctly taste the sweet and savory flavors of the pork, as well as the pate, unlike some banh mi that just have a light smear of pate and the flavor fades into the background. If I could change one thing, I'd use less cilantro, or at least take the leaves off the stalks, so the celery-like texture doesn't interfere with the sandwich.

I don't usually factor in location, since good food is good food, no matter where you are, but you're pretty likely to run into some people on the street who are not all there. You know, people who are talking to themselves, or going off on an incoherent rant, or who seem to be yelling at you, at themselves, or no one in particular. 

Luckily, I didn't have to deal with their weekend lines. There were only a couple of people ahead of me. The space is no larger than a takeout counter, so when a line accumulates, it can easily go out the door. 
If you're in the area and there isn't a long line, and in need of an inexpensive & satisfying banh mi on the go, Saigon is great for that. However, if there is a line, the sandwiches are not a must have. In fact, there are quite a few other banh mi joints nearby that are a pretty decent substitute as well.
author: Joy W.

description: Came here based on the reviews expecting to have the best sammage ever.  I was not all that impressed.  50% of my sammage was shaved carrots.
author: Mo L.

description:
With everything being so expensive in SF, I was surprised to see the price of  $3.75 for a sandwich, although, the size is slightly smaller than a sandwich from Thanh Da in NYC... (I remember back in the day, a banh mi sandwich was $3.25 in nyc, this was over 10 years ago)

There are not many options for the types of sandwiches which is fine.  I wanted to get the basic one so I chose the pork.  Wow.  The sandwich is that good.  The pork is very flavorful.  I ended up stuffing my face while trying to walk through the botanical gardens...classy, I know.  

On my last day in SF, I bought two pork banh mi(s).  One for breakfast and one for the flight.  I was afraid the sandwich wouldn't make it for the flight, 5 hours after I had purchased it. (that ended up being delayed)
I ended up eating it while waiting for my flight.
author: Ming T.

description:
Last week I saw people taking picture outside of this hole in the wall place. I was like wtf? is it that serious? must be tourists! 

Today I was HANGRY at work, so at 3:30pm I decided to get a sandwich. I put my life on the line for this sandwich. I have pregnancy craving. I want some meat but when I think of it, I want to throw up. I put on my big girl pants and went to saigon to give it a shot. They did not disappoint! I go the combination with ham, pork, pate. Anytime I see mountains of meat, it just makes my heart skips a beat! LOL. as far as the sandwich tho I got the combination. Yes just got it, and chewing on it as I type this review. If you grow up in Oakland, you know Ba Le is the place to go for your viet sandwich. Let me tell me Saigon Sandwich is better than Ba Le. SHHHHHH... the sandwich is so big it cant fit in my mouth ;) no complaints. LOL meat are flavorful, especially the pork! I am in doubt I will have to get a lb of pork to go. Sandwich for $4.50, this place is LEGIT! save your stomach and give your wallet a break! I will come again by later this week.

Today, saigon made me understand why people were taking pictures outside.... I can see clearly now... Btw, do you guys have stamp cards? I will fill up that 10 stamps FAST!
author: Kris J.

description: The taste is decent but man, a sandwich for just $4 you can never beat the price anywhere.
author: Yi Y.

description: I've been coming here since I was young and the price and quality hasn't changed. For a sandwich that only costs $4, most people would expect the sandwich to not make you feel full, but their sandwiches always fill me up. They make each sandwich fresh and give it to you quickly after ordering. The sandwiches taste best when you first buy them, but I ate mine a few hours after and it still tasted great. I highly recommend Saigon Sandwich to anyone who doesn't want to spend much or anyone who wants a good bahn mi.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
SF, The city where Yelp began. There's no wonder why Saigon Sandwich has over 2700+ reviews. 

It's good,  affordable (3.50-4.75 a baguette) and one of the cheaper eats in SF. 
Wait time can vary from no wait to 6-8 people out the door. But the line moves quick.

I think the major selling point for Saigon Sandwich is how much they pack the baguette. 

Cash Only!
author: Anh L.

description:
I don't crave Vietnamese sandwiches often, but this spot does it really good. Right in the heart of Little Saigon/Tenderloin neighborhood of SF, this is a small hole in the wall (literally) place where it has enough room for a counter to order your sandwiches, a fridge with refreshments and desserts, and a teeny tiny counter along the window that seats two max. I love their combination pork sandwiches, and for 4.50 it's so worth it. They offer a few other basic options such as just plain chicken and different varieties of pork for about 3.75 and tofu for those non-meat eaters. The sizes of these sandwiches are good portions as well; for my stomach size it can be about two meals! Service here is super friendly and kind. A lot of people seem to come here right before they close to pick up orders by phone or to get a last minute sandwich. 

Don't think about parking here as it might be hard to find since the area is pretty busy!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I'm not one to be amazed by sandwiches, but holy crap, the banh mi here was off the chains! Totally blows anything I've had in NYC out of the water when you're talking what a regular banh mi is supposed to be like. 

I was walking to another restaurant not too far from here, so figured we might as well start with an "appetizer" of two banhmis split between the 3 of us. Result: we were pretty much full by the time our actual lunch got to the table.

For the low, low price of $3.75 a sandwich, I got a roast pork, and a fanci roast pork. The regular roast pork was the absolute star of the show - the meat was so flavorful and juicy, I kept hogging that one when we passed the sandwiches around the circle. The fanci roast pork, while still good, just didn't oack that same punch.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Got the roast pork banh mi and it was great, not to mention it was only $4 (cash only).

Got lucky and came at a time where the line wasn't out the door, but they move pretty quickly. There's only two seats inside so it's definitely more of a to-go place.
author: Melody Y.

description:
Hmm, so I might be picky but this place didn't live up to the hype that I've read about. 

Perhaps I'm more used to Oakland's banh mi's but I think the filling here wasn't as impressive. I had the roast pork option and the BBQ sauce was very overpowering and salty. The pork also wasn't the typical slices that I was expecting- it was the very thin cut type. Moreover, the bread wasn't toasted enough to give that crunch, although it was warm. To be fair, for $3.75, this place is super cheap for SF standards. 

The ladies are fast and efficient though so I appreciate it. But if I had to choose somewhere to get banh mi's, I probably wouldn't visit this place again... at least not for the roast pork banh mi.
author: Sammy T.

description: This is the real deal.  A true Banh Mi. And the price is unbelievable in SF.  Go, now, immediately. Even if it's not open. Just go and wait outside until it opens!
author: John R.

description:
Amazing bahn mis for only around $4 (CASH ONLY)! The place is a hole in the wall in a sometimes not so great area but worth stopping by. The lady who made the bahn mi was so friendly and quick. They also sell drinks and snacks which looked great.

I got the special combination bahn mi which was at a slightly higher price for $4.50. The sandwich was packed with various meats and vegetables (mainly carrots). The bread is perfectly crispy with delicious pate and the sandwich is well sauced so make sure to get napkins if you're taking it to go.

Overall highly recommend and one of my favorite places in SF for a cheap and quick meal!
author: Linda X.

description:
Wait Time: 15-30 Minutes 

Unique: 2/5 - Hole in the wall Vietnamese Sandwich Shop. Sandwiches, Bottled Drinks & Snacks. They have a simple menu, and keep it simple and easy. The Special Combination is one that I will come back for, I usually do not opt for the special combination option, but this one is an exception. 

Service: You get your food made by sweet ladies. The wait and location isn't the most comforting or appealing, but worth it for a quick yummy lunch.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
I really like small places and good food.

Authentic Vietnamese sandwiches are on the top of my list.

Quaint place and good food in San Fran.
author: Barry R.

description:
Hi, I'm Minh!

I live on the east coast but when I visited SF, I knew I had to check this place out. It was recommended to me by my Vietnamese Lyft driver who grew up in the area. The banh mi here is very cheap (under $4, just the way a banh mi is supposed to be priced at) l, delicious, and huge. In all my years of eating banh mi, this is the biggest serving I've ever encountered, even bigger than the banh mi in Vietnam itself. GO HERE!! As far as I'm concerned, Saigon Sandwich should be a national treasure. When I got back to Boston and went to my local banh mi joints, there was a feeling of disappointment in that the banh mi I was holding was not the one from Saigon Sandwich.
author: Minh P.

description:
I would rate Saigon Sandwich four and a half stars.

I'm not sure there are many better deals in San Francisco than the bahn mi sandwiches here. The variation is limited, but the entire sandwich costs only $3.75. I couldn't find any other spot with more flavor per dollar. 

I had the roasted pork bahn mi, and it was delicious. The bread was crispy yet soft. The carrots, daikon, and cilantro with fresh and added an element of crunchiness. The meat was savory and juicy.
author: Joseph T.

description: PSA: The tofu sandwich is not vegetarian.  Another yelper tipped that the brown sauce is chicken based, so just order without brown sauce for a veggie sandwich, right? NOPE!  I watched them make a line of sandwiches using one set of tongs to do everything: spread mayo (using tongs for mayo is odd, but okay), pick up pork and then pick up chicken.  I then watched them use the same set of tongs that had just been in the pork for someone else's sandwich go and pick up the tofu for my sandwich.  When I asked about it she said, oh, you don't want any meat?  I ordered a tofu sandwich without brown sauce, I think it's safe to guess I don't want any meat.  Also, using one set of tongs and cross-contaminating everything is really not good food safety.  Their sandwiches are truly amazing, so if you eat meat this is your place for banh mi in SF.
author: Esembee B.

description:
I have eaten many banh mihs in my life (obviously I love to eat Vietnamese sandwiches period) but this has to be one of the best I have.  The thing I love about this meal is it is always cheap (prices have gotten up by a quarter but still cannot beat a meal under $5!).  But this particular sandwich has all the parts done right that make a great banh mih.  Let's start with the bread, it needs to have that crunchy outside but when you bite into it, it's nice and chewy and the bread can hold the contents.  The bread is toasted in the oven that provides that nice crunch.  Next part of the sandwich, the meat.  I have tried both the chicken and pork and both are great grilled meats and they put so much in there, you can easily take some out and make a mini one for a snack later!  The other part of banh mihs that I love is the pickled vegetables and their pickled veggies definitely are one of the highlights of the sandwiches.  They lather a combination of mayo and a sauce that is similar to teriyaki, this glaze definitely adds to the flavor of the whole sandwich.  NOTE:  if you are eating the sandwich later, you can ask for the veggies on the side and they will pile it in a ziplock bag for you later! 

You will not disappointed with this sandwich, both your stomach and wallet!
author: Lauren S.

description:
Delicious banh mi, without the frills.

I came here, not terribly hungry, having eaten at Brenda's nearby not more than a few hours before. Nonetheless, I had been meaning to try Saigon Sandwich for a while now, and being so close to where I was staying, I felt I had to pay a visit.

The special combination (roast pork, pork loaf, and pate) banh mi is absolutely delicious. A freshly toasted baguette, stuffed with tender roast pork, with a generous spread of pate, and finally stuffed with thinly-sliced carrots, jalapenos, and cilantro. The crustiness of the baguette, the softness and chewiness of the meat, and the crunch of the vegetables all come together for a great and filling meal. You know it's good when the juices are running down your arm and you just don't care. You have to think about how quality the ingredients might be, but since the sandwiches are so tasty, it's easy to forget that you might not be getting the absolute best pork/bread/vegetables available in SF.

Vegetarians can also come for the tofu banh mi, which I was told was delicious as well. The couple ahead of me told me that they swore by the tofu banh mi for years, so that's gotta stand for something.

As for service, the ladies behind the counter aren't the friendliest in the world, but they do work incredibly efficiently, churn out sandwiches like clockwork, and are surprisingly patient with special requests, so that's really all you can hope for. Also, there is no questioning that the value is outstanding. For a fully loaded banh mi, I'd expect to pay about $6-8, but almost all banh mis are about $4, which is absolutely unheard of in this day and age. I'm not complaining at all, but it's crazy! I have a hard time finding no-frills banh mi in New York, and even the less expensive places are at least $8-10 for a sandwich. Note that it is cash only. 

A must-visit for both banh mi aficionados and value hounds alike. Given that I typically stay around Hayes Valley/Van Ness, I'll definitely be back if I want a great cheap meal.
author: Eric J.

description:
We all know that a place with this many reviews and this many stars might be worth trying out.  It's the coveted banh mi after all.  For less than $5, you can get one that will cool down your banh mi blood cells.

To avoid the lunchtime line, I stopped by around 7:30am and was a solo customer.  Will it still be good by 12pm though?  I'm sure my combo banh mi tasted even better while at its freshest, but I cannot deny the cheerful forest animals that pranced around me while I took each bite.

Once unwrapped, my sandwich was bursting with filling, a nimiety of bright green and orange.  A very happy banh mi I'd say.

A happy banh mi with patê so rich, meat so soft and bits of fat that were hardly the chewy type I loathe.  The sliced peppers stung my lips, yet the pain urged me to take another bite of pickled flavors and the myriad of prepared pork.  They each tasted unique, but together, they were a group hug from longtime friends that were just meant for each other.  

Even the bear of a bread appeared tough on the browned exterior.  Through the crispy shell there is an inviting bed of dough, a perfect resting place for the other pieces that make this banh mi dac biet one of the best I have ever experienced.

Maybe I'm just deprived of good banh mi in Dallas.  Even so, I have this memory to fall back on whenever I try to enjoy one back home.
author: Sharde A.

description:
Cheap? Check, Delicious? Check. What more could you want from a sandwich shop? 

Always my go to lunch spot if i'm in the area. Their meats are always well seasoned/cooked and the sandwich is a decent size since they use the french rolls. The women who own the shop are always quick to serve you and polite! 

I'd recommend the pork/chicken/tofu if vegetarian. But any of the other meats look just as good! 

Also watch out for the spicy jalapenos if you're not a spice person, ask for no jalapenos. The kick might be a bit much for people who are sensitive to spice! 

Just be aware it's CASH ONLY, probably the only con but there are atms within a block away.
author: Sam T.

description: This place is good!!!!! If I'm ever in the area again, I'd get the banh mi again but when am I ever in the tenderloin???? The prices are better than most banh mi places which makes this place great! The flavors are good too! Just wishing it was in a place I would frequent more often...just FYI, cash only!
author: Kylie L.

description:
I really dont get it the great reviews....yes the pate is legit but other than that its an average sandwich. Order the special combo and it was ok. The grilled pork in it was dry AF and flavorless. It basically ruined the sandwich. Probably would have been better if I got just str8 up pork loaf.

Over-hyped.
author: Guess W.

description:
Came here yesterday to get a banh mi after visiting the Asian Art Museum. It was raining cats and dogs, so thankfully there wasn't a long wait at all. The banh mi are mostly $3.75 each, although there are a few other banh mi that are a bit more. Cash only, and tax is included in the price of the sandwich. It's a bit pricier than what I am used to paying for a banh mi (usually I pay around 2.50-3$), but the banh mi here are pretty gosh darn good. I ordered the grilled pork banh mi (also known as a bánh mì thi.t nu*ó*ng), which was loaded with meat and pickled veggies, and laden with a rich, thick meaty 'dark sauce'. Usually banh mi is accompanied with Maggi sauce, but their 'dark sauce' was definitely something... something out of this world! The flavor, quality and dense packed nature of the banh mi is definitely worth the $3.75.  

As described by previous reviewers, Saigon Sandwich is a take-out kind of place.  First of all, you're likely going to not be able to sit down and eat as there is limited seating (two seats only!) and table space. There are also no bathrooms either.  Secondly, homeless tend to stand outside of Saigon's doorway.  They don't bother me, but it was a little sad/uncomfortable eating my sandwich inside Saigon Sandwich knowing they were probably hungry as they saw me and others eating away.

Lastly, there happened to be a few sparrows that were seeking refuge inside Saigon, probably to keep dry from the pouring rain and to try to find some food scraps to eat. These sparrows were definitely NOT shy -- one of the sparrows actually crawled and flew on my hair and then later climbed and crawled onto my leg. I always thought sparrows looked cute, but this one was pretty bold. It was definitely SPARROW VS. MAN.  Who would be able to win for the last bite of banh mi...sparrow or man?  While I do love mother nature and the great outdoors, it was kind of annoying having to guard/shield my food so it wouldn't be eaten by the sparrow.

Definitely worth a try if you're in the neighborhood.  If you don't want your food to be eaten up my bold and daring sparrows, I recommend you to take your sandwich to go!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Not much to add that hasn't been said. Solid banh mi sandwich for the price of less than $4. Love the kick in the jalapeno, and the perfect toasted-ness of the baguette!

Efficient ordering, too. They will note the orders for a group of people, make the sandwiches, and then distribute, at which time you pay. Can be awkward because the store is so small, but the banh mi doesn't let you down!
author: Liz C.

description:
I've been coming here for years now. Ever since they had their bahn mi's priced at $3.00. It has been so consistent, and always the same great flavors of their beautiful sauces and their proteins. Giving the customers great options from pork to chicken to fancy pork to pate all the way to tofu and even a combination of a little of everything. It's such an amazing little gem of out city. I give them 5-star review because it has not changed at all since I've been coming here from 2010. Also, from the customers that have been coming long before I, they have said the exact same thing. Only changes are in their pricing, which tends to go up 25cents every other year. 
But you can expect the same wonderful flavors, hospitality when they have the time to acknowledge you (don't get butt hurt because you have to understand that there are only 3 of them at most serving 1000s of sandwiches a day) and also their motivation to go as fast as they can to bang out the lines that constantly build up throughout the day all the way till close time. 
I'll forever be one of their top customers because I love them so much for their hard work and always willing to get you your food in a timely manor. Also, I still don't get how one of the ladies remembers your order EXACTLY HOW YOU PLACED IT and times that by 10 other peoples orders of multiple sandwiches. I always get the sriracha and it cut in half and she is ALWAYS on point. Only 1 time has she forgotten to cut it in half. But that's 1 out of 1000 times I've ordered from them. 

Thank you Saigon Sandwich. Y'all never disappoint!
author: Nick A.

description:
Best Banh Mi  FOR SURE  in the US. I don't know how you can compare sandwiches but this place is actually freaking amazing! Honestly maintaining the 4.5 stars after 2,000+ reviews is incredible, and this place deserves it 100%. This restaurant should be considered a SF landmark to be honest. The place is pretty small, but the line goes pretty fast.

My go-to is the Banh Mi Xui Mai (Meatball Pork - $4). The meat is actually magical. The sauce they drip all over the meat oozes with the bread catching all that sauce. Also, it's super flavorful with the pickled vegetables only acting as a slight remedy. The fact that this sandwich is only $4 and you can get full is so amazing! Definitely must get when you come to San Francisco!
author: Vivienne C.

description:
Bruh.........
My wife and I were on vacation and strolling down to get a slice from Tony's pizza near china town that everyone raves about but "NOT TODAY" 
What happened ??? Saigon Sandwich is what happened. 
Meatball Banh Mi is the best sandwich I have ever had !!!! 
I waited to write this review and after 2 months I still feel the same way. I thought maybe I am being hyperbolic or delusional but I want to go back to "frisco" lol people from there hate it when tourist call it that JK kinda not really lol but anyways I want to go back to frisco (last time I promise ;) just for that banh mi. 
Ive been to Saigon and Hanoi but nothing compares. 
The cherry on top is that it's only 4 dollars!  I would pay double for that sandwich. 
When tony Bennett sang the song "I left my heart in San Francisco" I think he left it at Saigon Sandwich!
author: Mike Q.

description: It's quite surprising about how I found out about Saigon. My grandmother recently just passed away and I was planning on serving Bahn Mi for family and friends during the viewing and my Aunty told me that this spot was my grandma's favorite place to go before she played bingo, many years ago. I know, WTF right?! Anyway, she loved this place and I can see why it's always busy. So, I called to order 50 sandwiches a couple of days before I needed it and the woman on the other line was happy to take my order. They had the sandwiches ready to go when I got there. Amazing ladies working their magic in that tiny place and the sandwich is huge! Definitely worth the $200 spent and we still had leftovers to have people take it home. Remember to bring your cash before you come here.
author: Candice J.

description:
Tiny lil shop, 3 women in the back putting it all together. No places to sit for the most part but really, they're sammiches so they're mobile anyway. Service is quick, and food comes out quick as well. It isn't the best that I've had but the price for the place makes it still worthwhile.

I got the tofu sammich and the combination to try things out. The tofu was good, it was marinated well which gave it a good flavor. I personally like when there are other things aside from tofu though. The combination was good, but not great. Other combination sammiches that I've had I liked the combination of the meats better. Overall for the veggies, there were lots of carrots and a good amount of cilantro. Always a fan when there's ample cilantro since some places skimp. I kinda wish there was a bit more daikon but that is just personal preference. Things were pretty well balanced between the veggies and the sammich topping.

The price is certainly good for the area, I'll probably consider coming by again. As per usual, it is hard to find a place with a veggie banh mi that I can add egg to but those are few and far between really. This will probably become one of the go tos if I stay here longer.
author: David C.

description: There is a reason why there are always people waiting in line for their sandwiches. The bread is soft in the inside and just crunchy enough on the surface so that it doesn't leave your gum injured. I love the pickled carrots that add just enough acid to balance out the fattiness of the meat. You can taste all the ingredients in every single bite.
author: GR Z.

description: This sandwich shop is running by 3 women.  The shop is very small and located in TL (tenderloin area) on Larkin and Eddy.  The quality of these sandwiches is excellent and consistent over the years.  One of the best sandwich shops in the Bay Area.  Would you are craving for a banh mi, you must get them from here.
author: Michele H.

description: Had the roast pork for $4 and it was a good value but the pork doesnt have much roasted flavor.
author: Organic T.

description: Seriously the most delicious bahn mi sandwiches I have ever had. The sauce/gravy is incredible.
author: Alyssa K.

description:
Finallllllly got here in time to try the banh mi spot that everyone and their mama swears by. Verdict? MMMMMM!

The combination special includes a generous portion of chicken, pork loaf, pate, and the usual pickled veggie culprits. Proteins were spot on... juicy, flavorful, and overall good eats. But beyond that, a few other things stood out as well. I liked that it wasn't too bready. Whereas some banh mi joints tend to leave a lot of the bread crumb intact, Saigon Sandwich does right by the customer in taking it out. Also, the picked veggies are julienned much thinner than your standard banh mi joint. It was a welcomed change in texture providing just enough fresh crunch, but not too much. 

For four bucks and some change? I'll take three more sandwiches to go, please *clap emoji.*
author: Vi T.

description: Best banh mi sandwiches in the city! inexpensive and delicious. I always get the combo pork and they stuff the hell out of their sandwiches with meat and veggies to the point where it overfills. I also get extra pate and they are very generous with the amount they put. Each bite you get a nice crunch from the baguette bread that they use. Only two seats in this place so be prepared to order it and run to your car so you car eat it.
author: Ada H.

description:
The Vietnamese sandwiches here are delicious (and cheap), but they can easily become pricey if you're not careful.  I'm a real skinflint, so I make sure never to pay any more than I have to.

Here are some helpful tips to avoid overpaying:

Don't put any money into the parking meter (if you're driving).  It's around $3.50/hr to park in the area, and it usually takes about 15-20 minutes to wait in line and get your sandwich, which means you'll need to put approximately $1.00 into the meter, transforming your $4.00 sandwich into a $5.00 sandwich.

Don't get a parking ticket for refusing to put any money into the meter.  Your $4.00 sandwich will become an $82.00 sandwich.

Don't give money to any of the numerous crackheads loitering about.  If you get spotted handing one of them a dollar, another one will approach you, and then another, and so on, and before you know it, you've just given away like $5, increasing the cost of your sandwich to $9.00.

Don't get mugged.  Your $4.00 sandwich would then cost $4.00 + the contents of your wallet/purse.

Don't purchase a handi-j or a blow-j or a quickie from one of the streetwalkers in the area.  Your $4.00 sandwich would then cost $4.00 + $5.00 + the cost of an AIDS test.

Enjoy your $4 banh mi and be safe out there!
author: Warren L.

description:
Quaint  little hole in the wall shop.  The neighborhood  is scary though. 

Lines are long, but it moves quick..


Got  the roast Pork Bahn Mi. Messy, but flavorful.   Bun is toasted and crunchy.  Filling is overflowing....good price at  $3.75.

I recommend cutting it in half and get extra napkins.
author: Jerry W.

description:
To steal a quote from one of my favorite reviews of all time, this place makes the "dankest of the dank" bahn-mi's I have ever had.
I have tried countless bahn-mi sandwich places, and this one is incredible. They packs your sandwich FULL, you will not be disappointed. 
The biggest mistake would be passing by this place and not getting one of their $4 treats!

Enough said, enjoy!
author: Andrew K.

description:
The sandwiches are great! They are cheap and fast and delicious.. (and nutrious??)

 Definitely recommend this spot.
author: John S.

description: Fast and easy. All they need is a foot long version. I only get the chicken and it never disappoints. Also $4 is clutch
author: Brian B.

description:
The exterior of the shop may look sketchy but their food is phenomenal. This place is mainly a fast food restaurant and best known for its Vietnamese sandwiches. Their baguettes were being heated in the oven when I was making an order, and you basically get to choose your choice of "main" ranging from chicken, beef to tofu. The sandwich was one of the crispiest and most juciest Viet sandwiches I've ever had in Boston, and for $4, not sure where else can you get such a great deal. 

They also do thai iced tea for $2 and Vietnamese drip iced coffee, which reminds me of travels in Thailand and Vietnamese. All in all, an authentic sandwich shop. If there was some seating would have been great, but not complaining for the price we're paying
author: Amos Y.

description: Best banh-mi in San Francisco. This is also just fun spot to go to because it is such a hole in the wall. The sandwiches are so cheap and really good, and they work really quickly to get you your food. Great for lunch take-out as there is no seating.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Best.  Sandwich.  Ever.  

I'd call ahead if you are ordering more than 10.  And I'd order more than 10.

Amazing
author: IAN W.

description:
I went to Saigon Sandwiches on a Friday around lunchtime as I saw it had the highest rating out of all the Vietnamese bánh mì sandwiches in the area.  When I walked by, I saw it had quite a crowd of people lined up to order, as well as a scatter of people waiting for their food.  I was a bit shocked to see the interior with 4 Vietnamese women quickly working in a bánh mì sandwich assembly line.  It didn't look like very sanitary conditions, but I still ordered a roast chicken sandwich for $3.75.  

I was worried it would take a long time to get my order, but it was pretty fast (5-10 minutes).  I could see this getting out of hand with a lot more people because when I placed my order, the lady just wrote down my food without my name or without me even paying.  Then, she just called out "one roast chicken."  I had to look around to make sure it was my actual order and then paid.

There is a small area at the front beside the cooler with two chairs you could sit and eat at, but with all of the people crowding inside, I wouldn't recommend this.  There is no seating outside, as well, so it's more of a "take-away" sandwich shop sort of thing.  When opening the wrapping to the sandwich, I saw how messy it was put together.  I wouldn't have minded waiting a bit longer if they made it less messy.  The bread was a bit too hard for me, and I can see it hurting the top of people's mouths when biting down.  

Overall, the sandwich was ok, but you can't really complain about that price.  I think that's the only reason why this place has such a high rating.  I eat a lot of bánh mì sandwiches personally, and this place definitely was not matching what Yelp had me believe it should be.  Maybe I came on an off day?  I'm highly disappointed to read on Yelp that this is the best bánh mì sandwich in San Francisco; that's unacceptable.

What I ordered:
-Roast Chicken Bánh Mì Sandwich ($3.75)

Pros:
-Very inexpensive

Cons:
-Sketchy neighborhood with many homeless people
-Looks unsanitary in the interior
-Messy sandwich
-Bread is too hard
-No comfortable seating area (take-away only)
-Confusing ordering setup
author: Justin A.

description:
SO good. A line out the door every time we go there for lunch is a great sign. It can get a little crazy, so keep an eye on who ordered ahead of you so you know when you'll be next. I always get the pork and ask for extra sauce, but it's all good.

It's in the middle of the tenderloin, so there are plenty of homeless around. If you can afford it, buy an extra sandwich (they are $4 each) and hand one out :)
author: Walt S.

description:
This is probably the cheapest and best tasting Banh Mi in the city.

Don't like those long lines though...
author: Agent K.

description: The sandwiches are absolutely perfect. I ordered a chicken bahn mi and it was amazing, perfect amount of condiment, veggie, and a hearty amount of chicken. Even better, for two sandwiches I paid less than $8! Definitely come here, but make sure to bring cash as they do not take card :)
author: Ran W.

description: In my opinion, any satisfying meal you can get for only $4 is worth it, let alone a super tasty roast pork banh mi. It was very flavorful and fresh, and I particularly thought the bread was surprisingly good quality. There's only two chairs, so you must go somewhere else to enjoy your sandwich, and make sure to bring cash. I went at around noon on a weekday and was able to get my sandwich in under five minutes.
author: Vivian J.

description:
Huge fan of the meatball sandwich here. I usually end up partnering with one of my co-workers to do halfsies to get some variety. 

Here's the drill, get in line - there'll be a line if you come any time close to lunch time. Figure out what you want, make your order, if you want a drink, mention it now, pay up (cash only), grab your beverage then go outside. 

There's not much space inside and you won't get a number - it takes a few minutes to get your order ready anyway. If possible stay in earshot or listen in once in awhile for your order. You'll also probably want to remember who was in front of you so you can gauge when it's your turn. 

We usually end up bringing these back to the office to sit down and enjoy the sandwich, I don't recall any places to sit down in the area.
author: Jeff C.

description: Found a great spot to eat for the cheap! Can you say 4 bucks for a great Vietnamese sandwich!   There was a line out the door but I only waited 3 minutes before I was eating deliciousness! Fresh vegetables and soft roast Pork!
author: Ryan H.

description:
My first Bahn mi. Super delicious also cheap!!:) 
It was totally worth it. Also liked their rice pudding which was only $2 and 
delicious. Location is little bit scary but it doesn't matter for me. 
My friend said baguette was little bit hard though. But it was okay for me.
author: Yenny O.

description: This place is located at a really shady part of town.  If getting here by train/walking, one would have to walk about 5-6 blocks from the Powell Station.  The sandwiches were a decent sized baguette, slathered with a generous serving of pate, and the vegetables (cilantro, jalapeno peppers) seemed pretty fresh.  Overall, the sandwich was average and was not worth walking through a very sketchy area to get to.
author: Amy M.

description:
Great. Great! I'm gonna humble brag or just plain brag about spending time and falling in love with Vietnam. I've had Bahn Mis from the likes of Anthony Bourdain's favorite joint in the beautiful city of Hoi An - OH MY GOD.

Saigon sandwich - Damn. For 3.75 this place is really awesome. You will walk in and there will be literally nothing but hardworking folks serving up some great sandwiches. There will be people lining out the door because there's no room inside and also because we all want a Bahn Mi. A nice menu to choose from. 

I got the roasted pork. It had some fat on it that I had to strip away, but it was really delicious and really authentic. 

Would I come here again? No doubt.
author: Priti K.

description:
Finally get to try Saigon sandwich! The line was long and out the door on a Saturday morning, it is definitely a popular Sandwich place!

I got the special combination sandwich, which was a little smaller than I thought. The bread itself is quite hard, I was expecting more crunch on the outside only, not the entire roll to be hard. Lots of cilantro and jalapeno pepper, great pickle veggies. The vegetable portion of the sandwich is great, giving a very fresh taste! There are many types of meat in the sandwich, which I thought were all compressed too much and mushed together (instead of layered). I couldn't taste the distinct flavor from each meat, and the sauce in the sandwich tasted like a tuna sandwich.  

There are definitely generous amount of meat and fillings, but the flavors just don't stand out. The sandwiches are very freshly made though, not a bad place for Vietnamese sandwich if you are in the area!
author: Karen C.

description:
The Vietnamese sandwiches (banh mi) are soooo good and affordable here.

They're open at 7:00 am every morning and they offer everything from banh mis, Asian snacks, drinks and Vietnamese pork cakes. 

I usually get the combo sandwich. Its a combo of various pork meats. I love lots of pate on my sandwiches but it's unnecessary to ask for extra pate because they already pile on a mountain full on your sandwich. 

Their bread is warm and chewy with just the right amount of bounce. 

Busy times are lunch time around 12pm but the line moves pretty quick.
author: Kelly L.

description:
I almost don't wanna write a post about this amazing place! This is a true spot for locals. This is where we go on our way to Dolores Park or before a Parade. 

We've known about this spot since their sandwiches were $1.75 and their shop was the size of a closet. Best bánh mis in town - no questions about it. Their meatball sandwich is now $4 - Which c'mon - It's amazing for such a well-made treat. 

They use fresh french bread, a generous amount of meat, carrots, cilantro, jalapeños, and their secret sauce. They also have pate, fancy pork, roasted pork and chicken sandwiches, as well as combinations (like their meatball-pate sandwich).

Try it with some Vietnamese chips, and a cold Green tea Ginger Ale.

Thumbs Up.
author: Charo F.

description:
Not sure what happened, but my banh mi (combo version) wasn't quite as I'd remembered it to be.  Yes, the bread was wonderfully crusty, and yes, there was a thin layer of pate...

But it just didn't taste as good as I remembered.  They were pretty busy for a Saturday afternoon...perhaps that was the reason it wasn't so awesome.  

Hopefully it'll be better next time?
author: David B.

description:
Disclaimer: sketchy location.

Looking for traditional-amazing Banh Mis? Then you need to check out Saigon Sandwich. 

This hole in the wall, cash only mom & pop will have your mouth watering.

Despite the out-the-door line, I decided to stop by one Saturday for lunch. This spot is so tiny, and low-key unsanitary looking...but the ladies are sure to get your sandwich made asap. And let me tell you-it tastes good!

I had the combo sandwich for less than $5. It was amazing.

Fresh, quality ingredients, and traditional Banh Mi flavor, what more can one ask for?! Definitely worth checking out.
author: Christina L.

description: My sandwich was delicious. They were not skimpy when it came to the meat or veggies. Was very cramped inside and CASH ONLY (had to go to the ATM). But that won't stop me from coming again.
author: Davina D.

description:
I feel like I shouldn't post a review so I can keep this place my little secret.

I've been here a few times now, it's probably one of the few cheap but delicious bahn mi joints in the city. I went here the other day after failing to get a free Ike's sandwich a few blocks away. Probably not the best neighborhood to walk around, but this place is such a treasure if you happen to be in the area already. Not going to lie, I had no regrets walking away from a 2 hour wait for a free Ike's sandwich. The bahn mi here are only $4.00!!! 

They're generous with their meat and toppings, and the bread is always crunchy on the outside. DELICIOUS! 

This place is teeny tiny. Just enough space for the kitchen, cash register and a couple people to stand in line. Usually the line is out the door, so I always try to go before or after peak hours. There are no tables, which is okay, as sandwiches make the perfect take out food.
author: Alison S.

description:
Special combo for $4.25. The banh mi is packed to the brim with meat and topped with slightly pickled veggies. The bun is toasted and the sauces really help bring it all together. 

This small mom and pops Viet sub place is really da bomb. I couldn't find a good bowl of pho while here in San Fran, but if you're craving banh mi or just a bomb ass sandwich this place is forizzles.

Edit: I couldn't stop thinking about banh mi the other day. Love it, feel it, taste it. I miss this place so much.
author: Nancy H.

description: The sandwiches are fantastic. Give your order to the lady who takes them rapid-fire, then wait for it, and pay when you pick it up. The only drawback - no seating.
author: Celeste S.

description: One of the best places for Vietnamese Sanwiches in San Francisco. Toasted baguette with bbq pork. The chicken is pretty good too! I love the fact that all ingredients are fresh and tasty.
author: Thu L.

description:
Top banh mi in SF.

I biked over at around 4:23pm on a Sunday. I saw a take-out box full of fried chicken and collard greens on the sidewalk. By the time I locked my bike, 17 pigeons began circling the fried chicken.

When I walked into Saigon Sandwich with a friend, I realized the interior decorator did an excellent job at creating a hole-in-the-wall aesthetic. Assuming that this was not deliberate, this seemed like a promising sign.

I approached the counter. The staff comprised of two Vietnamese women. The cashier was likely 63 years old and about 4 foot 8. She did not take my order until about 5 other people stood in line behind me after 212 seconds. She then took everyone's orders at once and sent them off to the builder of banh mi's.

I ordered a tofu banh mi. You'll see the menu up and to the right of the counter. The wall has an off-white color.

In exchange for $5 in cash, I received my banh mi a 3 minutes later, wrapped in paper. At this time, I made the mistake of not grabbing a napkin. Remember to do this. This was a key mistake.

Upon exiting, the aforementioned fried chicken had been entirely devoured, yet the collard greens were untouched. The obvious next question was whether pigeons were cannibalistic, perhaps liable to eat a fried pigeon if the opportunity came about.

The banh mi was delicious. Juicy. Fresh. Flavorful. The juiciness was both a blessing and a curse. Had I remembered to grab napkins, it would have only been a blessing.
author: Sebastian L.

description: Small hole in the wall Vietnamese joint that serves bomb sandwiches! I ordered their classic special and it was packed with tons of juicy meats and a mountain of veggies smothered with some tasty spread. This would have been the perfect sandwich if their baguette was less hard and crunchy.  I was in and out in a breeze.
author: Thuy N.

description: Not sure what is great about this place.  I adore mom and pop shops that serve up honest, good food.  But this place is just okay.  It is definitely not worth lining up for.  There are other banh mi places popping up in the city and some of them are way better.
author: Gab T.

description: Probably the best banh mi I've had! I ordered 4 of the special combination, the pate is what makes the sandwich and they are not shy on the pickled carrots which is my favorite. Me and my boyfriend came probably 5 mins before closing and the ladies working were lovely enough to take our order. The only thing is the area is a bit sketchy lol. I was visiting from Phoenix, but because of the yelp reviews I had to try it out for myself and it was well worth it!
author: Linda N.

description: So this place...... underserves my banh mi needs. I ordered their vietnamese sandwich (banh Mi) and they loaded a bunch of carrots onto the sandwich. The taste of raw carrots. Yuck! It's missing a lot of good stuff for a complete banh mi. Call me picky.
author: Yennie L.

description: Omg the pork is unbelievable! It can stop you in your tracks! The pork is juicy, flavorful, and paired perfectly with the sauce and other ingredients. The price is awesome! I will always go out of my way to stop by here anytime I'm in SF!
author: Marcos P.

description: A bit overrated for banh mi. In a not so great area so if you are craving banh mi go early in day time hours. Price is decent. Although there are better banh mi places around the city that I would pay a little more just to enjoy not having to deal with the area and the smell outside due to the homeless hanging out.
author: Diana N.

description:
This is the first time I went to a restaurant that was featured on the food network where the review was spot on. The Bahn Mi was the best I ever had. The one thing that stood out about their sandwich it that there is a hellaton of meat on it. Most Bahn Mi's have so little meat you can barely taste it. 

They were only $3.75, so I assumed they would me teeny, so i bought 2. I could barely finish 1, so I have another for later. 

It was stuffed with pickled shredded carrots and onions , cilantro, some kind of awesome sauce sliced jalapeño peppers on a crusty roll. 

If you are anywhere near San Francisco you must go here. 

Oh yeah - only take cash.
author: Monica C.

description:
This place is good for quick Vietnamese sandwiches.  Saigon style authentic  sandwiches.  All $3.75.  
Don't try the tofu if your  vegetarian. It's delicious but it's basted in meat sauce.   Always a long line for lunch but it moves quickly.
author: David C.

description: $3.75 for a banh mi? It can't get any better than that. Be sure to tell them no spicy if you don't like spice. Got the roast beef and it was delicious. Quick and easy
author: Shyann C.

description:
Ambiance?
Service?
Menu options?
Piffle!

Value, flavor, speed & satisfaction?
You betcha!
author: Ken B.

description: The cheapest meal you will find in sf!($4) I usually go here to share one sandwich with a friend. So yummy!!
author: Clara L.

description:
You can never beat a good banh mi sandwich at a decent price in the city. I had the combination pork special and it met all of my expectations. The bread had just the right amount of crunch and softness, the pork had a nice flavor, and the cilantro, carrots, jalapeños and cucumbers worked nicely to bring it all together. There was a line because I want around lunch time on a weekday, but service was fast as the women behind the counter took orders and whipped up sandwiches in lightening speed. 

I will definitely go back here again.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Traveling from New York i have to say this is the BEST Viet sandwich i have ever had. 
When i arrived at the place i was skeptical on how great the reviews were on yelp. The store is legit a hole in the wall. Once i took a bite into my roasted chicken viet sandwich i was in love. The price is unbeatable too.
author: Arra C.

description:
This is the best banh mi place i have ever been, asia included... 

$4 for a full-on sandwich in san francisco, that is crazy, the staff is very nice also, they apologize when they mess up orders and re-do them, which most cheap asian restaurants will not. 
Another bonus that they handle money with different hand than the one making sandwich, seems obvious but most cheap asian restaurants dont follow.
author: Jesse J.

description:
In the past, whenever I wanted a Vietnamese sandwich, I would usually get dropped off (since parking sucks in the city), run inside, and place my order.  This means the only thing I see when I step out of the car is the blue awning and my only interaction is with the ladies inside.  Now that I'm in the area and actually have to walk here, I get a taste of cannabis and urine--wait I mean I get a taste of the heart of TL.  

Hi unidentified human or animal poop smears on each block, questionable
Hi person hiding under that sheet doing something inappropriate, I see you
Hi lady with pants dropped to the floor squatting midway taking a fat piss, skills
Hi homeless guy sitting on the sidewalk with your genital tanning in the sun, I hate uneven tans too
Hi two men shooting up in broad daylight, where the party at

Once you get passed all of that and purchase your banh mi to go, you get to revisit all of those sightings again when you head back 

Banh Mi Thit Nuong - love thit nuong (pork) in my sandwiches and noodle plates.  

There's always a line during lunch hours but it goes by quick.  The sandwiches are now $4.75 but still worth it compared to others I've had.
author: Linda N.

description: Wow. Best lunch deal in town! Delicious Vietnamese sandwich for just a few bucks (get the roasted pork) and made in a few seconds. And they don't screw you on the drinks, either ($1). -- Heard the legend. Now, I've eaten the truth!
author: J C.

description:
I know this is a staple in SF for amazing banh mi but I just didn't enjoy mine that much :( came on a Saturday around 2pm and luckily there was no line at all!!

I ordered the roasted pork and steamed pork + pate. Sandwiches came out within 2 mins and was about $4 each. So cheap. The sandwich is loaded with meat and they are not shy about the pate which was amazing. However, the flavor of the meat fell flat for me and the whole sandwich ended up just feeling a little dry. Overall I did enjoy the sandwich but it was not amazing enough for me to make a special trip or recommend to visitors coming to SF. Sorry :(
author: Isabella L.

description: Probably the best bahn mi on planet Earth, according to my wife who is Vietnamese so that gives it plenty of credibility. I would drive an hour from South Bay just to eat this
author: Phillip W.

description: So, I don't know if my review is skewed because I got there 45 minutes after opening but, I had a hot, fresh baguette with delicious meat and it was filled to the top with fresh vegetables and amazing flavor. The pat is definitely creamy and delicious. My only complaint is that it is $4 for one sandwich when, I am a girl from Southern California and near the Little Saigon area, and I'm used to paying $4 for three sandwiches with just as good quality. The area is definitely sketchy, no matter the hour. But, I think I found a sandwich shop here in the city to satisfy my Vietnamese sandwich craving until I go back home to visit.
author: Crystal K.

description:
Sure wish they had a vegetarian option. I was REALLY looking forward to trying one of these but Noooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo...meat only...

Man, what a bummer.
author: John C.
