description: I highly recommend the $4 tofu sandwich. Usually bahn mi sandwiches are a little dry, but here they have a delicious slightly creamy sauce that really makes it a complete sandwich. I've heard the chicken sandwich can have some bad pieces of chicken, but the tofu sandwich is as good as I've ever had. If you're like me and can't handle spicy food then make sure to check for jalapenos because there can be some big slices.
author: Ben E.

description: Amazing stuff. Came here with a relatively large group and ordered the chicken banh mi. They made the sandwiches super quickly, they tasted amazing, and they were only $4 - what more can you ask! Their drink selection is also super diverse; I went for the diet cherry 7UP, which I didn't know existed until today. This place definitely lives up to the 3K review hype, check it out!
author: Rajiv M.

description: Loved this place when I was young and it's just as good as I remembered it, only thing is their sauce has changed a little but nevertheless it's still pretty good over all......it was $2.50 back then but $4.00 now, not bad for 20 years !
author: Johnny H.

description: Amazing place to get sandwich.to be honest I don't like tenderloin.but Saigon sandwich definitely make me go there again   Again and again! I alaways Order sandwich combo it tastes amazing .and it's good deal nothing to complain!
author: Clancy Y.

description: Gear tasting banh mi's AMAZING price. Thats why they have a super high volume. Everything down to the bread tastes great. If you're on a budget or you're thinking about buying lunch for everyone in your office. This is the place to go. They also have a good selection of drinks and desserts to make a complete meal
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Best $3.50 banh mi sandwich ever. I enjoyed their pork sandwich today and couldn't be happier. I would give it 5 stars if there was a place to sit inside or near by to eat my sandwich.

The fresh carrots and veggies with the mayo sauce and the flavorful pork is delectable. They had a little hot jalapeno in there for good measure which added a fierce kick to my sandwich. 

I went at 2 pm on a Sunday during President's Day weekend and there was no line.
author: Keiko T.

description:
One of the best I've had!! What a great no frills shop that serves quality sandwiches at great prices. Keep in mind this place is cash only and have very limited seating (like 3 chairs).  I do think the bread could be softer inside and crisp outside, but I'm just being a stickler. 

I got the combination one and roastedpork/BBQ pork which we both really liked. Give this place a try people!!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I've seen the Saigon Sandwich shop referenced in a lot of other vietnamese restaurant reviews so I finally made the trek into tenderloin to see what all the fuss is about. Location is't too great honestly, but its not too long of a walk from the city hall. There are only a few seats by the window in the building - most of it is take out.
There are some tasty snacks, canned drinks, and viet desserts laid out at the counter. Besides that the menu isnt too complicated. You can get a banhmi sandwich that has chicken ($3.75), or pork($3.75), or pate($3.75), or all of them in it as a combo ($4.5). It comes with a generous serving of meat, jalapeno, carrots, cilantro and some mayo.
It was a solid sandwich, and also a decently large serving. In FiDi, people would pay $10 for this.
Some things I wasn't ecstatic about was the 'fancy ham' that they used - not sure what it was but it was a bit dry - and the pate which overwhelmed everything else maybe bc they were a bit too generous with it lol. But definitely would stop by here again for a good banhmi!
author: Grace P.

description: Does this place even need another Yelp review? Seriously this is as good as it gets! I LOVE the caramelized sauce that they use on the baguette and I always get extra pate (liver spread) with their fancy meat. Just make sure that if you aren't eating it right away that you tell the ladies to put your veggies on the side bc it CAN get soggy. I will miss saigon sandwiches when I leave sf! For 3.75, there's really not a better place in town for a full meal!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
After having banh mi's literally everywhere I go, I've finally found a place that can satisfy me. You know when you order a sandwich and when you finally get it, all you see is the French baguette? Or you're wondering why there's only like a few slices of pork or chicken and IT'S JUST NOT SATISFYING? Even though it was dirt cheap so it's kinda forgivable?

NOT THIS PLACE. I'm so happy to find this place. Was in the neighborhood this morning and wanted some Vietnamese food. This hole-in-the-wall was literally a hole in the wall. I went with the combo sandwich which was the most expensive at $4.25 and dude, it's so worth it. It's worth like $8. Or maybe $10. But $4.25? Yes. Combo with lots of meat and carrots and radish and cilantro.

Cash only!
author: Lucy Z.

description:
No room to sit, stand or loiter?

No problem!

(plus it's warm AF inside this place)

Just walk in, have cash ready, order one of each sandwich, and then walk the streets back to your office utterly TORMENTED as you are forced to decide whether to eat the pork or the chicken first.

(2-cents): eat the chicken first. pork can hold and might even get better.
author: Mike V.

description: $4 pork sandwich. Good flavor and fast service. Bread is a little stale compared to Lee's across the street but still super tasty!
author: Mandi W.

description: Love Love Love! Super close to my parents's apartment in the city. Love going here for mid day snack. I ultimate favorite the is Chinese meatballs sandwich (Banh mi xiu mai). Very meaty. the sauce is tomato base is it is salty, sour, and sweet.
author: David Dat T.

description: Delicious. Almost like what my former neighbors from Vietnam made. I'll go back again.
author: Carrie H.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and this is by far the one banh mi shops i would NOT recommend.  

First of all, the keys to an excellent banh mi are:  Crispy on the outside and hollow on the inside french baguette that smells good, excellent pate, and homemade egg yolk mayonnaise.  This place lacks all three.   The bread they're using is not french baguette, it's thick, doughy and chewy.  They over compensate their poor quality pate by putting a lot of pate on the sandwich and the mayonniase, I don't have a word to describe it.  

We went out of our way based on over 2,500 yelp reviews to give this place a try and was deeply disappointed.  

They really give you a lot of meat for the sandwich and by the average American standard, is worth your money but not your taste bud.
author: Annie P.

description: Had the roast pork and the fanci pork. Line was manageable. At $3.75 it's pretty good. The fanci pork was good but the roast pork was exceptional. I liked it more than the one from the ones at westminster. Definitely will be back if I'm around here again.
author: Marco S.

description: Best bahn mi sandwich in SF and under $5. I highly recommend the tofu. The ladies working are always so nice!
author: Scarlette T.

description:
Prepare yourself for lines around the lunch rush. Lots of people make large orders, and I've waited anywhere from 5-20 minutes here while they scramble to make 20 sandwiches for one order. 

You'd be hard pressed to find a more reasonably priced, generously sized banh mi in SF. Don't expect to sit down and eat though, there's only two chairs. The Tenderloin is great and the neighborhood isn't the big deal people make it out to be, you're like three blocks out of Civic Center max.

My favorite sandwiches are the tofu and meatball--don't opt out on the jalapeños, they really make the sandwich!
author: Sarah W.

description:
This is an interesting place-- my company pre-ordered 200 sandwiches for an event and I went to pick it up. The order was not ready at the scheduled pick up time and I ended up waiting an hour as the 4 women hustled behind the counter making the sandwiches. There's only 1 table inside so don't plan on eating in.

In the hour of waiting, the door was constantly flooded with people stopping in for a sandwich--all different types of people which was neat to see. The people who came in to get a sandwich or two were instantly in and out the door, I think the big order wasn't part of their usual routine and threw them off a bit. The women were very kind and helped me lug the bags of sandwiches to the car.

The sandwiches are very good and at an excellent price. I wish I lived closer so I could stop by more often.
author: Kelly F.

description: Truly delicious banh mi. Totally worth getting hassled by the homeless.
author: Quigley Q.

description:
I learned about this place years ago from my Yelp friends, yet never really had the opportunity to go when they were open. Now that I work in the neighborhood, I like to walk down for lunch or pick up a few sandwiches to go.

Before my friend Mariela D. left the bay area, I loaded up a bag of the roasted chicken and roasted pork. While I'm driving to her place, I'm having these crazy hunger pains from the smell. We all split them up and ate them, bringing one home to my guy who enjoyed it as well. 

At $3.75 for a big hearty and healthy sandwich, you cannot go wrong.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
The most you can ask for is an extra of something. You can say extra meat, extra pate, extra carrot and radish, extra cilantro, blah blah blah. If you dont want something in your sandwich I suggest you wait till you get to your eating destination open it and take it out. Be prepared when they take your order and order with confidence. Speak up and be direct and annunciate as clearly as possible. After that, PLEASE MOVE OUT OF THE WAY.

Use the time while you are in line or waiting for your order to analyze what type of drink or side/sweet you want and always listen for your order. The lady who takes the orders will usually holler your selection and then attempt to make eye contact with you.

Promptly show her your drink and side selection, pay up, and then either sit in one of the two stools and eat or yet again, PLEASE MOVE OUT OF THE WAY.

I had to learn the hard way. I have bumped into people, deserved heavy shade sighs from people. Ordered wrong. Asked for too much. Complicated everything! 

Now I know the ways. Thank you banh mi Jedis or as others have called them, Nazis. IDK anymore.

I want to hug the woman here. The best banh mi in the City!
author: Niana D.

description: All around perfect sandwich for anyone on-the-go and pretty hungry. A full meal deal in a sandwich, with protein and vegetables and great flavors in a super cheap package and ready to go in minutes. People line up for these during peak hours, but the line goes quick.
author: Jordan W.

description:
Beggars can't be choosers. 

And for $3.75, these sandwiches are a bargain. Menu has about 8 sandwich varieties- roast pork, roast chicken, meatball pork, fanci pork, tofu, and 2 combos options. Large bread roll and good portions of the fixings. Can also buy Asian snacks and drinks here.

Tip: Ask for them to cut your sandwich is half. They don't usually do that.
author: Joanna L.

description: Was on jury duty and found Saigon Sandwich by their reviews on Yelp.  I was surprised by the price ($4, really?) but mostly by the deliciousness of the roast pork sandwich.  I asked for hot sauce and they gave me a plastic bag so I decided to go it alone - there were enough jalapeños to spice it up.  I'll make my way back here for sure!
author: Roberta B.

description: I came here when I visited SF for the first time. I was short on money so I ate here. The banh mi was so filling and delicious.
author: Yumi P.

description:
CASH ONLY

Arrived around 1230pm on a Sunday and there was already a short line going out the door! The line definitely goes by quickly though so if you feel stuck in one place, it's because they do all the orders all at once for a bunch of people that are still waiting to pay, and then they all leave at once!

Being so highly rated in the SF area, I expected an amazing banh mi.  We ordered the combo which had PLENTY of meat and PLENTY of pate. but too much mayo and not enough veggies!!! It made the banh mi too saucy and wet in the end, which is the first time I have ever seen that before. For $4.25 though, it is a great deal. 

Definitely not a take out type of banh mi to save for the next day if you were thinking of saving one. 

Huong Lan in SJ, you still win my heart!
author: Kathy D.

description: Pretty good reviews on yelp.  Decided to stop by to grab a sandwich before walking around the city.  Not too big of a sandwich, but definitely stuffed!  Slightly too much of Pate, but that's okay.  Overall not too bad.  I wish the bread was less dense, slightly less pate, and more of the deli meats.
author: Ivy T.

description:
The best..,yes I did say best banh mi ever. For $4.50 this sandwich had a thick layer of meat and it was a heavy sandwich. The falcons were great and they have a special spread that is like a mix of mayonnaise and their BBQ sauce. Just delicious. Bread was nice and fresh, service was fast and efficient. 

One lady Will ask everyone in line what they want, she'll start putting in the meat, then the 2nd lady will put in the veggies and such. When some sandwiches were done and wrapped,  the 1st lady then take on the role of cashier. Truly efficient,
author: Helen L.

description: Took sandwiches to-go as a snack during our hike. The sandwich was packed with veggies and meat. It was still delicious 3 hours after being made. I had the xiu mai but if I had known the combo was so popular I would've gotten that one! Overall a delectable, cheap meal on the go!
author: Han N.

description:
Many years ago, I visited San Francisco and ate the most delicious banh mi of my life. For a city choke full of amazing food, I could only remember this buttery morsel of deliciousness. 

Perhaps I set my expectations too high, or perhaps I have just dined at too many fine establishments and raised my standards too high since then. Either way, the combination sandwich this time was short of spectacular. The meat fillings, definitely the pate, were delicious, but the bread could use some work. The bread was borderline tough/stale, leaving much room to desire some flakey crisp bread during each bite.
author: Kathy D.

description:
You may be thinking : " two stars?! Really?!" Yes, really. Was it because the owner/ sandwich artist/ front counter lady yelled at me in front of all the customers which resulted to me getting laughed at walking out like a kid getting sent to the principals office, head down and everything? Nah, I'm actually used to getting yelled at by Vietnamese women. My bfs mother for example . Was it because their bread was hard as a rock making it hard to eat? Possibly. Or was it because the sandwhich was all carrots and a sprig of cilantro , no daikon? Yeah, that too. 

I had high hopes for Saigon sandwhich hence the yelp reviews and line all the way outside the front door. I had even higher hopes when I met a new friend while waiting in line. He told us that lines start to form outside the door the moment they open up at 7 am. He also mentioned they're way better than lees down the street. Ok, so I'm game. Let's see what you're all about. I had my bf order for us while I chit chatted outside with my new friend Armando. ( If you're reading this, Armando then holla at your girl ! I couldn't find you on yelp like I said I would.) 

No wonder the lady yelled at me, she's from the same area as my bfs mom. My bf told me he sensed she was in a bad mood so he decided to soften her up by speaking her dialect to her. It worked ! In fact, he sweet talked her to the point where she gave him $1 off our order . I'm not surprised though cause my bf IS a sweet talker! I mean how else did I fall for him?! 1 star because of that and another star because even though the bread was hard and it had a lot of carrots, they did pack it with lots of pork. Like hella hella pork ! I ordered the thit nuong ( grilled pork) but it was more like a brisket sandwhich . Would I come back ? Probably not but who knows.
author: Monica C.

description:
For less than $5 you can't be the value for what you get. I got the combo with pate, roast pork, and sausage with all the pickled veggies. The bread was solid and the meats were tasty. Was it the best Banh Mi I've ever had? No, because I've had the real deal in Vietnam. However, the sandwich I got was solid and hit the spot and deserves the 5 stars because it only cost me $4.75

I got in at 11:30 before the lunch line showed up and was out the door in less than a minute since they already had a sandwich made and ready to go. If you're not familiar with the city, it does suck to have to navigate the Tenderloin to get to this gem but it's definitely worth it!
author: John H.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend for a late lunch on a Saturday (there was pretty much no wait, but it was a weird time). The store was very small and meant for a quick to-go bite of banh mi, or Vietnamese-style sandwich. There are a couple of stools that we used before walking to Van Ness for a movie. Upon entering, we are greeted by two Vietnamese ladies who are polite, though direct and wasted no time in asking for our order. 

I chose a roast pork sandwich (banh mi thit) and my boyfriend got a fancy pork sandwich (banh mi cha lua) which also came with pate (minced liver paste). I admit the idea of pate sounds scary, though trust me, it's delicious and I highly recommend it. The sandwiches also come with pickled carrots and daikon, cilantro, green peppers, and some sauces (tasted like mayo and ?). The countertop is scattered with a variety of Vietnamese desserts and on the side are coolers with a variety of Asian and American beverage. 

After ordering, the lady took the bread out of a mini-oven and made the sandwich to our order.
Now this bread was noteworthy! The exterior was very crunchy and the inside was soft and slathered in the delicious sauces. The toppings were generous and the portion size is actually quite substantial for a super cheap price ($3.75 each!). I suspect that the fancy pork (cha lua) came from a package, though likely the grilled pork was prepared by themselves. Regardless, both were delicious and some of the best banh mi I've ever tried (I'm Vietnamese!).

Overall: While not the nicest restaurant (or area), Saigon Sandwich is the perfect quick bite for an unbeatable price.
author: Vivian L.

description:
For $3.75 a sandwich, you are definitely getting your money's worth here. I got the roast pork, which is so juicy and flavorful, and they do not skimp on meat at all. I was concerned at first because I saw hella carrots, onions, and jalapenos, but as soon as I bit into it, I saw that they had packed it 2/3 full of meat inside. The savory flavor of the meat contrasts nicely with the fresh crisp veggies to create a very filling sandwich. My only complaint is that the bread is a little tough, and it's thick so you really have to squish it down in order to bite into it. 

It's a small shop and I can only imagine how crowded it gets during normal lunch hours, but they are very efficient with taking orders and putting the banh mi together - I was in and out in less than 5 min, even with 4 people in front of me. There are only two very cramped window seats, so I would recommend bringing it back home or to work. This place is cash only so come prepared!
author: KC W.

description: Sandwiches are less than $4 each, come on. Simple menu, and no frills shop. In and out in less than five minutes if there's no line. Since I've had their sandwiches a few times now, the only gripe I have is that they are inconsistently made. My most frequent visit, I ordered 2 sandwiches. One was loaded with 10-12 chili slices and the other had 4 (yes, I counted).  i understand why this happens because during the lunch rush, the sandwiches are literally slapped together like it's nobody's business. The lady in the back was rude when I said I pre-ordered on the phone and she said still must wait like everyone else. Huh? Then why pick up the phone. Didn't even ask for my name or number, just hung up after saying OK to my order.  Anyway, there are plenty of banh mi sandwich shops to explore in a couple of blocks radius.
author: Dan F.

description:
when you mention "Saigon Sandwich" to a SF native, you'll hear, "that place is so good!"
came here, and there was already a line out the door, but it definitely goes by fast. 
Fresh bread and these ladies are generous. 
I got the combo, which comes with fancy pork (which is that sliced thing you see that comes in a log at supermarkets), grilled pork, and pate. The lady loaded my sandwich with pate and pickled veges. 
I had to cut my sandwich in half so that I could even bite into it! 
As I was picking at my sandwich, I found a nice, healthy piece of black hair. I'm blonde. Can't be mine.
I would have asked for a replacement, but since this is such a "mom & pop" type of place, I opted not to.
Otherwise to my fun, Cracker Jack surprise- the sandwich was really good, with really delicious, home made, house,  brown/ buttery sauce.
author: Maria C.

description:
I love their sandwiches, BUT ---

Sometimes chicken means pork.

You can ask for 4 chicken sandwiches and one or two of them will be pork.  This has occurred on several occasions so far.  I'm not sure why this happens but I have a simple theory:  they're running low on chicken, but there's enough pork left to make all the sandwiches and help who's next while additional chicken meat is being prepared.  Or possibly they want to conserve their supply of chicken because it costs more than pork?  

I don't really know, but I know pork when I eat it.  It's ok, I'm not a big complainer and have no religious or other reasons keeping me from eating pork, but it should be known to anyone who does have holdups with the pig meat. 

Ok. Now that that's out of the way, this joint makes the best Vietnamese sandwich I've had and there are plenty to chose from in SF.  Love the raw, hot peppers bringing the heat, nicely in contrast to the sweet shredded carrot.  The meat is always fresh due to the steady business throughout the day and the glaze (or whatever it is) sets up like a sweet barbecue condiment in the bottom of a more than decent, quarter french baguette.  Sometimes that bread is chewy but usually with a bit of crispness.  You get crunch, tanginess, chew and both kinds of heat all in one sandwich.  Many sandwiches are far more plain for more money.    

The neighborhood can feel a little shady.  This comes from a born and raised SF native.  That stretch of Larkin, Polk, Eddy and Ellis always felt that way.  Like something was going down nearby, or was about to.  If you feel unsafe in that kind of setting, bring a friend or two.  The payoff is a great sandwich.

As I typed this, I just finished a Saigon sandwich (chicken..) and have another in the fridge awaiting a test for the other white meat.  But when it's time for dinner, I'll eat it either way.
author: Jackson B.

description:
Came on a Saturday afternoon and was glad there was no wait. It's a simple menu that's cheap and executed really well.

Of course I opted to get their combo. The meats were good and the bread was the right amount of crunchy exterior into that soft bite. What makes their sandwich great is probably the generous amounts of pate and that mayo based spread. Like some people said, definitely great to eat that day but not great for saving in the fridge. 

A couple tips: It's cash only if you're not prepared. There was a decent amount of metered parking when I went but you might be forced into a garage during the busier rush. Also in typical Tenderloin fashion, watch out for some of the homeless crazies around. One happened to bum rush the tip jar with $2, as the ladies behind the counter busted out their taser to no avail. 

To the contrary of my personal friends and many Yelpers, I don't think this is the uncontested best banh mi in the Bay, but I will say it's a contender. Would definitely come again for a quick bite if I'm in the area.
author: Dave N.

description: I love this humble, fast, convenient, no-frills place. I like to get the combo banh-mi and it's a very wallet-friendly $4.75. Fresh produce on sandwiches and tasty.  I go as often as I can, or when I happen to be carrying cash since it's cash only.
author: Sally M.

description: The best thing about their sandwich was that it was loaded with pate. Other than that, it was pretty average. Lots of pickled carrots but little pickled radish. I prefer when those veggies ae more bitter too. The sandwich is large and they use softer bread rather than the long harder one (I like both types). The pork was a little dry. Overall, it's good but not something I will crave.
author: Phi N.

description: Trying to eat healthy, so having the roast chicken. However there are Soo many people ordering the roast pork.
author: Rowland W.

description:
$4.00 for roast chicken, roast pork, meatball pork, fanci park, pate

$4.75 for steam pork and roast pork and specialty combination

Their sandwiches are super small so I decided to leave and go to my go-to spot only a block away from there "Lees Sandwiches". Lees are cheaper at $4.50 for a Specialty sandwich and their sandwiches are a lot bigger then this place.
author: Rick H.

description: Everything you would expect a delicious Bahn mi to taste like. They packed the sandwich way more than any other place I've been too and add a gracious amount of pate. The baguette is super crunchy which is a plus for those who like that extra crunchy outside and soft inside. So good and fresh tasting! I normally don't like jalapeños but they were so fresh and gave the banh mi a great crunchy flavor :) Would definitely make the trip in the shady areas of Tenderloin to eat this again and again!!
author: Kimberly S.

description: Been coming here for a while now. $3.75 total for most sandwiches. Its a pay and eat somewhere else type of place but you could eat there only if you have less than 3 people due to them having only 2 seats and a small seating area. I got the roast chicken and tofu. Both are decent for the price.
author: Wesley K.

description:
This was the very first thing my boyfriend and I ate on our trip to San Francisco because it was fortuitously located a block away from our hostel. It is definitely a hole in the wall- small and undecorated, with Asian snacks lined up on the counter and a menu with all of six items on it.
I got the grilled chicken sandwich. For the amount of food, the price is absolutely rindonkulous. Only $3.75 for this super thick, super juicy, veggie filled sandwich. I love how generous they are with their meat and cilantro.
There was no line when we got there, but one quickly started forming behind us so I'm guessing this place gets pretty packed.
Definitely a solid place for banh mi.
author: Jordyn Yian C.

description:
I love their marinated tofu Bahn Mi.
I specifically booked a room at the Phoenix so I could have one for breakfast.
author: Michael D.

description: I was around the area for jury duty and found this place surprisingly good. Plus it's only $4. CASH only though
author: Donna D.

description: It's a pretty authentic place but all the rave reviews need to be set in context of its good for a lunch snack but don't go overboard. It's not the holy grail people!
author: James T.

description:
Listen to the reviews and don't be fooled by the neighborhood and looks of the place. The food is where it's at.

I had to walk a while to get there through a scary neighborhood and I wasn't sure if the walk was worth it. It definitely was! This is probably the best Bahn Mi you can get, if not, It is definitely up there in terms of quality and freshness!

The owner and workers of this place were extremely nice! They made sure I didn't have anything I didn't want in my Bahn Mi and definitely cared for their customers. Every bite of this amazing sandwich was flavorful and juicy. The meat was so tender and you can taste the freshness of the condiments.

Did I mention it costed $3.50?! What more can you ask for? I would definitely come here again! If this place was a walk distance from where I live, I would most likely grab lunch here every so often.
author: Jackson G.

description:
Very good Vietnamese sandwiches in a small hole-in-the-wall place.  You have to get here through the Tenderloin area, so just make sure to be safe.  But the actual shop is safe and with good food.

The 2 ladies working there are very nice, not super fluent in English but good enough.  There are only about 6 different types of sandwiches for you to order so it's not that hard.  I enjoyed the combination sandwich which has the pate, roast pork, and ham.  They really stuff these sandwiches with a lot of meat!  

The taste is very good, the portion is good, and I liked the bread they used.  It's $3.75 - $4.25 for a sandwich.  So, I've had cheaper Vietnamese sandwiches before but you do get good quality and portions here. 

It was delicious and easy to order. Don't come too late, because they can run out of bread.  People know this is a good place to come get their Banh Mi craving satisfied so you should check out what it's all about.
author: Matt K.

description:
Wow!! Talk about the perfect home-comfort hearty delicious sandwich. Much respect and love to the Vietnamese and French fusion that brought about the Banh Mi. 

Everything is delicious here -- as in all 4 menu items. I definitely recommend the Combo Banh Mi that has chicken, pork, and pate. Or just the Chicken Banh Mi. Or both! For $4.75/ sandwich -- you should just get two or three or more! Chicken is sweet and juicy, almost like teriyaki. Baguettes are toasted beautifully. Pickled carrots and garnished are refreshing, sweet, and tangy. 

The ladies here definitely mastered their Banh Mi craft!! It's amazing!
author: Ellen W.

description: One word, AWESOME!!! Only 6 min walking from my hotel when I was in town, and the price is great! The ladies working here very nice, will definitely come back next time.. 5 stars for sure...
author: Ky Anh N.

description:
Pork juice mixed with mayo dripping into my lap. Mayo smeared around my mouth. Crumbs all over the car seat. Dirty hands. Tons of crumpled napkins. Kind of like a Carl's Jr. commercial....'cept no supermodel. More like the eating experience of a bombtastic banh mi sandwich from Saigon Sandwich--so good, it'll be eaten before you can even drive away. 

Despite a line, the husband and I waited no more than ten minutes to get our sandwiches due to the super fast assembly process - one lady takes people's orders through the whole line and the two other ladies start punching sandwiches out as she calls the orders back. Because of this, it's really hard to customize a sandwich (almost frowned upon really). Just make sure to add the pate as it doesn't come standard with the regular chicken or pork. The banh mis are made with juicy meats, fresh crunchy bread, not-too-sweet pickled veggies, Viet mayo, cilantro, and a way-too-spicy-for-me green pepper. $3.75 per sandwich was enough to fill me up for the rest of the day. 

It is in the Tenderloin so be wary of those around, like the vagrants passing through with soiled pants bumming for change. Cash only. This is a grab-and-go kind of place despite the two seats by the window.

Top ten in SF for delicious cheap eats!
author: Jan P.

description:
I live for their fanci pork w/ patè banh mi. 

The bread is a perfect consistency- not too crispy- and the toppings are flavored the best in my opinion. 

Just eat it! Go. Get. It. And. Eat. It. Yum!
author: Lennox B.

description:
It was late in the day and I was starving. Located just outside Little Saigon, Saigon Sandwich offers cheap fulfilling sandwiches. 

This is a small hole in the wall place where sanitation seems a bit questionable. They only accept cash and offer many other snacks and drinks in addition to bahn mis. Each sandwich is $3.75 and filled with a creamy white sauce, pilled with meat, and topped with cilantro, jalapenos, and pickled carrots. My general complaint with bahn mis is that the bread often is a little too crunchy and there isn't enough "stuff". And while bread comment still holds, these sandwiches were so large that it was hard to get a good bite! The roasted pork was also very juicy and started leaking through the paper it was wrapped in and the paper bag the sandwich was put in. That's a pretty good sign to me. However, I would suggest grabbing a lot of napkins and maybe not eating while walking. I ended up dripping on myself and struggling to take bites while walking through the TL. I think what really added to these though was that sauce, I don't know what it was, but it also really helped to add flavor. 

For $3.75 there's little else you can get to really fill you up.
author: Liza X.

description: Location of the place isn't that great food is great everything else is just disgusting from where the location is to how the inside is Pretty Dirty not sure what thier score as far as city guidelines otherwise great food
author: Meishi M.

description: We got the roasted pork, xiu Mai, and roasted chicken all with pate. My bf and I really like it. Way better than most sandwich shops in San Jose. The meat is flavorful and moist. Def going to stop by here more often for my future hikes in sf!
author: Tram T.

description: Legit bánh mì. Good pâté and the place seems to be run by this older Vietnamese couple. Bread was a little hard but as a whole it hit all the right notes for a decent price for the area
author: Henry T.

description: Their banh mi is delicious! I recommend getting the combo.
author: Vicente E.

description: I was mildly skeptical about Saigon Sandwiches, but, I decided to go there immediately after checking into my hotel, which is just around the block from their location in the Tenderloin. It was 2:30 in the afternoon and I walked right up to the counter. Ordered the roast pork. It was all that people say it is. That combination of pickled vegetables, roast pork, crispy roll, cilantro, jalapeno, and what I hope is spicy mayonnaise, was extraordinary. You would be hard-pressed to find a better sandwich, whether it's at Carnegie Deli, or greasy Tony's. And, I think it was moderately healthy. For $4, a great value.
author: John S.

description:
YUUUUUGE & delicious sandwich for $3.50 (regular) or $4.75 (combo).  Yum!  What a find.  Perfect for pre-show, on-the-run dining.

Sketchy neighborhood - I went during the day and felt safe.
author: Doreen S.

description: Best price banh mi in a while!!! Tried of paying $10??? .... Saigon Sandwiches are all $4.00. Super fresh produce.   Perfectly crunchy baquette.   Tofu was nice and crispy not soggy.   My friend enjoyed the roast pork completely.   I will be back to try the roast chicken or the pate,  maybe together!?!?    Highly recommend SS!!!  Do one item and do it well!!!!
author: Molly A.

description: There's a reason SS is so popular, it's a great sandwich for a few dollars. Chicken, pork or the combo - you can't go wrong. In San Francisco, any place that has a line out the door is worth the wait.
author: Delta M.

description:
cash only
roast pork 
sauce not vegan
vegans, there is no vegan shit
legendary for a reason
you don't know bahn mi til you know saigon sandwich
author: Troy R.

description:
I just realized I haven't updated this review since the past couple loser experiences.  It has gone downhill with the new menu board a couple years back.  I remember having the wife run in and getting 4 sandwiches, all "NUMBER ONE"S".  Number one use to be dac biet, it should be dac biet, fancy pork, headcheese, ham and pate but it changed, we got 4 roasted chicken sandwiches, WTF.  I think the American folks jacked up this place so bad that they had to change dac biet number one into roast chicken.  Hella whack.  I have been eating banh mi since elementary school with little paris in chinatown.  This stuff ain't new to me, but having roast chicken be number one pisses me off.  My friend last week went and got a sad ass looking sandwich that had no pickled vegetables or mayo, WTF WTF.  He said his sando got switched.  Damn I say to myself, these foo foo Trader Joe's shopping hipsters really did a number to this once upon a time my favorite banh mi shop.  Pickled daikon, carrots, fresh cilantro and jalapenos, is the heart of a banh mi including extra dirty greasy mayo and pate, A MUST, TAKE NOTES***.  If your banh mi doesn't have these items together or you don't like them, just go whole foods deli and get a turkey avocado on wheat.  If Saigon allows their customers to have no veggies and no mayo on a banh mi, I just lost all respect for them.  Its not always about making money, you need to keep the pride and passion to teach the world how banh mi should be and not let them manipulated it into a subway sandwich.  I mean having roast chicken or roast pork is fine, at least include all the veggies, mayo and pate, otherwise it ain't no banh mi.  I'm done with this place.

P.S. - For the folks who eat organic, all natural, locally grown, gluten free, no MSG, NON GMO, yea you probably won't find it here and also it won't help altering your sandwich, just take it as it is.  Saigon's pate is my favorite, better than me making it fresh with chicken liver and butter at home, but guess what, it comes in a can, one of the richest flavors in the world.
author: Kevin L.

description: Best Bahn Mi I've had, they have tofu, and it's inexpensive.
author: Isabel G.

description: The restaurant is really small and only had two spots to sit. Ordered at the counter and they only take cash. My friend recommended the combination sandwich that had pork, chicken, and patay, which was a great choice to try as a first sandwich cause I tried all the fillings.
author: Amina B.

description: Saigon Sandwich is the king of ALL Banh Mi places in SF. They can't be beat. Their bread is second to none. However, they don't have all the ingredients for a true Banh Mi Dac Biet (Combination Banh Mi). They're missing the ham! Either way, this is the spot you need to go to satisfy Banh Mi cravings
author: Brian L.

description: This place was amazing. Got a roast pork sandwich and added siracha. Will totally come back here before I leave town.
author: Adonis W.

description: The combo sandwich is super tasty. Don't expect any pleasantries from the staff. Prices are super low, lines are incredibly long.
author: Bonnie B.

description:
No longer the best banh mi I've had. Still pretty good and better than average. Bread is inferior to a couple other places I've been. Not as fluffy or tasty as some others. Sauce that is in the chicken banh mi is way too salty. I'd recommend the meatball or roast pork options instead. 

Veggies are still very fresh and service is always super efficient.
author: Sean B.

description: The bread is excellent, the vegetables are crisp and fresh and the meats (I've had the pork and the chicken) are uniquely seasoned and very flavorful.
author: Russell M.

description:
So good, no line at 11:30 am, no need for details, even the bread was hot!

Fast and friendly service.

I can't wait to go again. I'm stuffed for $4.25
author: Michael B.

description:
First off, a sandwich in SF for $3.75?!

But not only that, a FREAKING AWESOME sandwich in SF for #3.75?!?!?!

My boyfriend kept talking about this place as his favorite banh mi place and I hadn't gone until he finally took me there. The meat with the pickled carrots/radish was so amazing! I'm personally not a fan of cilantro or peppers so I opted those out. I think if the bread was just a littttle bit less hard and thick, I would have found this absolutely perfect. But for now, this is as close as a perfect banh mi can get

Oh and try those desserts in a cup too! We got the mango one with some boba-ish pearls inside. It wasn't too overly sweet, it was just right
author: Angela W.

description:
THE BEST BANH MI IN SF!

The sauce is extremely flavorful, sweet with umami. Their mayo is delcious, decadent with a touch of sweetness. It pairs so well with whatever filling you choose. Their tofu banh mi is the best! The tofu is soft and has so much flavor. It's cheap and quick. Definitely ranks number one for me!
author: Tina Y.

description: The best saigon sandwhichs in the city! Very small location, no seating and usually a line but for $4.00 and sweet heaven in your mouth its all worth it!
author: Kill K.

description: All the other reviews raving about this place are true. This place is as legit as they come. Try the combination (Thit Cha Pate) for  $4.75.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Value: 5*
Taste: 4.5* Good pate and BBQ pork 
Fast service, the long line moves fast. These ladies have it down!
author: Sophia L.

description: Small Vietnamese joint in the city! They have great sandwiches and the menu is basic.
author: Mylo D.

description: Just the way a Vietnamese sandwich should be! Good ratio of meat, to veggie ratio with a good bread to hold it all together. Lots on flavor and pate! They don't skim you with the ingredients like other places do these days. I had the combination and my bf had the chicken which was surprisingly very good as well. There was no line when I came on a Sunday morning, which was great!
author: Judy N.

description:
Delicious banh mi! Special combination pork with pate is always my go to banh mi order. I really loved this place for the fresh flavor, the speediness, and the good price. 

One star knocked off for lots and LOTS of cilantro stems without leaves in the sandwich. I picked out a forest of stems before I could eat it, but otherwise great!
author: Jen B.

description: Awesome Bahn Mi sandwiches. I really liked the chicken the best.  Really excellent value and the bread is to die for.  Just take it to go though. There's no room to sit in there.  This is where you go for an awesome deal on totally legit vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Jason B.

description:
My first time here... not going back either!

From seeing at the line here the last time I walked past, I wanted to give this place a try and see what the hype was about!
- The bread is the wrong kind- it should be a crusty oval shaped  with very soft center. Here they use a real baguette bread that's too firm and gives it the wrong taste.
- I ordered a roast pork with mayo and pate - this is a very typical kind any street vendor in Vietnam can do... here it doesn't have the correct flavor of a grilled or roasted pork - no flavor (marinade is wrong or missing)! 
Plus, it seems to be steamed, it has a chewy texture!
author: Dan S.

description: I think this place is a bit overated as I've had my share of banh mi  sandwiches throughout my  life.  I had the special combo sandwich and it was merely ok. The only thing that this place has on lock is the price. However I'm not sure if it justifies being harrassed by the sketchy people in the neighborhood, avoiding the random pieces of feces on the sidewalk, and being paranoid about whether your car is going to be broken into.
author: R B.

description:
I had a lunch date with my buddies Salty P and Vegg Mosby at Saigon Sandwich on a sunny weekday afternoon. 

You already know Vegg Mosby from our time at Would You Believe (aka McClaren's), but there are 3 things you need to know about Salty. 

1. Salty loves to play volleyball.
2. Salty loves to look at girls who play volleyball.
3. Salty might not even like volleyball, he just goes for the girls (pending verification).

And that's why Saigon Sandwich is the perfect place for Salty. 

To start, a Viet Sandwich here is packed with nutrients, ideal for a volleyball player. The chunk of BBQ pork has enough protein to build those calves necessary for a fiery jump serve. The toasted baguette provides the carbs needed for that 5th set game point situation. And of course, the spicy jalopeno is sure to give Salty the jump to dive for a crucial loose ball. Forget the gatorade, pack a Saigon Sandwich in your duffle! 

Saigon Sandwich is also perfect for Salty because the whole sandwich only costs $3.75. Yeah, that's cheaper than a Subway foot long. That means Salty can save more of his dollars for when he takes one of the volleyball gals to a fancy date. This is especially important since taking them girls to Mickey D's may result in a spiked volleyball straight to his face.   

Sure, the sandwich can be a bit dry and the pork kind of bland, but think of all the benefits that Saigon Sandwich brings to Salty. It replenishes him as a volleyball athlete AND it keeps his wallet from depletion on a date with a volleyball girl. The benefits most definitely outweigh the cost (esp since its only $3.75).

Me and Vegg are gonna each grab a vegan Saigon Sandwich to watch Salty play volleyball one day. And if Salty really only likes volleyball for the girls, we'll grab him a sandwich and he can join us on the bleachers #MorganBeck
author: Ringo M.

description: Best banh mi sandwich. Special combination is only $4.75. Roast chicken is only $4. Crispy baguette, with pickled radish and carrot. Tastes authentic. Bring cash. Also be careful. Sketchy neighborhood.
author: Alias A.

description:
OH MY GOD. I've never known about this place and I regret not learning about it sooner. I love Banh Mi Vietnamese sandwiches and this place is one of the best deals in the city.

$3.75 for a monster sandwich, why would anybody go for the "$5+ dollar foot long" when you have Saigon Sandwich. I bought the special combination, barbecue pork, and meatball pork sandwich. The combination had a delicious pate duck liver spread that just melts in your mouth. Cue the Homer Simpsons "Donuuuuts" drool. This place is THE BOMB.

And the sandwiches are HUUUUUGE (in my best Donald Trump impersonation). One sandwich is enough to fill up most people - I was so excited I pounded back TWO like a pig.

This is in walking distance to my work - my new "go to". They've got two janky little chairs you can sit in and cram your sandwich in, but this is really a "to go" place though.

If you can't take spicy heat - watch out for the Jalapenos. I love them though.
author: Doug R.

description:
OMG. Their sandwiches are both delicious and cheap. 

I ordered the roasted chicken sandwich and roasted pork before. Anything you order will be a definitely hit. You really can't be hating this place since you pay less than $5 for a great lunch. So filling and large sandwich (though I do wish they cut it in half). Otherwise, no faults! 

Protip: just go.
author: Nina Y.

description: Amazing flavors of the veggies, shredded pork's brilliant. Very reasonably priced.
author: Cristopher K.

description:
HOLY HUGE BANH MI! These were probably the heaviest banh mi's I have ever held.

Street parking. Located in the sketchiest locations. Cash only. Don't expect great service, order, pay, get your food, and leave.

Roast Pork - $3.75 - Pork was nicely cooked but the flavor gets boring after you eat a few bites.  

Special Combination - $4.25 - Excellent pate and Vietnamese cold cuts. The roasted pork adds that roasted meat flavor. The sauce was creamy and sweet. Great mix of flavors and textures. One of the best combo banh mi's I have had in awhile.
author: Kevin W.

description: I got the tofu Banhmi. Friend got chicken. Sandwiches: great. Prices: even better. Lady working  the register: super sweet with lotsa smiles. Not in the best location but worth the trip.
author: Pattie K.

description:
Seeing all the 5 star reviews for this place, I feel like I'm the black sheep for giving just three. I was so excited to eat here during my trip to SF and I had pretty high expectations from the raving reviews. But sadly, they weren't met :-/

My friend and I got the roast pork and roast chicken for a total of $8. Super cheap! I took my first bite but it was just the bread part which was a bit chewy and didn't have a particular taste. I eagerly took my second bite with the meat but was a little disappointed again. The meat was also a bit chewy and wasn't juicy/flavorful like I expected. The veggies were pretty good though. My friend loved it so it was really just personal preference.

Everything is to-go since there is no seating area. Go early because there will be a long line. But they prepare the sandwiches rather quickly so you won't wait too long either way.

I haven't tried that many banh mis before so I'm planning to restore my faith in them. But probably won't be returning here to do that.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This place as seriously gone down hill. I think they changed their bread vendor or recipe. It lacks the classic texture and taste. It used to be crispy and crunchy on the outside and still fluffy on the inside. Now the ratio is different and there's less breading or something. There's definitely a difference noted on my last few visits. It's still a cheap eats but quality has definitely seen better days.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
At $3.75 per sandwich, I'm not sure I can complain about anything. The place is incredibly small, and their ordering system is strange, but it's a quick place to get your banh mi fix in during lunch. It's not located in the best of areas, but then again, what great hole-in-the-wall is?

**CASH ONLY**
author: Brie R.

description:
The best bahn mi in the city! I only wish they were open til 6p so I could get a sandwich after work if the craving hits! The last time I was able to get a sandwich was during jury duty last year.

I normally get the Special combination ($4.25) or Roast chicken ($3.75) with or without pate added. The roommate typically gets the Roast pork ($3.75). The bread is the perfect consistency. Their veggies are nicely pickled. Perfect amount of meat and pate to veggie ratio. Squeeze some sriracha on it and I have the perfect Vietnamese sandwich. Yum!

Now if only I could convince them to stay open later so I can get my bahn mi fix any time I want!
author: Elena N.

description:
Crunchy and delicious. What more could I ask for in a sandwich!?

$3.75 for all the sandwiches. There's roast chicken, roast pork, siu mai, pate, and fanci pork. Now.. fanci pork sounds "fancy" but really... it's just a white slab of meat.

I got lucky. When I got there, no line; when I left, the line appeared. Sandwich was prepped quickly. They give a really generous portion. Even eating 1/3 of a sandwich, I was full!!! I think my favorite was the roast chicken and siu mai. The roast pork tasted a little plain in my opinion but nevertheless, they were all delicious. SOOOOO coming back for more.

BTW, the 31 stops half a block away. So if you are taking the bus, take that and be careful! So many homeless and crazies around.
author: Benita M.

description:
$4 Banh Mi Dac Biet was a great lunch decision. Baguette was perfectly toasted. Crisp, crunchy on the outside,  lightly mayo-ed on the inside. Not dense like most banh mi breads and there was just enough pork to complement the carrots and cilantro.

It was fulfilling and 4 bucks well spent!
author: Carolina S.

description: Looking for an authentic version of your favorite Banh Mi sandwich? Then this tiny shop is your next stop. Great toasted crispy bread, well seasoned pork and meatball, spicy jalapeño along side tangy carrot and rich mayo goodness -- and for $4!!?? Amazing.
author: James W.

description:
Favorite banh mi in California. I always make time to come to tenderloin to get my banh mi fix when I visit SF.

I recommend the roast pork, very flavorus. Has juicy meat, topped with the usual garnish like jalapeño, cilantro, pickled daikon and carrots.

The line was out the door but the line moved fast. Good sign the place is yummy. Only thing missing are seats for restaurant but the sandwiches make up for that.
author: Albert M.

description:
Walking from Phoenix Hotel, Saigon isn't as far as I thought it would be. Just a few hundred steps and a few turns ,stops and maybe a couple of demanding requests from a friendly neighborhood local who lives just on the side of Saigon, you wonder why the TL is the only place to be to get some amazing sandwhichz.

After questioning why Saigon hasn't updated their interior yet, they make their food on the spot. On a lazy day, that's where I was, you normally find two people working. But on a busy day, you'll probably find three people. Why does this matter? It doesn't. I just wondered why this place only fit two or three people inside their place. 

There was a total of five people with me and we thought we could all barge in and find a seat. 
Noooo. There was literally two chairs, a shelf that looked like it was going to drop to the ground, and two big fridges. This place is tinyy

Since we were all small and stuff, we fit with no problems. 

Oh the food. Samichies
The sandwhices were good. 3.75 or $4 for a sandwich. Not bad right? It's pretty decent. 
However, the bread. The bread. It's hard. Think of a toasting a slice of bread and when it's done toasting, you leave it out for some time. After some time, the bread gets hard like a rock. That's what i Felt like eating when I was trying to chew into the Saigon. I wanted to dunk the sandwich in a glass of water or something to soften the bread. 

My friend suggested that I squish the sandwich down so it'll Be easier to eat. She was right. Thanks. You're the best . Squish it! Duh!
author: Tony N.

description:
Miraculously, it seemed, we arrived at 1pm on a Saturday to nary another human being. Within minutes of our arrival, an unceasing line had formed out the door. What was everyone ordering? Oh the special combo, the roast pork, or the chicken. Good signs, I'd say, as we also got the special combo and roast pork.

I'd say they were both good choices. However, an in between sandwich would be best for me. One with that delicious pate and roast pork only. Also, is it just me or is this sandwich missing that dikon that is so ubiquitous? And thank goodness there's not a lot of mayo. Yuck.

Anyway, a contender for the sandwich bracket for sure.
author: Andrew R.

description:
This is a hole in the wall Vietnamese sandwich joint.
Nothing fancy, no credit cards, inexpensive food but also filling. 

Their menu is simple. 4-5 types of sandwiches where the ladies heat the baguette and assemble the sandwiches.

They don't skimp on the vegetables nor the meat.
I ordered chicken and pork which came to $7.50.
The chicken and pork have these sauces so it can get messy if not eating at a conventional table. Don't expect to sit there and eat. There's literally 2 chairs in the tiny window seat.

I say that was a solid meal. Good amount of veggie:bread:meat.
If I was around the neighborhood, definitely may try their other sandwiches.
author: Eunice K.

description:
True test of an awesome Banh Mi sandwich...you can still taste the burn of those lovely peppers on your lips hours later.....

Saigon Sandwich is an institution. They serve some of the best Banh Mi Sandwiches for perhaps the cheapest price in town. 

For 3.75 you get an amazing roast pork sandwich on a wonderful light crunchy baguette style roll. The pork is very tender and flavorful. The veggies are super fresh and crunchy...and yes those peppers add the pop that blows the taste level of the Banh Mi off the charts.

Only downside I can see is that the lines during lunch can be crazy long. Not as long as Brenda's up the street but still long. 

If you are a germaphobe/ neat freak/ have cleanliness issues...this might not be the place for you as those amazing ladies crank out sandwiches in not the most pristine of situations. I believe gloves are optional.....I did like the crunch of that hang nail yum. Just kidding

But what the heck the city gave them a 94 in cleanliness...better than many other fancy places.

Check it out!!!!
author: David G.

description: Gotta support my Viet folks. They make bomb sandwiches at a price that can't be beat. I also like to get their ready-made tapioca desserts in the fridge. When I want a taste of home, i come here. Good on the belly, good on the wallet, good on the soul. Come here for a to-go lunch if you're in the area.
author: Mary L.

description: Great value for $4. Everything is fresh & yummy! Might have to wait a few minutes in line, but not bad.
author: Shawna G.

description:
Yummy Vietnamese sandwiches! The roast pork banh mi is delicious - tender and flavorful pork, though definitely on the fatty side.

Quick rundown:
+ Only $3.75
+ Freshly made on the spot and still warm!
+ Good portion of meat and veggies
+/- Fluffy bread, but the crust is a little chewy and I would've like it crispier
- Kind of heavy on the mayo, but that's probably just me
- Cash only
author: Jessie L.

description: Stopped by here before going to an event at Bill Graham. This place offers delicious banh mi for an amazing price for SF. I ordered two of the special combos and my bf got the steamed pork. I was not expecting to get full off of one sandwich but it was delicious. This place is cash only. There was a small line when we got there but it went pretty quick. Definitely need to come back here the next time I'm in town.
author: Lorna N.

description:
Got Roasted Chicken here and then walked across the street got a BBQ Pork from L&G Sandwich.  Saigon is not as good as L&G though it's cleaner.  

Saigon's portion is considerably smaller in term of bread, meat, and veggies compared to L&G.  If you like a cleaner place, then this is for you.
author: James G.

description: Delicious! Awesome Tofu Bahn Mi, I was amazed at the generous amount of fresh flavourful  vegetables and tofu.  The French bread was crisp on the outside and soft inside.  Bahn Mi, zico coconut water, 3 bean desert, I gave them a 20 and got 12 back.  Wow!  I came back for more.  The place is definitely a carry out, but if you are staying at a hotel nearby, an easy walk, and a must try.
author: Ajai T.

description:
Super good! So much meat. Good pickled carrots and sauce. So delicious. Vietnamese ladies making the sandwiches so you know it's good. Typically they're really quick so even if there is a line outside, it goes quick.

This is a good place to go/pick up. There's literally two chairs and a bit of standing space. My go to place for lunch when I have no idea what to eat especially given the $3.75 price.

Don't save sandwich for longer than half a day. It is most delicious when eaten fresh.

Cash only.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Finally! Heard about this place ten years ago- have driven by- meant to go in and yesterday we diid. Wow! 2000 
Helpers can't be wrong. Saigon does make the very best pork bahn mi sandwiches. The best! There are a lot of wanna bees....yes this place is a huge bargain.
author: Laurel G.

description:
My boyfriend's cousin-in-law recommended this spot because he had worked nearby and missed eating here.

The bahn mi sandwiches here are delicious. They are filling and ginormous especially since they're less than $4 each! I had the special one with extra meat on meat with lots of fresh vegetables. It was bright, colourful, and flavourful in every way. 

The actual shop is not in a great area and is super small with little to no sitting. Also, no matter who you are and how loyal of a customer, she will yell at you if you make any special requests or bother her with too many questions. But you can't help but laugh it off! 

This is the spot to hit up for a great Vietnamese sandwich especially when you spent so much already on flight and hotel to get here. ;-)
author: Janice L.

description: This place is a steal for $3.75 a sandwich. I tried the roasted chicken which comes with cilantro, pickled carrots and daikon, cilantro, jalapeno, and mayo. There's also some sort of savory barbecue sauce on it as well, but nevertheless the sandwich is delicious and if you're a big eater, you might need 2 to fill you up. As a heads up, it's cash only and there's no restrooms nor places to sit. I'll definitely will be back to try the roast pork and fancy pork!
author: Anderson H.

description:
This is one of our favorite spots to stop
At when we're in the city. I usually get the tofu sandwich and add jalapeños to it. Their ingredients are always fresh and I've never been disappointed. The place is small and parking isn't ideal. So we always take our sandwiches to go.
author: Shakila H.

description:
It may have been serendipity, but on the way back from getting sandwiches from here for my department i noticed an email from Time Out San Francisco naming this #1 of the top 10 Banh Mi places in the city. They clearly.

Everyone was raving about them at the coffee machine or the restroom when meeting up througholut the afternoon. Our most popular picks from everyone were the Roast Pork and the Combo with the Pate.  I had the combo with the pate and either that or the straight fancy pork pate is the way i'd go in the future..which i hope there will be!!

If placing a phone order, be simple and concise or have someone who speaks Vietnamese.
author: Betsey T.

description:
Maybe I shouldn't be getting Asian food since I'll be going to Asia next week for a 6 week vacation through Hong Kong, Singapore, Angkor Wat, China, and South Korea, but gosh darn the sandwiches here are just so good and so cheap!

The lady behind the counter looks like my Grandma, so I'm happy to wait.

The sandwiches are a bargain at $3.75, and they are jammed packed with fresh carrots and fixings, and for a little extra, I always add the pate.

Love the pate.

Be prepared for a long wait. I've been here at 2pm, 3pm, etc...and there's always a line...and some homeless people outside spanging for change.

Average wait time is usually 15-25 minutes. 

For me at least.
author: Jack R.

description:
The banh mi is cheap and decent. The bread isn't made in house, instead being delivered. I'm not sure if the delivery is daily, as I've only seen the truck once despite living just a block away.

No seating available.

They're cash only, which is a huge negative in my book and always makes me suspicious of shady things. Being cash only is just burdensome for customers and unsafe for the restaurant especially given their location. 

They tend to be pretty skimpy on the meat for options other than the combination, which has several types of meat. There are 3 other banh mi stalls less than a block away, so I wouldn't bother waiting in line here.
author: Brandon K.

description: I took the BART into the City in search of the best Bahn Mi sandwich in San Francisco. Saigon Sandwich is in a rough part of the city so be prepared to step over urine soaked sidewalks and the occasional hypodermic needle if traveling on foot. In route I was offered "Rock" and "the kind" by exuberant drug peddlers.  I was also offered "a date" by a scantly clad woman. I safely and eagerly arrived at Saigon Sandwich to find that it is cash only.   This initially presented an issue as I had spent most of my cash in route with my new "friends" . After cashing up I returned to belly up on a Pate and Roasted Pork Sandwich. Saigon Sandwich has few seats, so I ordered my food to go. This  establishment was clean, the workers friendly and hardworking.  The sandwiches were $4 per, and the bag the cashier handed me was nice and heavy.   I will certainly return to Saigon Sandwich. Their Bahn Mi Sandwiches are more addictive than the crack being offered on the surrounding neighborhoods streets. So good. If I lived in the city that would be my go to lunch spot.
author: Thaddeus T.

description: Try the grilled pork sandwich! So good and everything is fresh and prepared there. It's a grab and go sandwich place so don't expect to sit there, but take it with you and sit in front of the Asian museum and enjoy the view of the surrounding building.
author: Angel  G.

description:
Although This is the hands down spot in S.F. to get close to original Banh Mi's I would have to say that if you are a tourist then stopping by here and getting a sandwich is a must even though they raised their prices from $3.75 to now $4 for topping and $4.50 for more than one topping, ie their combination or if you want more than one type of meat or additional thing on your sandwich !
By the way if you're wondering my go to is the half pork and half pate sando
author: Food F.

description:
Damn dude, damn.

Was like I never had a real bánh mì before; the đac biet (combination sub) blew my mind.

Tiny little sandwich shop w a couple of old Vietnamese ladies getting down to business. You better know what you want before-hand, their system is inefficient and the menu doesn't reflect what sandy's are the best.

Just get the combo - it's fatty, and moist, and has tons of meats you won't be able to name.
author: Grayson K.

description:
I know I'm going to be an outlier here, but I'm not a huge fan of this bánh mì.  Per the usual, I went with the combination pork (the "special combination") - while it was definitely good, I probably won't be going back.

First, the "restaurant" (take-out counter, really) is in a pretty terrible neighborhood.  The things I saw at 2pm on a Monday were pretty disturbing - and after growing up in New Orleans and living for the past five years in NYC, I don't consider myself a wilting daisy.

Second, the bread is WAY too heavy.  You need serious jaw strength to get through this, and the fillings are completely overwhelmed by bread flavor.  I don't think it's very legit Vietnamese French bread - it was much heavier than anything I had anywhere in Vietnam.

Third, there isn't enough pate or "deli meat," but there is too much of the roasted pork, which is incredibly fatty and chewy.  Also, while the veggies are good and they'll add on more for no charge, the hunks of jalapeno they use are so big as to make them practically inedible.  It was like eating the core of a bell pepper, but spicy.

On the upside, the overall flavor is pretty good, service is SUPER fast, and a really huge and filling sandwich is only $4.25 (but, as I alluded to earlier, you're filling up on bread).

Despite some positives, I don't think I'll be returning.
author: Tay H.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwich ever!!! I got the roasted pork, which was $3.75, and the lady made is in under 10 seconds I swear. The beard was toasted but still chewy on the inside while the meat was seasoned and cooked to absolute perfection. They added some sauce that made the whole sandwich stand out from any other bahn mi I've had. Definitely recommend for bahn mi lovers, this will set your standard for best bahn mi!
author: Jingting W.

description: This place is straight up the best for a good bahn mi.  Inexpensive, quick, and perfect every time.
author: Aya S.

description: I've had Bahi sandwiches all my LIFE and this top one of the best I've had! The location sucks it's small you have to pick up and go but you won't regret going out of your way for this! Simply amazing
author: Shawna J.

description: Bus down Vietnamese sandwiches for the low Pull up whenever cause there's never lag and Saigon been around so a lot of consistency!!
author: Mohit P.

description:
loved the banh mi dac biet (special cold cut). perfect meat/spread to bread ratio. 
CASH ONLY
author: Christine T.

description: Their combination sandwich comes loaded with meat and pate, it's definitely worth the money! It's a little store run by two little ladies in San Francisco.
author: Deanelle M.

description: Get the pork meatball. Bring cash. The combo pork looked and sounded good, but I only had room for one sandwich! I'll be back!
author: Gee W.

description:
I am SO glad I live nearby. Once I got home, I completely destroyed the sandwich and forgot to take a picture for my review LOL. I'm a native to the Tenderloin and I've been coming here since I was young, and they never disappoint. There are a couple of other banh mi places around (Sing Sing, Lee's, L&G), but this one takes the crown. 

It's one of the more popular shops, it's rare to not see a line hahah, but the wait is totally worth it! And plus they prep the sandwiches so fast. Most of the waiting comes from people ordering bag fulls (because it's just that good). 

If you want banh mi's, come here!
author: Vivian S.

description:
I was leaning between 2 and 3 stars here, settled on 2. I think this was probably one of the most overhyped places I've been in SF.

The raves I've heard and seen in reviews are that you get a lot of quantity and that the ingredients are fresh. Huh? Am I missing something? Bro, if you're here you're in the tenderloin and surrounded by at least 5 other banh mi places. They all have fresh vegetables. They're all crazy cheap. Let's dissect just why this sandwich was not well executed

Yes, there was a lot of meat in this sandwich, unfortunately, it was matched by either not a lot of flavor or poorly executed flavor. My typical banh mi order at any sandwich place is a grilled pork and/or BBQ pork, and a traditional/house special (usually headcheese or pig ear, ham, and pate). The worst of these here was the BBQ pork which literally tasted like it was smothered in a bad American BBQ sauce (bad as in super pronounced taste of ketchup). The meat was so soggy it drenched the bread in minutes, defeating the point of using fresh crisp baguette.

This in addition to my first experience here, where in the mid afternoon they ran out of bread and asked if any of us in line would go buy them bread from Lee's. Save yourself the disappointment and go to L&G across the street, which is far better. I'll be reviewing them shortly
author: Neal B.

description:
Their sandiwches are usually very good, no complaints on that front.  They're cash only and I get it, small family owned business in the TL, not a shocker.

I order a large order from them for a conference I was organizing, I called it in by phone. In all fairness I did only give them a few hours of notice so the fact that they were able to turn it around was awesome of them.

The one thing I didn't like about that experience was that they wanted me to pay up front before they began the order. My guess is that they've been burned in the past by other folks who didn't pay.  I was over a half mile away, luckily not across town, but as a cash only business I would suggest  they find some other system. My order was for 50 sandwiches so I'd hate for them to lose out on that business.
author: Mike L.

description: Nice taste, fast speed for a to-go sandwich. Grilled pork is the best! Not many choices of taste but all delicious. Nice and clean.
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
This place is really busy. I waited almost 20 minutes for my sandwiches because there were customers who ordered 10+ Banh mi before me. They definitely are not stingy with their meat and stuff your Banh mi.

It sucks when you have to wait in line in the heat though.

The ladies who work here are very sweet and nice and try to work quickly. I took off one star because the bread was hard as a rock! But that's because I arrived 20 minutes before closing and there was still a line! Other than that, the pate, meat and veggies were tasty.
author: Lisa D.

description: Been here at least 3 times and I can now say their sandwiches are good.  They taste fresh and for the price,  they're generous with the filling .  Their roast pork is juicy and with gravy.  I like their meatball and combo sandwich too.  Appreciate that they still keep the price low coz other places now sell $7 sandwiches. Crazy.
author: Claire J.

description: If you want a cheap, filling, quick, delicious meal, this is the place to go to! There are 3 or 4 ladies working over here, and they are super efficient. It does get a little overwhelming at times because it feels like you are being rushed, but it's worth it. For $3.75, you get a good-sized Vietnamese sandwich. Perfect lunch spot.
author: Do P.

description: Delicious, cheap, amazing bread, fresh ingredients. Get the roasted pork or the special--you won't be sorry.
author: Nathan P.

description:
I used to love this place until today. They have a new Vietnamese lady working (bob cut with glasses) and she is rude as fuck. Never said hello or asked what I wanted. Just jerked her head as if to ask what's up. She didn't use any gloves to make my sandwich even though there were gloves right next to her. She was grabbing cash and a rag with her bare hands! I asked her, you don't wear gloves to make sandwiches? She looked at me then just turned her back to me. No response no thank you no goodbye. Rudest f'ing lady I've met in my life. You're 50 years old. Get some manners. 

The sandwiches are 4/5 at best and not worth the very poor customer service.
author: Ai N.

description:
My bf and I walked block after block, passing crazy ppl and smelly sidewalks, just to see what the hype was about. 

It was worth it. 

We both got the roasted pork sandwich and it was so amazing. My bf is Viet and he is very skeptical of Viet food in SF but, he really enjoyed the sandwich a lot. Meat was savory, vegetables was crunchy, I don't know what the hell the sauce was but I LOVE IT. And the bread was very nice with a nice crunchy crust. 

Two sandwiches cost us $7.50 iirc. It isn't that big but it is very filling.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Yes, it's cheap!
Yes, it's quick!. 
But while you may be saving a buck on the sandy, you are paying for it by having to stand around the tiny crammed cafe entrance while crackheads "entertain" you with their shenanigans. 
No, it is not the best Banh Mi. Too sweet in my opinion. 
Definitely a good bargain lunch if you are already in the area.
author: Nina M.

description:
Best.  Deal.  Ever.

For about $4, you get one hell of a Banh Mi.  For my money, the best non-gourmet version I've come across.  The bread is tremendous - they toast it and it is the perfect Banh Mi roll.  The meat is ALWAYS really good.  I can't speak to the pate, but I can tell you that the chicken, roast pork and pork meatball are ALL really good.  The roast pork is my favorite.  They've got a tofu version too.  Not my favorite, but if you're looking for a veggie option, it was good.  It's not the heaviest in terms of veggies, overall.  And, surprisingly, no cucumber (which is normally one of my favorite components of a good Banh Mi).  But, the secret is in the sauce.  It's mayo, and something else.  It is terrific.

Lines?  Yup.  But, they move quick.  There's a reason why people keep coming back.

One last thing - For $4, you'll be full.  You also might want to pick one up for later.
author: Adam S.

description:
Numbers don't lie. You really don't get 2000+ reviews and stay at 4.5 stars if you aren't a legit ass sandwich place.

We called in our 6 banh mi order ahead of time, and am I glad we did.  The line is quite chaotic.  You never know if people are waiting for their order, or if they are in line.  You kind of just have to snake your way through. And then it's pure chaos from them on, you never are quite sure if they got your order, or whose order they are working on.  They ladies at the sandwich place are just yelling at each other in vietnamese, and you're like..please let my order be next.

We arrived, and told them we had an order on the phone, and they made ours right away.  6 glorious banh mi sandwiches that definitely did not last as soon as we got to our friends place.  

I'm not sure how a banh mi can be so delicious, this is when I think that they sprinkled some crack on it.  So delicious, so out of this world.  
The meat is extraordinary, the bread is the best, and the rest of the innerds though simple, some how amaze.
author: Pauline M.

description:
I love Banh Mi's and this place is definitely on my top list for it! 

Their shop is very small and can get very crowded in there. But the ladies usually take a load of orders, then make the sandwiches. So even if the line seems endless, it goes by very quickly once they take orders! 

They dont only sell Banh Mi. They have a lot of Viet traditional desserts and drinks or snacks! So a lot of variety. Cash only though, so make sure to keep cash with you when you go here.

Here are their pricings:
Banh Mi sandwiches - $3.50 - $4.00 (no more than $4)
Most desserts - under $3-4

Most popular Banh Mi:
BBQ pork
Combination

Parking is hard to find because it's located in the Tenderloin of San Francisco, so I suggest walking here.

Cheers!
author: Inge C.

description:
Sorely unimpressed. 

But at 4$ or whatever I paid for it, I will get over it.
author: Sarah H.

description: Best Vietnamese rolls in the city and so cheap and filling too. Whenever I come I get the pork or chicken with every thing including sriracha so bomb!
author: Rita A.

description: The absolute best!Crispy delicious heaven! Had the veggie bahnmi with tofu. OMG! so so good. And so reasonably priced. I wish it was open all day. So good!
author: Ashmita V.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is probably the most popular Vietnamese banh mi shop in the city. Yet I didn't get a chance to try their inexpensive, though very deliciously satisfying sandwiches until recently. One reason I've stayed away for so long is the fact that Saigon Sandwich is in the Tenderloin.

The menu is simple: fancy pork, roasted pork, roasted chicken, pate, combination, or tofu. The fancy pork is generally my favorite and must-order meat at Vietnamese sandwich shops. But Saigon Sandwich's roasted pork was very good as well, though a bit too fatty. The meat portions are fair, but the pickled carrots and daikon radish are plentiful with a very mild acidity to them. All of these ingredients stuffed in a fresh, flaky, and crispy baguette is the prefect quick meal.

Sandwiches are priced at $3.75 as of November 2013. It's slowly increasing, but it's still reasonably-priced and affordable. The shop also sells desserts and chips you'd typically find at Asian supermarkets. The two female workers are quick with prepping your orders that even if there's a daunting line trailing out of the hole in the wall shop, you'll reach the front of the line shortly and your hunger will be quickly satisfied.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
What a steal! $4.25 for the special combo = a pork loaded, tasty banh mi. The other sandwich options are cheaper. The ratio of ingredients are perfect and on the plus, they are generous with the meat. The jalapeños aren't very spicy so it'll add more jalapeño flavor than heat to your sandwich. The best part of the banh mi is the bread. It's slightly toasty, for crunch and the bread is warm and soft inside. 

We went before 11am on a Sunday, found free metered parking just out front, didn't wait in line to order, and sat at the only seats in the joint. If you plan to pay a visit, do yourself a favor and order an extra sandwich or two for later.
author: Maya S.

description: Super quick service! The tofu banh mi was really good. I asked for extra sauce but thinking about it I probably shouldn't have. Definitely come here if you are looking for  cheap and quick food. I heard the line can get long but I went on a Sunday afternoon and I was 2nd in line.
author: Neil P.

description:
So I came back and tried the special combo with extra pate.
The pickled veggies were too sweet and the pate tasted really fishy.
Overall disappointing.
author: Heejin L.

description:
I've had banh mis in Hanoi, Saigon, Danang, Nha Trang, Singapore, Seoul, New York, and Seattle.  I have to say, I've been to Saigon Sandwich 3 times, and every time it's consistently in the top 3 banh mis I've ever eaten.
