It's at the #2 spot on my list, just under Banh Mi Huynh Hoa in HCMC (EDIT: The address is 26 Le Thi Rieng in D1 if you are ever in the area).  Keep in mind that the price point here is pretty amazing when you consider the best in Vietnam costs ~$1.50 and here in downtown SF it's $4.25.  Economically, this doesn't make sense. 

The bread is so crispy/fluffy, the ingredients are both fresh and plentiful, and the ratio of vegetables to meat to bread is spot on.   The pate itself is nice and doesn't taste cheap, and it's a nice compliment to the heat from the fresh jalapeno.  The waiting time is almost non-existent, even though they are making it fresh, right in front of you.  Other places in the area pre-make the main part of the sandwich, pop it in the oven, and throw some fresh greens on - BOO to them.  The staff here are always friendly to me, and I've been here when there's no one and when it's packed.  In any case, this is a place where if you're a regular, they'll treat you like one.

Next time I'm trying something different - maybe a roast chicken banh mi.  These are even good the next day, just pop them in the toaster oven to crisp it back up!  

Just be careful getting here, you probably should come up from Market St if you haven't been around the Tenderloin much.  Also listen out for the dude that screams hi all the time at max volume.

Try not to come at peak hour, or else you'll be waiting out on the sidewalk.  There's not a lot of space inside to maneuver once you've ordered.
author: Ben K.

description: This was my last meal in San Francisco before heading home. The boyfriend and I decided to pick something up for brunch, drive up to the Sutro towers for the view and chow down. After the first bite, it was all I can focus on. This has got to be the all time best banh mi I have ever had. It was so well balanced with the pickled veg, roast pork, pate and crusty bread. I couldn't believe it was under $5 bucks! No others can ever compare.
author: Tina W.

description:
Overpriced and tiny compared to the OC sandwiches I'm accustomed to. However, I will give the pork Sandwich points. Definite must try. Never had or seen that type of Vietnamese meat in a sandwich. Props for uniqueness. And my cousin and I hail from little Saigon SoCal

I would come here during the day - we walked and were nervous - we were babies though
author: Tiffanie T.

description:
I don't know what the hype is all about. I visited this place during lunch and was expecting to be blown away by the roasted pork sandwich everyone is crazy over. 

I was utterly disappointed. 

The bread wasn't even toasted, making it very stale. The meat was dry and too salty in flavor. In addition, their "special sauce" made it even saltier. The sandwich didn't include pickled daikon either, which is usually in a traditional banh mi.

I would not be eating at this place again, despite its unbeatable price of $3.75.
author: Amy D.

description: Best banh mi ive ever had, hands down. Also the cheapest. Only downside is since it is a small place sometimes the line can get very long at lunch, and there are no places to sit and eat. Shout out to my co-worker for telling me about this place.
author: Michael M.

description:
I usually don't bother yelping my Bahn Mi experiences because its just not that interesting.  A baguette with sour pickled daikon and carrot, cilantro, and cucumber isn't nearly as alluring as a steak, sushi, or pizza so I don't bother. Bahn Mi usually isn't even as exciting as its cousin Pho. And definitely not as interesting as the Dos Equis guy. Now he's interesting!  Check him out!  Watch clip:  http://youtu.be/L-4zfsy6rsM

And I know I'm late being that there's over 2100 reviews for Saigon Sandwich but here's my thoughts.  These Vietnamese Sandwiches are better than the rest.  I had a "combo" which I believe is Pâté, cha lua, and roast pork.  The different textures from the pâté and other meats combined with the crisp pickled vegetables was really tasty.  Not to be overlooked is the bread/baguette used here at Saigon Sandwich.  It's not a flaky, cheap bread that lacked flavor but is a solid deep gold crust with soft interior with good taste.  

Saigon Sandwich makes a Bahn Mi about as interesting as a Bahn Mi can get.  "I don't always eat Bahn Mi, but when I do I prefer Saigon Sandwich. Stay hungry my friends"....
author: Michael L.

description: A tiny restaurant, but lightning fast service. You can order a roll of toasted bread, fresh cut veggies, and tasty meat (I got roasted pork) all for $4. Not a lot of room to eat inside, but they package it up to go so it seems like a nice place to grab something in a hurry and also check off that "I ate something healthy today" box.
author: Lauren Z.

description:
I really dont think you can mess up a Vietnamese sandwich because the ingredients are so basic and delicious. Saigon sandwich tasted like Lee's Sandwich and that place is yummy as well so four stars for all of them. I came here around 10am to get take out for lunch and there was no line when I got there. Surprisingly a small line formed at that time but they get you in and out of there so quickly. We had a big order that consisted of about 10 sandwiches and even though they rushed our asses, they were able to take our order, tender our cash and make them within ten minutes. The location of the place is in Tenderloin so it totally felt sketch but thank goodness it was during the daytime.

I got the pate sandwich but since there is no meat in that, I added chicken so it cost $4. Pate is this goopy, thick sauce that adds a thick layer to the sandwich. I cannot imagine someone just ordering a pate sandwich so you definitely have to add a side of meat. Honestly, I hated that nastiness. It is some weird layer of leftover meat grinded up and compounded into paste form. I just imagine it to be the paste version of balogne cause I am almost positive the disgusting leftover body parts of intestines and animals are in that goop. My friend got the classic pork sandwich so I was able to get half of hers. I am so happy that she didnt listen to Yelp and got the pate as well. I scraped off the pate off of mine and ate the chicken. The chicken was bleh but the pork is the way to go. 

**TIPS**
1) Cash only.
2) Know your order ahead of time because they rush you like crazy.
3) NO PATE. Get the plain pork sandwich.
4) Enjoy!
author: Amy H.

description:
I'm a big fan of bánh mì sandwiches. When I found out you can get one for $3.75 in downtown SF and it was delicious, I had to check it out. Verdict, it's as delicious as they get. I ordered the Pork, $3.75. The meat was well seasoned and there was a lot of it. The carrots and cilantro were very fresh. The bread was nice, just hard enough. I will definitely go back when I'm in the area. 

** Important note - It's cash only**
author: Russell G.

description:
Hands down the original and the best banh mi with choice ingredients.  BAkers of Paris rolls with authentic Viet pickled vegs and flavorful meat.

Owner lady is so sweet and compassionate as her prices are ridiculously low - practically a charity to benefit the community.  but taste is so much better than. trendy places that charge $9+
author: J H.

description:
Highly recommended.....no no, it's horrible, you won't like it (Doubt my reverse psychology will work). The worst thing about this place is , everytime I go the line seems to be longer, lol.
A San Francisco must!!
author: Michael P.

description: Probably the best Vietnamese sandwiches in SF for the price! Service has opportunity, hence the four stars but what do you expect for a $4 sandwich??! (Btw, you don't have to be Asian or speak Vietnamese to get that amazing price!) Usually a line during lunch but moves rather quickly. Sure you can spend $10 elsewhere for the boujee service but really?! I'll deal with the attitude and save $6 for another sandwich!!
author: Nora J.

description: Pretty tasty and affordable option around Civic Center. Bahn Mi is always tasty and it's not different at this place. The only thing is that I'm not very good with spicy food, so next time I'll make sure to ask not to include them.
author: Gui K.

description:
So I went back and got the tofu and it is GREAT!  Meaty tofu hunks covered in tons of yummy sauce. It's super duper filling. Almost more filling that the pork. And people do ask for special things like, no cilantro (WTF I'll take his cilantro then, give me extra). Somehow they actually do manage to keep track while cranking out a bahn mi like every 5 seconds.

The sandwich roll was also, again, gloriously crunchy. The crunchy roll, the flavorful sauces, the freshness of the ingredients really sets this place apart. The price sends it into outer space. 

I have to try to NOT come here. I will say, "Self, today we are DEFINITELY going to check out The Chairman," which is also on Larkin, but my feet involuntarily keep walking down the street  to here... Dangit! They say, "But we want to try the pate or fancy pork this time!"
author: Cynthia C.

description:
It's simple.  They make a good, inexpensive sandwich.   

I had the pork sandwich with cilantro, carrots, jalapeños, and mayo on a fresh roll.  Once home I pulled the jalapeños and was mostly happy.  The mayo made the sandwich a bit too sweet for me, but that's a matter of taste.  But never mind.  This one very good sandwich made one very good dinner.
author: David D.

description: Simple and delicious. A prefect hangover sandwich too I live just a few door away and have been coming here for years. It's always the same  which is probably why I love it so much.
author: Andy B.

description:
Talk about cheap. There's a lot of meat in these sandwiches for $3.50, but the high score isn't for the price. I'd pay $10 and still give the same score because these are delicious sandwiches.

All the sandwiches are made the same way. Take a French baguette, then add some dressings, meat, carrots, cilantro, and sliced peppers. It's a similar concept to making an Italian sub, but with Asian flavors. The best part of the sandwich is the meat. The roast pork is mild, but is soaked in a juice that reminded me of eating a French dip sandwich. The chicken is a similar invention. The pork meat ball is "one-a spicy-a meat-a ball" that is soft and meaty. We skipped the "fanci pork" because it was drier, less-fatty, and thinly sliced compared to the regular pork.

There are two seats at a bar. Otherwise, it's food to go. We took our sandwiches to the close Twin Peaks and to the not-so-close Lassen Peak.
author: Brian U.

description:
Great Banh Mi. They are open early at 7am so that's a great time to get some fresh sandwiches with no lineup! I had the Fanci Pork (which is slices of Cha Lua I think). The bread was crusty but also chewy - such a great bread! The sauce was very tasty.

The serving size was really large and had generous amounts of meat, pickled carrots, fresh cilantro, and some slices of jalapeno.

Highly recommended.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
If it were just about value I'd give it five stars but unfortunately there's other factors to consider.
The efficient ordering process has slipped in to a rude yelling at "what you want".
Sandwiches look hurried and slopped together.. 
They still draw a decent crowd but I believe it has diminished a little do to quantity overcoming quality.
Finally, there's a better place to go a half a block away.  Where you will find the same value with a smile and a very handsome sandwich.  It's also my opinion that  they overall taste better too.
To top it all off, they also have a customer loyalty reward program, something Saigon does not.
author: John W.

description:
I don't even want to know how this place can charge $3.75 for a huge meat heavy sandwich that is just maybe one of the best banh mi's in the city.  (Don't tell me either as I want to continue eating here)

There is not much to the place, Three ladies busy stuffing the sandwich in a tiny little sandwich shop.  They have a little round table on the side with two chairs, but most people order to go and be on their way.
author: Amihan M.

description:
After a long day at the Asian Art Museum where BBF and went to see the Emperor's Treasures from the Taiwan National Museum where we spent 4 hours, I was really hungry.  Unfortunate for BBF, I tend to read everything about the exhibit and ooo-ahhh over whar I like. 

We looked over the food booths at the Pride event right outside at Civic Center and nothing really appealed to us, so I took the opportunity to introduce her to Saigon Sandwiches.  
There are only 2 seats at this tiny place and most folks buy a sandwich and head out.  

I got a pork, $3.75 (they have a couple of specials like the pork combo which cost more) and it was full of tasty pork meat with lots of shredded carrots and way too many jalapeno peppers.
The bread was light and crispy.  A homeless guy parked himself right outside the front door while folks coming out the door would drop change into his cup.  Makes me wonder why they don't tip the little ladies who make their sandwiches because the panhandler can make more in the day than the ladies at Saigon Sandwiches.

I picked up 3 more sandwiches to take home for the family and she did mess up the order and didn't give us a meatball sandwich, it was 3 chicken sandwiches.  BFF tried the pork combo which had the same pork I had, sandwich meat pork and pate'.  She was very happy with the sandwich and bought 2 more to take home to her Hubby.  I always look forward to picking up a sandwich from here when I'm in the hood.
author: Ry T.

description:
Pretty damn good sammie for $3.75.

Not the best; but pretty damn good. 

Closes too early for my liking, though.



Here's what you do:

Try your best to get in line.

Yell out what you want.

Throw a wad of money on counter. 

Transaction complete.
author: Aren A.

description: Great tasting sandwiches (big and buff too) at $4!!!The owners work super quick. It's a small place, so it's more of a grab and go establishment.
author: Vincent T.

description: Love the Bahn Mi's! Roast pork, combo and meat ball. I get it with extra pate. Yum. So good & tasty! The only drawback is that it's a very small place and crowded with long lines. It doesn't stop me from going though. Great prices. The ladies who work there are fast. Seemed unorganized at times because they don't give out a number and don't take our names. They call out the sandwiches and amount. Everyone look at each other to see who responds. It still runs smooth for them and it works. I'll definitely be back when I'm in the area.
author: Amy H.

description: Not that well lookin' but it doesn't matter. The sandwiches are delicious and cheap. Friendly staff.
author: Daniela D.

description: Huge roast pork sando for only $4. Really tasty, filling: creamy sauce, pickled carrot, jalapeño, cilantro, tons of meat. The ladies inside are chomping on bettlenut and they don't have time for pleasantries, so get your grub and beat it!
author: Robert H.

description:
I'm not sure if this is the best bahn mi I have ever had, but it is definitely very good and a great bargain in the city.

$3.75 for all sandwiches. Ordering is easy, because there are only 5 options: roast chicken, roast pork, meatball pork, pate pork, and vegetarian. CASH ONLY.

The line is long, but it moves so fast. The staff here has it down to a science, and they collect a bunch of orders at once and make everything quickly.

I have had the roast chicken and the vegetarian (tofu). Both are really good, because the proteins have been marinated and are packed full of flavor. They also stuff the sandwiches with plenty of meat, but also plenty of pickled carrots and daikon, which is my favorite.

Lots of Viet snacks and drinks also available. If you're curious, just ask around. Plenty of people are regulars and have answered our questions about what stuff is.

No seating here.
author: Alice T.

description:
Saigon Sandwich was so convenient when it was just a block from my office. But I've moved on to a new office across the Bay and I missed eating Saigon's bahn mi sandwiches. I was in the area on a Saturday and had to stop in for some sandwiches.

There was a line, but not the ones I experienced waiting in during the weekdays. We ordered a roast chicken and a roast pork.  Now that I've tried many more bahn mi sandwiches from various restaurants, Saigon's is the best that I've had. The meat is tasty and they use a flaky sandwich bun.  Though the price has inched up to $3.75, it's still worth the price for these delicious sandwiches.  

(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/saigon-sandwich-san-francisco?select=416S1cFmI3ZyHQQhnPZyjw#416S1cFmI3ZyHQQhnPZyjw)
author: Al L.

description:
+ THE FOOD
My fav!! I grew up eating this and to this day, I still think it's great. My favorite is getting the combo sandwich. I love the cha lua, pate, and other pork cuts because they're all very flavorful. The pickled veggies are also a great complement to the savory meats. The bread is nicely toasted right when you order so everything is fresh. They give huge amounts of food because you get pretty full afterwards! 

+ THE PRICES
I've seen the prices rise steadily over the years but I still remain a loyal customer. To me, it's worth the price because they give so much meat and veggies. It's a great lunch meal because it's simple yet filling.
author: Cindy C.

description:
It's true... you have to leave Sonoma County to find your quintessential banh mi.  We found it here.  Over 2,000 4- to 5-star reviews can't be wrong, right?!

My husband and I both had the combination pate.

It was everything we'd been looking for in a banh mi - price-wise, flavor-wise, and size-wise.   The pate was creamy and flavorful, the carrots, cilantro and jalapeno were fresh and crispy, the mayo had just the right amount of tang, and the meats were tender and tasty.  

I think we've created a new tradition.

Now we know where to go when the banh mi craving gets too strong.

Cash only, and no dining in, unless you're lucky (?) enough to get the little 2-seater spot right by the door.  Looks like a fairly miserable place to enjoy such a delicious sandwich as everyone is hovering over and behind you.  We walked back to the car and ate our sandwiches there.
author: Stephanie V.

description:
I love this place.  I stop in everytime I'm in the city.  Good crusty bread, and stuffed with fresh carrots, cilantro, and your choice of meat.  I personally love the roasted pork, it tastes like Viet Nam.  And for only $3.75, you get great value.

If you stop in around lunch time, expect a wait.  There is usually a line down the street from 11:00 until 12:30.
author: Richard M.

description:
when the sandwich maker spreads in the whole can of pate up in ur bread, u know u got a GOOD sandwich!

we ordered their Banh Mi Special Combination that included roast pork, cha n so forth.. I told my wife, "Wow! They spread the whole can of pate on ur sandwich.. most places will only give u ingredients equal 2 that amount of pate." .. n then I asked her, "Did u c that amount of pate spreaded on our sandwiches?" UNBELIEVABLE!

The sandwich costs like $3.75, about an inch shy of a foot, but packed w/ ingredients: cha, roasted pork, pickled vegetables, cilantro, mayo n YES! the whole can of PATE

it was so good n filled up like a BIG, AMERICAN sandwich that we came back 4 more.. y can't we have this here?
author: Johnny L.

description:
3.9 STARS!!  If you love creamy pate and a good bahn mi !  Then this is your place!!  My fave is the roast pork sandwich,  though I haven't try the other ones.. 

I heart Ba Le in Oakland b/c it's way closer than Saigon Sandwich. However,  ever since they moved to the new location- the sandwiches are not as yummy as before, still good but not a WOW!
author: Cindy C.

description: Delicious Vietnamese sandwiches for reasonable prices.  Take out only but worth the wait.  The bread is really good as well.  Try it and you will not be disappointed.
author: Ed A.

description:
BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES YOU CAN GET IN SF! It's a very small storefront in the Tenderloin and for an amazing price. 

There's only 4 or 5 choices - I recommend the pork sandwich though I've heard great things about the combo sandwich as well. Where can you get a sandwich LESS than $5. It's better than subway! 

You'll order your sandwich, the lady will write it down and then call out what you ordered - pay then. 

CASH ONLY.
author: Stephanie W.

description: I was in the area and thought that I would walk to Saigon Sandwich to get a banh mi as I remembered that this place had one of the best banh mi's around.  I was very happy to enjoy the roast pork banh mi.  It was just so delicious and fresh and authentic yet so simple.  This place really does make the best banh mi that I've had.
author: Jason G.

description:
My go-to banh mi place in the Tenderloin was closed. I've seen the Saigon Sandwich reviews so I decided to get a banh mi here and compare. I ordered one with chicken, without jalapeños. 

First, let me just say I'm amazed that the woman who took the orders is so organized! She took everyone's orders, made the sandwiches, called out the orders, and then took the money without any errors! I was afraid she'd add the jalapeños on mine since she was going so fast. That wasn't the case. 

And the sandwich was delicious! The chicken was dark meat, so it was tender. And the sauce was flavorful that went well with the pickles daikon and carrots. It was messy to eat as everything was crammed in but it was so good! The only minor complaint I have is the bread... The ends of the bread were hard so it was difficult making the first bite. But once you get to the middle, the bread is crunchy on the outside and chewy on the inside. 

The place is small with a very limited seating area. They also sell Asian snacks like dried mangoes and Yan Yan. There's usually a line but the wait isn't long.
author: Vira P.

description:
I've been spending so much of my free time in the Tenderloin these days, that you might get the false impression that I'm a streetwalker or crackhead.  

Perish the thought.  This upstanding citizen is simply cruising the streets of the 'loin in search of delicious food, and lots of it.  It never ceases to amaze me how much amazing grub is hidden amongst the tenements.

Case in point:  Saigon Sandwich.  

This hole-in-the-wall is minuscule, uninviting, drab.....

Yet it cranks out some of the best banh mi sandwiches in all of San Francisco.

For $3.50, you can have yourself a massive, generously stuffed sandwich for less than the cost of a cup of coffee elsewhere in the city -- served up by some cheerful Vietnamese ladies who barely speak English, but will eventually understand what you want if you enunciate "rrroooaaaasssttt pppoooorrrrkkkk" slowly enough.

My friend and I shared two banh mi: one with roast pork (natch), the other with meatballs.  They were stuffed to the brim with juicy, tender meat, lots of spicy cilantro, pickled carrots, and other veggies.  The bread might've been a little tough for my taste, but my friend insisted it was just right.

We were lucky enough to get there early enough to avoid any line and grab the 2 (yes, just 2) available chairs.  However, by the time we were leaving, the line was out the door and down the block.  Consider yourself warned.
author: David G.

description: Roast pork bahn mi for $3.75 is all you need to know. This place is fast, cheap, and good. I'm going to start coming here every single day for lunch.
author: Austin W.

description: I'm Vietnamese and have eaten countless banh mi's and this is ONE OF THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH I'VE EVER HAD. Get the roast pork, nice and juicy.
author: Khanh N.

description:
So good, we went back twice!

Surprisingly there were no lines when we went. We went around 8am on two separate weekdays in mid June 2015. The roasted pork was amazing! I didn't like the roasted chicken. I found it very dry for some reason. The fanci pork was delicious. The sauce they used for this was sweet and I love sweet sauce! I loved that they heated the buns and were so generous with the ingredients. Our sandwiches were filled to the brim.

Open up a location in Toronto PLEASE!
author: Ellen C.

description:
Worth the trek through the tenderloin, although last time I went I saw a guy get murdered. Well technically he was just shot 5 times before getting into a car and speeding away (hopefully to a hospital).

The pate is quite livery. Be warned.
author: Johnny C.

description: Fantastic bahn mi! Super small place a few seats mostly pick up and go. Simple menu but try their desserts. We had a coconut dessert with cendol mung beans and kidney beans. So good! The sandwich was delicious smaller but tons of filling for 4.75 (a combo) Packed with meats and deliciousness. Its in a very shady part of San Francisco though so beware.... Lots of homeless people around.....
author: Prima Z.

description: Everyone knows that this is the best lunch spot north of Market and east of Van Ness. Cheap, delicious sandwiches that you can pick up quickly even if there's a large line outside.
author: Jake F.

description:
Finally checked out this sandwich 'shop today. As I sat down and eating my Tofu banh mi, their business is seen very good compare with other two restaurants in the block and mostly crowed. Most banh mi is 3.75, + 0.25 for extra side meat. If anyone strictly vegan, please do order tofu vegan(banh mi chay) and no dressing/sauce. Also for anyone prefer healthier, do request without dressing/sauce in your sandwich. 
  Last thing, the portion is generous, huge, messy, best bang for you bucks (people still complain about it). The veggies (Đ Chua) is the best part of it because you are order a tradition Vietnamese Sandwich.
author: Minhnistah M.

description: More than amazing. It's not a fancy place, but the sandwiches are great. Low prices. My choice was Roasted pork. I definitely want to repeat.
author: Pipe P.

description:
This is arguably the best banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich) in SF. 

My go-to is the adventurous "special combination" for $4.25. A toasted baguette loaded with Vietnamese cold cuts, pate, and a creamy / sweet sauce. They also add in a bunch of pickled carrots / turnip and cilantro, so the banh mi is practically a health food, right?
author: Linda X.

description: Best pork bahn mi in the city period! Generous portions and priced nicely made by 2 old ladies! Awesomeness!
author: Miguel Y.

description: I went back again. Well, I was in town for the day and busy working, but had a colleague pick one up for me. So. Effing. Good. It really is. I dream about these sandwiches. I will never make a trip to San Francisco without going here. It is that damned good.
author: Bennett S.

description: The hype is real. I honestly think this might be the best Banh Mi I've ever had! I got the steamed/roast pork and I didn't think it was possible to stuff so much meat into one little baguette but these ladies are the real MVPs for hooking it up. I nearly didn't make it to this place but was able to stop by half an hour before my friends had to check out of our hotel- best decision I've ever made. The worst decision I've ever made was not ordering extra ones for the plane ride home :(  I don't think I will ever find another Banh Mi anywhere else that is as filling and flavorful as this one. Make sure you come with plenty of cash and take a bunch of napkins with you because this is the juiciest banh mi (is that even a thing?) you'll ever have.
author: Lilly C.

description: Cheap and fast. Meter parking readily available in ghetto. Line can be out the door but expect no longer than 15 mins. These ladies are efficient! Banh mi is good but the chicken has too much teriyaki sauce or something and the pate is pretty salty. I would recommend the steamed pork banh kit with extra veg. They make the best pickled veg here. Everything less than $5 be sure to bring cash.
author: Mindy D.

description: The tofu Vietnamese sandwich is my all-time favorite. I always ask for a little extra gravy because the gravy is poppin! I also like the chicken sandwich. Flavors are in point. It gets really busy the line tends to go out the door. The shop is pretty small. But the food is fantastic!
author: Claudia T.

description:
BOMB. AS. EFF.

There are a few banh mi places near Saigon and after trying them I can say it is the best without a doubt. I stopped by for lunch and picked up a roast pork sandwich for just $3.75. The pork, bread, and cilantro were all fresh and the meal has to be the best bang-for-buck I've seen since moving to San Francisco. 

Heads up: There was a line at lunch but it moved quickly. They are cash only but the shop next door has an ATM.
author: Eleazar V.

description: Visited SF and came here for banh mi due to their great reviews. First bite...What in the world is this??This is NOT how banh mi taste. Can't believe Denver's banh mi in Federal Ave, called Bale French Sandwiches, tastes SO much better. Their bread here is too doughy. Their Vietnamese mayo tastes awful. The special sauce they added made the sandwich SWEET and way too much pate!! Such a DISAPPOINT...worst sandwich I've ever had
author: Laura S.

description: I really like this place. Too bad it's not close to home nor work. But maybe that's a good thing. Prices are VERY reasonable, the ladies are very efficient & the sandwiches are delish! Ordered 1 Roast Pork & 2 Roast Chicken sandwiches. They even scooped out the bread, as I requested. Once I placed the order, the sandwiches were ready in about 10 minutes.
author: Luisa k.

description:
Holy Crap.  Believe the hype.  It IS that good.  It really IS that cheap.  And by "it" I mean their roast pork banh mi (toasted roll sandwich including mild peppers, cilantro and a seasoned mayo based sauce $3.75) with pate (for an extra $0.25).  Don't expect to find a seat inside here (though I did), as there are only two low chairs at a micro bar up against the window. And you may not want to eat right outside since the folks who loiter on that block of the TL may be bothersome.  

The place is tiny, as in it's only about 12 feet wide, and made up mostly of just the service counter and kitchen... plus stands with some random Asian snack products and a cooler with drinks - including three flavors of Sunkist in cans for $1 each. Based on throughput while I was there, t's 90% take out - and I think cash only.  

Quiznos, look out.
author: Aaron M.

description:
It's a really tiny restaurant with the best vietnamese sandwiches around! 
I recommend the special, dac biet.

They get really busy and the line will be out the door.
author: Lily H.

description:
We went to pick up some sandwiches for lunch today and one very long walk later we ended up with one chicken, one roast pork, and one meatball banh mi (I think it was meatball...but it was more like sautéed ground meat...like a loose meat burger).

Not a great area... but not the worst either.  

It's a little confusing and a lot cramped... Tiny space and lots of people, but these gals behind the counter, even without speaking much english, are working so rapidly that you barely notice the time waiting for the sandwiches.  

The bread was perfectly chewy, I'm talking the perfect soft and chewy roll with just that little tiny bit of crunch when you bite into the crust...  and the amount of food you get is definitely worth the very small price you pay.  

I've got to say though, I did expect a bit more flavor... I also thought there would be more pickled flavors and more spice... It was good and I would definitely go again, it just wasn't a big flavor punch if you know what I mean.  The chicken tasted a bit like teriyaki and the pork was juicy, but the "supposed" meatball was my favorite.  All of them were a bit on the sweet side.  Next time I think I will try the special combination pork.  Maybe the pate would give that little bit of flavor that I felt it was lacking.
author: Christina S.

description:
Luckily my sister recently discovered her fondness for Vietnamese sandwiches so we decided to try this spot out on our lunch date. The place is small, there are three chairs but it seems to really only sit two people... you can always take your sandwich to city hall though and eat there since it's close by (=

The lines get long, and it's a little disorganized but moves fairly quickly (cash only by the way!). 

The bread here is THICK and a little hard...that's probably my biggest gripe about the place. While the bread easily could have ruined the sandwich for me everything else was just soooo good! I got roasted pork with pate and let me say, the hype on the pate is real! My sister got the roasted chicken and I honestly preferred the chicken to the pork. The chicken is super tender, juicy and flavorful without being overly salty. 

My boyfriend being Vietnamese I decided to get him the combo to go to see what he would think of it... He said that it wasn't a combo, since it was missing pork belly but still really liked it! He said he's had better but he really enjoyed the pate and the bread didn't seem to have bothered him like it did me... however I didn't see him right away so it had been sitting in the fridge for a whole day and the bread was a lot softer than when I had it fresh. I guess this means it is safe to keep your banh mi for a day or two if you want some for lunch that week or whatever with it still being delicious if not, even better in this case! 

And okay... I'm going to be honest... I bought another sandwich to "surprise" his mom with but my boyfriend liked his so much..and I was hungry and lacking food in the house so we ate hers as well T_T_T =x =x...was just too hard to resist I guess haha. Oh well, gives me an excuse to make another trip down here!

The ladies aren't particularly nice or rude but I don't care, they get the job done.This place may be a taaaaaaaaaaaad bit more expensive than regular banh mi spots but not enough to make a difference (what like fifty cents??), I'm honestly surprised some people complained about that. Still less than $4 for a filling and satisfying sandwich so I personally would still consider it a good deal.
author: Melissa C.

description:
"Bang Me" for only $3.75!

Where else can you get a really good, freshly made, loaded Banh Mi that will fill up your belly for only $3.75? Only at Saigon Sandwich of course! I can't get over how cheap it is with so much sandwich. Every time I come here, I always order 3. One for lunch, one for dinner, and one for my sister. I love the Banh Mi Thit Cha Pate (roasted pork, fanci pork, and pate) with everything and extra jalapenos. I love how they just randomly stuff meat, pickled veggies, and cilantro inside a french roll and it comes out so consistent every time. The roasted pork sandwich is my 2nd favorite. Love their pate, its soooooo good I want to eat spoonfuls of it.

I think they ladies are nicer to you if you order in Cantonese. I've tried ordering in English one time and received totally different treatment. Hahaha! I even got short changed by them (I paid with a $20 and they thought it was a $10). I straight up told them I only carry $20 or larger bills and never carry small change and they gave me back my money. Haha! I'm still going back every time I'm in the TL!
author: Janny S.

description:
Oh, the things I would do for a Saigon Sandwich! This place has THE BEST bahn mi ever! I lived in San Jose for four years, the capitol of delicious Vietnamese eats, and this place somehow beats them all! 

The sandwiches are all between $3.30 and $4.00 (so incredibly cheap for the size) and for the quality they are definitely worth the long walk from my work through the TL! 

This week I have eaten 3 sandwiches and don't regret a single bite. nom nom nom- I'll be back very soon.

TIP: Bring cash and be sure to remember that there is no place to eat inside!
author: Stephen D.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place! 

The bread is nicely toasted, they're very generous with their pate spread, the veggies, and the meat. MMM the pate spread is my favorite. 

I usually get the special combination which comes with cha lua (vietnamese pork roll) and pork. 

All the sandwiches are less than $4! What a deal! 

There are only 2-3 seats by the window so it's best to come with the intention of bringing your sandwich somewhere else to eat.
author: Michelle T.

description:
ROAST PORK WITH PATE BANH MI (5/5):

The banh mi here changed my world view about sandwiches in general. The roast pork with pate banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich) cost only a few cash bucks and comes full of fillings and flavors.


TAKE OUT SERVICE (5/5):

Friendly smiley saigon sandwich lady, rare to find middle aged asian ladies without the menopausal face these days.

Since I couldn't hold my balls to try my banh mi after getting it from the lil take out joint, I walked to Lee's Sandwich a block down to illegally sit at one of their window counter stools and stuff myself. Jizzed so hard eating my banh mi but will remember to get water first next time because I was like dying and crying at the counter after biting into an unexpected jalapeno while staring out the window and at some frightened passerby.
author: Tian Q.

description:
How can sandwiches get better than this? As everyone can see - $3.75. Made in literal seconds. The ladies ask you if you want pate or not and then a perfectly wrapped, beautifully seasoned banh mi is handed to you. You pay (cash only) and devour. 

Okay, sure, it's in the middle of the Tenderloin. Just watch where you step and you'll be fine. We braved SF traffic multiple times to stop at this specific spot during our trip and did not regret a single minute (or bite). 

Didn't get the chance to try too many of the fillings, but the roast pork is great despite being nontraditional. And that bread crackle... the perfectly pickled carrots+daikon... the meat/bread ratio... UGHHH. Thank you Yelp for helping us find this place. It is truly amazing.
author: Irene L.

description:
The best bahn mi I have before, better than what I can get here in Oakland. Do not be deterred by the long line as the system is efficient and fast. The women who work there make the sandwiches quickly, so the wait is short. 

FOOD: I got a roasted pork sandwich, so nothing too "adventurous", but a staple of this great Vietnamese sandwich. I found the ratio of meat and vegetable to be correct, and the sandwich was really full. The meat was exactly how roasted pork should taste like. The vegetables were also tasty and right amount of cilantro to cut through the meat. Yummy yummy. 

SERVICE: There's not much to comment here. It's fast, money exchanged, sandwich in hand, out the door. 

Love, love, love this place. If I am back in Little Saigon, I will swing by! But next time, I'd try the pate or the combo. 

As always with these joints, cash only!
author: Albert H.

description: This place rocks. Great sandwiches that are filled to the brim with meat and veggies! Line is almost always out the door with a minimum wait of ~5 minutes. Always have to get their special combination! No other place around that tastes as good or packs as much stuff in their sandwiches as Saigon Sandwich. Total bargain! Personally, I would ask them to not toast their bread (sometimes it's too hard to enjoy), but otherwise a must go to destination!
author: Nick C.

description:
Perfect banh mi for a perfect price! Just... Be careful. Area can be tricky!

I go here for lunches. The roasted pork banh mi is an incredible steal at under $5. The service is quick, but this is basically a grab-and-go shop. Little to no seating, and you have to be careful, given the homeless population around the Tenderloin (oftentimes, they can be aggressive... It's sad, but just be careful and vigilant about your belongings, and find a nice charity to give to.)

The food, though, is excellent. They also have a small range of Asian pastries and snacks. 

Highly, highly recommended*!

*With the above caveats...
author: Suzanne B.

description:
This is a story about Postmates. Before you think, "Then why are you writing a review about Saigon Sandwich?", let me explain: I'm going to use Postmates to explain why Saigon Sandwich is so awesome. Postmates (delivery service in SF) is convenient, but they add a pretty ridiculous markup to anything you order. Saigon Sandwich is so cheap (under $4) that even if you get the sandwiches via Postmates and add the delivery fee, prices remain fairly reasonable! Now *that's* cheap.

Saigon Sandwiches are probably the best banh mi you can get in the city, and definitely at the best price. Seriously, this place is so cheap it seems borderline sketchy... But the ingredients seem to be of decent quality, tasty, and delicious. Hefty portions of meat, pickled vegetables, and quality French bread. Yum!

Head over to Saigon Sandwich and grab a cheap banh mi, or if you're feeling indulgent, get it via Postmates!
author: Brittany C.

description:
I love this place, but unfortunately I'm not in the area that often when it's open. Anytime I'm nearby, I try to stop by to grab a sandwich. I usually order a sandwich with pate and cha lua, but you really can't go wrong with anything here. The roast pork is also delicious!

Be aware that it is cash only!
author: Cynthia M.

description: You probably won't find a meal for anything cheaper than this in SF. I got the roast chicken sandwich, which came to 3.75 total (they include the tax on the price on the menu, which I greatly appreciate). Because it is so cheap and filled me up, I gave it 4 stars. The taste was ok, it was a bit too rich for me. The sauce on the meat overpowered all the fresh components of veggies that are so essential to a bahn mi, so it was not the best Vietnamese sandwich I've had. Some tips: go right before they're closing for a quick dinner, there was no line there when I got there. Also tell then to put some extra veggies in!
author: Emily H.

description: Totally my favorite place for VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES in the bay area. There is always a line but the ladies there are quick. Must get their SPECIAL COMBO, loaded. Which they call it the Banh Mi Thi Cha Pate. Combo steam pork, roast pork and pate. They serve it with so much pate too. OMGoodness!! The best sandwich ever!
author: Sandy B.

description: The roasted pork is my go to but chicken is also delicious. Staff is friendly
author: Brock F.

description:
The banh mis here are soooooo freaking good - totally worth the hype! $3.75 for a sandwich with substantial meat and pickled veg. Definitely coming back to try all the different kinds!

Only downside is that it's kind of in the ghetto.
author: Amy Y.

description:
The tofu/vegetarian sandwich is sooo delicious!!! Crunchy bread, tasty sauce, lots of veggie filling, great price: Vietnamese sandwich for the win! I always come here when in SF. These ladies crank out sandwich after sandwich every day, and they leave us all satisfied and happy with our food. Thank you ladies for all that you do! 
Do yourself a favor and ask for the tofu/vegetarian roll next time! Tastiest tofu roll I have ever had.
author: valerie v.

description: This is probably the most famous banh mi store in San Francisco. It's been open for decades. Sandwiches are consistently fresh and delicious. I love all their sandwiches but my favorite is the chicken banh mi. Service is fast and pleasant. There is always a line out the door.
author: J.J. P.

description:
This special combo sandwich is so bomb! It's stuffed with plenty of meat and sauce. I highly recommend it. It's 4.25 each. 

Cash only!
author: Carrie Y.

description:
5 stars with some HUGE caveats, but 5 stars nonetheless!

Okay, so why Saigon Sandwich is a 5 star place to me....

1) CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP.  No really, where else can you get a pretty sizable sandwich for less than $4 in SF? 

2) Simple but tasty!  I got the pork bahn mi and it was really delicious.  If you are not a fan of spicy things, then you may want to ask them to skip the jalapeno

3) Convenient if you are in the area - it's a great lunch stop if you live or work nearby or if you are going to see a show at the Orpheum and want a lunch option in the city

All of that being said, I wouldn't go out of my way for this.  It was delicious, but not so delicious that I would drive 1 hour or more from the South Bay just to eat here.  If I lived closer, I'd be a regular.  The price point and taste in combination are 5 stars!
author: Alyx F.

description: I'm a Vietnamese foodie living in SJ, have tried almost all places in SJ and this is by far my fav place for bánh mì. That's all.
author: Trammi N.

description:
My review will most likely be lost with the masses, but as a San Francisco resident and lover of all things banh mi, I MUST pay homage. 

HAIL BUDDAH THIS IS A DAMN GOOD SANDWICH.

Banh Mi is a staple in my "diet"; a comfort food. I grew up with it. I enjoy it. The bread rips the roof of my mouth and its aftermath pops off dress shirt buttons.  Saigon sandwich is in a league of their own in the sandwich game and they have over 2,XXX cultish reviewers to prove it. 
The outside is anything but impressive; faded blue awning, dirty large window, a homeless guy pissing on your car, etc. Once you get past the exterior, you are greeted by a small and cozy(?) interior filled with people and Asian snacks. Max capacity may be 7....or 8 on a good day.

Okay down to the nitty gritty, this isn't your typical Vietnamese joint in the TL. You don't have a huge menu... they give you just a few choices. I call it the in-and-out menu approach (and Ill translate for my fellow mi trang):

Banh Mi Ga (roast chicken)
Banh Mi Thit (roast pork)
Banh Mi Xiu Mai (meat ball pork)
Banh Mi Cha Lua (fancy pork, pate)

My favorites: 
Banh Mi Thi Cha (combo steam pork and roast pork)
And....the holy grail. 

BANH MI CHA PATE (special combination....no questions asked, or we will have to kill you off). 

 Ladies and gents, if 2000+ reviews, 300+ pictures and obesity in the good-ol-US-of-A at an all time high doesn't convince you.... Please allow me. For the love of god please get the combination. You will sleep better at night, you will be honorary Vietnamese (all inclusive: redness whilst drinking and lactose) and I will love you long time. 

Why pay $160+ for a happy ending down the street when you can get one for $4.25  in your mouth!? We are in a financial crisis and a drought... do it for America. 

Price points range from $3.75-$4.25 so any excuse moving forward is invalid. 
post-sandwich aftermath: http://33.media.tumblr.com/1fc3882615c33cc903bf92b1765dbab5/tumblr_n2fwx04rMO1qbcq3wo1_500.gif


Treat yoself, du ma!
author: Ryan L.

description:
Hmm. This place was really rated high, so my expectations were really heightened. And credit where credit is due... it was very cheap, ready in under a minute, and tasty. 

That said, it really wasn't better than other bahn mi I've had around the city. Not really certain why the uber-high ratings, I thought it was comparable to but not really tastier than, others.

Cheap and fast, decent taste, but nothing that special.
author: Sean B.

description:
Honestly, I think the only great thing about this place is the cheap prices. Most sandwiches are $3.75, with no tax added. The sandwiches themselves aren't that great in my opinion. Each time I've been, the bread was very hard and stale, which surprised me given the rate at which they sell sandwiches. I most recently tried the chicken banh mi, and while they gave a good amount of chicken, it looked old and as if it had been sitting there for a long time. The chicken was a dark brown color and had a slightly mushy texture. I thought they put way too many carrots and jalapeños, making it too heavy and spicy. 

Besides their prices, I don't think their sandwiches themselves are that special relative to other banh mi options in the city.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: I used to order the pork sandwich, but the pate sandwich is so glorious that I haven't ever switched back. Try the PATE. Or add the PATE to any of your sandwiches. I am not metro, but please trust me. Get the PATE.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Service is fast, but don't expect them to hand coddle you. You better know exactly what you want and don't ask questions - I made that mistake asking to cut the sandwiches in half after she made it and let me say that I am pretty sure the lady called me something mean in viet :p 

But like all the reviews said, sandwiches are amazing, chewy, flavourful and cheap. Always go for the fanci pork with the pate, really yummy and I guarantee you will be shocked you finished one..or two in one sitting.
author: Sherina Y.

description:
The BEST Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had. Sandwiches have gone up a bit - $4.25 each but its totally filling and flavorful (I was starving when I ate mine and it filled me right up). Keep in mind that you'll wait to take your sandwich to go due to the location of Saigon Sandwich as well as the small amount of space inside.

PS. Cash only
author: Courtney C.

description:
These sandwiches will always have a special place in my heart. $3.75 for the most amazing Banh Mi sandwiches?! Can't find a restaurant that can beat the quality/price of these amazing gems. Very good comfort food.

There's always a line for this place, but it goes by very quickly. You'll have to venture out to the tenderloin to eat here, but there are so many good up-and-coming restaurants in these area that its always worth it.

CASH ONLY!
author: Daniel Y.

description: Huge and tasty banh mi for $3.75.  I had the grilled pork.  Only needed half the sandwich but couldn't resist eating the whole thing.  This place is a true hole in the wall.  Take out except for two window seats
author: Jessy B.

description:
SO. GOOD. I never get to come here, it closes too early for me to get back from work and opens up too late if I'm going hiking on a weekend. 

But I made it happen. SO GOOD. 

I ate a roasted pork and and a pate sandwich, in a park in North Beach, drinking ...water.....with the sun warm on my face. I will come back here forever. 

Oh it's around $3.75 - $4 per sandwich.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Yummy sandwiches with quick service. Only problem was how actual homeless crack heads kept coming in and out begging for money and making weird moaning noises. Made being in there a tad bit uncomfortable. It is located in the Tenderloin (highly populated with homeless neighborhood) so you should come here expecting a run in with at least one crackhead. It can be your street cred moment.

Anyway enough about the bum situation. The sandwiches, drinks, pastries and snacks are all priced very reasonably. Especially for the size of the sandwiches! Huge and delicious with amazing flavor. 

I got the tofu sandwich and wow. It was worth the bum situation. I would go back again but I might order over the phone to have it ready for pick up. This way I could be in and out.
author: Foodie E.

description: The absolute best value lunch in SF. It's almost exclusively a "to-go" type sandwich place and they don't have any frills, but it's always a safe bet.
author: Will O.

description:
We were on the hunt for the best banh mi in Little Saigon and with an overhwelming amount of 2500 reviews on Yelp, it was a no brainer.

I am Vietnamese and am very picky when it comes to banh mi...I was very surprised to see how much filling and meaty goodness is packed into these sandwiches. My guy (who is the tallest whitest guy ever) goes all in and we order 4 special combo sandwiches, 2 to eat now and 2 for our flight back to AZ. I was speaking half Viet half English with the little ladies behind the counter and felt I got a little special treatment for trying so hard.

Pros:
-How simple the menu is! 4 different kinds
-Excellent pricing
-Very generous with the pate
-Super sweet so we tipped them and to them it's the most startling act of kindness
-Travels well! Great for lunch the next day!

Cons
-WAY too hot in some bites, my mouth was on fire and we had to stop by to get milk somewhere
-I asked for veggies on the side but the lady said no that it would taste better, the little Viet girl inside of me just nodded and obliged even though I was the one making the request.

Great, flavorful pork and pickled veggies balance the soft but crusty baguettes. You cannot beat the awesome prices for a quick 2nd lunch which is what we did. Order all the sammiches @ Saigon Sandwich!
author: Michelle N.

description: I live walking distance from a popular Bahn  Mi shop in Sunnyvale...after tip toeing my way to Saigon Sandwich, I am more appreciative how difficult it is to work hard and to offer an affordable and delicious vegetarian sandwich without becoming a sterile chain restaurant.
author: Edmund F.

description:
I planned on rating this place four stars. Then I realized it's really the best sub-$5 meal I've ever had in my life. Seriously, where can you find something this good for not just $4... but $3.75??? What a steal. 

Confession: The sandwiches were so cheap I actually ordered two. One Chicken Banh Mi and one Pork. I got close, but I couldn't finish the second. 

They were both delicious, but I actually preferred the chicken. The sandwiches are a simple, somewhat spicy mix of meat and veggies with just a hint of sauce on a crisp bun. It's really hard to explain what makes the sandwiches so good, but rest assured; you will love them. 

The storefront has no seating, the only drinks are sold out of a cooler, it's cash only, and good luck understanding a word the happy women say to you. But you're not coming here for the ambiance. You're coming for some of the cheapest, most delicious sandwiches you will ever have.
author: David B.

description:
Absolutely great, cheap, solid Vietnamese sandwich.

Two huge sandwiches loaded with lots of meat and fresh veggies for less than $8, how can you go wrong?

I've only been here in the morning (7am-8am) so I have never experienced the epic line. 

Chicken is great, pork is great, and tofu is amazing!
author: Mailah G.

description:
Saigon Sandwich may very well be the banh mi mecca of San Francisco... hell, the United States.

As others mention, if it's a walking journey that will bring you here, it's one worth taking but please be conscious of the activity you'll encounter in the Tenderloin neighborhood. On an especially warm day, my brisk trek was overflowing with characters more savory than the accoutrements I'd eventually meet in my sandwich. But that's really a side note - my point is that you should exercise caution, be alert and stay off your phone (especially if you're a woman going at it alone). 

Like most legit banh mi shops, this one is tiny. There's a counter for ordering, a straight-to-the-point menu featuring five phenom sandwiches (with their English translations), a cooler containing sugary favorites such as Fanta (*cheers*), teas and the like, a steady line usually comprised of a dozen hungry denizens, and room for about one average-sized person to dine-in. 

I am the 1% - or more accurately in this case, 'the one' - lucky enough to snag the lone seat. I set up shop in the small quarters, mostly because I couldn't bear devouring the much-lauded sandwich a moment past its ideal state. And I'm glad that I stayed, because my banh mi had it all - succulent roasted pork, carrots, radish, daikon, cilantro, jalapeno peppers and a spread of mayo - all housed within freshly-baked bread. Soft but crusty, chewy and delicious, this bread served as the springboard of the consummate banh mi sandwich.

For $3.50, I had a lovely meal that proved to be perfectly-portioned for my lunchtime (read: lighter) appetite, but may be a tad smallish for some. The solution? I promise you won't ever be sorry if you order two.
author: Jelena Z.

description:
Very authentic viet sandwiches for a cheap and affordable price. They don't skimp out on their portions that you get in your sandwich so you get full from one sandwich. I order the bbq pork which comes in chunks of pork so it gives you something to chew on. The place is very tight so be prepared to take your sandwich to go. The french baguette bread is very crummy so expect to get crumbs everywhere. 

They also sell various other traditional viet desserts and snacks on their counter.

The location of the shop is pretty much in the Tenderloin so there are lots of homeless and signs of sketch (no so friendly neighborhood). There are sometimes homeless people begging outside. My friend got harassed by one while trying to purchase a sandwich so be careful.
author: Curt C.

description: I've only had them once, but it was the best BBQ pork banh mi I've had, so far; I've tried a bunch of banh mi's, including those in San Jose. There is another shop kitty corner to this one, but their bread is all wrong.  It is cash only (3.75) and they can run out. Note: if they runout, sometimes it's only temporary until they make more.  Instead of telling you to wait they will just say "they are out".  The line may be Long but it moves fast.  If I lived in SanFran I would go here all the time.
author: Angelia T.

description:
While i was on the way to SF, i was doing all my foodie research. I saw how much people rave about the sandwiches, i had to come here and try it. Also it is in little saigon, which i have never been in SF. 

Location 

It was in a more run down kind of environment. I did have people approach me for change and help. Of course i gave them my loose change. As Well crossing the streets got people rolling down the window and hollering at me. That was ignored obviously lol. Its like dafuq, aint got not time for you. lol 

Vibe 

Came here looking forward to a wonderful  meaty bahn mi!

Layout 

Well its not a sit down type of restaurant, because there isn't a spot to sit down. no outside seating as well. 

once you enter, you walk up to the crowded counter with lots of viet snacks all prepared. Then not he wall there is a menu of the sandwiches and prices. I already knew what i want so the menu on the board isn't needed. There is also a fridge with all kinds of drinks. 

Food 

I had just finish dining in at Brendas, which is one block away. I had to come over and pick up 2 sandwiches for later. 

Roast pork 

Well when it was time to eat, which was maybe 3 hrs later. The bread was hard as a rock. The meat was good though. But i don't think it is char grilled. The meat did have some flavor but nothing special. I did request the veggies on the side to prevent it from being soggy. They did give me lots of veggies which was a plus. The sandwich did have lots of mayo in it. They also put some sort of brown paste which tasted sweet. 

I do have to say it was ehh, maybe because i didn't eat it right away. But i have experienced better with duc huong in SAC 916 or in San Jose, where the bread is soft no matter when you eat it. The meat from duc huong is char grilled, which i like and gives it a different flavor. Saigon sandwiches do give 2x the meat for only $3.75, but when bread is hard as a rock, its kind of meh. 

Pork meatball 

This was for a friend. I asked what they rate it out of, and they say 5 out 5! so guess that was very good. 

Overall

This was my first bahn mi in SF and first visit of little saigon in SF.
author: Alex T.

description: For Vietnamese sandwiches this is the spot - super quick, cheap, great if eaten in 30 min from when they make em. Cash only is only drag because I don't carry cash on me in this day and age. When I have it on me tho I'll get two!
author: John O.

description:
Great value. Very good sandwich for such a low price.

Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah Blah I don't need to write anymore, Yelp!
author: Iván C.

description:
3.75 for lunch? How can one complain.....

I have only tried their tofu banh mi and it was supper yummy. Tofu was on the saltier side. 
Their health score is claimed to be 92/100 but if you actually come inside, you will find out that this place is quite disorganized/dirty/grimy. 

Tip: If you want it to be cut in half, ask. CASH ONLY.
author: Anna H.

description:
The love affair is over. She made my sandwich in 10 seconds. FLAT. It tasted like it.
One bite was Unrendered fat and bread. 
One bite was boy sauce and bread and carrots. 
One bite was jalapeño and pork and the jalapeño slice was BIGGER than the pork. 

This place is gotten real f'in sloppy. 

I'm feeling queasy just thinking about the sandwich I ate, you can't go home again. But tourists will love it and the two ladies are going to get rich so that's life, but not for this local. 

I'm seriously bummed. The sandwiches used to be out of this world crafted with love.
author: Nik D.

description:
Hole in the wall for Vietnamese sandwiches located in Little Saigon!

Must get Banh Mi - Pork Sandwich!  Meaty, flavorful and cheap!  

Great place to make a pit stop for a sandwich when you're on a time crunch!

Don't expect much dining space!

Cash only!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Ahh i forgot to take a picture of my sandwich! Lol

My coworkers and i ordered in for lunch, and delivery was super fast! We usually order earlier int the day so that it arrives by lunch, but using PostMates, the order arrived within only a half hour ish from Tenderloin to Mission neighbourhoods

I had the thit cha with 2 kinds of pork. It was so good! And a sizeable portion considering it's only $4. I found this place originally from a list of banh mi places on the Thrillist website, and i'm glad i did - i don't think i would have been likely to "accidentally" find it since i don't usually hang out in Tenderloin

Anyway, really good banh mi and i would definitely order from here again. Maybe next time i'll actually go there myself lol
author: Bianca C.

description: Bargain.  Been eating there for years and always the same; perfect balance of veggies, meat, sauce and crunchy bun.
author: Larry W.

description:
Between the amazing bread and a pretty sketchy walk here, the sandwiches were a topic of conversation all weekend long! My aunt didn't want to eat at a touristy place, so we took a very non-touristy walk through the Tenderloin to wait in line for a sandwich!

First off, the bread is amazing. Perfectly crispy on the outside while still soft on the inside. I tried both the roast chicken and roast pork, and both are sure to please. The fillings are very generous so I was pretty full when I finished. 

Probably the only negative about this place is the wait. We came around 2:30 and waited in line for about 25 minutes. I was starving/drooling and couldn't wait to get my hands on one of these sandwiches! There isn't really any place to sit, especially with a long line, so we took our sandwiches a few blocks down the street and stuffed our faces near the Civic Center. 

At $3.75 per sandwich, this meal can't be beat!
author: Suzanne O.

description:
The sandwiches here are ridonkulously good! I tried the grilled chicken which was mega-flavorful. The rolls were fresh and chewy, and the rest of the ingredients were taza-fresh! To top it all the prices are crazy reasonable too. If you don't like this place; I hate to break it to you--but the problem isn't them. A process of elimination you will quickly uncover where the issue really resides ;)
(Just sayin)
author: Vivek N.

description:
The best things can come from small packages. This place is one of them. This place can be hard to find and easy to miss as there isn't any a definitive sign on the door. You're hint will be the line outside the door. Good lucking with finding parking nearby and with eating at this place. There is a small table facing the street with enough room for two people, but most of the time it'll be occupied by people waiting for their sandwich.

I decided to get the combination sandwich. For $4, I wasn't expecting much. When I received the sandwich, I was surprised by the large portion size and the amount of meat that was in it. The sandwich tasted pretty good, but about 60 percent through, I started to get tired of it. I'm not sure whether it was just me or I needed a side to go along with this sandwich. Nonetheless, I was satisfied with my selection.

The service here is what stopped me from giving this place another star. This place is cash only and for some reason I only had $100 and $2 bills. They would not take my $100 bill so I gave them my twos. They took a really long look at it and eventually accepted it. Overall, you get your money's worth here and if it isn't too busy, I would definitely try this place again.
author: Jason P.

description:
great banh mi sandwich!

Came here on one of my first visits to SF a few years back and was glad to see not much has changed... I think inflation hit a bit... maybe $2.50 to $3.25 now, but still a great bargain!
author: Sasha B.

description:
Last Wednesday, we braved through walking into the heart of the TL's to show my non-Asian coworkers what a real banh mi was all about. 

Requirements of a true banh mi:

1) A Vietnamese person makes this sandwich - 100% authentic and typically from a hole in a wall shop. 

2) None of that fusion shit. Don't get me wrong, I love my pork belly, fried eggs, and warm toasted baguette too but that's not a REAL banh mi. 

3) It costs less than $5! 

I've been asked if I want to go to Bun Mee several times and I can't justify a $8 sandwich that won't compare to the sandwiches at Saigon. No thanks.

It's been a while since I've walked to Saigon and boy is the line freakin long during lunch. Not only that but the homeless are chilling right there asking for money while you wait, which can make one feel uncomfortable. These two things alone don't detour me from getting my meatball sandwich.

They have a pretty good system worked out at Saigon:

1) cash only (ATM inside)
2) line up
3) give the first woman your order
4) move to the waiting area which is 2 steps to your right and a total cluster f@$k if there are a lot of people waiting already 
5) a second woman will call your order and you pay in cash at that point 
6) you're free to squeeze out of the tiny shop and enjoy your sandwich in safe environment guilt free

Enjoy!
author: Jeanne L.

description: I try to come here whenever I'm in SF.  Their pate is very good!  My mom had chicken, and it was also very good, though I prefer the pate since I find them more flavorful.  Seating is non-existent, so do have it to go.
author: Justin H.

description: Uhhh hello?! There's a reason for these many reviews and ratings.. it's self explanatory. If you haven't been, shame on you!!!! Cheap and delicious. Pate is bomb diggety!
author: wendy h.

description:
This was a good banh mi. 

I like the hoisin type sauce in addition to the mayo. 

The bread was also very good. You lucky SF'ers with your delicious bread, making sandwiches so much better. 

The only complaint is the long line and tired workers.
author: Hae A.

description:
Great sandwich! I had the Thit Cha... I've stayed across the street a couple of times during my stays in SF. I've noticed the lines out the door on those occasions. Something happened on this current stay. I saw the line...I figured what the hell. Once you get comfortable with the language barrier, which in theory does not exist, since somehow someway...I said, "Thit Cha" the best I could...she said whatever she said, and they nailed the order, "Thit Cha w/o mayo" and that's what I got. Great customer service... It's quick bursts of interaction...but very efficient as both ladies were in perpetual motion in their kitchen...

Food wise...it's about an 8-inch roll that is STUFFED full of the goods...for $4.

If I'm in the neighborhood again...I'll be back
author: David S.

description: The best place to get banh mi sandwiches! Where else can you get a sandwich packed full of meat and veggies in a delicious sandwich roll for less than $4. It's so popular, it's hard to find when there isn't a long line out the door. They do turn out sandwiches pretty quick, freshly made. I like the special combination and the roast pork. This place sets the standard when it comes to banh mi sandwiches and that others are compared to.
author: Nick N.

description:
Wait in line, state your sandwich, pay, receive your sandwich, leave.

That is as simple as ordering gets at this place. But for $3.75 for a filling sandwich, there's really nothing but praise for this place. SO CHEAP.

During lunch hours it can get busy but usually I'm in and out of there within 5 minutes!

Highly recommend BBQ pork for newbies. And to note: they always add jalapenos and cilantro unless told otherwise.

Enjoy a quick, cheap, and delish meal!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: I love this place the best banh mi I ever had in the U.S fair price and really good sandwich! I didn't bring any cash this Morning but the lady let me take the sandwich and pay tomorrow! This is truly touched！I would add this restaurant to my everyday lunch list. Thanks to the kind people there.
author: Scarlett M.

description:
I was on my way to City Hall and needed a quick and cheap fix. Yelp led me to Saigon. This place is legit...and certainly cheap! I got the combo and man did they pack in the meat. I love the fact that I can taste the pate mm mm mmm.

The price is listed for $4.25, but they only charged me $3.75. The line during lunch time can be long, but it goes by quickly. It's a hole-in-the-wall place with nowhere to sit and eat, but who cares. Actually, even better...less overhead = cheaper food for us.
author: Huong V.

description: Best banh mi I have ever had! So much flavor packed into a small parcel. They put a lot of the filling into it though so it is very filing(for me at least). I got the roast pork one and it was just amazing. The workers are super fast and so you need to pay attention to your order!
author: Chelsea M.

description: Tofu Sandwich is amazing. I dream about it sometimes. How do they get the bread to be crunchy and soft at the same time?! Friendly ladies and so affordable.
author: Violetta M.

description: Good flavor, but the bread was too thick and dense for my taste. I prefer a light baguette with the insides pulled out so the portion of sandwich to filling is even. Still, a great sandwich for the price. Simple, predictable, and filling. If passing by its always an easy stop along the bus route.
author: Sarah O.

description: Straight up. Cheap, delicious, simple. Bahn Mi.
author: John R.

description: Hands down the best banh mi in SF! I've tried many banh mi places but this one is incomparable. Price wise it beats everyone. Combination which is patê, roasted pork, and fancy pork cost 4.25!  This for me is the go to sandwich because it has everything. They pack a lot in the sandwich and most certainly don't skimp on the meats which I really appreciate!
author: Roseanne V.

description:
THE HYPE IS REAL YA'LL. This is 100% the dankest of dank Bahn Mi in the city. Ridiculously cheap (you don't buy meals for less than $4 in 2015) and out of this world flavor. My friend and I were actually on our way to another restaurant when we saw there was no line to this place because it just opened. CHILL. We were not disappointed, as soon as I took my first bite of the roast pork.. I panicked and the glutton in me wondered, should I order one more? Should I bring some home for my family? Is my life all downhill from here??

The ladies who work here are freaking fierce, keep doing you plz and thanks for blessing SF with this heroic sandwich
author: Kim S.

description:
Like every other viewer I will tell you the sandwiches are awesome and cheap. Cheap even by TL standards. 

Only thing I have to add is that you can sit comfortably while you eat if you walk downhill a few storefronts to Boba Delight.

Do not go to Lee's, I have had every Saigon Sandwich and they are all awesome!
author: Roger L.

description: Some of the best tasting Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. The bread was fresh and the ingredients were too. I ordered the pork and tofu. Must say I like the pork better but only because it had more flavor. Cheap eats, and you better plan to take it to go as there aren't but two chairs inside.
author: jonelle y.

description:
This is my favorite banh mi spot in the city.  I've been coming here for years and have never been disappointed.  I always get the same thing as it's super hard to veer away from the combo.  

The place is a hole in the wall and a little sketchy...all in all though, it beams of character.  It's located right in the heart of little Saigon.  Parking sucks.  You might as well take public transportation.  

Cheap?  Heck yes.  

Super duper 5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
The shop has no friggin seating. You walk in and a counter greets you about 3 feet from the door. There are people standing around and there's no line since there's no room to form a line. You are unsure as who is there to order or who is waiting for their food. Don't expect to be greeted by the cashier. There's only three employees and they don't have time for that sh*t. You just have to walk up there, tell them what you want and step aside. Again, there is no seating inside or outside the shop. 

We ordered two Banh mi ga (chicken sandwich). The bread itself is hard - too crunchy for my taste. So why the four stars? Cause there's something about what they stuff inside these sandwiches that just rocks my taste buds' world! It's so flavorful yet not salty. Whatever they put in their paste that they lather up the sides of the bread is weird.. But I like it. lol I walked out the shop started walking back to my car while unwrapping the sandwich, took a bite and was like wait a minute wait a minute - I have to sit down to eat this lol 

By the way - cash only. Parking here as expected is a challenge. We parked in the garage on golden gate ave by the Subway sandwich shop - $3.50 an hour.
author: Carolyn N.

description:
$3.75 FOR A BANH MI??? That's insane. Plus, it was so big that I couldn't even finish it.

All the reviews have pretty much covered everything, from the tiny tiny space with barely enough space for two people to sit to the scary but extremely efficient lady behind the counter. 

It still blows my mind how dirt cheap these sandwiches are. 10/10 would come again!!
author: Sabrina C.

description:
The ladies who run this joint are hard.

Talkin bout "NEXT!"  before you're even done tellin them your order.
You be like, canigetextrapeppers!!! saying it hella fast before they say next.
Sometimes they hear you, sometimes they don't.  Even if they did, you probably won't get your extra peppers.
Gangsta.

And if you watchin them make your sandwich, and notice they didn't make yours to order....you could TRY to holla at em midway.  But you bout to get the stank eye.
I'd be the girl behind you in line uttering under my breath like oooooooooh.  You stupih.  

Cuz they could curse me out all they want, it ain't gonna change the taste of their smackin ass banh mis'.  It'll taste like a nice, cursey, toasted sandwich, extra peppers if it tickled their fancy.  It ain't gonna be on my request thats for sure. I'm no nosy pepper.

Cuz you know what a nosy pepper does.
.
.
.
.
.

Gets jalapeño business.



o_O
author: Rho T.

description:
5/26/14  Lunch

Picked up sandwiches from various Vietnamese places for a friend's picnic party. Saigon was one of the shops. No line on Memorial Day. Just three people ahead of me. Saigon is a pure sandwich shop with a small menu that covers pork, chicken, and tofu.

The baguette is the same kind as Balo, most likely from Little Paris, yet another Vietnamese place in Chinatown. Roast Chicken ($3.75) banh mi has tender chicken shreds with pickled carrots, pickled daikons stuffed full and spilled out of the pate-spread sammy. They have jalapeno chili and a bit mayo. No soy sauce. Very good and filling. Roast Pork ($3.75) banh mi has the same condiments and ingredients but tastes even better. Compared to the chicken, the roast pork one has less portion of meat.

Two ladies man the store. I spread pate on the baguette and the other assembles the sandwiches. It's friend, cheap, and no frill. Saigon has very tasty sandwiches but not the best ones. Why? Inconsistent taste. The 3 roast pork sandwiches from the same batch had different amount of condiment, specially the pate, mayo and meat. I cannot tell you how heavenly when you bite into the warm crunchy baguette and taste that blending of mayo, pate and meat. Maybe they are slammed so the sadwiches don't always come out perfect. So 4 stars for very tasty sandwiches.
author: Matt Y.

description:
Cash only.  $3.75 per sandwich.  These are the real deal.  Shop is run by 2 little Vietnamese ladies.  We went around 3:30pm on a Monday, and got the last 2 sandwiches, because they ran out of bread.  Sat inside to eat (they have only 2 seats along a tiny bar by the window), and people kept coming in one after the other to order sandwiches... but alas we had already gotten the last 2, which we were savoring in front of them.

A couple regulars were nice enough to buy a bunch of loaves from Lee's across the street, then brought them to the ladies so they could have their sandwiches.  (The cashier lady had stated earlier that Lee's refuses to sell them any bread... They know of their steep competition.)
author: Vanessa O.

description:
Being French-Vietnamese, living in Asia, and traveling through out Vietnam I love these sandwiches. I grew up eating these sandwiches all the time. Saigon Sandwich is a decent bánh mì shop but not amazing. The more I think about it, the more I get a little upset with this place. I ordered bánh mì tht ngui. Ovetall, the flavors are good but their sandwiches are no where near the ones in Vietnam. 

Pro:
- French butter (good start)
- Decent price
- bánh mì was good (should have toasted the bun)

Con:
- roast pork was not roast, WTF (classic sandwich has pork with a little char, hence, roast pork). Traditionally, roast pork should be roasted with char edges which adds a crispy flavour to the sandwich; but the pork here is cooked in a microwave or sauce pan. They don't cook the proper roast pork.
- Jalapeño too large. 
- not enough cucumbers
author: Pierre C.

description: Saigon Sandwiches is the only place that I trust to get a great Vietnamese Sandwich whenever I'm in town. There will probably be a line snaking out the door if you go here. The shop is tiny and there's not much sitting room. You get in line with everyone else who knows this secret, order your sandwich however you would like it (I get the combination with NO mayonnaise), get your sandwiches fresh made, and go find somewhere to eat it like the park by the Capital Building or a quick bus ride up McAllister to Golden Gate Park. They also have other things like hand rolls, Vietnamese bagged snacks, and drinks in a cooler. The sandwiches are what make the line almost certain, though the wait time is never more than ten minutes.
author: Steve N.

description: Tofu sand which was seriously delicious and a steal at $3.75-that's cheaper than making your own lunch
author: Crystal Y.

description: Tastiest Vietnamese sandwich in SF! My staff bought it last Friday! Must eat! I am already craving for more! I usually get my sandwiches in San Jose, can't beat the price or taste but Saigon is on my list now for Vietnamese sandwiches! Try it yourself! You won't regret it!
author: J W.

description: The best bahn mi in San Francisco and is a good sign when there is always a long line out the door during the lunch hour.
