I usually get the Roast Pork sandwich which comes with a lot veggies and jalapenos. The pork is very flavorful and juicy. Make sure you ask for less jalapenos if you cannot handle spicy. The also offer Chicken, Meatball, and Pate for their meat options which I have yet tried. The staff working here ted to work fast on orders by making all the sandwiches in batches. Talk about efficiency when it comes to having an assemble line. They also speak Cantonese here which means friendlier service. The area around this shop can be a bit sketchy, so I would recommend keeping an eye on your surroundings.
author: Peter C.

description:
Came here last Sunday with some friends from church and YESSSS, such a win! This place looks like a hole in the wall for sure but with over 2k reviews... It's a pretty well known and popular spot.

$3.75 for a special combination sandwich (: *drool* and is supposedly the best place for vietnamese sandwiches around this part of town. We came in a large group but that was no problem for this tiny little sandwich shop. They made and spit out our orders one after the other in a quick, but still quality manner. 

The menu is simple and straight forward, just choose what kind of meat/filling you want:
-Roasted Chicken
-Roasted Pork
-Meat ball/Pork
-Tofu
-Combination, my favorite!

Comes with your standard Vietnamese sandiwch veggies.

They have lots of drinks to choose from - water, coconut juice, snapple, soda, etc. They also sell Vietnamese/Asian desserts and other snacks to munch on.

After we got our orders we trekked over to a park to enjoy our sandwiches in the sun :) Yes, would come back!
author: Grace J.

description: Come on now, best Bahnmi around. Keeping sf real in an important era of wackiness. Saigon is a lifestyle dude
author: Auston M.

description:
Amazing Vietnamese Sandwiches!

When I have to bring lunch for work or grab a quick lunch and I can't decide where or what to eat, I know I can always resort to Saigon Sandwich.

Their breads are made fresh and they're kept warm in a toaster oven before being assembled.

I've tried their chicken, roast pork, and combo sandwiches. All were delicious with perfectly cooked meats. Their steamed pork rolls are delicious and I love their pate. Sometimes I ask for extra jalapenos because their peppers aren't too spicy in my opinion.

Great prices, all around $4. Can you beat that?

If you've never had a Saigon Sandwich, you're missing out. 

CASH ONLY. I mean cmon, you're in the TL, of course it's cash only, and don't be surprised if there's hobos outside. 

They also have viet desseerts. They look freshly made and I bet they're delicious.

The ladies working here are amazing. They take a bunch of orders and remember everything without mistakes. They also add in their heads. Don't doubt them, they don't miscalculate, at least not that I've seen. And they're super fast.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
O.M.F.G. 

This place is SO good. Super fast to pick up an order, and I have to say, definitely the best banh mhi I have ever had; in fact, it was one of my weekend highlights. Usually, the meat isn't as tender and moist, so I was really surprised. (I had the special combo.)

Suffice it to say, I'll need to incorporate more of this place into my life now that I've tried it.
author: Diana K.

description: If you have ever had a real banh mi then you will not like this. I don't know why this place gets good reviews as I threw away half my sandwich, it was that bad! The bread was slightly hard, not fresh. The pork was overdone and soft, rather tasteless. The pate was just gross, looked, smelled and tasted like you would imagine cat food tastes like. All in all a terrible place, in a bad area.
author: F E.

description:
Until someone shows me otherwise, banh mi (not bahn mi) doesn't get much better than Saigon Sandwich in SF. The lunch hour wait can be brutal, as there are practically lines out the door every day. It's all happening in the name of a $3.50 sandwich, made in a place that doesn't even have seating and closes at 6PM every day. Those who are hanging out in line know the deal: this is killer banh mi that is worth the wait.

Saigon Sandwich has the luxury of being located in the seedy Tenderloin, home to the "Little Saigon" hood of SF, where crazy hobos and dive eateries go hand in hand.  The menu is notoriously simple, located on a green board on the upper right hand side of the wall, with thit (pork), xiu mai (meatball), and ga (chicken) listed as their main proteins. Chay (tofu) is also available, though not listed is dac biet (special combination), which happens to be the one I order almost every time.

The sammy seems a bit on the smaller side, but taste more than makes up for it. The bread is toasted almost perfectly, with a generous slather of pate, a gorgeous piling of pickled veggies, cilantro, daikon, peppers above a stuffing of choice. Whatever the filling, it's makes for the perfect lunch under $5.

There are other Vietnamese snacks available at the counter, but the sandwiches steal the show. The ladies are super nice, though are pretty sparse with the English outside of money and menu words. They've done an outstanding job each time I've been here, I can only see bigger and better things happening for Saigon Sandwich, where the banh mi sandwiches are at their top of their game.
author: Jando S.

description:
Sandwiches are excellent! Also, you can't beat the price here. Super inexpensive and tasty. 

Give this place a try!
author: Indira S.

description: INSANELY DELICIOUS. Small casual hole in the wall that was so quick and cheap! The boyfriend and I both had the pork sandwich. It's like a dream in your mouth. Only downside is there is no where to sit, even in the surrounding area since its in a bit of a grimy neighborhood. So we called an uber and had an agonizing 8 min drive back to our hotel because our sandwiches smelled soooo good. We inhaled them in 2.5 minutes.  I will be craving this for years after I leave San Francisco.
author: Rebecah J.

description: I have been going here for almost 6 years ! Amazing Sandwich!! When I want a Vietnamese sandwich I fix up my cravings at this spot in the Bay !!
author: Prayank J.

description: OMG the best bahn mi Vietnamese sandwich I ever ate.  I came to San Francisco from Seattle for the weekend and came upon this place.  I ordered the combo sandwich and it was amazing.  They did not hold back on the meat or pate.  The sandwich was flavorful and filling. I wish they had this place in Seattle. I must try if your in the mood for a Vietnamese sandwich.  Only bad this is there are no sitting area.
author: Sam T.

description:
Best $3.50 I have ever spent.  

Sure, it's in the tenderloin - minus one star
Sure, they only take cash - minus a second star
Sure, the line can be incredibly long -  minus a third star
Sure, there's no seating inside, so you have to take it to go - minus a 4th star
Sure, the staff can be difficult to communicate with - minus a 5th star

But it's the best Vietnamese sandwich I've had in the States - plus infinity stars.   

If the line is too long, there are a few other good options.  While not as good, I do like Lee's Sandwiches across the street, which also has $3.50 Bahn Mi.  Lee's use a longer, thinner French baguette and have less meat and fillings, but the fresh bread compensates.  I also like Lee's smoothies, Vietnamese Iced Coffee, and variety of Vietnamese snacks that Saigon Sandwich doesn't offer.  (Saigon Sandwich does have a fridge with about 4 or 5 Vietnamese desserts, which are very good.)
author: Greg B.

description:
Friend brought me one,  but I had just eaten lunch. 
Threw it into the fridge, toast it the next day & still delicious! 

What is there to complain about for the price?! Loads of juicy meat, fixings and all the goodness wrapped up nice and neat.

I'll be heading over myself after jury duty :)
author: Angel L.

description:
Their sandwiches are delicious but sanitary / quality is a little questionable. There's also not much description on the items they're selling so it was a little hard to decide what to get unless you are familiar with Vietnamese. I decided to go with "Fanci Pork" because, well, it sounded "fancy" but turns out it's the luncheon meat variant... while I'd much rather get the roasted pork. 

However, if you're craving for an authentic, cheap banh-mi in SF, then this place is probably your best choice. 

Usual drills for such a popular hole-in-the-wall:
- cash only
- sketchy neighborhood
- parking is extremely hard
- service is non-existent: be ready with your order and don't ask too many questions
- expect to wait in line for at least 15 min
author: Effie G.

description:
We happened to find ourselves in the neighborhood and made a beeline to Saigon Sandwich for a late lunch. 

***ROASTED PORK SANDWICH

Toasted bahn mi baguette filled with jalapeño, cilantro, pickled carrots & daikons, chunks of roasted pork, & mayo. Frankly it tasted practically identical to pretty much every other Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. It was definitely decent--I always like the contrast between the sweetness of the pickled carrots & daikons and the savoriness of the meat. The cilantro & the mild jalapeño gives it that unmistakable Vietnamese feel. The flavor of the meat wasn't very pronounced, but it certainly wasn't bad. There was a bit too much mayo for my liking, but I have a fundamental disagreement with that condiment. And I generally find the baguette to be a little on the tough side, even after being toasted. The wife kept complaining about how short this bahn mi was in comparison to the generous portions they serve in just about every shop in Oakland, at half the price, with superior flavor. 

***ROASTED CHICKEN SANDWICH

As I mentioned, the flavor of the meat was very subdued, so much so that I honestly would've had a hard time telling the difference between this and the pork sandwich. And everything else was exactly the same. 

ALL IN ALL:

Vietnamese sandwiches are a fun snack, but it takes something special to get on the radar. Unfortunately Saigon Sandwich was just too average to inspire me to make a return visit.
author: Elliott D.

description:
These were the best sandwiches I ever had! I would eat this every week if I could. I've been dreaming about these sandwiches ever since I got back to Dallas. We got the combo banh mi. The baguettes are baked perfectly -golden and crispy and warm. The pickled carrots are delish. The cilantro and jalapeños I could live without but my bf loved them. The meaty stuff- not too sure what it all was but I gobbled it all down. 

The area was real sketch so you might want to take that into consideration if you are walking. 

Also, their health rating was a 96/97. Always a plus.
author: Grace S.

description:
Best sandwiches in the area for sure!

The bread is fresh, the meat (I love the chicken but the pork is great too) is amazing, and the people are friendly even though they don't understand English very well. That's kind of an understatement, you often need to repeat your order even if it is just one simple sandwich. For only $3.75 though, it's totally amazing.

Most of the time you have to wait in line, but they work really fast so you rarely need to wait more than five minutes. Which is totally worth it!

Oh, and the area is kinda sketchy but that's not this place's fault.
author: Maarten V.

description:
Not too sure why this spot got such high reviews. It's average at best. I guess this is the best you've experienced? What makes a great bahn mi is the bread and this one is STALE & ROCK HARD!!

This place isn't very sanitary either. When you watch your sandwich get made, you can watch the same person collect your money while simultaneously touching your sammy, ungloved. Do you know how many germs are on dollar bills? So disgusting.

While I was waiting outside, a man rolling on the ground in the front of the shop was smoking crack like it was nothing. Ahh, city life.

All of the 'Loin smells of urine, so if you can deal with that, you'll be good.
author: R S.

description:
Yes, the sandwich is cheap. But for a simple pork sandwich, I'd rather go to roli roti. We phoned in our order ahead of time and the lady hangs up before you're done talking! She did it to me twice! The sandwich is simple, but in a bad way. I'd rather have my traditional Viet sandwich with a variety of meat.

Tip: If you speak Cantonese, use it here for better service.
author: Diane Z.

description:
SAIGON SANDWICH IS THE REAL DEAL.

Even my coworker (a former Vietnamese refugee) buys sandwiches here -- and no he does not live nor work close by. In my book that gives this shop instant street cred.

The regular sandwich is only $3.75 with all the traditional fixings and a generous shmear of pate. That is damn cheap compared to some other more "modern" banh mi shops opening up around town, though truth be told I'd pay $7-$10 for this sandwich. It's that yummy.
author: Tiffany W.

description: My favorite Vietnamese sandwich place ever!! Best prices and consistent! Have yet to find a place that beats them
author: Kayden P.

description: We got a BBQ pork sandwich each with good, thick slices of pork and all the fixings on fresh bread.  You call out your order to the lady, pay her in cash and you have your sandwiches a few minutes later.  Can't ask for much more than that!
author: Maile N.

description: Great place to pickup a cheap delicious sandwich. Sometimes there is a bit of a line but it goes really quick. If you haven't had one stop in and give it a try.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
Wasn't necessarily Banh Mi's Biggest fan till I had SAIGON SANDWICH that sell really CHEAP sandwiches and drinks! What's more amazing is their TOFU VEGETARIAN BANH MI that I've fallen in love with! YASSS the tofu veggie banh mi was bomb! The marinated tofu slices were packed with flavor and incredibly moist, topped with a shiiii ton of picked carrots, jalapenos that created a bit of heat, tangy mayo, fresh cilantro and cucumber. I honestly prefer it over their meat sandwiches. The marinade from the tofu mixes in with the mayo and into the bread that it softens the baguette and makes for a great sandwich, that the pork sandwiches don't necessarily do. Sometimes try to get extra picked carrots to go :) THAT GOOD!

The sandwiches CAN BE SPLIT IN HALF and can be considered a bit big for others. So the first couple times, I usually split it in half and switched up the tofu banh mi with whatever my friends were having. Was able to try the Roast Chicken, Roast Pork, Fancy Pork and Pate because of it! Haha! All were pretty delicious but my meat recommendations are arranged in order of preference!


Side note: THIS PLACE is made for DROP-BYs/TO GOS. They have two seats by the window but it can get cramped especially when people start to show up. The shop interiors aren't modern or trying to impress. You come here for the food and that's how everything's set up: with practicality. Cashier, just a few feet from the door, with a bunch of snacks laid out on the counter, the open kitchen just behind, then two fridges on the right for drinks you can check out, counter overlooking the window with two chairs. Ordering and getting your sandwich ready to go will take relatively 15 mins max. because the ladies who sell over there have perfected their sandwich making production line so you can be in and out of there in time for some coffee at Philz nearby and back to whatever important things you need to get down in the day.

WANT. Tried to recreate this at home and have yet to figure out the tofu marinade. GAH! If anyone knows how, help me out!
author: Margaret G.

description:
This place is great! Definitely a home-feel hole-in-the-wall place with fresh bahn mi. The ladies are busy, but nice. They are quick. So even the line is long, the wait is usually not that bad. 

I don't really feel compelled to write a very thorough review because....look at the number of reviews here! I'm very impressed by how cheap the prices are, especially in the heart of SF. I hope they stay the same!

I always get the tofu sandwich. It's very juicy. I love taking the sandwiches to a park, or to civic center, somewhere outside and eat it while enjoying the warm SF sun (and chilly wind). It's a great weekend lunch. 

Btw, there is once I went there and they just happened to be slicing their onions, with a meat slicer machine. It was soooooo strong it brought tears to my eyes within 3 seconds of stepping into the store. I truly admire those ladies that stay in there and make sandwiches for the entire time.
author: Wendy K.

description:
Oh...my.... These sandwiches are so good. I got the pork - it came with a ton of shredded carrots, jalapeno, and cilantro. Extremely simple, but it was heaven in my mouth. I was stuffed after finishing the one sandwich, only $3.75. 

This is definitely a place where you just get your food and take it somewhere else to eat...preferably far away from the restaurant haha. The neighborhood isn't the best and the restaurant only has one tiny table that would probably be so crowded by all the people waiting that you wouldn't want to sit there anyway. There was a line when I went at lunch time but it moves quickly. Those ladies are swift sandwich making pros!
author: Jessie X.

description:
Saigon Sandwich has really taken off. It used to be that I could come by at 3:30 in the afternoon and  there wouldn't be a wait. No longer. Saigon attracts all types - tourists, businessmen showing visitors an authentic experience, little asian ladies buying a huge bag full of banh mi. The original woman who worked here seems to no longer be as involved as she once was, but the other women are doing a good job running the spot. 

Prices are up a quarter, which means that now Saigon is still the most affordable and delicious option ever.
author: Ari F.

description:
Tried the tofu based Vegetarian sandwich, it was great. I'm happy about the food and I'm giving three star for other reasons.

Surrounded by homeless people, one of them even walked into the place while I was standing to place an order. She saw me paying by cash and getting a dollar back. The owner kept saying something asking her to go away, but it did not work. I felt the owner did not care much either.

Now here is the bad experience, the homeless woman who walked in, blocked the way out and wouldn't let me go if I didn't give her a dollar. She kept demanding and as I walked away, she tried to hit me with her leg. She was an older woman, I did it bother and kept walking away.

Now the sandwich was great, as a visitor I don't know what times are good to avoid homeless people, but it did unfortunately create a bad experience for me. I could easily blame the city and not this place, but I'm bit concerned for tourists who end up here so hopefully they can watch out.
author: Murali S.

description:
Overall: Great mom-and-mom place in Little Saigon with not only a great bahn mi but also great che ba mau (tapioca dessert)

Ambience: Don't come here for the ambience.  This kitchen + counter + mini grocery store is nothing to sit and take in.  It's just two hard working vietnamese women furiously and artfully making vietnamese bahn mi sandwiches.  

Food: All of the components are clearly prepared upfront and so even though there was a long line, I didn't wait long for my tofu bahn mi ($3.75).  The tofu itself was fried in-house and well-marinated with soy sauce and I got some hints of ketchup I think.  The mayonnaise was definitely more sweet than tangy, which suggests it was also homemade.  Add your pickled carrots/daikon, cilantro, jalapenos and one of the best baguettes and this makes for an awesome sandwich.  I have to admit that the pickled veggies were a little tasteless, couldn't taste any vinegar and were more sweet than anything else and it would have been a homerun if they were just a smidge crunchier.  Nevertheless, together, this is one of the best tofu bahn mi's I've had.  I decided to go for the che ba mau dessert ($2.50) which is basically a tapioca sweet soup that they had in cups.  It was without question the best I've ever had.  It was the perfect level of sweetness and had a ton of different flavors.  The tapioca and beans were perfect and blended well with the soup portion.  This was the perfect on-the-go lunch.

Would I come back again?  Absolutely although walking from Moscone was a bit far.  I might still make the walk in the coming days while I'm in town.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Great for a banh mi fix in SF! Just not super authentic (I've had my fair share of banh mi in San Jose / OC / Saigon / Hoi An).  

Ordered the Thit Cha Pate (no mayo). Bread had a nice crunch to it! Good amount of meat (cha is like a Vietnamese pork ham) and well balanced with the amount of pate. This was the first time I've had a banh mi that had a sweet, Teriyaki-like sauce. Interesting and flavorful taste, but I personally prefer something more plain. I've also had more satisfying pickled veggies at other places -- this one seemed like 98% carrots, 1% daikon, and 1% onion. 

Try it out if you're nearby! I probably would not go out of my way to get here.
author: Doreen H.

description: The sandwich is really filling, and for $3.75, you probably won't find a cheaper lunch in the city. The grilled pork quality is above average, but the texture was more akin to pulled pork (very fibrous) and really lacked that unique bahn-mi spice and taste. It tasted like a generic pulled pork sandwich, which, don't get me wrong, was delicious, but I was looking for a little more zing to the sandwich. I think what contributed to this overall brandless flavor was the fact that their sauce was more of a plain mayo than whatever magic sauce I've had in previous bahn mi sandwiches. All in all though, solid sandwich.
author: Zi-on C.

description:
I'm not sure how I haven't written a review for this place yet.  I used to come here pretty often when I went to school in the neighborhood, and now that I'm not, I still find occasion to come here for the glorious, glorious creation that is the Saigon Sammich Tofu Sammich.  

That amazing, godly thing is stuffed to the brim with several delicious patties of fried tofu, all nice and fatty, marinated in this sweet, mayo-plus-something-else blend.  The result is a creamy, slightly sweet concoction that is filling, tasty, and perfect.  Add to it the standard banh mi condiments of cilantro, pickled veggies (carrots, daikon, and onion), and some jalapenos for you spice lovers, and you've got a sammich that is, IMHO, quite perfect.  The bread is also done just right - there's a crispy outside and a softer inside.  

I think it's $3.50 or maybe $3.75, a very reasonable price for a VERY big sammich that will fill those with even the biggest appetites.  

I've tried some of the other sammiches here, and they're good too, but I think the tofu sammich is the BEST item on the menu because it's unique, it tastes so good and perfect, and also because personally I'm more partial to vegetarian sammiches than meat ones.
author: Vivian C.

description:
The tofu banh mi is better than Nutella x America. 

I want to marry the lady who runs this place, but she's too good for me. And she knows she's too good for me. And she probably knows how I feel about her too. But she sells me sandwiches and doesn't make it awkward for me because she's classy like that.
author: Zak F.

description: I like this place a lot. I go there at least couple of times a week. The sandwiches are best in this  area, and price is decent. My coworker goes here every week too.
author: Meichelle L.

description: So I went back about a week after my first time.  Gosh darn these sandwiches are good.  And the price is right.  They also were all wearing gloves and washing their hands while preparing the food.  So now they get 5 stars.  If you like Banh Mi, you should go to Saigon Sandwich.  The end.
author: Paul W.

description: Loveee bahn mi and this place sells excellent bahn mi! Their sauce, pate, picked vegies, meats really create that mouth flavor explosion and it's super delicious!!!! I just wish I took a bite of it when it was still warm in my hands. It was like heaven for 10 minutes.
author: Hoyan L.

description: I'm so thankful for this place near my work. Even though the price went up by $0.25 it's still worth it! Tofu with extra jalepenos all the way!!!!!
author: Flip T.

description:
The taste of the banh mi here is not the best I've had, but it's decent. 3.5/5

Sanitation here is sub par. On more than two occasions, I've found curly old asian lady hair touching my sandwich. Also, the lady handling the cash/coins is also handling your sandwich. Just try not to think about it when you bite in.

Speaking of coins, here's another annoyance: this place is cash only (which is cool for dodging taxes n stuff), but the lady at the register will bitch you out if you include pennies in your payment. Her exact words were, "No pennies next time. I'm too busy."

No Saigon Sandwich next time. This place blows and doesn't recognize coinage as U.S. currency.


BTW: Vietnam House across the street serves banh mi for cheaper and with less hair
author: David H.

description:
Why did everyone review Saigon Sandwich? Because it's great!  

* Order the roasted pork w/pate - $3.75 + $0.25 extra for pate
* There's no seating, heck, there's barely any standing room in there. 
* They take phone orders.
* The area isn't great, which is probably why they close at 5pm. 
* They do not have a "combination #1" like most Vietnamese sandwich places. 
* If there's a line at Saigon Sandwich, don't get tempted by the Lee's Sandwich right across the street... unless you want spring rolls or iced coffee, both of which Saigon Sandwich doesn't have. 
* Cash only.
author: Rachelle T.

description: Best place for a banh mi in the city. Super cheap, cash only, fast friendly service even though it's always busy. :)
author: Diandra J.

description: Could be one of the best sandwiches I have ever had in my life and having to only cough up $5 to get one? Can't really beat that combination. Only knock on this place is that it closes early. Other than that you can't go wrong with whatever you end up trying.
author: Jethro P.

description:
I had no idea a banh mi sandwich could be this juicy, flavorful, and fully packed with fresh veggies!!! It's most definitely the best one I've ever tried, and will possibly ever will. 

Definitely get the pate, which is an additional $0.25. It's slightly gamey, so stay away if that sounds gross to you. But if that sounds as amazing to you as it did to me, you're in a for a very juicy, fine mess of a delicious experience. And not to mention that bread! So crispy and light as air at the same time.

I also like to ask for some sriracha inside the sandwich for a bit of a flavor dial up.
author: Julie S.

description:
I wanted to try something new so I ordered the fanci pork and ordered my usual combination (pork, pate) -- mmm (also have had just the pork and the pate -- the combo is the best of both worlds!.
Fanci pork is just the white pork that comes in a big chunk and you can slice -- very boring! For future reference for myself, stick to the combination -- it's the best one!
author: Siv L.

description:
I've been here about three times, and two out of those three delivered mouth-wateringly delicious sandwiches. Finger-licking delicious, even! My bread was a bit hard on the third visit, but even angels fall.

I was suspicious of what a tofu banh mi would be like, but was not at all disappointed. There's also a pretty robust assortment of Vietnamese snacks and desserts around, if you'd like a complement to the main attraction.
author: Shendi X.

description:
I didn't believe my cousin when she told me Saigon sandwiches is better than Lee's. 

I tried it for myself, and oh but it is! I usually go with the special combination. 

$4.25 - the 10 inch sandwich is packed with pickled carrots, jalepenos, cilantro, roast pork, steamed pork, pâté and some sort of sauce that makes the whole sandwich that much yummier. 
They also sell taro tapioca pudding and mango tapioca pudding. Both are delicious. They also have some other random Vietnamese desserts. I don't know what they're called. 

There's no where to sit inside but who cares. Get the sandwich, eat it asap. The meat is all nice and warm on a toasted baguette :)

*I've taken my vietnamese friends from Orange County (where everything is vietnamese) here and they said it was the best viet sandwich they've eaten. 

Cousin was right, bestest sandwich ever.
author: Kayla O.

description:
Delicious, inexpensive sandwiches! They are my favorite vietnamese sandwiches and I look forward to them every time. I would give it five stars, except I am subtracting one for cleanliness.

This Saturday, I bought 12 sandwiches from the restaurant. There were 3 women working there and their hair was NOT tied back or in hair nets. My dad found a LONG HAIR as he was eating his sandwich. I found a long hair under the rubber band of another sandwich. 

So 2 out of 12  sandwiches had LONG HAIRS in/on them.

Inspect your sandwiches before eating them! These are cheap and delicious, but not the cleanest sandwiches.
author: Jen L.

description: The best banh-mi in SF.  I swear by this place.  I am sad I moved further away, but every time I am near the TL, we always make a stop.
author: Shaun C.

description:
Line out the door at lunch and high star rating on yelp doesn't always line up to reality. I'm not sure why this place is so popular.. the Banh Mi or vietnamese sandwiches are extremely subpar. They fill the sandwiches with a super gloppy, wet mixture of mushy meat and don't even use proper french baguettes. 

Banh Mi are supposed to be inside crispy, airy baguettes.. not soft, chewy fake baguettes. In addition, the combination banh mi's are supposed to be filled with thinly sliced meat with freshly made picked vegetables and a light coating of pate. 

In my search for authentic bahn mi - sadly I don't think there are any in San Francisco.. most of the good ones are either in East Bay or way South Bay.
author: Henry W.

description:
I've had my fair share of Vietnamese sandwiches, and this place rocks. They don't skimp on the meat or the veggies either, and everything comes stuffed in a French baguette with the usual accoutrements of pickled carrots, jalapeños, and cilantro.

BTW it's only $3.75 for a big ass sandwich (regular), but you should DEF treat yourself to the combo for $4.25 with extra pate. It's worth the extra $.50 cents. Trust me.

Tip: I usually buy 2 or 3 or 4 and save it for lunch the next day (it's just as good when you put it back in the toaster/oven)

PS: They are located in the Tenderloin. Kinda ghetto but not tooooo far from Union Square either. Just avoid making eye contact with the crazys.
author: Cynthia L.

description: This place is far more than meets the eye. Simple, fresh, great value food. We ordered 110 banh mi for an event and they were incredible. Thank you Saigon Sandwich!
author: Phoebe D.

description: Incredible taste at a ridiculous value. Fresh baguette and fresh ingredients. Well seasoned meat. Can't miss for a great lunch. No where to sit. Grab it fast, dodge all the homeless on your way back to the hotel, sit down in your room and enjoy pure and simple blissfulness. Perfection in a fresh bun for $4.
author: Chuck M.

description:
These are phenomenal sandwiches.  Some speak of the size but they are jammed packed with ingredients.

Had the roast pork and combination.  Never had anything like it.  The spreads and pate they use are unique.

The ladies were very nice and kind which was a welcomed sight.
author: James S.

description:
"NEXT! WHAT YOU WANT?"

"Roasted Pork plea..."

"OKAY NEXT!"

*2 mins later*

"ONE ROAS POK! 3 DOLLA 75 CENTS!"

"Here y..."

"THANK YOU NEXT!"


I love this place.

Fast, cheap, and good viet sandwiches. No extra for extra veggies or whatsoever. I recommend Roasted Pork or Tofu. Oh and it's cash only. But it is so cheap so even if you forget if you scrub out the changes you have in your pocket, you'll be able to pay it.
author: Brandon K.

description:
The banh mi is pretty solid--it wasn't to the point that it blew me away or anything, but I can see why it's so highly rated relative to many of the other places in the city. Generous portions of meat and veggies, right amount of sauce, and it all came together pretty nicely. Bread could've been a bit warmer, but otherwise it was fine. Also tried one of the desserts in the fridge (no idea what any of it is called, but I had the green drink one with red bean and jelly things)--it was quite sweet, maybe a bit too much so, but still very affordable.

That said, I feel that this banh mi does not come close to the one I've had outside the city, specifically in Falls Church, VA. Understandable since SF is not so much a Vietnamese enclave. If you're willing to travel, you might consider going down to the south bay and San Jose for an even better selection.
author: Tony D.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwiches in San Francisco. Although they put those really really hot peppers in there I usually take some of them out period but excellent
author: Erin L.

description:
Ouuu wee these sandwiches are good!

I've had my fair share of banh mi since I grew up in Oakland Chinatown, but this is definitely one of the best I've had.

My brother recommended that I check this place out because I was starving in my hotel room and desperate for a bite to eat between lunch and dinner.

I got a roast pork sandwich and it's so interesting. Covered in a bit of mayo and more sauce and a kick of the jalepenos, onions, cilantro, and daikon/carrots, it's pretty darn good.

It's also one of the only places I've been to that STUFFS the bread. THERE IS SO MUCH MEAT. I've only finished halfway and I want to keep eating but now I'm stuffed. 

The ladies are also really nice. I told them in Cantonese I had to try this place out because my brother recommended it and one of the ladies joked back "Why did you only order one sandwich then?"

Coming back for more whenever I'm around! And you should too!
author: Leslie L.

description:
Stopped here for a sandwich while I was in the City. I had the grilled chicken sandwich. I kid you not, it blew my mind. It was the meatiest banh I've ever had! The flavor was outstanding and the service was quick. The vegetables were fresh and the sauce was amazing! If you're in the City and can handle the neighborhood- GO EAT HERE!

Lastly, I got full for $3.75 in San Francisco for lunch.
author: Thomas P.

description:
Delicious bahn mi sandwiches. The meat and veggies are fresh and the sauce makes sure they are flavorful and moist. The tofu is likewise a great addition if you're into tofu.

My only complaint is that the workers don't always seem to understand what I'm asking for.
author: Russell M.

description:
CAN'T BELIEVE I NEVER REVIEWED THIS PLACE.

I loveee coming here for a quick and cheap lunch when I'm around the area. LOVE the banh mi pork combo. I've also tried the banana sticky rice...which was a little heavy for me, but still good.

Next time I want to try one of their viet jelly drinks!!! Every time I come here, I stare at the drinks through the clear sliding doors, yet
author: Jeanette S.

description:
this place is such high hyped! Today, I walked in around 2, and there was only one customer is waiting. The lady who worked here asked what I want and started doing my roasted chicken sandwich right away. 
She didn't toast the bread and started putting all the ingredients on the bahn mi. I got my sandwich in 5 minutes. 

OK. Tastes time. The bread was hard and cold. People who care about their diet or sodium intake, WATCH OUT! I didn't know they spray the mayonnaise on the bread, usually I would ask them don't. The chicken is OKAY. They were a bit salty side. Also, I think like other reviews have mentioned they put too much sauce in the end. The sauce were creamy and flavorful plus the mayonnaise made you don't taste the chicken anymore. Ughhh My Vietnamese bahn mi became an American sandwiches. 

Hm I am not sure I will come back..it's cheap but I had better.
author: Chi Yi L.

description:
Absolutely love this place!! Always a must eat when I come back to SF.

It's ridiculously cheap (still the same price it was years and years ago) and it is so delicious!! 
I came here this weekend and forgot they were cash only. My boyfriend only had 8 bucks but that still got us each a sandwich! When does that ever happen in the city anymore??

The sauce on the chicken banh mi is amazing. I'm not usually a huge fan of chicken options at most places, but it wins my vote here. The pork is also a great option - really well flavored and well cooked but doesn't have the sauce. Pork pate is also phenomenal.

NOTE FOR ALL SPICE WIMPS - the jalapenos will burn your lips/mouth. If you are sensitive to spice, ask them for light jalapenos or none at all.
author: Justine F.

description:
This place is good, especially for the price.
However, I wish there was more variety in the fancy pork banh mi.
I  believe they only have ga.
Add pate for $0.50.

But good crunch to the sandwich. It's stuffed with pickled veggies and meat!
author: Adorable T.

description: Awesome little banh mi spot. Service is quick and sometimes hilariously rushed by the ladies behind the counter. A warning though the sandwiches do taste different after time so they must be consumed immediately like all great foods. Support this business because places like this are disappearing in the Tenderloin!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Hole in the wall located in a less than beautiful part of SF. Kinda sketch, but it's only a half mile from the closest BART station, so maybe around 10 minutes of fearing for your life. Pretty worth it!

Would recommend the special combination sandwich. It includes pate with an assortment of other meats. For those who don't know what pate is, it's chicken liver. Almost spat my food back out when my girlfriend first told me, BUT it's not baddd.
author: David L.

description: The best hole in the wall sandwich shop in the tenderloin. Has vegetarian options. Fair prices. Would come back all the time if i could.
author: Frank Z.

description:
Hard to find, tucked in the corner , right next to parking lot. Saw a door, cash register and blackboard menu. 
Almost no seating area. 

But the sandwiches are TOP NOTCH. Bread is crunchy on the outside and soft inside , freshly baked . The meat , any of them are really delicious and nicely seasoned. The pickles are not so thinly cut , perfectly julienned. 

We always get their sandwiched otw to SF / beach / Marin 
They have good drinks too!!
author: Ans G.

description:
We drove here for a Saturday lunch from the Sunset expecting something quite stellar given the incredible reviews. 

Decent bread, uneven sauce spread,  and very copious amounts of spongy tofu made my sandwich a little subpar, but not bad if you were in a pinch. Lee's Bakery (the banh mi chain) would be a better pick if you had the option. The ladies running this shop are, however, quite endearing in how feverishly determined and efficiently they run the shop. Had our sandwiches in less than a minute from the time we ordered.
author: jon o.

description: Move over and let me in! Just moved to San Fran and been yelping for the best foodie digs in town and today was Saigon Sandwich's turn. This was the best Banh Mi pork sandwich I have had in the U.S. The hype is real, kids- and for 4 dollars? It's going to be a staple, as its 4 blocks away. Onto the next but saved in my favs.
author: Stefano P.

description:
This is a good place for a good cheap lunch! For 3.50 you get a sandwich that's really packed with meat (there is a tofu option), and dried pickled carrots, cilantro, bell peppers, and a big slice of jalapeno. The bread is a perfect compliment for the filling toppings. Yum. Probably the best Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever had. Everything was so good and so filling! Also they have some kind of sauce that makes it pretty messy when you eat. But so good.

This place does get pretty packed though, but the ladies working here are really efficient. You walk in the door and you order, and then you wait for them to call out your order then you pay. The ladies have a good idea of who ordered what so it wasn't so bad. But make sure to give yourself 10-15 minutes of wait time. 

I'll be coming back! 3.50 sandwiches and a satisfied stomach. I don't know what's better than that!
author: Joan T.

description: This place made me feel like I was back in Vietnam! Sandwiches are super cheap at only 3.75, that's unheard of especially in SF. Given that price, I wasn't expecting much but was pleasantly pleased. Each sandwich is about 10 in long, and stuffed with enough meat and veggies to keep you full. I ordered the chicken banh mi and the meat wasn't chewy, overcooked or full of disgusting chicken parts (you know when you order a really cheap sandwich and you get a mouthful of chicken skin, cartilage or tendon--I'm not a fan). There was also plenty of carrot, cilantro and jalapeño stuffed (a bit carelessly) into our sandwiches. I asked for some Sriracha and she really smothered it on there, so my sandwich was a bit too spicy. This place is good and I'll definitely be back, but I wish the vegetables were a bit more pickled.
author: Trena M.

description:
Real bahn mi, at a real bahn mi price. I love this place. The veggies are always fresh and crunchy.

Roast pork.
Pate.
$4 foodgasm.
author: Shane G.

description:
I'm on the fence about this place - between a 3 and a 4. I had high, high hopes for this place because I've heard quite a few people talk this place up. Usually the only reason I'd be in this area would be for Brenda's and by then I'm too full to buy a sandwich, lol.

Onto the review.

$3.75-$4.25 for a sandwich.
The banh mi itself is probably the ONLY banh mi that has actually made me full. It's chock full of filling and the bread is fresh (not hard and stale/stratchy!). The ingredients are fresh (shiet, it better be with that long line!) It's a different tasting banh mi that I've ever ordered. I think it's the sauce they use- some kinda brown teriyaki-ish sauce which I don't think I liked. I prefer just mayo and pate. I like the taste of my usual ones better but that's just me. The price is on par with Sunset and Chinatown prices but it's definitely more filling. I'm not sure I'd crave this sandwich but that's subjective to me but I do see the hype!

One con was the ordering process. There was a long line but it appeared to be for people to receive their orders. I stood in front but the lady didn't acknowledge me with eye contact at ALL! I understand if English isn't your first language but body language is universal. I think they do their orders in batches. Iono. It was kinda confusing for a first timer. After the receiving line was done though she went straight to taking orders again and I prob got my sandwich in 3-4 mins. Total waiting time was 8 mins or so.

Lastly there are a bunch of viet desserts that also look pretty yummy to round off your meal. I didn't get to try it but maybe next time!
author: Emily C.

description: This place not only has good food, but they also have incredibly low prices as well. If you are in the area and want some quick, fast, and cheap food than you came to the right place. Nothing too superb, but for the price you would be missing out if you just walked by
author: David N.

description:
This must be the San Tung of Banh Mi.

Why?

Loved by Yelperz, worshipped by 7x7 and other top 10, best 100 type lists. 

It's a "small business" so it must be hip

There are no other half decent banh mi options around (Balo was closed on Saturday during the Asian Heritage Celebration Street Fair). For sure this place is better than Lee's...but at least makes baguettes in house and is toasty, but they are skimpy.

But I'm guessing their success is due to the fact they serve Sir Mixx A Lot sammies....because it's BIG and PLUMP.  Maybe that's why people love it so much. You like Big Banh Mi and Cannot Lie?

2000++ reviews, so it's gotta be good right?

Or maybe I just don't get it.

The cha lua banh mi was pretty good. Well toasted baguette. A ton of veggies inside, although I felt the vinegared carrots lost their crunch and character. The usual cilantro, jalapenos etc. But the most interesting thing was their....sauce. It was like some aspic....gelatinized broth/stock (either pork bone or chicken with soy sauce). It was really tasty. Maybe if that were heated up into some meatballs and wrapped, it could become some banh mi sauce xiao long bao. Not bad, but can't help but feel something was still missing.

The combo was a horrid mess. The baguette was insufficiently toasted. It seemed like the Vietnamese aunties and grannies (who also speak Cantonese) were trying to force feed the baguette with as much veggies as possible (if the baguette were a goose, I'd be having foie gras by now). There was quite a bit of pate , cha lua, roast pork. This is a monster at $4, but the combo had way too many flavors and textures...in some ways they were clashing. And it didn't help it started to get really soggy inside.  

Ate the cha lua sandwich first. Had I left it at that, would have been fine...but having the combo after that was an overload, and soured the experience quite a bit. Not the greatest move.

This is probably the first banh mi shop I've been to that did not have café sua da (Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk). Doh. At least I got my fix later at Hai Ky Mi Gia (where their iced coffee tastes a bit like liquor...hardcore stuff).
author: Ken K.

description: The Banh mi here is amaaaaaZing!!! The bread is super crispy and the heaps of meat are super generous. Very simple menu with enough options. At $3.75 a pop it's super affordable!
author: Sushie T.

description:
Okay, this place has enough reviews about its sandwiches. Yes they are dirt cheap, yes they are delicious.

But I'm here to talk about something far more important - the thing that I think makes going to Saigon Sandwich just a damn interesting experience.

They have this one short Asian lady always working at the front, and it really just is a spectacle to see her go to work haha. When days are busy and there are long lines, she literally takes your order within 5 seconds, shoos you out of line, and screams at the next person in line. If you aren't paying attention when it's your turn to order, she'll just start screaming at you in her broken English because she's got no time to waste! Seriously, this is efficiency at its greatest. Definitely worth the trip into the loin.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
A friend wanted to get lunch. He has a small budget so we opted to go here. Cheapest banh mi place I've ever been to. And the quality is still great!

Workers aren't exactly super friendly, but it's not like I go there for that. I grab my sandwich (this case, roast chicken for $3.50) and walk back to the park in front of city hall or by the federal building. People watching is interesting for sure. 

Anyway, the sandwich is wonderful. Crunchy French bread roll and authentic fillings. I love their chicken banh mi! My friend had the roasted pork (same price) but it was made slightly messier. Not sure if this has something to do with the fact that I bought something else aside from the sandwich. The roasted pork is still good though, I would recommend. 

I bought the taro pudding dessert thing in their fridge ($2?). No idea what it's actually called but I was excited that it was taro flavor. It tasted just okay though. 

I want more banh mi.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Finally checked out this Saigon Shack. It's pretty much Viet fast food. Lady takes your order, you wait, you pay then go. It was pretty quick that I even risked not paying my meter. 

Pork banh mi was excellent! It's $3.75 and the portion is a bit smaller than others I have tried. But still hecka cheap for a lunch and enjoyed every single bite. 

Whether it is the best banh mi ever... That is debatable. I can't claim it is, for now.
author: Suji C.

description: The combination sandwich ($4.25) is the best banh mi I've ever had. The sandwich comes with a massive load of pate (literally oozing in every bite), a little bit of mayo(?), two to three kinds of pork/ham meat, generous amount of pickled carrots (my fave!), and just the right amount of jalapeños. And the best part? There's never a line when I go :) Don't ever change, Saigon Sandwiches! You are perfect.
author: Annie S.

description:
It is amazing that in today's San Francisco we can get such a delicious and filling sandwich for only $3.75!

I love their tofu banh mi! Don't let their jalapenos fool you, they pack a punch. Service is relatively fast but be ready to wait for your sandwich as there is always a line.
author: Anish B.

description:
I love this place! I would eat their banh mi everyday if I lived closer. They are cheap, amazingly delicious and super fast. I always get the barbecue chicken or pork, they are so juicy and tender. My mouth got watery as I wrote this.

I tried to find a replacement near my work, but I can't ever find one that's as good as this place.
author: Nana K.

description:
3.5 Stars

They have a simple menu: sandwiches (roasted pork, roasted chicken, meatball, tofu & combination).  They have other packaged items such as candy (Hi-Chew & those Panda crackers) and other treats as banana sticky rice.

My husband and I tried ther roasted chicken and roasted pork banh mi.  The sandwich wasn't as warm as I would have hoped.  The french bread was fresh but a bit too thick for me.  I ended up with a lot of bread left over.  The chicken and the pork were seasoned well - both tender.  The sandwich had a good salty, sweet & spicy balance with the pickled veggies & jalapenos.  Overall, a pretty good sandwich.

It is a hole in the wall type of place so don't expect to eat your food here.  Oh...and bring cash.
author: Rose A.

description: So happy to find each visit that this place hasn't gone downhill, or upscale.  The $2 sandwiches are now $3.75 but that's to be expected. Thank God for an alternative to Lee's Sandwiches.  These people know how to run a sandwich shop!
author: tout le monde a.

description:
Yeah, I'm going to have to use some outré analogies for my feelings about this banh mi, so prepare. You know how you feel after a really spectacular orgasm? You aren't quite ready for another one yet, but still have some small aftershocks and feel just sort of puffy and tingly for a while after? And several times during the day as you go about your work, you are still thinking back to that particular session and fondly going over a few of the details in your head? Yeah, this banh mi was the sandwich version of that. After I devoured this thing, I couldn't stop thinking about how good it was and sort of wanting another but knowing that I was too full for it. So many details: the bread slightly crusty but soft inside, the fresh grated carrots, the cilantro, the slow roasted meats, the hints of vinegar somewhere in the sandwich, the slight sweetness coming from some sort of vegetable snuck in the layers, THE SAUCE. And the weird little jar of fruits and what seemed like grass floating in a cup that I got to drink with the banh mi. A perfect lunch. And a real treasure that I found through searching yelp for best Vietnamese food.

One suggestion: this is sandwich chaos here and it needs organization. There should be two lines. Left side to order, once you order move to the end of a line on the right to pick up. The way the sandwich pickup exists now is there are no names, numbers or other ways of figuring out which order is up, people just sort of mill about on the sidewalk not knowing who is next and sandwich thieves such as myself may accidentally grab and pay for what was likely someone else's order...sorry not sorry

2018: tourists should know: this area is overrun with homeless junkies, so if you do not know where you are going, use car service like Lyft to get there and back.
author: Michele D.

description:
Yum Yum Yum
This place is the best :D 
Ask for extra pate! 
They really hook you up with it all the time !
author: Yumi K.

description:
In the context of Asian restaurants, the rule is the dirtier the better. 

Saigon is a little hole in the wall with tons of fillings laid out behind the ordering station. It's not apparently dirty but just feels dirty because it's small and there can be flies. The sandwiches however are on point. I love the pork and chicken but my fav is the combo. 

Don't plan on eating there as there isn't any seating.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
I always see long lines at this place. And in general long lines = good eats. My first time there, I waited with the peeps in line with $3.50 in hand for what I expected to be a great sandwich. Oh boy, was I disappointed. First off, you have to be on your A game as far as situational awareness. This area is sketch. Urine and fecal stuff litter the streets. While waiting, I see a dude stop and take a leak in the middle of the sidewalk. No joke! But I digress, its not fair to review for what is essential not in their control.

Anyone who is a fan of Seinfeld knows about the soup Nazi. Well this is the bahn mi version. Geez. Ordered the chicken and waited outside. 4 min and I had it in hand. Walked back to the office. Folks, the sandwich is good, but not great. Ratios of meat bread and veggies are acceptable. But really nothing that takes my breath away. Except the stench of urine outside.

But if you need a cheap lunch in overpriced SF, this is probably the place to go.
author: Kris P.

description:
Did not feel welcoming but I can deal if the food is worth it. The components complement each other well and here are the highlights. 

I got the pork and it had a good flavor. Unique and not overpoweringly acidic. Cilantro and bell pepper were nice touches and the creamy mayonnaise mixed well with the sweet teriyaki hoisin sauce. 

Since they were closing, it was evident they sold the leftover ingredients I normally hold in high regard. The baguette was stone cold and harder than a San Franciscan brick, meaning it was just brittle enough to break with 90% of maximum force after the crust was removed like the shell of a hard boiled emu egg. The sauce moistened the inside of the roll, but failed to do so for the pork which had a texture similar to rehydrated cuttlefish moreso than cooked meat. 

I can empathize with why people like this place, but it took a lot of deep introspection as well as a new prescription of reading glasses for me to really see that picture. I felt a small town Asian style log living with imported products. Compared to the competition in the surrounding area, I can see by the reviews are so inflated. 

My advice is to get there early and bring cash to this place, just not too much.
author: Holden N.

description:
This review is for the meatball (xiu mai) sandwich and that one only...

I've came, I saw, I conquered. Nicely flavored (and good amount of) meat, soft but crunchy bread, and just the right amount of vegetables. It may take a little bit of time to get your sandwich, but it's definitely worth it. 

If you're in the area, might as well drop by and get one, even if you're not hungry!
author: Andrew C.

description:
What the heo man, I came here and the first bite I took just instantly transported me mentally to the corner of Nguyen Trai and Cong Quynh in SaiGon. I think San Jose and Westminster have a lot of good banh mi but I never realized how distinctly Vietnamese-American they've become until I tried Saigon Sandwich, where it's truly Vietnamese like straight from Vietnam. The pate and pork are delicious, and the peppers have a proper kick to them. The sandwich is friggin huge and cheap too. 

Plus, GREAT SODA SELECTION. If I could give them a sixth star for their old school sodas, I would. I've never craved carbonated sugar water so much as when my eyes glazed over the orangina, strawberry sunkist, cherry 7up, A&W Cream soda and oh so much more. The only black-eye on their selection is that the sole diet-cola they have is the diet RC Cola. Bummer right? Oh well still 5 stars.
author: Monte H.

description:
For $3.75-$4.25 they have some of the best sandwiches EVER. I've tried Balo down the street 3 times before finally never going there again. This place is much cheaper and tastes so much better. Some might complain about the bread, but it is great for me, although it could be better. But for around $4 for lunch, I have no complaints!

PS: Don't give any bums outside money, they'll just keep coming back
author: Da X.

description:
This is straight up the home of the bahn mi nazi. Sandwiches are about $3.50 and boy, was this a great and laughable experience. This place is a dive and so as expected, not the highest quality of meat though the veggies were bright and fresh as can be. Just to reiterate this is not your gourmet bahn mi joint. Come prepared to wait in line and order. Don't ask questions 'cause I did, and boy did I get yelled at/attitude/over charged. Don't even bother asking them to cut the sandwich in half.

Over all this is definitely a hole in the wall, cheap and authentic bahn mi. A solid spot for a to go lunch. Manage those expectations and you'll be a fan!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
For some bomb banh mi, I will absolutely brave the cracked out homeless people of Tenderloin any day of the week.  This humble little sandwich shop is crazy busy, with sassy old Vietnamese ladies hurrying to get people in and out. It's cheap, legit, and extremely filling.  We got the roasted pork banh mi ($3.25) on a big crusty french roll, and it was PACKED to the gills with pickled veggies, jalapeño slices, and juicy, flavorful pork.  A lot of pigs were harmed in the making of this sandwich.  And they were delicious.

Plenty of snacky things, sweets and drinks are available, and since there's not much seating, it's more of a grab and go.  Better yet, call in your order ahead of time and bypass the long lines and scary street walkers!
author: Lorraine P.

description:
BEST BANH MI I HAVE EVER HAD! Trust me, I'm Southeast Asian, I've had a lot.

Pork Sandwich: A little small (in length) compared to what I usually get in So Cal, but it's STUFFED FULL of yumminess so that definitely makes up for the length. The meat is so juicy and flavorful, especially when it's warm! There must be crack in it because it's so addicting. But at the same time, the meat is not sauced or greasy like some banh mi sandwiches. It's just pure pork flavor explosion. Do ask for more cilantro, more pickles, more jalapeno, if you want, although this bad boy is already packed to the brim!

CILANTRO! Tons, I'm in cilantro heaven.

DAT BREAD! @______@  Crispy, soft, warm, fresh, and doesn't tear up your mouth with open sores after you're done eating (true banh mi eaters know what I'm talking about). I can eat this sandwich forever.

Lastly, what makes this place the best! LITTLE OLD ASIAN LADIES! So damn cute I think of my mom!

Small place? Long Lines? Who cares!
author: Steve C.

description:
I don't see how anybody could give this place less than 5 stars.  Its less than 4 dollars for about an 8 inch banh mi sandwich that makes for a perfect lunch.  I got the pork banh mi.  The bread was firm and basically like a baguette.  It held the roasted pork, cilantro, and slaw well.  The pork was very tender, juicy and flavorful.  Its clear that this is a popular destination for local businesses as 2 separate people came in while I was waiting for my sandwich to be prepared who were picking up over 15 sandwiches each (which I assume was for an office).  If more places like this existed, there is no way that subway would exist.

The only drawback of the place is that it is clearly a take out place with limited-to-no seating and in a more sketchy neighborhood.  But it was easy to walk 4-5 blocks to find a nice place to sit and eat.
author: Scott B.

description: I eat veggie/tofu Banh Mi all over the place and Saigon Sandwich is among the tastiest in SF. Two stars off for the shard of broken glass I removed from my mouth that, but for some miracle, I hadn't swallowed.
author: Kramfm M.

description:
Banh Mi for $3.50 in San Francisco is as good as it gets! We walked all the way from the Financial District to get the sandwiches here because, yes, they are that good. They have a good combination of sauces, veggies, and meat (although I wish mine had a little bit more peppers like I requested). 

For the price and the size of the meal, it's perfect.
author: Jess D.

description:
Solid 4 stars:

Pros: great portion size and excellent meat to veggie to bread ratio. Not only was it stuffed with yummy picked veggies but an amazing sauce to complement the meat. Great value for your money!! The meatball and roast pork were our top two!

Cons: please check your order before you leave especially if you order more than 2 sandwiches. We got 4 blocks away to the car with 6 sandwiches before noticing we had another persons order. No biggie if you don't mind going back and getting exactly what you really wanted.
author: Foodie For Life L.

description:
No wonder I'd never found it before - no sign, no address #... the only way I spotted it was from the people outside. Be ready to wait, and be ready to holler your order from down the line. I often heard people ordering two and three sandwiches at a time with customizations, which meant they'd been here before.

The prices probably can't be beat. $3.50 each, although my sandwich was a little smaller and more fatty than other local renditions. The two "expensive" options were the $3.75 thit cha (steamed + roast pork) and the $4.00 thit cha pate ("special combination", perhaps steamed + roast pork + pate).

The menu has no further information than each sandwich's Vietnamese name, English name, and price. Other than the main meat (or tofu), you don't know what you're getting unless you're familiar with their sandwiches or Vietnamese sandwiches in general. It sounded like they use mayonnaise rather than the historical Vietnamese x French spread.

They also have a bunch of other foods and drinks laid out for sale, many of which are unnamed mystery items, kind of like the entire storefront itself. What was also a mystery to me is why I only saw one glove despite more than one hand of more than one person assembling the sandwiches.

Note that their hours have changed:
Mon-Sun *7:30* am - 5 pm
author: Dan B.

description:
On the basis of a cheap gem among the many expensive choices of eateries San Francisco offers, this spot right here is definitely one of the best. 

Came here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon, probably like 1:30ish. Upon my arrival, this little hole-in-the-wall was not packed at all, nice and quiet. Took a quick look at the menu, a really straightforward one, and saw that each sandwich was $3.75 and I was mothafuckin ecstatic. One of the ladies behind the counter pointed my way and I shouted out "meatball pork" and she got to it, the best way I've ever ordered food. Took a couple minutes too to make the thing, which was another bonus.

The sandwich itself was pretty fat. They were real generous about the insides. I saw the lady herself pack my shit too, it was glorious. Not the long and slim banh Minhs I'm used to but I wasn't trippin. Took a seat at their little window setup (not much of a sitdown) and went to town. With the first bite, I noticed how crunchy the roll was, real crunchy actually, but it wasn't that burnt crunchy, something in between. If we wanna get real meticulous, my chompers had to work a little extra. Y'all with that weak chomp game, this spot ain't for you. Nevertheless, I got a good ass first bite and boy was it flavorful. Specifically the pork, that shit was juicy, succulent, and just overall GOOD. There were some visible pork meatballs in the sandwich but I think the rest crumbled away. I wasn't trippin though; that shit was tender goodness. The freshness of the veggies brought the whole thing together, and man that sandwich was HELLA good. All for $3.75 too? I'll definitely be back, prolly like next weekend! Come and get y'all a good ass banh Minh!
author: Kameron S.

description: superb hole in the wall Viet Namese sandwich shop serving maybe 5 different kinds of subs or bahn mi. Very simple menu...this AIN'T the Cheesecake Factory big boy. They CRUSH at these items...pros at making a GREAT sandwich in under 90.seconds for under 4 bucks...cash only sweetheart. It rocks!
author: Mustapha C.

description:
I lost my banh mi virginity to Saigon Sandwich

On my trip to the USA last summer, Lolia S took me to her favourite banh mi joint in town and I believe, her favourite in the USA. The whole experience was made more exciting by the fact that Saigon Sandwich is located in one of the shadier parts of town, so we parked up, zipped in, ordered and zipped out as quickly as possible before taking our spoils to enjoy in the more sedate surroundings of Japantown

The place is small and we were lucky that the line wasn't too long - I hear that it can be frighteningly long sometimes. However, the ladies serving were working like dervishes nonetheless, churning out sandwiches at an impressive rate

I was super-excited to take my first bite of this legendary Vietnamese sandwich and I could see straighaway why this French-Asian fusion concoction is so popular. Crusty bread, creamy pate and mayonnaise, crunchy, sour pickled vegetables and warm soft meat all add up to a perfectly balanced mouthful of heaven

I don't have any other banh mi references to compare against but I enjoyed every single bite of that banh mi sandwich. I hope I haven't been spoilt by Saigon Sandwich and that it's all downhill from here!

Thanks, Lolia S!
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Best Bahn Mi sandwich in the mother fucking city, at the best price for $3.75. Cash Only, this shit is Authenticcc as fuck I try to come here at least once or twice a month absolutely satisfying to the T
author: Sophie Z.

description:
After demolishing a large bowl of chicken pho, I found myself still a little hungry.  I know one shouldn't eat so many meals in one day, but when you find yourself in an area of 5 star restaurants it's time to be a little more adventurous.  

The pho ga at Turtle Tower is simple and clean.  Saigon Sandwich was the perfect contrast.  Meaty, crunchy bread and lots of fresh vegetables.  

The line out of the door was an expected sight (even at 2 pm) but the ladies who run this hole-in-the-wall establishment are efficient and organized.  I really expected a much larger storefront like Huong Lan or Thanh Huong in San Jose, so was surprised at how small this place was (really with only 1 seating space).....expect to take your order to-go.

I decided to go for the 7x7 Top 100 Things to Try in SF recommended roast pork sandwich, but that felt a bit safe, so I added pate for an even more sumptuous sammy.  

To be honest, I wasn't able to eat the sandwich til almost 2 hours later after walking a bit in Union Square, but it was still excellent.  The bread, rather than soft or too crunchy, was a perfect mixture of both.  The pate was spread generously throughout the sandwich and the roast pork was tender and delicious. 

It's too bad this place is so busy or I'd order to-go orders everytime I drove by the area.  At $3.75 for a sandwich, the prices just can't be beat.

Saigon's Sandwiches are cash only and are a significant upgrade over the nearby Lee's Sandwiches or any other Vietnamese sandwich chain that you've had.
author: Randy F.

description: Sandwiches are truly authentic.  The roasted pork is by far my favorite! Just a heads up that it's cash only!  There are also other vietnamese snacks/desserts available
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Staff is friendly and very fast. Great for a rushed lunch but please stick to the chicken sandwich.
I wish I never tried the pate sandwich for all of our sake. 
A MUCH better quality and hygienic Viêt sandwich-shop nearby is cafe dolci across equinox on market street.
author: Rayan D.

description:
I don't usually find myself in this part of the city but if I had to think of a go-to place to grab lunch in the area this would be it. Nice and quick place to get a vietnamese sandwich for a decent price! From memory they have tofu, pork, chicken, pate, and combo options.

I came here around 11:30am and there was no line! I was in and out within less than five minutes. I opted for the combo ($4.25) since I do like pate and the pork. Pickled veg, cilantro, and jalapeno seem to be standard so just let them know beforehand if you don't like those. There are literally two window seats so seating isn't exactly a given. Cash only.

Definitely worth checking out if you like bahn mi sandwiches and if you're itching to find out why this place has 2.5k reviews.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Cash only.  Saigon Sandwich makes good Vietnamese sandwiches.  They recently remodeled, but it still looks kinda dumpy.  They speak Cantonese to each other, & they can speak English too.  They probably know Vietnamese, but not sure.

I got a Steamed Pork/Roast Pork sandwich $3.50.  It took a while because there were about 4 people ahead of me.  Sandwich is tasty.  Next time I'll ask for Extra Pate.

They close at 5pm now.  So sad.
author: Ann L.

description: By far the best banh mi I've had in San Francisco. The pork was tender,the greens crunchy, and the picked carrots delicious. The sauce brought the whole thing together and was proportionate to the amount of meat and bread. My only complaint is the area where they are located. Saigon is located in a more run down part of town with many shelters in the area. I did not feel safe walking through some areas towards the shop and I was berated by several vagrants along the way. I do not mean to put anyone down because of their situation but their actions towards me made me uncomfortable.
author: Caleb J.

description:
The quickness in which they serve you deserve 1 star.

The quality of the meat and crispness to the bread earned this place 2 more stars. 

But next time I will order the vegetables in a separate bag because the ratio they include on the Sandy are not indicative of a true Bahn mi. 70/30 rule meat to veggies. 

Also the veggies are waaaaay to cold. 

3/5 stars.
author: Charles P.

description:
Probably the best banh mi spot in SF. 

Don't waste your time on those overpriced hipster chain places that have been popping up lately.

Stopped in on my way back from work and ordered the roast pork. I was out the door sandwich in hand in under five minutes. 

Did I mention it was only $3.75 for the sandwich? My BART fare cost more than that!

The sandwich itself was amazingly filling and flavorful. Plenty of everything, all of it fresh, and I could taste each ingredient  both by itself and combined with everything else.

The only negative about this place is the kinda skeevy location and the fact that they only have three or four eat-in seats.

Definitely coming back here more often!
author: Graham H.

description:
ALL VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES SHOULD BE LIKE THIS

The sandwiches are PACKED with meat & veggies. The bread is baked at the place, so it's always fresh. The lil ole Vietnamese ladies just stuff the sandwich like there is no tomorrow. I don't think I ever had a Vietnamese sandwich this stuffed with meat & veggies. Very popular, and sometimes there's a line, but hey a sandwich for $3-4, yes please! The combo with patay sandwich tasted great as well!
author: Lisa W.

description: One of the best, most inexpensive lunches I've ever had. For $3.75 you get a delicious Vietnamese sandwich. I had the roast pork was was great. Given there was no one else waiting, I received my sandwich almost immediately upon ordering.
author: Mike J.

description: Wished I'd doubled up on the sandwiches...they were delish...ordered the chicken sandwich with extra hot peppers.  The ladies crank those sandwiches out in lightning speed.  The bread was warm and crispy yet soft - filled with lots of fresh veggies, flavorful chicken and generous spread of the sauce - creating a harmonious balance in every bite.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Got excited by the positive reviews, so I literally walked the whole mile for what turned out to be a big disappointment.

First off, the bread is not baked right. It is coated with a thin layer of sugar/honey to give it a nice complexion, but that was burnt off and hence the bitter taste. The bread is thick, which is nice when warm but hard to manipulate with your jaws when eaten after 10 minutes.

The carrots/daikon pickles tasted as if they were made of sugar. Too sweet. Killed the taste of everything else.

I ordered the meatball (xíu mi) and the fancy pork (ch la). The meatball pork was nowhere close to exceptional, by which I mean one can easily make at home. While the fancy pork is a bit better, the sugar pickles prevented me from completing the sandwich.

In short: subpar subs. Definitely not up to "Saigon" standards.
author: Ch E.

description: I ordered the dac biet, it was too sweet for me and the bread was very chewy. My favorite banh mi still comes from Oakland Chinatown. It wasn't worth walking through the TL for it.
author: Briget P.

description: Been here for almost 10 years and the quality has not changed. Always a line but it moves quickly. The 2 women who run this place got the system down to the tee. My favorite Banh Mi. If you're going to take a few home to eat later, ask them to separate the veggies so the sandwich won't get soggy.
author: Eddy C.

description:
I haven't reviewed this place yet? 

This is the best Vietnamese sandwich in San Francisco. 

There is nothing else to be said.
author: Justin S.

description: Best Saigon sandwich I have ever tasted. Keeps me coming back or dreaming about it until I can get my fix! Lol
author: Lucy R.

description:
On the go.Best be on the go! 
No place to sit and eat in this joint,or anyplace near it. 
The hood smells like piss, cardboard boxes in every every shadow.

They are super nice.
The sandwich is great. 
The BBQ Pork is full of flavor.

Super, simple and effective at $3.75 each
2 pork.
2 canned drinks.
Under ten.

Totally delicious.
author: Ben M.

description: I am Vietnamese and I approve of this place!!! It's authentic, cheap, and delicious! They don't skimp on the carrots, cilantro, or meat. You can't go wrong with any of their sandwiches. Best to order and eat elsewhere since the neighborhood isn't the safest and the store is very small.
author: Logan N.

description:
Delicious and nicely-packed sandwiches to go. 

This place is tiny and there is no real place to sit down, so only come for takeout. 
I ordered the special combo Banh Mi and in a few minutes I was gleefully enjoyed a very tasty sandwich. The sandwiches are around 4 bucks and are nicely packed with meat, the usual veggies, and some nice slices of jalapeno. 

I also tried one of their pork buns. It had a good amount of ground pork filling and to my surprise there was also some Chinese sausage and half a boiled egg inside! Pretty filling for less than $2.

I''ll definitely be coming back sometime soon to pick up some sandwiches for nice picnic in the city.
author: Augusto T.

description: $3.75 fully loaded sandwich. This place lives up to its reviews. As hole in the wall as it gets. No english. Small lunch board. Just tell them what you want and wait when they yell it out. Not organized at all, but you won't be disappointed.
author: Kaila L.

description:
Tiny hole in the wall, in a neighborhood that was a notch above McAllister & Turk in shadiness.  There was a short line (5 people deep) with the counter ladies keeping things moving quickly.

The Special Combination Sandwich made it all worth it!  It had fancy pork, pate, and maybe some for of creamy / slightly sweet sauce?  The whole sandwich is an interesting burst of flavors (pate, pork, carrots, slightly spicy jalapeno, sweet and creamy and savory) and textures (crunchy carrots, creamy pate, and nice bite to the meat).  I usually like Banh Mi and this was unlike any other Banh Mi I've had -- just one big smorgasboard of flavor and textures stuffed into a big roll.
author: Kathryn C.

description: Had the most delicious Tofu Banh-Mi ever. And such great value for money! Highly recommended.
author: Parul G.

description:
It's good. It's cheap. It's fast. It's line out the door at 10am on a Tuesday. It's $3.75 for a banh mi that satisfies. 

I don't have the slightest idea if it's authentic. Where I grew up the Italian family was what passed for diversity; and I've never been to Vietnam, so WTF do I know about that? But I do know that for less of the price of a big mac I can get a freaking great sandwich from two little old ladies who bust their asses to feed the multitudes. I can get down with that. And it's so freaking good. SO FREAKING GOOD. 

Oh and shrimp chips, y'all. SHRIMP CHIPS!!!!!!111!!

So when your hipster friends yammer on about delicious $5 toast or the new patchouli IPA they're homebrewing and how Saigon Sandwich is played out or overhyped or whatever, just nod along. That's less people in line at Saigon Sandwich. Less people between you and the nommy yum yums served there.
author: Jacob R.

description:
Why did you guys change your pate and start skimping me!?

$4 for the combo now 

*sigh*

And you gave me cilantro 

BUT WHY CHANGE THE PATE!?
author: Susy C.

description:
I lived right above this incredible purveyor of sandwich gold for a year when a Tofu Banh Mi was $3.25. This is the place that I measure all other Banh Mi against.

The bread is crisp but soft, the tofu is flavorful, the do chua tastes fresh and sweet. It really doesntget any better than this! 


For vegan tofu sandwiches, make sure to ask for no "chicken sauce"
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I realized I write a lot of crabby reviews - especially about the Tenderloin- so I wanted to highlight one of my favorite places in the neighborhood. 

Saigon Sandwich is a small Vietnamese mom and pop shop specializing in Bahn Mi and other take out items. There's always a line out the door and no where to sit (hence the 4 stars), but the sandwiches are to die for. Don't be fooled by the new trendy Bahn Mi place up the block- this is the real deal. It's cheap and delicious. Good bread, ample meat and toppings, great spicy flavor. Last time I checked it was $3.75 for a sandwich. THREE SEVENTY FIVE.  Go to there.
author: Sarah T.

description: The hype is real.  Easily the best banh mi I've ever had.  Their sauce is heaven.  I tend to eat vegetarian, and their tofu sandwich really was great.  It was pretty large too - I ate half for breakfast and finished the other half with lunch.  Solid prices, quick, and an all around great restaurant in SF.
author: Zach S.

description: Unless it's truly horrible, how can anyone complain about a $3.75 sandwich nowadays? Especially when they are so generous about their meat! I ordered two roast pork sandwiches. Though I thought the roast pork was a little on the sweet side, overall it was very good. The bread was crunchy and toasted right in front of me, meat and pickled carrots very generous, yummy sauce, and great on the cilantro and jalapenos as well. AND the service as extremely quick. I'm going to try their other meats next time, but I'm looking forward to coming back.
author: Carol A.
