description: Delicious, cheap and packed with typical banh mi ingredients (meat, carrots, cilantro, jalapeños). The ladies at Saigon Sandwich don't skimp and are the most efficient people ever - you'll be in & out (unless there's a line, but even then it's fast). Still, we ordered over the phone and quickly picked up the sandwiches from the TL on a lazy Saturday afternoon. My chicken banh mi was yummy, but I was definitely feelin' jealous of my partner's combination sandwich. That pate is fantastic.
author: Aradhana V.

description:
Tasty, inexpensive sammiches. Cash only (surprise, surprise).

Much like a crack addict[1], I absolutely had to stop back in for a sandwich. Their special combo remains my favorite in the region, with a crunchy baguette full of trimmings, packed full of meat. One sandwich makes the perfect light lunch; two call for a siesta.

[1] My friend and I watched an actual[2] crack addict steal from their tip box. If you're going to tip and the staff aren't terribly busy, hand them your tip directly.
[2] She probably was one, we don't know for sure.
author: Dave L.

description:
Every year, I travel to the Bay Area with a group of 35-40 teenagers (yes, because I'm crazy). I endeavor to expand their culinary horizons while we're there, but within the limitations of a pretty tight budget. Enter Saigon Sandwich.

Most of them have never had bahn mi before they come on the trip, and in the several years I've been taking them here, I've only had one or two who weren't crazy about it.

The sandwiches are tasty and filling and ridiculously cheap.  The cilantro and carrots and peppers are fresh and crunchy and delicious.

The downside, of course, is the lack of seating. I pick up the sandwiches and take them to a park or something for them to eat.

If you're looking for an inexpensive, delicious lunch, you can't beat Saigon.
author: Dara M.

description:
PROBABLY THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH I HAVE EVER EATEN. 

It took almost 45 minutes just to order and wait for my combination sandwich but it was completely worth it. The sandwich was fat and filled with meat, carrots, and salad. Every bite I took had a burst of flavor and it satisfied my cravings so much! I even wanted another one!!!

It is on a one way street so be sure to scope out parking spots right and left so you don't have to keep circling around.

I tried their pork sandwiches and wasn't that impressed. Always order combination!
author: Lauren K.

description:
It's alright. I still think Lee's is better.

Cash only.

Got the special pork and the roasted pork. The roasted pork was definitely better than the special pork, but still nothing to get all excited about.

It's cheap though, so I guess that is a plus.
author: Hazel J.

description:
I wasn't a believer and thought it nearly impossible that a city like San Francisco could have good Vietnamese anything; but my friend, who is a native of San Francisco, swears by this place so I had to give it a go. 

I got a little taste of each of their very popular sandwiches: roasted pork with pate, pate and butter, and sieu mai (meatball) and pate. All I have to say is that these sandwiches are incredibly good! Their homemade pate is slightly on the saltier side for my liking, but it's balanced with their pickled veggies (also homemade) and soft bread. The meats were extremely rich and hearty, which left me pretty darn satisfied considering I'm only eating a sandwich. Their sandwiches were about $3 each, which I think is pretty standard.

I'd really love to come back to try their chicken sandwich...
author: Lien T.

description:
Ventured to this awesome place b/c of Instagram. I was parked at Wells Fargo and walked a couple blocks down on Larkin. It was early in the morning and I didn't want to leave SF without trying the best banh mi in town.

As I walked in I was greeted by 3 Vietnamese ladies. They were prepping for a busy day. I ordered the roast pork banh mi ($3.50). I couldn't wait to take a taste of it! I told myself I'd take one bite and head back to Sacramento. Boy.. I was wrong!! I couldn't get enough of the delicious sandwich!!

It had everything you would expect in a banh mi sandwich. But the meat made all the difference. It was very juicy and they packed the sandwich with lots of it. I just wished I left with more than one sandwich. 

Next time, I would like to try the tofu banh mi. 
Best banh mi I've ever had!
author: Karla Marie D.

description: If I was basing this on taste alone this would probably be 4 stars or maybe even 3.5 stars. It seemed like they used a couple different sauces (mayo and something else, dang it I should know this considering my parents were born in Vietnam) which complemented each other well. Tofu texture was something new to me, in a good way that while definitely nowhere near real meat emulated it better than regular tofu. However, I personally like my bread crunchier, and the carrots could have had more vinegar to them (and this is coming from a guy who normally doesn't really like vinegar). Those critiques seem inconsequential when you hear the cost: $3.75 including tax. You get a roughly 6-inch sandwich that is both more filling and cheaper than Subway's 6-inch, so even if you didn't factor the quality and the SF competition it would be a not too shabby deal. However, a non fast food sandwich in SF is normally going to be at least double the price and probably on average a little lower quality. Basically, I haven't found anything out there yet that can even compete with Saigon Sandwich on even 2 of the 3 things I think it excels at, let alone all 3: low price, quality, and filling without making you feel sick.
author: Alan B.

description:
I love Saigon Sandwich. I've been a fan for over a decade. However, the new employees are not abiding by health code. 

The cashier was making sandwiches and collecting money simultaneously. She did not wash hands or wear gloves between changing jobs. I know that it is busy here, but it's important to use clean practices. I don't want to get sick or have other patrons get sick. Cash is not clean! 

Please Saigon Sandwich owners, instruct new employees on health code laws. I am a huge fan of your business and don't want your business to go down the drain. You all work so hard!
author: Ellie J.

description: One of the biggest attraction is the cheap price. Maybe I had high expectation but I found the banh mi ok. I had better ones in the City.
author: Anna C.

description:
i love this place!.. the choices are simple and every one of them is great, except i wish they would go back to the bread rolls they used to use!  those were soft and chewy and let you enjoy the filling as the centerpiece of the sandwich. 

the rolls they use now are heavy and dense and you end up chewing the bread more than the filling...  it gets tiring for my jaw!  please bring back the softer banh mi!
author: dee c.

description:
I've actually tried to come here 3 separate times with no success.  I just can never get here in time.  No worries, I just end up at turtle tower down the street.  

I was in the area for brunch and actually stopped here first.  Not happy about the fact that several homeless people were soliciting while we were in line, and then entered the shop and sat down.  The owners then shewed then away.  We were talking to some people in line with us and they were making their second trip in 2 days.  This means it has to be good.  Seriously though, San Jose has some great Vietnamese sandwiches...the bar is pretty high here.

We got the meat ball which was so tasty.  This place is amazing, and speedy too.  We ended up going back the next day to try the pork and the pate.  Both fabulous, but I think the meat ball is my favorite here.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I found out about this place when I stayed in a hotel nearby.  The neighbourhood is a bit sketchy, but the food is worth the courageous trek to "Little Saigon."  The one thing that stands out about this place besides their amazing sandwiches is their unbelieveable prices.  I paid only $3.50 for one of their roasted chicken Banh Mi sandwiches - the best part of the sandwich is the fresh and spicy jalepenos and the lovely taste of the cilantro.  These two ingredients create an incredible fusion on your palate.  Saigon Sandwich does it best though bringing out the full flavors of these two ingredients.  

This is one of those places that you can come to early in the morning to prep for your afternoon lunch or dinner; they are open at 7:30 AM.  I truly love this place.  The New York Times article on this place was right.  It is definitely a must eat if you are in San Francisco or America!
author: Nancy S.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwiches in SF. Though the price for the BBQ chicken sandwich has almost doubled, it's still only $3.75. Fresh meat, vegetables and warm French bread.  Huge output from a tiny place in the Tenderloin.
author: Richard D.

description: Got the special combination and it was amazing.  Probably the best I've ever had.  Bring cash and plan to eat somewhere else.
author: Scott B.

description: i hope this little mom and pop banh mi place stays here forever. The banh mi is cheap, delicious, and they make banh mis at an incredible rate. I ordered 14 banh mis, and they were ready in less than 15 minutes. I'd go with the pork here as the chicken is not as delicious as the pork.
author: Derrick W.

description:
Saigon Sandwhich was the first Vietnamese sandwhich I ever had. That was about 5 years ago and since then I have tried other spots. Both in Long Beach and in San Francisco and this spot beats them all in taste and in price! The ladies that work/run this spot are admirable. They work extremely hard and efficiently and keep the line moving. 

This spot isn't a dine-in spot-it's simply a quick get in and get out with the best deal in town!
author: Judith G.

description:
3.75 $ a sandwich ??? Whatttt??? If you are hungry and broke, Saigon Sandwich will fill you up for under 5 $. That been said, the bread is small not a huge bun but it's filled so much with the meats that it can't hold it in. It's messy as hell. 

Now to the actual taste well, after wanting to try vietnamese sandwiches for a while now, R & I finally did it. We had the chicken the roast pork and the steam pork and roast pork combo.  Our least favorite was the chicken one, it was a little to greasy for our taste. The other two were fine. 

We weren't absolutely amazed by the sandwiches, but a great deal for what you pay.
author: Tamara S.

description:
If there's a better Bánh mì for this good of a deal anywhere else in SF - I don't know of it. For $4 you get a stacked sandwich that is better than the rest. 
You need to walk through a pretty seedy area to get there; and there's no seating inside or out but... it's an amazing sandwich. I promise you won't be sad if you go here. SO. GOOD.
author: Chuck R.

description: preordered sandwiches at 8 in the morning for our Alcatraz tour. Never thought i'd want to eat this thing this early but the smell was AMAZING. Held on till lunch time and the sandwich was still awesome. It's got some legit substance.. PACKED with pork and carrot, some jalapeno and fancy pork pate. YUM. also super cheap! will definitely be back.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Fast and efficient even though you see a huge line. It looks a bit confusing when you walk in to pay because the place is so small. Chicken sandwich was delicious! One of the better places I've been :)
author: Allyson L.

description:
Looked it up in Yelp and made our way down for a late breakfast / early lunch. It's a bit of a hole in a wall with only two window bar seats available, but the food more than makes up for it. We had the roast chicken and fanci (with an "i") pork banh mi. With every bite, we were more and more convinced these were the best banh mi's we've ever had. The roast chicken was flavored so well with just enough pepper and kick and still super tender. The sauce added to the sandwich only added to accentuate the flavor of both the fanci pork meat and the chicken. The veggies were pickled perfectly; not over powering and tasted super fresh. The bread was also very crispy without being hard.

Definitely going back next time!
author: Ian C.

description:
If you are looking for a traditional bahn mi sandwich, go NO WHERE ELSE. Cash only. Always stand in the line. No seating. Pork, all the way. 

Even if you are just in San Francisco for a little and want a local or dive food experience, go here. The chef barely speaks English, actually she may only know how to say different meats in English. It's so good.
author: Wendy K.

description:
This is the best Bahn Mi in the city. Hands down. And they somehow manage to sell it for ~ $4!? Absolutely ridiculous.

I stopped by here while biking through the city, and after eating my roast pork sandwich I had to go back to get another one for the road. They heap your roll with mountains of pork, and with the addition of cilantro, peppers, carrots and some sort of magic sauce you will wonder why you don't live right next door so you can have this sandwich for every meal.

The shop itself is pretty small and takeout only. While making each sandwich is pretty fast, they usually don't have more than 1 or 2 people manning the counter at any point in time. So be prepared to wait a bit during rush hours. They also have different selections of meat (chicken, meatball, fancy pork) that completely change the taste of the sandwich (since it is already so simple). Try them all out!
author: Dennis R.

description:
Food
Combination Banh mi, it's good but fed can't compare to vietnam's fresh bread rolls 
 

Service 
Nice ladies. Opens early!!! Can grab for breakfast. Of course cash only 



ATMOSPHERE
super tiny only for Togo. In middle of TL
author: Angela L.

description:
Sitophilia: sexual arousal from food. 

Now I'm not saying that I necessarily get turned on by these sandwiches,  but they are so good that I would consider a FWB situation with one if it meant getting to eat them daily. I guess what i'm saying is that they are so good that I would probably make love to them.
author: M F.

description:
I got the tofu bahn mi and it was good. $3.75 for a large, flavorful sandwich. The tofu has great flavor, in fact I questioned that it was actually tofu multiple times while eating it, but it's slightly more oily than I'd like. I like the veggie bahn mi from Fresh Brew Coffee in Nob Hill better because it has fresher ingredients and it's as oily (although they do have a mayo-like sauce), but it's also more expensive, $5 for the veggie. 

The service was great, the ladies made our sandwiches in less than a minute. 

5 stars for the service, portion, and price, 4 stars for the sandwich. 

They also have a great selection of asian snacks.
author: Maleenee B.

description: From Vietnam town in LA to South San Jose, no one beats this place. Meat? GOOD! Bread? Good! Pate spread? Good! Price? Good! Meat stuffed to the brim? Good! I bought 10 sandwiches once to bring home and ate it over a course of a few days. Breakfast, lunch and dinner, all covered with delicious and cheap sandos from Saigon Sandwich.
author: Loan L.

description: I don't care how good the sandwiches are here.  This place is dirty as fuck.  I found a long, pube-y looking hair deeply embedded in my pork meatball sandwich.  Immediately lost my appetite after that.
author: David C.

description: I've been frequenting this place for many years but never wrote a review.  Not much has changed which is a good thing.  They are consistent and you know what you're going to get from a customer service and food quality standpoint.  No frills, just simple banh mi's that are to the point and very reasonably priced.
author: Landon Y.

description: Cheap! Tasty! Fast! Efficient! Don't let the area scare you.  If you are near by definitely stop by. They only have 5 sandwich choices and that's it!
author: Michael T.

description:
Probably the best banh mi I've ever tried. The french baguette is fatter than usual, toasted to obtain that chewy and just-on-the-cusp-of-crunchy texture, and filled to the brim with roasted pork and pickled veggies. Packed with so much thinly sliced tender pork, my banh mi could barely fit the pickled carrots and dikons, both of which added the perfect crunchy texture as well as a refreshing sourness to the sandwich.

My cilantro and jalapenos were abandoning ship though, and I had to coerce them back to their rightful places with some forceful jabs. The jalapenos added a touch a heat. I didn't have too much cucumber or dikon in mine, but at 3.75$ who am I to complain? The only suggestion I have is to skip the fancy pork and stick with the actual meat items like chicken or roast pork or a combo.

Though I had to take my order 3 times and still ended up with four banh mis instead of two... I don't think I can or will complain about getting four banh mis instead of two.
author: Chia L.

description: Delicious, fresh, simple, cheap, fast service. No where to sit. The sandwich doesn't easily get soggy, and flavor is on point. Minimal variety -they stick to what they are good at. The options are roast chicken, roast pork, pate, pork meatballs and fanci pork. The roast pork was excellent $3.75
author: Ron M.

description:
Really good bahn mis here, I don't know if I'd say they're the best in the city but for the price at $3.50 a sandwich it is definitely a hard deal to beat!

The sandwiches themselves are on toasted baguettes, the meat is grilled and really tasty
But my favorite part of the sandwich is the pickled veggies and the cilantro they put on top of the meat, this part can make or break the sandwich for me but they do it well here. You can get two sandwiches for $7 and have an awesome meal.

This place is the definition of a hole in the wall joint, the Vietnamese ladies that run this place crank out sandwiches as fast as they can which from what I've seen is pretty quick, and every time I've gone there has been a line out the door. Just make sure if you come here you plan on a short wait and that you being cash! They only accept cash!
author: Zach C.

description:
Amazing. Really is as good as it gets.

Saigon sandwich took a little bit of hunting down. For a place with such a huge following on yelp, it's literally a tiny rectangular sign behind many others, marking an establishment not that much larger than a moderately sized bedroom. Probably less.

It's not sanitary in the least. I should probably warn you, random peruser, of that now. But the food is dirt-cheap, even by my standards (and I come from a place where the COL isn't nearly as toasty as SF) at roughly $3.75 a go for a sandwich roughly the same size as a subway 6''.

I got a chicken banh mi, and it was pretty much wonderful. The chicken....is, well, straightforward, but the sauce they put on it - I don't know if it was soy sauce and I was placebo'd out the door - really sells the whole affair. It's kind of thick, has a zing to it, and altogether made my day. Then you have your carrots, peppers, greens etc...

It was a reasonably filing bite, and I'm almost assuredly coming back here again. I normally do the entire picture routine with a lot of my food, but I scarfed this one down before I even realized I had a pre-chowdown task to do. As far as service goes, I was in and out of there in a bit under a minute and a half. Not much in that department. 

Try it!
author: Rohan Y.

description:
Pros: 
Delicious and cheap.

Cons: 
Very crammed space to eat it there.

Food Experience:
We saw this on yelp and it looked sketch but we went and it was SO delicious. Maybe it was the morning or it was that very long walk to broadway to find a park with some benches but it was very good. I didn't want the taste to end. However don't get your drink here just go somewhere else cuz it was $1.50 for a snapple.

Conclusion:
I completely recommend it here!
author: Irving B.

description:
Went here today after having it bookmarked for months. They only have a few options and we decided on the roast pork plus the combo based on other yelp reviews. 

I would say I'm well versed on Vietnamese food because I am from seattle. This was not what I was expecting and I won't be back. I tried a bite or two of both sandwiches and let my boyfriend finish them. There was too much mayo, not enough spice, and it was super salty. 

I think I will still with my grilled pork bahn mi from elsewhere for now...
author: Anne K.

description:
THE BANH MI HERE ARE HELLA GOOD!!!

I came here on a Monday morning when they just opened (yes at 7), they were just opening and they still had bags of bread (I'm assuming they don't bake it themselves) and were just toasting it. I ordered 2 different kinds, 1 with cha and other just meat (no idea just from what I remember on the board). Ladies were quick, friendly and not stingy on anything. For both it was just 6.50, so 3.25 each. That's how much they are nowadays everywhere else, and man this place is super worth it! Everything was perfect, the bread (even though mine wasn't warm or toasted, it was still good!), the veggies (didn't see any daikon in mine just carrots, which made it sweeter), the spread (mayo, pate, and something else. soy sauce?), and the meat. Everything just worked wonderfully together. And it still tasted delish a day later in the fridge (not soggy or anything).


This place is really a hole in a wall, you will probably miss it (like i did) if you don't pay attention. It's on the right hand side (one way street). Glad my friend told me about this place and challenged me by telling me it's the best! it's not the best i have ever had, but It's totally top 3! they know how to balance things out and where ever they buy their bread, i hope they don't change.
author: Lena T.

description: You can't beat the prices of this place! It's $3.75 for a substantial sandwich. While there's often a line, it moves quickly. It's worth the short wait. I recommend the Pork, but you definitely can't go wrong with anything they have. They also have an assortment of Asian drinks and snacks to go with the sandwich. Cheap, fast, delicious, filling. Highly recommended.
author: Neil T.

description: Ordered the pork and chicken sandwiches, they were good, the meat had great flavor, as for the veggies, the carrots were soggy, the jalapeno slices were dried out and lacked freshness. Woman at the counter was somewhat rude, but no biggie.
author: Erica G.

description:
$3.50 for a pate and pork sandwich? FUCK YES

Places like this are why I miss California so much... I'm still looking for a place that makes as good a Vietnamese sandwich.  Much less, at this price.
author: Josh D.

description: One of those places I'm thankful to have discovered through Yelp. The special combo sandwich was deliciois, surprisingly cheap, incredibly tasty, but take away only and not a fancy place. Definitely worth dropping by if you're in the mood for an amazing sandwich!
author: Pat ..

description: OMG! very tasty, very affordable, what else could you ask for? Great for take away, there not much space to eat in.
author: Lucy D.

description: Awesome sandwiches and cheap as chips... Less then $4... Meatball  and pork are my favs but chicken is great too! Work nearby and go most days
author: Jack O.

description:
Best banh mi in the Tenderloin! Much smaller than Lee's, and few choices (which is a bonus). There's about five sandwiches, and they're all good and under $4.

If they're cutting onions, place your order and go outside immediately -- that's why the woman operating the machine is wearing swim goggles. It's a LOT of onions.
author: Adam D.

description:
It's in a sketchy location..so don't pay mind to the homeless people asking you for change while you wait outside to place your order..the sandwich was good.. I ordered the bbq pork sandwich and it was large. The pork texture wasn't what I was expecting but it was still yummy. Although I was expecting some more bbq texture? I dunno it's hard to describe. It's not as firm as I felt it should have been! 

Can't beat the price though. I think it was $3.75? For a large sandwich? That's as cheap as it will go in this area...and also sf in general. Too bad it's a little far from my office so it's not a feasible lunch spot for me. Oh well..I am not that disappointed that I can't make it here for week day lunch. Cuz this place is only good-okay to me.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Saigon Sandwich (bahn-mi) was recommended to us by a San Francisco native when we were the city visiting from Seattle. This little place is somewhat obscure, but very popular--one of those local secrets. The menu is small, with only 4-5 bahn mi sandwich options, along with an assortment of drinks and other packaged Asian snacks. In my experience, a small menu is a promising sign that the items are well-done. Saigon Sandwich did not disappoint! 

I tried the Chicken Bahn Mi--the bread was fresh, meat well-grilled, served with fresh, pickled carrots & daikon, and cilantro. When we arrived with our group, the line was long, but moving quickly. Service at Saigon Sandwich was incredible efficient and friendly. 

And the very best, most surprising part? Sandwiches were under $4! (cash only) While they are not huge (about 6 inches in length), they are certainly filling and just the right amount for a fantastic price. We will definitely be back when visiting again.
author: Anika C.

description: This is honestly one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches in San Francisco. They use a nice flaky bun. The hours are reliable. The service is brisk. The prices are good compared to other lunch options, but I've been watching them go up over the years. Of course, I think the best sandwich is the special combo, but I am a fan of the fancy pork too (pate and cha lua). The roast chicken and roast pork are solid as well. Call in your order because the line can get long. They have vietnamese drinks, desserts, and snacks also.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Best Vietnamese sandwiches in San Francisco. I love their meatball sandwich with extra pate! Their bread is toasted to perfection, the carrots and cilantro are fresh and they add a generous portion of meat. They also have really good Vietnamese desserts as well. I love their green jello with mung bean on the small trays and the dessert cups in the fridge. My favorite ones are the red, yellow and white cup, the green brain-looking cup and the cups with just rice, beans and corn. All really good.

I love this place. I just wish they had more closer locations. Maybe soon.
author: Laura T.

description:
Saigon Sandwich, you are my new favorite Bahn Mi.  
I ordered the combo and the pork.  Yes, I ordered two. For Me and for me. Don't judge! The bread is nice and flaky and the ingredients are fresh.  There was a line, but it moved fairly quickly.  Overall, two thumbs up!
author: Christine K.

description:
Since I work in the neighborhood, my goal is to have tried all their sandwiches by the end of summer, but that's turning out to be difficult because the ones I've tried so far were so delicious I kept wanting to order the same thing.

If I must rank the ones I've had, it would be Chicken, Roast Pork, Tofu, and Cha Xiu (ground prok). But really, all of them had generous portions and exploding flavors. The bread was always crunchy and the pickled vegetables had the right amount of crisp and tartness.

I also tried the green tea mochi they sell on the counter, one of the best. 

Saigon makes Tenderloin worth coming.
author: Lisa P.

description:
I liked this place, but I didn't LOVE this place. However, given the quantity of food and the price, I must bump this experience to four stars. You cannot, simply cannot, get more food at a better price / value than this.

For me, Vietnamese sandwiches are very, very traditionally, a freshly baked roll, stuffed to pieces with pickled vegetables and traditional Vietnamese ham. Or BBQ pork which is a far cry from what you'd grill in your backyard normally on a Sunday afternoon.

This place sort of takes a twist. All the meats here are meats you would not usually find in Asian style dishes but more American style meats although it still includes the freshly baked roll and the pickled veggies. However, this is where the problem lies. It doesn't taste the same! You can't get a combination roll with American meat flavors and still have a Vietnamese sandwich.

Well... at least it was cheap and good, just not as authentic as I had hoped.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Literally the best place EVER to get Vietnamese sandwiches. Whenever my mom's in the area she'll buy around 5 sandwiches to bring home to us and she'll ask for a whole bag of carrots, cilantro, and jalepeno seperately to add onto the sandwich later to prevent sogginess. It might be in a bad area and although it's a hole in the way, you won't regret trying this place out. Definitely recommend and I have nothing bad to say about this place.
author: Celine C.

description: OMG! This place would be the death of me if I lived in SF. So my New Years resolution was to be vegan. But eating animal doesnt count when you are on vacation right? So I decided to get my nasty on with pig my favorite meat whilst in SF. For three dollars I got a DELISH juicy bbq pork bahn mi with tons of pickled crispy carrots and japapenos. IT WAS SO FUCKING GOOD! I said to hell with my health and I have been on a lets stuff all of the dead pig products into my body that I can ever since.
author: amberley w.

description:
"Hey, I got you a vietnamese sandwich. Don't worry though, it's _banh-mi."

I think this is the best banh-mi spot. Always get the pork combination at $4.25. Delicious, fresh, and spicy (the jalapenos here are on point).

There is always a line here, but it moves pretty quickly. Maybe like a 10 min wait.
author: Andy J.

description:
Believe the hype people.  

First off, the portions are great and would totally be worth 10 buck at any food truck, but here is the catch: THEY'RE LESS THAN $4!!  I had a coworker introduce me to the incredible world that is Vietnamese food via this quaint establishment near Civic Center and I haven't looked back since.  The Pork Bahn Mi is awesome and explodes with a lot of flavor and a little bit of spice.  Don't shy away from the Tofu Bahn Mi because it filled me up even more than the Pork.  Its an awesome place and have yet to hear one bad thing about it.  Cash only and there is usually a line, but they're quick and delicious.
author: Samuel B.

description:
A knockout of deliciousness in a Banh Mi for 3.75$ 

Whaaaat?!?! Yep it's true, GO, TODAY, have it, love it. It is fresh, it is flavorful, and it is filling.
The lady that helps you is very fast and mechanical, and is a bit hard to understand, but more respect to her for being a freaking trooper and running the show like it's a flawless swiss watch. She is fast, and she does not mess around. Your sandwich will be made on the spot, and will be made fast.

The person greeting will only say "Hi Hello", and then you tell her whether you want "chicken or pork", and you're on your way. No small talk, all business, like the flavor of their food.
author: Rodrigo P.

description:
One of the best hole in the wall places I have been to in the U.S. If you don't care too much for lack of decor and ambiance, this place will definitely satisfy your Banh Mi cravings. I got the tofu banh mi, and I won't even hesitate to say it was one of the best sandwiches my tongue has tasted!

They toasted the bread just right - crispy but not too hard on the outside, soft and fluffy on the inside. The tofu was very flavorful and made the texture pairing with the crispy veggies heavenly! Plus the sandwich was just around $3.00! That is definitely a bang for your buck! 

Too bad I don't live in SF! I would be a regular at this place if I did!
author: Paul Q.

description:
Combination with pate for $4 is the best thing ever!  I actually stopped by here after eating lunch at Turtle Tower and saw a couple other guys doing the same thing.

The pate is what really stands out about the banh mi here.  I haven't had it with so much flavor and texture before.  There are little cans of it in the front for purchase and I wonder if it's the same kind in the sandwiches.

What could be a little better is the bread.  It's moderately chewy and moderately fresh.  It does come toasted but I feel like the outside could be a little more crisp and the inside more fluffy.  Also, I did notice that the vegetables could have been more pickled.

Also, they pack in the meat so you are getting every penny of your $4's worth.   It can get quite busy but the two ladies work fast.
author: Shannon L.

description:
4 1/2 stars.
My coworker got me a chicken bahn mi. It was super good! I think one of the best I ever had. The chicken was tender and their sauce was delicious. I want more!!!
author: Karen H.

description:
So. Good. 

I've had plenty of banh-mi sandwiches in my day, and I can truly say that the combo here is my favorite one ever! This is my go-to place between classes. Sometimes there's a wait, but it's well worth it!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This spot been at the same location over 20
Years! 

Always a line but the wait is pretty fast to order and prob total time of 15
Mins to get your sandwich. 

They toast the their French bread to a crispy crunch and adds the right amount of sauce and meat with pickled veggies and jalapeño. 

My favorite is a fancy pork with pate. They even have vegetarian option! 

Very good Vietnamese sandwiches!!
author: Joanne K.

description:
Its 8:00, Ante Meridian, I'm walking toward Civic Center to take a Muni operator exam in 30 minutes, and I have a fierce craving for protein. The natural answer (at least for a man who is both broke, and has no conception of a proper American breakfast) is a Banh Mi, and thankfully Saigon Cafe opens at 7:30 (Banh Mi for breakfast?! Shut up, you stupid kids from a late 90's Cookie Crisp commercial.). Its a breakfast which costs less than a large cup of coffee from Philz right down the block ($3.75 as opposed to $4.00). Order something from both places, and savor the flavor of the paradox which is San Francisco, 2014. 

The Banh Mi here aren't great, or awe-inspiring, but they certainly are good. A half-pound of slightly gristly, pre-prepared, mildly spiced (although a bit too sweet) dark meat chicken nestles within a crusty french roll, a generous (perhaps too generous?) slathering of mayo, pate, and fish based sauce enrich the meal with extra calories and (totally delicious) fat. An extra-spicy request simply results in more jalapeños, although its not like I'm complaining. Did I even see a perfectly pickled onion among the crunchy slivers of daikon and carrot? Casey dreams of onions: a story of a man and his gastronomic whims.

I took the Banh Mi down to civic center plaza, the decaying faces of methamphetamine users juxtaposed against a backdrop of our staid and stately city hall; humanity's terrible beauty arrayed for all eyes to see. The crisp morning air bit as I bit into my crisp sandwich.

Overall: A basic, but good sandwich at an excellent price. 3.5 Stars.

Extras:

Service? They get you your food quickly. Who needs good service?!

The Muni Operator Exam: Easier than the LSAT, although I probably did worse on the former than the latter (Damn you customer service section!).

If I ever get married at city hall, I might have my reception here. 

Transit accessible by: various Golden Gate Transit Lines (Including the 92, 70, 101, and 80) MUNI, (5, 5l, 19, 31, and Van Ness/Market Street Corridor Bus lines), the Muni Metro, and BART.
author: Casey U.

description: I have to say for the price and the taste. This place is bomb. Where can you find a delicious generously stuffed banh mi for under $5? It is surely a hole in the wall. There is always a line despite during the non-rush hours. The atmosphere is not that welcoming to sit and eat, but that's not a big problem. The banh mi, is one of the best ones I've ever tried. My favorite would be the roasted chicken. I came here pretty frequently especially whenever I go to farmers market or civic center. I think what makes their banh mi taste so good is the sauce and the generous portion of meat and pickled veggies. The pickled daikon/carrots gives just the right amount of crunch and acidity to the banh mi. I really want to give this place a 5 star but I think there is room for improvements, such as the cleanliness of their ''kitchen'' area and shelf, the organization of their counter and kitchen, and the way they store the baguettes. I saw a lady take out baguettes in a half opened bag that is placed on the floor pushed aside. She took the baguettes out and put it straight into the oven/toaster without gloves. However I have to say the workers are hardworking ladies! I do hope that they will be able to open another one in SF that's more organized and clean. Another suggestion I would give is eat it fresh! I bought my coworker a banh mi here that was eaten about 3 hours later and the bread became hard to chew.
author: Sam N.

description: I used to live in the building right above Saigon, so I was spoiled. Since I left the city, I rarely make it back . Yesterday , I had an opportunity to speak into the city with my co-workers to get Saigon! I hyped them to them of course. When we arrived( some never have been to the city) and they saw the area, I got the 'are you nuts look', after they ate their roast pork, they knew and are hooked! As great as always.. So good , I painfully but yet enjoyably stuffed two sandwiches down. It might be a while until I have another but I loom forward to it.
author: mario a.

description: I love this place for their authentic and cheap Vietnamese sandwiches. I also like how this placed is run by Vietnamese mothers which means the food is homemade. The sandwiches are definitely the cheapest ones I found so far. Coming to this small deli reminds me of home. I would highly recommend this place if you want a homemade and authentic Vietnamese sandwich. My favorite sandwich will always be the combination sandwich. It has pate, mayo, variety of meats, pickled daikons and carrots, and jalapeños. I want to try their meatball sandwich next time. I think I will go there again for lunch.
author: Peter N.

description: After living in SF for 10 yrs this is still the best place to get Vietnamese sandwiches, super tasty and amazing price-still under $5!! Plus the ladies work there are always very friendly;)
author: Ladywolf M.

description: Probably the best in San Francisco. Extra gravy on any type of sandwich. Vietnamese know how to pack a punch.
author: Julius S.

description:
Two ladies, one sandwich shop. You should believe the hype when it comes to the banh mi's at Saigon Sandwich. It's so good I would literally go out of my way just to grab one.

People seem to come in waves here and the line does dwindle down every now and then. I arrived at the right time and only waited a few minutes before they took my order. The guy ahead of me had a very large order...

I always like to get the best bang for the buck so I went with the thit cha pate (special combination) for $3.75. I chose well because the sandwich was so good that I am hooked. The pork was tender and full of flavor, the bread was just the right amount of crunchiness, and there's plenty of pate on the buns. They didn't skim on the ingredients and really packed the ingredients in. I also grabbed a che (cold drink) as well. Saigon Sandwich makes really spectacular sandwiches and leaves other shops in the dust.
author: Tim G.

description: Extremely fast service even with a huge line. best bang for your buck in the city
author: Jimmy Y.

description: Saigon sandwich. Best Vietnamese sandwich in the city hands down. Nothing's changed, just the price because I remember taking a trip here with some friends during the high school days lol went up like 75 cents or so but it doesnt matter. Same good vibes and long lines at times but it's worth the wait cause they work fast. The sandwich is good everytime. Never dissapointed. Try it folks! Daaaa best!
author: Jaydee S.

description: Lightly crisped baguette, juicy meat with its juices, creamy pate, crisp carrots. No cut up gums! Super cheap and super sized. I had to squish it to fit in my mouth. Might be one of the best banh mi in town.
author: Jason C.

description:
Checked another Top 100 off the list. Roasted pork sandwich was delicious, filling and cheap. The meat was seasoned superbly with fresh veggies and a delicious sauce. Only tiny downside is the bread which is a bit hard on top and can pose a challenge for the roof of your mouth. Slightly painful but worth the bit of maneuvering. Also purchased a dessert, I don't know what its called. It was fried coconut wrapped in a gummy gelatinous substance packaged in banana leaves, or some kind of leaves. Who cares what it was called, it was tasty as well.

To go, cash only. 

I will be back for more. I can see this becoming a regular lunch spot.
author: Nicole Z.

description:
I've been here many times, but neglected to write a review.  Today, my husband and I stopped by here to grab a quick, inexpensive lunch.
We both ordered pork sandwiches, known as bahn mi in Vietnamese.  Although the price has risen over the years from $2.50 to $3.50, the ladies here continue to make absolutely delicious sandwiches with generous portions of pork, fresh cilantro, shredded carrots and what seems to be mild, pickled onion.
The baguettes are large but crisp on the outside and soft on the inside.
We took our sandwiches home and had a great lunch.  If you've never been to Saigon Sandwich, run - not walk - there!
There is always a line going out the door during the lunch hour, but the line moves fast and it is worth the wait.
author: Philip C.

description:
A great sandwich at an affordable price. The staff isn't going to crack jokes or be a memorable part of your experience here, but the food is why you came and why you'll come back. I get the chicken sandwich when I decide on eating (let me rephrase: ordering from) here and it is delicious. There isn't an abundance of taquerias in my working environment, but there are plenty of bahn mi options. 

This place gets packed and the level of order can become overwhelming at times, but I've found if you stray from the typical noon to one lunch hour you'll be alright.
author: Michael G.

description:
Considering taste, price and serving size this is likely one of the best sandwiches in the country. Only $3.75 for the most tasty roast pork Bahn-MI you will ever taste. They take cash only so be prepared. 

One is not quite enough, two is too much. I recommend coming with a friend order 3 sandwiches and spliting the third one.
author: Trim W.

description:
I'm giving three stars because my hubby really liked the Pork Sandwich.  We made the trip from Livermore to SF just to try the banh mi.  However, while in line waiting to order I noticed that one of the woman who was handling the money also went to the back and started handling bread without washing her hands.  That was a dead stop for me and I hold him to forget the chicken sandwich I was going to order.  If that happens right in front of me I don't want to know what could be happening behind closed doors.

If it were up to me, the cross contamination would be ZERO stars.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Be mindful of the neighborhood... It's f!¢#ing shady. 

We got 3 sandwiches to try- pork, chicken, & fancy pork.

The pork was excellent and by far the best. The chicken was dam good. 

The fancy pork was an impulse move since I had/have no idea what it is.  It sliced like deli meat. 

All the sandwiches were a good size. They were not skimpy on the meat. A bunch of shredded carrots, some cilantro, fresh jalapeño slices, and maybe mayo (or some equivalent). They were deeelicious!
author: Ed E.

description:
Hands down the best Vietnamese sandwiches ever.

Their bread is always fresh and crunchy and their ingredients are also fresh. I usually get the chicken or combination meat -- which are both really delicious. Their mayo is homemade (which is my favorite) and also their special sauce, which completes the sandwich. The sandwich even tastes good the next day, just pop it into a toaster oven and you're good to go! 

There's always a long line whenever I seem to go though so calling in advanced to place your order for pick up is most definitely the way to go.
author: Adrianne T.

description: How is it possible that this hidden gem is straight up in the hood of San Francisco?! I really don't care if I have to walk through crackheads and homeless people just to get to this BANG MI joint! It's by far the best banh mi sandwiches I have ever tasted up in the bay area. These badass viet ladies sure do know how to get their hustle on making dem bombass sandwiches. A must have to take to-go whenever I visit SF.
author: Mary S.

description:
I remember eating here when I was a little kid with my family and this place was just a regular place, not too crowded or anything and now 20 years later this whole "banh mi" trend started to happen and this place is a huge hit. I am very happy for them, especially since they had to close their restaurant across the street a few years back due to poor business.

I am Vietnamese myself and I know my Vietnamese food pretty damm well and this place has probably the best banh mi in the U.S. There are other commercial places (*cough* Lee's sandwiches *cough*) that tries to make the Vietnamese sandwich, but this place simply  has the best hands-down outside of Vietnam. The seasoning of the meat and the pickled vegetables are on a different level compared to most places and the prices are fair $3-4 (unlike this stupid food trucks, ie. Nom Nom, who tries to rip you off by selling banh mi for $7-9 and on top of this, they have a much lower overhead).

If you want authentic banh mi that's delicious and the best, come here and do not get scammed by all these damm food trucks who sells them for over $7 because of the stupid trend.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Go early!
Am I allowed to review without actually eating the sandwich?  I tried, really.  I did a total detour on my walk and speed walked one full hour out of my way to get there at exactly 4:40pm (they close at 5pm) on my last day in San Fran.
The door was wide open, the food smelled sooo good and I thought to myself- I made it-- to the tastiest sandwich in San Fran perhaps at the lowest price! 
And then the lady shook her hand and shooed me away, sort of like I was a dog..just shooed me out of her store.

So go early as it appears they stop serving well before 5pm.

Sadly, I ended up at Taco Bell that night.
author: Alexandra C.

description:
BEST BANH MI in the city. I'm often in the general area and as soon as I think about their pate/maggi sauced baguettes, I'm sucked in and end up shelling over $3.50 for some toasty eatings.

They have an assortment of other Vietnamese edibles, but definitely come for the sandwiches.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I've eaten a lot of Banh Mi. A lot. 

This tiny little place is hard to find if you don't know what you're looking for, but my coworkers tracked it down and we ordered sandwiches for everyone and took them to eat on the grass by City Hall.

The pork wasn't dry, the spread wasn't too buttery, and the bread was perfectly flaky. The pickled carrots were amazing, the onions strong, and the cilantro not too plentiful. It was everything that a Banh Mi should be. Maybe not the best I've ever had, but definitely in the top ten!
author: Christina S.

description: We ordered two sandwiches  (Xi Mai & Meat) before we heading out to Napa & both were really tasty and delicious.  We also got other snacks too and it were good.  The prices are not bad.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Food-Travel-Adventure A.

description: As best as it gets! So happy to be working in that area, it opens at 7am, so i grab it for breakfast and eat half for lunch! Roast pork is my go to! amazing!!!!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Do you want a solid seasoned piece of pork, in a simple crackly bun, with lots of cilantro, hot HOT peppers, carrots and seasoning?

Do you want one for next to nothing?  Cheap as borscht?  Hungry?

This is the place.

A real simple no frills option that is very popular but doesn't take long to get served.  IT's either chicken, pork, or meatball pretty much and it's under 4 bucks.  Crackly bread, nice size, lots of cilantro and a wonderful simple flavor.  A good quick bite, and real tasty.  Definite worthy stop.
author: Ethan L.

description: Their sandwiches are really good. I always come to get some when I'm in the area. There's always a line so be prepared to wait. The reason I'm giving a 4 stars is because their bread is like a rock when they keep in overnight!
author: Alice L.

description:
My "cred": grew up eating and learning to cook Vietnamese food from my mom. Lived in Saigon for a while. My short verdict on Saigon Sandwich: great value, pretty good sandwiches that are close to the real deal but fall a bit flat on the bread. 

I have a lot of sympathy for places like this. I feel there are good reasons to support a spot like Saigon Sandwich: 1. You get way better value here. $3-4 a sandwich 2. The sandwiches are generally closer to authentic. 3. You get to support an immigrant small business where they share some of their culture. 

But let's talk about the sandwiches themselves. The meat is pretty flavorful, the pickled Daikon/carrots have the right mix of sweet and sour and crunchy, the cilantro and jalapenos are vibrant. 

The one flaw here is the bread. It's too tough and dense. In Vietnam they make baguettes with a mix of wheat and rice flour. The result is brilliant: a crackling, crisp, thin crust with an airy, light interior. Not only is it a wonderful texture, it's physically better suited for banh mi, because if you have a chewier, denser bread like the one used at Saigon Sandwich, the act of biting into the sandwich compresses the inflexible bread, expelling the wonderful mix of ingredients and making a mess. If they changed up their bread, this would be a great banh mi. As is, it's pretty good. Food-wise: 3 stars; the value bumps it up to 4 for me.
author: Long L.

description:
This place is over-hyped. Banh mi is my life, and this was not as yummy as I had expected coming from reading all these good Yelp reviews. 

I ordered the roast pork sandwich, and the meat was very dry. The bread is pretty good though, not very hard and not too soft. My friend and I both had a tough time finishing our sandwiches. We've tried many other banh mi places and thought that this was going to be the ultimate topper of our list. Turns out to be a disappointment, and probably will be near the mid-bottom of our list. Only up is that it was a very cheap sandwich.

Sad to say, but this is definitely a join-the-hype restaurant that actually isn't very good :/.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Love this place! Have gone to other Vietnamese sandwich locations and the flavor is not as great as Saigon sandwich. 

It gets really packed here, it was a hole in the wall for so many years that on one really knew about it. I've been coming here since I was a child, way back when the sandwiches only cost 25 cents! and never really a line. Now everyone comes here and there is almost always a long line. 

 Its still cheap for a sandwich in SF! Parking street parking, yes homeless everywhere but hey its the Tenderloin, its worth the wait, its cheap, taste really good service is friendly, and they sell yummy desert.
author: Vanessa T.

description: OMG. I will be craving this place until my next trip to San Francisco. I got the patte banh mi with the default toppings. The bread was warm and soft. The patte and sauce was delicious and made a wonderful mess. The vegetables were crunchy and wonderful. Price tag: $3.75. The best sub-$5 meal I've had in the U.S. My only regret was not getting the combo.
author: David B B.

description:
I was debating between a 3 and a 4, but when I factored in price, there was no way to not give this place a 4-star review. Went in this afternoon for the first time and got the roast pork banh mi. It was served hot, it was served fast and it cost $3.75. Most importantly, though, it was delicious! Unlike some sandwich shops that give you a lot of bread and just a little filling, this sandwich is loaded. (And comes wrapped in a rubber band to hold it together, even after being wrapped in paper.)

If you need a quick bite, or a cheap bite, or a good banh mi, go here. Is it the best banh mi ever? No. (But I will say, I haven't had many so I'm not the expert here.) But it's a delicious sandwich.
author: David B.

description: Delicious, good sized sandwich for under $4. It is a quick and easy place to grab lunch. There is usually a line during the lunch hour but it is worth waiting for! I highly recommend the roast pork sandwich.
author: Caitlyn K.

description:
This place suffered from extra hype.
I thought it was good, but nothing too special. People have been telling me it's super tasty but I didn't get that same feeling.
They stuff their banh mi with a lot of pickled daikon and carrots and it is definitely more messy than other places with their sauce and mayo. The bread was crunchier than I expected. Which can be a good or bad thing.

The pork roll was a letdown. Just wasn't very good. I should have tried the chicken or grilled pork.

in true vietnamese fashion, cash only.
author: Lan N.

description: Awesome reception like  always ...... i'll always get Veggie Pho and its legit amazing.. my friend they had chicken and beef pho which is great according to them.....
author: Santosh L.

description:
I can't keep trying to will myself into liking Saigon Sandwich. I tried it several times before finally writing this review and I'm sad to say this place does not satisfy my banh mi cravings. 
The bread is too dense and hard. I love carbs but I feel like I could get lockjaw when eating this sandwich. The mayo sauce is oddly sweet and the veggies aren't pickle-y enough. I think the best part of the sandwich is the pate, which I can buy in a can, from them! 

I might return if the bread is changed. Otherwise, I'll continue my search for a great banh mi here in SF.
author: Ariel E.

description:
Very affordable, quick, efficient, tasty. 

I had the chicken sandwich. The chicken itself is nicely seasoned, but not the shredded version which I prefer. Saigon Sandwich's chicken are cut in chunks, in a slippery sauce it seems. Or it could have been the excessive use of mayo. The truth is, I struggled to contain my sandwich. Those ladies behind the counter do not skimp in the ingredients. However, that leaves one to wrangle with a sandwich that cannot contain itself. I basically left a chicken and veggie trail from the tiny shop on Eddy all the way to the courthouse. 

Great sandwich, get napkins.
author: Elisabeth H.

description: Saigon has by far the best and inexpensive Banh Mi I've had. I normally order tofu for myself and a pork for my boyfriend. The line can get long, but orders come out quick. Definitely recommend!
author: Shawnty Q.

description:
Hi, Hi, Hi, Hello, Hi, Hi, Hi, Next, Hi, Hi, Hi, Hello, 
sandwich that will make you cry, jalapenos that will make you weep, 
best sandwich in town, if you don't know now you know, 
roast pork, pate, combo, all day, 
don't ask me about fanci pork, nobody knows
author: Roy C.

description:
From a quality perspective, this is the best Banh Mi I've ever had, including Vietnam. Loads of shredded pork, just the right amount of pate, and fresh herbs that enhanced the flavor. The crunchy yet soft bread was the perfect balance. 

For the price, this place is as good as it gets. Less than $5 for a filling, deliciously authentic Vietnamese Banh Mi cannot be beat. 

For the service, it took us less than three minutes to get our sandwiches with four people ahead of us. 

Overall a total gem worth going to (and returning).
author: Neal C.

description: These sandwiches really are amazing! The bread is really tough and crunchy, but it holds it all together and just works better than you might think.
author: Adamme K.

description: BBQ chicken and pork both delicious. Good sized sandwiches for the price. Mostly take out as there's only a small counter with a few seats.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Haven't been to this place for over 10 years. Decided to go here since my friends wanted to get vietnamese sandwich. Got the special combination for $4. Decent price for a sandwich. They made the sandwiches quick even if there's a lot of people. 

The combination sandwich is sooo good. It has good sauce. The bread is soft. There's plenty of meat and good among of vegetable. Its a real authentic vietnamese sandwich
author: Julie N.

description:
Saigon sandwich makes the best vietnamese sandwiches that I've had.  You can't get a better lunch for only $3.75! 

My go to is the chicken sandwich with no mayo.  It's not dry without the mayo since the chicken is moist and juicy.  I think it may have a little sauce on it as well.  The chicken is of relatively good quality compared to other banh mi places.  The bread is what I think sets this place apart from others...it's soft yet toasty and warm.

The sandwiches are cheap! Take out only.  I think there might be 1-2 chairs in there.  There's normally a steady line of 2-5 people throughout the day which goes by very fast.  You can also call in your order if you wish.  Highly recommend!
author: Stephanie W.

description: Don't know what the hype is here. I got the veggie Bahn mi, and the tofu was soggy and the veggies were uneventful. Perhaps the meat ones are better, but I beg to differ on that too. The place wasn't very clean either, so I question that too. If you want to know some good Bahn Mi places,  just reach out to me... But this isn't it. Plus, they don't take credit card, so cannot get your points! And  the lady that takes your cash gets very confused on giving change back. #foodietriplefail
author: Sonia A.

description:
DROOOOOOLLING JUST THINKING ABOUT THIS PLACE!!!

This place totally hits the mark for Vietnamese sammys.  I always order the combo and roasted pork.  The combo is slathered in pate, roast pork, Vietnamese style meat, pickled veggies, jalapenos, cilantro, onions & their special "crack sauce."  The roasted pork is similar but less the pate & other meats.  It also has the special "crack sauce."  The bread is always fresh & they are super generous with all the fixings.  I feel like I'm ripping them off each time I buy a sammy.  They could charge double and won't hear a peep out of me!!

Turtle tower is just up the block (another one of my favs) so each time I'm at Turtle, I will stop by & pick up a few sammys for later!
author: Wina K.

description: ***CASH ONLY*** This place looks a little sketchy when you go in but the line out the door never lies. The sandwiches are as low as $3.75 and you can try to eat two but its not likely.
author: Steven F.

description:
where in San francisco can you get a sandwich for $3.75?  And its a very very very good one at that?  Right here.  your search is over!

My BF found this place , and to be honest i was really hesitant, cause its not in the greatest neighborhood, and its so tiny.  But never under estimate something good.  it can be anywhere and any size.  and this place proves it!

I have ordered this for myself.  I have brought family and friends who visit me, here.  And i have even ordered 45 sandwiches for a work event.  ALL rave reviews.

when calling to place an order, speak clearly, and slowly.  And when you get there just walk up to the front....  everyone will get over it!
author: China B.

description:
This is as good as you can get when it comes to Vietnamese sandwiches.

For $3.50, you can a fresh roasted pork or chicken sandwich loaded with cilantro, jalapeno, and pickled carrots on a fresh baguette.  Add a drink for $1 and you get a meal for less than five bucks.

If you are adventurous, you can add some Vietnamese steamed pork and/or pate to your sandwich ($3.75 to $4).  

Great place for a quick, cheap, and good lunch.
author: Harvey K.

description: The BEST sandwiches around!! I've tried many other places but always come back to my old friend. For me the bread is always so important. I don't like the kind that is super light with crumbly exterior. The bread here is always good (I think they user Bakers of Paris rolls) & remains in tact during consumption. I've been getting the tofu for a while now & man is it good (of you like that sort of thing)! They are large pieces too (not thin strips which I don't like). I used to get the combo, chicken or roast pork and rever those were always on point! You can't beat the price either (tofu $3.75), and it will keep me full for hours!
author: Laurie E.

description:
Summary:  Good, not great. Mostly hype. Go to the place on Eddy across the street.

I absolutely love banh mi and have had many many sandwiches from many many different places. As long as the price is under $4 its hard to mess it up.  

Saw all the glowing reviews and had to come try this place out. I came on a Sat afternoon to a predictably long line. Out the door. However it moves quickly.  While in line I noticed a vietnamese place across the street (cant remember the name) with huge banner advertising $3.25 banh mi.  50 cents cheaper? hmmmmmmmmmm

So i did what any banh mi lover with too much time on their hands would do.  I got both and did a taste test.  While Saigon's is perfectly fine, this other place blew it out of the water.  Meat was juicier, veggies were more pickled. I was honestly surprised.

So do yourself a favor, skip this place and go across the street.
author: Nick E.

description:
I am not sure if you can find anything out there more delicious for $3.50 than the banh mi at Saigon Sandwich. Seriously, toasted to perfection, flavorful and juicy meat, and just the right amount of pickled veggies (and a spicy jalapeno slice) all partying in your mouth is as unbelievable as it gets. My favorite part is how the bread gets soaked with the juices from the bbq pork to give it amazing flavor and texture. Not a lot of other banh mi have this element to them. I found out the secret after my 6th time ordering there: they ladle a collection of "au jus" from the bbq pork directly into the bread before assembling the rest of the ingredients. GENIUS.

They are so efficient, these ladies are gems. Taking orders even when you're standing in line and haven't even made it into their doors yet, they really know that what they're selling is a hot commodity, and rightly so :) 

warning: cash only.
author: Tuwie N.

description: Oh my gosh.  I went to banh mi heaven. For some reason I had a banh mi at the Fairmont and at Lees but this sandwich was the best I ever had. The bread was soft and crunchy the meat was marinated just right the veggies were seasoned perfect and tons of cilantro and jalapeños  There is always a silver lining to any tenderloin stay.  If you ever stay at the Phoenix or you want to take a walk down Larkin do it.  2 old ladies making and selling just say your order and pay and wait.  And wait for a little Vietnam banh mi-raculous!!!!
author: Toby N.

description: Great sandwich for the price! Generous fillings and great flavors! Would definitely recommend the roast pork with pate. Would definitely come back!
author: Lucy Q.

description: If you are a local.. you know where this hole in the wall is... best freaking sandwiches ever The pate is my favorite one here.. everything from the pickled veggies inside to the bread and condiments are nice and plentiful. It's hard to resist buying 2 sandwiches though because they are so damn good.. Some people in line have bought 2 for themselves.. and Don't get me wrong, I've seriously considered it, but theres no way I could fit 2 sandmitches in my tummy.
author: Eleana H.

description:
Came here during a day trip to San Francisco.  I'm Vietnamese and grew up eating banh mi almost every day of the week so I feel like I would know a good sandwich if I had one.  Thought the sandwiches were okay.  It was good, but nothing special.  Tried the check and bbq pork.  Wasn't too impressed with either one.  

They are very busy.  There was a line out of the door when I came during lunch hour.  Had to wait about 15 mins for 4 sandwiches.  

There is not a place inside to sit so be prepare to grab your food and get out of there.  

Pricing was about $4-5 bucks for each sandwich.  

Probably won't be back.
author: Monica T.

description:
Best Banh Mi ever. Ever. I love this place as it's a complete shithole that turns out the best sandwiches in the city. It's no frills, nothing good to look at, but as you step up and pay an amazingly low price for your food it's like walking on a cloud.

My work has early lunch so I try to get here by 1105, but even then the line has sometimes started. Definitely worth the wait, though.
author: N'olo J.

description:
I consider myself a major sandwich lover, and I think that Saigon Sandwich counts among my top two favorite sandwich places in the world. 
They're simple, cheap, and to the point. I don't come for the ambiance, cleanliness, customer service, or the "fancy pork." The roast pork bahn mi is utterly divine - it's a generous and intense combination of flavors that delight my taste buds. 
Endure the wait, get a sandwich (or two), and eat it on the go, in a park, or anywhere except in the actual shop. You won't regret it.
author: Eliza F.

description:
What can you find in the Tenderloin? 
uhm.. crackheads in broad daylight!?
Absolutely, but that's not all!

Just only the best mutha-effin' Bánh Mì's evrr! 
AND it's only THREE ta FO DOLLAAS each!!

(watch out for the crackheads though)
author: Albert L.

description:
I was hungry, I didn't feel like using lots of words, and I had $4. 

I came, said two words, and left with a hefty lunch. 

Beware of scraping the roof of your mouth with the toasted bread.
author: Loli L.

description: Absolutely no words to express how delicious and plentiful the subs/ sandwiches are here!!! The subs are jam packed with ingredients, the ladies here definitely do not cheap out on meat like most places. Try the meatball sub, you will not regret!! I'm drooling just thinking about this joint!! Will be back the next time I'm in SF.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I love coming Saigon to have my flavors vietnamese  sandwich.
Tiny little restaurant at a sketchy homeless neighborhood , for $3.75- $4.25 
Roast park, chicken or combo  sandwich come with carrots , cilantro , pate
very yummy, I wish I will give them 5 star but I can not because 
one,  food was not in consistency. ( 20%) of the time pate tasted fishy and 
the pickled veggies is little too sour or sweet.   
Two.. lady in the counter  she like to yelled at people..
overall  I still  do like to go there get the sandwich.
author: Ming L.

description:
This place never disappoints. Hint: If you ask them to add sriracha to your bahnmi, they will. 

From the bread, to the secret bbq sauce, to the veggies, to the pate... everything rocks so well together I almost feel guilty paying only $3.50 for it. 

YUM!
author: Krista N.

description:
Every time I make a trip to San Francisco, I always make it a priority to come here. They are literally the best Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever tasted! Don't let their hole in the wall kind of look scare you away. I promise you it's really delicious. Don't believe me? I'm sure the next time you go there, there's going to be a line. 

It's a really small shop, and they also sell some Vietnamese goodies on the side as well. It doesn't matter what sandwich you order, it's going to be heavenly either way. They definitely pack the meat and the baguette is so crunchy yet soft. I love everything about it. 

The only downside is that they have like...a really small booth that can hold like two people, so it's not a dine in place. You're going to be more comfortable if you order like 20 sandwiches and took them home.
author: Mary N.

description:
As everyone (almost everyone) has said, Saigon Sandwich is an awesome little Vietnamese shop that serves banh mi. Stopped in on Sunday for a late, late lunch (4pm I guess is technically not lunch but whatever) and there were only a few people! Cheers to no line.

Ordered two roasted chicken banh mi and one roasted pork banh mi ($3.50 each). Bread is warm and toasty (perfect crunch to it). Lots of meat in the sandwiches along with carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, daikon and just enough mayo. Jalapenos give it a nice heat but if you don't like spicy, you should ask for your banh mi without it.

Anyways, great place in Little Saigon. Cheap and delicious!
author: Jonny M.

description:
Saigon Sandwich packs a mean punch in their banh mi. The ingredients are fresh, the baguette is crunchy yet soft and the sandwich itself is massive. Plus, it's a steal at ~$4.

You can't go wrong with the pork! Grab your sandwich and enjoy at a nearby park.
author: Melissa W.

description:
To all the haters below- YOU CAN SUCK IT!!! "Area is scetch... smells like urine... the line is big"- go to the Fillmore and get dry ass sandwich from BunMi place for $8 and chew on that crap.  
This is the best bunmi place in entire city I know about. You get more than you pay for and it is so damn delicious!!!
author: Iaroslav K.

description:
There is a reason why ppl give 4.5 stars here after 2000+ reviews.

Price: unbeatable. What do you expect for 4 bucks in SF

Food: I wouldn't say their sandwich is huge, but they stuffed a LOT of meat in it. Must add the pickled veggie, cilantro and jalapeño. I think they put a butter-ish spread on the bread as well. I usually get the roast pork or the combo MINUS the pate cuz I hate the pate taste, but the roast pork is marinated and tasty.

Lunch time there is a line usually, but it moves fast enough.
author: Ruxin H.

description:
(3.5) ~ Good overall food & service, BUT not the best Banh Mi we've had.  Their roll is more of a "hoagie" roll than the traditional French Baguette:(  NOTES:  Cash ONLY and NO seating = Take-out only;)

OUR MENU
** Coconut Water(vita coco) = (4) very good
* Special Combo Banh Mi = (3.5) Good Filling(w. a kick), but the roll was too tough to chew...
author: Craig D.

description: This place is still hands down one of the best in San Francisco. I would eat it everyday if it's healthy. Keep up the good job! I know you guys works really hard to feed all your hungry customers!
author: Aylee G.

description:
Saigon Sandwich opened day after new years when few other vietnamese biz'  was.
vietnamese ladies in an assembly line cranking out the favs: roast pork,  roast chicken, meatball. no waiting.  banh mi already made.

eats: roast chicken (3.50)
-chopped/mashed chicken, cilantro, jalepenos slices..in a large bun
-bun toasted,  chicken tasted sweet. not much veggie inside, mostly tasty chicken.

crumbs:
-vietnamese  cashier said a sweet "thany you" in perfect english.
-shop has no seating, just grab and go.
-a little higher than oaktown, but then oaktown has more veggie, tess meat...
author: Victor G.

description:
Emotionally recovered from my grotesque Sing Sing episode, I finally took Tom R's advice to visit Saigon Sandwich. This tiny market has been touted as having the best banh mi, and the line was already steady and long by the time I got there this morning. With a small two-seater by the storefront window, the structural layout of this Asian convenient store is adorned with snacks, candies and chips of all sorts. They have all the baseline banh mi choices to choose from, and my special combination ($3.50) was small in size but rich in flavor.

I thought the warm and toasty bread had the right amount of crunchy texture but the edges were still a bit too sharp than desired. The quality of the pate was rich, pointed, and the texture was nice and creamy than dry. The rest of the filling included a juicy set of roast pork, steam pork, carrots, cilantro, and jalapeno slices. The roast pork and pate combination made the sandwich creamy and delicious, but I also thought the carrots could be pickled while the stack of jalapeno slices did not inspire. Fish sauce and pickled radishes were absent for it to warrant a five star rating.

Even thought the antiquated setting and bustling ambiance may still render suspicions about its sanitary conditions, but their practice of keeping their baguettes heated while using gloves and tongs to making their sandwiches provided some level of respectability. Thanks to Tom for the solid recommendation. I will be back.
author: Daniel L.

description: Amazeballs. I tried the Pork Sandwich. Mind = blown. I don't know what's in the special sauce but there's definitely some umami being created there.
author: Cameron N.

description:
Place your order but don't try to pay the lady immediately lest you get scolded. They have a system going on in here. The best part about this place is the pate-with-any-other-topping combo - delish!

Also, don't expect good service, but go for the sandwiches which are a steal. I've learned to not expect good service from these sorts of places anyway - but then you know the food is good!
author: Lisa W.

description:
I really can't understand why this place has 4.5 stars on yelp... My friends and I decided to drive out to Saigon Sandwich after reading all of the wonderful reviews on yelp. I absolutely love banh mi and so maybe I have high expectations? 

Regardless, I thought that the sandwiches were mediocre at best. They were sloppily put together and the bread seemed a bit old. It was warm, but very chewy and difficult to bite off. 

ALSO! The "fanci pork' is not fancy at all! It is just cha which is the equivalent to a pork hot dog... meaning processed pork patties... Nothing fancy, premium, or special about these whatsoever! That being said, however, i absolutely love cha and would eat it on its own all the time as a child. I just found it extremely misleading that they would call this stuff "fanci pork."

Anyhoo, I regret driving so far out of my way and paying for metered parking to try this place. Seriously over hyped and nothing special about their sandwiches. If you've had authentic banh mi, you'll be disappointed.
author: Diana B.

description: I like Vietnamese sandwiches but this one has to one of the saltiest sandwiches I have eaten at. There's just way too much shredded carrots that comes with the sandwiches. I'm not a big fan of carrots... The chicken left me thirsty. BTW, It's cash only.
author: Ann L.

description: My favorite vietnamese sandwich ever! I love the pork combo with pate. The bread, sauce, meat and veggies combine to make an on point mouth-watering sammie. My favorite. Neighborhood is definitely sketch, but they aren't open past 7pm so you should be fine. There's a line at lunch hour. Bring cash. The sammies are soooo cheap!
author: Aleyna S.

description:
+1 for the pate
+1 for the bread
-1 for lack of variety
-1 for bbq pork (it was too sweet)
author: Sherry L.

description:
Not sure why this place got so many good reviews. Maybe because it is located in San Francisco, where there aren't really much choice for good Vietnamese food and people are too hungry?? The bread is as hard as rock, I guess maybe it was too early in the morning, and she had to use the bread from yesterday? It was obviously more than one day old, and you better have "teeth of steel" to bite on it, the meat taste ok, the price is ok.

The store is very small and dirty too, parking is difficult. Anyway, it was my first and obviously last time here.
author: Shan S.

description: Quick service even though there was only three people working during the business lunch hour. The sandwich was good, a little too juicy for my preference. Make sure to grab napkins!  For $3.75 it was a good deal! I would definitely go back again, but next time I'll try the combination since it's probably less juicy!
author: Katy Z.

description: Stuffed with the juiciest pork of all time. Baguette was excellent texture. Best banh mi I've ever had. Only 3 seats or so, best for take out.
author: A. B.

description:
Oh, Saigon Sandwiches, you never fail me in that you are still the best in SF no matter how hard I try to give other places a chance to compete. This is a long awaited review as I've had their sandwiches for years now. The bread, meat to veggie ratio, Pate, Price and Consistency is hard to beat. Even if its in a sketchy neighborhood, I still give you 5 stars.

The banh mi is definitely made by professional asian ladies who run the place like a well oiled assembly line. That's why the line moves fast so please don't be deterred by any line you see, it will move fast and it is worth waiting.

I usually get either the roast pork or the special combination(includes headcheese) but since they are relatively small and the price is cheap, I recommend getting one of each. You won't regret it!

Food Highlight: Both the roast pork and the special combination with extra PATE!
author: Rich L.

description: 2 bahn mis for $7, not sure how you can beat that. They were very good
author: H G.

description: Cannot believe how cheap it is!!! The sandwiches are among the best we've had, everything about them are just perfect--crispy bread, delicious meats and pickles, etc. We also had some of the desert drinks, which are really good but very sweet. Line can be long, but it's worth it!
author: Dave Y.

description:
All of you Tenderloinians who wrote about how how huge this $3.75 bahn mi sandwich is must collectively weigh 100 pounds! 'Large' is an overstatement and my ability to eat three of these amazing sandwiches would prove it. 

I am from Texas. Just kidding. But this sandwich is definitely not from Texas, nor is it underwhelming nor small in any way. It is a perfect hefty size.

Hefty might be defined in terms of thickness versus length. Saigon Sandwich's bahn mi sandwich is larger than a burger and a little smaller than half a sub from Subway. Unlike a Subway sub, it makes up in VOLUME. While VOLUME, in phallic terms, is very important, the same holds true with sandwiches. You can have a really long veggie-filled baguette with delicious innards but if the sandwich isn't thick, I mean PACKED, spilling out from every angle, you can certainly enjoy it but it wouldn't be very impressive. I prefer both though. Like, the same holds true with the best of the best burritos. I want to hold a burrito the size of my foot and feel almost uncomfortable at the end. With this bahn mi, I want to have to catch every leaf, carrot, daikon, tofu spilling out and me catching it with my mouth and have sauce dripping all over because I don't feel uncomfortable at the end. There's no way a pickled veggie sandwich, unlike a burrito, can ever do this to me.

The freshly prepared and amazingly tasty fried tofu is something I cannot get enough of, as well as the incredibly fresh vegetables. The service is very fast too. The lady working there made five different sandwiches for five people in less than two minutes.
author: Chris G.

description:
Quality Vietnamese sandiwch for under $5? Tried it once and I was hooked. I have had my fair share of banh mi's, but Saigon Sandwich's stand out the most. I would go out of my way just to go to this place to grab lunch.

I've tried different sandwiches from Saigon Sandwich, (meatball, roast and steamed pork combination, etc...) and I love their sandwiches even more every time.
