The sandwiches taste perfect, and will leave you either full, or wanting more sandwiches. All-in-all this place is a perfect place for those looking for not only a cheap but quality lunch option.  

But be wary, this place is no secret to those who live or work around the Civic Center area, and gets really BUSY when the lunch rush comes around. A line is formed out the door, and it sometimes edges up to the street intersection (not that far). At the same time, be sure when you order, clearly state what you want. The order-taker might not not hear if you don't want certain things in your banh mi.
author: Ethan T.

description: First Bahn Mi I've ever tried and I'm in love! It is extremely affordable given the huge portion and the generous servings of meat in the sandwich. The sandwich was flavourful and had a unique taste to it which leaves you wanting more!
author: Ting Yi C.

description:
Deliciously satisfying, flavorful, and cheap. 

This place gets busy with lines going out the door for a chance of feasting on some darn tasty banh mi.

Probably the best Vietnamese sandwiches in the city. 

Keep in mind that this place is ca$h money only. Thas how we Vietnamese do doe, mang!
author: Ann S.

description:
I don't know why i wouldn't give this place 5 stars?

Went on Sunday for lunch, got there and line was not that long. First time here so had to learn quick how to order haha. Well the menu is on the wall and it's short and sweet. Couldn't decide but went for the tofu, meatballs, and special combination.

Tofu- I love meat so maybe this was lacking for me. But good taste nonetheless.
Meatballs.. amaze-balls! Yummy to my tummy
Special combination.. the sure winner of the bunch for me. Next time I may order this and another one with just pate.. I love pate!!!

Oh I love the old ladies behind the counters! There are no tables here so plan to eat somewhere else. Although my partner and I grabbed the 2 chairs they had and ate at the tiny counter facing the street. Score! I did notice a lot of people dropping off someone at the curb, and they pick up food, while the other person drives around. Sounds like a good plan haha

We'll be back! Esp since we're just a couple of blocks away :D
author: Vol T.

description:
I was surprised to see a line out the door of this super tiny and kinda dirty hole-in-the-wall banh mi shop. 

But once I bought my $3 roasted pork sandwich and took my first bite, I knew why. It's freakin delicious! Way better than Lee's Sandwiches. The portions are a tad bit smaller, but the crunchy bread, soft roasted pork, cilantro, mayo-like sauce, radish, carrots, everything together was just so good! I understand the hype now. 

As for seating, it's pretty nonexistent. There's only a tiny counter with 2-4 chairs so this place is better for when you're on the go.
author: Diana I.

description: No line, but a lot of homeless people at the door. One of them, completely covered in urine, entered the place and just grabbed something from the refrigerator. Only two seats available, one for which I had to wait for like 10 minutes to sit on. I thought the service was ok, the ladies who work there even smiled to me. But yeah, grab your sandwich and get out of there as fast as possible. Oh, the roast pork sandwich was good, as everyone says.
author: Lucas C.

description: Great Banh Mi!! They didn't skimp on the ingredients and the bread was fresh. I especially liked the roast chicken - big chunks of tasty meat along with thick slices of jalapeno! The ladies preparing the sandwiches are very fast and efficient so you barely have to wait after you order. Only downside is there is no place to sit down (there are only two seats inside, but the space is small).
author: Josh L.

description: Best deal in town, $3.75 for a bahn mi with your choice of roast chicken, roast pork, fanci pork or pate ... or $4.25 for a combo of roast pork, fanci pork and pate. Great crusty bread, tons of meat, flavorful veggies with a nice bite of acid.
author: Anna B.

description: Great place! The service is quick and the price is pretty good for a Bay Area Vietnamese sandwich shop. I walk all the way from FiDi just to grab 2 of these for lunch.
author: Kevin N.

description: The best Vietnamese hoagie I have ever had in my life! The wait in line was about 15 minutes. I normally would not wait in line for a hoagie but the reviews had me curious. It was so worth the wait. Not too bad for a Monday I guess. The pate spread made the sandwich so much better. The ladies were so quick. I was in and out after I placed my order. Customer service was great.
author: Tien K.

description: WOW! I've grown up on banh mi's my whole life, and this is the BEST i've ever had! Coming from garden grove, where there's an endless amount of vietnamese food, i was  doubtful how one sandwich can be THAT much better than another. It blew my mind even when I ate it a few hours after I bought it. It must be out of this world if i had eaten it when it was fresh. I got the roast pork with pate sandwich and it's a must try! I think what makes this banh mi different from the others is their sauce. It's sweeter than other places and it keeps the sandwich moist. Now i'm sad that I can't get this everyday :( Saigon Sandwich, please come to Orange County! I promise you'll blow everyone else out of the waters!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The food is not expensive,  but amazing. I have never been disappointed in any of their sandwiches.  My favorite at the moment is pork. And my girlfriends favorite is chicken. But we always cut them in half so we both get half of each. 

I also love having no idea what any of the plastic wrapped goodies on the counter are. Sometimes when we are feeling ballsy we but one and eat it. Those are a lottery, cause even after eating them I couldn't tell you what they are. Sometimes they are sweet and some times, not so much.

They have puddings? In the fridge with jelly or nuts or something in them. They are in the bottom of the fridge, those are good too. But I also couldn't tell you what they are. 

I guess I could ask what all of them are. But if you are there at lunch it's very fast, and if I'm not, I feel like if I knew it would take some of the fun out of it! 

Over all they are super fast at making the sandwiches and they are on top of remembering who ordered what with out a computer. I love it. I come here any time I am close.
author: Chandra W.

description:
Really tasty sandwiches, served very quickly and cheaply. There's a few seats, but most people take it to go, and the atmosphere is designed to get you out the door as quickly as possible. If only there was a good place to sit and eat in this neighborhood...

Would love it if there was a BBQ pork option on the menu.
author: Aubrey P.

description: Pork Bahn Mi, pork bahn mi, pork bahn mi, you have to come here and get there prork bahn mi. I came here on a mission to explore San Fran based on their food spots. I ended up at this whole in the wall in the middle of the city and it reminded me of skid row in LA. So if you are not from the area or if you are not familiar with city living you might want to bring someone with you. I passed many struggling people asking for money and telling my kids to stay in school and can I have the rest of your drink? When I got to the location it was tiny and nowhere to wait inside it could have been a walk up window and never made a difference. As I waited in line I noticed that it was filled with Vietnamese snacks and drinks as you approach the counter. The kitchen area is organized Madness with someone taking orders others prepping and others creating your sandwich. But this location is so hectic that it looked like a mess so I would recommend a wall for this place for those high maintenance customers. As for me I am a street cart kind of guy so I don't mind at all. As for my bahn mi it was packed with flavor and the season was spot on so I will definitely recommend this spot if you are in the area. I wouldn't hunt it down because it wasn't blow you away good but definitely worth leaving the wharf and exploring the city.
author: Gary M.

description: The Banh Mi here is so gooood. My favorite. The whole menu is good. Such a whole in the wall place, but those tend to be the best I think. It is a cash only place and the ladies make these sandwiches like an assembly line. The place is so small too. I don't think seating actually exists. Love it here. Highly recommend.
author: Julie L.

description: Cheap and delicious.   For under $5 you can get a stuffed banh mi sub sandwich.  I tried the grilled beef and it was juicy and delicious.  Cash only.
author: LT P.

description:
Even when the line is out the door, service is super speedy!

I buy the combination sandwiches and my fridge is stocked for up to 3 glorious days.  It's super cheap too!
author: Mimi X.

description:
This is my new GO TO spot for all Vietnamese sandwich cravings.

FINALLY tried Saigon Sandwich's roasted pork sandwich today & it did not disappoint! There was a good amount of pork stuffed between the crunchy bread, complemented nicely by shredded carrots, onions, cilantro, mayo, jalapenos, and some bomb sauce. 

Had to deduct a star because the lady that made our sandwiches had a bit of a diva-tude -- She wasn't too nice when she took our order, made the sandwiches in a huff, tossed them on the counter when she was done, and bounced to the back without another word. We waited a while with WTF expressions on our faces before another lady finally came to ring us up. Oh well, still a fan!
author: I. L.

description:
I came to SF for a conference a few weeks ago and having done my research ahead of time, I was really excited to try this place and I was not disappointed! 

This is one of the best Bahn Mi's I've ever had and I am still salivating at the thought of it!! The bread has the perfect crunch and texture, the roasted pork is generous and so flavorful/savory, the pickled vegetables are perfect. 

The wait wasn't too long, and given just how delicious and cheap this place is, Saigon Sandwich is a gem. I'll be back for sure.

PS. The surrounding area sure is "colorful" as another user described!
author: Annabelle L.

description: I heard it from friend, he said it's tasty. Then I once bought 20 pieces for group lunch, everyone was happy and enjoyed it.
author: Olivia J.

description: So a sandwich here may be $3.75. Big fucking deal. I'd rather have $10 bahn mi I can actually bite into than a $3.75 one stuffed in a stale, stiff baguette that may chip my incisors. The stuffings may be reasonably generous but it is wrapped up in thin freezer paper that the mayo oils start seeping through in about two minutes. No.
author: Jin C.

description:
I absolutely love this place. Their banh mi sandwiches are always delicious, filling, and very inexpensive. My favorite is the pork though the chicken is very good as well.

It can get a bit hectic when you're ordering but the turn around is fast and worth it!
author: Andréa W.

description:
You pretty much get a very good and cheap Vietnamese sandwich here--$3.50 each.
I was paying with a $20 for 2 sandwiches and expected to get $6 back but got $13 instead so I was confused for a second. I also got a yummy dessert. Best prices!

Wait might be long, but worth it. If it's your first time here, try the Banh Mi Roasted Pork--so good. The baguette is the right texture. The "fanci pork" is Vietnamese ham if you're wondering. You can sample any of the meats (at least what I saw someone doing).

Best Vietnamese sandwich spot in Little Saigon, SF.
author: Marlon T.

description: This place piles on the pate! The sandwiches here really are worth the wait. I had the special combo sandwich and really enjoyed it. The reason why I give it 4 stars though was because I don't like the cooked pork in the special combo. I thought it would just be cold cuts so I was surprised to see it in there. But the amount of pate in there is almost as thick as the bread and I love my pate. The veggies were nicely pickled and everything was balanced. My friends seem to really like their tofu sandwich and grilled chicken so next time I will be trying those.
author: Celia Z.

description:
Haha... love the hole in the wall places!

(1) Fast service: these ladies are hella fast! 

(2) My favorite: The pork Banh Mi!

**OVERALL: know what you want before you go... crazy lines, crazy fast, crazy banh mi! 4 stars!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
I don't know the hype to this place.
It's MSG loaded, I knock TF out after half a sandwich.  Plus the meat's cold.

I really really tried to love the place, so I went multiple times and each time i was KO'd by the MSG.  Then one time, i bought a tapioca dessert, and it was moldy.  What's with that?  I said adios to this place immediately after that, and just giggle when i see the line out the door.

Y'all can have this place to yourselves, I'll just go to the other viet sammy spots around the way.
author: Isa H.

description:
= (     SAD FACE   = (


Two weeks before Christmas 2012

Me : Uncle Kwang is going to get you the biggest, softest, most awesomest teddy bear ever!

Niece : You promise?

Me : Pinky swear!

*gets kissed on the cheek by niece*

So Xmas rolls around and I come into the house with a small box, in it a jacket. She opens it up. The look on her was so sad. It made me want to cry. 

Neice : Uncle Kwang you are mean!

So what does that have to do with saigon? I came to Saigon sandwich expecting great things. But what I got was a sandwich that was mostly all veggies and mayo. The bread was hard as rocks. I had cuts in the inner roof of my mouth. So bad. After I took my first bite, my coworker said you ok? With all the glowing reviews, what the heck happened? I love to support my peoples, but this is all wrong. So this is how my neice felt after opening that small box.

Me : Uncle Kwang is not mean. Come with me to the car to help me.

Shes huffing and puffing all the way, as soon as she opened the car door and sees that costco sized teddy bear she screams! 

Niece : Yes you are mean! you shouldnt play games on little kids! I love you though!

So Saigon Sandwich, a second chance will be coming soon, I'm coming back in one month. You better suprise me with something big!
author: Q L.

description:
I consider myself a banh mi connoisseur.  Due to the 4 1/2 stars and the over 2000 reviews, I was obligated to give Saigon Sandwich a try.  

Overall, its a satisfactory sandwich, but here are my gripes.

1) Too much sauce made the bun soggy :(
    It was super messy.

2) Good amount of meat, but the main topping was an excess of pickled carrot.
    
I've eaten banh mi all over the Bay Area, Southern California, New York, and most other major metropolitan cities.  
My favorite banh mi place is Dakao in San Jose.
The sauce is great without a soggy bun (and awesome bread), meat is plentiful, toppings are numerous, price is unbeatable.
author: Matt W.

description:
Let me dissect this $3.75 banh mi sandwich: 
BUN - lightly toasted and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside
MEATS - roasted pork, roasted chicken, fancy meat (my bf's fave; looks like white bologne)
VEGGIES - pickled daikon and carrots, fresh cilantro (but where's the cucumber? - my inner Bostonian asks)
SAUCE - special mayo; I should have asked for extra because mine didn't have enough and left my sandwich kind of dry
PATE - the most important part - literally a spreadable meat/liver paste as unpleasant as it may seem - but absolutely delicious; didn't realize you have to add it on as a combo - so don't forget to ask for it!
I would not say this is the best banh mi I've ever had, but this might be the best in SF.
author: Christina H.

description: Best cheap tasty roast chicken banh mi For only $3.75! Oh the crunch and add some sriracha for a nice heat to combat the sweet pickled carrots and radish. Fast service and a great find.
author: Dara D.

description: Simple Vietnamese sandwich place but extremely good value. A great pork meatball sandwich for $3.75. I've been disappointed with all other Vietnamese sandwiches I've had after eating at Saigon Sandwich.
author: Petter B.

description: Best banh mi sandwiches in San Francisco!! For $3.75 I recommend the roasted pork. The chicken is good too!!
author: Taj M.

description:
This place has enough reviews as it is..but I must say....the BEST BANH MI EVER!!!! Oh yummy banh mi, why must you be located in the dangerous part of town? Little Saigon is smack dab in the tenderloin district (aka the "TL"). So I suggest getting your fix only during the day. 

Chicken banh mi ($3.25) - ingredients are fresh, pate is savory, and they use REAL slices of chicken. Not that crap, cold stuff that Lee's has. The bread is softer here and they pack it with the right amount of stuff - lots of meat and veggies. EXCELLENT.

There's a line out the door..but it doesn't take long to get your order. About 10 minutes or so. No seating - just order and go. The ladies running this place are sweet, efficient, and work hard to make all those sandwiches for the hungry masses. I wish they had a receipt or number system so you know which order is yours. They just call out the sandwich that's ready - so just remember who was standing in front of you.

I like to pair my sandwich with a trip to Quickly's down the street from this place. More so cause you have a place to sit and enjoy your meal..plus Quickly's has a tv to watch Friends or some show while you're eating, and offers sriracha sauce which I love plenty of on my banh mi! I'll save the rest on Quickly's in the TL for another review.

Overall: 5. You can't beat the price. & that banh mi craving will definitely be fulfilled at this place! Check it out...during the day!
author: Loriel L.

description: The bahn mi are delicious. We had the chicken, pork and pate and they were all excellent. Inside seating would be nice but I can't complain when it so good. Word to the wise, watch yourself as you walk through a zombie like mob of transients to get to this place. (Yes, I exaggerated but you catch my drift)
author: Review M.

description:
These ladies know what's up. 

It put viet places in the east coast to shame. 

Turtle tower and here will always be must check-ins spots once I land in SF. 

Cheap and good. Enough said!!!
author: Chris L.

description:
Ok... I'm not huge on Vietnamese sandwiches... So, maybe I don't know anything.
I've had them about 9X my whole life.. and, well, they're ok.

Everyone's been talking about this place.. so, I try it. and yes, with the pate and all that. 

One word came to mind after two bites. DRY. 

There was soo much bread. and the pate.. and the bread.. Did I mention bread? 

By the end of the sandwich.. the roof of my mouth was paying for it.. big time..
and my mouth was dry. 

If this is your idea of an awesome sandwich.. by all means, knock yourself out. 

Me? I'm sticking to Ike's and Little Lucca
author: Garland W.

description:
You walk in....these are your thoughts:
"Man this place is a duuuuuuuump!  WTF are with the ghetto signs!  They have 3 things on their menu?!  Okay, five....um, still I dunno.  Okay wait in line....uh, no one knows what they're doing, this woman is yelling Chinese at me....awkwardly tell her you want a pork sandwich.  She doesn't want your money yet, you have to wait till the sandwich is made...uh, they asked me if I wanted it to go  To go?!  You guys literally have two cramped chairs, an awkward distance from each other, and right in the middle of everything!  No, I'll take it to go thanks.  Okay, got it, take it home, blah blah....  This sandwich!  This f#cking....are you kidding me with this sandwich?!  Are you f#%^&(*&^ing kidding me?!  This is the best sandwich ever.  This sandwich is killing me.  When was the last time I ever ate anything this good?!  Where the FFFF is my phone so I can text my friends?!   Next bite, it's time.  THIS SANDWICH!!  AAAAH!  The perfect jalapenos, the delicious sauce.  This sandwich is why I was born.  Okay, I'm going in again...."  and then you die from happiness.
author: Theo T.

description:
When I get a hankerin' for banh mi, there's not much I can do to convince myself to eat something different. I've seen some great executions of this humble sandwich, but not really in SF - until recently. In general, I look for three key criteria:

1. Crunchy, perky roll
2. Appropriately authentic ingredients (pâté is a must, cheese is a no-no)
3. Even distribution of ingredients throughout entire roll surface area - if there is cucumber on one side, and pork on the other, you won't be seeing me in your shop again.

Saigon Sandwich hits each of these, so I give high-ish marks for taste and delivery. However if I'm totally honest, I'd have to say that the experience overall is kinda stressful.

This is a tiny place, with standing room for only about 5 people; come prepared to contort your body as your fellow customers access the drinks fridge. At 11.30am there were already about 10 people in front of me, with a line snaking out the door, although I still got my roll within about 10 minutes, which isn't too bad.

The ambience is completely chaotic. There was one woman brusquely taking and handing out orders, and two other ladies putting the rolls together, while the phone rang continuously. There was a lot of shouting going on, and 80% of the people waiting were confused about how to order, where to stand, and which order was being called. Some people missed their orders because they were on their phones (fair enough), and one poor girl got so flustered by the experience that she paid and left the store, without her food. She then had to fight her way back through the wall of humans, her face aflame.

All that said, the banh mi is pretty good; the best I've tried in SF so far. The roll itself was properly crunchy, not one of those sad, hotdog bun-type breads that sometimes pass as banh mi. I had the combination with everything, including lots of jalapeños, coriander, and a generous smear of pate. It was very, very tasty.

I would do a lot of things for a really good sandwich, so the poor experience of actually being in the shop won't stop me from going back. But based on what I saw, I think the best way to go would be to figure out what you want ahead of time, phone in your order if you can, and get in and out of the shop as quickly as possible.
author: Lauren D.

description:
I came here again on a recent trip to San Francisco and I had to bring my friends here to try their sandwiches. They loved it so much and bought 10 sandwiches for the rest of our trip! I seriously can't find a Vietnamese sandwich place that taste better than the sandwiches I had here back in Virginia. I am forever spoiled! Can't stop thinking about the extra pate....

The only negative thing about this place is the area. It's a bit sketchy so just be aware.
author: Twitney L.

description: Ok this is the last time I come here. I have been coming here for a long time. But this is now the third time the french role was stale. I don't understand I can't be the only one who is getting stale bread. The bread is not fresh like it use to be. If you like stale, soft bread I guess this place is still good.
author: Joe N.

description:
I wanted this to be amazing! Unfortunately, not so much. The bread was stale, the veggies weren't fresh, and the pork was extremely dry. 

If you want a great Banh Mi, go check out Fresh Brew Coffee at the corner of Bush and Taylor.
author: Sarah M.

description: So much deliciousness in a Vietnamese sandwich! The carrots are sweet and sour and the bread is oh so crunchy! My favorite place to get a bahn mi!! Cash only and the most authentic place made by sweet Vietnamese ladies
author: Julie M.

description: Best banh mi in SF. Hole in the wall but those ladies rock out those sandwiches. Even the veggie sandwich hit the spot. Don't be afraid to stop by if you are in the area.
author: G L.

description: Wow the Banh mi is amazing! Bread is warm and toasty, meat is tender, veggies are fresh, and the spread, YES! Can't beat it, $3.75 is the deal of the century. I'd probably buy it for double the price.
author: Raniel C.

description:
$3.75.  BOMB ME !!!
Best deal on the best Banh Mi around.  If you are in the area on foot and they are open, even if you just ate, get one or two, or... and eat or take it/them with you for later.  Perfect perfect perfect attention to the little details that elevate sandwich to art.  Please Ban Me from all other viet-nom impostery and guide me to Saigon Sandwich... THIS is IT.  From now on, I pledge to be banhogamous.  Dearie me!
author: Bob K.

description:
This little tiny hole is a well visited spot for many natives and visitors. Located in the shady space of the Tenderloin, Saigon Sandwich hosts a little menu accompanied by good flavor, portion, and price.

Cash only. Random little nibbling items for purchase on the counter. The eating counter space along the window is slanted, somewhat detached, and not really that useful for eating unless you are desperate. Beverages are stocked in the standing cooler against the wall.

Fortunately, when I went in, I only encountered one other person ahead of me. The time is took to get my chicken banh mi sandwich? 1 minute.

I know. Fucking speed!

I carted that thing off to have with a bottle of water while chilling at the Ferry Building for a spell. Excellent food stuff.

NOTE: Prices are about $3.75 for the average banh mi.
author: Cate T.

description:
The place is small and crowded, might not be the cleanest, and there's only about 3 different selections to choose from...but here, you can find the best banh mi in town!  

Love lil places like this!  Please note, you can not eat inside here.  It's take-out only.  It's so small, there is barely enough space even for that.  

Go with the roast pork sandwich, and have a nice day.
author: Koji Y.

description:
Wtf?! How does this place have such a high rating? I'm truly stumped.

We ordered the chicken and pork sandwiches. The preparation looked unappetizing as the lady took the pork out of a big plastic bag stuffed with meat... And the sandwiches turned out to be unappetizing - the bread was tough, the veggies didn't have enough flavor and weren't distributed evenly, the meat was bland and there wasn't enough hot sauce!!
author: Margaret R.

description: Great for a quick lunch grab! Trouble is, there's not a lot of a standing room, it does look like a hole in the wall where sanitation seems somewhat questionable, and the sandwiches unpack a bit messy... but the service is fast and friendly, and you're full for $3.45.
author: Erica O.

description:
As much as I hate to say it, we were all pretty disappointed by the sandwiches here.  They were pretty standard and there was nothing standout about the flavors.  $3.50 for a sandwich is pretty awesome, but once again, we were not sadly not impressed.

There are way too many options in San Francisco so we will likely not be back.
author: Carrie C.

description: 5 stars for authenticity, super friendly ladies and for the price. I'd give them an additional star for showing no modesty on proportions. You shouldn't pay more than $5 for a legit bahn-mi special combination sandwich and you don't have to here.
author: Sheena A.

description:
I think its the bunch of sauce and the big ol sloppy pork that makes bahn mi from Saigon Sandwich so delectable to this ngi da trng. I get one of those and some che, sit myself in the park away from the sketchy mc sketchersons outside, and have a lovely time.

It could just be the hype, it might not be the best in the bay area, but would you really feel good not trying it?
author: Ben M.

description:
Out of all the Banh Mi I've had in the bay area, this place realllllly packs in the meat.  The roast pork is actually pretty flavorful, and cooked fairly well.  On the flip side, I actually enjoy having a bit more veggies in my sandwich, and I felt like I needed both more jalapenos, and more cilantro.  I didn't notice the cucumber at all, which was also a little dissapointing.  The peanut sauce is pretty awesome though, it gives the sandwich a rich and slightly sweet undertone.  

To really top it off, the sandwiches are $3.75.  The sandwich itself is 4 stars, but the price makes it 5.  Why am I getting charged almost 6$ at other places?!
author: David B.

description: Yep, love me some banh mi's. This is just about as good as it gets. Little bit on the small side but I'll let it slide.
author: Sistrsprkl S.

description: Unanimously the best $3.50 you can spend on a filling 3 minute meal. My Vietnamese ancestors would be proud. I never even cared much (nor disliked) but pate, but Saigon Sandwich makes some homepage duck liver (I think) that tastes like paste made from unicorn tears and Angelina Jolie's saliva. Lord almighty. The $3.50 pork / chicken options are all amazing (try them), but the $4 all meat combo is the bee's knees. Sometimes the line is a block long, but it moves very quickly. The 3 ladies working here need to raise prices, supply and demand! I'd happily pay $0.50 more for this wonder.
author: Chuck N.

description:
The best sandwich in San Francisco (period)!
I am a sandwich fan and I have to say that the other reviews are very accurate.
My staple here is the chicken sandwich. I am picky when it come to the meat, bread, toppings etc. This place has top notch ingredients for a great value. Highly recommend it.
author: Midhun J.

description:
Okay finally got my hands on the banh mi from this place. Verdict: Very good, but still overhyped IMO. A lot of it is probably due to the fact that it is more of a unique product in SF to have Vietnamese sandwiches, but were this in SJ... not sure if it would still shine as bright.

I got the Banh Mi Cha (which they call "Fancy Pork") and the meat itself was alright.  The baguette had a nice crunch, but not so crunchy that your mouth is shredded by the time you're done. The pickles were on the sweeter/milder side, which has less a less intense fish sauce essence and is what I think really makes it distinct from other banh mi shops that I'm used to.

Still think it's a little overblown, but that's not to say I'm not a fan. When I return, I'm gonna make sure to add the Pâté, which I'm hoping will force me to bump this review up to 5 stars in the future.
author: Alan W.

description:
The more things change in San Francisco the more SS stays a clean little funky sandwich shop. Took 20 minutes to eat a fancy pork sammie while doing so I thought dang this is a really good sandwich so many layers of love. This is my hood been here since they opened glad to see them prosper.

Everyone is treated the same here an important factoid. Paired with the 5 star sandwich SS remains a San Francisco institution.
author: SF T.

description: Best banh mi I've ever had. To die for. And the prices are good as well. Roast chicken and pork is the bomb!!!!!!!
author: Peter S.

description: Huge sandwiches and definitely worth the wait. I wish they threw in more jalapeños tho.  I would definitely come again and try a different meat.
author: Debbie L.

description: This place is quite tasty. I recommend the combination pork because thats pretty much the standard at all vietnamese sandwich shops. They do have a tofu sandwich that my friends always get since they are vegetarians and they are always satisfied. Ive gotten their sandwiches at least twice a week simply because its so cheap and good!
author: Jeff C.

description: Others sandwich makers take note, this is how you do banh mi. Perfect pork. Crunchy bread. Flavorful sauce. Awesome deal for just $3.75. This would definitely be my go to for lunch if I lived here. I may have to take a dozen back home to share with the guys in mke who try to do banh mi.
author: Andy K.

description: I'd say this was an average to above average sandwhich... I got the pork one ad immediately walked to a park a few blocks away to eat it. The cilantro on the sandwich was above touch to balance the heat from the peppers. Bread was great but outside of that I don't know what all the fuss was about.
author: Clark L.

description:
One of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had. At $3.75 it's a steal! There's always a line here and rightfully so. The bread is delicious, and the meat to vegetable ratios is generous. I've tried almost all the sandwiches here and the chicken is my favorite with the pate being my least. I've read some reviews that rave about the pate though, so maybe it's just an acquired taste. When in doubt, choose chicken though and it'll be a safe bet.

The lady who works is here also super cute in a old asian grandma kinda way and is super nice. Her english isn't the best, but that's something that adds to her charm. 

I'm giving this place 5 stars because it's cheap, delicious, and the turn-around doesn't take that long even if there are usually 10-15 people in line in front of you.
author: Courtney Q.

description:
$3.75 bomb me x 2! Two tiny asian grandmas cranking out the best pate and pickles on the planet! Nevermind the crack heads, they're not hungry! 
Great selection of pork and chicken, as well as traditional coldcuts and pate.

It's the bread though, crusty yet delicate, the crumb soft and fluffy. Like a pate fluffernutter. Pate is rich and fatty, balanced with heaps of picked carrot and daikon, zapped with slices of jalapeno.

These gals ain't afraid of SPICY!! 

Loved it, ate it on the tailgate of the car parked in a free parking spot in the tenderloin....
And smiled all day!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Combination sandwich is amazing (steamed pork, roasted pork, + pate). Definitely on par with the real stuff I had in Southern Vietnam.

Cash only and only like two seats so not a dine in place.
author: Sara D.

description:
This place redefined what I thought a vietnamese sandwich should taste like. DAYUMMM... I am coming here EVERYTIME I visit SF! Saigon sandwich exceeded all my expectations. There was a line coming out the door, but the wait wasn't that long. 

I got the combination sandwich because I like pate in my vietnamese sandwiches. NO REGRETS THERE. Everything about this sandwich was heavenly. I'm having a major case of drooling just thinking about it. The meat and hams were so tender and juicy. The bun was crispy in just the right places. There was pate slabbed all over the inside. The onions and vegetables were crunchy and delicious. Remember to pick out the jalapenos if you're not a fan of spicy things. 

5/5 for EVERYTHING. I loved it. 

PLEASE OPEN ONE IN THE SOUTH BAY. Preferably right next door to my house. I would go every day.
author: Sarana C.

description:
It's still the bomb!!! The layout's changed but the food is the same. Super yummy Meatball Ban Minh (Xiu Mai), loaded with that awesome pickled carrots slaw. The bread is toasted hot and crunchy.  

I shouldn't have been surprised by the price hike...all their sandwiches are now $3.75...cash only people!
author: Pauline L.

description: Extremely affordable.  Extremely fast.  Extremely delicious.  (Plus, I love the Vietnamese (I assume?) rice desserts on the side.)
author: TJ M.

description:
Holy crap, what is the deal with the massive amount of hype this place generates?  After putting this place off for a year since it first was saved on my Yelp bookmark I was finally able to come here since I was in the neighborhood.  i bought both the roast pork (since every raves that it is the best thing "EVER") and the meatball since those are usually my personal favorite vietnamese sandwiches.

All in all...it was okay.  Hence the 3.  On my scale where Lee's get a zero as in I won't even bother ever reviewing a Lee's since it's a cop out, Saigon Sandwich gets a decent grade.  But while I've had worse, I've also seriously had better.  The pork was was underwhelming.  Perhaps it was because of all the hype these reviews had that gave me too high of expectations.  But I swear I've had better roast pork sandwiches (albiet it was in SoCal).  And I'm not personally a fan of the pulled pork style...As for the meatball...completely disappointing.  Not quite sure what else to say than that.  Perhaps it's just not my personal favorite type of xiu mai sandwich (I prefer the ones with tomato sauce and some peas).

3 stars isn't bad though...probably the best you can get in this area.  I would close the door into coming back and maybe trying the combo or cha lua (fancy pork) sandwich.

The line, while long, does move fairly quickly.  Those three older ladies who work at this location move very efficiently.  And if you know Vietnamese like me, they'll actually smile at you when you order and pay.  Lol...
author: Kim D.

description:
We traveled into the Tenderloin just for Saigon Sandwich, and after trying the Special Combination sandwich, I feel like Saigon is more acceptable than spectacular in my eyes. For me I really like BBQ Chicken flavored vietnamese sandwiches and since Saigon only had 4 or 5 options (none of which were BBQ Chicken), it's possible that I was simply unable to appreciate the Bánh mì here with my American-born taste buds. 

Besides this, it is worth noting that the sandwiches are between $3-4 each, which is practically a steal. At that price, you might as well venture in and test the Saigon sandwiches against your own tastebuds for the same price it would take you to drive to the nearest In-N-Out for example. My guess is that you are more likely to be like the other 90% of people who rate Saigon Sandwich as 4 or 5 stars than the lowly 10% like me. May the odds be ever in your favor.

Other details:
The shop itself is very small. You walk in and it's just a counter and their kitchen, with 2 seats facing the window, a small refrigerator with pudding, drinks, and sweets, and standing space for about 6 people max.
author: Eric S.

description:
These samiches are pants down THE BEST. Why? Idk!! I'm telling you it's got something to do with their messy/dirty (although it's not as dirty as it used to) that makes the samiches taste delish!!

They're always the right combination of crunchy and soft. Even though they probably use the same fancy pork as other places, their pickled carrots and pate makes the samich taste special.

Every time I come here, one is not enough. I want to keep eating and eating and eating! But I've gotta settle for one for the sake of human kind.
author: Oriel F.

description: I love this place, I have been going there for over three years. The sandwiches are amazing; if you are in the district, go to this place! This is the best sandwich shop and it is affordable too!
author: M W.

description: Great hole in the wall place for nice Saigon Sandwich. Few simple choices, mainly different types of meat. Really cannot go wrong with any item. All tastes great. Sometime there is a line, but it pass through quite quickly. Very affordable price to get one of the best Vienamese sandwich in the city. Hard to beat. Cash only, so visit the ATM before lunch if needed.
author: J Y.

description:
I ate my first Saigon Sandwich overlooking the most beautiful view in the Bay Area, atop Angel Island in the middle of the bay. One would think the expansive panoramic view would eclipse the sandwich...but it did not!

Hands down the best banh mi I've ever had...all others I've had before seem inferior.

Fast service and incredible prices also are a huge plus, and the fact that my friend lives incredibly close doesn't hurt either!

I'll dream of Saigon Sandwich...yes, it's that good!
author: Greg S.

description: A really good banh mi place. Banh mi is cheap. The downside is that there is usually a line at lunch and how long it takes to get your sandwich depends on how good you are at pushing and shouting.
author: Karl K.

description:
I was with my Vietnamese ex for three years.  You can say we mostly conversed in English because my Vietnamese is limited to these three things:

1. cam on (pronounced as "kam un" which means thank you)
2. Banh mi dac biet
3. tôi  muon tinh duc

#1 and #2 above definitely helps you with the ordering part.  These ladies run this place like a well-oiled machine, but they speak minimal English.  Plus couple in the fact that there's usually a line out the door at lunchtime, they really don't have time for chit-chat anyway.

I dragged my bf over here so we can both savor one of the things on the Big Eats SF list which is:

#22 Vietnamese roast pork sandwich at Saigon Sandwiches. 

Toasted bread, tender roast pork with pickled vegetables, cilantro and jalapeno all rounded up with a sweet sauce -- the perfect to-go lunch for only $3 each.  

Oh yeah, don't even dare say #3 over here -- it roughly translates to "I want sex", which I'm sure will result to having a Banh Mi thrown to your face.
author: Janice C.

description:
BEST BAHN MI IN SF PERIOD!!! TRY THE MEATBALL!!!

Prices are cheap for one of the best sandwiches in SF. Even though they raised the prices since I started to go there in 2000, you can still get a bang-for-buck meal for a little over 5 bucks. The bed is perfectly toasted and the meats are always tasty and well marinated.
 
The ladies who work there are super nice even though they have to put up with retards who can't order and homeless people trying to mess up everyone's day. 

Parking is a bitch but if you know what you're doing, you know how to get around it.
author: Ron R.

description: Ohmygoodness pate bahn mi. They also make little rice ball treats stuffed with bananas and other deliciousness if you have friends that do not eat wheat/meat/other allergens.
author: Meagan S.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is by far the best lunch you can get for $3.50! Even though they get really busy during lunch, the Vietnamese ladies behind the counter quickly crank out the sandwiches by the dozen. The Bahn Mi roast pork is pretty tasty and the special combo is even better, with plenty of liver pate.  I recommend avoiding the "fanci pork" which is stuffed with a strange  greyish processed pork cake - still tasty, but roast pork and the special combo is a lot better.

The sandwiches go great with a large can of coconut juice. Unfortunately, there's not much seating (only 2 chairs by the window) - so you'll have to take it to go.
author: Allen T.

description:
I've been coming here for years. This place is almost perfection. The only thing missing is the headcheese on the combo. I find this to be very, very sad indeed. So sad that I had to knock off a star. The bread is nice and perfectly toasty, the slathering of pate is generous, the pickles are delicious, and the price is right.

While I love Saigon Sandwich, the absence of headcheese has me going to Lee's up the street on occasion to get my fix. Don't hate.

Also, their steamed pork is pretty damn good, but I often prefer grilled pork. Why? Because thit nuong is where it's at.

NY Times suggested that the banh mi at Saigon Sandwich "may be the best in America."
http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/07/the-vietnamese-sandwich-banh-mi-in-america/

This article, judging by the comments, apparently pissed off a lot of Houstonians. While I've never had a banh mi in Houston, I sincerely doubt that there are better banh mi sandwiches to be found there. Why? Because fuck Texas, that's why!
author: J K.

description: I'm going to keep it simple: this is the best bahn mi in SF...cheap and delicious! Must try if in the area.
author: Javi M.

description:
What has not been said? I've been coming here for 2 years now. And I love this place. Their sandwiches are always hot, freshly made, filling and tasty. Puts a smile on my face everytime.

Maybe that's why I get so upset when people say sandwiches at Lee's are good. Obviously, they haven't had Saigon Sandwiches! Makes me want to drag their butts across the street and show them what's up. That even though it takes longer and now pricier for a sandwich, there is always a long line. 

I love those two ladies. Their system simple yet efficient. I'm fairly picky when it comes to garnishes. But I hate the thought of messing up their rhythm and flow for my selfish needs. Rather I just pick out the unwanteds back at work.

Sometimes I wish the ladies would get more help. Can't imagine going through 3 hour lunch rushes everyday hustling around making sandwiches for hungry people breathing down their necks. But then again, I wouldn't want Saigon Sandwiches to change either.
author: Marti L.

description:
I don't remember the last time I have seen a place with a 4.5 star rating based on over 2,000 reviews, so I went in with high expectations.

And this place DELIVERED.

It's an absolute hole in the wall, with a bit of standing room by the counter and a couple of chairs by a ledge along the front window. The front counter is filled with East Asian snacks and candies that I had never seen before, but the core menu for banh mi is very simple - pretty much just choose your protein. 

The sandwich was delicious. What really made the difference for me was whatever sauce they used, which kept the tasty but fairly simple bread nice and moist. The meat (I got chicken) and other fillings tasted fresh. All in all, the best banh mi I can recall having, although I don't get it all that often.
author: Manu V.

description:
HELLLLLLO GORGEOUS! (refer to picture)

I love a good banh mi and after giving up on the option up north (refer to Yi Shen review) I was excited to renew the love in San Fran. This is exactly what a Banh Mi should be; crusty bread, great marinade on the chicken, good spice and super crisp herb and veggies. Oh and nice and big for under $4. 

Like I said, hellllllo gorgeous.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Great Banh Mi sandwitch in SF!  It's not so much the bread, its the meat in the sandwich.  The pork was perfectly marinated and sliced!
Great cheap eats!  Their Pork sandwich ($5) made the 7X7 top 100 list and wow was it great!  Another great sandwich they sell that I'm a fan of is their pork meatball sandwich.  It's not really a meatball shape.  It's a ground pork texture with pickled carrots, radish, fresh cilantro and sliced jalapenos in a toasted warm french bread. 

This is a to go place.  Very small and very limited menu.  I'm a fan of their sandwich!
author: Ying F.

description:
Holy crap that's a good banh mi and I've had a lot of banh mi in my life. Their spead adds an amazing richness to the sandwich that sort of makes up for the not particularly charred crispy pork.

crap that is a tasty sandwich.
author: Misha T.

description: Excellent Marinated Tofu sandwich. I'm a vegetarian, and I loved it. Great for vegans too.
author: Reena S.

description:
THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES EVERRR. 

been coming here since I was little. I love pâté and they put a gracious amount! i usually get the special. It used to be a lot cheaper but it's still pretty affordable. they don't skimp on meat so I'd say it's still pretty worth it. when i say i want a Vietnamese sandwich, that means I want one from Saigon Sandwich.
author: Kristina L.

description:
$3.25/banh mi sandwich..stuffed silly up to the very brim with fresh veg and one bona fide filling meal were one to eat the whole thing at one go. 

Pate and grilled pork.... needs more depth of flavor in the grilled meat, for sure.... bread is not the authentic type, as in altogether too dense. 

Call out your order to the stressed lady acting as gatekeeper, even when you're the 6th person in line.... got there just before the line started getting seriously challenging.


Don't hate me, but I really truly do prefer Lee's sandwiches.. altogether in one composite random bite, theirs is more palatable and flavorful, and they do the baguette just the way one would have in France.... perfect balance of everything.
author: Jana C.

description: After moving to San Francisco, I was in search of the best eats around the SF area. I yelped and saw the high ratings, so I had to go and try for myself. A small little hole in the wall shop serving delicious Vietnamese sandwiches. The ladies making the sandwiches were super friendly. I ordered the fancy pork with pate, this is by far the best pate I have ever had. They don't skimp on the pate either! It's generously slathered on paired with the Vietnamese steam pork (cha) is a match made in heaven. I can't wait to come back and try the different kinds of sandwiches they offer. Highly recommended!
author: Nhi N.

description:
My husband and I went there after a sushi chef recommended it the night before.  My husband and I walked there from union square where our hotel was.. DO NOT RECOMMEND... you have to walk through some not so nice parts of downtown... 

We were underwhelmed by the sandwich.  the place is a little tiny store where they sell premade things and the sandwich was so so to us... Don't think we'll try again when we go abck to SF...
author: JoAnn H.

description:
Saigon Sandwich. Apparently I've been living under a rock for 21 years of my life until I tried Saigon Sandwiches. Like seriously. Where have I been?!?!

Their combination pork with extra liver sauce is amazingly orgasmic. Literally the best vietnamese sandwich you'll ever have in your life. Sandwiches packed full with condiments and pack a huge punch of flavor.

 Be aware that some of them have a jalepeno, I didn't know so when I cut my sandwich in half, I bit SMACK into the jalepeno and rushed in all the burning sensations.  So I'll have everything on there except that jalepeno please! :D
author: Harriet W.

description:
Best banh mi!

A bit of a hole in the wall but the sandwiches are spot on! Sandwiches are made with baguette out of the oven and made to order. I tried the roast pork and it was excellent. The condiments and picked veggies are fresh and tasty. Portions are generous and the prices are only $3-5.

Menu is super basic with just a few meat options for the sandwiches and nothing else. On the counter and on racks beside the counter are some Vietnamese desserts and packaged goods. No eating space inside, take it all to go!
author: Jennie W.

description: I had high expectations for this place and sadly I was disappointed. We ordered the chicken and pork bahn mi and overall it was just okay. The bread was tough and didnt taste fresh. The chicken was really dry and I just didnt enjoy as much as I wanted to. May have to come back and give it another try.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Well deserved 5 STAR! drove an hour to get there.. they ran out of bread!!! 
was upset, but I had to come back, figured it must really be the best.. went back the next day and I have to say it was the BEST Vietnamese sandwich I ever had!!! so happy I came back!!
author: Danny H.

description: My favorite place near work. Super cheap and friendly. Sandwiches are pretty good, I had the pork.
author: Antonio I.

description: Very very good choice. 3.50 banh mi with many meat or tofu choices. Wow. Cash only. Clean place, very friendly owner.
author: Dominic C.

description:
WOW
Sandwich nirvana.
My other favorite banh mis is at Out the Door but that's a $10 sandwich for what is supposed to be an inexpensive item.
Enter Saigon Sandwich.  When I made my maiden visit on 11/9/14 pretty much perfect.  There's a popular place in the East Bay that yelpers love, this place is 1000% better.  
If there's a downside it would it's in the Trendyloin and there is limited parking but as far as sandwiches go this gets big ups!
author: Yong K.

description: Never goes wrong. This place continues to be the best Viet Sandwich in the city. It is quick, cheap and truly delicious. I ordered this time the roasted pork and the flavors are always clean and yummy. This is a quick grab and go place, and it is cash only. You might see a line once in a while but it goes by super quick. Totally recommend this place to everyone who is looking to eat a delicious Viet Sandwich.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: The viet sandwiches are smaller than the ones I usually have but these cost less. The bread was really crispy and crunchy. The roasted pork are mostly meat and not fat, which is a good thing. This is like a healthy version of the viet sandwiches in New York.
author: Susan L.

description:
I'm Vietnamese-American. I'm from Southern California. I know how to pronounce banh mi correctly. 

I have gotten 5 banh mi s from Saigon Sandwich: pork, chicken, combo, and 2 meatballs. The chicken is more tender and flavorful than the pork. The combo wasn't really memorable. Finally, I found the meatball most flavorful, although it lacks the texture. 

Although it is not the best sandwich I have had, I keep coming back for its convenience and price. The price is expected of a Vietnamese sandwich, if not more on the expensive side of a sandwich (to hell with other establishments that try to sell sandwiches for more than 5 bucks...). It's really close to City Hall. 

My biggest complaint has to be the baguette. I almost tore the roof of my mouth a few times. Take small bites, squash it down a little bit. I'm not a big fan of eating the elbow of the bread with my last bite. 

The service is quick. Maybe its just my uncharming personality, but I didn't get any brownie points with them for speaking Vietnamese. Please let me know if someone has had better luck.


These are three bad ass women who get sandwiches DONE.
author: Diana N.

description: I've never felt compelled to review a restaurant having just finished eating there...until now.  Not only are they an amazing deal ($4.75 for a gigantic coconut curry sandwich) but the quality is out of this world.  Cold and crispy veggies, crunchy French bread, and perfectly seasoned chicken.  I'm coming back tomorrow for sure!
author: Christopher D.

description:
A small sandwich place.  Doesn't look nice at all but the taste of the sandwich are amazing. 
Had the roasted chicken and my friend had the pork.  Both were super good
author: Oded H.

description: The BEST bahn mi Sandos I've had on the West Coast! It's a hole in the wall with a secret. Check it out, you won't be disappointed.
author: Harvey D.

description:
As I sit here (literally shoving my face with a meatball bahn mi), I am so happy that tears could come out of my eyes. I just bought myself 6 sandwiches (and I'm still undecided whether I will share). I am having a love affair with my lunch right now. 

Yes, Saigon Sandwiches have the best bahn mi in town. I highly recommend the roasted pork and the meatball sandwiches. I honestly don't know what "fanci pork" is so I didn't order it. 

Roasted pork is MUCH tastier than roasted chicken. I'm normally a chicken person, but trust me... get the pork. 

What is so amazing about these sandwiches? The meats are SOOO flavorful. The bread is fresh and fluffy with a still hard, crunchy exterior (the way a mini baguette should be). They don't skimp on the fillings and they pile it with pickled carrots, cilantro, and a little bit of jalapenos (there's also some mayo involved). The only thing I miss is the pickled radishes.

Saigon Sandwiches is in the heart of the Tenderloin. If you are a girl, make sure you go with a friend or only go alone in the daylight. It's always better to be on the safe side. (OK, I will stop lecturing you like my mother now).

Cash only. Sandwiches run around $3.25 (depending on what you order). Go, it's worth the wait. Oh and do yourself a favor and order yourself two. You'll thank me later.
author: Jackie T.

description: Saigon Sandwich deserves very high Yelp reviews. The Banh Mi is excellent, perfect actually. Where else can you have a full delicious meal in SF for under $6? A sandwich, chips and soda? Would go back in a heartbeat. Keep in mind the location is in a terrible part of town, lots of homeless people, dirty streets, and smells that could kill a charging Rhino at 20 paces. Buy your food, drive to a quaint park and enjoy the SF sunshine.
author: Henry J.

description:
Grab and go, affordable, quick, and nom nom nomlicious. 

My friend Kayla had been raving about this place for quite some time so I knew I had to eventually try it. I am a huge fan of sandwiches because they are one of the easiest foods to eat and they have every nutritional thing you need in them. Vegetables, grains, and proteins all there in one bite...what more could you really ask for. So I took my boyfriend here to get sandwiches for our picnic in the park. Well that plan never really happened because we finished the sandwich before we even got in the car. Because we shared a sandwich our lunch in total was $4. The chinese ladies that work at this vietnamese sandwich shop are all nice and funny. So if you are looking for a cheap hole in the wall grab n go kind of place I would suggest trying this place for sure.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Saigon Sandwich has been claimed the best Banh Mi spot in the Tenderloin, or at least in San Francisco.  I've tried most of their Banh Mi sandwiches and I don't have any complaints.  Saigon Sandwich definitely does live up to all of the hype.  

If you're new to Saigon Sandwich, I would recommend you try their Roast Pork or the BBQ Chicken first.  You can then make your way into trying other sandwiches like the traditional Combination or the Meatball Pork with Pate.  Also if you can't handle spicy, ask the ladies to make your Banh Mi w/o the jalapeño. 

Great for light lunch snacks or food you can take on a picnic.  It's cheap, taste great and fast.  You'll be tempted to take few on the road, for later, but these sandwiches are best eaten right out the oven.
author: yusai g.

description:
my favorite banh mi spot 
found out about this place like almost 10 years ago
author: James J.

description: Divey little walk up sandwich counter.    Good Bahn Mi sando, somewhat questionable cleanliness....   Only $3.75 for a decent sized sandwich.   Line was out the door, but went quick.
author: Dave C.

description:
I used to like Vietnamese sandwiches. Now I love them. 

The bread is fresh, the meat is tasty, the ingredients, a perfect blend. Pork banh mi ftw. Really, the food alone deserves five stars. If only I could give an extra star or two for the PRICE!
author: Fern L.

description: I would get sandwiches from here several times a week before I moved from SF. It is easily the best deal in The City. Health codes be damned!  Don't be turned off by the somewhat lax approach to food safety. It's not old school Tu-Lan style food safety issues level,  but could be close. But not once have I gotten sick!
author: Matthew K.

description: The best! Filled with meat (juicy and flavorful) and stuffed with pickled daikon and carrots. Bread is perfectly crunchy and soft on the inside. You really can't beat the price for the quality and amount of ingredients. Cash only!
author: jennifer m.

description:
Lives up to the hype. A hole in the wall in tenderloin but definitely worth a visit. I tried chicken, roast pork and pate. Pork is the best. And chicken is also well flavored. And you cannot beat the price of $3.75. So I always order 2. And, remember to ask to cut the sandwich in half. 

The 3 ladies there are efficient bahn mi magicians!
author: Linda K.

description:
If you like Vietnamese sandwiches it doesn't get much better. There is generally a line out of the door when I pass this place, but they are so fast and efficient. Pork banh mi is amazing. 

You can't beat the price and quality in SF.
author: Tara K.

description: Omg so good! I'm so psyched to work near such a delicious sandwich place and a great bargain. I absolutely love Vietnamese sandwiches and these are delicious. If you're from out of town, note this is in the worst part of town. Don't be scared. I've known of people to pass up coming here because, once scoping the area, they found the...scenery...detestable and unclean. Don't do it. This place is solid. Their health ratings are great and the sandwiches are on point! So delicious!
author: J J.

description:
Best Viet sandwich I've ever had!! 
Always get the special combo which is loaded with chicken, pork, and sliced pork rolls. They are super generous on the pate which is my fav part!! Yummy pickled carrots and daikons..few springs of cilantro and 3 pieces jalapenos. 
The bread is from Paris baguette which gives it the crunch and texture of a Viet sandwich.  The ladies can be quite rude. I went one time when they were about to close the gate and she totally knocked me down, screaming that I shouldve came earlier. Still, she went in to make my yummy sandwich and even gave me a smile handing it to me. Much appreciated.
author: Linda T.

description:
Best Bahn Mi sandwiches in town! This place beats all the other stores/restaurants that sell Bahn Mi. A hole in the wall place located in the TL. 

Must try!
author: Philip K.

description: My all time favorite Vietnamese sandwich place! I always come here when I'm in the area. There's often a line that goes out of the little shop but it's totally worth the wait. They make the sandwiches as you order it and they're pretty fast at it too. Their French bread is nice, crunchy and perfectly sized, so the bread won't hurt the roof of my mouth when I bite into it. I usually get the special combination sandwich which has different assortments of ham and pork. The pate isn't too overwhelming. They also put a good amount of vegetables to balance out the meat. I absolutely love their sandwiches and I'd recommend it to anyone especially if you're looking for good food in SF!
author: Jennifer Z.

description:
Saigon Sandwich makes some of the best Banh Mi sandwiches I've ever tasted.  The french baguette bread they use for the sandwiches is kind of small, but what it lacks in size, it makes up for in flavor, texture, and freshness.  As far as the sandwich fillings, I've tried and loved just about all of them: BBQ Pork, Meatball Pork, BBQ Chicken, and even the Tofu. 

For the longest time, Saigon's prices were $2.00 and below, but slowly through the passage of time, their prices have crept up to closer to $4.00.  It is still worth the price, though.  Frankly, I was surprised at how they could have made much profit with their old prices.

They also have a good variety of other Vietnamese products, pastries, steamed buns, desserts, etc.  They have a custard flan, topped with a thin caramel syrup that is oh so yummy, too.
author: Danielle O.

description: my roommate thomas brought home a bunch of sandwiches one night, he already had in and out and I was like hell yeah I'd want some banh mi.. ffff yeah its so good, one bit of that meatball is just an explosion of flavor and the pickled vegetables gives it good texture and the bread was just  yum too.. the expectation was yeah.. just another banh mi normal one, but then one bite is heaven. I wanna go there now and I dream of banh mi everyday after that eventful night.
author: kristopher v.

description:
For as long as I can bee-line to and from Saigon Sandwich through the Tenderloin untouched and unharmed, I will continue to feast on the roasted pork bahn mi. 

This is one of the best deals in the city, $3.95 will get you a huge, flavorful and perfectly crafted lunch.  How a sandwich composed of such simple, fresh ingredients can be that flavorful is beyond me.  Mind. Blown. Don't let the line-out-the-door deter you, the sweet ladies behind the counter work hard and keep the service line moving. You will not be disappointed, promise!
author: Brianna M.

description:
1 star for convenience 
1 star for taste
1 star for the 3 viet ladies slaving away in that tiny shop 
1 star for fearing for your life while walking up the tenderloin to make it here -  which      makes the food taste better. 
1 final star for how deliciously cheap they are. (4 bucks each, quarter more for the special) 


Ps. Get the special combination and tell those 3 saints to have a wonderful day.
author: William L.

description:
Ordered: 
Roast pork sandwich.

It's hard to not give a pretty solid review to banh mi.  It's remarkably difficult to find a better price to benefit ratio, especially in a city as full of itself as San Francisco (see Out the Door in the Embarcadero for how to not do banh mi properly).  So for nothing else, the humility of a small banh mi shop in the Tenderloin can't get anything below a 4 star, for the sheer audacity of surviving without pretense in a city that sustains itself upon it.

That being said, there's nothing particularly remarkable about the sandwiches, but I guess that's the point.  The meat is plentiful, the sauces drippy, the bread nice and crisp.  You get the mix of savory and sweet that defines banh mi, weighted more towards savory.  It is good.The service is eh but who cares.  Just get your damn sandwich and go and eat it atop a rooftop while admiring the number of drivers who dare to brave Hyde street and its seemingly perpetual deadlock, you goddamn hipster asshole.
author: Norman S.

description:
There's a reason why so many people have reviewed Saigon Sandwiches.
Their bahn mi are delicious, satisfying, a good mix of savory with veggies and sauce. My favorite is the plump chicken bahn mi served toasty warm (mmm, mmm good!). Real down home Vietnamese fare and the best in San Francisco!

In the recently renovated space, you walk up to the counter, put in your order and watch the ladies efficiently churn out the sandwiches. They toast up the bread rolls en masse so they are slightly crisp on the outside but still soft and springy on the inside. They then apply the secret sauce, pile in the fixings (meat and marinated vegetables) and then wrap it up in a snap! 

Maybe I'm being a pain, but I usually ask them to cut my sandwich in half and leave out the chiles. They're so nice to accommodate me.

Only a couple of seats by the front window so it's best to take out your sammies.
And since all the yummy sandwiches are less than $4 each, it's a deal...or would that be a steal?
author: Joanna T.

description: I will have dreams about the roast pork. They aren't shy about lathering the bread generous amounts of butter, heaping the hot meat inside the warm bread, and squeezing in a large handful of veggies. You can't easily beat this at $3.75. My only nonexisting complaint would be that the bread is chewier than I prefer, but still so good. Always get a second to go, you'll be so glad you did. And don't share - you'll want your own to enjoy, trust me.
author: Josh P.

description:
The best sandwich is the tofu sandwich. 

I like how the bread is not excessively toasted like other bun mi joints. Haha. 

Get the dehydrated taro and fruit packages. Those super rock.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Came here to grab a sandwich for lunch. My coworkers love it and there was a long line which is always a good sign. 

However, It was meh. I wasn't a fan of the sweet sauce they put on the sandwich and was put off by the fact that they used ham instead of real thit nguoi. The pate was also just lumped in the middle so I got a huge chunk of it half way through the sandwich. Not the best surprise. 

Not bad I guess for San Francisco where the "little Saigon" is only 2 blocks and smaller than one of the Vietnamese plazas in San Jose but for my sandwich needs I'll stick to Thanh Huong in San Jose.
author: Tu T.

description: Located in the Tenderloin, don't be surprised to trip over a coma induced heroin junkie, or hear an occasional gunshot, but for the best Bahn Mi in the city for a shockingly inexpensive $3.75, it's worth the risk of being mugged by some drug dealing gang banger. I'll be back (with a weapon).
author: Brian S.

description:
Fantastic. Best bahn mi ever? Probably. Enough said really.

I think the only thing I have left to say is how fulfilling these sandwiches are...great value for your money, even if you are a frequent eater you won't be hungry for hours and hours
author: Paul M.

description:
Awesome sandwich, cash only, special combination or roast pork, $4. 

There are unwritten rules here:
1. Have your order ready before you get to the cashier, (have the cash ready too) 
2. Remember who is in front of you, wait outside once you've ordered
3. Once the person in front of you gets called (no names), be at the ready to grab and go
4. Enjoy :)
author: Kevi L.

description:
I think I actually might slightly live here.

BF and I crave this place at least monthly.  The banh mi is cheap, fast, and good.  We even found a usual bench area to sit across from Phil'z where we enjoy our sandwiches.  He gets the special pate (not really my thing) and I always get the grilled pork.

The ladies who work here are super nice.  Just recently we actually we went and there was only one working in the hot hot heat.  She managed to gracefully take all the orders the sammiches.  The other ladies made it back in time to help her, appears she went on some errand.

Ya the area is not that nice, but it is only open until 5pm anyway.  Worth it to come here.  Best banh mi in SF!
author: Adele Z.

description:
All the bahn mi places I've tried in SF are about the same quality and taste. The prices here make this place pretty awesome - $3.25 for a sandwich! Whenever I go, I buy at least 4 to 5 sandwiches to eat for later if I so desire or hand out to friends.

The place is again, like everyone says, shady McGrady. If you love homeless people and love to be around urine and fresh out of the body fecal matter, then this is your place. I parked the car and walked on the sidewalk next to a place that was apparently designated as a public bathroom (guess I didn't get the memo yet). If you can get past the disgusting nature of the area, the food is definitely worth going for. Safety is another issue but I've never had a problem here.
author: Julia P.

description:
Hell yea,


best banh mi I ever had!!! Their pate is bomb and always  ask for extra.

I ordered one of each, which was one combo one steam w pate, and one pork.


All were good, I like the combo and loved the pate, 

Their menu is simple basically 3 sandwiches and a vegetarian one.

The only thing I wish they had some some fishcake sandwiches.


one of my shorter reviews however the food is stop notch, price is good, but with all of the homeless peoeple fighting and throwing bottles at each other I didnt stay long, nor was it fun to go there.

They have two small seats that you can sit at but I doubt any actually eats there!

Be sure to be ready to fight for good food(literallly)
author: Mike R.

description:
The best banh mi you'll find in SF...or Portland...or Seattle.  I've searched high and low,  and I always come back to Saigon Sandwich.
The roast pork seems to be the favorite,  but I do venture over to the roast chicken now and again.  Even the tofu is great. 
Don't let the line dissuade you.  Those ladies are on fire, and they can bust a move like nobodies business. I've never waited more than five minutes.  Enjoy!
author: Robert K.

description: I gauge all Vietnamese sammie with their sammie.  I like their meat ball sammie; I don't think is that healthy but I'm hooked!  its good either hot all cold, kind of salty and too much fat but you only live once and can't count calories all the time.   I've tried Lee's when Lee's were pretty good but now they are stingy on the meat.  Whenever I'm near by like going to the museum or library, I would walk up here to buy a couple of sammie to eat right away and to take home.  Kind of straight that there's so much carrots in it but I do like carrots and usually plenty of pepper.  Oh the sauce is pretty good also.  Yes, they are the sammie Nazi so bad ass so cruel and yell at you and get the order incorrect because there are so many people in line and yes very often that the customer is fighting about the order being wrong so don't ask them to take this out and put extra of this so they don't get confuse and always check before you leave.
author: Mar H.

description:
Locals rave about this spot. It's a cramped holeinthewall eatery in the tenderloin. But you can't beat these prices for a freshly made Vietnamese sandwich.

The ordering to receiving can get a bit confusing since there's no clear place to stand, but the ladies there have good memories and as long as you pay attention, things will work out.
author: Christophe C.

description: Sandwiches were Great!  I was not impressed with the eating area and had to take my sandwiches outside to eat as it was small/cramped for two people. It was the right amount of meat with the fresh cilantro and pickled taste with Jalapeños that lingered nicely.  Lady who took my order was nice but spoke little to no English. I will come back to try the special pork sandwich.
author: Juice B.

description:
I only say two sentences at this place. 
The first: "One Roast Pork."
The second: "Thank you." 

It's delicious every time.
author: Jon J.

description:
Probably the best banh mi (vietnamese sandwich) i have ever had! $3.75 for roasted chicken, roasted pork, meat ball pork, fanci pork, or tofu.

My wife and i got roasted chicken and roasted pork. The chicken inside was definitely thigh or drumstick meat. Pork was very thinly cut and marinated. The big difference was how soft but not too crunchy their bread was where it did not cut up the inside of my mouth like most banh mi does. Also instead of radish and carrots they had onion and carrots inside. Also this creamy  looking sauce with a good amount of pepper in it too. Definitely give you a good amount of meat and veggies. I would say probably 3-4 oz of meat and like same volume of veggies.

Such a great deal!! Definitely coming back here again!
author: Sean L.

description:
This was the first stop of a "must eats" food crawl my friends took me on last month. They said I haven't had good banh mi until I've tried this place and they were right! 

This little hole in the wall shop filled with little viet ladies assembled the BEST tasting banh mi I've ever had. We got the chicken and pork sandwich and I was hooked after one bite. The meat was so juicy and tender, stuffed in a crispy, light baguette....O...M...G! There isn't a place that serves banh mi this good in Little Saigon, what is up with that? Not to mention the sandwich was like $3 bucks or something. 

Saigon sandwich, can you please come to OC and show Little Saigon what's up?
author: Bobbie W.

description: Had the fanci pork and chicken banh mie sandwich. The pork was the more flavorful. Wonderful warm French bread, also the vegetables in the sandwich were fresh,sweet and made the sandwiches delicious. Only 2 stools to sit at, bare bones, so pretty much take out and enjoy!
author: John B.

description:
Hungry in the TL? Go here. Amazing sandwiches, definitely some of the best grub in the city. 

Food network should hit this place up, seriously. Everyone I bring here goes ape shit.
author: Nick O.

description:
As much as I'm scared for my life whenever I'm in the Tenderloin, I think this Saigon Sandwich shop is pretty worth coming out to. I got the Roast Chicken Sandwich-SO GOOD! The bread was fresh, the chicken was flavorful and moist (not dry like a lot of other places), and their special sauce was amazing.

Downside? This place was cramped and extremely grimy looking. Also, they ran out of 1 dollar bills, so they gave me and my coworkers our change in quarters. For a sandwich place that takes cash only, I would expect them to have a lot of change on hand, hence me giving them -1 star.
author: Angela K.

description: So many bahn mi sandwiches in this part of town. Only 1 shop has a line out the door. All the good things yelped about the roasted pork bahn mi, spicy of course are true. Saigon Sandwich is now my go-to place for jury duty take out lunch. Hopefully it'll be awhile before I buy my next sandwich. Completed my jury duty in one day. Yay!
author: Debbie T.

description: FRKN BOMB DOT COM. Maybe the best banh mi I have ever eaten in my life. It's just unbelievably delicious. I recommend any and every sandwich. Just bite everything.
author: Joan H.

description:
The pork is great and for $3.50 you can grab a yummy desert. Worth the wait of there is a line. I've tried all the sandwich shops in this area and they are very much #1 for all reasons. The Pork is the best if you like spicy ask for spicy which means more fresh jalapeño slices. Mmmmmm

Try the wrapped desert things in front of the cashier. I just tried the rice one that has banana in it. Very good! I have yet to try the green jelly things. I have no clue what they are but I'm up for it next round.
author: Heather W.

description: The best and tastiest banh mi you can ever find!  The flavors you get from the simple ingredients are out of this world! Cash only! Long lines during lunch time, but definitely worth the wait.  The best one is the combo sandwich which has many cuts of meat giving you that surprise of flavors and textures!
author: Sarah S.

description: Great sandwiches that are both delicious and affordable. That is if you are willing to wait with the crowd. Do not come here if you are on a time constraint.
author: Dee S.

description: Gotta love Saigon sandwich! A neighborhood staple, great prices!! They have a bunch of weird desserts too which are not bad! I stay away from the fancy pork because I think it's pate, and I'm not into that.
author: Matt N.

description: Expertly prepared bahn mi's made by two rockstar women. The mayo takes it from ordinary to extraordinary!
author: Regina D.

description:
Here is yet ANOTHER rave review for Saigon Sandwich...

It's cheap ($3.75 for tofu [or I think any sandwich?])

It's quick (lines of 13 people get reduced to 3 in a matter of seconds)

It's bomb (this place has set a high threshold for banh mi sandwiches...now every place must taste just as good or face my 'this isn't as good as Saigon Sandwich' critique.)
author: Maple S.

description: Hands down - the absolute best Banh Mi (Vietnamese sandwich) ever! And to think that Vietnamese sandwich chain opened up across the street to try to put these little old ladies out of business. They don't even stand a chance, these ladies beat every other Vietnamese sandwich place in the city. There's weeks I eat here every day for lunch. I can't get enough of them.
author: Peter K.

description: Been a while since I came here but I really loved it on previous occasions. This time was different. Between the unfriendly, stand-off staff to the average tasting pork sandwich & then overloaded chilli that was sliced almost whole...I won't be returning soon. Fresh Rolls in the metreon on 4 th is far tastier & fresher (no staff sneezing on my roll here).
author: Nicole E.

description:
I fucking love this place. Although the combination does not have head cheese the pork inside it is super tender, there is shit tons of pate, and the bread is warm. I love it! 

Summing things up:
1) super fucking cheap 3-4 dollars
2) quick service
3) alot of fucking food.
author: Reiko n.

description: If you're looking for a cheap place to grab a quick bite around Civic Center, Saigon Sandwich is the place to go for cheap, authentic Banh Mi.
author: Annie M.

description: This place is so cheap! I paid about 3.75 for a sandwich. It was really good for the price. I can say it's my favorite Vietnamese sandwich but Ill definitely go back.
author: Tanner B.

description: My Vietnamese coworkers swear by their sandwiches because of the size and cost is cheap!  I'm still not convinced that it's quality fillings (meat/tofu/veggies) and the bread is always stale.  Maybe that's the way it's suppose to be?  Edible!
author: L T.

description:
I loveee Viet sandwiches and always come to Saigon Sandwich whenever I'm cravin' for one.
