It's about 3.75 for a sandwich nowadays which makes me a bit sad cause I swear it was cheaper back in the day. But still, even at 3.75, it's a pretty good steal for a bomb ass sandwich. I personally don't have an absolute favorite here but often find myself craving either their meatball or tofu banh mi.
author: Teese N.

description: The pork banh mi was good (even though I've had better). It's a good deal for the price! We bought two.
author: V U.

description: The food in this place is awesome! I had the Chicken sandwich for $3.75 and it was excellent.  The service, although quick, reminded me of the Soup Nazi on Seinfeld, but not in a mean sense. The place looks like a dive, but it's worth checking out.
author: Carlos Q.

description:
This tiny sandwich shop is very popular, so prices keep going up (a little). At about $3, it's cheaper than Wrap Delight ($3.29), but 50 cents more expensive than Baguette Express and Lee's Sandwiches. It's a great cheap lunch. The store carries a large assortment of bagged snacks and chips, as well as Vietnamese deli meats (cold cuts) and desserts. It's one of the few shops that has a tofu Banh Mi (other shops with tofu: Wrap Delight, Cafe Dolci). They have 2 seats by the store's window.

My usual lunch is the chicken Banh Mi http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/_MTFge2zeZAhUZ6M4HuOUw/l, and a can of Grass Jelly drink. Sometimes I also pick a bag of Nong Shim's Korean onion rings. I don't come here as often nowadays. Both the roasted pork and meatball sandos are very tasty, the tofu version has gravy in it, so it can be messy (drips on your clothes). I'm not a fan of the fanci pork (cha lua). The pate and combination (fatty ham, headcheese and cha lua) sandos are good but lately I'm trying to reduce the amount of fat I eat, so I'm avoiding those types of foods. The bread is better than what u get at Baguette Express, less crumbs when you bite into it. Over the years they've changed breads a couple of times, sometime ago during a weekend I remember getting a different bread that was too hard. The current bread seems fine now.

Note: The friendly serving lady does use a disposable glove to handle the cash, and takes it off to handle the sandwiches.

Banh Mi menu & prices ($3-$3.50):

Ga = roast chicken
Thit = roast pork
Xiu Mai = pork meatball 
Cha Lua = "fanci pork" (steamed pork mixture - like thick slices of fluffy/silky bologna)
Pate Gan = Liverwurst or minced pork liver & fat
Chay = tofu (fried tofu, comes with gravy)
Thit, Cha - roast pork & steamed pork - $3.25
Thit, Cha, Pate - "special combination" cold cuts - $3.50
Jambon = French ham
Jambon, Cha, Pate - $3.50
author: Luis C.

description:
Best bahn mi ive ever had fo sho!
Pate mixes with the mayo and pork juices, sooooooo goooooood!!! Do it, do it!
author: Nic B.

description: Saigon Sandwich - cheap and quality Vietnamese sandwiches. Order the pate, get everything on it - don't forget the coconut water for your hangover - try to find a place to eat it (Lee's across the street?) then sit back and enjoy how it's meant to be.
author: Chris P.

description:
San Francisco has never never never failed to fill my belly with yummy food filled with goodness.  

We traveled with another couple who we have become very close friends and they introduced us to this mom and pop shop.  What made it even better was that it was only about 4 to 5 blocks away from our hotel.

Anyhow, we all ordered the special, which has all kinds of delicious meat in it.  Our friend loves paté, so we got extra in all the sandwiches.  Who knew that it was going to be globs of the stuff in the sandwiches.  Although, it did make our sandwiches even better.  The bread was toasted perfectly and had a buttery finish to each bite.

Definitely a good find for our travels up there.  It was a good stop to pick up while heading to the airport also.
author: Crystal H.

description:
I don't think this place needs another review with their 1,000+ rave reviews, but here's my two cents:

During the summer, my friend and I were heading to Stern Grove, and he wanted to stop by here. He was raving about it and said the sandwiches were cheap and delicious! He idled his car as I hopped in line. The line moved fairly quickly. The shop is tiny, but they seemed to have had a lot of snacks and few prepared items that probably many neglect. Everyone comes for the sandwiches! 

My friend asked for a tofu sandwich as he claimed it was the best. I placed our order for two tofus and a pork and the total was under $10! I tried both and was quite impressed. Dollar for dollar, this is a steal! I thought the sandwich was a good size and it had incredible flavor! I will definitely be back!
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Great Banh Mi!

I had the special combination which had pork and pate. Excellent sandwich if I am in the neighborhood. I will admit the experience of getting the sandwich is a bit burdensome. It is packed and there was a very loud homeless man outside. So, if you don't mind putting up with crowds and the Tenderloin, it is a great spot for a sandwich. The price is great too!
author: Ryan M.

description:
My favorite banh mi place in the States. Well, I haven't tried that many, but at least 10 in California and Maryland.
There's something about their combination of the bread, sauce, meats, and veggies that make the sandwiches fantastic. I've tried a number of the different types, and all are good. 
It's not a 5-star review because sometimes they put too much stuff in the sandwich, and less is sometimes more; and it's not a place you can really hang out and sit down.
author: Pedro L.

description: The tiny shop has surprising good sandwiches, made very quickly and at an incredible pricepoint! $4 gets you a combo steamed pork & BBQ pork banh mi that's plenty large for lunch. Only sandwiches and beverages though, so don't get your hopes up for pho or anything else...
author: Jordan W.

description:
Sometimes you have to make sacrifices to get the best things in life. In this case, one must ignore the interior scenery of Saigon Sandwich for the 4-5 mins it takes to have a sandwich made. Put it out of your mind, just walk out the door like nothing happened. Focus on the treasure you have with you -- its truly a diamond in the rough!!

Saigon Sandwich is a San Francisco classic -- highly recommended!!
author: Soren D.

description:
my update review...just because....

Dear Saigon Sandwich...i still love you and will drive mucho distances just to have you in my hands and into my mouth whenever I have a hankering for a meatball sandwich.  And...Dear Steamed Pork Bun, I love you too =)

Also, the remodel of this place is much better.  Looks like those ladies have more wiggle room back there.
author: Emy B.

description:
Despite what some other Yelpers would have me believe, I decided this place did not top any of my other banh mi experiences in life. Sure, it was fairly quick and a straightforward $3.50 for any sandwich option you could think of that also appeared on the limited menu, but the bread was way over-toasted. The filling on my roast chicken sandwich seemed all right, but I didn't enjoy it nearly as much as I would have had I been able to sit down at a table. Instead, I had to endure the smells of urine in the Tenderloin as I walked and ate to get to my next destination.

The verdict: I'm not coming back to Saigon Sandwich unless I absolutely have no other options in San Francisco.
author: Tiff T.

description:
This is the first VN sandwich I ever had, back before the series of tubes that is the internet. Today I was walking home and decided to pop in. They have quite an operation here. There were about 15 people waiting for sandwiches at around 11:25. Two women in front were making sanwiches as fast as they could. A woman in back was using an industrial carrot shredder over a bin the size of a small bathtub. I wondered if the sandwiches, still modestly priced at 3.50, were still good.

I walked home and ate the sandwich. I found it to be excellent. The roll - a rice flour french baguette roll - was fresh and delicious. The meat and veggies were hearty and plentiful, and the sauce they use is delicious and goopy. I would have liked more, thinly-sliced green peppers as opposed to one big globby bit. Otherwise I found it to be yum. Here's to lasting memories.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
A great little shop to grab a lunch and go explore the city.

I'm a sucker for banh mi, and this place is one of the best I have ever had. The bread is warm and soft with a good crust. The fillings are great too.

I usually order the Special Combination because you get the headcheese and the pate. The meats are delicious, as well as the pickled veggies and seasonings.

This place is very affordable. You might have to wait in line and you'll have to deal with the sometimes-confusing ordering, but it's worth the small inconvenience.

Also, it's in the Tenderloin. Nothing horrible, just enjoy the sights and sounds... and smells.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches is proof positive that you can't judge a dive by its cover! Nestled right in the Tenderloin (yes, sometimes scawie) is the best Vietnamese sandwich shop and is a regular winner of Best of the Bay.

This place is tiny--as in, smaller than your average bedroom. But who cares when they are pumping out these to-die-for sandwiches. My favorite is their Banh Mi Ga (Chicken) that is so packed with flavor. Also, what makes their chicken so tasty is that it's marinated in 5-spice then grilled. My suggestion: ask for extra pickled veggies and jalapenos. Yummy, yummy, yummy. Unlike other shops, this place packs their sandwiches with tons of meat that it's bursting at the seams.

The shop is a small production but that is what adds to the charm of the place. The folks (who, let's be honest, could pass for one of my aunties), have somewhat limited English but are geniuses in creating these dynamite sandwiches for under $3!

After trying Saigon Sandwiches, you will never look at Lee's Sandwich again.
author: Nam N.

description: This little spot ended up being right next door to our endearingly cruddy little hotel in the Tenderloin, which we discovered after smelling the deliciousness from our room. It's a small takeout operation (there's two stools available at a tiny counter in the corner) selling, I believe, 4 types of banh mi. I had the chicken banh mi, which was fantastic. My husband had trouble deciding between the pork and the pork meatball, but settled on the pork, and was then delighted when the lady behind the counter slipped in some meatball so he could give that a try too. Both sandwiches were excellent - full of flavor, plenty of spice, fresh bread, and only $3.50. They were sizable, too - I had trouble finishing mine. Awesome lunch-on-the-go if you're in the area!
author: Kristin M.

description:
I always come here every time I'm in town! It's still the 2  old ladies working there and they call your order by saying "hello hello".

Unfortunately, our sandwich got mixed up and I got the chicken instead of the special, but it was still good. They give LOTS of meat and they stuff it in there and the marinated carrots and onions are delicious!

It's not the best location and there's always a line!
author: Alice H.

description: This place is not at all worth the hype. The staff is not all that friendly and the sandwiches are only flavorful because they are literally dripping with sauce (which really not how Vietnamese sandwiches like this are supposed to be made).  There are much better places just around the corner.
author: Maria R.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Saigon yet! I LOVE LOVE LOVE the vietnamese sandos from here! Best ever!

The chicken is one of my favorites, however, all of them are good. Lots of flavor & they use REAL meat, instead of imitation-like cold cuts that a lot of other vietnamese sandwich places use. They also put some kind of special mayo sauce that's to-die-for!

There's always a long line going out there door, but the wait isn't bad because they're pretty quick at putting them together. It's definitely a hole in the wall, but hey, hole in the walls are usually the best, and this one surely is!
author: Alysha K.

description: Came here to pick up some sandwiches for lunch. These are some of the best banh mis I have ever had. The ingredients are fresh and the pork is grilled to perfection. The baguette is soft on the inside and crusty on the outside. I got the pate sandwich, which is amazing if you tend to enjoy liver pate and the irony taste it provides. We took our sandwiches to Union Square and ate lunch in the nice weather while being entertained by a nearby schizophrenic publicly proclaiming the evils of the U.S. government. The sandwiches were incredibly cheap and filling. They also have a large variety of Asian beverages like chrysanthemum tea and grass jelly.
author: Peter K.

description:
The short of it:
- BEST Bahn Mi sandwiches
- hole in the wall
- located in Tenderloin District
- cheap, fast, and good!
- Favs: Tofu Bahn Mi, Chicken Bhan Mi

The long of it:
This is how much I love this place. I trekked all the way to Saigon Sandwich from Union Square area through the crazies, drug addicts, homeless people on the streets. Probably not the wisest idea to go through this walk on my own (I put my safety on the line for these sandwiches!).  But, I'm glad to report I made it there and back safely. It's a good thing there's a police station on the way...made me feel a little more at ease. Anyway, this place is known for their Vietnamese sandwiches. The special thing about it is that there's this special brown sauce they spread on the sandwich, not sure what it is (combo of mayo or soy sauce?), but whatever it is it is delicious! The bread they use is good here too. I love the tofu sandwich, it's VERY tasty! Might be my new favorite! The sandwiches here used to be $3 but they have raised their prices to $3.50, still not bad, but it's quite a significant increase from last year. The ladies who run the place here are super fast at making sandwiches. Btw, sandwiches are good fresh and still go the next day! So make your trip worth it and buy a bunch!
author: Kristin A.

description: For all those vegetarians this place makes one of the best veggie Banh Mi i've ever had. Firstly, it's hard to find veggie Viet sandwiches anywhere.. and even harder to find them in Vietnam (most of the time I was served bread with mayo and nothing else when I was there...they don't quite get the vegetarian thing). Saigon Sandwich is cheap and tasty, definitely worth going out of your way for.
author: Kels E.

description:
This place is hyped up that is true however it LIVES UP TO IT! =D

I'm a traditional Vietnamese female from San Jose and that's pretty much as great as it gets for Vietnamese food. But this Saigon Sandwich shops blows all the other Viet sandwiches I've had out of the water. I went there and ordered the 3 meat ball sandwich and a special combination meat sandwich. IT WAS DELICIOUS, stuffed to the max with condiments, meats, and vegetables. I'm telling you these Asian ladies are not stingy at all!

I would deduct a star for the small interior with no places to really sit and eat as well as a disorganized pick up/pay counter but the sandwiches are so good that I Don't Care =D

Coming back for sure and gonna get 3 sandwiches at a time instead of just 2!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Great sandwich - Awesome, no-nonsense bahn mi.

I highly recommend getting the special combination sandwich. Lots of liver, so it was especially appealing to me.
author: Harley C.

description:
It's been nearly 10 years since I've first had a banh mi from Saigon sandwich... I miss it dearly.

No Vietnamese sandwich (unless we're talking about the homeland here) stacks up in either quality or flavor. Fresh & crispy French baguettes and the most legit pate spread. Amazingly, their sandwich prices have remained relatively low over the years ($3) amidst recession, and though the sandwiches aren't hulk-sized, I can almost guarantee you that you'll be satisfied with just one sandwich. 

It was once a hole in the wall that only locals knew about, but with such good sandwiches comes fame... Frequenters range from office employees and police officers to bums in the street. Lee's is nothing in comparison.

Tips: 
*Get the special combo, you won't regret it! 
*Cash only
*Expect at least a 10 minute wait during peak times, but those two ladies are FAST.
*Unless you're really good with spicy food, don't get jalapeno peppers
*All sandwiches are good...no lie. Try all of them at one point.
*Speak Vietnamese, and they will be much more courteous to you. As always.
author: Colleen M.

description:
What's really crazy is that I thought I loved bánh mì BEFORE trying Saigon Sandwich. 

I just didn't know... now I do and there's no going back.
author: Nicole G.

description:
If you're wondering whether this place is worth the walk (dodging crackheads and sidewalk shit along the way) here is your answer: no.  There are better banh mi to be had (Cam Hung in Sunnyvale comes to mind) elsewhere, in locations that will not risk life and limb.

Is it bad food?  No, not at all.  It's definitely too sweet and lacks depth of flavor, but it's well within the bounds of edible.  For reference I had the roast pork version, but the too-sweet judgment would hold true across the board, since the carrot/onion (why the fuck is it onion and not daikon, btw??)/cilantro/jalapeno blend was to blame.

If I somehow ended up in the Tenderloin and only had $3.50 available to me, I would spend it here.  Otherwise I'd wait for my next trip to the South Bay-- or better yet, SoCal-- Westminster has the best Vietnamese food in the states.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I've been going here since 2006.  NOBODY CAN BEAT THIS PLACE.

Back in 2006, sandwiches used to be $2.50.  Seven years later, it increased $1. Sure, that's looks a lot on a percentage basis, but the that's like nothing compared to the rest of SF in terms of the aggregious food inflation over the past seven years (see below).  I don't know how Saigon charges so low relative to SF.  Or maybe, I don't know why everybody else thinks that they can charge more in SF. Seriously for $3.50, you get the best tasting bahn mi and you get a stuffed sandwich.  

I've been to all the food trucks and many of the new 'trendy'  bahn mi stores, and they just don't compare!  Those competitors charge $6.50 for less meat and the food always tastes worse!  I laugh at all the sheep who go to these new 'trendy' bahn mi places.  They don't know where it's at and they don't have the balls to walk through the tenderloin (which is actually pretty safe).

Recommend the Grilled Pork bahn mi
author: Jon K.

description:
Best authentic Banh Mi in SF !
The lines are long on some days, but with a little patience come great tasting sandwiches :)
The roast pork or chicken banh mi is amazing, that combined with the shrimp chips comes pretty close to heaven !
This should be on everyone's list for their Banh Mi fix
author: Vish E.

description: The best spot for delicious savory Vietnamese sandwiches (bánh mì). I love going to the place for brunch - it's not too crowded. Expect a line if you're there during lunch. Service is fast. I usually go for a chicken sandwich though the roast pork is popular as well. The meat is packed with delicious flavor marinated in a special homemade sauce. The bread is toasted and crunchy. You ought to eat banh mi with the veggies (cilantro, sour carrots, etc) for a complete experience. Each bite of banh mi transports me back to my childhood. After the last bite I want more. If you don't intend to eat right away you could ask for the veggies in a separate bag otherwise it becomes soggy. Great place to get a quick bite if you don't feel like cooking. Only $3.75 for the best banh mi in the city. If you happen to be in the Tenderloin with friends or family this is the place to treat them to authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Hua T.

description: Great sandwiches 2nd time here grabbing lunch before going to the theater.   5 is for the food it's a real hole in the wall.  Seating is non existent except for 2-3 chairs at a crude counter
author: Tracy H.

description: Straight up hole in the wall viet sandwich spot but their delicious sandwiches totally makes up for it.
author: Britney V.

description:
My boyfriend bought me a pork sandwich before we went to the Giants game.   I was so hungry by the time we got there, I just busted out the sandwich.  Omg, the first bite took me by surprise!  It was AMAZING!  It wasn't the usual pate and pork slices other shops, they were actually grilled pork!  DELICIOUS grilled pork. The taste and herbs were phenomenal!

It was so good that I scarfed the entire sandwich down, I didn't have room to fit any garlic fries in my tummy.  I would want to come back during the day and grab a fresh sandwich.   The one my boyfriend got me got a little soggy by the time we arrived at the game.  Despite that, it was still delicious to me.
author: Nancy S.

description:
this is a pretty mean banh mi... and for $3 bucks, it's a deal!  Bread can be hard at times, but there is no other banh mi's in the city that can compare... seriously! i think it's their sauce on the sandwiches that gives it the extra umph.  their combo is my usual... it's always good! 

coming here for lunch is such a hike... and the people in the TL... man... characters!

I had lunch here today... it was HOT as hell btw, so i decided to just eat my sandwich at the shop... and noticed a meth/crack "input ur drug of choice" head sitting outside with a coffee cup... that's fine because i have no pitty for people like that... then it wasn't until i found out that she's also holding a pet rat that almost made me loose my appetite! luckily she left after one of the ladies at saigon gave her a dollar on her way out of work... the meth head left and kissed her rat and i was able to continue on with lunch... 

ugh... the things i do for good food...
author: Kelly H.

description:
Went to this placed a few week ago and it was probably the quickest order I have ever gotten. I placed my order and 2 minutes later it was in my hands. Unfortunately, the bread was not as warm as I would have liked but the sandwich was good. Warm bread would have made things a lot better!

This very minimalistic sandwich shop is sparse in the decor but I wasn't there to hang out... I was there for their sandwiches. What they lack in their decor they make up in taste and quickness of fulfilling their orders.

I will have to go back and seen if the 4 stars I gave them goes up by one start at my next experience.
author: MoMo A.

description:
There's no way I could properly describe this hole in the wall, mouth-watering banh mi-tastic sandwich experience. It was so delicious I scarfed it down in about 2 minutes and I was in heaven. Silly us, the bf and I initially decided to split a banh mi then quickly realized we needed 1...or 2 of our own.

This banh mi place is the best I've ever had! These sandwiches are simple, tongue tantalizing, delectable and authentic.

I had the tasty tofu with the combination of  pickled veggies doused in Sriracha, perfectly laid on a lightly toasted baguette. The boyfriend tried both the pork special and chicken banh mi. His favorite was the chicken- marinated tender juicy chicken with the perfect balance of meat, veggies, on toasted bread.

As a a native of Westminster aka Little Saigon- I APPROVE. 

Bang mi Saigon Sandwich.
author: Vivian S.

description: Deceptively large considering its $3.75, but as countless others have said, would pay twice the price. Generous portions, but a bit too much sauce to appeal to a more Western palette. Still, cant beat the price to quality ratio.
author: Joon B.

description:
Whoohoo, Banh Mì! I tried the roasted pork with no mayo for $3.25 (Most are priced at $3.25)

Sandwich was pretty delicious. If you're a sandwich eater, you can't go wrong here.

Place was ridiculously busy considering I rolled in on a Monday around 3:30pm and it was lined out the door. 10 minute wait, no big deal. 

There is only a couple stools so you can't really dine in. 

Overall, good, but I just can't get 5 star excitement over this place.
author: Lauren M.

description: The location obviously leaves a lot to be desired, but I can't fault the 2 sweet ladies who run this shop for that.  These sandwiches would be a great deal at twice the price.  Worth a special trip.
author: Richie T.

description:
7AM-5PM = Banh Mi breakfast lunch and dinner. 

Crunchy crust
Chewy bread center
Crisp tangy veggies
Flavorful meats  - Chicken better than pork (seriously)

Order on arrival
Call in
Eat in 
Take out
Fast as heck
Dirt cheap

Eat now
Eat later
Eat tomorrow
Eat warm
Eat cold
All good
author: Snuffles B.

description:
$4 for a combo meat banh mi - roast pork, pork bologna and pate. 

this sandwich is stuffed with meat! and it's an interesting addition with pickled onions. adds a nice tart/sweetness to it. crusty bread, flavorful tender pork tenderloin. 

the vietnamese lady was very nice (my vietnamese boyfriend was shocked). we went on a monday at 10am, no line. but all other reviews talk about waiting in lines, so beware. 

the shop is small, only 2 seats at the window counter. i think it's cash only.
author: Lin Lin S.

description:
My friend from out of town didn't like his first Bahn Mi experience. Perhaps that's sacrilege considering we are talking about San Francisco's much beloved Saigon Sandwich here. It was probably because I explained to him what head cheese was after he had finished half of his sammie. 

I like me a yummy combination Bahn Mi anytime and while Saigon's isn't my favorite, it is still a mighty good sandwich. I'm on the fence about the secret sauce that folks seem to talk about. I feel it brings out the "porkiness" in the meat ... not necessarily a good thing on a hot day. But the overall combination of flavors are good and at $3.75 for the combination, still a cheap eat. 

If you haven't had Saigon Sandwich before, you should stop by if you happen to walk by it since it seems to be the standard from which all other Bahn Mi in SF is measured against.
author: Jon L.

description:
There is perhaps no other argument in favor of colonialism than the banh mi. The perfect melding of two cultures and cuisines, it comes together as spicy and salty, sweet and tangy, crunchy and soft (no bloodshed, slavery, or racial intolerance here!).

Saigon Sandwich does one of the best renditions I've had in a long while. And not only is it large, it's cheap ($3.50). In terms of flavors/textures per dollar, it's definitely a winner in the Bay Area. 

That's more than can be said about the adjacent neighborhood, which can get a little *weird*. But that hasn't stopped the flock of hipsters who arrive en mass to write 1800+ yelp reviews and order things as asinine as "tofu banh mi."

Stick with the meat guys. Pork is a privilege.
author: Jeff T.

description: I have gone to this hole in the wall 3 times now since I started my new job that is 10 blocks away. I just want to let yelp know that I will be going here probably for the NEXT COUPLE YEARS. I am the type of guy who orders the same thing cause I get comfortable with what is DELICIOUS. maybe one day I'll venture out to try the chicken sandwich, but right now the roasted pork sandwich is pleasing me in ways a girl can never do.
author: Gunter L.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE since i was a kid and the sandwich was $2.00! but now that i'm an adult, it's still cheap for under $4.00 for a decent and yummy sandwich!!!

the ladies are machines and remember who ordered what! amazing!
author: Ann L.

description:
I am a sucker for delicious meals that are also cheap. Although I could understand that cheaper meals often mean less of an eating experience, this is untrue for this place. For some inexplicable reason, Vietnamese sandwiches are always so delicious and always so cheap. This place is certainly no exception.

Everything in the sandwich was perfect. The meat was deliciously cooked and seasoned. The vegetables added a nice crunch and refreshing bite. And, because I like spicy food, I especially enjoyed the cilantro and jalapeño peppers. The bread they use also provides a great crunch. And you can get all of this for about $3.50. AMAZING! It can't get any better than this.

My friend ordered one chicken and one pork bánh mì and said he couldn't taste the difference in the meat. So, I say just go for whatever meat (or tofu) you'd like.

The service is pretty nice and easy. Just say what you want, and they'll have it ready in approximately 2-3 minutes.

This place is a gem in the Tenderloin. Perhaps even all of San Francisco. I will definitely be coming back here.

In short:
Sandwich: A+
Price: A+

Tip: Beware of the peppers. They automatically put them in. If you don't like spicy food, just ask them to not include it.
author: Larion S.

description: Got a pork and chicken sandwich. Super tasty and good price at $3.75. Would highly recommend it.
author: Michael M.

description:
I grew up on banh mi and there are plenty of great banh mi places in the south bay, but Saigon Sandwich surpasses them all!  The bread here is so much better than anywhere else and they use roasted pork instead of grilled pork normally found at other places, which makes for a really moist, succulent sandwich.

My favorites are the fancy pork with pate and the roasted pork.  The combo gets you all those yummy fillings.  There are few places I'd say I love and I LOVE Saigon Sandwich!
author: Thi D.

description: Good, but not the best I've ever had. Bread was fresh, and jalapenos packed a punch. I'm used to a #1 being a mix of meat and pate or head cheese. I tried a "pate" thinking it would be something like that...but no, just pure pate. The BF liked it, but it was too reminiscent of cat food in both texture and smell for me to get on board. The pork I had was quite nice though, hence the positive review. Slim pickins on nearby street parking; lots of transients in the blocks surrounding; no bathrooms, long lines and no chance of being able to sit down to eat at the 2 chairs stashed by the window. I wish they had a tip jar, because the ladies on the sandwich assembly line were working non-stop!
author: Melissa I.

description: I love this place it's amazing! You may see a crowd, but it's worth the wait. I'm 1/4 Vietnamese , 1/4 Chinese and 1/2 African American and I was never taught anything about my Vietnamese heritage. So coming from Soul Food growing up to researching about Vietnamese food, this is the best Vietnamese sandwich the Bay Area hands down!
author: Leo R.

description: I thought that it would be better based on the reviews, but after receiving the sandwich the flavor was just ok and the meat was too juicy and it made the whole thing soggy.
author: Natalee P.

description: Granted the sandwich is good but the people who work there are fucking rude as hell! They sold my mom a molded sandwich so we went back to let them know politely. And they called my mom crazy. What kind of business would you have if rude to them? Next time I'm there I'll talk to the owner.
author: Pauleena P.

description: I look for excuses to come out to the neighborhood just to pick up my favorite banh mi.  Tiny little shop with maybe 3 stools at the window, but usually standing room only and filled to capacity with people waiting for a little bite of heaven.  Yum!  Cash only but less than $4 which is unheard of in SF.  The sandwiches are freshly made, delicious and I usually get one or two to save for the next day.  Even if the line is out the door, they are efficient and quick.  My favorite is the roast pork, but the combo is good as well.
author: Nivita S.

description:
Definitely the Beyonce Knowles of Banh Mi Sandwiches. 

I decided to check out this place solely based on the amazing Yelp reviews. I ordered the tofu sandwich for a steal at $3.50.

Pros:
Very large portion size for the 3.50 price.
The sandwiches are generously filled with tofu, mayonnaise, sauce and veggies.
Super filling meal. For most people, one sandwich is more than enough to keep them full for a couple of hours.
The bread is crispy and fresh. The mayonnaise and special sauce give this sandwich a sweet taste.
Amazing value for the 3.50 price.
Tons of other Vietnamese style goodies such as pastries, chips and drinks.
Fast wait time. I've never waited for more than five minutes for a sandwich even when the line was long.


Cons:
The customer service is pretty much non-existent. 
They only take cash. I recommend you give them a 5 or 10 dollar bill because they also don't carry a lot of change.
Nowhere to sit. You can walk a couple blocks down and eat at the park or in front of the library.
Super small place.
The neighborhood is shady with lots of homeless people. Just be careful.

Overall, the surrounding area is as hideous as Jay Z. But the sandwiches are as amazing as Beyonce.
author: Penelope R.

description:
Yeah... they're good.
No.. they're not bad.
Just read all the other thousands of reviews.
Menu is simple.
Grab a drink.
Pay.
Eat. 
Bam!
Back to work.
author: Alex A.

description:
Legit vietnamese sandwich. 

The bread is nice and toasty. The sauce/ gravy  they use in their meat  has a nice sweet flavor. It goes really nice with the fresh jalapeno. They do a good job of stuffing a lot of  meat and veggies into the bun.  

The vegetarian sandwich is also good, although a little soggier than the meat sandwiches. 

If you like spicy, you can ask for sriracha directly on the sandwich or in a to go container. 

I've also tried some of their rice pudding desserts. Those are super sweet and asian tasting (even for me, being asian and all), so be prepared!  

Only $3.50 for a sandwich. Great for a quick, filling lunch. The onion chips are also good!
author: Jamie T.

description: On this visit, the long wasn't too long, but of course, it's still out the door!  But so worth the wait!  We ordered roast pork & tofu, please be ready to give your order because there's no time to waste! :) The pork was flavorful & plentiful, falling out of the French bread.  And of course the veggies is what makes the whole sandwich for me!  Yummy!  My daughter had the tofu, the only vegetarian sandwich they offer, she couldn't stop telling me how good it was and how whatever the sauce is on the sandwich was the bomb.  Whatever you order here, you can't go wrong!  And for $3.75 each, your crazy not to order an extra!  I did!
author: Judy S.

description: I love Vietnamese food and the sandwiches here were superb. There is a very limited menu here but everything we tried was outstanding including the deserts. If you love Vietnamese sandwiches and are in the area please make it a point to try this place, you won't be disappointed.
author: John S.

description:
$3.25 for a delicious roast pork banh mi. 

Plus other tasty treats like pork buns and coconut rice and tons of sweets.

Enough said.
author: Jessie M.

description:
Yum, yum, eat 'em up. Very well put together Banh Mi - I had the chicken. The roll is tougher than I'd like and the atmosphere is lacking, but the $3.75 sandwich made my mouth sing.

There was a 10-person line at 11:30 on a Saturday morning.
author: Richard B.

description: Me and my bay bays favorite spot in the hood. Grubbing Vietnamese sandwiches. This is the real deal not your Pac Heights bun mee BS. If I walk by I always go in and buy two sandwiches just to have at home. No matter if we have dinner plans those sandwiches never go to waste. My man always gives me high fives when he sees the bag on the kitchen counter.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
It's Saturday afternoon. Just got back from the park with the pup and we are hungry! He says, "We need something quick, and close by." well, cheap too helps and since this place is only about.. 30 seconds from us..it was a perfect choice.

there was a line, but it went quick. we learned the ropes fast, but didn't know which Banh Mi to get, but picked roasted pork would fit our mood (which turned out to be the popular choice of the day). go in, order (and she gets a couple of people to tell her what they want all that once), huddle on the side, pay your couple of bucks, and head on out. filled me up, but my bf was contemplating on getting another. who cares- it's like $3.50! go a little nuts and get extras!

this was awesomely delicious. i've only had one other banh mi before, and it didn't even compare to this. hot pork, great crunch on the bun.. wins my for my cheap, fast, and delicious sandwich award.
author: Abigail W.

description:
i've heard so much abt this place and i swear it lives up to the hype.

Awesome goodness between fresh and crunchy french baguette. Im veggie and LOVE their tofu s/w
author: Shal S.

description:
I loved the chicken bank mi. It's loaded and covered in a great sweet sauce. 
The place is cheap and the old vietnamese ladies give you a sense that it's super authentic food. 
I wasn't a fan of the one with the duck liver.  I couldn't take the texture.  
It's just not my taste.  I'm sure others may love it.
author: Robert S.

description: The best banh mi I have ever had.  I had the tofu, even though I do eat meat, and my friends had the pork.  Inside there are four, maybe five, older Vietnamese ladies slaying it.  I am devastated that I'm unable to have this everyday!
author: Alice K.

description:
Came here once and now I'm hooked.  The woman behind the counter knows what she's doing and is very sweet.  The sandwiches are perfect and I don't have to modify one single thing.

In addition to their amazing sandwiches they have an abundance of other vietnamese snacks/drinks.

I always get the special combination, and the only word of advice is to eat it that day ... they toast the bread and add their amazing sauce which gives it that extra star for me.  I tried eating it the next day ... and it was good, but the bread became soggy in the middle and very hard on the ends.

-- this place has definitely become one of my regular stops in SF.  I tried eating a vietnamese sandwich from one of my regular places in Sac, and it just doesn't suffice anymore.  This place has ruined all other vietnamese sandwiches for me ... and I'm OK with that. ;)

** NOTE: CASH ONLY!! **
author: Pia V.

description:
*FIST PUMP*

Saigon sandwich has some kind of drug in their sandwiches because I'm hooked! I keep coming back for more each week!! This is my favorite go-to Banh Mi sandwich spot in all of SF. Big Eats SF, says it's that good, so listen!!! You can't go wrong with cheap and delicious food! With that said, great combo all in all!

Each time I've taken a bite, my tummy does these silly jumping jacks for being in high spirits! Soft texture from the inside and the crunchy toast from the outside of the french baguette, pate, daikon, carrots, jalapeno peppers, cilantro, mayo, various type of meats offered (cured pork, bbq pork, chicken, beef, etc.) and that sweet flavorful secret sauce is created into "my" special sandwich. 

The two ladies who work here make so much money, I don't know why they still charge chunk change for their delicious sandwiches!! The ladies hustle quick when they make the sandwiches. By the time you finish ordering, I swear they work like oiled machines, because your sandwich will be ready within minutes! They don't speak English well, so translating to them is difficult. Make up your mind quick when ordering, because you'll piss them off and the rest of the customers standing in line behind you!

If I were you, skip the other Banh Mi sandwich spots. If you don't have dollar bills, I'd search underneath the sofa for coins and beg for quarters, because you won't regret your trip here!! FYI, cash only!!
author: Fraulein C.

description:
This small shop didn't disappoint.  Located in a big shopping center, parking was easy and we found this shop in a jiff for lunch.

The inside doesn't feel quit new, it seems a little cluttered with random food stuffs and there are only like 3 tables.  But well, that isn't why you come.

The service is straight forward, pretty quick and they push (or offer) that if you buy two you get a third.  Which honestly, is awesome.  My friend gave me the third one for dinner, since I'm always busy in the evening to get something for myself.

The sandwiches are tasty, fresh, have soft bread and good.  I really like my chicken and chinese bbq later was pretty darn tasty.  Yum!

We also got three smoothies, yes three . . .  avocado, taro and honey dew.  Taro is my new fave and here the drinks were pretty fresh and tasty.

Prices were cheap.
Fast service.
Tasty food.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
Just finishing up my roasted chicken Banh Mi and it's so good that I had to write a review before I forgot. 

Concept: simple, there's 5-6 selections on the board; all sandwiches are $3.25-3.50 each (tax included/cash only) 

Staff: 2 cute little ol' asian ladies; 1 takes the order 1 makes the sandwiches 

Taste: French roll is deliciously crunchy; chicken is moist and juicy; a nice big heaping of pickled julienne carrots, a sprig of cilantro, and a few jalapenos.... 

Delicious!
author: Betty C.

description: The best banh mi sandwich I've had. Cheap and quick (if you're lucky to not get a line out the door). Cash only.
author: Jorge V.

description:
I get a lot of flack for my opinion of Saigon. Look, I first went when I was vegan and it was my first semester in 1L- can you blame me for not liking anything outside of alcohol and chocolate in those days? Apparently, because its always "How can you not like Saigon?!? Have you been there?!?" 

So after watching No Reservations on Netflix last night where Tony went to Vietnam- and roasted a whole pig- I figured I should reconsider my opinion of Saigon over breakfast of a meatball sub. 

Some interesting notes:
1. My mouth is on fire due to the jalapenos.
2. OMFG THE MEATBALL SANDWICH IS DELICIOUS. Did I seriously just pay only 3.25 for that!?!?!

That was a pretty fantastic sandwich.
author: Emily D.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a kid back when sandwiches use to be $1.50. That's right a $1.50. Now sandwiches are approaching close to 4 dollars. Adjust for inflation and ehh... I guess.  I've tried everything on the menu at least 30-40 times and my favorites would have to be the chicken and combo banh mi's. I didn't feel the need to write a review for this place but there is something that I definitely want to point out about the quality of the sandwiches here.

***One thing that everyone should note is that the lady with the curly hair makes the worst sandwiches out of the 3 that work there. You should be especially careful and watch how she makes your sandwiches. The sandwich comes with a combination of a white and brown sauce and quite often enough, she will forget to put one or the other which makes it tastes pretty bad. At least for me. Sometimes I won't even order a sandwich there because the lady with the jerry curls is working. The lady with the short hair (tallest of the 3) makes the sandwiches the best there hands down so if you get her taking your order, you should be just fine.
author: James S.

description:
This is one of San Francisco's hidden gems. The decor is simple, if not a bit intimidating on the scary side that begs one to question the hygiene of this little shop. If not for the constant line of people waiting for their deliciousness, one might easily be fooled to pass this place by. 

But don't be fooled by the appearances. If you are willing to be adventurous just for a minute (or ten, depending on the wait), you will find yourself indulging on one of the best sandwiches this city has to offer.

The food is fresh, made to order, from the ingredients that are at times prepared right in front of you. Go crazy and order the pâté sandwich. Try the pork. And be a bit more adventurous and don't skip the jalapeños. Whichever sandwich you choose, every bite of it will be full of that Vietnamese sandwich magic!
author: Yelena K.

description: First time there today and completely fell in love with this place! Right down the street from Civic Centre in Little Saigon, this place is a small takeout joint with great sandwiches made to perfection. They are cash only so keep that in mind. They are a great lunch stop and will keep you full and happy the rest of the day--or at least until dinner. A definite must if you're looking for a quick, delicious bite!
author: Victor G.

description: Sandwich was good... They sell all kind of sodas BUT Coca-Cola, I wish the place was bigger to have a seer. I had 2 sandwiches and a soda for under $8 dollars!!!
author: Enrique R.

description: Exactly what you're looking for when you are in the mood for an authentic banh mi sandwich.  The bread is just the right crispy, the meat is tender, and the toppings give the sandwich enough spice not to leave you looking for more sriracha.
author: Joe L.

description:
$3.50 for a great Banh Mi sandwich should not be passed up. From the looks of the line forming out the door by 10:15 a.m., it doesn't look like many are.

If I lived in SF, I would eat here at least once a week.
author: Broc S.

description: Oh my! Do they place crack in their sandwiches (fittingly so since the neighborhood where this tiny shop is located is beyond sketch)?? As soon as I polished off my chicken Bahn Mi (purchased for the bargain price of $3.50) I had to have more. This was one damn good sandwich (dare I say the best Bahn Mi I've had). The bread was crunchy and soft, the chicken (a boring meat by most standards, was very flavorful) and the toppings all super fresh. Did I mention this was all for $3.50..Get thee to the Tenderloin asap. Everyone must try The Saigon Sandwich Banh Mi.
author: Ritu K.

description: Listen, I'm not gonna say a whole lot here. I'm just going to tell you that of you find yourself within the general area of this place, you owe it to yourself to stop in and get a sandwich. They are wonderful. Fresh ingredients and surprisingly low prices. Just go! NOW!
author: Tim S.

description: Went here today after pride parade. We were starving and knew just what sounded good. The line was out the door even though there was many other Vietnamese sandwich places within steps. They had all the sandwiches pre made and I don't know if that was strictly because they knew how crazy it was going to be after the parade. They were warm though so that was better than I expected. I had the roasted pork sandwich and my husband had the combination recommended by someone in line. I'm glad I didn't get this one because it was heavy on the pate. (I personally am not a fan), but he liked it. I would eat here again.
author: Sharon R.

description: Great sandwich only for $3.75? I dont i can complain. Ling line but worth the wait. I tend to get 1 extra one to eat at a later time.
author: Jeff A.

description: Four bucks for a sandwich. I don't like the chicken or the pork as much as the special. Special comes with pork and fancy pork which is the meat loaf and pate. Comes with cilantro and jalapeños yummm and drenched in their mayo and homemade sauce. They have all sorts of desserts too that I will be sure to try next time. cash only
author: Karina H.

description: For $3.75 for a pork bahn mi, the price is unbeatable. And while it may seem chaotic to newcomers, don't let that discourage you from trying this place.
author: Simon O.

description:
Hmm, my boyfriend tells me many stories about this delicious Saigon Sandwich place so I was anxious to try it when I flew up north. 

As expected, we had to wait in a line (San Franciscans love waiting in line haha) and ordered our highly affordable wonder in a baguette. We got the Roasted Pork for only $3.50 each. I would say this is a good sandwich but not that best I've ever had. Like any other viet sandwich, it is accompanied by pickled radishes/carrots, cilantro, and jalapenos. The meat is decent quality, which I definitely appreciate but it wasn't OMGTHISISSOGOOD.

I'm giving this place a 4-star as a combo of the sandwich and the price!
author: Joyce M.

description:
Better late than never I guess.  Even though this little sandwich shop is the T-loin's worst kept secret, I found a way to stay in the dark about this place despite its strong yelp appeal, a 7 x 7 must eat endorsement, and being next to the federal and the superior court house.  

I finally made my way there and, whoa Nelly, I'm sure I glad I did.  Authentic Banh Mi loaded with flavorful meat for a lil' over three bucks?  Why not?  I'll take two please, one roasted pork banh mi and one chicken.  Delish!  I would have preferred my sandwich a little warmer and spicier.  Oh well, I got two sandwiches for the price of half a sandwich in the FiDi, no complaints here.  Watch out, the sandwich shop next door has a very similar looking blue awning.
author: Angel S.

description:
Whenever I'm at work and feel like gettng a little more exercise, I head on over to Saigon Sandwich to grab a bite.  Getting there at 12 and 12:10 really makes the difference.  There's usually a pretty long line by 12:10, but the wait is never too long.  The woman at the register takes about ten orders, and the woman behind her makes all the sandwiches, then  the next ten orders are taken and so on.

I've ordered the meatball, chicken, and tofu sandwiches.. all which are very tasty.  The bread is sometimes too hard but the filling is always perfect and has a way of making a smile appear on my face.  The meatballs are simple pork meatballs and are moist and not too salty.  The tofu are fried tofu skins and are topped with a little sauce, and the chicken is quite tasty.  No matter what sandwich you order, they all come with pickled onions, carrots, and radishes, and a slice of jalapeno pepper, which is extremely spicy.  

If you're ever in the tenderloin area and don't mind the interesting personalities of people....   stop by and grab yourself a vietnamese sammy!
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Ate there for the first time tonite, as I was staying at the Phoenix hotel across the street(the rock and roll hotel). Ordered 1 roast chicken and 1 pork banh mi sandwich, they gave me one pork. May have been the best sandwich if my entire life...
author: Michael I.

description:
$3.5 for a keeping-it-real sandwich......what else can I ask for? I am so happy to get a fresh made roast pork banh mi AND a banana sticky rice for only $5! No wonder there's a line every time when I walk by.

I highly recommend this place if you are looking for a lunch to-go in TL. You can't go wrong with Saigon Sandwich.
author: Jamie L.

description:
the worst customer service ever yet 1 of the best banh mi's in the city..it's a love hate relationship. we managed to stopby with no queue (gasp, say what?!) and ordered the roast pork & combination sandwich. I kindly asked for the baguette to be extra crispy but the lady scolded in chinese "it's already crispy as hell!! the more you bake it the harder it gets, SHIT!"  (note, she didn't actually say "shit" but you can tell she was thinking it and probably some other profanity haha) Needless to say, the baguette was NOT crispy =___=

anyway, from personal experience, if you have horrible customer service, you best live up to the 2k reviews with 4.5 stars fame... and saigon sandwich did.
author: Jen C.

description: This place really dont need anymore reviews. But hands down the BEST Vietnamese sandwich I ever had. There is always a line but the wait really isnt that bad even when it goes out the door (mostly out the door during lunch time). I put 14 mins in the meter (1 block away) and when I got back there was still 2 mins. When I got there only 3 people were out the door. I think they take a bunch of orders at a time and make all the sandwich for the group of people. Once they made it, its distributed in the order it was placed. It was also really good price is think most sandwiches cost about $3.50-4 dollars. Very filling! I was 3/4 the way done when I felt full but it was so good that I finished it! I almost never go there because of the distance but when I do I usually order extra. Its taste just as good the next day!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Substantiate banh mi for the price. Been eating her since the 80's.  Sandwich is still more I can or should be eating in one sitting.  

Use to roll with the Xiu Mai (meat ball), but my metabolism slowed down.  Now, just rocking the chicken.
author: Sam T.

description: My fiance showed me this place one afternoon and it was amazing! Not the best location but the quality is really authentic and the prices can't be beat! The bread is fresh everyday and the pate was excellent.
author: Kai D.

description:
I had to come here while visiting, after all the rave online about the pork banh mi. Honestly, I was unimpressed. Bread was hard and not really warm, and the meat was mediocre. Not especially tender or flavorful. Thought the chicken had better flavor. The best part for me was the cilantro (and the price). 

Didn't think it was worth venturing out of the tourist-ridden Union Square area into parts of town I was uncomfortable in for this sandwich. Granted, that's probably because I am in fact a tourist, unfamiliar with this city, and if you are familiar with it perhaps it won't be that big a deal. But for tourists, perhaps it's best to save this for your 2nd or third visit...
author: Farheen Q.

description:
They make a good Vietnamese sandwich. And the price can't be beat at $3.75.

It's a hole in the wall and you can tell that they make their bank off the sandwiches. It's not a place where you'd want to linger, just get your food and keep it movin'.

The bread was excellent, the veggies fresh, the sauce was spicy, but not overpowering. I had the chicken sandwich and just beware it is dark meat. I am not a huge fan of dark meat myself, but for $3.75, I'll suck it up and deal.

If you're looking for a quick and cheap lunch on the edge of the Tenderloin, this could be the place for you.
author: Robin P.

description:
My quest to find the best Banh Mi in The City lands me in the Tenderloin district. Sure, it's a rough neighborhood but there's plenty of hole-in-the-wall places here. Saigon Sandwich falls into that category. 

Just like the neighborhood, it's rough around the edges but there's a hidden gem in every nook and cranny. Heck, if the line goes out the door and wraps around the corner, then these damn sandwiches ought to be worth it. And by golly, are they ever worth it. 

Run by two old ladies, these duo can beat the best well-oiled machine assembly line during the lunch hour rush. Factor in their age, their feat is extraordinary as they go through dozens of simultaneous orders. 

I don't know what their secret ingredient is or how they make they sandwich that is different from other places; but whatever their doing, it's definitely working as they turn out the most delicious Banh Mi's I've ever tasted. All the textures and flavors will dance in your mouth. And you can't beat their prices. For $10.00, I can get three different Banh Mi's for breakfast, lunch and dinner.
author: John G.

description: So goooood! The combo sandwich is amazing and cheap. The pate is good, and the bread has the right amount of crunch.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Combo is the best vietnamese sandwich.  

When you go there do not take into account the following when reviewing:
service, location, atmosphere, general cleanliness, bums, street walkers, stray dogs, screaming prostitutes, mindlessly wondering drunks, street blocked off for police activity...generally anything else besides the sandwiches.
author: Christian H.

description: First time customer, but very impressed with the sandwiches. Located in a very sketchy part of town, that is the main detractor. But when I went there was a short line, and it moves pretty quickly. I had one tofui, and one roasted pork banh mi. Tender meat, good shredded vegetable topping, and the mayo/sauce went really well with it. Great value for $3.75 per sandwich, no tax. Will definitely try it again if I'm near the Civic Center.
author: Steven Q.

description:
OoooooOOOoohhhh yeah! The banh mi here is as good as everyone says. For some reason I didn't want it to live up the hype. Probably because I hate waiting in lines (and because I hate hype...kinda, haha). But lucky me--I was in the 'hood around 11am and NO LINE. I had no choice. And I HAD to write a review (like 1800+ glowing reviews wasn't enough for Saigon) because I wanted to relive the experience, okay!?!

Definitely THE definition of a HOLE in the WALL (no seating). But didn't look dirty (MAJOR plus). The ladies working the register and making the sandwiches were really friendly (what the what? ye-yah!). 

Roast chicken banh mi ($3.50) was ridiculously good, my friends. The chicken was so tender, flavorful, and MOIST...and they use good cuts of meat--no gristle! I'm trying not the cream myself. The pickled veggies (cilantro, carrots, radish, ONION, and a jalapeno slice weren't really spread evenly through the sandwich--my *only* minor criticism. Now, the baguette was the BEST! Perfectly baked--FRESH and soft and crunchy in all the right places. If you're not into pate/mayo spread then watch out--they SLATHER it on. Buuuuut it's soooooooo good (and I HATE mayo) and makes the bread even better!! 

Damn, I am sooOOOOoooooo in love. Man, I wish it were winter so I could allow myself to eat baguettes on the daily!  

Note: CASH ONLY
author: Kristine W.

description:
Over the years I've heard a lot about Saigon Sandwich. As an SF native, I've never been so I decided it was time to give it a try. There is a steady stream of people that fill this little shop. It seems that this Saigon Sandwiches has been under constant new ownership the last few years. I came with someone who grew up eating here and has said the quality has gone downhill.

The sandwiches are cheap, under $4. I got the chicken sandwich and it was filled with meat inside a pretty fat baguette. There was some kind of sauce all over the meat, but it was still dry. Sadly I had some kind of cartilage in my meat and that just grossed me out. None of the refrigerated desserts were labeled so I got what was familiar, mango pudding. The texture of the pudding was just repulsive. There may have been too much gelatin in it. 

There are so many other great vietnamese sandwich places in the city, this just isn't one of them.
author: Adelina W.

description: I'm from San Jose and there are many Vietnamese sandwich shops but this one here in SF is the best! I love coming here for their roast pork sandwich. The flavor and texture of the roast pork is well marinated & it's juicy as well. I would definitely come back to this place again and again AND AGAIN !
author: Jane N.

description:
I am in love.

this is the kind of place I love.  Inexpensive, unpretentious, great "hole-in-the-wall" establishment serving the best banh mi I've ever had in my life.

$3.5 gets you any sandwich (combo $4) on the menu.  

I was so excited after finding the place on yelp and as we approached the shop we can already see the line outside the door near noon.  I normally will not wait for food but after peeking around we decided to stay...  and boy was it worth the wait.

single file line to order.  three little Vietnamese ladies run the shop.  one is making and cutting bread.  one is assembling the sandwiches.  the last one takes your order and hands you the goods.  no nonsense.  if you don't move along the locals will admonish you to get your a** moving.  

I got the combo and the pate and grilled pork were extraordinary.  the size of this banh mi was perfect for this 6'1" 180 pounder.  Bread was of the perfect texture...  oh my....

only minus is no iced coffee.  they sell canned Mr. brown if you want....

do not miss when in this area...
author: Jeff L.

description:
96.
Yes, 96 is the new number on the green paper.
It was ..... 40 something?

3.50
Yes, still $3.50. Still GREAT!!!
It was ..... 2.25 was that price I remember when I was here for my 1st time many years ago.

I was here yesterday right in the lunch time, so line was long, but the line was going lot faster than i thought. The lady took about 5 order at once. 

Do you know or Have you heard of  "Vinatural"?
It's a Taro chips.
In a dark purple color bag.
8.8 oz bag, back of the bag says:
" All natural organically grown, modern vacuum drying technology with no added chemical preservatives uniquely keeps all natural flavors, flesh colors, and especially the nutritious values of the fresh fruits in the products.
These dried fruits products not only smell good, crunchy and have an interesting taste but also provide nutrients such as vitamins and minerals which are good for our health."
I was like, "OK, sounds good."
So I got one, even though the bag design lookin' so ugly as fxxx, as most Asian food products are, it's like a GMO fake colored product from China or something. 

But the taste nothing. No flavor at all. I didn't know what the fxxx i am eating. Could not tell. It's so strange that no flavor chips. 
I don't want any vitamins and minerals when I having potato chips. 
I want a strong bad-ass potato chip flavor.
I know I am not having a healthy food.
I know that.
But I like a kick-ass bbq flavor, all not natural but 100% chemical produced bad ass potato chips for crying out loud!

I don't care about the Taro chips.
But I care for the sandwich very much.
Still 5 star.
author: Nobu K.

description: Bringing Banh Mi sandwiches to music festivals is a tradition of mine because 1.) I don't like spending a lot of money on mediocre concert food and 2.) banh mi still taste delicious hours after preparation. Saigon Sandwich was right next to the Treasure Island shuttle pick up spot so I had to pick up several sandwiches to bring into the festival. The ladies here PACK the sandwiches with meat, daikon, and more meat. With only two workers and a line out the door, they were frantically grabbing tong-fulls of ingredients. It's amazing how simple, cheap and delicious a sandwich can be. You have my heart Saigon Sandwich.
author: Cindy A.

description:
I dont know why people like the sandwiches here so much that I couldnt believe it. Probably, there have not been a real good authentic one here in San Francisco, yet. 
I tried for several times and I think the foods are not that great.  

I have very high expectation on the food healthiness and I believe the place is not qualified for its service. 

The Pate put in sandwiches probably had been stored for awhile since the taste is weird. Some of my friends now experienced the same and I wish none of us will get sick because of that.
author: Hallie N.

description:
I have been here so many times that I stopped counting.  Actually, this place has been around since I was a little child when their sandwiches cost $1.50.  How time has changed over the past 20 years.  What hasn't changed is their sandwiches.

I usually and almost always ordered the barbeque pork with everything in it.  It is the most succulent and flavorful sandwich you will ever eat. Their marinated vegetables, cilantros and jalapenos combination is absolutely to die for.  No place compares to them.  

Although their price has risen, I will make an effort at any distances to get their sandwiches.  Along with sandwiches, they do have many other desserts and treats.  But the sandwiches is what is known.

If you can, avoid lunch hours because you can wait as long as an hour to get your order.  Best to call ahead and pick up.  

I would give them a five stars rating but I was a little ticked off because they increase their sandwich price in recent weeks.  But no matter what, I will make a trip just for these yummy, tasty sandwiches.
author: Angela L.

description:
Blown Away!

Had the vegetarian tofu banh mi, the combination of flavors is wonderful. Fresh veggies, perfect amount of spice, whats not to like :)
author: abhi s.

description:
This place serves great banh mi thats a little different from the americanized 'Lee's Sandwich'. Its a very organic tasting sandwich, Unprocessed meats, fresh liver pate, carrots that have been pickled just enough, lots of veggies! Such a well rounded asian sandwich. 

I feel like all the good authentic asian places are gems in the sunset and richmond... clement/irving... I work in the city... market-ish area and aside from chinatown, the side closer to broadway and green, further from union square... aside from that area... authentic asian food is really hard to come by. Especially the fast kind. The asian ladies working the counter are just like the ladies in the heart of oakland chinatown... good food and... 'hurry up and order, I dont have all day' attitude...make me feel like I'm getting the kind of asian food I'd find overseas... it makes me smile!
author: Mish L.

description: Man I remember when they use to sell these for like 2 dollars a sandwiche. Went to preschool and elementary school in the area and these would be my lunch every single day of school. I got the bbq pork and always always did I get the extra sauce to go with it. Not a fan of the pate and still not. But in all honesty I could probably eat the bread and sauce.
author: Kelly N.

description:
Succinctness is an elusive virtue, and so I will keep this as brief as possible. Well I might just be making excuses for my laziness.

Anyway, what can I say that hasn't already been explored by the reviews that have preceded mine? Line and unsavory neighborhood be damned, these sandwiches are more than worth the trek and the wait. I daresay they are the best Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever had: The bread is perfect -- a delightful crunch of a crust, balanced with a soft white inside, not one that turns to dust like with some other sandwiches out there. The meat is solid on flavor, and together with the veggies and mayo, each complements the others nicely, without any one ingredient being too overpowering.
author: Eddy P.

description: Convenient place to stop by and grab lunch. Very generous portions, I usually get one of their special combo sandwiches and have never been disappointed.
author: Wendy T.

description: This is my place for banh mi aside from the location its in.  I love their sandwiches here.  I usually get just pate or the special combination but both are good.  Eat it when it's fresh though, otherwise if you leave it too long the bread will harden and it'll be hard to chew. They give a lot of meat and fillings, so it makes the sandwich look really big and its very filling, and best of all its pretty cheap for their sandwiches.  The place itself isn't fancy, looks pretty old and dirty, but can't blame them since its in a not so good area.  Sometimes there's long lines outside during lunch time, so get here early if you can.  So far this place is the best for banh mi!
author: Henry N.

description:
Saigon sandwich. Oh how you delighted my taste buds. A little heavy on the "light sriracha" but hey I can handle it. Hands down best banh mi I have had in the city, plus they are generous on the fillings. 

Saigon sandwich is a must. Sweet lady. Fair prices and it's quick!
author: Doug P.

description: So waited for about 20 minutes for a sandwich. Yeah, it's cheap but it's the same price of every other Vietnamese sandwich place. There was a good amount of meat in the sandwich with veggies in it. I personally didn't think there was anything that special about this place. I really didn't like the combo sandwich.  I should have gone with chicken. The Saigon deli in Oakland  on International is definitely better.   If your in the area and the line is short or no line at all then try it out.  If there is a line, I would move on.
author: Sean B.

description:
Yum...for $3.25 you get a fully-packed sandwich that's sure to have you going back for more! 

Got the chicken Banh Mi. Hard sub roll, dark meat chicken (although I did get 1 boney/fatty bit in my meat which was unpleasant), carrots, jalapenos (which I took out b/c I'm a wuss!), and lots of cilantro. It had a delicious refreshing taste and the hard roll was big enough to fit in your mouth & chomp down, spraying crumbs back on your plate. 

Grab & go though as it's only big enough for the 2 ladies at the counter & max of 2 people in the store. Easy to "stand in line" here because there's no room! But that only makes it that much better...
author: Marissa H.

description:
I can totally see this shop and its owner in an SFGate healine or something "An American Success Story: Vietnamese Immigrants Find Success and Zagat Ratings in Tenderloin Sandwich Shop."  Ok, I do not know if they are actually Vietnamese nor if they are immigrants, but what I do know is that the sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich are delicious!

The bread is a tad on the crunchy/hard side for my taste; however, it is still delicious and not dry at all.  You've got to try the Special Combination--a melt-in-your mouth combination of patte and pork.  Yum.

Your order will most likely have to be "to-go" as there is only a small counter in the front window that can accomodate 1-2 eat-ins.

Tip:  Avoid the lunch rush and onslaught of Government employees (this would be me) and UC Hasting Law students (I wish this would be me) by grabbing your sandwich at 11:30.  Saigon Sandwich has a peculiar operation and logistics where they will take 5 or so orders, stop the line, make those orders, then take the next 5 orders.
author: Matt S.

description:
For $3.25, this is THE BEST Banh Mi you can get in SF.  Wanted to come here for a long time but never had the chance to until now and I'm glad I finally stopped by!  

Had the Roast Pork and it was awesome;-)   The meat, sauce and veggies were delicious, and the bread they use has just the right amount of crisp on the outside and soft and chewy in the inside.  

I ate this sandwich an hour later after I got it and it was seriously still so good.  Price-wise, for a sandwich, I don't think it gets any better than this.
author: Kahanalei M.

description: This place was a couple of blocks from the hotel I was staying at. Didn't find it until my last day there and I kicked myself for not finding it sooner. A very simple shop, but efficiently run by the ladies who were there. I ordered two of the bahn mi ga and they were fantastic. I had to admit I was suprised by the constant flow of people in and out at first but after having the sandwiches I am more suprised there is not a constant line.
author: James R.

description: Cheap & Tasty. I just went here for lunch again. The chicken and pork are good. Don't get the fancy pork. It is Spam!
author: Richard S.

description: Great sandwich.    Tried it once and it was great. $ 3.25-4.50.  Got two seats by the window to sit.  Some drinks and deserts are also offered.  Saw a guy order a dozen sandwiches which slowed down the line a bit.
author: Jim T.

description:
I was in town doing some work in the Civic Center area looking for a place to eat, I ask Yelp and see that this place has 1850 review and 4.5 stars....I figure that is a good place to go.

I walk up to a non-assuming place and see a line of 20-25 people snaking outside the door and what looks like utter chaos inside with the lady at the front yelling at people outside the store for orders.

Somehow this system works - after minimal time in line, I hand over $4.50 for a sandwich and a water.  It was pure heaven - by far the best banh mi I have ever had.  I can't state it any better than the other 1850 people that have reviewed it, but do yourself a favor and get to this place as soon as possible if you have never been.
author: Rob E.

description:
I visited Saigon Sandwich on a Saturday afternoon around 12:30 p.m. and there was a small line out the door of about 10 people.  The place itself is very small.  There's just a fridge with drinks/desserts and a counter overflowing with snacks and other goodies.  When you walk in, the cashier will ask for your order- make sure you're ready to order.  Then, just wait to the side for a couple minutes while the two other ladies make your sandwich.  The cashier will yell out your order when ready.  Pay, and go on your way.  The whole process is very quick/easy.

The sandwich itself is as good as I can imagine a sandwich to taste,  The bun is freshly toasted- such that it's a bit crispy, without being overly crunchy where it scrapes the roof of your mouth with each bite.  The meat is very flavorful.  I ordered the roasted pork and it hit the spot.  They also fill the sandwich with a generous serving of pickled vegetables, cilantro and peppers.  The perfect combination.  At just $3.50 a sandwich, this is a steal.  The serving size is very fair.  You really can't go wrong with this sandwich.

My boyfriend and I also tried one of the drinks from the fridge.  It was green and had green jelly, red beans, and yellow beans too.  I'm not sure what it was called.  It was very sweet and a kind of new treat to us.  At $2.50, it's a fair deal, but I think I'd rather just get another delicious sandwich for a dollar more.
author: Samantha L.

description:
This is hands-down the best Vietnamese sandwich place I've been to in the US, and I grew up in Little Saigon. I also lived in Saigon, Vietnam for two years, and this place is still right up there with some of the best sandwiches I've had in Saigon.

Yes, there can be a long line, but it moves pretty fast and if you can get there before or after the lunch rush, this is a great place to grab a sandwich.

Order the banh mi cha pate ("fancy combo") for a sandwich that is just stuffed to the brim with meats and pate. That's actually one of the reasons this place is so much better than other Vietnamese sandwich shops: they are REALLY generous with how much food they stuff into their sandwiches--not stingy at all and you get definitely get more meat than bread.

Get it with a can of the grass jelly drink from the fridge (make sure to shake it up and drink with a straw so you can get at all the little grass jelly cubes) for a perfect quick lunch or snack.
author: Phong Q.

description:
We had the day all planned out with driving to Big Sur for some hiking and exploring.  I planned on buying a few snacks for the road in case we got hungry and decided that Banh Mi sandwiches fit the bill. - something small and cheap for a quick meal.  We ordered 2 sandwiches: the chicken and the Pork. 

Honestly, I was so skeptic with all these positive reviews of how this was the best banh mis sandwiches ever.  I mean, really how much better could you make a banh mi?  I'm from DC, with a large Vietnamese population and we have some pretty good banh mis over there already.  

We drove the scenic Highway 1 route, stopped took pictures and enjoyed the view.  Hiked up the Julia Pfieffer Park for almost 2 hours and my boyfriend (fiancé a few minutes later!) decided as we reached the very top of the mountain that he was hungry and wanted to eat his banh mi.  Mind you, we were out all day, sweaty and dirty that I did not want to eat anything without washing my hand first, so I declined.  He shrugged and grabbed his banh out out of his backpack and started to go to town on it, saying how delicious it was.  I thought he was just hungry and even a rock would taste to him at this point so continued to ignore his comments, but the obvious happiness on his face - I just couldn't ignore that anymore.  He gave me a bite and it really was much better than any other banh mi I have tasted.  There is plenty of meat stuffed in and pickled vegetables, but it's really the marinated sauce that makes it so darn good.  I was surprised I didn't see the lady smear on any mayo on the sides of the bread, but it is just perfect the way it is.  Given the meat was cold and the sandwich itself was kind of mashed already from being at the bottom of a backpack, it is still oh so good.  We both sat on a bench at the top of the mountain, completely satisfied (and engaged!).
author: Jenny S.

description:
My all time FAVORITE vietnamese sandwich shop.  I've been going here for 16 years and I can't seem to get enough.  

Chicken is still my number one!!!

Oftentimes there is a huge line out the door, but it moves relatively quick because the ladies are hustling like there is no tomorrow.  I LOVE the sweet workers here.  They are quick, kind, and accommodating.  Sometimes I feel bad that they have to deal with all the crackheads that try to come in.  The ladies deserve props for having to constantly deal with the Tenderloin crazies coming into the shop in the midst of working fast and friendly.


4 SERIOUSLY LAME reasons for rating of 2 stars or below:  

1)  They ran out of several ingredients.  (Guess thats what happens when your sandwiches are bomb!)  

2)  There are only two seats to dine in, its a very small shop.  (Its the structure of the building and the nature of the business.  The sandwiches rock you @ssh0le)

3)  Their fancy pork really isn't that fancy.  (All fancy pork is basically the same in any bahn mi sandwich you get across America.  "Their fancy pork isn't that fancy" is comparable to:  "Spam isn't really a fresh cut of meat from my local butcher.  I ordered a Spam sandwich even though I did't know what Spam was.  After eating the sandwich, I realized that I don't like Spam and now I'm gonna rate this business down because I don't like Spam."

4)  I need a bag to carry my sandwiches.  (Its 10 cents honey.  Its 10 cents everywhere you go in San Francisco.  Just pay the damn 10 cents.  The other options is bringing your own bag.  Yeah, go green.  BYO bag.
author: Clementine M.

description: I'm not the most qualified person to rate the Bahn Mi because I can't eat pork, but the tofu one was very different from the ones I've had elsewhere. Instead of fried tofu, their version has big chunks of stir-fried tofu with this savory sauce with black pepper. If you get the tofu one, make sure you eat it right away since the sauce will make the bread soggy if you wait for too long. $3.50 for the tofu one
author: Maggie L.

description: Hand down the best Bahn Mi sandwich I have ever had all over US. It on my MUST list for SF. You won't be disappointed and bring cash.
author: Sang-Woo K.

description: Ordered the chicken and pork for takeout.  This place will not disappoint you.  Generous portions of meat and veggies. Very reasonably priced.
author: Greg J.

description:
I've been coming to this store for 8-10 years because I live nearby, but here's my assessment.    The sandwiches are ok.  If you've never had a vietnamese sandwich or  never had better, you'll love their sandwiches.

The problem is that they pack too much into the sandwich, which does not translate into better tasting -- but you definitely get alot for your money.  They also pack ALOT of vegetables, which has vinegar added ... which then overpowers the taste of the meat and everything else.  They also pack alot of meat/protein in there, which is great but it's salty.  There's also alot of mayo and sauce, which starts dripping in a messy way.  Usually, the food sits in my stomach and I can still taste it after many many hours; it doesn't digest well for some reason.

Don't get me wrong.  Sandwiches are still delicious but now that I've had better, I realize how lacking theirs are.
author: Max M.

description:
I don't know if you'll find better Bahn Mi in the city, let alone for less than $4. Taken here by a long time local, and it was immediately added to places I must go when visiting the city.
