Wait in the line, and take your food to go (or if you're lucky, maybe the 2 stools by the window will be unoccupied). 

Tip: Grab your sandwich and walk up Larkin to Lee's for a drink and/ or something else to go with it. Then walk back down, and go find somewhere by the civic center to sit and eat the best sandwich you'll ever spend less than $4 on!
author: Justin O.

description: The price is a five star and the food is ok. The problem is the place is dirty and I found a hair in my food. The lady was nice and friendly, but could not stop coughing.
author: J B.

description:
Always skeptical of Vietnamese anything - because I'm a Vietnamese foodie, having a grandmother and aunt for chefs.

I was pleasantly surprised...how could you mess up a $3.50 sando?  Good bread, good meat, generous on the pickled veggies, onions and cilantro.  If you like it hot, they're light on the jalapeño, so be sure to ask for extra!

All in all, I still prefer the banh mi in OC's Little Saigon, but this will work for me up north.
author: Alex T.

description:
Great Banh Mi for $3? WINNAR.

My standing +1 and I wanted to sample a few, so we bought one roast pork, one roast chicken, and one pate. The pate was so good - rich, smooth, and sapid. In fact, it was so flavorful that (since we were stuck eating in the car during traffic) we ended up alternating between a bite of the chicken/pork banh mi and a bite of the pate banh mi to balance the overwhelming flavor. Next time, we'll definitely opt for the combo.
author: Asha S.

description:
Great place for lunch! I work just around the corner. Like others have said, the neighborhood is not the best and there is often at least one panhandler hanging out outside, but it has never really bothered me much. My usual is the tofu sandwich, which is super yummy...and messy, so make sure you have plenty of napkins!

I would also like to add for anyone who is a strict vegetarian (which I am not), this place may not be the best option. On a few occasions a little bit of pork or chicken has sneaked into my tofu sandwich. The ladies who run the restaurant put the sandwiches together in an assembly line, so some meats might get a little mixed together sometimes.
author: Jen A.

description:
Delicious and way too affordable.

I walked here for 40 min round-trip from home just so I can eat a sandwich from here and enjoy my favorite TV show. Very well worth the walk. It was a Tuesday afternoon, around 12:30 PM. When I got here, there was already a line out the door, as usual. It took me around 20 min to order and to get my food. Let's just say I was underestimating the portions because I was very very hungry, so I ordered two: the special combo ($4.25) and the steam & roast pork ($4.00). I opted out of a bag ($0.10) and my wrists became sore after carrying these two heavy bricks back. 

One was already enough to get me full. The ladies really do their best to stuff the sandwich full of meat and veggies. I'm saving the other sandwich for dinner.

One thing I would like them to improve on is to stuff the veggies in more evenly. I would really love to take a bite with everything there as opposed to taking a half bite of meat here and then a half bite of veggies there.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
meatball 3.75
special 4.25

I finally got to eat this sandwich after becoming a frequent visitor of SF the last few years.

It was pretty good, slightly spicy, good sauce and nice distribution of ingredients in the sandwich.

I don't know if it's the greatest Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had but it's definitely up there with all the ones I've ever had.

I will definitely be back to try the rest.
author: Will C.

description: I Went inside and they had a rush like the Yelp reviews stated . since there was a lot of people in line seem like the workers were under staffed and were rushing to get the sandwiches out so the quality wasn't all that it could be. The sandwiches weren't too bad but I wasn't thrilled. I guess you get what you pay for.
author: Bryan P.

description: Walked 4 blocks through the tenderloin for the pork Banh Mi... Thats two sandwiches, two drinks and one adventure for $10.
author: Solomon S.

description:
I was a little disappointed that, after all these amazing reviews, Saigon Sandwich wasn't the best banh mi I've ever had. It wasn't even the best that I've had in San Francisco. 

My favorite banh mi is roast pork with pate, but here the pork lacked flavor and the pate had some grainy characteristic that reminded me of cat food. The pickled veggies lacked tang and were overwhelmingly sweet. As a couple other reviewers noted, the bread, while warm and flavorful, had more "chew" than the crisp, airy baguettes I preferred in HCMC. 

Despite all this, the sandwich was decent, fresh, filling, and cheap, and squeezing in and out of the busy shop during lunch is an adventure in itself. I snagged a little pork-and-rice ball wrapped in banana leaf, which I ended up liking more than the sandwich. I'd be fine eating here again, although I don't expect to have Saigon Sandwich cravings, which is more or less what merits a 3 star review from me.
author: Monica S.

description: This is an amaizing place.  Great prices as well.
author: Frank C.

description:
This place makes one of the better banh mis I've had from SF. However, I would like their bread to be more on the crisp side rather than crunchy. What I found was that the sandwich could be a little difficult to eat because the bread, albeit good, was too hard! 

Maybe I was served more "stale" bread but an establishment should always serve each customer their best product!
author: Michael S.

description: Whenever I find myself in the Bay Area I make it a point to pick up at least a dozen sandwiches for the road.  Everything is fresh.  The pickled veggies do not give a odorous smell.  In fact, the sandwich taste even better when its marinated and simmer with the veggies.  Living in South Cal, had my taste of variations of banh mi sandwiches especially in the OC area. This hits all the elements of a tasty banh binh.    A part of me wishes it would expand, but given what happened to Lee's Sandwiches. Rather they keep it as is,  doing what they do.
author: H D.

description: Stopped by with some friends because I HAD to try this place that has great reviews and everyone seems to love. I had the pork sandwich and I'm so glad even though there was a line outside our orders didn't take very long. The ladies working seemed pretty nice and are quick! Next time I'll have to try my sandwich with pate. The pork was pretty good but I think I would like the meat balls too.
author: Katherine L.

description:
I'm Chinese, so I love a good deal. Saigon Sandwiches gets 5 stars because it's absolutely delicious and great bang for buck. I've never been a huge fan of Vietnamese banh mih, but I think that's because I've only ever had it from Lee's. Saigon Sandwich does not skimp on the ingredients. They use fresh, crunchy French rolls that they stuff chock full of grilled and marinated chicken, beef, or pork (veggie option: tofu) as well as pickled carrots, daikon, onions, cilantro, and sliced jalapenos! I can't take the heat of the jalapenos, but even after discarding them, they still leave a nice spicy taste on the rest of the ingredients. Service is quick and attentive; they will pay attention to special requests such as "No cilantro." For around $3 a pop, no wonder there is always a line out the door!

I try to stop by here whenever I visit SF. Such a good deal!
author: Leslie H.

description: These guys set the benchmark in SF for what a banh mi with high quality:price ratio should be. $3.50 for a super tasty sandwich with a nice amount of meat all up and down that roll that will fill you up all by itself?? Why not treat yourself to another and make it dinner, too, for less than most lunches around town! The grilled pork is my fav, with somewhat of a bbq'ed flavor to it. The chicken is good, too; I wonder if they marinate in similar sauces? Their sandwiches are peppery and plenty spicy enough if you get the jalapenos. By the time you eat half your mouth will have a bit of a lingering burn. The seasoned mayo + cilantro, carrots, daikon and a few sauteed onions round out one satisfying sandwich.
author: Linus W.

description: These guys are awesome, but remember to call in your order ahead of time. Otherwise you'll be waiting in a line to get your sandwich. My favorite is the pate + chicken together. Sometimes when I'm on vacation I dream about this sandwich.
author: Dana O.

description:
I was salivating after reading the reviews here and seeing the pics.  HOWEVER, I am saddened to say that I'm rather disappointed.  When I was in SF on Friday, I went totally out of the way to make a stop here to get the infamous Vietnamese sandwiches!  My bad, I mistaken the Roast Pork and Jambon as one and the same, thit and thit nguoi... how was I supposed to know!  :(  So I ordered the Jambon Combo with Pate... I really wanted to LOVE IT........... but it just didn't do it for me.  I've had much better in SJ.  I'm willing to give this place one more try, and will get the roast pork sandwich next time around.  Friday afternoon at 2:30pm and the line was a little out the door.  Is it because there aren't many similar shops around or does this place truly deserve 5 stars? Hm, I shall see the next time I'm there...

The shop is tiny!... and kinda run-down.  But whateves, hole in the walls are usually the hidden treasures.  The two ladies spoke Cantonese but it's a Vietnamese sandwich shop... I ordered in Vietnamese, and when I overheard them speaking Cantonese, I responded in Canto.  That squeezed a smile out of one of the ladies.  They were nice, just didn't strike up a convo with anyone, well because, there's only two people working and the line was out the door.  I noticed Lee's was literally down the street... It says something if people are willing to wait in line here over a quick order down the road... I'll be back!
author: Mindy D.

description:
I call them the sandwich nazi. you go up, you order, you get your sandwich, you pay.

Not your average fancy $8-9 dollar yuppy bun mee you get from "Bun Mee" or "Southern Pacific" 

They're incredibly well priced and solid Vietnamese sandwich made by a bunch chinese-viet ladies. 

My favorite go-to in the city.
author: Jane B.

description:
Best Banh Mi in San Francisco!! 

Recently remodeled (not that I minded the claustrophobic space before)... Saigon Sandwich is still the only place to go for Banh Mi's in SF!! The service is quick, efficient, and friendly (well... friendly enough). The ingredients are fresh and they pack your sandwich full of delicious fillings. They have the classics like roast chicken, roast pork, fancy pork, combo... you can also do tofu or make your own combo sandwich! And i LOVE the fact that they jalepeno's they use are always really spicy. The veggies are pickled perfectly and the bread always delightful. 

The place recently upped the prices. As of today, most sandwiches are now $3.50, with the combo now at $4.00. Still... great prices regardless. And even though the place is in one of the worst, smelliest parts of town and there's always a line out the door (at whatever time you go)... this place is still worth it all!!! Yum Yum Yummy YUMM!!

10 stars! A+++!! Hive 5's!! Thumbs up!! Dance time!
author: Bobbie L.

description: Pretty dzope. Had the pork ban mi and really enjoyed it. Had the classic hot cold crispy deliciousness that draws me to ban mi. Will definitely go for more heat and more pickled veggies next time.
author: John L.

description: Picked up the Combo, Pate & Meatball sandwiches for the drive back to LA after Valentines weekend and made for a tasty treat on the road. Definitely would come back the next time I'm in town!
author: Ryan G.

description:
Cheap and delicious Bánh mì thit nguoi.

Complete review (in French): http://blogs.lexpress.fr/styles/french-foodies-chronicles/2011/12/06/mon-meilleur-banh-mi/
author: Chloë O.

description:
Every time I'm in SF, I'm here.

On this visit to the city, I came several times.
Twice in one day when I had to wait for a car at the nearby Hertz!

Such a simple thing, yet so very delicious.

The goodness extends beyond Bahn Mi, try the sticky rice and banana or pork steam buns too!

I think the prices went up a little since my last visit.. Whatever, well worth it.
I'm feeling sad I can't have one right now, 3000 miles away.
Maybe they mail order??!
author: Jeff G.

description: As walking by to pho place, saw long line at this place. I heard this place had best banh mi so I had to try! I got the chicken and thit with pate banh mi. The bread was hard and thick. I like my bread fresh and warm and soft. The meat was ok, nothing special here. Sorry but SJ still have best banh mi. I was disappointed on results based on the hyped. The place is very tiny with 3 middle aged women working. That's why line is long. They take my order and few others and they make them and then you pay. Although I saw cashier lady helped out making sandwich. I was kinda gross out by that.Sorry not coming back.
author: Trang L.

description:
$3.75 for a huge filling Vietnamese sandwich is a steal. I would come here every day for lunch if I could. Line was long but went by very quickly.

The Pork Roast is delicious, but many of my friends got the Pork Roast with Pate and said it was amazing. 

I also got one of the desserts from the fridge that had tapioca and Taro. Interesting texture. I'll definitely try another one next time, considering it's only an extra $1.75.
author: Vandy P.

description:
$3.25 for a sandwich, really?? Yes it is!!! Saigon sandwiches are cheap, and they are also very good.

The 7x7 list had the Vietnamese Roasted Pork sandwich as a "must try", so I ordered that and the Roasted Chicken. The bread is crunchy & hard, but the shredded pork is soft, tender, and full of flavor. The hard and soft combination proves that opposites do attract & in this case, the flavors/taste blend very well. The julienned carrots, sliced onions & peppers also give it that special "oomph". Slap some Sirachi or hot sauce (whatever you like), and you have yourself a very good Vietnamese Sandwich.

Good place, but unfortunately located in a not-so-safe neighborhood of SF. Come during the day for a "safer" lunch experience. It's right across the street from Bambuddah Lounge & Turtle Tower.
author: Joy A.

description:
I was hoping for better, but found the sandwich greasy, over-stuffed, light on pickled veggies and did I say GREASY.

I was in San Fran for 5 days with an express goal to try some good bahn mi.  Yelp and some recommendations from friends led me here.  Wife and I navigated over and around drunk people to find this busy hole in the wall.  I ordered the chicken and my wife had the tofu (we don't eat pork, SORRY).  We found a place to sit in front of city hall a few blocks away.  I ate the part that included veggies and tossed the rest, which was just greasy chicken and bread.  My wife took a couple bites and tossed the rest because her tofu sandwich was a greasy mess and hard to manage.

On the plus side, the bread is good and the value ($3 for a large sandwich is incredible).  Maybe I caught them on a bad day?  Maybe this is a place more suited to folks looking for more meat and fat, whereas I look forward to the pickled veggies in my bahn mi.
author: Aaron L.

description: I had a craving for a Vietnamese sandwich. I checked out Saigon Sandwich and the place was busy so I waited in line. I'm happy to tell you it was worth the wait. Nice bun and tasting roast pork with all the fixin's. Not the best I've had, but considering the price , not bad. Next time I'm in SF I'll be back.
author: Jim M.

description:
I usually, ok, I try to go to the gym every sat morning.  after I'm done working out I always end up having a craving for a vietnamese sandwich from Saigon Sandwich.  I've been coming back over and over again.  it's a little hole in the wall in the tenderloin.  when I say little I do mean little.  they only have seating for 2 and when there's a line, it's literally out the door even though it's only 5 deep.  once you walk in you can tell this place is authentic not like Lee's sandwiches.  I thought Lee's was a vietnamese mcdonalds... =O

I always order two hoping to save one for lunch the next day.  never happens.  it is GOOD!  I always order one combination pork and one meatball.  all the ingredients are fresh and the bread is soft on the inside and crunchy on the outside.  I've tried other sandwich places and you can tell their meats are/were frozen.  the veggies are pretty much the same, pickled carrots and radishes, cucumbers and chili peppers.  the combo pork is a cold sandwich with slices of pork and pate.  the meatball was nice and warm just oozing juices and packs lots of flavor.  it's especially good mixed with the bread.  

I don't usually drive in the tenderloin but when the sandwiches are that good it's totally worth it.
author: Samson M.

description: Wow really ? Yelp you have disappointed me horribly! So many good reviews on this place? Hands down the worst banh mi ever. The meat had no flavor, there was some gross brown sauce slapped over the bread which made it soggy , and the sandwich was pretty much just tossed together and was falling apart the moment I unwrapped it. Avoid this place !!
author: Sharon N.

description:
First timer there and it was as good as the reviewers wrote. The place is cheap and definitely worth a visit if you're in the area. 

The bread was excellent, the veggies fresh, the sauce was spicy, but not overpowering. I had the chicken sandwich and I will be going back for more.
author: Mei C.

description: Probably the cheapest sandwiches in the area. I usually get three to share between me and my coworker. Meatball + Chicken sandwich is the way to go, IMHO.
author: Theresa D.

description:
It's not too hard to impress me with a banh mi, but this was the first place I frequented, and I love the product.

$3.50 for a nice-sized banh mi sammy. Really can't go wrong with that. Chicken, pork, pate, are all featured here, but I always go for pork. Sometimes the amount of meat varies from sandwich to sandwich, but I never feel as if I am getting skimped.

Workers are always pleasant and smiling, and work through the long lines of hipsters like there's no tomorrow. So I never feel like I end up waiting too long. Have your order ready to shout out while your in line - the ladies will take care of you!

Also not far from BART either.
author: Conrad B.

description:
Suuuuuppeeeerrrr sandwiches for only $3.25!!! Wayyyy better than subway! Vietnamese sandwich is the way to go: more nutritious, more crunch, more meat, and most importantly you will feel so satisfy after eating one!
This location make amazing sandwiches! My favorites are pâté with steam pork and roasted pork. I live in the south bay where a lot of Vietnamese sandwich shops are nearby but if I go to the city I always try to pick up one or two from Saigon Sandwiches! Crunch bread with good balance of pickle vegies, meat and sauces!! Recommend to eat right away or else the bread will not be as crunchy!
author: An N.

description:
Thank you for being consistently yummy and well priced! I'd tell you the secret to avoiding the line but then I might have to wait longer!

My favs include the combination Bahn Mi and the grilled pork Bahn Mi.
author: Matthew B.

description: There's honestly nothing to complain about except there's no sign on the door! The sandwich was pretty big and flavorful! I love how they just pack it and each bite has something different! The ingredients are all really fresh and plentiful. I splurged for the combo and it was well worth my $4 with no tax! I wished that I could have eaten the warm sandwich right there but I brought it home and it was still just as good! Definitely coming here for my sandwiches now.
author: Stella Y.

description: Not sure what the big deal about this place- sauce a bit too creamy, thick bread  - tasted better bah-mi on clement st or at food trucks. Maybe the price is right for the quality of food?
author: Rebecca C.

description: Tried the roasted chicken, roasted pork and the meatball bahn mi and all were excellent. The line was very short and the service was super fast. Only $3.75 apiece! Amazing lunch value.
author: Jeff S.

description: Anytime I am in the tenderloin is a good time to come and get a pull pork jalapeño sand which from here. This snack makes every walk through this side of town worth it. They close early so we have to get here before late noon, There is some modernized seating across the street on the corner.
author: Dove N.

description:
OMG these 3 dolla Vietnamese sandwiches are ah-maaaazing...

Found this tiny shop by accident.  Originally walked by bc some bum was sitting in front of it shouting crazies and scared us away. haha    But as we walked by we checked the reviews on yelp and saw how stellar they were so decided to go back and heave our way past the bum.  

We only tried the chicken banh mi and it was fantastic.  Grilled, marinated chicken with some sort of light sauce on top.  Bread was perfect and it was a filling size.  The only thing that was bad was that we didn't buy more!!!!  If the chicken was great, I can only imagine how delicious the others are!   We'll be back and I'm taking like 10 with me to San Diego!!!
author: Bernadette M.

description:
I saw the ridiculous 4.5 star rating on Yelp & HAD to come try this place out when I was in SF. When we were there, at like 4pm on a Saturday, there was a nice steady line of customers to the door, so good sign!

Anyway, we got special combo sandwiches. Not the best banh mi I've ever had, but the meat & sauce was delicious. However, there wasn't as much veggies as I wanted and I didn't even taste the cilantro! The baguette was nice and crispy though, and the price is definitely right at $3.75 for the special. Not a huge sandwich, just right. The little space also had a huge variety of Asian snacks and desserts. & like 2 seats, so plan to takeout. Lady at the counter was super nice and efficient.

The area has pretty shoddy street parking ($1 for 20 mins!) and it's also kinda shady... When we were walking back to our car a couple blocks away, we passed by plainclothes police officers arresting people I had just asked for change for the meter. Yikes...
author: Vivian H.

description:
i don't get the hype about this place. probably because i've tasted better up the block...

tried banh mi cha lua, xiu mai, and ga. i wish it isn't so messy that everything comes out when i'm tryna bite into it. the banh mi ga was really fatty for the times i came and ate here -- and i ordered in vietnamese thinking they would do me right. i just didn't like it. i thought their xiu mai tasted funny to me, which really sucks because i really wanted to like it and banh mi xiu mai is my favorite. i think the one i liked the most was probably the cha lua because you really can't mess that one up. 

also wish they would cut the sandwiches in half sometimes. =\ oh well!
author: Victoria N.

description:
tl;dr GET THE COMBINATION SANDWICH. CASH ONLY

Err mah gerdd best bahn mi I've ever had. The combination sandwich is so amazing, I had a a few days ago and I've been craving it since. Bread nice and toasty with the insides nice and fluffy, and the outside isn't too crumbly and doesn't cut the roof of my mouth. Meat so juicy, but not so much that it makes the bread soggy, the pickled veggies and the jalapeno. mmmmmm
author: C. Z.

description:
I used to think that Kay's sandwiches in San Diego were great.  Then I thought Lee's sandwiches in LA were wonderful.  Now I see the true light- Its all about Saigon Sandwiches in SF. 
Absolutely delicious, its worth making a special trip out for this cheap and delicious treat!
author: Sayaka K.

description:
Picture this. It's noon, you work downtown SF and you're craving a bahn mi sandwich. You want it to be fresh, delicious and inexpensive. What do you do?

If you're like me, you call Saigon Sandwich, order food for takeout, hop on the 38 (L if possible) take it to the Tenderloin, avoid the crack heads and bums and get lunch! Done and done.

Now for the food. The sauce on the vegetarian banh mi is a little suspect, tastes kinda meaty, a bit like a gravy. Also, the veggies weren't as crisp and fresh as I'm used to. I will give it a second go around, but not with a bus trip involved. That was cray cray.
author: Shira O.

description:
Ever since this place was reviewed on an SF foodie blog,  I guess it is no longer the best kept secret in the Tenderloin, and perhaps all of SF.

Affordable, quick, great size, and DELICIOUS - need I say more?
author: Kyla R.

description:
Y'all this is not like the Vietnamese sandwiches that you will get at a random donut shop in SF or the Asian Market. This place Rocks! I can NEVER pass on an offer of this delicious goodness delight! I thank Mimi for introducing me to this place. 
PLUS: 
Toasted warm French Rolls 
Crunchy mixed veggies in rice vinegar (carrots, jalapeno, & radish) 
They go heavy the the Pate (YUM) 
They have a wide array of choices of meat 
The combo Special is my FAV. 

Do not get disappointed if you see a long line from the door out to the sidewalk. This is just a reassurance that the place is GREAT! I give props to the 2 ladies that makes these sandwiches. They get that line moving--SUPER FAST!
author: Rhodora E.

description:
This is my favorite bahn mi place in San Francisco. And then I bit into this: 

http://twitpic.com/xurte

Not so much anymore.
author: Adrianna C.

description:
I am not very knowledgeable when it comes to Vietnamese Sandwiches, but my tastebuds know when they reach that heavenly bliss!

I was told about this place by coworkers and decided to try it out for lunch one day. I quickly realized that noon is obviously not the best time to go (although the long line did move quickly). I advise going after 12:30 or around 1p for lunch.

I order the Roast Chicken every time for $3.50. Occasionally I ask for extra jalapenos for nice kick. The veggies in the sandwich always taste fresh and crispy. The bread is perfect, and the chicken flavorful. Sounds simple... I thought it was, but I've had so many nasty Vietnamese style sandwiches at other places; makes me appreciate Saigon Sandwich even more! 

The ladies working are always super efficient and don't play around! You better not doze into La-La Land while waiting for your order or you will be called out! It's great.             :-)
author: Sam C.

description:
Roll over Lee's Sandwich!

My hotel was located right next to the sandwich shop. First couple days I passed by, there was always a line. The day we checked out, told ourselves to try this place for lunch. It was 11 AM and no line!

Only two ladies who worked there. A little older in age, more like moms however, super nice and quick with our orders.

Ordered the combination which basically, they slabbered everything in the sandwich. Several types of meat, spread, picked vegetables in a toasted french roll. From far away it looked small and didn't look filling enough. Once you open the white paper wrapper, you'll see much food there is. It definetly was a stuffer! It was full of flavor. Levels of meat over meat and the pate sauce was amazing. You cool down from the picked veggies then you spice things up with the jalepenos. To be honest, I left satisfied and full.

It's these places that you find unexpectedly that are the ones who leave a long lasting memory! cheesy huh? I know
author: Clark Y.

description: Their sandwiches are very very good, but damn it I just got ripped off. Kinda pissed off about it too. I was looking at the snacks at the front table and the ladies were giving me completely different prices for the bang bong lan. I'm Viet so I listened to then bicker whether its 2.50 or 3.50. Then they said 3.50. So with two dac biet sandwiches for 4.25 each and the snack plus a bag, it should have equaled 12.10. I gave them 15.10 and I realized once she gave me back 1 dollar. Dammit pay with cash places that have a 15 minute wait! Still good food tho. Sigh, so much internal conflict.
author: Nancy P.

description:
BEST BANH MI SANDWICH IVE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE!!! after eating here, i honestly can't eat banh mi anywhere else (i always compare it to saigon and complain that its not as good). its seriously the perfect blend of bread, veggies, and meat. the bread is always fresh and perfectly toasted, the veggies are perfectly seasoned/vinegared, and the meat is awesome. i've tried them all but chicken is by far my favorite, since. they use a special "teriyaki mayo" (for lack of a better word) that seriously makes the sandwich (and WELL worth the extra calories). and the chicken is the "good part" of the chicken and not just gross skin and fat. 

if you're in the area and don't stop here, you're definitely missing out. the two women who own the place are so cute and work so hard. and for $3.50, it honestly can't get much better. if there weren't always a line (but don't be scared, it moves semi-fast) i would eat here almost every day!!
author: lisa l.

description:
I love banh mi.

The combination of crunchy French bread with pickled veggies on top of flavorful meat keeps me drooling.....Not to mention the kick  in the taste from the jalapeño and cilantro. 

Oh, and it's under $4? Okay, I'll take two. 

There was no line, no wait. I grabbed the sandwiches to take to Marin Headlands and see the Golden Gate. Too bad I ate it all before I got there. Mmmm.

*cash only
author: Alice A.

description: I've been going here since the late 80's. The food has CONSISTANTLY been DEEE-LICIOS for all of this time!! 'Can't say that about a lot of places. And, SOOOOOOOO inexpensive. My fav is the meatball.
author: Sabrina R.

description: The sandwiches are good but the ladies, who work there, aren't friendly at all. If you don't look at the friendly service, you can come here to enjoy the good food. To make sure bring cash for food.
author: Liam T.

description: Thin crispy bread, delicious marinated meat, big honking peppers. That's all I need to say. Under $4 for a sandwhich, fuck yeah.
author: Rohan D.

description: Been eating Vietnamese sandwiches growing up, so I know what a GOOD Vietnamese sandwich should and suppose to be like. This place used to be good, but now ever since mama retired, its gone nasty. Basic essentials of a good Vietnamese sandwich:  remove some of the breading, and secondly, it needs to be toasted more. This is no more than a Vietnamese sloppy joe.
author: Peter T.

description: Great banh mi! Had the real thing in Vietnam and this was very close to it. At under 4 bucks, you can't beat the price and taste!
author: Michael Z.

description:
I've had this place bookmarked in my phone for MONTHS, but rarely find myself in the *lovely* neighborhood known as the Tenderloin. On a particularly nice day last week, I decided to enjoy the sunshine and make the trek to Saigon Sandwich. 

To get there, I had to partake in the obstacle course of avoiding homeless people asking for money, wailing prostitutes, and urine puddles. Delightful. Once I'd overcome that feat and entered the itty bitty sando shop, I was greeted by 3 super friendly woman who quickly took my order. I got the pork sandwich (for only $3.50!!!), as well as the coconut & gelatin dessert wrapped in some sort of leaf (not sure what it's called). Despite there being a handful of other folks in the shop, the staff was extremely efficient in preparing and ringing up my lunch. 

There really is no where to sit at the shop, so I took my food to the Civic Center park to eat with a friend. It was DELICIOUS. Everything from the spice, to the proportions of meat/veggies to bread was perfect. I devoured the whole thing, which left me almost painfully full. 

If this was in another 'hood it'd get 5 stars for sure. But for the price and quality, I'll definitely be back regardless of the location!
author: Kori M.

description:
Nothing really to say that hasn't already been said.  Best Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had and the cheapest price I have seen.  I feel a little sorry for the old Vietnamese ladies working there -- I feel like they could be making so much more money.

I have some Vietnamese friends say there are better/cheaper places in San Jose.  Unless they are paying for the plane ticket down there, I think I'll stick with Saigon Sandwich.
author: Lenza M.

description: I love their Pork sandwich, extra meat, and no mayo. SOOOOOO good. ...damn, now I want another one.
author: Chris N.

description: I can't believe there is a sandwich this good and this cheap in San Francisco.
author: Max P.

description: great bahn mi shop. lines can be long but move quickly.
author: Rudi R.

description:
I was at the main library. Since I was so close to Saigon Sandwich I couldn't help myself. Plus, I am currently working on the 7x7 list. I got there around 2.35pm. There was 2 other people there but since I was only ordering one sandwich I got mine really fast. I ordered the roasted pork with no pepper. $3.25 
I didn't eat breakfast or lunch so I was really hungry. I ate it on the walk home. It was pretty good but I usually get the chicken. I like that more. I think there's more texture with the chicken. Overall it was good. I would probably go back to the chicken.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Still a fantastic banh mi for 3.50
The rolls are much more warm and toasted. The huge amount of fresh sliced pork or chicken which is sliced around 745am when I pass by on the way to work. Service with a smile. I wish there pickeled veggies were as tasty as Latte Express on 5th ST/ entrance to mint plaza. The place is wayyy better than Lees across the street.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
I grew up on banh mi sandwiches and Saigon sandwiches makes a roasted pork banh mi that stands out from the rest of the pack. This is the only thing I've tried here and the only thing I'll get  since no other banh mi place offers anything like it - at least, to my knowledge. 

The slices of roast pork is slathered with a tasty gravy-like sauce and placed in a toasty, soft on the inside but crunchy on the outside, roll. I prefer my sandwich without the mayo (not a fan of mayo, period) and pickled veggies. Instead, I like it with the pork, fresh jalapenos and cilantro. 

At $3 it's a great price for a satisfying lunch. It's a small place and sometimes there's only one person holding up the fort (that I can see) so there might be a long line.
author: Cyndi G.

description:
what i ordered... roast pork bahn mi

sandwich was ok, lots of fillings even with the mild tasting meat but the bread they used was so hard it hurt's my jaw after i ate the whole thing

ambiance... bad (tiniest hole in a wall i've seen so far / cluttered )
service... ok (nice and quick)
cost... $- (inexpensive)
author: Gors P.

description:
LOVE THEIR SANDWICHES!!

I love the chicken and the meatballs!! Next time in SF I'm for sure stopping by again.

First timer - menu is on the wall on the right hand side after walking in (next to the fridge). It was really hard for me to find it at first. &They always seem to be in a rush so it would help if you know what you're looking for.
author: Jenna T.

description:
This place offers the best, holiest Vietnamese sandwich that was ever placed on this earth.  I usually order the Tofu sandwich, and the special sauce/mayo that they stick in there is divine.  Wanna know what else is great?  This place is RIDICULOUSLY cheap!  You can get a sandwich for just over $3 (talk about DEALS).  Most of the time I can't even finish the entirety of one of their sandwiches in one sitting because their bread is so filling, so $3 works for me (especially as a broke college student).  

One time last year Saigon Sandwich was closed for an entire month due to renovations.  I was forced to eat at Lees nearby.  Believe me, I wanted to cry.

Don't eat at Lees.  Do your tongue a favor and eat at Saigon Sandwich.
author: Marika M.

description:
Simple almost hole in the wall small store in the TL on Eddy and Larkin. Everytime I've gone, there has been a line (of about ~6-12 people). Their sandwiches are a decent size, extremely affordable at $3.50 a pop, and absolutely delicious! Well, I exclusively order the roast pork, and usually grab a couple of their taro pudding as a dessert as well.

As a guy living alone and not that into cooking, I can get by on one sandwich a meal here and save some money over eating out all the time! One sandwich would be a little on the small side for a grown man, but with a little something on the side would be fine. The register girl, though has a strong accent, is friendly and welcoming, though you can't expect superb service from a $3.50 a pop sandwich store in the TL.

I buy 4-6 at a time on Sundays since that is the only day I can go and chuck 4 in the fridge right away which usually lasts me through Tuesday. Of course they are better fresh but are perfectly edible even a day or two after by gently heating in the microwave.

They are open at 7am 7 days a week so if you are a morning person you can go before work. Its a shame they close at 5pm so I can never make it after work.

Neighborhood is TL so its shady and rough. One time I went there was a crazy dude outside who yelled something nobody could make out every 2 minutes on the dot. If you absolutely cannot handle creepy neighborhoods then this place is not for you, but if you go when the sun is out, its not TOO bad.

Highly recommended.
author: Ken S.

description:
This is probably the best roast pork bahn mi I've had that I can think of in San Francisco. Cheap great tasting sandwich and quick service.

For those that haven't been here, it is very very small, and there are only 3-4 chairs by the window.
author: Ken L.

description:
Renowned as being the best Viet Sandwich place in the city.  I finally got to come here.  They dont' have a sign above their shop right now.... but this small shop was still packed and people kept on coming, and it was already like 2 pm.

This place already has 1 billion reviews.  Believe it, Its pretty dam good.  Just try it.
author: Steven F.

description:
A friend recommended that we stop by this place for sandwiches to go for the beach, and I must say, I am very impressed by the quality and taste. Not to mention the prices are wonderful for the quality of the sandwiches.

I've tried the combo sandwich so far, must try the other options that they have! A lot of folks seem to order their vegan/tofu sandwich, I may try that one day!
author: Ming S.

description:
I love this place!

I've only ever eaten the Tofu Bahn mi, but its so yummy! 

This is a tiny hole in the wall place, TINY. But the ladies inside are really nice.

Make sure you bring small bills, cash only.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Souless in my search...
I need a banh mi sandwich...
Saigon satisfied!!!
author: Derek N.

description:
Dirt cheap (tree fiddy!) and delicious, it's the epitome of what banh mi should be. I was in the area one morning, and made it in just before the lunch crowd. Ordered the roast pork and chicken, and as soon as my sandwiches were ready (which was surprislingly quick!) and I paid, I ran out with those bad boys under my arms like I was protecting a football as I ran in for a touchdown. By that time, the line outside had extended to 15 people long, all licking their lips and jealously devouring my sandwiches with their eyes.
 
By the time I found a spot to chow down, the sandwiches were still plenty warm, so I had half of each. And then I finished both. The bread was toasted just to the right crispiness, the meat was tender and perfectly roasted, and the sandwiches included plenty of cilantro, pickled carrots and daikon. It was absolutely divine. I was close to nirvana, even. At least until I bit down on a jalapeno. It's just my personal taste, but I ended up picking those out. My only complaint is that there's no space to eat there, so the only options are to stand outside, or to walk over to the UN plaza or the City Hall area. That's ok, though, I have my sandwich to keep me company.
author: Y D L.

description: To sum it up- heartbroken. I had been trying to find the time to try out their legendary banh mi for ages. Maybe it was because we came a quarter til closing but.. BUT.. they were out of pork, the bread grinded my mouth raw, extra jalapeños pretty please equated to two slivers. I shouldn't have said anything. So little chicken. Im so disappointed. The word is HYPED.
author: Zalee B.

description: For $3.50, you get a fresh banh me bursting at the seams with pork, fresh veggies AND a generous slab of pâté. This is easily the best banh me I've ever had.. and I grew up in Orange County, where "Little Saigon"/ Westminster is easily accessible. If you like Vietnamese sandwiches, YOU MUST GO HERE!
author: Denise H.

description:
It's been a minute since I've had a really good Vietnamese sandwich and I figured that it is loooooooooong over due!  All sandwiches are $3.00 - perfect for recession wallets!  Unfortunately I ordered a chicken sandwich but they messed up both orders and gave me two tofu ones BUT THANK GOODNESS it was DELICIOUS! I would give them 5/5 stars, but because I live in San Bruno and I had to drive all the way to SF for this and I didn't find out until I went home for now I will be giving them 4/5 stars!

[http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hqQoVK0vadOX7_4gN1sh3g?select=UNYmoj456dGeJYLyyo7DsA]

[http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hqQoVK0vadOX7_4gN1sh3g?select=LCV9RInwmqnavzbD2Pi4kw]
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
The lady behind the counter gave me my sandwich and another customer their sandwich, then she accepted our money separately.  I have her a $5 and the other person gave her $4.  But when she handed our change back, she switched it and gave $1.25 to the other person and $.25 to me.  It was my first time there. The other person walked off quickly after they got the change and when I tried to bring it up to the lady at the counter, she didn't understand. So I just left, deciding $1 is not THAT big a deal.  
I walked back to my building on the next block at finally got to try the famous Saigon sandwich...which was pretty disappointing.  It was the first time I've had onions in my bahn mi...and I've had plenty of bahn mi from different areas of California.  No pickled radish either, which is usually a staple in the sandwich.  The sandwich was much sweeter than what I'm used to.  The bread wasn't all that great either, not as crispy and fresh like many other places.  Meat was decent and probably the best part about it...since the jalopenos were not spicy at all...and I got mostly stems on my cilantro.  Over all it was a decent tasting as a sandwich, not particularly as a bahn mi.
author: Maysee V.

description: I'm a bit picky about meats, but I love the pate combo sandwich here and I don't care what's in it. I love this place! You can't beat the price and their quick production. I feel good supporting this amazing Tenderloin spot, and am glad that people know about it.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
OMG AMAZING.

The Baguette is SCRUMPTIOUS. crispy on the outside, tender on the inside. The pork is nicely seasoned, not over-sauced, and it is a nice lean cut. 

It's only 6", though, and Lee's sandwiches are about 2" longer for about the same price.
author: Bootylicious J.

description: I love these sandwiches. The bread is soft on the inside and crusty on the outside. The fresh jalapeños and pickled carrots are amazing complements to the tender meats. I'm a fan of their Asian desserts: rice cakes, rice cakes in banana leaves, "puddings" with jellies and beans... It's all good.
author: Therese M.

description:
Listen. Forget about the dingy shop, perhaps some questionable food-handling (all Asian shops do that, please), and stop complaining they "jacked up" their sandwich prices by a WHOPPING 50 cents (it's $3.50 now). 

Just shut up and take my money.
author: Abel L.

description: Pork Meatball no Pate was amazing!! Must eat Two lol Heard about this place from a friend and he HAD to take us here while we were in San Fran. A lil ghetto but most def worth every bit of it! The Best Banh Mi i've ever had yet so far...
author: Tatiana C.

description:
Their tofu sandwich is one of the few things that i crave for... the sauce and the tofu is so flavorful, and it's perfect with the crunchy french bread.  The price is unbeatable!!  Ugghhhh i want one NOW!!

P.S. I heard someone asked the cashier if there is MSG in the sandwich, silly you... of course there is!
author: Mandy C.

description:
The banh mi is the french viet version of the McDLT only really good! Roast pork, pate, pickled carrots on baguette...stop it.  These friendly ladies serve it up fast and fresh.  They were good sports too as I paid in change and was waiting for a sigh or comment under the breath.  She genuinely smiles and says 'see you again sir'  

It was so good I wanted to share, so gave the smelly down on his luck gentleman outside the last bite and he gave me a free street smart paper, which is awful btw.  Like a bag of chips there's hardly anything inside.  Unlike the banh mi there's lots of good things inside.
author: Clark G.

description: I wasn't sure how great a banh mi could get, but this tiny store in the Tenderloin makes one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had! I ordered the grilled chicken sandwich, and the marinade on the chicken went perfectly with the light spread of mayo. I loved that they load on the pickled veggies and cilantro, and the best part of all was that their baguette was perfectly toasted for a soft interior and crunchy outside. My boyfriend had the roasted and steamed pork combo, which I highly recommend. The different textures and flavors of the meat make for a more unique sandwich, and the portion of the protein makes it extremely filling. On top of the fact that the sandwich is amazing, the price is so friendly that there's no wonder there's always a line out the door. I will be back without a doubt as it's probably the most perfect banh mi I've had!
author: Ashley T.

description:
Seriously the best Vietnamese sandwich I've experienced. 

Initially I found this place hard to find. In not so great a neighborhood (not terrible either though) and no sign on the door. But when I saw a line quickly forming, I knew that was the place. There were two women cheerfully making sandwiches, one older and one younger. As they were making sandwiches for the last batch of orders, a line would quickly form, made up of all kinds of different backgrounds - the local high school hipsters, the Russian student, the basketball player, and of course the asian foodies.

What makes this place delicious? The meat is incredibly tender, flavorful, and fresh. The ingredients are very fresh and just the right amount is put in. This place is no b.s. pure authentic quality. Can't get much better than this.
author: Derrick P.

description: I was very impressed with the sandwich. Very tasty, great size and cheap as heck. I got the chicken which was recommended with the price and size I was a very satisfied  patron!Looks like your walking in some random persons dirty kitchen. No one washed their hands after collecting money. Hey that is San Francisco underground eatin! I will be trenching through the hood for this hidden delight again its worth it.
author: X X.

description: Just arrived from NYC and needed a banh mi fix. Relatively few options-- we picked roasted pork and fanci pork. Both were gorgeously loaded with cilantro, jalapeño and carrots on wonderfully fresh bread. All for $3.75. Just wish there was more of a spot to sit and savor.
author: Catherine C.

description: No idea as to why it to me so long to get here.  Our office ordered sandwiches from lunch here and I was told the pork sandwich was the only way to go.  Such good advice.  $3.50 for an amazingly yummy sandwich.  Make sure you call ahead to skip the lunch rush, line is typically out the door.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I had this place bookmarked for a long time and was extremely looking forward to trying out. Didn't have to wait for too long.. So overall review of their Banh Mi... We ordered Special Combo and the Roast Pork.. the quality of ingredients, particularly roast pork was fantastic but unfortunately ingredients were inconsistently added - mine only had carrot pickles and hardly any radish pickles hence the taste was uneven. And the key to their famous flavour is Mayonnaise! This was the disappointing part and it didn't do it for me. Ah well, I've tried it now and don't have to go back walking on the dingy streets.
author: Bomin K.

description: Their banh mi is soo good! Perfectly seasoned even though the bread is not that crunchy and lil bit soggy. But the taste is, the bread wouldnt even matter. Totally worth the wait and its only $3.75. Just too bad they only accept cash.
author: Sulistiani M.

description: Just close your eyes while watching them make the sandwiches bc it will freak you out (sorry cluttered and questionable culinary environments give me a really scared feeling I'm going to get sick) , and just EAT. Because that Banh Mi is the BEST
author: Lauren V.

description: My first Bahn mi ever, they never really appealed to me but I loved it. I had Roast pork, perfect combo of ingredients and so cheap!
author: Alice W.

description:
I'm not sure how quality the meat is, but the roast pork sandwich is DELICIOUS. I love the carrots and the little sauce they put at the bottom and for $3.50 it's a good deal. My friend who grew up in the city showed it to me and I've been a fan ever since.  Only thing I dislike is that they close at 5pm, but considering the area it is in (Tenderloin), I guess I can't blame them for not wanting to be around after dark and closing late at night.

Overall I like the place and definitely will continue to go back.
author: John C.

description: Stuffed delicious combination sandwich for $4.25! They were closing up and didn't have change so gave me $1 instead of .75 and nicely told me to keep the change. The women who run the shop are super sweet and their sandwich is full of flavor.
author: Y W.

description: As if they need another positive review...tastes great the day of...even better next day :)
author: Manish B.

description:
OHMYGOD. This place has truly changed the way I see Vietnamese sandwiches.  Never will I settle for a sub-par sandwich where the bread is hard, it gets stuck in my gums or damages the roof of my mouth.  Never again will I settle for a sandwich that is 80% bread, 10% mayonnaise, and 10% filling...where the fillings are microwaved, or where "extra" means a few more slices of carrots or one more piece of pork for $2 more....

The bread was fresh and warm, the meatball was soooo flavorful and garlicky and tasty....and they packed in more veggies than I thought could fit in the bread.  I couldn't even finish it.  All for less than $5.. I think it was around $3.50 or so, but don't quote me on that- I was way too hungry to notice.
author: Betty W.

description: I heard its the best Vietnamese sandwich place in the Bay Area, and I would totally agree!
author: Mario L.

description:
Cam Huong in Oakland was my favorite Banh Mi supplier.  They still are, but Saigon Sandwich has some bomb roast pork banh mi!  Perfectly toasted bread filled with tender, melt in your mouth pork and pickled vegetables so carefully arranged by the two nice ladies running the shop.  

Lines are long, but worth it.  Expect to dine on the sidewalk or elsewhere because they lack dine-in space.
author: Kathleen W.

description: My Vietnamese eye doctor recommended the sandwiches, and he didn't even know I worked in Civic Center. You can't get a better warm meal for the price--anywhere. I love the meatball, no mayo. Just one question: has it changed? My colleague went a month or so ago and the meatball looked completely different. I'm afraid to find out. Is it still the same? Thanks Yelpers!
author: Karen G.

description:
The fantastic value inherent in these delicious, loaded $3 sandwiches should make the rest of the food-serving world ashamed of themselves. 

This is the downside of Saigon Sandwiches. Now, every time I'm in some fancy-pants restaurant* and they want me to pay $6 for a side of broccoli, I won't be able to stop thinking about the two tasty sandwiches stuffed with daikon, carrots, peppers and loaded up with pate that I could get instead.

As I walked away, it took all my willpower not to go back inside and get another.
________

*Which is a lot. I'm a big deal.
author: Peter D.

description:
My 2nd review for Saigon, and I'm bumping up to 5 stars.


Why? It's perfection in a sandwich. The bread is a perfectly crisp french baguette. I love the meatball pork, it's moist and delicious. There is a variety of green stuffs to cut into the richness: pickled vegetables (delightful!), cilantro, onions, and peppers. (ask for no peppers if you're sensitive-- these are no joke)


And to top it off, the service is brisk but never rude. I ran into the Saigon Sandwich lady on the muni once, and our conversation went like this:

Me: *questioning glance*

Saigon Sandwich lady: Yes, I'm the Saigon Sandwich lady.

Me: Cool! I love your store!


It was akin to meeting a celebrity. I sure was excited. 
Saigon, please don't ever change!
author: Cathy S.

description:
I've had some really good banh mi at Eden Center in NoVa.

This place is on pace, if not better than any of those spots in NoVA.

It was a tiny spot with one little table. There were two ladies working in there pumping out orders for a line of people that wrapped out the door.

We didn't have to wait at all, but I reassured people in line that it was worth it. I had the pork sandwich and it was awesome. The bread was crunchy but not hard. The meat and veggies were very plentiful.

Kristin had the chicken and I didn't think that was quite as good. It just wasn't as unique.

The prices are amazing, which is one of my favorite parts of banh mi. We got out of there with a drink for $16. Crazy.

The only problem with this spot is the location. It's in the Tenderloin and you'll 100 percent guaranteed to see some bums around. Seeing them picking through the trash right outside the restaurant just isn't ideal when you're dining.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Really cheap and delicious banh mi from this little hole in the wall. 

They even offer vegetarian options which is a little atypical from my experience.

Service is not great, but it's rapid fast, and you're only paying $3.50/sandwich, so whatever. Line gets long around prime lunch hours.
author: Paulina D.

description:
I came here randomly, just noticed it on yelp. 

I ordered the roasted pork sandwich for ($3.50) and it was good. They made it fast, the meat was still warm and the bread was perfect. However, the sauce on the roasted pork was just a bit too sweet for me after I ate half of the sandwich.

Next time I will get the combination banh mi!
author: Erica T.

description: So today I had the chicken sandwich and it was a disappointment. Yes, even though the sandwich was robust with all the fixins, the chicken did not taste like chicken. I think the pork or the combo one is the way to go. I definitely will not be getting the chicken one again.
author: Sharon G.

description:
Honestly, best banh mi I have ever had!

I went on a weekday at lunch time, and there was no wait; I am not sure how it is on the weekends since other yelpers have complained of lines.  The price was excellent, and the sandwich filled me up! 

The ladies were very nice and they worked quickly.  The outside may not be the most inviting, but don't hesitate to try it out! You won't regret it!
author: Samantha H.

description: This place offers not so much a sandwich as it presents an ode to meat.  The trappings of this place are pretty bare, dare I say grimy, with 2 seats at the counter by the window for in-restaurant dining and enough space to fit maybe 4 people between the doorway and the counter where you order. The sandwich comes in a fairly thick roll, more bready than the other nearby shops (I'd actually preferred it if they hollowed out part of the inside) but I guess you need a roll of that size based on how much they fill it with.  The pork combo is overflowing with pork roll and pate with an acceptable amount of roast pork. While they pack the sandwich with meat, they unfortunately skimp out on the veggies as my sandwich was devoid of cucumber with no daikon to be seen either, and the carrots were minimally pickled (if at all). They sauce their sandwiches with a good helping of what I suspect is mayo and Maggi sauce which can ooze out dangerously between bites and cause an unsuspecting mess. If I was starving and looking for the most bang for my buck, I would choose this sandwich over the others based purely on the calorie to dollar ratio; if you're looking for a more balanced sandwich, I'd recommend checking out Lee's or L&G.
author: Gene C.

description:
I know what I'm looking for in a banh mi, and I found it here.

I'm almost at a loss on where to begin describing the sandwiches here. I tried the roast pork first and special second, and they were monstrous things to behold. How the two little ladies were able to cram so much food into a baguette baffles science.

What was common to both sandwiches was precisely where the flavor(s) came from: the meat. I have never eaten a pork sandwich where the meat actually fought with itself. Allow me to explain. The roast pork was marinated sweet-style, but I could taste - two distinct kinds of sweetness - along with the natural flavor of the meat. As for the house special, the pate came on strong just like pate should before relenting to the more subtle flavors of the cold cuts.

I do recommend eating these sandwiches soon after getting them. The bread is super crunchy, when fresh, and every bite is just a crunch crunch chomp chomp of perfection.

When I do visit San Francisco again, this is one of the few places I'll make a return trip to even though I'll be mostly trying new places.
author: Maciej G.

description:
Saigon Sandwich does not need another review, but I can't help but write a review considering I have become such a frequent patron here the lady recognizes me.  

Usually after devouring a large bowl of chicken pho at Turtle Tower, we walk across the street here and order sandwiches to go or eat one on the spot.

The awesome thing is they carry a pretty good Tofu Banh Mi for vegetarians.  Order the combo or the Roasted Pork or Chicken Banh Mi!

Probably the best banh mi in the city.
author: Carli F.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I've had a lot of vietnamese sandwiches, but this place is my favorite so far, even beating out Cam Hung in Sunnyvale, which was my favorite before I tried this place.  Even after being stuffed so full we thought we were going to explode, this sandwich was super tasty.  That's how I know it was amazing, actually.  

The bread was super good, and so was everything else in that delicious sandwich.  I honestly don't know what it was about it that made it so good, but I will definitely back to grab another one sometime soon!
author: Jenna L.

description: Generous portion, cheap, and tasty banh mi! Got the roasted pork for 3.75! Line was out the door (so you know it's gonna be good!), expect to wait. Minus one star for cleanliness, behind the counter looked like utter chaos! But for a hole in the wall not entirely unexpected. Awesome food though!!
author: Christopher C.

description:
Roast pork banh mi was really good.  

I went for breakfast around 9 in the morning and there was no line.
author: Pete C.

description:
hearty, tasty banh mi!

When I can make it here on a weekend, i try. The sandwiches are pretty big- i usually eat half and save half for later (good to eat then shop at union sq or westfield). Sandwiches are $3 something.

I like the roast chicken and roast pork. Premium pork is ok. I've never successfully been able to order mine extra spicy.

This place gets packed so go early or late and avoid the rush. Also beware the crazy people walking around.
author: Christina C.

description:
First time yesterday at this place where i have seen huge lines gather at lunchtime.
I felt fortunate to get in without the line and only one person before me.
I ordered the chicken banh mi to eat in as I don't live in the city.
It is a very small place with only 2 seats to eat orders in. Obviously its a take out place.
i got a snapple with the sandwich and sat down and started into the incredible sandwich. With the first bite I realized why there was such a fuss over this place. Delicious with a capital"D".
i put my drink down next to my sandwich and within 10 seconds I started seeing the bottle slide down towards the floor. HMMMMM, slanted counter? I guess so.
The two places and chairs for eating in was shared by a common counter that was joined at one end to form a right angle situation. i took my drink and tried it out on the "other" counter directly to my right. The bottle seemed to be much more secure and wasn't sliding down. Cool.
Within a minute the bottle slid down and fell on the floor. No breakage but liquid around me.
The owner came over with a broom and dustpan? (strange way to get the snapple off the floor) getting the puddle of it into the dustpan but leaving the area that i was sitting in and myself still with wet shoes and juice all around me.
Her remark to me was "it's ok". No it's not OK. First of all WTF is up with not using a mop to get the sticky stuff off the floor as a consideration for customers that will come in. And secondly what about me?
I kept eating, but this experience was on my mind taking away from the enjoyment of the food.
I got up and got another snapple from the case that was right to the left of me.
After a minute or two, the same person came over to me specifically to say "You got another drink, you pay me" I said "I don't think so". I sat there thinking about the fact that this place would not even spend a dime on fixing that counter (which was the cheapest one's I have ever seen.) It seemed so stupid to me that they wouldn't invest $40.00 max to just level it properly so that problem wouldn't keep recurring.
When I finished, I stood up and sincerely asked if she wanted me to really pay for the "extra" drink. She said Yes. I mentioned that she should probably have a sign there that warns people about placing there drink on that counter. When I said that she seemed embarrassed by that statement in front of other customers that were standing in line. It seemed like against her nature to say it but did.As i reached in my pocket and pulled out a five starting to hand it to her she reluctantly said "It's Ok"
The sandwich could not be faulted despite my experience with yet again another greedy owner that doesn't have the business sense to procure regular customers by just treating them humanly and spending a very small amount of money ensuring their comfort. I guess that is what happens to politicians and restaurant owners: Power or success makes them forget their humble beginnings!
it's sad to say that this is more the rule than the exception in the 44 years that I have lived in the bay area.
All that being said I WILL go back there, separating the wheat from the chaff, but next time its "to go"!!!
author: Jerry S.

description:
$3.50 - $4.00 for a sandwich that will fill you up.

Both the pork and the tofu combination bahn mis are delicious! The bread isn't dry and doesn't scrap the top of my mouth like other bahn mi places, and they are so generous with veggies.

There were 8 individuals in front of me when I got there Saturday afternoon. However, the line went by soo fast - talk about assembly line efficiency!

Only 2-3 seats for sitting. Best to pick up some sandwiches and take them to a park to enjoy the indian summer in SF!
author: May I.

description: The sandwiches are delicious and the service was fast. We also got some jelly dessert to with it. The only downside was the homeless man that decided sit directly at then entrance and yell "Hi" very loudly at 10 second intervals. We gave him some money but it didnt stop him from yelling. This is not to disparage the business since its out of their control. It is in the Tenderloin so I guess I shouldn't be surprised.
author: Olivia C.

description:
We decided to come here because of all the reviews.  Upon arriving I wasn't sure what to make of this place.  There seems to always be a line, we got into line, waited shortly until we made our order, they take about 10 peoples orders at a time then make the sandwiches and hand them out.  I usually go with the chicken extra spicy! 

A great place to order to go on a nice day! After my visit I knew I loved this place and have been back multiple times!
author: Mallori S.

description:
Hands down the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had.

The BBQ chicken and BBQ pork sandwiches are to die for. Hard to pin point exactly what makes these sandwiches the best I've ever had. But the bread is toasted to perfection (crunchy and savory, never too hard) and the meat is marinated perfectly.

Note: This isn't a cafe or a restaurant, it can almost be described as a hole in the wall, and easily missed by drivers. There isn't any seating available (2 chairs by the window) and probably a maximum capacity of 10 people standing. 

Despite that... BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES EVER.
author: Ada C.

description:
How on earth have I not reviewed my favorite banh mi place in the entire city? Jeebus. I'll keep it short and sweet.

Best. Ever.

Don't know what they do to make it taste so good; don't want to know. Pork combo makes my tastebuds sing. I've sampled banh mi at a handful of other places in the city and Saigon Sandwich is hands down the best. Totally worth the trek. And at $3.75 (or is it $3.25??) a sandwich, it's a freaking steal. 

Heaven.
author: Karena Q.

description: Good sandwiches for cheap in a not so nice neighborhood.  Plenty of street parking.  Go early, I walked in an at 11 AM and was out in 5 min.
author: Curt C.

description:
Tucked in the middle of the tenderloin. One block away is the FBI building and you go down 1 block towards this place, crack head to the left right front and back.
type of place where it's too small inside to eat because it's packed with asian goodies
best thing to do is a drive by, have someone go down and order while another drives around the block
i ordered the special combination. had the usual fillings. the only thing i would've preferred is all my meats are cold cuts. i dont really like having roast pork in the sandwich.
not shady with the pate that's for sure.

would i come back? maybe if i was in the area. but there are other vietnamese sandwich places to try

but this place is overall a winner if you looking for a banh mi fix
author: Andi I.

description: So depending on when you go, you could walk in and out with a delicious sando or wait a excessively long time, but it's totally worth it. Get the pate spread. Nom
author: Lainey D.

description:
JUST the smells warmed my soul on a freezing day of fog!  So just imagine how satisfying the sandwiches are!  

For those that DON'T know...
Traditional Vietnamese sandwiches comprise of a French baguette-like torpedo roll, filled with an array of different cuts of meat, and layered with pickled vegetables (which have a sweet tang--different from American pickling), fresh cilantro, and jalapeno peppers.  In Vietnamese, these sandwiches are referred to as "Banh Mi" (bunn-me), which literally translates to bread.  The original Vietnamese cuts of meat are labeled, at Saigon Sandwich, as "Cha Lua & Paté", but this establishment has several variations (and vegetarian options), which are equally tasty!

For those that DO know...
The ingredients here--at least in all my orders thus far--are fresh.  The sandwiches are cleanly assembled, and the tastes are well-executed.  Also, the bread is toasted/served warm--it's a big pet-peeve when other places don't warm their bread!  The prices (circa this review) are $3.25/sandwich.  They also have a solid selection of Che (Vietnamese desserts) and beverages.  Cash only.  I adore this place!
author: Diane N.

description:
I'm on my quest to try as many of the 7x7 100 things to try before you die list. The roast pork sandwich is one of them.

I've actually wanted to try this Vietnamese sandwich shop for a while, but it quite out of the way and not in the best neighborhood. Surprisingly, I walked in on a Saturday afternoon and there was no line!  I ordered the roast pork sandwich and noticed the women spoke Chinese! 

The sandwich was good, but wasn't great. The bread was crunchy and fresh and the meat was tender and juicy. The veggies were a little on the soggy side and there was a little too much mayo on the bread. 

I am still on my quest for the best Vietnamese sandwich... I've only found status quo so far.
author: Lisa L.

description:
In high school, I was introduced to Vietnamese cuisine and I loved it. However, none of the places in Houston, to my knowledge, had banh mi on the menu. Though I could have just been completely satisfied with the pho and spring rolls. Actually, I know I was. 

Years ago, I watched a show on sandwiches around the U.S. on Food Network that talked about the elusive bahn mi. How did I miss that one- I had to try one! After moving to SF and realizing that I was once again, in a city where great Vietnamese food was available, I started my search. I was recommended Saigon Sandwiches and I never turned back. I even introduced a Vietnamese friend to the place and because of her I tried everything that was there to try: the fried banana and the gelatin like substance stuffed with meat and rolled in a banana leaf, among others. All pretty yummy, but some people might not be able to cope with the texture. All in all, Saigon Sandwich is still one of my favorites.
author: Norma ..

description:
When I use to live in the Tenderloin, I would walk up half a block by myself to buy myself a sandwich. This place has the best Vietnamese sandwiches! It's a whole in the wall. There is only two chairs where you can sit. Most people just order and leave.  The line does get long, however the two women are so fast with preparing the sandwiches, it's no more than a ten minute wait after she took down your order. 
 
I use to get their Fancy Pork when I was younger, but now their Tofu or Chicken are my new mouth watery favs. The bread is really crunchy too if you like it like that.
author: Lisa T.

description: So freaking good and super cheap ! I think people who give bad reviews are just too picky. The only bad thing I have to say is the neighborhood is pretty shoddy. I used to go to Little Saigon in Westminster and had all kinds of Viet sandwiches but this is one of the best and one of freshest sandwiches I've had. Would definitely go back again ! Yum!!
author: Jennie C.

description: absolutely delicious. In the middle of nowhere and easy to walk past but this place had the best pork bahn mi sandwich I've ever had.
author: Jackie W.

description:
Best tofu vietnamese sandwich I've found anywhere in SF.  

Cheap, consistently awesome, and worth the wait in line.
author: Alicia J.

description: hannnnds down, THE BEST Vietnamese sandwich I've had in the states. And as a Vietnamese banh mi lover, I've tried my share of different places so you can trust me on this one :). Make sure you come hungry, cause these sandwiches will surely fill you up! To me, what makes the sandwich is the pate, so if you're brave enough, gettttt you some. Can't get over the price as well, $3.75 for a simple sandwich, whhhhhat a steal. This place should definitely make it on some sort of checklist for when you're in town, I try to get here every time I'm in town.
author: Christina N.

description: Hole in the wall in little saigon (read: the tenderloin) with psychotic hobos outside. But perfect Bahn Mi for $3-4 dollars. Make sure to have them spread their weird pate stuff on first, it's great.
author: Basil G.

description:
This is the best Banh Mi sandwich in the city!!

It is a small place in the Tenderloin. You can usually find a long line outside. However, the line is not a line to order your sandwich. When you are ready to order a sandwich, you need to shout it out loud to the cashier. She will then place your order. Then you step aside with the rest of the people and wait for your banh mi. 

Their Banh mi is tasty and cheap. $3.50 for a sandwich! I recommend the meatball sandwich or the roasted pork sandwich. The bread is perfectly toasted. Crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Pork is flavored so well that there is a party in your mouth with every bite. 

If you are lucky to be selected to be a juror at the Civic Center Courthouse, this is an excellent place to grab a bite. It's quick and easy. 

Bring Cash!
author: Molly T.

description: Great bread, pork is fatty, sauce is okay. Definitely had better at Portland food carts.
author: Cayla C.

description:
The Saigon sandwich spot is kickass! I actually read a few 1 star reviews to find out what exactly dissatisfied these Yelpers to be so stingy with the stars, because I know  this place serves Vietnamese sandwiches that are deeeeelicious. Apparently, some dislike the sauce used in their sandwiches, others complain about long lines, and a small number claim this place is for tourists. 

Okay, I admit long lines formed during busy lunch hours can be a frustrating test of patience, but fact that hungry people are willing to endure the wait should be seen as a sign of something great at the front of the line. 

I'm not sure about the tourist claim, but I've never seen a guy wearing a Hawaiian-print shirt and an oversized DSLR camera strapped over his neck waiting in line  before. 

Bashing the sauce, on the other hand, is something I don't  condone. I love the sauce!   It is fatty, decadent and sinfully tasty. One word to describe the combination of a decadent sauce and the rich, full-flavored pate (brought in from the Vietnam-California capital, San Jose) used in the pork combo: LUSCIOUS. 

I'm not suggesting that Saigon serves the most delicious or "authentic" Vietnamese sandwiches out there, but their sandwiches--especially, the sauce-laden pork 
combo--definitely make Saigon a force to be reckoned with.
author: Dave L.

description:
After I finish this review, I'm going to review Gandhi (five stars: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohandas_Karamchand_Gandhi). After all, what hasn't been said about that dude?

$3.50 banh mi that hits the spot every time you have hunger strike? Sure, I'd line up. And I do. Fresh, forgiving baguette, pate and meatstuff? Yeah. I'll do that. But don't be dumb like me and let your stomach do the ordering. On an exceptionally ambitious outing, I decided that these were indeed a bit small, so between me and Fee Ants (fiancee), we'd order three and split one of them. Way. Too. Much. Deliciousness. I pretty much puked. 

This one's a cash only joint, but there's an ATM in Prime Dip a couple doors down. There's also a masturbator a couple blocks down. Avoid that dude and his windburned pecker - cross the street if you have to.
author: Roy M.

description: sandwiches are good and cheap best banh mi Ive tasted so far
author: Krystle P.

description:
That was the tastiest sandwich I've ever eaten. And it was so quick and simple.

Amazing bread, tofu, shredded carrot and onion, jalapeño, cilantro, and some soy sauce. I'd pay more than the $3 they charged me for that thing so feel free to tip. We had some easy going language barrier situations, but we worked it all out. I guess if you just say tofu and vegetables they shoot for the mayo, but I said no mayo and so on to the soy sauce. It's not so much about what you order as is it is making sure to rattle off things you definitely don't want.

It was fast, cheap, and delicious. I think next time I'll get two.
author: Justin N.

description:
One of the saddest parts about me swearing off soy (seriously, ladies, that sh*t fucks with your hormones) is that I have to give up the tofu bahn mi at Saigon. I'm going to erect a shrine to it's memory under my desk at work, and look longingly at others' orders as I grab their other most-amazing sandwich with meat and pate. 

Though that meat mousse will satisfy me fully so I'm not up nights weeping, I'll still miss that fried-to-sweet-perfection tofu. And don't even get me started about that curried tofu sandwich at Petite Deli in North Beach. Sigh.

I digress. The point is that this place serves up some of the tastiest bahn mi sandwiches in SF for around $3.50. You may have to dodge some serious crackheads, human feces, and broken syringes to get there, but trust me when I say, it's worth it.
author: Christina S.

description: Vietnam sandwich is amazing. try Cha Lua. I always come here when I'm in town.
author: Linda Z.

description: Quick stop in here for a take out lunch while at class nearby.  The mango tapioca pudding was nice and sandwich full of meat.  Service was quick and friendly.  Really not much else to say about this place. No tables. Sandwiches are 3.75.
author: Jacob F.

description:
This is the place where I had my Banh Mi cherry broken. And it will continue to be the standard that I judge all others. (Even if I find my way to Vietnam.)
The sandwiches are cheap and delicious.  That may seem like a typical answer, but it is the best two words that can describe this place.  Someone, a few years ago, a non native I may ad, was nice enough to bring me a sandwich from this place.  I have been a fan ever since. In fact I love sharing this place with others as well.

It is extremely intimate and is tucked away in a very impoverished area of San Francisco.  And that is one reason why I deeply love this place and my city.  In what other town in the US can you see  a banker, a hippy, a  hipster, a homeless, and a tranny  all lined up outside the same eatery?

Really, for selfish purposes, I was very reluctant to share this place. (The line gets long enough as it is.)  But since I do my best to not enter the heart of the city during peak commute and tourist times, I thought what the hell.  Plus they do serve one of the best sandwiches that I have ever had.

I love the combination.  I use to order it with extra jalapenos, but they no longer agree with me.  However, it is still tasty and comes with canned pate, and uhhhhh, uhmmmm so other meat products.  Maybe processed chicken loaf?  Meat by product ham like meat substance?  I actually do not know and am completely content in my ignorance.  I just know that it is good.
author: Joshua C.

description:
Food is absolutely delicious and worth it and so much more, but the low rating comes from the fact that there are so many health violations going on it's ridiculous. I don't see how they still have a pretty high health score. It needs to be updated ASAP!

I come in here to one of the workers sitting in the middle of the kitchen (which is right in front of you as you enter) eating ramen in a bowl with chopsticks. Since my family and I ordered 10 sandwiches, I just watched the way these women worked in the mean time while waiting.

1.) The sinks have these filthy rags hanging from them. There are also fresh clean paper towels. I did not expect that they dried their hands with the rags instead of the paper towels. That's disgusting.
