2.) The lady who ate ramen put her hand inside of her mouth! She didn't even wash it afterwards!

3.) Everything, including utensils, looked filthy! I saw the big pot they used to boil chicken get drained into a weird looking bucket!

4.) A few of our sandwiches were served to use burnt, but my family and I felt that we shouldn't point it out because of how easy-angered these women are. They are easily aggravated and take shortcuts in health codes of conducts because (I assume) they're just the 3 workers against the world. There is no stopping for them, which would explain the poor customer service, absence of hand washing, and replacing burnt bread.
author: John H.

description:
Two words- Banh mi! (: I Love love love their banh mi! Growing up in San Jose, I've had my fair share of banh mi at home and in stores. This place is the only place I've had in SF that gets pretty close to home. I always get the Fancy Pork Pate banh mi and bf gets the special combination with pate. The pate is like crack. I've seriously been here 6 times in the past 2 weeks! I just can't get enough of it. (:

Give these ladies a break! Yes the staff doesn't speak a whole lot of English but they know enough to do their job. To the arrogant jerk who yelled at them for mixing up his order (even after they offered to make him another banh mi to compensate), if you're tired of them not speaking english go to an American joint jerk! Most Vietnamese/Chinese establishments don't have waiters that speak perfect English. Their busy trying to provide for their families they're not gonna learn English just so they can serve your arrogant ass. Just my thought. (:
author: Jeanette N.

description: Really good sandwich for really cheap ($3.75). All Vietnamese sandwiches taste similar to me but for the price and the efficiency (line out the door but took all of 3 minutes to order and another 2 to get my sandwich), you can't go wrong with this place. I would definitely stop in again and maybe try the chicken or meatball (went with the pork).
author: Steven G.

description: I really don't get this place, It took me 20 min to get my sandwich because they messed up my very clear order. The staff seems like they don't know what they are doing. I will chalk it up to the bad weather that day. I might try again.
author: Ceo S.

description:
After learning about the intentional interference with economic advantage in torts class, I became more hesitant to criticize food and hence took a yelp hiatus. . . But I miss writing about food, so here I am. 

Rest assured though, this is an objective review that comes from the heart. While Saigon Sandwich may not be the best meal I have ever had, it is the best meal I have had for the value. Food is all about value, right? For $2.75 to $3.00, I get a warm, puffy banh mi stuffed with fresh ingredients and flavorful meat. Saigon Sandwich is like the In-N-Out of banh mi- a broke law student's heaven on earth. 


Personal favorites: Pate, Combination   

Bonus: They also carry a small, but well-picked bunch of Asian snacks. 

Downside: No space to eat inside. There is always a long line around lunch time.
author: Shan F.

description: If you are looking for a place with attentive staff, this is not the place for you. If you just want a delicious vietnamese sandwich, definitely stop by. This place is a total hole-in-the-wall with a cleanliness standard that would be cringe worthy in a third world country, but the food is cheap and delicious. Cash only.
author: Julia T.

description: This place is kind of cute and they are definitely very fast with the food, but there's nothing too special about it. The Bahn Mi is pretty standard tasting so if you just have to have one then by all means go, but there are a lot of better places in the city.
author: Dexter H.

description:
Efficient as hell for a tiny place with a long a** line. Wow. Delicious. The tofu banh mi was AMAZING. The bread is fantastic. The mayo they put on is the moneymaker for sure. I love everything about this sandwich. My mouth is watering as I type. Please, just go.

NOTE: Cash only. Located in a bad neighborhood so come for lunch and bring quarters!! The guy in the deli across the street doesn't like making change for dollars.
author: Rosavida C.

description:
I think i would give saigon sandwich 3.5 stars, but I'll have to round down to 3.  we got the roast pork and the roast chicken to share.  for the price, the sandwiches are definitely a solid choice.  the meats in both were tasty and had a good amount of filling.  crusty bread was good, too.

i definitely really enjoyed saigon sandwiches and think the value is awesome.  I would absolutely come back here.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Known to me as the NO-SIGNBOARD-BANH-MI shack today. I remembered they used to have a sign outside, oh well, maybe they have a reason for not having it anymore. Being in the Tenderloin, it's definitely a treasure found in turd. You can get full just by paying $3. I get the tofu banh mi all the time, because it's just melt-in-your mouth good. The crispiness of toasted french roll, and generous portion of shredded carrots, jalapenos, radish and cilantro. Then of course, the sweet, marinated tofu comes dancing in. 

If you don't mind the grumbling Vietnamese aunties who run this place, you'll be fine. Also plus one more star for traditional vietnamese desserts and snacks they sell there. Definitely not a sit-in. So, grab your sandwich and go.
author: Rika P.

description:
I've come here for years because I've always liked the ingredients in their sandwiches.  The only unfortunate thing is the food in preparation, too often, I get a sandwich that's jammed with either too much tofu/meat/chicken on one side and nothing but carrots/daikon and jalapeno on the other half.  

The sandwiches always seemed to come to me in such a hurry and in anger that when open up the wrapper, the food tends to fall out of the sandwich and onto my lap.  Not cool when I have to come back to work from the smelly lunch on my clothes. 

I hate to give them 2 stars but I don't think it'd be make a difference since this place has gotten so much hype over the years.
author: thuy n.

description:
The combo sandwich is the best banh mi I've tried so far in SF.  It was made with all kinds of cheap, fatty meat that is probably bad for your health, but good for your mood. And, some kind of mayo beacause at that point, why not?  The bread is also close to perf, with that delicate balance of crunchy and cut-the-roof-of-your-mouth-to-ribbons, falling slightly on the ribbons side. 

I also tried the "fanci pork" which is good, but not quite as stellar. 

They make the sammies fast, and there's nowhere to sit or wait. You can take a minute to stare at the variety of snack type things crowding the counter, which are individually wrapped and mostly unpronounceable. Don't bother - just point and pay.
author: Rob R.

description: i LOVE  bahn mi and this place definite made it to one of the best places to get one. Too bad, im an outta-towner. The wait wasnt so bad and the two chinese ladies working there are pretty good with their assembly line setup. The bahn mi was jam packed with picked veggie and meats. I asked for extra spicy cause i LOVE my sirachi and jalapenos. If I was in SF longer, i definitely would had visited this place a few more times.
author: Angela L.

description:
Teeny banh mi shop pumping out little footballs of goodness, nomnomnom. This will be the BEST $4 you drop during a day out goofing around the city, I promise!

If you're a pate-monster, the pate banh mi will practically have you on pleasure overload. They also have some sort of sauce that's slathered on every sandwich, delicious. The meat:veggie ratio is just perfect.

Beware it's a REALLY tight space inside, with barely enough room for a few people in line and a couple people waiting for orders. Basically, with just 4 people in line, it's out the door.
author: Ting S.

description: I got the pate banh mi sandwich and it was delicious. The pate had good flavor and texture. I wish there were more pate in the sandwich though. I love pate!
author: Samantha K.

description: Heaven on earth. The best banh mi in San Francisco by far.
author: Rich S.

description:
Not like this place needs another review, but I have to add: after all these years (20+ and counting), Saigon Sandwiches continues serving the best bahn mi in the Bay Area, hands down!

For the dirt cheap price, you can't beat this combo of fresh French baguette stuffed FULL with ohhh-so-tasty pate, meat, and pickled veggies! Awesome filling to bread ratio, unlike so many other places (Lee's, Little Paris, etc... I'm looking at you)!
author: Steve L.

description: This was definitely a good and cheap Vietnamese sandwich. The combination is probably the best to get here since they pile it up with meats and pâté. But if you're not a pate fan than you should opt for the roast pork... Which is good too but not as much meat stuffing. This is definitely a super tasty and fresh sandwich and for $3.50, this is so much more worth it than any American fast food for lunch. Albeit, if you're looking for some high quality, fancy sandwich that totes around with pretentious ingredients and local farm produce blah blah blah than this is not going to be what you want. But if you're looking for a down to earth, authentic Vietnamese (which is street food, humble food) this is it!
author: Stephanie H.

description: I didn't know I could love and crave a sandwich so much! I got one earlier today and I already want another! I highly recommend the BBQ Pork sandwich. I've never reviewed a business on Yelp before but their sandwiches gave me enough motivation to do so!
author: Andrea K.

description:
Best tofu sandwiches.  The tofu isn't deep fried like other places, it's juicy and crunchy, and the sandwich is stuffed with carrots, cilantro, and jalopenos.  Just yummy goodness for lunch.
Long lines, so get there before the crowd.
author: Karen L.

description:
Don't plan on returning.  I still don't get the hype.

They cleaned up the place and moved the counter.  With that, I have clear view on how the sandwich was made.  They spread mayonnaise and hoisin sauce first, then shove some pork in, followed by spread of pate, then a few slices of gio lua and topped w/ pickled carrots.  

This is the combo at $3.75 - while it tastes ok, to me, it's all wrong.
author: Gloria H.

description:
After watching the Human Centipad episode on South Park, I have been quoting the scene where the Japanese guy is tempted with a burrito and he says "I sorry Kyle, I tried to resist, but burrito it is a too dercious!".   And let me tell you, these Vietnamese sandwiches are TOO DERICIOUS!!!  

If I were a homeless person in San Francisco, I would be here at 7 am every single day with the money I either found on the street or begged off of people.  The chicken sandwich is only $3!!!  And I was stuffed for 6 hours!!!  

The chicken was cooked perfectly.  It had the perfect amount of heat with the jalapeno peppers as well as the best consistency with the bread being crunchy, then going to the juicy chicken, and then the crunchy vegetables layered on the bread.  The sauce they put on it was like crack.  After eating my sandwich I couldn't resist finishing off the scraps that Divya could not finish.  

With a side of the weird and also dericious shrimp chips, it was the perfect meal.  Just don't expect to sit inside their tight space...best bet, bring it home and prepare for food coma....it is toooo dericious!!!
author: Rahul S.

description:
My fave? Grilled pork, ask for light mayo. 

The special combination includes roast pork, pate and steamed pork. It's good but more rich, the pate adds an extra dimension of flavor. 

Sooooooooooooo much better than Lee's (which I went to once because Saigon ran out of bread and closed early). Don't even bother going to Lee's.
author: Jess C.

description:
Couple days ago, I had to pick up a buddy from the train station. After a long day, all that he had to eat was a lousy and overpriced $7 breakfast burrito from McDonald's. So, you can imagine how insanely hungry he was. I had just come from the gym, so I was getting pretty hungry, too. The first thing he says to me when we get in the car is "I'm starving! I need food in my belly now!" This was his first time in SF and he wanted to go somewhere quintessential of the city.

Naturally, this led me to choosing Saigon Sandwiches. First off, it's ridiculously cheap! $3! Come on! You can't beat these kind of prices. The sandwich itself is amazing. I had the roast pork sandwich. The bread was soft and chewy but with a nice crispy crust. The inside is stuffed with fresh vegetables and meat that is perfectly flavored. Service was great even though it was a wait. With food this good, I'd gladly stand in line. The lady serving us was very friendly and also very prompt.

All in all, my friend and I were both very pleased. In fact, he has even come back a second time only two days later to get another one before he had to head back to the East coast. I highly recommend this place not only for the very reasonable price but also the quality of the sandwich. While a very different style of sandwich, I'd put this up there with Ike's. 5 stars, no question.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I'm one of those weird people that don't get pork; I get roasted chicken.

I've had it before, but I didn't remember it like this and recalled it was more standard...  Personally, not the best  banh mi I've ever had.  I got something that was kind of like a grounded mystery meat sauce with the smallest bits of meat.  It was kind of disgusting.  I'm almost positive they gave me the meatball pork by mistake.  Blech.

I also paid extra for pate, which can make or break the sandwich, but I didn't taste any due to the meat sauce.  I don't think it existed.

It sucks because veggies were really fresh.  The bread was a LITTLE too hard.

Not impressed, and there's a lot of other places nearby.
author: Lily N.

description: This place is legit. I got the combination, and it was spectacular. I wanted in and had no idea what I was doing because it's really just a counter with no formal line, at least while I was there. So when the lady looked at me and motioned for me to order, I just said 'combination' and then waited outside until she yelled out at me that it was ready. I can't wait till I'm back in SF so I can go again.
author: Marc A.

description:
three words - TOFU BANH MI.

YUM!
author: Holly C.

description:
+Wait time is shorter than before
+no tax on food
+PHENOMENAL food

Must I say more? I recently had Nom Nom truck and I swear they might as well pack up and just go because they'll never compete with Saigon Sandwich. I always order the Xiu Mai sandwich and for $3.25, it comes with carrots, cucumbers, cilantro, heaping portions of meat, pate, and spread. The baguette wasn't hard and no battle scars in my mouth as a result of eating the bread. My roll was actually pretty soft which I prefer much more. 

Saigon sandwich finally hired a younger female to take all orders and man the front. The ladies are working away in the back making all the sandwiches. I'm glad they were able to take my order over the phone and it was hassle free. There was plenty of parking, and it was a Sunday that I went. You can't beat the price and its also great knowing you're not compromising your taste buds either. You won't disagree either once you've tried it. You won't be sorry, hurry and go already!
author: Connie C.

description: The area is a bit sketch, so go during the day, but go! We had the roasted pork bahn mi and it was simply delicious! The sandwich was $3.75 and more than enough! The bun was sturdy enough to stand up to the luscious roasted pork, house made mayo, and crunchy pickled veg piled high on it. Wonderful! There's only two seats in the place, so be prepared to take it out, but it is so worth it!!!!
author: Sondra M.

description:
Very, very good Banh Mi, and I've had a lot of them.

I finished it about 2 hours ago, and all I can think about is having another one.
author: Jon C.

description:
I LOVE that their banh mi is 1) cheap ($3.50) and 2) one of the best ever!

A long line for a humble restaurant = good eats

Food: 
I got the roast pork sandwich and every single element of that sandwich was just sooo delicious! The baguette was perfectly crunchy and doughy, there were lots of veggies, vinegary carrots, and a huge chile slice (but good thing I had that yummy bread to counter the spice!), and the pièce de résistance: the roast pork - I got me some good hearty slices with lots of flavor, and there was some really good sauce or something underneath the meat that got all soaked up in the bread. Nice. 

Establishment/Atmosphere:
If you wanna sound pro, make it easy for the nice ladies working at Saigon and be succinct.  Say "1 pork" for one roast pork sandwich, "1 chicken" for roast chicken, "2 combo" for 2 combo sandwiches, blah blah etc lol

They are efficient, friendly, and hard-working, which makes the crowded waiting for your order more forgiving. Plus, there's lots of other goodies, snacks, and drinks to look at and ponder purchase while you wait shoulder to shoulder with other hungry people. 

And make sure you remembered the one or two people who ordered before you, cause you might lose track of when your order's ready =)

All in all:
I'll definitely have cravings for this place again, but the only "eh" was the location and lack of seating for full enjoyment of this good food. I can't wait for Philz Coffee to open up at Larkin and Golden Gate!! That might be my seating solution!

Yummy banh mi!! Must try!
author: Hana K.

description: It's good enough to give me my Vietnamese fix but not as authentic as the ones in oakland.  They use a mix of American and Vietnamese mayo which isn't traditional and not as buttery as it should be.  The roast pork is probably the best sandwich there.  The combo which is the real classic banh mi is ok.  Proportions are off and I like my mayo buttery aka authentic.   It's the second best in SF.  The one in inner Richmond is the best.  Banh mi are better in oakland...more authentic.
author: So S.

description:
Complete flock mentality here in regards to this overrated, under quality place. (And I'm not just trying to be the rebel here....)
Long line means they cannot possibly put the love into these sandwiches to make them good. People: these sandwiches need time to toast the bread crispy, add the right amount of pate and veggies, and when this place is slammed, there's no way you're getting this. Go around the neighborhood (preferably off Larkin) to many of the other Vietnamese places that have crews of Vietnamese people hanging out in front. You'll know you are at one of these places when the old lady behind the counter says "only pork" when you ask what types of sandwiches they have. Try these instead, and you'll never wait in this line again. Heck, roll out to Clement if you have more time. Why deal with a dirty place that serves substandard sandwiches? Trust me, I know.
author: Brian J.

description:
Very good tofu banh mi sandwiches for 3.50 only. The bread is good and the veggies very crisp and fresh, they add just the right amount of coriander and chilies to make it perfect. The tofu is well prepared, even my meat-loving boyfriend enjoys it very much.

It's just a hole in the wall and they also sell deserts and drinks. 

They've raised the price twice since I moved to SF, which is not that long ago. But who can blame them, they deliver a good product and they are very popular. It's still a very fair price but come try it quick before the next price increase.
author: Jamie Starr X.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches is a gem of a store in the Tenderloin. They create their own little assembly line that quickly fashions a sandwich for you that I appreciate, because you don't want to get starve in line.

I think no one really mentions that this place uses GRAVY in their sandwiches; therefore, I will point it out because it is a rarity in most Banh Mi.

Prices run under $4 for their sandwiches. 
Their Banh Mi comes in a toasted roll layered with gravy and mayo, topped with your meat(s) of choice, then pickled vegetables, cilantros, and jalapenos.

Tofu has great texture and flavor. Be warned that the juices may drip onto you if you are not aware as you take bites.

Special combination is always a good default for those who want a great balance of meat, veggies, pate and bread...drools...

There are loads of other che (desserts) package to grab on the go with your sandwich, in addition to the other chips and cookies you can purchase to make your meal complete. 

There is no seating so be ready to grab your food to go, and yes, the location of Saigon Sandwiches is sketchy as others have mentioned. Bring cash, and prepare for good food.
author: Casey L.

description:
I don't care how unpolitically correct this sounds, but it's so fitting that Saigon Sandwiches is in the Tenderloin because the special combination is my personal CRACK. 

I've had other sandwiches here (chicken and meatball), but nothing hits the spot like a special combination.  The special combination touches on every flavor profile that is holy to man:

-Fresh bread rolls that are toasted to crunch perfection, yet still doughy on the inside
-Delicate slices of cold, fancy pork (steamed pork) layered with the tender, warm roast pork
-crisp, pickled vegetables and cilantro
-spicy jalapenos
-the intoxicating blend of the gravy from the roast pork with mayo and .... my personal favorite...
-the savory goodness of pate

$3.75  = so little to pay for such perfection in a sandwich.
author: Monelle A.

description:
fantastic place!

I always get their pork meatball banh mi and it always hits the soft spot.. also a $3.5 price tag never hurts either. I sometimes find the pepper too spicy and end up embarrassing myself in public, but this is not an issue.

I would recommend that everyone in the city should make a trip to TL for this place.
author: Sung C.

description: Love love love this place!!!! They have the best banh mi with a really really reasonable price.
author: charlie v.

description:
I grew up on vietnamese sandwiches in LA. They were afterschool lunches, treats for after the dentist (though now I don't know why), and all around comfort food. Then I went to Berkeley for four years, where the lack of good Asian food (with the exception of Indian and Thai food) is alarming. Luckily, I now live in SF where Saigon Sandwich exists right in the heart of the Tenderloin!

Roast pork sandwich: This sandwich is freaking amazing. The meat is so, so tender and is still warm half an hour later. There isn't tons of seasoning on the pork, and it doesn't need it. The mayonnaise and hoisin sauce (?) complemented it so perfectly. I can eat this like every meal for the rest of my life. 

Combination sandwich: This is okay if you want some variety (comes with steamed pork, roast pork, and pate) but the pate isn't really as wonderful as I have heard. It's also this pink-colored liquidy consistency so kinda weird. It does add moistness to an otherwise dry sandwich.

Price: The most expensive one is the combo sandwich, and that's $4. Soooo yeah, a common theme I'm noticing is how most of my 5 star review are cheap, good eats. Gotta love that!

- Bread: So the only complaint I have is the bread. I'm used to viet sandwiches on crusty, soft French bread. As mentioned in the reviews, this type of bread is particularly dense and heavy, which does lend to a drier sandwich overall. The one upside is that it prevents sogginess or chewiness if you're saving the meal for later. The first time I had the roast pork sandwich, I bought it at lunch and ate it for dinner hours later. It was still incredibly delicious after being out all day, and I would have still given it 5 stars then. 

They have limited hours so keep note of that. Their cold desserts are also really cheap and a refreshing way to end the meal. Pretty much, this place is too great.
author: Shira C.

description:
Do you know what "do chua" translates to?

Sour stuff.  sour thing.  a substance of sour taste.  that sour shit.

Dont forget to get extra "do chua" !

It's the orange carrot and white daikon that comes standard in every sandwich, but you'll want more.  you NEED more.  load it up.

you can ask for a dollar's worth and they'll give you a good amount in a ziplock bag, or you can try making your own pickled orange and whites (but beware, your house will smell like funky death); it's so friggin tasty and you can jar it up for future use.

top it off with sriracha and pair it with a nice cold 333 or tiger beer (heineken too if thats all you can find) and you've got yourself an authentic Vietnamese streetfood meal.  well, i dunno if that was what the locals did, but thats what i ate every morning at the asscrack of dawn when I visited Saigon....sandwich and a beer for $1.50!

Roast pork is good, but undisputedly better with pate. Get the chicken with pate for $3.50, i think thats the best here.  I dont think they make Thit Nguoi here (which is the standard Vietnamese sanwdich).

anywho, cash only if you're heading over to Saigon Sandwich...how much more authentic does it get? you know a vietnamese sandwich joint sucks when it takes credit!
Saigon Sandwich is awesome, $3 sandwiches = everybody wins.  For sure, SF's best vietnamese sandwich shop

walking here is a trip though.  if you're coming from turk street, you're sure to run into crackwhores and dealers.  i saw an asian woman slip a 20 to a dude in a jersey for a dimebag of rocks by a parking meter about 30 feet away.  we came here after a wedding all dressed out and suitted up and all sorts vendors wanted to sell us all sorts of illegal goodies.  you know how tenderloin rolls
author: Christopher N.

description:
Some body said I could go there for a good sando but I forgot who said that..  First off its real cheap and thats good for a bro on a budget.  But there real small to so thats less good and you could eat 4 of these things at once and only feel a little full..  Maybe its cause I'm kind of a big dude so when I came in here they started talking loud and looked scared and looking over at me and I don't know what they said but its got to be about the paint stains on my pants..  Dress for WORK and not sando ladies OK???  

Got to say I like the colors inside and the SPICE is good to.  Cilantro in a sando???  haha OK whatever but it tasted fresher like that.  Took the pork and went back for chicken and then pork again..  YUM !! Could eat these for lunch all day !! 

Bread was crunchy on the outside and soft in like you could expect. The pastey junk inside was OK but kind of weird..  Wanted to like it more but we could agree to disagree about that.. 

Semper Fi !!
author: Xavior G.

description:
This sandwich place is right in front of a bus stop and it's still hidden a little :)

Great Bahn Mi, simple menu, inexpensive, and great tasting. You can order over the phone and it'll be ready/waiting once you arrive.

My favorite is the combination (bbq pork is amazing as well, but not my favorite). It's a solid Bahn Mi. 
* Bread was crunchy, but not too much.
*The portion was a good size, but not overwhelming. 
*The meats/veggies were a perfect combination.

Do not bother spending $7-9 for food truck Bahn Mi... for $3.50 you can get one of these bad boys and be quite the happy camper :)
author: Nick E.

description:
I fell in love with Banh Mi sandwiches in New York.  I'm still looking for a place to rival what I ate there.  And this place was good, but still not good enough.  The bread is warm, the food is fresh, and the vegetables are pickled.  

A word to the wise, really think about the jalapenos.  If you like really spicy, go for it.  But if not, you may want to ask for a sandwich without them.  

Be careful about the neighborhood, its a bit sketchy...
author: Denis S.

description:
Good stuff....super cheap.

I like to get a sandwich with just the veggies and peppers.
All kinds of Vietnamese treats in here, always something new to try if you feel adventurous.

This place is generally pretty busy...sometimes lines out the door.

Today I got two sandwiches for 6$....

The rolls are soooo good.
author: Ralphy J.

description: Simple, cheap, and satisfying. Baguette + meat + pickled carrots and cabbage + cilantro + jalapeno = delicious. Sure, there's only one table. But banh mi are made for eating on the go.
author: L. C.

description:
Oh, Saigon Sandwich, thank you for always being there for me.

I love Vietnamese sandwiches and this place is no exception. When I work in the TL and forget my lunch I can always count on a yummy, filling and inexpensive meal from Saigon.My personal favorite is the Pork sandwich, of course. For about 3 dollars you get a great sandwich and they have a lot of other yummy treats to offer, such as coconut and sticky rice. This place is tiny and usually packed but the women working rock those sandwiches out like it's nothing. If you do have to wait it's not for long and it's definitely worth it.

Not only do I love the sandwiches but I also love the entertainment that comes along with the location. If I'm lucky enough to grab a seat at the three person counter facing the window I love to sit and watch all the characters make their way around Turk and Eddy while I eat. 

Saigon Sandwiches does it for me.
author: Denise S.

description: One of the only few authentic banh mi houses left. Most places esp. in socal aren't even making the meats and sauce in house anymore. Enjoy an authentic banh mi here for not $9 and get extra pate.
author: Theresa N.

description:
This place is more like a convenient store rather than a sandwich shop, but the 2 Vietnamese ladies there get it done, managing the phone orders, in-house orders, and the crowd. When we got there, the line was out the door. They take orders about 10 at a time and then start making sandwiches. Then they hand them out and take the next orders.

The combination did not live up to the hype. The meat was warm and soaked into the bun a bit. It was not as big of a sandwich that you would get at say...Lee's, but the mom and pop factor is there and for $3, you can't complain.
author: Steve V.

description:
This is a great place to grab a sandwich and a coconut drink.  Lots of little things in the fridge and I try to try something new every time I go in.  The ladies who run the joint are great, they remember what you want and make it perfect every time.  Quick quick quick, clean and so tasty I love this place so much.  

Go and get a sandwich there, bring cash and be hungry.  You will love it!
author: BellaLissa B.

description:
This is my all-time favorite vietnamese sandwich place!

It has to be the sauce they use for their sandwich and how they prepare everything. I love it with the extra jalapeños. San Francisco has a lot of places with vietnamese sandwiches, but this place is one of the best out there.

Combination Pork is my favorite, and this place makes it great. There is usually a line during lunch time, but its worth the wait. When I used to work in the Civic Center/TL area, I would always make an special trip to Saigon Sandwich to get my viet sandwich fix. I could eat like 2 of these for lunch, or even repeat for lunch and dinner.
author: Jason H.

description:
I usually don't care for banh mi that much and when my sister told me that this place had like the best banh mi ever...I was a bit skeptical since I wasn't really sure how good banh mi can actually be, but I was I proven wrong...

My sister and I did like a 2 mile walk to get their sandwiches here. Its a small little place in Little Saigon. There was a good amount of people there when we got there, but they are pretty fast so we didn't wait too long.

We got the combination pork with pate and cha with pate. They toast the bread here too. I couldn't wait to try it after having to walk another mile back to our hotel...First bite..It was amazing!!!! it looked really messy but it was soo soo good! The bread was still warm and it was nice and crispy. The combination pork was different than any other that i have tasted. I couldn't stop eating it. Seriously, their pate is like crack. 

If you love Banh mi you HAVE TO GO HERE!!!! I can't even fully describe to you how good this was. One of the best things I have ever eaten! Now every banh mi that I eat is just not the same. I would be a regular here if I lived closeby!
author: Phuong K.

description:
It's all been said... but I must reiterate:

- The chicken banh mi is the best.
- Extra jalapeno requests accommodated without any fuss.
- Prices are awesome.

Not really sure what more a sandwich shop could possibly do to be (even more) kick-ass.
author: Vandana N.

description:
This place is highly overrated! I was visiting SF with a friend and tried this place based on the reviews from fellow yelpers. We were not impressed, in fact...utterly disappointed. 

I'm all about hole in the wall places but location only was really sketchy and the women making the sandwiches weren't wearing gloves and had flies circling (not sanitary!). IMO this place was a total MISS. 

We ordered the roasted chicken bánh mì and it literally had small and medium sized bones in it! Really disgusting. So unless that's what you're into.. I don't get how anyone could give this place a 5 star, let alone 2 star rating.. Wouldn't even consider giving it a second chance.
author: Nora N.

description:
My family and I have been coming here for years, up until I found a roach in my sandwich! I'm really bummed because their sandwiches were like NO OTHER :) (well, NOW I guess 'no other' since there was a roach in it =\ ) It kind of makes me think how many roaches I probably ate without knowing =X

Oh well. Guess I'll be on a hunt to find a good vietnamese sandwich place.
author: Stef C.

description:
Nomnomnom. Saigon Sandwich lives up to all the hype you've heard and then goes beyond it. Just come out around noon on a business day and you'll see the long line creeping out past the door.

At $3.50 a piece, a sandwich is a true bargain. Crispy French roll, delicious sauce, and a variety of meat to choose from, I can't get enough. Personally, my favorite is the Pate, but the roast pork is definitely the classic that most people get.

Recently, our student org placed a big order for sandwiches for our general body meeting. The transaction went smoothly, they got the order right, and it was ready for pick-up on time. Thanks Saigon Sandwiches!

I don't know how SS does it or what they put in their sandwiches (my guess is crack from the nearby drug dealers), but the quality of the sandwich simply transcends any banh mi I've ever tasted, even the ones from Orange County. Awesome.
author: Tom P.

description:
Dang over 1,800 reviews with 4 1/2 stars and for good reason. This small little shop sells some BOMB Vietnamese sandwich. The line is always going to be long and out the door but it's totally worth it. $3.50 for a big sandwich with lots of meat! Chicken, roasted pork, fanci pork.

So good I may have to come here every day.
author: Eugene H.

description:
Well, I didn't like it. I don't like the idea of giving bad review, but I want to be honest and this is what Yelp about. I am going to places because of Yelp.

The meat wasn't of good quality. The bread was not fresh. The vegi without any taste.

The line was very long and that's why I am planing to give this place a second chance.

If it will be good I will add another review.
author: Ido T.

description: i get it. everyone likes this place because what comes inside the sandwich is really good. still, the bread is NOT my thing. i've given it two chances. it's not terrible but i just want a traditional banh mi with REALLY good french baguette style buttery bread. this isn't it. not nostalgic at all, but hey, i guess it's not meant to be. i'd rather have the baguette sandwich from sing sing on hyde.
author: Thao T.

description: Tofu.all.the.way! Price and flavors will keep me going back for more!
author: Josie C.

description:
So yeah, Saigon Sandwiches is located in the Tenderloin, and yeah, sometimes you'll see a line out the door, but the ladies working behind the counter have perfected the art of "batch making" the sandwiches, so you are usually out the door in about 10 minutes.  Sometimes I wonder how they make a profit when the price is $3 a sandwich.

It's hard to describe the deliciousness of the sandwich in words, but it's just the perfect ratio of meat, veggies, and bread.  The jalapenos definitely have some kick in them, so I take those out.  Anyway, this has to be the best place to get vietnamese-style sandwiches in the city, maybe even the best value lunch in the city, period.  I'm salivating right now just thinking about it, haha.  So simple, yet so well done.
author: Marlon E.

description:
So I think this is it:  the Platonic ideal of banh mi.

I've spent maybe ten full days in SF over the last year but somehow eaten six sandwiches from here in my visits. It's just that good, and by it, I mean like every sandwich. Any of the various pork ones, certainly, but the tofu vegetarian one also made my friend exclaim "I didn't know tofu could taste and feel like that." It's just damn delicious.

Spend less than $10 for a big beautiful sandwich, a drink, and whatever fluorescent tapioca item strikes your fancy. 

t's just a storefront and the line always seems to go out the door. But it's a quick wait and so worth it.
author: Enrico E.

description: The best tofu Vietnamese sandwich ever. So much flavor packed in such a small, delicious sandwich. Best flavor in the tofu- felt more like eating seitan. They also make an amazing dessert made out of peanuts- to die for. It's worth going to this little whole in the wall.
author: Carolina S.

description:
Awesome place for some great cheap eats. The line does get a bit long, but we were lucky and got there before the line got crazy. 

The sandwiches are a little over $3. I've tried the roast pork & the chicken, and they were both really tasty, although I think I enjoyed the pork a little more. The meat is packed with flavor, and the bread is nice and crispy, even whilst soaking up the flavor from the pate, the meat, and the pickled veggies. 

Philz Coffee is only a couple blocks away! So since there's no real seating area at this spot, we headed over there to grab a cup of coffee to pair with our sandwiches.
author: Euna K.

description:
My 100th review goes out to Saigon Sandwich, the best Banh Mi joint in the TL! Vietnamese sandwiches always compliment my Saturday/Sunday afternoons. Finding a good Vietnamese sandwich place in the city has been a little challenging (thank you, Little Vietnam) but I'm starting to have hope after trying out Saigon. 

Saigon Sandwich is literally a hole in the wall on Larkin Street. There are only three women working here, and the kitchen takes up most of the shop. When I came in, there was a line and a constant flow of satisfied customers going in and out of the shop. I ordered a chicken and tofu sandwich. I love the bread! It's not flaky and crunchy like most baguettes, but it's got the texture of ciatbatta bread. They slap a lot of pate for flavoring, which I can go without. However, it does add a more distinct taste compared to other sandwiches that I've tried. There's something about Saigon sandwiches that makes it really unique from the other places.

Saigon isn't the CLEANEST Banh Mi shop, but then again what is?! I love this place, and I'll be back for more.
author: Linda T.

description: I don't know how this place got such a good rating... Maybe it was the rating itself that made me expect way too much out of this place but was then disappointed. I'm Viet from southern california (Bolsa, Westminster is a hometown of mine) and this place did not make the cut. I ordered the chicken sandwich. The sandwich fillings were not distributed properly so one bite I had way too much pate then another bite I had 80% carrots. The meat was too salty and the sandwich overall was just not anything worth coming back for. Oh and I read that someone earlier had posted something about the shop being very unsanitary - I was looking at one of their homemade multicolored sweet rice on the counter and noticed a thick black hair strand. (Thought it was funny)
author: Lydia L.

description:
Vietnamese sandwich for under $3 here. 

I got a bbq beef sandwich here at 9:45am and when the lady handed it to me, it was still warm. First sandwich was gone in less than 5 minutes since I was starving. The lemonade I also bought just made it that much more refreshing. 

The meat wasn't tough, the veggies were really fresh and you can't just get ONE sandwich. You're an idiot if you only purchase one. Eat one now and save the other for later on in the day. 

Banana sticky rice, and Viet jelly drinks here are also good!

Keep in mind, CASH ONLY.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Everybody who knows me knows that I'm an avid pork hater. I simply cannot stand the flavor, smell, and texture of dead pig carcasses. Nonetheless, I ordered a roast pork sandwich because of all the rave on yelp.

Well, Saigon Sandwich definitely succeeded in enhancing the pork aroma. That's a major accomplishment for a banh mi shop. Most vietnamese sandwich establishments that I go to serve dry, bland meat on soft, stale baguettes. 

The breakdown:

Roast Pork Banh Mi

Meat- Very PORKY taste (not pleasing to my palate but I'm sure this porkiness would appeal to others). Good cuts of meat, I'm thinking pork shoulder since the protein strands were quite long. Not overly fatty like most places. Pretty lean stuff.

Sauce- Got the sando with no mayo, but the brown sauce was deeelish!  A bit too sweet though. I'm guessing they used a little fish sauce, some pork drippings, soy sauce, sugar, and maybe a tad of five spice or a dash of anise/cloves. Not too sure, but it was really savory. The taste lingered on my tongue for hours on.

Vegs- Meh. Not spectacular. I wish the pickled carrots and radishes were cut thicker. They were kinda soggy and bland, not doing much for the banh mi in terms of texture nor flavor. Thicker cuts would pack in a better crunch. Lots of cilantro, though. Jalepenos were legit. Good amount of heat that nicely contrasts with the sweet flavor of the sauce.

Baguette- For me, the bread is what makes or breaks a sandwich. Saigon Sandwich's? Super crisp and crunchy outer crust and a soft, dense, and chewy crumb!

I don't know if this was necessarily the "best banh mi in the world," but it was definitely one the better ones I've had.
author: Colleen W.

description:
I love this place!  The line is always out the door for good reason.

The meatball sandwich (toasted french bread, mayonnaise, juicy ground pork, carrots, onions*, cilantro, and jalapenos**) is absolutely amazing!  Price: $3.25.  Yes!  Cheaper than doing your own laundry.

* Mints might be necessary after consumption.
**Beware of the jalapenos!  Apparently they are extra spicy this time of year.  You have been warned!
author: Fei L.

description:
Great stuff.  By far the best version of the tofu vietnamese sandwich ive had.  Great sauce, plenty of vegies and just perfectly toasted.  I usually get a pork or chicken bun to go with it.  I actually prefer theirs to the Chinese dim sum ones.
Best to go at a little bit of an off time to avoid the lunchtime line, but the 2 women whip out sandwiches at an amazing pace.  Likely the best thing you'll get in sf for $3.50.
author: Ric S.

description:
Cheap and scrumptious bahn mi?! Where?? Saigon Sandwiches of course!! The only location I know of that has understood the epitome of what bahn mi should taste like. Bravo! And for prices ranging from $3-$3.50 a piece, you can rest assured it won't break the bank. Another plus!

As you can see from the menu, options are fairly limited but you can't go wrong with their roast chicken or pork sandwiches. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hqQoVK0vadOX7_4gN1sh3g?select=YkxnfFL5BnYHX1NfX2a1KQ) I am dying to try the ones with pate though. Mmm...I'm salivating just at the thought of consuming another Saigon creation! They also sell a bunch of random Asian snacks and Vietnamese desserts.

I tried the roast chicken and pork sandwiches...both were mouth-watering and simply tasted amazing! The chicken was tender and  marinated with a sweet, BBQ-type sauce it seemed...yum! The pork was a bit on the dry side for me and wasn't as flavorful, but still really good. The bread was toasted but soft on the inside...just the way I like it.  It was also dressed with mayo, lots of pickled carrots and cilantro, cucumber, and onion. Perfection! I opted to leave out the jalapenos this time though. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hqQoVK0vadOX7_4gN1sh3g?select=tARzS27Dj4XLI2LWiM7f9A)

The ladies that work here are sandwich-making machines! I enjoyed watching them taking orders, collecting money, and doing what they do best all at the same time. Apparently, there's always a line around lunch time but they take phone orders and it was pretty empty on a Saturday afternoon. Bring cash!
author: Karen Y.

description:
God, that's good sh*t.

You can't help but wonder just WHAT kind of lovely sauce they put on their sandwiches because it is A-MAZ-ING. The right prices for the right flavors and textures... you can't go wrong here. Even at almost 2pm there will be lines and waiting, but all well worth the anticipation! Please try one. My mouth starts watering every time I tell someone about this place. For the love of God, try one already!
author: Joanne Y.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwich in SF. The bun is warmed and crunchy,  amble amount of meats. Great prices. Love this hole in the wall. Excellent banh me
author: Khai B.

description:
Let's see, what can I really add to the already full list of reviews of Saigon Sandwich...

Well, after being bullied by Lolia S. and Matt G. about not experiencing Saigon Sandwiches yet (this was back in early March), I....somehow didn't give into their comments until yesterday. Yes, I apologize, I've been slow in getting around to Saigon Sandwiches. I rarely venture around that part of town, but on Saturday night, perhaps luckily, I happened to stay over at a friend's place which happens by chance to be right around the corner from Saigon Sandwiches.

So, after getting up around 11:30am and sauntering out trying to find food in the semi-gritty neighborhood, I realized I was very close to the sandwich shop. I made it a point to go around the block and was greeted with a relatively short line. It seemed, at noon on a Sunday, there are quite a few Vietnamese who hit up Saigon Sandwiches. The ladies behind the counter were chattering with all the customers in front of me, and none of the words they spoke were familiar to me (side note: I'm convinced that most Vietnamese places in San Francisco are in fact owned by Chinese-Vietnamese, since I recognize the Cantonese they speak). So, already, the hype of the place was living up to itself with the fact that even Vietnamese themselves love Saigon Sandwiches.

The decor is plain, very plain: cramped with only two window seats (and nobody really seemed to actually eat in; they just sat down briefly to wait on their orders). The displays in front of the buns, Vietnamese desserts, snacks, etc. was a chaotic bliss to see; disorganized, but somehow customers are able to dig through and find what they want. There's a huge display of drinks to the right of the store, next to the counter: lots of Asian drinks and cold desserts inside.

The line at first seemed to move slowly, but after the ladies finished with a 3-sandwich order, one of them asked for the rest of our orders in line. With the amount of sandwich orders taken, I was only waiting for my sandwich for about 5 minutes at most. This lapse of time allowed for me to eye all the delicacies in front (what a way to make people buy impulsively!). 

The selection of sandwiches was somewhat predictable (I mean, what I've seen at other banh mi shops): prices were quite a steal though. For $3, choose from the one-topping sandwiches; the most expensive (if you can even use that word here) sandwich was one of the combos (I think there was a combo), which still only topped out at around $3.50 or maybe $4. Still, it's very rare to find decent meals under $5 these days. I'm not sure of the other sides/desserts on display, but I decided to pick up a Banh Bot Ban (mung bean tapioca plate), which cost $1.50. For the sandwich, I went with Fancy Pork.

The ladies are efficient in what they do, I can tell you that. After I got my sandwich and paid, I walked out and decided to enjoy the sandwich over by the Civic Center. The pork was juicy and flavorful; I think I only found one jalapeno in my sandwich though, which was a little disappointing. However, no other real complaints on the sandwich--definitely a good deal. The dessert was not overly sweet and messy; use the coconut milk (comes in a small container) as a drizzly topping over the tapioca balls.

If I lived or worked around the area, I would go to Saigon Sandwiches much more. However, since I don't...well, it was nice to try it out anyway. My loyalties (in terms of banh mi) will lie with Cafe Dolci (at Grant and Market) for the time being, though.
author: Helene K.

description:
Got a roasted pork sandwich for $3.25.

Took 4 bites.  Found a long black hair inside!

Prior to hair discovery, I was starving so I kept eating it even though the quality of pork grossed me out.  The bread was fresh and soft, but the pork made me want to puke - I think they over-season the pork to cover up the poor quality of meat.  Never going back or recommending this place to others.  

so if meat quality doesnt matter to you, then maybe you will like this sandwich.  if it does, try dinosaurs in the mission/castro - same size, maybe a $1 more, but roasted pork quality is actually good!
author: Ali G.

description: For the life of me I don't understand why this place is so highly rated. The food was disgusting. My boyfriend and I were starving but we couldn't bring ourselves to get through half the sandwich. He got the pork and I got the chicken. The meat was slimy and the bread was too hard. The only good thing about the experience was that we only paid $7.50 for both sandwiches. I guess we got what we paid for. Both sandwiches went into the trash and we were off to our next restaurant. OVERRATED by a landslide.
author: Luba A.

description:
There's only one lady who runs this joint, and she's in her 50's...at least that was the case when I was there on a sunday late afternoon.  Very homey, cramped, and busy at 5p.  She's got a great attitude and it seemed like she gets plenty of business from her regulars who shout out their orders with a wave.  It's a bit irritating at first because you're wondering if she's got the previous orders memorized since she doesn't take notes...but you soon realize she's a pro.

So since she obviously had her system down, I was very excited to taste the food, so on to the food: We had the grilled chicken and grilled pork sandwiches with two mr. coffees and a bag of korean onion chips...all in all very yum.  The sandwiches are a bit smaller than where most places sell it, and I've had other places put picked veggies and pate in my grilled meat sammies so I was expecting it here :(  but other than that the flavors were all there, very intense so i only ate half of one.  The bread was very crispy and tore up the roof of my mouth and it wasn't too yeasty..so it was a toss up for me.  The flavor of the meat overwhelmed the taste of the bread so, eh.

I'll probably be back when I'm in the area & craving a banh mi or wanting some cheap asian snacks or drinks.  I'm not sure if I'd go out of my way just yet...maybe I'll try her other sammies but until then, we shall see.  My rating would really be a 3.5
author: Blia L.

description: took my friend here this weekend since it was up the block from the new boba tea place - Boba Delight which is delish btw. They had a short line but it moved quickly. This place has legit Bahn Mih and sell about 5 or 6 different kinds from chiken to pork to combo. They are quick and you can personalize a little. I think its much fresher than other places and tastier too.
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Best vietnamese sandwich in SF hands down! Cheap and delicious! They have pate and fresh veggies in each sandwich on request. 

Only downer is that it's in the tenderloin. But I've never had a problem!
author: Junel S.

description: ok, The tofu version is even better. I could live on these things!!!
author: Thömas F.

description: Greatest bahn mi sandwich I have ever had. I tried the pork sandwich and the juices and the sauce along with cilantro, carrots made it's so much flavor full. No wonder they have such great reviews. If I am ever in the tenderloin area again, there is no other place I can go to get a sandwich than here.
author: Varun V.

description:
It's been a long time...

And you're still rocking it!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I ventured over to this tiny place today because I read such amazing reviews, and let's face it, I am a sucker for great food.

I ordered the tofu, and I can honestly say, it was one of the best banh mi sandwiches I have ever had in my LIFE. The bread was so fresh and crispy, the tofu was thin and flavorful, and there was an abundance of traditional veggies, cilantro and some jalapeños. It went above and beyond my expectations!

The store itself was very small, basically just walk in and get your ($3.75!) sandwich, which is made by two older Viet women. They were so nice. The only drawback is that the area is not the nicest or seemingly most safe. I'll be going back next time I'm in town!
author: Kali N.

description:
I almost didn't go after reading Herbert L's review and the reason he assigned only a 1-star rating:  cleanliness; or lack thereof.

I really rather liked the pork sandwich, would recommend this sandwich and will return.

As for Herbert L's comment about the proprietress making sandwiches with the same gloved hand with which she made change, I do believe the proprietress read Herbert's review.  

There were at least 8 people in front of me and I studiously watched every move the owner made.  If she would have given the slightest hint of wanting to touch money, her nose, arse or anything other than food with that gloved hand, I would be gone baby gone. 

Instead, the owner actually removed the glove when making change and then slipped on a brand-spanking new glove to resume sandwich-making chores.

Thank you Herbert L for putting the owner straight and thank you Saigon Sandwich for a really rather lovely pork sandwich.
author: Jay D.

description: I came here yesterday (6/27/15) for the first time because a friend told me about it. When I went in.. it was super smaller than I thought it was.. I waited about 5 minutes for my order considering there was so many people! It wasn't that bad.. but I docked one star off because I questioned the cleanliness and how sanitary it was.. I watched the ladies making the sandwiches and the lady taking and writing down orders.. there wasn't much hand washing seen after touching the money and then the bread.. one of the other ladies that was assembling the sandwiches had on gloves but she turned around and touch the paper the other lady took the orders on with the gloves on.. but I enjoyed the sandwich very much! I got the combo.. the pate was delish! I wish the carrots were more pickled though! But other than that I'd come back with my friend!
author: Joe C.

description:
True, it can be a bit sketch in the middle of the tenderloin, but it's worth it!!

Super cheat, delicious vietnamese sandwich! 

I always manage to go when there's no one there. 

Huge variety of sandwiches and vietnamese pastries.
author: Erica L.

description:
I love this place! 

Why? 

Because the sandwiches are delish,  it's a rare find near my school, close, convenient, and cheap. I went in today to find they raised the price from $3 to a whopping $3.25, but that doesn't prevent me from fulfilling my sandwich craving! I usually get the roast pork sandwich but have recently been on a chicken fix. If you go during the lunch hour, be prepared to wait a while. Their toaster oven looks very  vintage and you might question if it still works, but when you bite into the crunchy outside and soft inside you call bread, you will know that bad boy does wonders.
author: Heidi G.

description: Not huge fan. But it's good place to have quick bite since it near my school. Cheap and fresh! What's more..
author: Momo G.

description:
OH MY FUCKING GOD!!!  i love this place.  my aunt use to live right next to it in the apartment building and i would love to buy one before or after i get there and also bring one home.

Now that my aunt dont live there no more i come by whenever im around TL because those sandwiches really bring back the old memeries.  i remember when i use to cost 2.00 for a combination...2!!! thats hella dam good,  now its 3.75 and i still buy 3 everytime i go there.

The best Vietnamese sandwiches in San Francisco =]
author: Steven K.

description: I just experienced a stimulation where a young food preparer was eating by putting chips in her mouth with NO GLOVES on the proceeding to make my sandwich and then continue eating. I confronted her and all she did was shrug "as if" oh well. According to food and safety workers must always maintain good hygiene and cleanliness when handling food products for the public. HACCP is a preventative measure to identify potential hazards associated with food production and preparation, and to develop mechanisms to eliminate or control these hazards. Some dude tries to interfere by telling me "it's a private business, they can do whatever they want." Really, just amazing what people don't know.
author: K S.

description: SF's finest sprinkled crack into these sandwiches. It is really that good. Roast pork FTW at $3.75 a pop. That sauce!
author: Jeanne C.

description: I remember I used to come here EVERY SINGLE day after high school NO JOKE. Growing up the only Vietnamese sandwiches I ever tried was from Little Paris in Chinatown and I thought those were good until I tried this place. What I love is that they stuff it like crazy and aren't stingy about it. I've tried every single sandwich and my favorite is the combination. The mayo and the pate makes all the difference in the world. I came back here recently and the prices have gone up!!! It's been years so I shouldn't be surprised. Still a busy joint. Still long lines at time. Still a tiny tiny shop. There's like only one seating for two people at the most. Cash only. Hard to find parking. Hobos everywhere. Don't forget to pay the meter if you park on the streets on a weekday before 6pm. I brought my hubby here and he said the bread was too crispy and likes Lee Sandwiches better lol. We are both bias cuz he grew up eating that and I grew up eating this. I told him hey there's a Lee Sandwiches down the street. Overall, I love this place. The sandwiches have a unique taste to it that you can't find elsewhere. I also found a spot in San Jose that I absolutely love...so they are pretty much tided for #1 in my heart. Take the 19 Polk or 31 Balboa bus here. Or take the 47/49 Van Ness bus and walk. Or take the 38 Geary and walk. Many ways to get here by foot. Parking will be hard. Love their sandwiches, it's a must!!!
author: Jan E.

description: My favorite banh mi place. I live on the opposite end of sf and I will take the bus to the TL just for this sandwich. Ask for no mayo though cuz it'll get soggy if you don't eat it right away. Can't go wrong with any of their selections
author: Evan L.

description:
By far the best banh mi in San Francisco.  Their pate is top notch and is a great addition to any sandwich.  Yes, you can request extra pate.  Baguettes are delivered/baked fresh daily and are best consumed same-day.  This is not the sandwich you save for the lunch tomorrow (though you'll frequently be tempted to do so...)

Beware of local crack dealers.  They mean well, but it just doesn't mesh well with the sandwiches.

See http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/hqQoVK0vadOX7_4gN1sh3g?select=v7nU6KTkvCKeDHujIKYM_w for the latest menu prices!  Sandwiches start at $3.25 (old price was $3) and is still an incredible value.
author: Andrew C.

description: good prices cheap by san francisico stanards but hey its the tenderloin a hidden gem
author: Leigh G.

description: Not a big fan of their giant greasy sandwiches. I usually get my banh mi's in Little Saigon in Orange County so I guess I'm used to something completely different. I came here on a rainy day and it was slightly crowded. I got a pork sandwich and my friend got a steamed pork. We sat down in the only two chairs available facing the street to feast. My sandwich ended up being soggy and overly stuffed with salty pork and my friend's was completely flavorless. I was severely disappointed and will never come back again. I give the food 2 stars and the wonderful ladies behind the counter an extra star.
author: Lisa N.

description: I love the hint of sweetness on my tofu sandwich.  Is the secret ingredient honey?  The serving of the sandwich is a generous portion for an individual.  If your not feeling too hungry it can and should be shared with a friend.  We found parking on a Monday morning right out front and the ladies were not busy at all.  They were even kind enough to allow us to use their bathroom.  The prices of $3.75 is definitely a steal compared to what i'm used to on the east coast.  I definitely recommend their tofu sandwich.
author: Joanne T.

description:
Pulled Pork + Cilantro + Hot Peppers + Special Sauce = Fantastic.

Cheap ($4), Bountiful portions, Tasty! .. Bring Cash.
author: Helen D.

description: This place was making banh-mi's long before it was trendy.  Now that I don't live in the city anymore, when I'm in town for something I make a point to get here and pick up 5+ sandos.  Best banh-mi I've ever had.  Authentic, non-gentrified hole in the wall.  Perfect.
author: Adam J.

description:
I went today and the sign said "Open 4/2/2011." It was April 2nd but the store was still closed.

I was sad. And hungry.

I will come back tomorrow and try again.

Why? Because this is the best banh mi in the world. And if you disagree, I'll fight you for it.

I have a special sandwich that I order, and the ladies are so sweet - I step up to the counter and before I can say anything, they ask "How many?" I get a roast pork/roast chicken/pate combo off the menu, extra veggies and peppers, cut in half. Mmm. Perfection.

For variety's sake, I also get the meatball sandwich or the tofu sandwich sometimes. They are also amazing.

Actually, everything here is amazing.

Please be open tomorrow. T.T
author: Mary M.

description:
It upsets me how much I love this place and how far away it is from me.

This is how good it is - I drove from Palo Alto to get a xiu mai banh mi. There's nothing more to be said - GO!
author: Meg H.

description: So so so worth it! Cheap, delicious, fast, convenient - couldn't get any better than that. My friends and I got the roast pork sandwich and we were all really pleased with it. They were really generous with the filling both for the meat, vegetables and garnishing. This $3.75 sandwich is sure to leave anyone (decently) full and satisfied.
author: Olivia P.

description: Who doesn't love cheap, great tastings sandwiches?  I wish I was called to jury duty more often as this was the first time I was able to try the Vietnamese roasted pork sandwich at Saigon Sandwich.  I was bummed I got dismissed after one day though as I could have gone back multiple times for their $3.50 sandwich.  Great find and has the perfect taste of sweet and spice.  A must try.
author: Blake B.

description: The sandwich shop is not is a particular safe area, but its worth the trip. Get the roast pork sandwich, its only $4.0, full of flavor, and big size of sandwich. You'll just want to engorged it until its all gone. Very, very, very delicious!
author: Daisy J.

description: Very cheap, plus I loved my sandwich - the ingredient proportions were perfect. The lady making the sandwiches was also quite nice, and service was fast. There was a short line even though it was late in the afternoon, but I think it was worth the wait. Definitely not the best neighborhood, though, so bring a friend!
author: Delia Z.

description: Excellent prices even for the Tenderloin. There's always a line no matter the time of day. Sandwiches here are saltier than some of the ones I'm normally used to, but they're still pretty good. There was a long hair strand in one of the sandwiches, but that problem is common in the food industry.
author: John D.

description:
Oh, the Tenderloin.  My best friend in middle school lived here, and as 12 year old girls we walked around the Tenderloin as if it was nothing, day or night.  7-8 years later looking back, I'd be scared shitless to do it all over again!  Such dumb kids we were..

Boyfriend and I  found metered parking, enjoyed the weird smell of the Tenderloin, and walked past a pack of drunken homeless at 4pm, and safely got into Saigon Sandwiches without a disturbance.  This place is tiny and is half sandwich store, half storage room.  Aside from sandwiches, they also sell miscellaneous Asian snacks and drinks.

I ordered the special combination sandwich, and I really didn't think it could be that great.  Surprise, it was awesome.  It was filled with pate, and other spreads that I can't distinguish that make the sandwich awesome.  I should open it up next time before I inhale it.  I never ever finish Vietnamese sandwiches, but I easily finished this one.  It also helps that it was a bit smaller.

Yummmm.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I'm rather embarrassed for those who gave this joint such a rave review -- and even more embarrassed for the New York Times writer who featured this place as one of the best banh mi places in the San Francisco Bay area. Frankly, it doesn't even merit a mediocre rating. Here's why.

First, the bread. It was hard -- and not fresh.

Second, the meat. I ordered the pork and my companions ordered the chicken and the meatball. The pork was so dry and flavorless, I wondered if it was even pork. The meatball was a pink disgusting mess. The chicken was also dry. Perhaps the oh-so-popular tofu might have been better, but that would mean I would have to actually give my $3 bucks over to them again.

Third, the veggie fillings. It was all carrots and almost nothing else. Minimal cilantro (I happen to love cilantro), minimal jalapenos (I also like a lot), no cucumber (typical of banh mi), no pickled radish...

Fourth, they didn't even give me pate. It isn't a banh mi without pate. 

Please, save your $3. This place is a joke. If you want real banh mi, mosey on down to San Jose. If you want OK banh mi, you're better served up the street at Lee's (and I give this alternative with a heavy heart).
author: Chanty Y.

description:
I really really love this place, so I'm really sad to report this, but they got a bunch of violations from the health department in late Feb of this year, so that may have been why they had to close. 

http://bit.ly/eJfjVZ

I really hope they reopen! Their pork sandwiches were amazing!
author: Michelle B.

description: Only Vietnamese sandwich place I go to.. Growing up in the tenderloin my dad always brought these home.. Now living in the east bay I only enjoy these awesome sandwiches every now and then. Always great sandwiches they never fail.. Only thing now is now people know about this spot
author: Joe C.

description: I fell in love with their tofu sandwich.  They've marinated the tofu, making it very juicy.  The combination with the chili and all the ingredients just makes my taste buds happy.  They have all the different Vietnamese desserts in their refrig.  Just ended up with the classic fresh soy drink and I'm in heaven.
author: Helen L.

description: All I have to say is the pork sandwich was Bomb! You must try this place but be careful of the area.. Not in the safest neighborhood!
author: Delilah L.

description:
My first 1 star review... I came with quite a bit of expectation but very disappointed. Never again.
I had quite a bit of experience with bank mi in SF and San Gabriel Valley in LA. The bread is ok but I surely had better, and I can make better ones myself. The problem is the meat, I had the steam pork + roast pork, there was an overwhelming fridge odor (I think it's from the steam pork) that I can still feel now after 3 hours and a mocha.
I had a much better one in "Fresh Brew Coffee" (as on yelp, but couldn't find the name in the store) on Bush by Taylor just a week ago for around the same price.
author: Roy C.

description: Sandwich was fine. The roast pork is tender and had good flavor. The bread is pretty dense. It's probably a 3 star sandwich but since it's so affordable I'll bump it up to 4.
author: J G.

description: So good and so cheap! The line wasn't long when we went but I'm sure on a weekday at lunch it's pretty crazy. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Maeling D.

description:
Best sandwich ever! Fancy Pork and hold the mayo!

NOTE: Call in for your order to avoid waiting.
author: Jason H.

description:
This sandwich shop definitely takes a different spin on the usual Banh Mi. The bread is different in that it's not the flaky French bread. They also load you up on the pate and it has a distinct sweet and meaty flavor to it. I ordered the combination pork sandwich but the pate made it taste like I was eating a teriyaki beef kind of sandwich -- very interesting. 

It's a very small place so don't expect seating. Also, I came at the end of the day and people were still coming in after me yet they didn't turn anyone away. Great business ethics :)
author: Sophia K.

description:
Thank you, Yelp! You led me to Saigon sandwich last November and it's been an obsession since. The bus ride to the Tenderloin is well worth it. We go as many times as we can fit into each trip. We returned again last month and ate a sandwich day after day. Grilled pork, chicken or pork meatball. I cannot decide which I like best because they are all delicous!

The only negative is that no banh mi near home compares.
author: Kellee K.

description:
Cheap, yummy and fast! Great if you want a quick bite that isn't as greasy as those fast food places. 
The place is pretty small and I never really ate my sandwich there; I usually take it to go.
author: Sandy T.

description: I love this spot.....just enough spice to make you wanting more...salivate....
author: Juliet W.

description:
Closed for all of March, 2011.

I guess for remodeling. 
But I get the feeling licensing/ Inspection 
had a word with them.
author: vin t.

description:
$3 for one of the most delicious sandwiches of your life. What's not to love?! The bread is crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and the meat is moist and tasty. My only complaint is that they put the entire stalk of cilantro in the sandwich, which is kind of hard to eat/bite off.  The roast pork and chicken sandwiches are both good, but the roast pork is much better.

Best bahn mi in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Sydney L.

description:
THEE best Vietnamese sandwiches in the world!!

And they crank it out so quickly too.

Their lines are always out the door...so be sure to call in your order.

Fancy Pork Sandwich w/ Pate
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/dU9wkzWHnpWpQLq7UpWgHQ/l

(Wednesday, November 12, 2008)
author: Kenny C.

description:
True to Yelp's word, there was a line spilling out the door and into the street... and true to Yelp's word, it was worth it.

Seriously, a hearty, pork-filled, heavily-lettuced, spicy-peppered, cilantro-stuffed saucy sandwich for $3?  This sandwich filled me up so nicely that I wasn't even hungry by dinnertime (unfortunately for me, since the restaurant I'd planned for dinner was even better).  

Usually I dislike sandwiches that have a lot of bread, but in this case the explosive flavor of the meat, sauce and vegetables stood up to it.  I'd eat this for lunch constantly if I lived in the area.

There was even a nice park a few blocks up to eat my sandwich in.  Yes, it was across from a strip club, but it was noon, so who cares?
author: Hannah E.

description:
I have this dream where Saigon Sandwich and Lee's Sandwiches would make love and bam! something magnificent would come out of their love making. Lee's would happily take in Saigon's filling between her bread. Oh the dream.....

Since I can't have a bit of both, I can definitely say that I prefer Saigon over Lee's, why?

-Their bread is kind of hard but the crunchy kind of hard (Lee's bread is better but it's not about the bread)
-The filling of all their sandwiches have a sweet tangy taste to it.
-Their Tofu is full of flavor (vs. Lee's which is plain)
-Their meatball is superb
-Their chicken makes you cluck
-Their pork makes you oink

Now if the above bullet points made sense to you, then you should definitely get you a Saigon sandwich because obviously you're hungry.
author: Eva L.

description:
Mmmm. Give me an amazing banh mi for $3. Get ready to stand in line though... You will have to take your order with a group of others and wait 10-15 minutes, but it's worth it.

Take the risk of walking through crackie central to get a sandwhich here. I promise you'll enjoy it ^_^
author: Catherine H.

description:
Wow, I didn't think a Vietnamese sandwich could be so much better than all the others I've had. Saigon Sandwich was so delicious and so cheap ($3.50)! Personally I preferred the chicken to the roast pork sandwich. The sweet mayo sauce is awesome, and I like the softer bread. 

if you like mochi and/or coconut, get the banana leaf wrapped dessert for $1.50. Perfect way to finish off an incredibly tasty, cheap, and satisfying meal (to go).
author: Amy X.

description:
I went to this place with a friend excited to try the Banh Mi, but we were disappointed.  We had the grilled pork and chicken sandwiches.  The sandwiches tasted really unbalanced.  The meat, mayo and hoisin (?) sauce really overwhelmed the rest of the sandwiches.  The carrots did not taste very pickled, and the cilantro and was falling out.  The bread, however was delicious.  

I personally prefer my meat well marinated and my veges well pickled, with a good balance between the two.  Although Saigon Sandwich is very inexpensive, I still prefer the lemongrass chicken and pork banh mi from Castro Tarts in the Castro.
author: Go S.

description:
Saigon Sandwich's tofu extra spicy bahn mi is quite possibly the BEST SANDWICH I HAVE EVER HAD IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. 

I have been compiling a list of reasons why I love San Francisco soooooo much and Saigon Sandwich's bahn mi went right to the top of my list.  Since trying Saigon Sandwich for the first time a few months ago, I have consumed approximately 30 tofu extra spicy bahn mi and 1 pate extra spicy bahn mi.

The sauce they use on the fried tofu is slightly sweet and savory/umami - totally unmatched anywhere.  I've been trying to figure out exactly what is in their sauce by studying every flavor.....so far I've gotten oyster sauce, nutmeg, maybe plum sauce, then my mouth has an outer head experience and all logic is lost.

I didn't fall as madly in love with their pate bahn mi (it didn't have their insanely delicious sauce on it from what I could tell, only mayo).  When I was there on Sunday 7/15 pate was still on their menu - not sure if they are still serving after the ban?  

I love that Saigon Sandwich is open early - it is easy to drop by and grab a tofu extra spicy bahn mi for lunch (and sometimes a second for dinner!).  YUMMMMMY!
author: Sarah T.

description:
Picked up 3 sandwiches on the way to the Giants game.

BEST. BANH. MI. EVER.

This place is straight to the point, no overwhelming menu like Lee's Sandwiches. Only a few options. Quick service (cash only). You're in, you're out. We opted for two pork and one chicken sandwiches. The chicken was decent, but the pork banh mi is where this place really shined. The pickled vegetables were spot on as well. The bread was not too crunchy (but definitely not soggy) where it rips up the top of your mouth, and I very much appreciated that. 

Note: If you get everything on there (which includes jalapenos), it gets quite spicy!

Will definitely return soon!! Makes my mouth water thinking about this sandwich again...
author: Brian L.

description: Saigon Sandwich is definitely one of those hidden places in SF. Located within the Tenderloin district, it's a small shop that doesn't have too much pizzazz to make it stand out, but the quality of the sandwich there was terrific! The staff there were just 2 Vietnamese women that make around 5 different types of sandwiches, with pre-bought  snacks on the side (Yan-Yan, Hello Pandas, etc.) I ordered their Vietnamese meatball sandwich there and wow was it delicious! Their sandwiches were definitely a lot more filling than Lee Sandwiches. I'll definitely come back for more!
author: Al B.

description:
This is by far, the best Vietnamese sandwich place ever!  Its just a hop, skip and a jump away from Turtle Tower.  So after I fill my belly with chicken pho, I head down the block to grab a sandwich togo.

I've tried the chicken and roast pork, but my vote goes to the roast pork( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/oQIHaG3z57in7ynUkhcU8A/l ).  The ingredients are fresh, and the bread is toasted to perfection.  Their jalapeno peppers are the real deal...definitely spicy!  They only have about 5 sandwiches on the menu, but that's what makes them so great...they stick to the good stuff!  

The shop is tiny, so if its busy, be prepared to wait outside...BRrrRRrr!!!  The two ladies running the shop are pretty efficient, so I've never had to wait too long for my sandwich.  You can't beat $3.50 for a good sandwich!
author: Patra I.

description: Whatever has already been said, I add my accolades. Most delicious sandwich ever. I have one in my back pack and will eat it at 35,000 feet and torture the rest of the plane headed east.
author: Moe B.

description:
Without the hype, i think this place deserves 4 stars but because i hate hyped up places that can't deliver to the amped up expectations, its receiving a 3 stars...but 3.5 is my true consensus

Good:
- tasty hot, crusty bread
- flavorful meats
- love hole in the wall joints
- the price

Bad: 
- too much veggie vs meat
- the neighborhood
- pate was okay, not incredible
- too much jalepenos

Verdict:
- its good, but not great
- tasty but not worth the trek
- still not better than Irving Deli for vietnamese sandwiches

Bottom Line:
- if around the neighborhood (which is never) and need a cheap snack (always), this place is great!
- if in the mood for the best viet sandwich, i much prefer Irving Deli to this place. 
- I think this place is good but overhyped because many of the regulars have never been to Irving Deli yet. Trust me...its better, cleaner, and has a much better location
author: Simon L.

description:
I've had a couple of different vietnamese sandwiches over the years and these are some of the best by far! Crispy bread, pickled vegetables, spicy jalapeños and delicious pâté. 

Their pâté spread is one of the best parts! They put a lot of the spread adding even more flavor to this delectable sandwich.
