On my first visit I ordered the Roasted Pork, Meat Ball Pork and Special Combination sandwiches. Yes, ALL THREE. I was completely satisfied.

Their customer service is prompt, getting you in and out of there as fast as they can. While you're waiting in line, they take your order and process it with efficient speed.

If you're in San Francisco and you love vietnamese sandwiches (or just sandwiches in general) this is the place to go first. And they're priced at 3.25 each!
author: Andrew C.

description:
After tasting lackluster Vietnamese sandwiches in SoCal, I ventured here in search of the best Vietnamese sandwich of all time. Unlike other people, I enjoy a regular ham combo over roast pork. I like my ham very thinly sliced (the red kind with the black peppers) and my pâté the same way (with pepper). This place lacks both of those requirements so I already know it can't be the best Vietnamese sandwich ever, but this place does have some highlights.

For $3.25 you can get a ham sandwich with pâté. I like how they include sweet onions, which gives the whole sandwich a nice taste. The other ingredient that I'm usually not used to is this type of sweet mayo (that's the only way I can describe it). I also like the French baguette, despite its small size. Add in the correct type of ham and some more cilantro and I think you have a winner. 

I also probably should have eaten this sandwich fresh, but I refrigerated it instead, then took it on a 4 hour-long flight (including wait times). By the time I ate it, it had been refrigerated for a good 4 hours and then sat at room temperature in my backpack for another 5 hours. It still tasted good to me aside from a few spots that were soggy, but good nonetheless. I don't think the flavor would taste that much different than from when I got it 9 hours ago. 

EDIT: Oh crap (literally). I think I feel the 9 hours of spoilage catching up to my stomach now. I guess pâté and mayo are best served fresh. Tasted fine, but ultimately was a bad idea. Still deserves four stars in my book since it was my fault for not eating it fresh.
author: Bailey Z.

description: Really cheap Vietnamese sandwiches with the perfect ratio of meat, sauce, veggies and bun. Quick service. Only downside is no seating.
author: Noji N.

description:
Everyone says this place has the best Vietnamese sandwiches in the city so I decided to stop by and pick up a sandwich before work. 

Ordered the roasted chicken sandwich with extra pate. The sandwich was smaller than what I'm used to but they really do stuff the bread generously with meat and veggies. When I asked for extra pate, they really gave me extra pate! 

Now the sandwich was good, but not the best I've ever had. All that raving probably killed the taste because I was expecting it to blow my taste buds away! High hope calls for disappointments I guess... 

Would I ever go back? Maybe if I'm in the neighborhood is hardly ever. For now I'll stick to my favorite Banh Mi shop- Irving Deli & Cafe.
author: Jenny K.

description: Good Damn Sandwich...I luv the Pork
author: Dave K.

description:
As much as I love refined eating and having extremely bougie dining experiences in the Mission, hole-in-the-wall cheap eats really do take my heart.  That said, Saigon Sandwich is the winningest winner of them all.  

BUT since you already have 1500 other reviews to tell you what exactly is sOoOOoo fabulous about Saigon Sandwich, I will focus on the setbacks of ordering here.

1. The self-righteous WASPy people in line who place their orders in English but try to pronounce "bánh mì tht" using a Vietnamese accent.  GOOD GRIEF. You're not impressing anyone, and especially not the ladies behind the counter who honestly are just trying to get through the line and PROBABLY don't give a donkey's tail about how your pronounciation is.  Maybe I am just jealous, but gimme a break. 

2. The line, though nowhere near what I imagine Ike's to be like, has usually AT LEAST a 15-20 minute wait time during and around peak hours.   Once you get to the front of the line, the ladies working tend to be a bit rushed and pushy for obvious reasons. 

3. Being located in the heart of the Tenderloin, a pungent smell of urine subtly blankets the air in the area surrounding its coveted little street corner on Larkin and Eddy.  Decent ladies of society, expect to witness illicit drug deals in broad day light and inappropriate cat calls if the line extends out the door (which it probably will).  

That said, I love the crisp of SS's baguette and the perfect ratio of daikon to julienned carrots to pate and how the sandwich is small enough that I don't feel like a super fatty mcfatty finishing it all because it is DEEE-LISH-OUS.
author: Cecilia X.

description:
*NOTE: They close at 5pm every day now, instead of 6pm. 

And they were mean about it when I showed up at 5:30 yesterday so I'm subtracting a star. Boner kill. I'm also sad because I can only get this yummy sandwich on the weekends now because I, like so many others, work until 5pm. Lame.
author: Betsy W.

description: Plenty of vegetable with pork in my sandwich. You better know your order when a woman in a counter say "Hi" to you. All the sudden, people began to order from a first person in a line. She gather an order about 5 people, and start to put a sandwich roll into a toaster. Ask them to cut your sandwich in a half when you place an order.
author: Vicki S.

description:
As good as it gets, and cheap too.

To me, it is the bread and pickled veggies are what makes sandwiches here awesome!

It's a hole in the wall, with very few seats, if at all. So I just always get it to go. The neighborhood is kinda dingy/grungy so be careful and on alert. Should be ok during the day.
author: Gino E.

description: Those ladies do it RIGHT.  Tofu and roast chicken varieties FTW.
author: Champion S.

description:
BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH IN SF. Hands down. 

It's a hole in the wall too which is kinda cool. They sell a lot of fum Vietnamese snacks and desserts too to complete your meal. 

ALL the sandwiches were good. I especially like the gravy and pate that comes with the sandwiches just makes it all nice sweet and juicy.  Fresh ingredients at a KEEP-IT-REAL price. What a gem!

Caution: it's so good that there's almost always a line so expect to wait a while during peak lunch hours or early morning
author: Tim T.

description: Had a chicken Bahn Mi. Was among the better ones I've tried in this area, but not the best. It could have had more veggies. Cant beat the price and how fast its served. I recommend it.
author: Little M.

description:
Bomb sammiches. I've only had the chicken so far, but next is the tofu. Their buns are delicious too. I wasn't sure if just the sandwich would be enough (it was, and I ate the bun later) so I got a bun too. It was filled with an hard boiled egg, veggies, and I don't know what else. Delicious. Both items for less than five bucks.

Hmmmmm, might have to hit it up for lunch tomorrow.
author: gabby m.

description: The flavor is sooo good, the ingredients are cheap and made me nauseas.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: We stopped by yesterday to grab some sandwiches for lunch. We ordered one chicken and one roast pork. The ingredients were really fresh and the jalapenos provide a surprising kick. The favorite was definitely the pork. The neighborhood is a little dodgy and there isn't space to sit so I definitely recommend planning to eat your lunch elsewhere. The ordering system isn't really clear for first timers, you order and then pay when your sandwich is ready. There were a lot of people cramped in the small space and it was difficult at first to tell who was waiting to order vs. waiting for their sandwich. It's worth the discomfort for such a yummy and well priced meal. I'll be back again to try some of the other sandwich types!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I truly believe that these are the best sandwiches in America.  I dream of these sandwiches all the time. They're all that banh mi should be.  Perfection.  I get excited when I hear the word Saigon.  I wish I could give them 10 stars.  They are in a class by themselves.  Best ever sandwiches.

The way they hollow out the bread so that they can stuff more filling in is ingenious.  Their pickled carrots are so good that I think they could sell carrot sandwiches.  The quality of the roast pork is really incredible.  The prices are unreal.  The meatballs are the tastiest.  Every element of the sandwich feels like it was created to be part of that sandwich.  I can't even ask for more jalapenos or any alterations because the sandwich is already perfect.  

Whenever I travel, I look for banh mi and I've not had one that has come close to Saigon.  I just wish they would open another location.  

If anyone claims that the banh mi elsewhere is better, it's clear that our tastes are just too different.  Saigon is the absolute BEST.

Update (5/08):  They changed their bread.  It's longer now and doesn't hold the filling as well now.  There's less filling too.  They were so consistent for so many years.  The sandwich is still great but not as good as it was.  I am devastated.  I would rather $1 or even $2 more pay more for the same old sandwich.

I've been back a few more times.  Alas, the sandwiches really aren't as good as they used to be but I haven't found any better place in America yet.
author: Lolia S.

description:
I used to love this place.  I probably would've given it five stars when I was fiendin' for their sandwiches and eating it several times a week.  But from that experience, two things happened: 1) I got sick of eating banh mi and 2) I realized they could be really inconsistent (e.g., freshness of bread, ratio of ingredients, phone orders will be wrong).  That's where the one star is lost.

That said, I love the chicken pate banh mi.  If you call ahead of time, you can swing by later and wave to the losers who are waiting as you zip to the front victoriously.  Sometimes, I forget to call it in and I am one of those losers.  Tears.

When you place a phone order, the two women pumping out the sandwiches at this joint will hang up on you when they think you're done ordering, even if you're in the middle of a sentence.  However, like a sprain, they ain't nothin' to play with so you just call back and politely finish ordering.  

For $3-$3.50 for a sandwich, you can't really complain.  I like to get v coffee at Sing Sing before/after.
author: Erika C.

description:
"I love the smell of napalm in the morning...and a good bahn mi !"
...so said Lt. Col. Kilgore in "Apocalypse Now". You didn't hear the second part in the movie? I believe that's because Brando cut a big one off-camera from eating his jumbo-sized bahn mi...and they had to edit it out. A true Hollywood story. I think I saw it on E!  

The mythic stature of Saigon Sandwiches certainly speaks for itself, though the problem is that it speaks in Vietnamese. A lovely language...but don't expect homespun conversations with the two women who seem to be in charge here. If you are looking for historical discussions of the Tet Offensive or Operation Frequent Wind, you may just have to wait for some other time since these ladies are busy, busy, busy. Even at 2PM, the line is out the door, and I always end up in front of the passive-aggressive guy who whispers insults under his breath.

You certainly can't beat a tasty $2.50 sammie. Pork or chicken, take your pick. Or the $2 braised tofu for you high-minded vegetarians. And don't even think of sitting in the lone table at the window...you'll be the recipient of dead-eyed staredowns from the waiting line. I usually take it to Opera Plaza nearby where there are a couple of unused picnic tables in front of the movie theaters there.

FOOD - 4 stars...a good Vietnamese sammie for an incredibly good price
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...just a hole-in-the-wall..and you have to block and tackle to get out once you get your sammie
SERVICE - 3 stars...monosyllabic dialogue is most effective here..."Pork!"..."Chicken!"...and they do thank you for your business
TOTAL - 4 stars...for them cheap, hearty sammies...'cause I love the smell of bahn mi in the morning...and the afternoon
author: Ed U.

description:
So the banh mi is VERY good, except for a small caveat: DO NOT GET THE HOT PEPPERS WITH IT. Some may argue that this makes the banh mi, but when I had it, I made the mistake of keeping the peppers in there and it was WAYY too spicy. It completely distracted me from the rest of how the sandwich tasted. I got it again a few days later and got it without the peppers and it was delicious. The bread wasn't too hard to bite off (which I HATE about sandwiches in general, and other banh mi places seem to have only hard bread..). The sauce with the meat was super good too. 

Not really an attractive venue. It's really meant for you to just pick up and eat somewhere else.
author: Emmanuel C.

description: I have no words for this place... You just have to go and try it yourself. Probably the best place I ever had Bah Mi Sandwiches in my life! I recommend the meatball!! I wish we had this in New York =/  If I could. I wouldve ordered the whole menu!
author: Johnny Y.

description:
$3.50 for a full lunch portion.

I repeat, $3.50 for a full lunch portion, delicious, roasted chicken banh mi with pate. 

Bring cash. 'Nuff said.
author: Aditi R.

description: It's not that great! Bread is not very crispy. I have been to Vietnam 3 times and this sandwich does not even taste remotely authentic.  The place across the way, L&M is WAY better! And L&M tastes very authentic.
author: April M.

description:
Despite the crazy people and weird smells, I'm so glad I live in the Tenderloin. I'm a block away from school and three blocks away from Saigon Sandwiches! Yeah!

The banh mi was so delicious and so huge it blew my mind. Although I prefer cold cuts, I really enjoyed the Combination Sandwich with hot roast pork and cold pate--I am in LOVE with the pate! The bread was great because it wasn't too crunchy that it hurt the roof of my mouth or too soft that it hurt my jaw from chewing. Gosh, I could go on and on--this was the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever devoured.

Carnivores will rejoice over the meat-to-veggie ratio. Definitely get the jalapenos if your tastebuds like a small kick. OMG, I need one now. So cheap, so good, so filling, so close by!
author: Liz T.

description:
We go to this place about once a month.  It has nice fresh Vietnamese sandwiches.  Everything I've ever ordered here has been good.  You can't beat the price!  

If you're going during lunch you may want to time it carefully.  There is always a line out the door, but it moves fast.
author: Tonie C.

description: Not as good as Huong Lan Sandwich in Sacramento, but definitely a good place for banh mi in SF. it's a very small shop with no where to sit to eat. It's more of a grab-n-go type. I had the roast pork and my boyfriend had the roast chicken for a total of $7.50. The pate and special sauce was delicious.
author: Jenlyn L.

description:
What's the best way to get here?  Walk down Market St. until you start getting scared.  Then turn right, and there it is, the best Vietnamese sandwich in town.  

Its the way the butter-spread blends with the pate, and the 3 other meats they smash into their combo, that creates this addictive, perfect sandwich.

Bring a friend, hopefully someone bigger and stronger than you, so that they can keep a look out, while you navigate the rough streets of the SF Tenderloin.  

You will need his or her brute protection because both of your hands should be full carrying enough sandwiches to last you the week, and to bribe hungry coworkers for favors.  

Or eat them all in front of the poor saps who can only watch in envy and desire as you consume the perfect sandwich in front of them.
author: Lam N.

description:
All I can say is that it's cheap ($3.25), quick and enough to fill your stomach.  It tastes better than all the Vietnamese sandwiches i've had....but i'm thinking to myself, is it really worth over 1,500 reviews and 4.5 average star rating???

it was a pretty interesting experience though...no where to sit so we just had to eat it on the streets of Tenderloin...one of the most dangerous places in SF.   

Some thoughts as I was stuffing this:
1) is someone gonna take my sandwich and run away
2) am I going to get mugged and pwned everywhere
3) Is someone breaking into my car
4) am I gonna go home safely 

it's a crazy adrenalin rush to eat Saigon Sandiwch as you are thinking and feeling these thoughts....I guess it's rare to get this type of dining experience so thank you for this thrilling meal....
author: Jang David K.

description:
The line is ridiculous, you see men in suits waiting patiently, clearly on their lunch hour and you know this place has got to be fairly decent.

Talk about perfection, Dutch roll not too crunchy and pork so succulent you want to leave a big ass tip to compensate for pricing something so good so cheap! 

You might be warded off by the interior though, no space whatsoever really. They do have a table window adjacent that may seat one or two patrons, but I'd rather stroll down towards civic center than eat in there. 

Try the other things they have to offer, like the grass jelly drinks, the bibinka looking delicacies and the vietnamese drinks, yumm =)

I love that the place is filledf with asian treats as well like nagaraya cracker nuts, Yin Yans, Hello Panda, Lychee jelly.

Be patient, the servers aren't very friendly but you gotta understand there is only 2 of them working handling about 10 orders at once or at least trying to
author: Myrtle M.

description: I've heard multiple people just raving about this sandwich place. I'm from San Jose and I am vietnamese. I guess I'll say I critique vietnamese food in the city because I've rarely had good vietnamese food in the city. Me and my coworker were doing some volunteer work, and this place happened to be down the street. So when it was our break time we walked over to see what the hype was all about. Got there and I ate the banh mi thit nhuong. Man oh man. One word: AWESOME. Best Banh Mi sandwich that has ever been in my mouth. Downside is it is in the TL. Hide your kids hide your wives and take them to saigon sandwiches.
author: Quyenna T.

description: Monstrously delicious sandwiches piled high with good stuff, at absurdly low prices.  The seedy neighborhood and "brusque" staff merely add to the Saigon ambiance.  This sandwich is well worth the wait.  One of the best food values around!
author: Doron A.

description: I grew up eating banh mi on the streets of Saigon so I'm pretty picky when it comes to a good banh mi. I freaking love it here. What makes it different is the sauce and the pate. They do stuff your banh mi with so much meat! I finally bought the pate by itself ($8/lb) so I can make my own at home and avoid the lines
author: Amy L.

description:
Given the positive reviews, attention from NY times and other food review sites,  I'm very surprised this place wouldn't be more proactive in trying to maintain a cleaner environment.  Most businesses would bend over backwards to ensure they don't loose these kind of good graces .    It''s almost as though they take demand for granted -- they haven't even attempted to communicate with their customers as to when they will re-open.

Also, why do so many people seem to accept a dirty environment specifically around Asian restaurants

Yes, the sandwich is good, but I give the one star to make a very important and disturbing point.

Is it just me or do others not feel this way?
author: David R.

description:
It's tasty but the service was awful...even rude. But I guess there's no such service thing, right?

Try the combo and you'll feel like sandwiches elsewhere is nothing. I guess that's just typical Asian style. Most of the Asian food are tasty.
author: Karan S.

description:
Under $4, awesome bread, delish.

Roasted pork topped with cilantro, jalapeno, and pickled carrots on a fresh baguette?? Hells yes. I love this spot. So tasty.
author: Francesca F.

description: There is nothing better than a late Sunday afternoon banh-mi, and this place never fails to deliver for a few dollars. (Although they just raised their prices a quarter on all menu items, so you'll have to fork out $3.75 now!) They make the sandwiches right in front of you. It's clean, fast, and cheap.
author: Danny M.

description: This has got to be the worst Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had.... grilled pork was bland... I paid for pate and and had no pate.... sandwich was filled with more picked vegetables than meat... I knew I should have went down the block to Lee's sandwiches instead. What a waste of time looking for parking and money.... save yourself the disappointment and do not come here.
author: huy p.

description:
After reading (http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/07/the-vietnamese-sandwich-banh-mi-in-america/) that this place may be the best banh mi in the country, i just had to try it out.  My coworker and I decided to make the trek in the annoying rain of San Francisco (not real rain, but enough rain to make you pissed off).  We walked the mile there through the TL...to find that it was closed due to remodel.  It will reopen on April 1st.  

Tip: Closed due to remodel!
author: Kevin T.

description: Saigon is my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place in the Tenderloin.  It is cheap (~$3.50 for a sandwich), uses French roll for the sandwiches, and has this amazing sauce!  I usually get chicken or tofu sandwich - delicious.  The sandwiches are sizable too, so you'll be satisfied.
author: Christine A.

description:
Simply the best Banh Mi I've ever had in my life. 
I bet you can't even find such a good sandwich shop like this in Vietnam.
author: Chi N.

description:
most of my yelps come with a story. whether it's a delighted tale of the food cart that makes ramen better than my grandma, a funny story about the chinese restaurant whose pu pu platter almost singed off my eyebrows, or even an angry rant about the moving company that almost lost all of my belongings; we yelpers tend to share the special moments that make up our experiences at these businesses. 

this is not one of those yelps. 

i have no story to tell about the amazingly delicious banh mi sandwiches at saigon sandwich. and you know what? no one needs a good story to want to eat banh mi. it's the reason itself. thin, tender slices of pork, slivers of crunchy, pickled carrots, the oh-so-vietnamese mix of cilantro and fish sauce, all nestled inside a fresh, crackly baguette. at $3.25 a sandwich, this was the best and cheapest lunch i've had in a while. and with 1,348 yelpers having said so before me, i doubt you need a story to inspire you to check them out. cash only.
author: Kris G.

description: Love it! Great Special Combo Banh Mi Sandwich!
author: Zoran L.

description: I have heard a lot about this place, and I decided to walk to Tenderloin to get it with a thought "it's better worth my trip through this area". There is a line, always a line though, so be prepared for it. They might take your order when you are still outside, and you get in to pay and get the food. Both the pork and chicken are yummy. The pickles are tasty and flavorful which many Vietnamese places fail to have. Closest version of Vietnamese banh my I have tried so far. Definitely a come back for me.
author: Zisele N.

description:
I had to pay $2 to take muni out to the Tenderloin from the FiDi just to try a Saigon sandwich... but it was well worth it!!

I decided to listen to the other yelpers and try the Roast Pork banh mi with pate ($3.75). The bread was perfectly toasted and very fresh. It does not cut the roof of your mouth but is still crunchy. The sauce they put in the sandwich is runny and was dripping out as I took each bite! I don't really know what the sauce is made of but i'm guessing a combination of mayo and pork drippings. Yuummmmm!  This banh mi is set apart from all others i've tried because of this runny, drippy sauce. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
A tiny little hole in the wall located in a shady part of town, Saigon Sandwich actually generates some pretty good Vietnamese sandwiches. Although I have had better Vietnamese sandwiches elsewhere in the city, the sandwiches here are not bad for the price (about $3.25 for a sandwich)

I tried the combination sandwich and also the steam pork/roast pork sandwich...both of which were pretty yummy.

The ingredients to the sandwiches were fine, but I do have one gripe about the sandwiches made here. Of all the times that I have been here, I always found my bread to be too hard/crunchy!! Don't get me wrong, crisp bread is great on a Vietnamese sandwich, but here...my jaw gets pretty tired from chewing before I even finish the sandwich!!

If you can conquer the bread, the sandwich is actually pretty tasty.

And oh yeah, parking sucks in this area. 

Also, please don't leave any valuables within sight in your car...
author: Albert L.

description:
the chicken banh mi. yum!! only $3.75 and packed full of flavor. what makes it so special? the bread. it's SF style afterall. also, the chicken is well seasoned, and they don't skimp on their ingredients. 

don't be fooled by the location of this neighborhood gem. yes, it's in the tenderloin district right behind the court house. but, if 2,000 yelpers managed to get in, order their food, and leave safely, so can you. just do it, says nike.

oh, and they recently expanded their kitchen which has a work space and counter that is surprisingly super clean. 

A++. 

p.s. we tried ordering ours to go (with the veggies in a separate baggie) but a few hours later, the bread wasn't as fresh. if you go this route, not to worry. take it home and throw it in your toaster oven -- voila, as good as new!
author: Cat B.

description:
If you're ever bored in class, thinking about food is a great way to keep you awake, therefore I Yelp. Haha. I'm telling you, it works.

3 little words, 1 meaning.
Cheap good eats = I love you. In my mind, it holds the same definition, just different word choices and phrasing. 

Ummm BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH EVERRR. Period. And I know it, you know it,  they know it, and everyone else in the city knows it; and what I love about it all is that they don't use this well-known fact to ripped us all off. Because they could, and people will still head over here at lunchtime like a flock of doves. Because if I would spend 5$ (a rip) for one in the Sunset and it's not even as good, I would definitely be willing put out more for than 3.25$ for this, & the Tenderloin does not scare me... at all. Maybe a little haha. &The crowd could get pretty tedious for a freakin' sandwich here, but better than the one for Ike's.
author: Betty C.

description:
Top ten reasons why I wish the software company I work for were run like this:

1. 1-minute sales cycle.  Customers get in and order as soon as you can get to them.
2. Quick customer service.  
3. Clear product differentiation - better and more ingredients, low prices.
4. Simple process to follow.
5. Cash only!
6. Immediate payments. 
7. Limited (product) selections, all printed right on the business card.
8. Upsell opportunities.  Love the sandwiches?  Try the other pre-packaged selections piled on the counter.
9. Customer referrals.
10. Low overhead.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This was my first Vietnamese sandwich, so I don't really have anything to compare... but it was MIND-BLOWING!  I haven't thought of an excuse to head into SF recently, but when I do, I definitely am coming back to this place.  There's often a line (only eaten here once, but I used to pass by it quite often), but the service is very fast.  The sandwiches themselves are very affordable and DELICIOUS.  Savory, sweet, tangy - everything that's best about Vietnamese cuisine on a perfectly toasty roll of bread.  

I'm pretty sure I could eat three of these sandwiches in one sitting, but one will be enough to make you a fan.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Katy O.

description:
I don't understand all the hype around this restaurant. The sandwiches are good, yes, but they aren't mind-boggling amazing. Sanitation can be a concern here as sometimes the cashier makes the sandwiches after she handles your money. 

There is always a line here. ALWAYS. I live right upstairs and whenever I go to work or come back home I would spot a line spilling outside the tiny space of the shop. 

The sandwiches are cheap, yes, but credit cards aren't accepted here, which is a deal breaker in my book. They do have a good selection of Asian drinks, though I prefer to just go down a block to Lee's Sandwiches to get a better variety of Asian drinks (plus I like their sandwiches more). 

Good sandwiches, cash only sucks, line is long, a little overrated.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Opens at 7:30am  . Tell me more ....in all of 2minutes you will be enjoying a ......mouth watering Boneless falling off the bone chicken wrapped sandwich ? that title does it no justice heaven bun ??? inside theeeee best French bread I've ever had in California and by the way it's $3.50 .  I always tip these ladies are hard working and serve an Excellent product !!!! Try it if you haven't like it if you've been !!!!
author: Adriana H.

description:
It's worth the wait.

Respectfully yours.
-Banh Mi-aholic
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'm basing this review on the bahn mi I had at other places (Nom Nom truck and Lee's Sandwiches to be exact). Out of those two places I have listed, I have to say if you want a bahn mi, go to Saigon Sandwich! I know there is a line and a hole in the wall and enough room for just one person to eat there, IT'S ALL WORTH IT! I usually go for the roast pork or chicken and they serve their meat on great bread, have the right amount of veggies and jalapenos and it's usually under five bucks.

So to Saigon Sandwich, you totally beat out a sandwich chain and a popular food truck. If I want bahn mi, I'll always go to you.
author: Edna F.

description:
Cheap, solid Vietnamese sandwiches. I would've liked more meat on mine but oh well. The bread is fresh and comes warm. It's a little hole in the wall so usually there's a line out the door. You just order when they say it's your turn and then you loiter around the front entrance until it's ready. There's like 2 stools you can sit on if you really want to stay and eat, but they are crammed together near the entrance. 

My reco is to get your sandwich here and then walk over to Lee's down the street and pick up a Vietnamese Iced Coffee and eat your sandwich there.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Terrific bahn mi with a tasty soft bun and lots of crunchy veggies.  I can't wait for another one.
author: Hillery G.

description:
HELLLLA nom  nom nom status.

I discovered this place in my itty bitty elementary school days.  The store is pretty dinky but like I've said before, dinky places + long lines is always a good sign.  The same ladies have been working there ever since I can remember and I always recommend this place to my friends whenever we pass by and so far, they've all loved it too!

I usually get the BBQ pork (cha siew baby) and I don't know if it's their sauce/spread that they use or WHAT (which is probably just mayo mixed with the BBQ pork-ness) but man do they know how to do Vietnamese sandwiches right!


Sandwiches are $3. Plenty of snacks and other goodies around the counter as well. Well to tempt us while we wait for our sandwiches -_____-


Definitely stop by and give them a go if you're still a Saigon Sandwich virgin.
author: Annie C.

description:
Okay, so why bother being the 1,478th reviewer...

...because...

1. Yes, these sandwiches are that good.

2. I could not believe how cheap these sandwiches were at ONLY $3.25!

3. Holy sh*t this is a bad neighborhood.

Don't go after dark.
author: Luis O.

description:
WINNER: Best Vietnamese Sandwich/Banh Mi

The best banh mi in the Tenderloin...only rivaled by my favorite banh mi  in New York City.  Get in line at this non-descript store front.  I usually get the combo or the pork.  The vegetables are crisp.  The pate is rich and creamy.  The bread is crispy. but not so hard that it'll cut up your mouth.  Some people say that there's a competition between Saigon's and Lee's -- to me it's not even a competition.  Go Saigon!
author: Sue N.

description: I don't understand the hype behind their bahn mi sandwiches. Yes, their are cheap but that doesn't make them more appetizing. They are mediocre at best but I suppose for the Tenderloin it's considered a Michelin star.
author: Jason B.

description: So glad I finally got a chance to try Saigon Sandwich! Aside from it being located in a not so great neighborhood and closing at 5pm (dinnertime!), everything I ordered here was delicious! The sandwich was fresh and tasty. The plantain thing I bought was also delicious. You really can't beat the price either. Hope they open another location!
author: Clarice C.

description: CHEAP AND DELICIOUS! I get the tofu bahn mi every time (I'm vegetarian). You have not had tofu Bahn Mi until you have had Saigon Sandwich! The tofu is delicious and textured (you'd think you were eating meat). I love this! The bread is crunchy and the pickled veggies are always fresh. Definite must if you are in the area! As a student at UC Hastings and an extern at the federal court nearby, I've gone here at least once a week for the last two years. Great food, and less than $4 for lunch.
author: Mike O.

description:
UPDATE 2-12-08:
The quality is back.  Thank goodness since Lee's wasn't doing it for me.

UPDATED 10-24-07:
How could a good thing become so mediocre?  What use to be a solid sandwich has become bland.  WHAT HAPPENED HERE?

Original:

How can you complain about a sandwich that only costs $2.50?  I guess you could, but maybe you haven't eaten here.  For the most part, the quality and taste of the sandwiches are pretty awesome.  There are days when it may not taste as fresh as others days, but overall, it works.

Tofu is a great alternative to the chicken, pork, meat ball, or steamed pork.  It has an egg-like quality to it which probably explains why I have it for breakfast (did you know they open at 6:30 in the morning?)

And it's definitely more authentic than Lee's.

learn to yelp those in need.
author: Dan B.

description:
This place has seriously the most legit and tasty Viet sandwiches. My cousin who is from Vietnam says this is literally the closest thing he tasted. My favorite would be the roast chicken (just cause i prefer chicken over pork) But they have chicken, pork, and combination. Everything tastes good. If you are a spicy eater like i am... :) Make sure to ask for extra pepper on the side. It will make your sandwich taste that much better!

On a side note: I would refrain from trying to buy drinks from this place because the price is kinda $$$. As an alternative you could go to Lee's across the street to pick up some boba or thai tea :)


Happy Yelping!!! xoxoxox
author: Kary Y.

description:
How the fuck do they get the tofu to be so good, so chewy and tasty?

I want to know.  Do they freeze it and then thaw and marinate it?

Anyone know? I asked some Vietnamese friends last night and they didn't.

And people, all this fuss about the neighborhood. Don't be so silly. It's not scary; It's perfectly fine.

Parking is okay, too. I parked right in front, got the incredible banh mi in two minutes, and took it to my car and scarfed it down.  I'm sorry I live too far away to have it twice a week.  Where do they get their bread?  It's damn near perfect.  Oh heck, it is perfect.
author: Pat P.

description:
I was up in SF for the Holidays and needed some Vietnamese comfort food so i decided to try Saigon Sandwich since everyone on Yelp was raving about their banh mi.  Silly me decided to walk from Union Square and it was quite an interesting walk through the urine scented streets of the Tenderloin.  The drunk vagrants in wheel chairs and Santa Clause suits mumbling at me really brought out that feeling of Xmas, haha.  I would probably suggest driving since the surrounding area is a little sketchy.

Anyway, I eventually find this small store where two little old ladies are making sandwiches behind a deli counter inside.  It's super tiny and narrow, but they do have a couple seats near the front if you want to eat there.  I order a couple of the grilled pork banh mi and rushed back to my hotel to stuff my face.

The sandwiches were okay, but far from mind blowing as others make them out to be.  The flavor was good, but I have to say that the baguette was way too hard and the meat was a little too "mysterious".  The balance of textures and flavors was just okay, so I'm really surprised by so many kick-ass reviews?  I guess I'm spoiled with all of the banh mi places in LA and OC, so if that's what you're used to then Saigon Sandwich is probably a place that you can pass on.
author: Hòa P.

description:
I found this place many years ago, even before they got SO popular. I should have reviewed them then, but I wanted to be able to walk in anytime and not wait in a long line. Those days are over. Luckily the two wonderful ladies work very fast!
This may be the best $3.00 sandwich in the Bay Area. Roast pork and Pate is my favorite with Meatball right behind, both with extra peppers. In fact, those two sandwiches are usually my order. Drive to Toronados on Haight and order a beer, eat the Meatball first and save the best for last!
That's a GREAT day in San Francisco!
author: Pete S.

description:
GOOD AND CHEAP. 
The beauty of vietnamese food is that it could be eaten at any meal. Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Late Night - Bring it on. And the best part of Saigon Sandwich? 3.50 for a sweet, meaty, veggie goodness with the delight of four vietnamese ladies hustling and bustling to fill in all the orders. 

All you need to know about Saigon Sandwich and 1800+ reviews from Yelp is that its GOOD AND CHEAP. that is all.
author: Tuti T.

description:
SPECIAL COMBO!
Get here fast. If you're feeling Vietnamese Sandwich, this is the place to be. Great price, great food. They have a a wide variety of drinks and snacks too if you don't feel sandwich is enough. The staff is friendly and the menu is clear to read.

The line can get long for lunch, so get there a lil bit before noon.
author: Lauren Y.

description: The BEST BANH MI SANDWICH EVER!!!  Like, whoa!  Back it up and drop it like its HOT FYAH, it's that amazing. I should of bought 10, cuz I live north of the Bay Area. Stopping there every time I'm in the city from now on. I want one right now!!!
author: Kai P.

description:
great banh mi!  although the quantity of the meat/veggies  and temperature of the bread may vary greatly depending on who makes the sandwich, the quality has remained consistent over the years.  growing up 2 blocks away, this was the go-to place for a lunch when there was no leftovers to take to work or school.  the chicken is always tender and flavorful, the pate is always savory and a great addition to their chalua, which is never tough or old.  

minus one star for giving me the runs.  i only wish my intestines could tolerate the mayonaise like it once did.  or maybe its because they don't change their gloves when handling money and making the sandwich.

either way, it's still the best banh mi in the city
author: Tina A.

description:
What's Yelpin' Yelpers?!

Rodney King here. Sunday Sandwich blues no longer. That grumble in your tumble is NOT the Vietnam war, it's the search for a killer Saigon sandwich. My heat-seeking stomach missile was in search of a Saigon sucker punch so I strapped in and went FULL KAMIKAZE!!!!! 

The lines are long for this HUNGER HANGAR, but 747-sized sandwiches are about to send your buds into orbit, and i knew stepping into this place, not only from the cinnamon atom bomb called trident some poor taste-slain soldier left at my feet, but also from the succulent spice-'SPLOSION wafting from behind the counter, that i was gonna win this war.  Personally, I went for the pork meatball hand grenade, bit in and pulled the pin.   A sensual blast of tangy sauce, spicy jalapenYO, pickled carrot, and cilantro over some damn good pork made me need a DRINK!
Wash that aftermath down with one of the shop's dozens of tropical refreshments.  You can pretty much call me Rodney the LYCHEE KING, so I went for the Lychee liquid.  DIZAM?  yes, and at like 5 bills for lunch, i'd say i've never been happier at WAR!
author: rodney k.

description: I Heart this place. Get in.  Get out. No nonsense Bahn Mi. Ignore all the freaks nearby. This place it totally worth it.
author: Chen D.

description:
Best vietnamese sandwich I have ever had!  Seriously!  Go try it! 
Only bummer, is that it's in a rough part of town. I wouldn't recommend going at night and during the day it's probably smart to bring a friend. 
Pork is my favorite, but the chicken, and tofu are also fantastic!
author: Lizi C.

description: I'd love to know what sort of pâté they use before going. Message me directly if you know whether or not they have poultry pâté or only pork/beef.
author: Uriah H.

description:
Good sandwiches for cheap.

Cash only, and get there early to beat the rush.
author: Mike L.

description: Such a good place. Super quick, filling, and cheap! As a college student  really cant complain. Probably the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had. Bahn Mi is always good, and this definitely tops that.
author: Mina M.

description:
Roast chicken sandwich was absolutely delicious even when eating next to a trash can in the Tenderloin because there is no room to sit down inside.  French baguette had a perfectly crispy crust, stuffed with juicy roast chicken, tasty mayo sauce, fresh veggies (cilantro, jalapenos, carrots). 

Only reason I'm not giving it a 5 is because $3 is a lot for a Vietnamese sandwich.  I can get 3 sandwiches at that price in Garden Grove. ;)
author: Connie C.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches makes the best chicken sandwiches in the planet. I can eat 3 sandwich for lunch. This place needs to expand,because it is so damn cramp.  
**Attention!!**
No negative reponse about this place, because there nothin negative
author: Matt G.

description: A great little restaurant! I have come to like bahn mi a lot since I tried a sandwich there. Not a fan of the cilantro in the sandwiches, and there isn't a lot of seating, but all around, a great lunch stop.
author: Stephen C.

description: Can't get anywhere else in the bay area for this quality of sandwiches. And it's only $3.75!! The marinade was fantanstic. They used to be so generous about giving out extra meat. So sad my sandwiches are getting smaller. Despite of that, BBQ taste...always my fav!
author: Sam W.

description:
I live right around the corner from this little Tenderloin/Little Saigon Gem. 
This is great for a quick, cheap easy sandwich if you don't hit the lunch rush. The ladies that usually wait on me are very sweet and I have to say every thing that I have had has been pretty darn good.

Not the most amazing eats in the world, but Darn good. Save yourself a few bucks and skip Subway, try one of these tasty Vietnamese Sandwiches and you most likely will be coming back for more.
author: Damien K.

description:
I've been coming here for years and much better than Lee's across the street.  The bread is toasted warm.  I like the special that has everything in it (pork pate, roasted port, mixed pork ham concoctions, cilantro, pickled carrots and dakon radish, house mayo, and jalapeno peppers).

The down side of coming here at noon is the line is crazy out the door.  Get there about 11:30ish and the line is reasonable.
author: Twist' D.

description:
My half Vietnamese boyfriend has been coming here since he was 8 years old.  That's over 20 years of patronage from a very satisfied customer.  As for me, I also love getting the banh mi--but with extra cilantro and no peppers.  

Last time we were standing in line here for lunch, my boyfriend told me a story about a customer he saw here years ago who noticed that the lady behind the counter used the same hand that she used to hold the money to also handle the sandwich.  The angry customer woman shoved the sandwich back in the lady's face and proceeded to walk around the store shouting, "Everyone listen up!  They use the same hand to make the food and hold the money!  That's nasty!  Don't eat here!  They're dirty!"

Needless to say, she was very much ignored and everyone still stayed in the long line, which probably stretched well onto the urine stained sidewalk.  That's how good the food is here.  Also, I noticed that they use gloves to hold the money and their bare hands to hold the sandwich, so it's all good. 

Speaking of homeless people, don't be surprised if you find one waiting in line behind you because the food here is cheap and it's the effing tenderloin!  Again, all good.

Also, eat the sammiches as soon as you get them while the center is soft and the outside is just crunchy enough, because if you wait too long, I guarantee you will end up breaking a tooth filling on the bread crust that has hardened into a brick.  I learned that the painful way.
author: Gail S.

description:
Pretty tasty, wish they did avocado...

Their veggies are fresh, so fresh there was a green catipillar or worm or something in one of our tofu sammy.
author: S T.

description:
I love the sandwiches here and the fact that they are so affordable. Also, I noticed a comment below that said the service can be slow but considering how long the line of customers tends to be at peak hours I think they are very fast and efficient at Saigon Sandwich.

The reason I won't give 5 stars is the service. I once wanted to give $5.50 for a $3.50 sandwich so that I would only get bills for change but the woman behind the counter handed me $2.50 before I could pull out my two quarters. I then got my quarters and asked if I could give her the four quarters for a dollar and she just turned her back and pretended to either not hear me or not understand me. On second thought, it is possible that she couldn't understand me. I was the only person there so I just sort of stood there amused for like two minutes seeing if she would turn around but she never did.

Otherwise, I love this place!
author: Colin D.

description:
This place is really good but it's not the best. I'm from Orange County so I've had a variety of Vietnamese sandwiches before.

The best thing about their sandwiches is that they stuff it silly. So much pate and meat. You can't beat a place with sandwiches for under 4 dollars. The quality of meat isn't the best but I'll come here once every few weeks because I live down the street.
author: Binh H.

description:
Legit banh mi. This is where value meets taste.

I recommend the roast pork, but add pate. Yes, ADD PATE! The combo yields SO much more flavor and deliciousness! Tasty alone too, but BETTER together. The meatball is alright but not my favorite in texture. 

I've had better bread, but it's good enough for me to come 2x in 3 days for 7 sandwiches. Oink :D
author: Gee K.

description: Definitely in my top 3 favorite sandwich spots in the city. I tried pretty much every flavor and they all are amazing. Service is fast, prices are cheap, and the flavor just explodes ... They also have fun snacks to boot. All in all in just great. Try it out if you have not already... That is all...
author: Anthony S.

description:
I haven't had a Vietnamese sandwich in a long ass time and boy, was I pleasantly surprised with what they have going on here!  The combination at $3 each is loaded with tons of stuff - pate, roasted meats of sorts, carrots, jalapenos, and just a bunch of other junk!  I definitely don't remember Vietnamese sandwiches looking like this before.  I remember more bread than anything else in the past, so this was definitely a find!  Places like Saigon Sandwiches have given all those other sandwich places a run for their money!

Walking in on a weekday, they sure are busy!  Lots of people milling around waiting for their special order sandwich.  And when you see lots of people in a hole in a wall type restaurant, you know they have something good going on there.  And while you're waiting, you can check out all those plastic wrapped goodies in Styrofoam and just add those to your orders.  It doesn't really matter that you probably won't know what half the stuff is anyway, but I'm sure it'll taste good nonetheless.  And hey, that's all that matters, right?
author: Teri C.

description:
Do not fly on a cross country flight without banh mi. Seriously. It's the perfect plane-ready food and you can get it through security without getting the shake down (unless your TSA screener is really hungry).

These sandwiches are good but the ones at Baguette Express are better.
author: Miriam W.

description: This is as good as it gets, ever. I'm vietnamese and I love sandwiches, so who better to judge. The meats were overflowing and glorious. The pate was oozing all over and the pickled veggies, crunchy and delicious. Ate it in the car after a quick glance at twin peaks. The area this place is in, is the guetto. The little asian women working there are really nice, ALTHOUGH they jipped me two bucks. I guess I will count it as a tip.
author: Steve N.

description:
Cheap. Tasty. Legit. 
Roast chicken one was really good, totally worth traveling to get one all the way from the Sunset.
author: Skye L.

description:
I'm sorry banh mi. I've been in the UCI area for so long and I forgot what you really tasted like. You know, before Lee's Sandwiches came along and turned you into a bastardized version of McDonald's. I'm glad I walked through the heart of the Tenderloin (which believe me, ain't nothing tender about it) to have a real banh mi again. Thank you Saigon Sandwich.

I had the pork ball sandwich. The bread was crispy but still chewy once you get past the crunchy exterior. The meat was fall-apart tender and had a slight peppery flavor to it which I really liked. A healthy bunch of cilantro and carrots with a jalapeno on top and you've got the recipe for a delicious Vietnamese Sandwich.

Lee's... never again.

Cheers!
author: Andrew B.

description:
The cheapest I can find with that kind of excellent quality. You cannot beat that in the city. If you find one, please let me know.

The sandwiches are good.

The hours are long - M-Sa 6:00am-6:00pm and Su 7:00am-5:00pm.

Glad to see variety of choices and many fancy interesting desserts. But, the combination sandwich is the best.

Do cautious about the neighborhood and parking is a bit hard. Usually DH drives over there and wait outside watching me get in and out.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
I have their number saved on my phone, so I can call in my order and give the ladies a heads up before I arrive.  Excellent for when you're in a hurry or just don't feel like standing around the TL by yourself.  

A few weeks ago, the aunties and I had a date to meet Yao Ming in Oakland, and so I thought I'd surprise everyone with a light meal in the form of a Saigon Sandwich. Called in ten sandwiches while on BART, and then made my way to the shop from Civic Center.  Just a few minutes later and I was back on the train and heading towards the Coliseum, goods in hand.  Made it just in time for the tip-off!    

p.s.  My favorite is the chicken, but my mom loves the fish cake.  I'm not even sure if fish cake is on the menu, but apparently they will make it for you if you ask.
author: Joanne G.

description: The sandwich is delicious because they stuff it with an abundant amount of meat, and patte if you decide to get it. I have the chicken or pork with patte. I'd get it without mayo.
author: Tuan N.

description:
Love this place! Best Banh Mi in the city. Whenever my coworker goes to the TL for lunch, I would ask him to pick me up a sandwich here. Poor guy.

Anyways, the food. You can't go wrong with the special combination or the pork sandwich. They're really well priced also.

Bottom line: Really cheap, it's delicious, and it fills you up. Win!
author: Steven B.

description:
Super awesome sandwiches! 

I don't know what it is that makes me like the place...

...the amazing flavor of the meat?
...the pate?
...the way it smells when I walk in?
...the shady guys hanging around the street corners nearby?

Maybe it's a combination of everything. It's probably the only reason I'll make a trip to the Civic Center/Tenderloin. 

(Well...this place and Lee's right up the street!)
author: Betty T.

description:
WOW. I didn't believe my friends when they recommended this place as the best Vietnamese sandwich you'll ever find in norcal but I'm a skeptic no more. This sandwich shop is a testament to the goodness of hole in the wall locations being the best places to eat.

If you even remotely enjoy Vietnamese sandwiches, this place might just blow your mind considering how simple it is. Just get it, cheap and delicious. Wish it was more accessible to me sigh.

Had the pork by the way, 'nuff said.
author: Steven C.

description: Great flavor, juicy meats and a packed sandwich. I tried this place twice already and the first time we were so hungry that we ate it inside, in the only open space we could find which only fit two people at the most! It was really really good. Wished there were cucumbers inside tho. The second time, the meat was just as flavorful but the bread was a little tough. Might he because it was the end of the day and I took it to-go, so didn't eat it until 15 min later. Neighborhood is really sketchy, especially depending on what streets you have to take to get there. But I knew this on the first day I came, and still came back the second day! Tried both the roast pork and the chicken sandwiches. I thought the chicken was more flavorful. Not a place to eat in, more like a quick, dirty little hole in the wall place.
author: Sandy G.

description:
The best bahn mi I've ever had. 

The BBQ Pork is carved and roasted. 

Cheap and delicious!
author: Joe O.

description:
Best vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. I am always craving this now, which is a sign of how great this place was. If only I lived closer to the city :(

$3.50 for a full juicy sandwich roll. The difference compared to other sandwiches is the bread and the sauce they use. The stuff inside were fresh as well. The bread was crunchy and perfect, not too hard that it cuts the top of your mouth. And it is dripping with sauce which probably makes it a bit more fatty than other sandwiches. But WHATEVER, it's $3.50 and delicious!!!

Long line though because it's small. And no tables or chairs. We sat on the curb and chomped on our sandwiches. Also CASH ONLY. But again, it is totally worth it.
author: Sachiko K.

description:
You'd think that as a vegetarian, I would stay far away from this place after I found a piece of meat in my tofu sandwich not once... but on two different occasions. But that just shows you how much I love the sandwiches here. I take that risk... but I eat my sandwich slowly and carefully.

This time I was smart enough to mention that I had found meat in my tofu sandwiches before and that I was a veggie. No surprises in my tofu sandwich this time. It was just as delicious as I remembered. Perfectly toasted delicious bread with perfectly pickled carrots and daikon. 

I think the only time I had a better banh mi was when I was in Vietnam. Don't be scared away by their homely store, or the long line. They are quite efficient at taking orders and making the sandwiches fast. They only have 2 seats to sit and eat, so figure out a place to eat your sandwich after you get it.
author: Angela T.

description:
The sandwiches are pretty darned tasty and cheap! 
We have come here many times and  ordered the pork. Recently tried the combo and loved it! Of course I also love pate', but wonder about the ingredients in this one??? After reading the review by John C., I think I'll have to also try Sing Sing nearby.

I think the wait is expected considering that there are usually only two servers working in a very small space. I don't mind waiting for this treat. 
My only negative is that the bread isn't as good as other places but the total end product is far better than others. Can't beat it for cheap eats.
author: Suzy S.

description: I entered the store and I swear within two minutes I was ready to walk out with my roasted pork sandwich. $3.50 for a huuuge banh mi sandwich, and filled with a great amount of pork. What more do you want?? The paste that lines the inside of the sandwich add a great amount of flavor and makes the sandwich seem much more juicy as well. Oh yeah there's some veggies too (HA). Ask for sriracha!
author: Jason T.

description: This is the best saigon sandwich place in Sand Francisco!
author: Erik V.

description:
This was a lovely beginning to a day/evening that ended in a pile of BART vomit (literally), thanks to an over generous paisa at City Club, and one part of the afternoon that I won't regret--especially because the aforementioned pile of BART vomit meant I didn't gain any weight from the oily delicious that is Saigon Sandwich. Yeah!!! 

'Twas a windy and chilly Friday afternoon in San Francisco when I met up with Robert L by Embarcadero and we took a little stroll into the TL for some bánh mì. In true Ashley fashion, since first discovering that I had to try these yummy Vietnamese sandwiches of yumminess (thanks to yelp and, largely, everyone's sweetiepie, Ligaya), and since having my first bánh mì in Richmond a few months ago, I've been a-hankerin', but very rarely fulfilling my desire. It's kind of like my sex life. But you don't want to hear about that, so suffice it to say that when Robert and I met up, having read the stellar reviews of Saigon Sandwich and hearing so much about their vegetarian sandwich, I knew that my fellow non-meat eater and I HAD to stop in.

This place would be easy to miss, a nondescript little storefront in the TL--except for the fact that there was a line out the door. Now, Ashley isn't one to wait in line for food, or anything else, but I was on a mission--and the line was fast moving. The two women behind the counter were taking order and throwing sandwiches together like nothing, quickly whittling the line down to acceptable size. 

Inside Saigon Sandwich, there are a variety of sweets and packaged foods for your enjoyment, but I was all about the tofu bánh mì, so that's what I ordered. And a soda out of the cooler. But, sadly, there appeared to be a booger (ew?!?) on the first one I grabbed, so I had to get another. That's worth only giving 4 stars for, I think. 

Once we got our cheap and delicious-smelling sandwiches, Robert and I walked down towards City Hall to enjoy our food in the wind, and boy, did we ever. The tofu's marinade was sweet and salty and delicious, and the carrots, peppers and cilantro, the latter usually not my friend, were perfect in the mix. It was delicious and filling and left me wanting more.

However, the sandwich, perhaps in a moment of clairvoyance, vomited all over the front of my shirt, so I walked around the rest of the day with a big Saigon Sandwich grease stain on my chest. Because I'm classy like that. Bánh mì vomit, aside, this cheap, convenient and TASSSTY place is definitely on my list of places in the city for a quick, yummy bite that won't break the bank. I should probably go back. Immediately.
author: Ashley M.

description:
SIckest sandwich in the city.  I can't think of a better use for a baguette... or pickled carrots, or grilled pork, or cilantro, for that matter.  Put them all together: it's a little slice of saigon heaven.

$2.50 each?  Jesus.  That's icing on the cake.
author: Laurence W.

description:
I am addicted to their sandwiches.

I love their sandwiches so much that I am willing to risk my life walking through the tenderloin district, to get spat on by the homeless people lurking outside this joint, and be mugged by the crackheads in the neighborhood to get 1 sandwich.

I think their sandwiches have crack in them.
author: Ally W.

description: The best roasted pork or chicken sandwiches in the city, packed with plenty of pickled veggies, cilantro, and hot peppers.  I used to pack these bad boys and take them with me to Warrior games (before new management banned outside food)...   They have a large selection of drinks in their refrigerator ranging from sodas and juices to sweet homemade dessert drinks and soy bean milk.  On the counter, there is a variety of pre-made food by neighborhood "aunties" that you can grab, pay, and go if you don't want to wait in line.  And how can you beat it at those prices...  Just don't hang around in the neighborhood streets when you eat.
author: Mike C.

description:
Whenever I'm in SF, I make sure to make Saigon Sandwich one of my stops. I think most people could get by just eating one, but since this is a rare treat for me, I usually stuff two in my face. This last time I got smart and ordered four, two roasted pork and two roasted chicken. I ate two at the Fillmore Farmers' Market and took my chances taking the other two back to Turlock. Thankfully they both survived the BART ride to Dublin and the car ride back to the valley. The next day I popped them in the microwave for 30 seconds and they were magical! Next time I'm ordering more.

It might be a little confusing for newcomers on when to order, so when the lady says, "What you want?" you tell her what you want.
author: Jon M.

description:
I've had a lot of Vietnamese Sandwiches, and this one was......NOT GOOD.  We had the roast pork and the roast chicken, and both were highly disappointing. And here is why:

-way too much mayonnaise 
-the bread was chewy, dry and dense
-the veggies were limp and soggy 
-the sandwich was too sweet and left and bad taste in my mouth

I couldn't even finish my sandwich (and that's a first for me).  Sorry, but we will not be going back :(
author: IRate New Yorker F.

description:
I left my banh mi heart in San Francisco...This is the standard to which I hold all my banh mi experiences. And I've yet to have one as comparable, although the search is definitely on. Perhaps I'll have to book that trip to Ho Chi Minh City soon....

Everything about this sandwich is quality. I've had both the roast pork and chicken, although the pork is my favorite. The meat is sliced super thin and then heaped on a fresh baguette along with the traditional accompaniments of lightly pickled carrots & daikon, cucumber, cilantro, chilies and of course mayo. 

Sure, you'll have to take your sandwich to go (although mine usually doesn't make it quite back to auntie's house), but on top of being one of the tastiest, it's also the cheapest I've ever had - $3.25! Keeping it simple at this small mom-and-pop kind of store, probably helps them keep the cost so low. 

Wish I didn't live so far away Saigon Sandwich.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
My review is officially outdated. So, I will update.

Meatball pork
Meatball pork
Meatball pork
Meatball pork 

$3.25
$3.25
$3.25
$3.25
author: Cheri R.

description: The best Banh Mi in town!  Scrumptious. The ingredients are fresh. The warm, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside bread is wonderful and truly makes their sandwiches stand out from all others in the area.  I've been getting my chicken sandwiches here for several years.  Always good.  Don't let the long line deter you, it goes fast.
author: Donna P.

description:
I can't believe Saigon Sandwiches have such rave reviews. I came here with my family and a few friends and all of us were majorly disappointed. My conclusion is that you waited in line for so long that anything would've tasted good by the time you got your sandwich.

The bread was not fresh at all. It was stale and overly baked so it was hard as hell. F*cked the gums all up and helloooo, they call me chainsaw! I still got messed up.

The do chua (pickled carrots and daikon) contained only carrots, no daikons whatsoever. It was shredded carrots also, not julienned so it didn't have the appeal or texture of a good sandwich. The pork and chicken meat wasn't even grilled - it was roasted so that sweet and savory flavor that we're all used to was not there. The BF enjoyed the xiu mai meatball sandwich though, but he eats anything.

I can't believe I walked through the loins for this sandwich! I knew I should've just went to turtle tower instead! I choose Ba Le over this any day. 

Totally disappointed!
author: Valeri N.

description: Where else can you get an amazing sandwich for $3.50????? Delicious, my favorite is the pulled pork followed by the chicken.
author: Misha Z.

description:
I love Saigon Sandwiches. Ever since I was introduced to it in High School, its been the top of my Vietnamese Sandwich list. They pack that little french roll with so much meat and veggies that I was actually disappointed when I went to Vietnam and didn't get as much goodies in my sandwich!!!

The prices HAVE gone up, but that's basic inflation. $3 for a Vietnamese Sandwich is still pretty darn good. Especially when its packed with the aforementioned meat and veggies.  

Lines here indicate how awesome it is. From 12-1PM, expect to wait a good 20-30 minutes. The ladies here stack the customers, so if you're lucky enough to be at the end of the stack, you don't have to wait as long.  Everyone gets their sandwich in order though, so that guy who only waited 10 minutes to your 20 will get the sandwich after you. 

The best thing is when the sandwich is still hot and you bite into the goodness. Yum...try to eat it within 15 minutes of getting it. Its still good when its not as hot, but its so much better when its fresh!!!
author: Lily W.

description: Wow what great place to eat and great customer service.  I came here because I was waiting a business meeting and it was delayed.  So I stayed for lunch here to and go the meeting . I am glad I had lunch here. The employee told what to get and it was great. I found a new place for lunch .
author: Anthony W.

description:
The BEST banh mi dac biet I have ever had! 

LOVED the pickled veggies, bread and pate. Every banh mi lover must go here. I can't believe I only ordered one sandwich, but we had gotten there right before they closed. I had wondered why there was no line, no patrons. I am so lucky that they did not turn me away. I thought since we were in the area (after going to the Asian museum) that we should try the sandwiches here. I am so glad we did. I think what set their sandwich apart from others I have ever eaten were the pickles. Something unique about them, I can't quite figure out what that is. Were there onions in the pickle?

The next time I am in San Francisco, I am getting 6 sandwiches from here.
author: Miss S.

description:
Yummy!

The tofu one is soooo juicy that i didn't even mind its meatlessness. 
Complete with jalapenos, cilantros, radishes, and its magical sweet tangy sauce. 

Don't get this place twisted w other similar looking sandwich places along the street - this is THE BAHN dot com (harhar)
author: Ami Y.

description:
I am sure the Saigon Sandwich have enough five stars that another one won't make a difference.  However, I wanted to send my five stars to the ladies at SS to let them know how much I appreciate their excellent services, and the best sandwiches in SF.

I have my regular tofu sandwiches every weekend.  And when I am there, I always remember to buy the deserts that are on the table.  Most of the deserts are great and remind me of the street food I get in Vietnam.

I highly recommend the banana leaf wrapped sweet rice and banana cake. It's the best.
author: Truong P.

description:
I have come here for at least 7 years, they have changed a bit through the years.
Now they use softer bread which I really like (back then they used another kind of bread which was harder). But the place become smaller as they expanded their kitchen space and now it would take only a small group of people to fill up the place. So they end up having a long line sticking out of the place most of the time.
Yet no one seems to mind since the sandwich here is always good.
author: Dom G.

description:
Banh mi sandwiches are tricky.  One misstep and the $4 Stairway to Heaven a good banh mi ought to be slides into fruitless oblivion:

The bread is not adequately crunchy and cannot bear the weight of the ingredients therein.  An oversized and sloppy meat portion imbalances the vegetables and, worse, renders its juices into under-mayonnaised bread (yes, that's a real verb), leaving the whole affair reminiscent of that last, drunken 4am run to Subway.

These fine folks manage to avoid all the pitfalls; they avoid peeing on the proverbial banh mi electric fence.  And for their efforts they are rewarded with virtually endless lines, a true American Dream come true in the heart of our very own Tenderloin, notable for neither its tenderness nor its ... loin.

Unfortunately our reward, as patrons, has been consuming sandwiches subjected to a serving process rather lacking in, shall we say, Six Sigma quality control of health standards or, put more in the vernacular, they had a friggin' 46 health score.

So they are shut down, and the Stairway to Heaven is being remodeled.  

These guys are on probation for me and, presumably, with SF's powers-that-be as well, whomever they are.  Great banh mi is a rare beast but when faced with major gastrointestinal distress as a not-so-unlikely proposition, the $4 sandwich does have what modern economists might call an 'externality' built into it.

Here's hoping for a brighter, banh mi-filled future in SF, complete with perfectly balanced sandwiches AND proper holding temperatures.
author: J W.

description: One of my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place, besides Little Paris. I remember when it used to be only $1.50 - $2 for a sandwich. Now it's $3.25 - $3.75, but still as delicious and cheaper than other food around the Civic Center. I love getting the special combination with everything, especially the pate sauce. The roast chicken was also good, but doesn't have the special pate sauce. If you take your lunch break at 11:30 instead of 12, there is not much of a line. I like coming here more than Subway sometimes. I also see a crowd of non-Asians coming here...which means Vietnamese sandwiches are gaining popularity. Yeah! However, I wonder if that is why some of the toppings are not as authentic like chicken and tofu. Original Vietnamese sandwiches only have Vietnamese meat...
author: Jennifer T.

description: I miss grandma and her sandwiches since I have moved to NY, I will be back!!!! So simple yet so yummy. Those pickled veggies and huge chunks of chicken. Yet to find a Vietnamese sandwich as good as Saigon.
author: Roxanne W.

description:
For an entire year now I have been roaming Larkin street for my dinner and could never find SS.  However I admit that my skills as a tracking scout are slipping since it was pretty much right in front of my eyes and walk past it twice a day at least.   

Imagine my surprise when I was looking for the secret Radio Shack in the tenderloin (never found) I come upon this spot finally.  Having not eaten I gladly pulled a quick U-turn in my Nike's and jumped in line.  Had my sandwich in two minutes and with a drink i was only out 4 bucks.  

I have been feasting on Lee's Bahn Mi across the street for a while and I found this sandwich a tad better in some areas and missing something in others.  The pork was far better quality and cooked a bit different than I am used to in these sandwiches.  I am used to a bit more of the sweet pickled carrot flavor too..  Anytime I eat a Vietnamese sandwich I power through the pain as the crust eviscerates the roof of my mouth.  (by the way if anyone has a tip on how to avoid this I am all ears.  Is it a tolerance thing or a conditioning issue? )  

As I took off down the street with my bargain lunch I came upon the massive crowd in the civic center watching today's world cup game.  Another unexpected bonus.  

I am pretty easy to please and these two surprises set me up in the right mood this morning.
author: Dru P.

description: Discover this place one day when I saw a long line during lunch time. Their sandwiches are priced amazingly cheap compared to other mediocre shops. I mostly eat meats with my sandwiches but my favorite at this place is the tofu sandwich. If you appreciate great tasty and good prices, most definitely  give this place a try.
author: Jova E.

description: Their sandwiches are so good! And they have so many other goodies by the cash register and on the side, most of the time hit or miss with those. But yea, if you stick with the sandwiches, you will definitely enjoy this place. Waiting times can be ridiculous during lunch rush, so I prefer to go just before it starts. Living in the area, I kind of know when this is, but then again, this place is busy 80% of the time.
author: Henry P.

description: Have to agree with another yelper that they are putting more fatty roast pork into the sandwiches.  The woman that made my sandwich was pretty nasty, she deliberately made my sandwich with 99% carrots after I mentioned that I like jalapeno peppers.  I also noticed that they started using some white onions in the sandwiches too.  WTF
author: Jim J.

description:
OMG!  Saigon Sandwich totally takes me back to the banh mi stalls I went to in Vietnam.  The pate is soooo delicious - rich, semi-sweet, tasty goodness.  When I got my first sandwich here, I went back every morning for days because I just couldn't get enough.

Large orders - Saigon Sandwich totally rocks with regard to large orders.  I ordered 70 sandwiches for pick-up at 7:00 am for my team before the races.  Totally wasn't a problem, didn't even flinch at the quantity and the time of pick-up!   Total professionalism!  And dedication to the Vietnamese sandwich art!  :)

I heart you, Saigon Sandwich lady!  :D
author: Fontane L.

description: With so many reviews, I'm not going to say anything different than the hundreds of other Yelpers have already said.  Bottom line, you're paying less than $4 for a exceptional banh mi sandwich; very reasonable.  I wish it were closer to the Financial District but if it were, the sandwiches probably would be higher in price.  This is definitely my favorite Bay Area banh mi place and the roast pork banh was a knockout!
author: Albie F.

description: This place is legit. I wanted to see what the hype was all about and stopped by during my trip to the city by the bay. Prices are around what you'd expect for the quality you get. I got the special combination, fanci pork, roast pork and meatball with extra pate. So good I had to get a sandwich every morning I was there. Bread is crunchy and chewy and soft on the inside. Pickled veggies were delicious. They're not afraid to pack in the meat either. Probably the best banh mi I've had in a very long time. The only regret is that I don't live in Frisco, else I'd be here every day.
author: Michael T.

description:
Amazing sandwiches! My girlfriend and I got the roast pork with everything on top. It costs only 3.75 for a whole sandwich which is very cheap for sf!

A little hole in the wall store but you know you've arrived by the line out the door. The line goes by quick and we only waited 5 minutes. 

The sandwich is the best banh mi ive had in sf. There's this distinctive delicious mayo sauce they have which makes it so yummy. 

Theres only 2 seats there so we brought our sandwiches to the civic center park. I would highly recommend this place! Check it out!
author: Marissa C.

description:
I read a review on Yelp and decided to go. The neighborhood is a little sketchy, but the non descriptive exterior of the place, along with the kind of grimy yet charming inside gave it that "I know this is going to be good because it looks like it shouldn't be good, but the line is out the door" feel. 

I went with the pork sam - phenomenal. Next time I go, I will ask for extra sauce. 

Enjoy!
author: John C.

description: Freaking awesome $3.75 sandwich.  Roast pork with plenty of shredded fresh veggies.  Bravo!  Deserves the high yelp score.
author: Ottis M.

description: Best bahn mi I had in the city so far. Juciy pork and great bread.   I have to try the pate next time I come.
author: Edward L.

description:
I don't have to tell you about the pork meatball sandwich.  It speaks for itself.

Buy 12.  And then bring one to me.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Quite depressing to see this place being remodeled, makes you wonder if it was a forced renovation. 

Sandwiches are the best around, Lee's across the street sells a larger version, but it tastes like plastic. 

I truly hope they don't raise prices once the doors open again, alas this may be inevitable. 

Aside from the sandwiches, they stock a plethora of beverages; from Cactus Cooler to Aloe Vera Juice. 

The dessert options are also fantastic; koala yummies or a banana wrapped in sweet sticky rice with coconut. 

Overall I suggest that nobody goes here....Im sick of standing in line
author: Carson L.

description: My favorite place for Vietnamese sandwiches. It's really good. I'd give it a 5/5  if they added some crazy twist to their sandwiches or  if their bread was better....DU MAAAAA NGON
author: Justin N.

description:
I've been coming here all my life and Saigon Sandwiches sets the standard for my Vietnamese sandwich.


I love my classic steamed pork sandwich (banh mi cha lua) with extra sauce.  They use the traditional Parisian brand french bread and I have never had a subpar sandwich.
author: Linda B.

description:
It has been my weekly lunch time traditional of speed walking here to pick up 15 Vietnamese sandwiches (yes 15) to bring them back to the FiDi for my coworkers and other friends in the area that are sick of the crappy lunch offerings in the FiDi.

The line can get a bit crazy, and even with me calling a full 1 hour ahead for my order, I still have to endure the crazy wait.

I've had it all here, but my faves are always gonna be the Meatball and the Tofu.

Meatballs are juicy and tasty, and the tofu is FULL of flavor and not a common banh mi option. 

Remember to get extra jalapenos for that extra kick!
author: Deanna T.

description:
For $3.25, scrumptiously flavored Vietnamese roasted pork in a banh mi BURSTING with pickled veggies enveloped in a warm, crunchy, freshly toasted French bread?  I'd find it hard to believe if you found that anywhere else.

Gem of a place.
author: Judy L.

description: Yum! This is my favorite place to get banh mi. The trick is to call ahead instead of waiting in line. Ten minutes later, you can waltz right in and your sandwiches will be waiting for you. I like all the sandwiches on the menu, chicken is my favorite. They sell cans of the pate spread of it in the store, I couldn't tell you where else to shop for that. Great sandwich on the cheap, you can't go wrong!
author: Halley S.

description: Hey you, tourist over there! Do yourself a favor and the next time you're on one of those Hop On Hop Off Buses get off at the Asian Art Museum and head up Larkin St. to Saigon Sandwich. Ignore the homeless sleeping on the street and venture through Little Saigon to the best Bahn Mi Sandwich shop in the city. The bread is crunchy and warm, the meat (Ga aka Chicken for me) is tender and juicy, the vegetables are crisp and fresh.  It's made right in front of you and just done right. Paired with a can of Chrysanthemum Iced Tea and you've got lunch for under $5!
author: Christy Z.

description:
