Bomb ass Vietnamese sandwiches! Nom nom nom..

Yes all the reviews are correct! Definite hole-in-the-wall; you'd miss it if it weren't for the blue awning and long line out the door during lunch! This place has few selections, but it's always better to specialize in a few items and do it well, then have a lot of items which aren't even that great, right?

The sauce is SO good, and it doesn't make the crunchy bread soggy. I love the bread here! They stuff that baby up with delicious filling! My favorite place to eat around here if I don't wanna spend a lot. Yummm

You already know, the area is sketchy.. but I'd brave the pee-splashed streets and creepy dudes for Saigon!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
Tons of meat in my Roast Pork sandwich.  The bread is really crispy, but not the thin baguettes like at Lee's.  I prefer this bread much more than Lee's! 

Would be 5 stars if they had pickled daikon and cucumber inside the sandwich.  It just felt a little imbalanced since there wasn't enough pickled veggies inside.  

Their meat is really delicious though! I'd definitely come back for more.
author: Anna T.

description:
Everyone is raving about the sammies but I actually had the fresh yogurt here.  It was SO GOOD and fresh.  It was like a regular plain yogurt, tangy and sweet and had a hint of lemon in it.  My aunt brought me here and she says they make it themselves!

you have to try it!
author: Heather T.

description:
I Love SS! The best Banh mi Ive had to date! When I visit SF its the first place I go after dropping off at the hotel! There isn't much more I can say that everyone else hasn't covered.

Pros: Fresh consistent ingredients!

Cons: Can't eat more then 2 in one meal!
author: Alexander C.

description:
Having laughed and giggled over the oh so popular Stuff White People Like list, I saw that many (maybe one-third to one-half applied to me, pretty whitey!) I saw an interesting twist.

#63 Expensive Sandwiches.  I HATE expensive sandwiches, but I love $2.50 banh mi, especially from Saigon.  I love them that I actually savor walking blocks and blocks (even on a twisted ankle) to wait in line out the door with mach force winds ripping up Larkin Street.  

Also love the mysteriously wrapped dumplings and rice goodies piled upon the counter in a leaning tower of pisa fashion.  Never ever ever been disappointed, except for now working in SoMa and having to trek even further!
author: Joanna M.

description:
I hate carrots. Hate them with a passion. I can eat corn, okra, kale, spinach, and even turnips. But carrots-bleah. 

Until I came to Saigon Sandwich.

I heard about a place that was open at 6 a.m. and thought, "yeah right." 

Oh boy was I wrong. During a morning jog, there it was flanked by so many other sandwich shops.

Only 3 things on the menu. Chicken, beef, and meatballs. $3 for a sandwich is insane!!! 

I walked in, asked for the chicken and walked out rather quickly not expecting anything. Oh my friggin' lord. It was hot, heavy, juicy  and that's just the sandwich. The fact that she gave it to me hot intrigued me as I wasn't expecting much. I peeled back a little bit of the white paper and bit into utter bliss. I didn't mind the carrots either!

The carrots, onions and cilantro were in a wonderful vinaigrette type sauce mixed in with jalapeno peppers and chunks of dark meat chicken. The bread is hot, flaky and soft and the filling was so irresistible I was making an ass of myself on the street shoving my face in a white paper wrapping walking in the ghetto but I didn't care. Mom wanted me to be a debutante so I remembered to stick my pinky finger up. Soooo good.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Cheap, great, newly renovated place.

I remember when I first came out to SF a few years ago. The sandwiches were something like $2.25. Now they are $3.25 but still a great deal. Crispy & chewy bun, great quality meat. (I usually get the chicken). The fried tofu ones are really good too. Be sure to order them without mayo. Not needed since they are so flavorful.

Location is a little sketchy being on Larkin and all. I've def seen some unusual characters pretty close to the place. Today I saw 2 trannies that were probably 190lbs or so each. I do some street photography but I was scared to take a picture because they definitely could have kicked my ass.
author: Noah K.

description: JEEEZZE!!! How I miss this place. nothing comes close nationwide. I am currently living in NYC if anybody can show me anywhere that even comes close to this SF  gem of a take out history.
author: Adam H.

description: My #3 most favorite viet sandwich shop in SF. It use to be at the top spot but since the remodel and the place got cleaner the sandwiches isnt quite the same. Still an awesome place for sandwiches I recommend the combination and tofu sandwich.
author: Linda L.

description:
5 Star Rating on the sandwiches alone.

To me, nothing else matters.  I've been coming here since I was a teenager (34 now), and in all seriousness, this is the best Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever had, bar none.  Nothing else I have ever had can hold a candle to the sandwiches from this restaurant.

Do these sandwiches contain Adderall?  Once you take a bite, you seriously focus on nothing else but the next bite.  It gives you "tunnel vision" and for the entire time you're eating this sandwich, it feels like you're walking down the street with your iPod on blast because you just tune the whole world out.  There could be fire and police sirens going off and you wouldn't even notice.  You could jump out of an airplane with no parachute holding this sandwich, and I can pretty much guarantee you that all you will be thinking about is "Can I finish this sandwich before I hit the ground?"

My friends and I used to come here and order 4 sandwiches each.  We'd eat 2 right on the window counter and we'd take 2 home to eat later that day.

You simply cannot beat the prices, quality, and freshness of these sandwiches.

You will be amazed at the sheer speed and efficiency that these sandwiches are made.  It's a sight to behold.

Do NOT leave San Francisco without trying one of these sandwiches.

I live in AZ now, and all we have here is Lee's Sanwiches.  I go there because there is simply nothing else around here.  Sad isn't it?
author: Jose T.

description:
Great value for the money! 

The food is good, the two woman run kitchen moves pretty quickly, unless of course you're right behind a 40 sandwich office-lunch order!  

I love coming here every two weeks with my date. =) In fact, I will probably go here this coming Saturday for a quick bite. 

They don't have Diet Coke, which is disappointing, but whatever.
author: Emdeezy F.

description: By far, the best Vietnamese sandwich place I have ever had.  The meat is juicy and flavorful. Big sandwiches.  Lee's has nothing on this place
author: Caitlyn C.

description:
Yum!

Ridiculously cheap and quite tasty. I got a chicken banh mi without mayo and the sauce on the meat provided the perfect amount of flavor and moisture... so if you're not a mayo person like me, don't hesitate to order it without, it's still yum. The bread is really great too.

I've never been inside the place; coworkers pick them up for the office on occasion. They get 2 each because they don't fill up on one. While I don't think it's necessary to get 2, it's probably wise to get some kind of side if you'd like this to be a full sized lunch. 

Would give one more star if it was more convenient (online or phone ordering, etc.) and if there were more veggies in the sandwich.
author: Richa A.

description:
I'm surprised that I haven't reviewed this place before.

Don't worry about that line in front, it moves relatively fast. Having ventured to every banh mi joint in the TL, I have to say Saigon Sandwich is the best. (Them Ky coming in a close 2nd)

The sandwiches are always freshly made. I'm currently eating the roast pork. I can eat this everyday and at $3.25, I can afford to.

Verdict? Believe the hype.
author: John T.

description:
Just ate here with my bf on our last day in SF and I gotta say... I've never had a banh mi that has so much meat and veggies in it before!!! I got the cha and pate sandwich and it was so good!!! The pate is different from the ones I've tasted before. 
When I first got here there was no one in there and I was kind of surprised. But soon after I ordered there was a longggggg line after me. Phewww! Glad to end my trip with a nice and delish sandwich. Will def come back next time I'm in town!
author: Kim V.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is the best. For $3.50, you get a delicious banh mi from some of the most efficient and friendliest Asian ladies in the food services industry (that says a lot because my kind can get super irritable). 

The wait can be intimidating but it moves fast. You order first, get any other snacks/drinks that are out on the display and then pay when your sandwich is ready.

They've always been accommodating and unannoyed when I've had specific requests (i.e. extra jalapenos on the side or extra Sriracha).

It's in the straight up Tenderloin so if you're not street tough like me, it can be a daunting neighborhood (I once watched a hobo fight as I waited) but I assure you it's well worth it. I'm not sure if it'll change your mind if you've tried banh mi sandwiches before and didn't like it but I think it's a good banh mi to introduce someone to.

It closes at 5:30 which is a bummer but is open really early, which I guess would be good for early risers who want to get their sandwich before work.
author: K C.

description:
So good and the best banh mi that i have found/had in a while.  Yes, it's the sketchy Tenderloin neighborhood and I was approached a few times by drunkards, it didn't bother me.  

By BART - get off Civic Center and you need to walk towards Larkin.

By Car - Good luck as street parking is hit or miss.

This takeout joint has two seats facing the main street. Or you park yourself somewhere at a park or a bench near UC Hastings Law to grub on your delicious sandwich.

Crunchy/Crispy Toasted bread.
Good size.
A lot of carrots, cilantro toppings. They skimped a bit on the jalapeno but I don't really eat that anyways.

Prefectly pickled carrots.

I didn't see any daikon. I will need to ask for more next time.

Cha Lua was good. (pork patty)

Pate was even better. It was gushing with tasty pate goodness. So goood.


$3.75 and cash only.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I wouldn't say this is a  great sandwich place. I've been here twice and they are fairly cheap considering the rest of the area. They were cheaper before and now $.50 cheaper than everyone else; expect for those whom are trying to charge $4.00. 

The location is really bad, being in the bad parts of the Tenderloin. The place is so small, 5 people in line would start forming outside. Regulars do however get to cut in line. All they have to do is say hi to one of them and they will stop what they are doing and make their sandwich first. 

The sandwich itself is fairly decent, but also having hard bread as another yelper mentioned. I liked the roast chicken, but really didn't like the Pate. The stuff looked like mushed spam and tasted like chicken liver.
author: M C.

description:
Check out the photos because they are a great representation of what you'll get at Saigon Sandwich. 

This place is a "hole-in-the-wall", nonchalant, mom and pop store/eatery that is packed full of Asian snacks stacked against the floor, counter, window, etc.  The layout of Saigon Sandwich is like a small, narrow hallway: you only have room to move forward (to the counter) and backward (out the door).  Basically, it's a small store where the only thing you see are snacks, storage boxes (of snacks stacked up everywhere), a narrow counter (to order), piles of freshly made Vietnamese breads, snacks and rolls, and the window storefront.  

This isn't really a restaurant per se.  There are no sit-down, dine-in areas (except for two or three spaces near the window), and it's a place where the majority of people order sandwiches to go. 

We ordered the roast pork and the roast pork meatball.  We liked the roast pork meatball more because it was more flavorful and it was nice getting chunks of marinated meat rather than slices of meat (roast pork).  All the sandwiches are delicious.  

What makes this sandwich are a few things:

1)  They toast the French rolls (gives it a nice crunch; I don't think they make the breads by hand, but they're good, 10"-long French rolls);

2)  The pickled carrots, daikon and onions.  Sweet yet sour... delicious combination! 

3)  The marinade for the pork (or whatever meat you choose)-- it's savory and fills your mouth with yummy goodness.

4)  Generous stuffing of cilantro, pickled carrots and jalapenos. 

Good to the last bite!  The menu is simple-- a board with only a few selections of sandwiches.  Sandwiches are $3.25 each.
author: Sunny S.

description: Saigon Sandwich has the best roasted chicken sandwich ever. I don't know what the secret ingredient is but it's great. Keep up the good work... ;)
author: Maria P.

description: I can barely describe what it is about the sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich that makes them so delicious. Balance of ingredients and seasonings, fresh quick deliciousness, it's really a nearly perfect sandwich experience, and well worth trekking through the dangerous wilds of the TL to get to.
author: Sam Z.

description: $3.50 for warm, delicious banh mi. I had the tofu and companion had the pork. Both incredibly delicious.
author: Mickey M.

description:
LOVE this place!! I've been here before, but finally decided to write a review about it :) The sandwiches are delicious and they are STUFFED!! They really make sure you get your money's worth! It's cheap too, which is always good, especially when you're unemployed and/or only working a part-time job that pays minimum wage :T
I have yet to try some of their other snacks, like the desserts and drinks, but they look FANTASTIC! :D
I would recommend going earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon cause there's always a line out the door!
author: Kei H.

description: This sandwich shop widely contributed to my massive weight gain (3 years ago--yes, I frequented this place. A LOT or used to for that matter). If you read further reviews you will see why.
author: Kat Z.

description:
Definitely one of the best Banh Mi places in SF, and satisfies every bit of lunch time hunger for only a few dollars, AND serving those tasty refreshing vietnamese desserts too!

Ok so I had the Roast Pork and a Pate Banh Mi. The ROAST PORK....ZOMG sooooo tasty, filled up well with juicy scrumptious pork. YOU CAN'T Go wrong with this option...i just wanted MOREEE. The Pate alone is a little overwhelming, BUT i wish I had got a roast pork with pate combo to add some liver-y zing to that sweet sweet pork. Ok so the only thing that makes this a 4, not a 5 star, is that its missing stuff. Every Banh Mi I had throughout the stretches of Vietnam from Saigon to Hanoi had that laughing cow spreadable cheese it in. And that simply makes it amazing...BUT this place unfortunately leaves out the cheese. Along with a lil more fixins. Maybe you can request to add a little more, but those fixins can change a great Banh Mi into ZOMG fantasmagorical Banh Mi.

Either way, have a great thrifty lunch in the Tenderloin with this place, and grab those desserts (especially that pink one with coconut, nut stuff, and random gelatin pieces....mmmm......sooo good and deceptive to what all the ingredients are)...all for under $7 (including a drink)!
author: Nehal N.

description:
Upside: The sandwiches are very tasty, unique, and cheap ($3.25!) Suck on that whole foods asking for $7 for the same thing.

Downside: The neigborhood.
author: Ash S.

description: This place is worth the trip to tenderloin. Tenderloin is supposed to be the "bad" area of San Francisco but honestly I've lived there and I have never once in my life got mugged. You do however need to wear protective shoes and clothing because occasional syringe can be found in the area. But as far as the sandwich, this place is amazing! Very legitimate Vietnamese sandwiches. Awesome!!!
author: J C.

description:
OMG!!! The sandwiches here were AMAZING! 

They're the best ones I've had so far! Nice crispy bread, fresh ingredients and with each bite bursting with flavor! I'm drooling at the thought of it! I didnt even get my own sandwich hahha! My friends got it after a trip to turtle tower and I was too full to get anything....or so I thought! One bite had me going back for more! hmm hmm good!
author: Maggie C.

description:
Yup .... Da Best. ....  Banh Mi (that would be Vietnamese Sandwich)

Ok, if u never had one, try one..... Banh Mi ...(sounds like .  kinda like BANG ME...which should get some folks excited) originated w/hen the French ruled  in Vietnam. (oh, a long, long time ago, and they loved to say BANG ME and the Vietnamese said that sounds like Banh Mi). 
Not a history lesson, but for the self proclaimed sandwich foodies, ahhhh, point of fact, sandwiches are not a native/traditional food of S.E. Asia. 

It is sandwich exotica compared to the chain sandwich places. 
Pretty soon you will be hearing "Subway" & "Quiznos" saying "BANG ME" 

This is NOT a place where you say: "I would like the whole wheat bread, with Mayo on the top slice, light on the mustard, heavy on the onions. with just a dusting of pepper...." = just order your sandwich and get out of my way.

So, go, try, enjoy. All of the sandwiches are great: the roast pork, su mai (kinda like ground pork), chicken, zau (sp? pronouned zaw) (kinda like a Vietnamese lunch pork/beef lunch meat) (maybe someone fluent in Vietnamese can help me with that one).




.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Ugh, had some combo sandwich with my other 2 friends who found this on yelp. It was okay, reminded me of potted meat or liverwurst spread. But WE all woke up this morning with diarrhea! 

After I ordered my sandwich, i looked in their cold case and saw scary, rotting ingredients, then i prayed i wouldnt get sick....didnt work...

PLEASE BE CAREFUL AND BE CONSCIOUS OF WHERE YOU EAT!
author: Mario M.

description:
Had the tofu sandwich and was blown away by the cost to quality ratio. Quickly becoming my favorite sandwich shop in town. 
The sandwich is huge. The neighborhood isn't amazing, but that's life. No one is going to hurt you.
author: Benjamin S.

description: I thought I would never find my beloved again. I overcame my despair by doing fervent searches for places that sold Bahnmi, however that turned out to be much of a fools errand since there was tons of places that sold bahnmi. But I didn't want an imitator, I wanted my sandwich. The one I fell in love with on first bite. The tender roast chicken. The sweet sauce that is well spiced. The shredded carrots, the bright cilantro. I wanted the chewy bread. I wanted a sandwich so good that I would easily pay ten times their $3.50 asking price. A sandwich so epic I salivate writing about it. As a stroke of almost dumb luck, I clicked on a yelp entry and saw a picture of the green menu board with tacked in white letters and I knew it was my place. Siagon Sandwich is very much a to go place not far from the UN/Civic center station. The orders are simple and straight forward , not too many options on the menu so ordering is easy. I got my two sandwiches, one pork and one roast chicken. One sandwich is more than enough to be fulfilling if I was of average everyday hunger. Still the sandwich was severed up within a minute of my ordering and before I could even take the three steps from the counter to the door I was enjoying my first bite.
author: Zorin D.

description:
I wanted to try this place after hearing rave reviews from friends and finding it in "The 2010 Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die."

I didn't get the Vietnamese roasted pork sandwich, but the tofu was was delicious! I've never had a Vietnamese sandwich like that before. Although a bit pricy for a small sandwich, it was definitely filling and a good choice for sandwich lovers. 

If you're looking for a super fresh sandwich with crunchy bread, stop by here to satisfy your appetite. 

Bring cash and plan to eat on-the-go, because this quaint shop isn't meant for linger-ers.
author: Jules C.

description:
The only reason this place gets a 4 instead of a 5 is because sometimes when something is too cheap and too delicious, you know you don't want to know where the meat comes from.

That being said, this is the best bahn mi you will ever eat.  In your LIFE. And I am not exaggerating.
author: Christina C.

description:
These sandwiches have the components to an authentic vietnamese sandwiches, but they are more like "Vietnamese sandwiches with a Chinese flair." 

The COMBINATION (Roast pork, Cha Lua, and Pate) sandwich was good, the pate is delicious! The bread was fresh, crispy on the outside, and a little chewy on the inside. The pork is where these sandwiches turn Chinese. There is a lot of five spice in it, it also leaves the taste in your mouth after the sandwich is gone. The over all   taste of the sandwich is also sweet!?! Like I said, it was a good sandwich, just not authentic.
author: Diana L.

description: By far the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had! Try the special combination if you like pate.
author: Nhi P.

description: Lives up to the awesome ratings. I had the chicken banh mi and it was large, juicy, and cheap. The service was quick for noon on a Wednesday and too. Definitely will go back regularly.
author: Aakash D.

description: Nothing can be wrong with this place. It is simple, cheap and delicious. Just a counter order to go Vietnamese sandwich. Very good roasted pork and pate, the toasted baguette on right size and fresh. Came Saturday afternoon so not much people, my win.
author: Z G.

description:
I remember the first time I watched Ratatouille the female chef made a statement that you can tell good bread by the sound. The crunch of the crust has a distinctive sound and you can tell amazing bread the second your hands over against it.

That's the bread at Saigon Sandwiches. It has an amazing grain and such a perfect crunch when you bite into it. The shop is very efficient with two women working behind the counter. They take the orders of everyone in line and then make sandwiches constantly until those orders are all filled. Then they repeat the process. 

I ordered the pork sandwich, which was delicious and full of crisp pickled vegetables. The price has gone up recently ($3.25 for a sandwich now) but that still makes it one of the best deals around. With the perfect filling to crusty bread ratio, you don't mind standing in line for this fantastic sandwich.

It is the crust that makes the bread, after all.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Simply put, the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. Price, not as cheap as some 99-2 dollar sandwiches you may see in San Jose, but for the quality of these sandwiches, VERY well priced. They toast their bread, great meats, with great flavors.

I recommend ordering on the phone and just picking it up, parking around the area may be a little difficult. Location is small, but they also carry drinks and desserts you can buy to go. Highly recommend to try, you won't regret it.
author: Austin N.

description: Pretty damn good authentic Vietnamese sandwiches made by Vietnamese ladies. I made the trek through the shady streets of the Tenderloin district to find the highly touted banh mi and I was not disappointed.  You can't go wrong with a tasty, fresh and perfectly spicy pork sandwich for under $4.  The place is tiny and a hole in the wall as it should be so there is hardly any room to sit down.  Next time I will get more than one to go to enjoy later.  As far as cheap eats go this is a winner and definitely worth the trip to the T.
author: Dan C.

description:
First off, this is not good! I live a half block away from this tiny Vietnamese sandwich shop. Too close for something this delicious. My diet will now only consist of pork or meatball, and for 3 bucks it's totally possible. Whatever sauce they put in that magical dream of a sandwich makes me want more and more and more. 

I've always heard there were long lines but for some reason, me being the luckiest man in the world, went and didn't have to wait but more then 4 minutes for my sandwich. I loath the day i have to wait more then 30 minutes (i totally would). 
5 stars!
author: Randy M.

description:
Okay so I've been a pretty picky eater all my life, and while SF has helped expand my diet..there are a few things I still generally avoid. Like carrots. And for some stupid reason, this is why I've always avoided Vietnamese sammiches. Well yesterday at work, we decided to buy everyone sammiches (and I myself being broke and starving), decided to go along for the trip. 
There's always a line here from what I understand, the line doesn't make much sense. You can't quite tell who's already ordered, who has a phone order, or who is still waiting. But when a store is filled with goodies and only 2 chairs...this is pretty understandable! 
$3 a sammich. HOLY COW. That's pretty amazing. For ANYTHING to be $3 in this city is a miracle. 

The cilantro, the carrots, the onions, the jalapenos, the sauce and juice. WHOA. This sammich is amazing!

WHAT ON EARTH IS MY PROBLEM?! HAVE I REALLY HELD MYSELF BACK FROM HEAVEN?!

Never again, Lauren...Never again...
author: Lauren S.

description: Small little shop of a whole in the wall with quite a large customer base.  You're lucky if you walk by with no line, as it's constantly a line out the door for their Banh Mi sandwiches.  Prices have gone up and the variety selection has gone down over the years.  They've expanded their kitchen working area at the small expense of floor space for customers standing inside to outside so that the line is even longer outside now because there's even less standing floor space inside for customers.  There is counter seating space by the window for two people, else everyone takes their purchase to go.  The Banh Mi sandwiches are excellent, but I ask for mine, no cilantro, no peppers, as their peppers are spicy hot.  Great place for one of their sandwiches.
author: George L.

description:
When a place has just under 1400 reviews in counting, I can't help but wonder what the hell they're putting in those sandwiches to garner all the hype. After checking out the "San Francisco EATS" exhibit at the Main Library, I strolled through a few crackheads and johns to Saigon and picked up one of their Combination Banh Mis. 

The sandwich is what you'd expect out of your $3 Vietnamese sandwich; crusty bread, creamy pate, assorted veg, etc. As far as I'm concerned though, this Banh Mi isn't of the Earth shattering variety. Surely good if you need a quick, cheap lunch, but nothing to wait in line for, especially in the heart of the Tenderloin.
author: Christina N.

description:
Delicious sandwiches for less than $4, OK there a little small but get 2. I find 3 between 2 people about perfect.

Go early as they get BUSY!! Regularly the line stretches out the shop! but always moves quickly. They have a little sandwich production line going on in there!

It has been recently remodeled to allow more people inside, but still it is a tiny location.

Special Combination for the win! A must try in San Francisco!

They have lots of interesting snacks and drinks but so far I have never been able to resist the sandwich.
author: Chris M.

description: Pick up is the way to go here, super fast and awesome.  Sandwiches are filled to the max, not scimpin on the meat here.  Cheap and good two thumbs up.
author: Mike K.

description: Don't know what all the hype is here.. Bread was way too hard, it wasn't crispy or flakey and had a stale texture. I drove all the way to sf based on all the reviews and was hella disappointed. The pickled carrot and daikon hardly had any taste. Tried their grilled pork and meatball sandwiches both with pate, it had an odd "teriiyaki sauce" flavor, and was mediocre at best. Banh Mi Ba Le in Oakland is way better. Seems like everyone here just decided to jump on another typical sf five star bandwagon. OVER RATED!
author: Alex F.

description: LOOK !! How many reviews of Saigon Sandwich ? No kidding ! They make KICK ASS vietnamese sandwich ! My favorite is roast chicken. *drooling* :P
author: DontHurtMe T.

description: Seriously a good banh mi.  Lees is a great chain but this place is the real deal despite the sketch neighborhood.  I've eaten banh mi the "best" banh mi sandwiches in Orange County to Eden (Virginia) and this place tops the list.   There is no great Vietnamese place in manhattan.
author: Loc V.

description:
Oh man, can't believe I didn't yelp about this yet!
I've been coming here since a little kid and this was the first vietsandwich shop I knew of in sf and until this very moment... It's still the BOMB.  

I don't really like eating pork but their Pork sandwich is SO GOOD. 

the COMBINATION is my fave because I love pate in my sandwich, yeah yeah liver yeah.. i don't care, That stuff is delicious!

they give you loads of cilantro, carrots and jalapenos and the sandwiches are only about $3! Honestly, I would eat two if I could but you know them baguettes... after one sandwich, the top of your mouth is all scrapped up as if it were in battle. 

It's a TINY little shop so sometimes you get caught up waiting in line but it goes by significantly quick though if your impatient, you can always phone order and that saves you looking for parking.  

Great, now i'm craving for some saigon sandwiches...
author: Tiffany N.

description:
long due review.... 

I got a tasty meatball & pate sandwich from Saigon Sandwich in my quest for cheap eats. Meatballs were very flavorful as well as the pate. You get a nice kick from the jalapeno peppers and everything is balanced by the sweet-sour radish & carrot pickles. 

Wasn't a big fan of the mayo sauce though. Aside from that and if they slather a more generous portion of the yummy pate this is a champion sandwich! 

word of caution, I experienced the sketchiness of the TL firsthand while munching on my bahn mi in their tiny store front. Hello? A guy got mugged right across the street! 5 minutes later, here comes the SFPD for a chase. Exciting huh?
author: Gordon O.

description:
The first time I had a sandwich from here, the boyfriend personally hand delivered it to me on my lunch break at school. This time around, we decided to drop by after lounging around at Dolores Park to feed our stomachs for the next meal and the next 2 meals to come.

We came and picked up a few combination sandwiches. Luckily the line was very short (about 2 people ahead of us). The place here is tiny--it's like a hole in the wall shop with two ladies behind the counter making sandwiches and ringing people up. You can't go wrong with these sandwiches because 1.) the mayo and pate are both like crack. The pate is soft and fresh (unlike other sandwich shops that use pate that is obviously old--if you don't know what I'm talking about, you will after you try these sandwiches) 2.) The bread they use is a smaller baguette but toasted, so it's nice and crispy. 3.) The sandwiches are stuffed with tons of shredded carrots and sliced onions. 4.) If this doesn't seem good to you then you need to go for an eye exam.

Another cool thing about this place is that they carry a lot of different flavored Hi-Chew candies, and some of them are quite unusual. The boyfriend and I decided to pick up a banana flavored one and then we were on our way.
author: Lily Z.

description:
Whenever I'm in SF, I always stop in once or twice for their wonderful sandwiches.

When I can, I'll buy couple of extra to eat on the plane on the way home.

Wish we have something this good in Chicago.
author: Bill L.

description:
Great sandwiches, quick service.
We tried a bunch of different sandwiches and they were all tasty.
Yum
author: Adam M.

description: Am I eating what other yelpers are eating? The bread tastes old and is difficult to chew.  I thought I'd give it a 2nd try but got the same old thing.  It's worse than the baguettes bagged at the Walgreens.  The only reason I gave it 2 stars is the filling - they give you lots of it.  The picked carrots and daikon are good, but the roast pork and cha lua are tasteless.   I'd just eat the filling, but then I wouldn't be eating a bahn mi, would I?
author: Bee Z.

description: Om nom nom nom :) I don't know what they put in their banh mi (cocaine? haha, kidding!) but they are so delish. I've never had to wait in line long because I've never been there during peak lunch hours. Only downside: there is nowhere to sit and enjoy your sandwich since it is a teeny tiny store. Since it is located in the TL, the safest place to consume this wonderful loaf of heaven would probably be in the car with the doors locked. Remember, DOORS LOCKED.
author: Audrey T.

description:
Best banh mi I've had so it definitely deserves the hype as 'gourmet' sandwich shops have yet to do better.

Full size sandwich with french bread is crunchy and the ingredients are moist and flavorful. At $3.50 for a really good sandwich, I don't know how to not rave about it. Just simple ingredients and good execution.

The roast pork is definitely my favorite and with the lack of good food options in the Civic area I'm glad they're here!
author: Sam H.

description:
Went today for the first time in a long time.  Last I came here was back in 2008 and man have they changed!!

First, there was a long line outside the door which I wasn't used to.  I guess after that New York Times article about it being the best Bahn Mi in America it picked up a bit.  I'll say!

In 2008, they were very hole-in-the-wall; run down looking, but I mean, if it's a good sandwich, I don't really care.  But, I'm not surprised they got shut down for a while.  They look 1 MILLION times better now and more clean.  I actually trust the cleanliness now, which is good (for others more than me).  

As far as the food:  Delicious!!  Oh man, best Bahn Mi I've ever had.  Much better than Lee's across the street, and well worth the wait.  Though, if I didn't live in the neighborhood, It'd be kind of annoying that I could (realistically) eat there.  There's only "4" seats, all crowded, where people stand to wait.

The Bad:  The good far outweighs the bad.  Mainly, since there're only limited choices, and a lot of people order the same thing, as I waited, it felt like people passed by me and got my order.  By the time I was done, it was a completely different crowd than when I started, and I'm pretty sure people who got there after me got my same order before I did.  This wouldn't be as bad, if it didn't seem that they would really care.  The lady ordering was so busy that it was almost strangely pretentious service.  With all the dough they have to make all day with a constant line, you'd think they'd think of opening a bigger location soon?  (Please?  Or more locations?)  


All in all, the minor annoyances of crowdedness, weird service, and location, this place still gets 4 stars, because it's just that good.  

I really wish they'd open more locations though, for their sake!  This place is too good!!

And soooooo cheap!!!
author: Jon O.

description:
How can you not love Vietnamese sandwiches. They are delicious and cheap. 

This is a little cramped hole in the wall on the edge of the TL with two tiny little women behind the counter. A counter which is piled high with vietnamese desserts, so high you almost don't see the ladies behind the counter. There is also a fridge packed to the gills with drinks both american and asian. And right behind you little shelved piled high with chips and such.

Their sandwiches are awesome here...cheap, filled with pork, cilantro, picked carrots and soo yummy. 

For less than $20 my son and I walked out with 3 sandwiches, a couple of drinks, chips, and some sort of banana based dessert. I love trying desserts. We will definitely be back to try the other pork sandwiches they have.
author: Maria M.

description:
Expectations are a funny thing...I have been hearing about Saigon Sandwiches for some time now.  How it's the best banh mi in town.  My first attempt at coming here was derailed by the extremely long line out the door.  It was a rainy day and I opted to go to Lee's instead.  Despite the negative reviews of Lee's, I really have liked all the Lee's I've been to.

Tonight I finally got into Saigon with nary a line.  I was excited finally try the deliciousness that was promised me.  Sadly, I think my expectations ruined it for me.  It wasn't bad, don't get me wrong.  It was fine.  But I was expecting something magical...and was left feeling disappointed.

All in all, I actually prefer Lee's...I know it's probably sacrilege to many of you but that is my honest to God review of this place.
author: Melanie N.

description:
I absolutely love love this sandwich spot. I grew up with Saigon Sandwich. My mom would buy our sandwiches here before heading to Chinatown to grocery shop. I've had everything on their menu at least once but my favorite is the grilled chicken. 

They get super busy during lunch times on weekdays but I love how they get you in and out so quickly. The ladies are quick. 

CASH ONLY!!
author: Serena F.

description:
This place is out of control. 
I only eat the tofu sandwich, but it's so insanely delicious, I *crave* it.
Don't be intimidated by the line outside, it moves fast because the ladies inside work absurdly hard.

Also, the sandwiches are $3.75. Ridiculously cheap.
There are only two chairs, so plan to eat these cylinders of joy somewhere else.
author: Katy H.

description:
I used to frequent Saigon Sandwich. My roomies and I would drive in from the Sunset to get sandwiches. I had a meeting at City Hall this afternoon, I skipped lunch, and picked up a sandwich after the meeting. I couldn't leave the Tenderloin without one. 

It saddens me that my current roommate has never had one of these heavenly sandwiches: chicken, special sauce, onions, cilantro, carrots and JALAPENOS. 

I've tried a few other places, but this is still the best.

I noticed that my old review had the price at $2.25, it's now $3.00. Still a great deal.
author: Melissa A.

description:
This is my favorite place in SF to get Banh Mi sandwiches. The roasted pork is what I used to get, but since trying the Roasted Pork with Páte, I don't think I can go without the Páte if that's an option. I have tried quite a few Bahn Mi from many different parts of SF, even "gourmet" Banh Mi. None even come close in my opinion to how well the flavors and textures mesh in the Roasted Pork and Pate combo from Saigon Sandwich. 

The  others range from pretty good to even bad. I didn't think it was possible for a Banh Mi to be bad until I had one. I've thought about buying an extra Banh Mi from Saigon Sandwich just to bring to the other place and saying "This is how it's supposed to be! Why can't you make it like this?!!!!" The only reason I've considered this is because I love Banh Mi so much, and the other place is close to my studio, while Saigon Sandwich is a bit out of my way. I have seriously craved their sandwiches for days, and  because I just couldn't take it anymore, made the journey out to their tiny dive of a shop. I don't work anywhere near the Civic Center, so going that direction is specifically for them.

There seems to be quite a few people that don't think it is anything too special, so I guess they have had even better Banh Mi somewhere else. That somewhere else seems to NOT be in SF, so that being said, this is where I will continue to come. The price is great, and the sandwich is always satisfying- crunchy soft bread, creamy Páte, savory roasted pork, tangy marinated veggies, and a kick from the jalapeno. What's not to like?Delicious!
author: CJ W.

description:
super good. super cheap. what more can you ask for??  
came over with a friend for a late lunch...we had perfect timing...people started to pile in right after we got our orders. special combination all the way!! soooo good. 
judging by all the people waiting in line and the one lady who ordered 28 bahn mis and my taste buds doing a happy dance just by thinking about those bahn mis....this place is legit!
author: Carol C.

description:
What?! A lunch for $3.50 in San Francisco? 

Alright, I found these guys through my trusted Zagat guide, which raved about the food. They're right on there - Saigon Sandwich definitely makes a 5-star roasted pork bahn mi. 

So this 3-star review is about the neighborhood. Yes, it's the Tenderloin, but I literally felt scared walking there from my place. And that was in broad daylight, wearing my leather jacket and tough shades.

My advice: try to find a way to get this food without spending a lot of time in the area....
author: Josiah M.

description: This is just an other over hyped place like others in Yelp. Their sandwich is clearly not something phenomenal at all! How do I know? Because I am a Vietnamese myself.
author: Tai V.

description:
its NOT a Huge Sandwich...to some people...the bread might be considered too hard for a french roll.  But its a true french roll...really hard.

its ONLY 3.25!  Its GOOD.  Its got a little bit of spice its got fresh tasting ingredients.

Its cheap it tastes good.  its quick and easy.  I say go with the roast pork.  This is tied for my favorite vietnamese sandwich to go with the place in Cache Creek which serves a really good fresh sandwich also.

parking can be easy but about half a block away.  not a huge selection of things...really 4 sandwiches, chicken, pork, fancy pork(don't know what that is yet), and pate.  Then two other things on the menu but i'm all about the Vietnamese Sandwich.  again for 3.25 you get something good.
author: Bing D.

description:
"You're gonna have to switch rooms..." her voice was harsh and prissy. Just what you want to wake up to after a night of hard drinking.
"Excuse me?" I roll over, groggy, mouth a dry dessert of tumbleweeds stomach acidic and tumbling in on itself.
"Your snoring," she spits, "It kept everyone awake, you know you do it so you're gonna wanna switch rooms."
What in the fuck is this? Yes. I snore. But look bitch you are sleeping in a communal dorm room in a hostel for 35$ a night. I am legit sorry if I kept you up but if you don't like it go stay at the fucking Hilton where you have recourse to make demands of people that may keep you awake. I inform her I'm going nowhere and perhaps she should move. She storms out. The Irish roll over. "What the hell?" one chimes... None of them were kept awake by my snoring and they tell me she actually woke them up in her attempts to get me to shut up. I don't remember that happening and I find it quite funny.

Lucky girl though, I am switching rooms as per my reservation which is now magically in the system. I upgrade - Ha! - to a 4 bed dorm. I'm joking, this isn't an upgrade, but it does cost $4 more a night. I move my stuff and have a shower before.. Free breakfast! Woo...

Oh. It's a few loaves of bread a couple bagels and cream-cheese and preserves. I opt out. I want something really really good in my slightly hungover state. Only one thing will do and I will track it down.

Banh fucking Mi!

Given that it's closing in on 1pm I feel banh mi for breakfast is gonna be just fine so I head out the door  in search of the Saigon Sandwich. I track it down about 15 blocks away. Another line of people snake out the door. This is a good thing. Locals order in groups of 5 or so as 2 women slap the sammies together at lightning speed. 6 or 7 options plus a few of those cold glutinous rice in leaf deals are on offer as well as the strange Vietnamese desserts that I always avoid. Simple choice, I ask a local which is best. Chicken|? OK. I usually go with pate and cold cuts but I trust her and grab a chicken. With a tall cold can of coconut water my wallet is only $5 lighter.

No seating in-house I head down the street to a nice little square outside a large bank looking building and dig in. Astounding. As good as the best in Vancouver. Perfect crusty flaky outside bun with a chewy inside holding generous portions of meat and wonderfully crisp pickled carrot jalapeno and cilantro... Aand the sauce. Wow, the sauce. It drips on my jeans and I curse at the waste. I care not for stains at this point I just want every ounce of this sweet sweet food inside of me. I chase each delicious bite with the coconut water with chunks of coconut meat in it. As quick as I started and I was done. Satiated and a bit remorseful I sit for a minute in the sun, contemplating my next move. I know I want tacos but I won't be hungry for a few hours. I need to find something to do. 

Looking up I see a beautiful Beaux Art building. It's the Asian Art Museum and there is a current exhibition called Phantoms of Asia. Contemporary Asian artists examining spirituality within their culture. Cool. I think I found a way to kill a few hours after that amazing start to the day
author: Christopher N. W.

description:
I'm a student from Brazil and it was my first Vietnamese sandwich: I'm addicted! 

The bread is crunchy, the roast pork is very juicy, and the sweet sauce gives life to these sandwiches! Maybe the secret relies on the fresh cilantro. 

I ordered to-go, paid US $ 3.5 and enjoyed walking around in Civic Center as a bonus.  Not bad for a foreign student.
author: Alida G.

description:
Today was the second time I decided to try this place. Right when I walked up to the side of the store, there was already about 5 people in line for a small hole in the wall place. 

  To my surprise, one of the workers took everyone's order down all at once and everything came out pretty fast. 

  I decided to order the roast pork sandwich, but after receiving my sandwich and the person after me order a "special combination" I was bitter because I figured a special combo would be so much more delicious. 

  The price for the sandwiches are definitely worth it, I think rounding up its only $4, probably it was $3.75. I definitely need to come back here again.
author: Pudgy G.

description: Great tasting fresh sandwiches that are quick to pick up.  The meat was good quality and the bread was all warm and toasty.  It's a decent sized sandwich.  The ladies here have a process down and can handle the crowds quite well.  There isn't really anywhere to sit so plan on picking up a few of these and heading elsewhere to eat them.  I'll be back!
author: K L.

description:
just as tasty as my first in 2000 when i was working at the California Culinary Academy

Bahn Mi Pate is complex and peppery juxtaposed with sweet pickled carrots onions, fragrant cilantro, & thinly sliced jalapeno on a crispy roll
author: Paul N.

description:
Food = 5. Location (in the  sketchy sketch of the Tenderloin) brings it down to 4.5

Wow. The bread is crunchy and soft. The meat is tender. The hot peppers provide the perfect kick. And the sauce they use is liquid crack. Absolutely delicious.
author: Vickie C.

description:
tiny place with excellent vietnamese sando's: filled with bbq pork, cilantro, jalapeno pepper slices on french roll. yummy. Terrific price too. We usually leave a couple dollars as a tip, how can they make any money? too bad, they don't sell frosty cold ones.
today 11/08/07, went back for the Meat Ball sandwich--- yummy. 
The slice of jalapeno brings sweat to my forehead. Had to remove my cashmere sweater! oh btw, price increase to $2.50 for a deelicious sandwich.  Still hard to believe they make any money.
author: Bert K.

description:
I like how their sandwich taste and I like the price!

This place taste much better than other sandwich shops on Larkin.  They have the right amount of meat, pickled carrots, and jalapeno slices.  

The ladies are nice quick!  They make your sandwiches after you place an order.  FYI, they taste better if you eat them right after being made.  If not, the bread get soggy from the veggie and meat juice.
author: Chie J.

description:
I am a serious Banh Mi addict, and I was used to paying approx. $3.00 CAD per sandwich in Montreal. Having moved here, I quickly discovered that the city DOES sell them but you need to go looking.

Saigon sandwich is funny. It's a true hole in the wall, and has only two ladies working there. One preps the bread, and the other stuffs it with the meat, pickled vegetables, and the cilantro and hot peppers.

Thus far, they have been the best Banh Mi I've had in the city, and certainly the cheapest. $2.75 per sandwich. I ate two yesterday for lunch and I had a serious post-lunch coma after...one plus a side should typically be enough to feed one person. 

In conclusion, if they were located closer to downtown (and less in the heart of the tenderloin), I'd probably eat them every day.
author: Jordan C.

description:
For a Vietnamese sandwich, this place definitely deserves 5 stars. Once you take that bite into the Banh Mi (vietnamese sandwich), it makes you crave for more. Even finish just one, you feel like you want to get another one. It's just that good of a Banh Mi. There is no better place!

Yeah, the place doesn't look that clean, a hole in the wall. There's the Lee's sandwich shop up the block, which also sells Banh Mi, but it's is not the same. If you know how to eat, you don't really care what the place looks like. 

There's no room to eat here, you need to eat somewhere else.

The line is long sometimes, but it gets by fast. Whatever, just go get a vietnamese sandwich here and you'll know what I'm talking about.
author: Loi L.

description:
PROS:  Best vietnamese sandwich in SF! Rock bottom prices!
CONS:  On the outskirts of the Tenderloin.  Wait can be a problem, especially when government offices unload for lunch.
author: Brian C.

description: Been here more than a few times now.  It's really good and they're very generous with sandwich fillings, but I only wish they'd make the sandwich more neatly!  A surprising glob of pate can be unkind to my "healthy side".  I think a better constructed sandwich, in terms of ingredient distribution, can go a long way!  Not really sure why there's always a line though, because it's not THAT good.
author: Christopher L.

description: An incredible sandwich for $3.75, this has got to be one of the best deals in the country. They close at 5 (and sometimes a bit early) and you can expect a line at lunchtime. The women running the show might seem disorganized and/or a bit salty, but they are right on. The fridge is full of outrageous drinks and desserts. Cash only. Go for the roast dark meat chicken or roast pork and ask for a squirt of hot sauce!
author: A C.

description:
This is my favorite place to get a Vietnamese sandwich so far. I haven't found a place that I like more! I used to like Little Paris..what was I thinking?! Anyways, the sandwiches here are flavorful and moist. I usually tell them to hold the mayo on my sandwich since the meat, carrots, cilantro, and a slice of jalapeno (it gives the sandwich a kick, but tell them if you don't want it in there; otherwise it's included) are enough for me. Oh, and they warm up the bread too.

The place is really small, definitely not a place for you to sit down to eat and talk with a friend (there's only two chairs facing the window); more of a  to-go place. The price went up a bit since the last time I was here; it's a little over $3 for a sandwich now..
author: Am Y.

description:
best bahn mi for me and the price is right to boot. Been known to put down a roast pork and steamed/roast pork combo in one sitting! Also love to get the coconut sticky rice wrapped in banana leaf

This is a place that does one thing and does it right. Great bread. Perfect pickled veg. Tasty, juicy pork. I love you, SS!
author: trvs l.

description:
I'm kind of hungry right now and craving a Vietnamese roast pork sandwich from Saigon Sandwich.

Warm, crusty bread, savory roast pork, pickled carrots, fresh parsley and spicy jalapenos to add a little kick -- a perfect combination.
author: Lis A.

description:
I've been frequenting this spot since I was a wee one. On a bad day, I get a sandwich here. On a good day, I get one. If I'm in the area, I get one.

It's fabulous when it's fresh and fabulous cold as well when the warm fresh bread has absorbed some of that delicious sauce so that the bread is a bit soggy which is a lovely contrast to the delicious pickled carrots which is almost my favourite part if I had to pick a favourite.

I remember when I came back from Chile, the only thing I requested was a sandwich from here and my mother got me 2. Scarfed it down even though I was sick. Can't say it cured me, but it was an excellent welcome home meal.
author: Deanna L.

description:
Holy crap - $3.25 for a D-licious viet-sando?! Are you kidding me?

It was a bit of a walk from my office, but man was it worth it. I had the 'fanci pork' or as we call it, 'crazy pork' and the grilled pork. The bread wasn't too crunchy or toasted, so it didn't hurt the roof of your mouth too much, but that sauce was oh so sweet and tasty. I'd go here again.
author: David N.

description: BEST BAHN MI EVER. And it's super cheap. I LOVE this hole in the wall...and if you are wondering, ugh do I really want to go to the tenderlion? the answer is YES, you do . I'm a veggie, so I've only ever had the tofu, which they cook perfectly, but my bf loves their pork too.
author: Ana Y.

description:
I risk my safety going to the tenderloin just to get these sandwiches. This is my favorite vietnamese sandwich place, hands down. I can't recommend one thing on the menu because it's all very delicious and I've eaten through their menu more than once. 

If you're in San Francisco and you happen to be in the neighborhood, stop by for a delicious sandwich at Saigon Sandwich!
author: Sara B.

description:
By far the best banh mi sandwich I've ever had.

Whenever I make my way to San Francisco, I try my best to pass by this hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese sandwich shop. I find the best food comes from these kinds of restaurants. While the ambiance, service, and location each have their say to the overall dining experience, for me, at the end of the day, the food is what matters the most.
 
Anyways, back to the review: It's best to go here fairly early or towards closing time, because lunch is ridiculously busy and the line is long.

Inside, it's a small shop with two window seats, and thats it. The Asian ladies behind the counter are working in tightly cramped quarters, but the sandwiches they produce here are nothing short of amazing. 

I recommend the pork meatball banh mi. The bread is perfect: crunchy on the outside, chewy on the inside, and the sandwich itself is flooding with juicy, generous slices of succulent pork meat, crisp pickled carrots, fresh daikon, and cilantro.

Oh, the harmonious dance these flavors play on your taste buds...

Stop by Saigon Sandwich and try it for yourself.
author: Peter G.

description:
Location: Little Saigon near Civic Center...........ummm sketchy
Ambiance: standing room only
YUM: meatball!! absolutely delicious
Bottoms Up: sodas, water, and juices in the cold box
Service: fast like lightning 
Notes: the best banh mi!!!

Eat it. Love it. Repeat.
author: Jenna s.

description:
I am about just done eating one of their chicken sandwiches again and it is about time to write a review.
I was afraid that after being closed for remodeling all of last month, the amazing quality and low prices would change. Not at all!

The only difference now is that the place now looks cleaner and more inviting, and you can see all 3 ladies that are working there instead of only the cashier :)
When they were closed I started getting sandwiches from a nearby place, and even though they were good, it's nothing compared to Saigon sandwiches!
So much goodness for less than 4 bucks.... there, you can have your 5 stars.
author: Vithiet L.

description: Delicious, filling and cheap! I walked over from #javaone and picked up a pork sandwich.
author: Chris R.

description:
What? Overrated. If you are used to San jose type Vietnamese sandwiches then I don't think you will be extremely impressed by this. 
I give it credit though, the bread is very crunchy and fresh ingredients! Only few items on menu so you don't have to get too confused when figuring out what to order
author: Veranna N.

description: A good sandwich, but (and this isn't going to make much sense) it was almost too nice. The pork is fresh roasted, shredded pork. I'm used to my Vietnamese sandwiches having that processed pork on them, and I guess I've grown partial to it. Some people have commented on the amount of mayo, and yes it was also more than I've had on any other sandwich, but it didn't detract from the taste of the sandwich. The sandwich is very sizable, and more than worth the cost. Honestly, I'm not sure how those ladies are staying in business charging so little. I got the pork sandwich, adding pate, and a coconut water for a little over $5. I was super full for the rest of the afternoon. Definitely worth the money and no legitimate complaints.
author: Chancy F.

description:
I'm late to this banh mi exclaim, but the location (not in the best part of the City) and hours (closes at 5PM; note the location) here have made it hard to get to until recently...

At a quick look at old reviews, it seems the prices have gone up and the ingredients have lessened.  
BUT, at any rate, two sandwiches (roasted chicken and meatball) for $6.50 is still a good deal AND they are pretty tasty. My mouth, tummy, and my wallet were all happy :)

Take-Away: I'm making a note to make a stop and grab (either the roast chicken or pork; pass the meatball) whenever I'm by the area!
author: Carol K.

description:
I don't know why I wake up every morning craving a Vietnamese sandwich...

I don't know why I go to bed every night craving a Vietnamese sandwich....

I finally got the chance to check this place out and let me just say that it was TOTALLY WORTH IT. No wonder this place has 1000+ reviews! It truly is a gem in the heart of the TL. Not in the safest or cleanest of neighborhoods, but definitely worth checking out.

-Roasted Pork (WOWZAAA!) 
-Chicken (AMAZING!)

Silly of me... I forgot to check-in. Darn. MUST GO BACK TO CHECK IN :) muhaha
author: Sandra P.

description: This was the first stop on my tour de food SF, and it was an awesome way to start. I got the chicken bahn mi, and it was fantastic. The chicken was deliciously juicy and marinated in some really good stuff. It almost tasted like char siu, which I used to loved when I ate pork. *sigh* I wish we had something like this around where I live, but I guess I'm just gonna have to come back to San Francisco and make room for one of these sandwiches every time.
author: Kristine K.

description: Definitely one of the best bahn mis ever! Reasonably priced too! The roast pork is my favorite.
author: Angela W.

description:
Are all Vietnamese Sandwich about the same???? NOPE!!!!

~~~ Thanks Yelpers!!!! ~~~

Weekdays or weekends.. morning, afternoon or later.. it doesn't matter. There's always some sort of line or crowd. Oh, parking isn't easy either. So why bother? Because the sandwich is that good to go through all that trouble for.

I was dropped off to order the roasted pork sandwich. There were a few people standing around, but don't be fooled, they may not be waiting to place an order, but to wait for their sandwich. Kindly ask and make your way through. There are two ladies behind the counter. One that takes your order and mulla while the other one prepares the sandwich. After submitting your order, the wait can be roughly about 15 mins. until you get yours... that is if there is no big order ahead of you.

The bread was crunchy and soft. The best part about biting into the bread is that it doesn't cut the inside of your mouth. The bread breaks off nicely. The roasted pork was tender and tasty. The veggies are just enough. The jalapenos give it a kick.

Price: About 3-4 bucks

Parking: YUCK! Good luck!

Service: Order your stuff and leave them alone.

P.S. ~ I've made multiple stops here.
author: Kaycie Y.

description: Good, cheap sandwiches and located really close to UOP. I used to come here all the time for lunch when I had a short time frame between classes. I really like the eggrolls here.. I think the taro in them makes them extra savory. Yummm.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Best banh mi. Dirty little sandwich store with a long line.

I don't even like coriander leaves that they use in the sandwich but I couldn't help myself but to finish the whole sandwich. Normally, I would spend my time picking those leaves out and throw them away but for this banh mi, I do not dare to mess up with what's inside. The combination is so perfect - that sting on my tongue, the crunchy bread, the savory meat... it's just too perfect for me to name there is one ingredient that should be left out of the sandwich.

ps: should I even mention that these goodness are cheap?
author: Cliff T.

description: Great sandwich at an easy price!
author: Virginia T.

description: I used to always go here as a child and I am surprised I never wrote a review for this place. I have tried everything on the menu and I can say without a doubt that the meatball sandwich, well under $4.00, is the best Vietnamese sandwich I have ever tried. The store is run by only women from what I saw growing up. The prices have raised slightly, going up to $3.25 a piece. The price point is amazing, the ingredients are fresh, and this shop has a line everytime I see it. Would highly recommend if you are near the area.
author: Johnson J.

description: Yassss. Finally a spot comparable to Saigon Vietnamese in NY. The combo here is especially generous with the paté and their "ham", both plain and fancy, seem less artificial than most. Great bread. Crusty and soft AT THE SAME DAMN TIME. Go here! The ladies are super friendly and didn't even give me the judgey mom glare for my pum pum shorts. Hooray. I'm gonna go ahead and check the "Classy" box below.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
I finally made it here after years of hearing about their sandwiches, and I'll probably be shouted down by folks who say these are the most authentic, but maybe I caught them on an off day - hmmm ... First, I found the bread to be a bit too crunchy or toasty. I don't like that feeling of having the sharp edges hurt the roof of my mouth (like Cap'n Crunch when it hasn't soaked in milk long enough). Then, it was soft inside which was nice, but it didn't particularly have that much flavor.

I had the chicken, but I thought that the sauce was too sweet, and though the chicken was tender, it wasn't BBQ'ed enough - too much like it had been just boiled or steamed and slathered with the sauce.

I'll give them points for fresher carrots and peppers, but for me the carrots were too firm and the peppers too hot.

Lastly, the sandwich was on the small side. I feel like I've had sandwiches out there with more filling for the same price, but it was still a steal at $3.25.

Final verdict - if someone else was dying to go, I would join her/him, but otherwise, I wouldn't make a special trip. Makes me really miss Little Paris in the Inner Richmond (haven't been to the Chinatown one). And no, I don't like Lee's, either.
author: Myla A.

description:
I wish I could got be overwhelmed like everyone else was. Seriously. I wanted this place to blow my mind because of all the reviews. I've been eating banh mi since I was a wee one so I can say I've had my fair share. It was good, but not mind blowing great! Especially for the long line.

I honestly think it may be because I had to wait to go home and eat it since there is no place to eat inside. By the time I got home it lost it's freshness. And they put a shit ton of mayo. I love mayo, but this was dripping in mayo O_O.
author: Sunie K.

description:
Every time I go here, I always get at least three sandwiches.  You would think that I would be sharing with other people...BUT NO! They're all mine, all of them.  I always get at least two meatball and two chicken.  My new favorite sandwich is tofu.  Don't get me wrong, I am a big meat eater.  But I love me some tofu.  Come fried or soft.  Plus each sandwich is 3 bucks, so I don't feel bad about buying four sandwiches (which sometimes is the price an average lunch downtown). 

Yes, this place does get busy.  I've only had to wait in line once.  I've learned to only come during non-lunch hours.  It's also easy since they open at 6AM.  Not that you'd find me there in the buttcrack of dawn noshing on a sandwich.  They ladies back there are super nice and hardworking as hell.  They don't even look stressed when there's a line out the door.  

This is probably the only place I would go to in the Tenderloin. I always brace myself before I step foot in crackhead land.  And yes...I do eat more than one in one sitting.  I am not ashamed. :D
author: Lisa X.

description: Vietnamese sandwich is all about the pate and this place put in lots of it.  Pate is not greasy filled with fat.  I heard it came out of a can.  But it's a good can.
author: Byron L.

description:
The first time I came here, I went with a Vietnamese friend of mine, who raved about the banh mi sandwich ... across the street.  So we ended up picking up sandwiches from both places for a side-by-side comparison.

There's no denying it.  The one from Saigon Sandwich has no equal!  First, the bread roll is perfectly toasted on the outside with a delicate soft inside.  The meat (pork) was comparable but what makes the banh mi here stand out are the pickled carrots (much more flavorful than the rather bland carrots in the other sandwich).  Even my buddy reluctantly acknowledged its overall superiority of the sandwich (hahaha).

So I was in the neighborhood this past weekend and jumped at the chance to stop by.  This time, we ended up with pork and fancy pork banh mi.  While both were amazing, I prefer the latter (more juicy and bursting with flavor).

Definitely the best $3.25 lunch option anywhere.  Never doubt the consensus view of a thousand Yelpers.
author: F. P.

description:
The bread & butter of this place is supposed to be their sandwiches (banh mi), but dude ... the bread is missing a lot of butter cause it was hard like a rock. It hurt my mouth to eat it. When it hurts to eat, it's hard to enjoy the food. The pork/meat mix and spread along with the cilantro and shredded carrots in the middle were fairly standard to what I've eaten.

A good-great banh mi would at the least consist of bread that crackles and flakes a little when pressure is applied to get the size small enough to fit into my mouth. The the shell (corners/edges, and rounded areas) of the bread should crackle as easily and consistently as the main body of the bread ... which means the inner part of the bread should have a nice warm fluff. Most importantly, the temperature of the bread should be warm to my taste, with the meat slightly warmer than all else. If the meat is hot, then the carrots should be at a cold and slightly moist setting to help alleviate the temperature imbalance. When I bite into the banh mi, the texture of the bread should allow me to capture all components equally. 

I can fathom and have eaten much better Vietnamese sandwiches than what's available here @ Saigon Sandwich. As for the eating area? It's almost non-existent. 

There are only 3 chairs here, and there could be more real estate to eat on the dashboard of my Honda Civic, than on the shelves available here. Yes, shelves, not tables... Also, 3 chairs doesn't mean the place will seat 3 comfortably. It's more like 2 comfortably because of the L-shaped design of the counter/shelves and it's respective positioning. Btw, I ate standing up because there was no way I could sit on the 3rd chair that was on the corner and pinned between my gf and another customer. 

The seating is something I can overlook because as a kid, eating while standing was for rookies ... I used to eat a stick of BBQ pork while walking and grocery shopping.

p.s. it's $3.75 for a sandwich that's as big as a 6-inch from subway.
author: Robert Z.

description:
Best deal ever!!! Quick, cheap and fast! I checked out this place because it was recommended by Frommers Guide for San Francisco. If you are not a fan of Vietnamese sandwiches, this place will turn your attitude around.

Honestly I am not sure if it was the price or the fast service, but compared to the places around-I would surely return to this place for another sandwich

WARNING: There are Jalapenos in the sandwich! I was so distracted by the overall aroma and taste that I suffered through the intense burning of Jalapeno.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I rarely write reviews on Banh Mi shops because I must've tried every single shop in Little Saigon.  Rarely does one stand out, but I definitely don't mean that in a bad way since the beauty of stiff competition means awesome food.  Suffice it to say, Saigon Sandwich would definitely fit in in LIttle Saigon just fine.

I ordered:

1.  Pork sandwich:  4 STARS.  
2.  Mung bean/tapioca dessert (che dau xanh): 5 STARS
====================
$5.00

The bread was just the right crispiness on the outside and softness on the inside.  The meat is definitely juicy.  What I enjoyed above all though was the Che Dau Xanh.  This is one of my favorite Vietnamese desserts ever, and there's something about Saigon Sandwiches' that was extra yummy.  We saved some for the morning after a long night of drinking....and wow!  Keep it cold, and it will be the most refreshing thing in the world when you're *nutrient deprived*.
author: Thu N.

description: In my opinion, Saigon Sandwich is still the best banh mi San Francisco has to offer.  Meatball and combination are my default selections. Add 25 cent more to get pate on sandwiches that don't have it already.
author: Allen T.

description:
This place wasn't as packed as it usually was today when I arrived around 2pm in the afternoon. This isn't my first time, but it was my first time trying the Xui Mai Sandwich aka Meatball sandwich. It's funny because in Cantonese Xui Mai means Shu Mai the dimsum! 

The rolled was toasty and cripsy..mmm...I was craving this 2am last night! So I had to come here today. The sauce was yum too! I think I must of bit into a jalapeno seed because that shit was hella spicy!! But I survived. The sandwich was $3.25 I think. It used to be way cheaper, but I had to satisfy my craving!

This place is SMALL, literally. But it's cute and it's authentic. I love the TL and their Vietnamese food!
author: Alice Z.

description: This place is straight amazing.  If they had Lee's Sandwiches bread they would easily be the best Banh Mi in the city.
author: Nico O.

description: Haha, just had to check out this place- tiny Vietnamese shop with famed sandwiches. Just down the street from the Asian Art Museum, stopped in for a bite. It's a bit chaotic, so its helps to know the system. The menu's on the wall, make some decisions by the time you need to order (not always possible when it gets super crowded.) They take orders in small groups (5-10 small orders at a time), the rest- wait in line. Know your order (and possibly the person who was in front of you) they shout out the order when done- which can be several bbq pork sandwiches, was it yours? Grab your bevvie of choice when you get rung up, so its calculated in total. Lastly, get out of there- everything's to go my friend, it's a sandwich shop not a cafe. You want some where to sit, there's some nice grass in front of city hall. Or if you prefer not to wait, you can go to the commercialized chain Lee's and get a sandwich there for the same price ($3.50), a slightly longer bun, but slightly less tasty, with less meat and veggies, but with a table and other dessert selections.
author: Naomi K.

description: It's simple. Saigon Sandwich is the best value sandwich in SF.
author: Ryan B.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE. I've been coming here since I can remember.. Even when i was in elementary school. This place is like a TL landmark.. everyone knows about this place ! 

Whenever i want a GOOD... no the BEST Vietnamese sandwich, I come here. I almost always get my favorite order, one that I grew up with: (I usually order in Vietnamese but i think this is what it's called in English) Fancy Pork w/ Pate, no jalapenurs nd cut in half :] Sometimes, tha wait could be long but it is so worth it. Just have patience! For about 5-10 minutes..sometimes.

If you've never tried the sandwiches at this place, you definitely NEED TO ! So recommended. They just re-modeled nd have been closed for a month soo I just got my fix today but wasn't satisfied as they didn't have Fancy pork :[
author: Michael N.

description:
The reviews are spot on. This place is a winner! Friends visiting me from other places ask me to take them here again and again.

Banh mi here comes with the usual fare of mayonnaise spread on a short french roll topped with grilled meat and picked vegetables. 

What's good: the meat is steamed in its own juices, making succulent and tender. I would stick to the Grilled Pork Sandwich, a favorite of the locals. It's very quick, even with the lines and you can load up on Vietnamese snacks while waiting for your sandwich.

I took off a star for their bread. Their breads are not fresh baked and they make no attempt to toast the bread, leaving the sandwich with a more stale texture. But, for $ 3.25 a pop, they do a pretty good job in SF!
author: Phu N.

description:
Yes, this is in the 'hood, there is pretty much always a line, and the sandwich spread is on the sweet side.

I still have not found a better Bahn Mi in SF.

I steer clear from anything other than the roast port (the fanci pork, yes, it's spelled w/ an "i" , is highly suspect, and the roast chix tastes similar to the pork, just not as good).

This place makes me happy to live in SF.
author: S C.

description:
The place is stacked from floor to ceiling with piles of random snacks in neon colors, but the smell of banh mi is enough to keep you inside even if you're claustrophobic.  Just forget about your phobias of pate, unidentifiable meats, whatever, and order the special combination.  That thing is friggin delicious, and it's $3.75 (my long-term fan friends say that's expensive), and it will basically fill you up.

There's nowhere to sit, but there are some nice benches in front of the Asian Art museum a few blocks away.

Don't bother with the tempting pork bao on the counter, they aren't nearly as good.  And get something to drink, that's a lot of meat to wash down!
author: Sydney H.

description:
There is a reason that people including myself line up here instead of visiting the countless other Vietnamese sandwiches that line up on Larkin.

This place rocks and is my favorite sandwich in the city.  I come here weekly and pick up the special combination-  Roasted pork, steamed pork, and pate.  Everything about it taste good from the crunchy bread and creamy pate to the vegetables as well.  

I also highly recommend trying one of the random banana leaf wrapped goodies that are pretty much always legit.  Don't be shy just ask if it's sweet or meat and go for it.  

They take orders in batches so just make sure you get your order in when one of the ladies starts asking.

Oh and definitely don't skip the drink selection.  Cool juices like guava and sugar cane.  No high-fructose syrup in these!  Deserts are bomb too.
author: Crandon J.

description:
After reading reviews and having a friend tell me about how great this place was, the hubby and I drove all the way from Vallejo because we were craving a good Viet sandwich. When we got there, as expected the line was nearly out the door. I didn't exactly enjoy how the cashier lady was taking everyones order down the line. I know this makes for quicker service but because she moves down the line so quickly it makes it harder to customize my order. 

I was hoping to find some BBQ pork and chicken but I guess theirs is grilled here. My husband got the pork while I got the chicken, both without cilantro and extra carrots. I was a bit disappointed that they didn't have cucumbers as I LOVE cucumbers on my sandwiches. We did wait a little while but when we finally got our orders they were nice and toasted and this place definitely does not skimp out on the meat. Although I didn't really enjoy my chicken one, the hubby's pork was very flavorful and the sizes were pretty big. 

Unfortunately, Saigon gets marked down a star for not putting cucumbers in their sandwich and for not have the BBQ Chasu pork. Overall, great flavor and very filling though at not a bad price.
author: Petra S.

description:
Meatball sandwiches here are the best!  I love the spicy sweet n' sour sauce they put in them.  And all for less than $3.  Plus I can get some grass jelly drink to go with it.  

It's a small hole in the wall with almost no place to sit, but most times you just get it and start chomping down on the sidewalk on your way to somewhere else.  

I salivate just thinking about them.
author: Jean K.

description:
Based on all the glowing and positive reviews of this dump, my review will probably get some hate mails.  First of all, I've been coming here on & off for years and I agree, their sandwiches are tasty, however, I've decided to STOP once and for all due to ONE reason;  which is CLEANLINESS.  I've found on a few occasions all kind of junk in my sandwich.  Every time I would convince myself that it is an isolated case, but after the 3rd time, and when I witnessed with my own eyes how GROSS they are handling the food, I can no longer convince myself that it is an isolated case.  

Good luck to all of you guys who enjoy their sandwiches, hope y'all have healthcare coverage, because you might end up in the ER.
author: Scott T.

description: You can't beat these sandwiches for $3.50 a pop. The meat is wonderfully tender and full of flavor and the bread is just the right level of crispy. Wait in line; it's worth it. Don't expect to snag one of the two seats though.
author: Brett B.

description:
satisfying, cheap and flavorful!

This place is my favorite sandwich spot in the city and 
I still have not gotten sick of it after 4 years!!
author: John B.

description:
I LOVE Vietnamese sandwiches as much as I love Vietnamese people :0) Saigon Sandwiches may be an itsy, bitsy, tiny, squeeze in, unflattering looking building, but who cares! We just want our Pork Banh Mi and rush on out of there. 

I only order the roast pork sandwich. Haven't yet tried any of the others.  The sandwich is made up of flavorful roast pork, thinly sliced pickled carrots, cucumbers, cilantro, pate, (minus the jalapenos on mine) and mayonnaise. MAYO? Oh no! FATTY, but sometimes you just have to say yes to a little good ol' tasty FAT! All these ingredients make great contrasting flavors and textures to this sandwich. 

This is like a subway, but VIETNAMESE style. Although, you get a better deal than a $5 foot long. This sandwich is only $3.25, who can beat that?
author: Sweet P.

description:
The first time I had a Vietnamese sandwich was from pacific super.. Oh my gosh I was like what is this??! Bad experience and from then on.. Haven't had a Vietnamese sandwich since... 
UNTIL a couple of months ago..( Reviews kinda late)
