Fiance took me to this small Saigon sandwich place that he kept saying it was the best Banh Mi that he has ever had hands down . I was a little iffy but I said ok..ok .. I'll give it a try.. Why not.. So after he got me the combo.. I took a bite bread was kinda hard almost chipped a tooth. but after that I was like WHAT that's sooo good and that pate.. Like crack extra pate please!! Definitely when I'm around the area ill grab a sandwich.. It jus sucks that I live so far..But if I lived in the area I would definitely be coming regularly especially for the price $3.25 cant beat that!
author: Shirl C.

description: Extremely cheap and very tasty. My favorite Viet sammies in the city. Can get a little crowded and the wait can be a little long, especially if the people ahead of you are ordering loads of sandwiches. Great hole in the wall!
author: Niran L.

description:
Best bahn mi in the city.  Sure Lee's is cheaper, but Saigon Sandwiches are sooo much tastier. 

Don't come here if you're not willing to stand in line.
author: Irene D.

description:
Their pork meatball sandwiches are yummy here and the bbq chicken sandwiches aren't bad either. I also like it that they have all the other goodies spread out for you to pick from while you wait for your sandwich to be made. 

The wait is sometimes ridiculous so call in first if you can.

Less one star because I like Sing Sing the best and I can't give them the same rating as them!
author: Chowmein P.

description: You will never imagine what's this little shop has to offer. I love the chicken sandwich the best.
author: Jacob T.

description:
This place is the tiniest place EVER! The line runs out the door during lunch time, which is expected as their store fits about 3 people. Small selection of sandwiches, which then translates to better quality. They're fast and efficient, taking 10 orders at a time and turning out the sandwiches in 2-3 minutes. The ladies are nice and speak to me in vietnamese. Not bad for SF.

Onto the food:
I grew up in San Jose, the land of amazing Vietnamese food (also the land of MOM!), so this sandwich did not strike me as amazing. I was kind of disappointed by their chicken sandwich as i've had way better. Their meat is typically flavored, probably with salt, pepper, garlic powder, soy sauce and oyster sauce, (most likely MSG), and it was big and more chewy than it should be. I'm more used to shredded chicken, soft, tender, flavorful and then doused with pate. This place is decent for the location, the population it serves, and the price ($3.25-3.75/each sandwich), but it's definitely not my favorite.

I am also incredibly bias when it comes to Vietnamese food, as all people due to home cooked meals and hometown eats.
author: Camille T.

description:
Ok come here if you like dusty, dirty hole-in-the-wall shops that violate health regulations. The place itself looks disgusting. The candy and snacks they sell there are just sitting with a pile of dust on top. The workers don't wear hair nets and they have long, greasy hair. That's not even the worst part.

Here's the story. So I went with my mom to get a couple of sandwiches for lunch. I've been here many times before and yes the sandwiches are great but I'm never going back again. This is why. So I was second in line waiting to place my order. The guy in front of me handed the cashier some money. She gives him his sandwich and his change. Ok then it's my turn. I tell her I want 3 pork sandwiches. She proceeds to the oven where the bread is and takes out the bread...WITH HER BARE HANDS. Not just her bare hands but the same bare hands she used to touch the guy's money 15 seconds earlier. and NO she did not wash her hands after she touched the money. I'm thinking OH HELL NO. 

I told her nicely but firmly (in Chinese), "Um excuse me, you didn't wash your hands after you touched that guys money and now you're touching the bread with your hands. That's not sanitary." 
She responded, "Huh?? What? I did. I washed my hands!!" 
I said, "No, I saw you. I was watching you. You didn't wash your hands or put on gloves. That's really dirty. Do you know how dirty money is?"
The other lady that worked there butted in and said, "She did wash her hands. You just didn't see it."

OH HELL NO.

Don't lie to me when I saw the WHOLE thing. I would've been happier if they just said, "Sorry," washed their hands and give me new bread. But NO. My mom didn't want to start "trouble" (typical Asian mentality) said just to let it go. They did give me new bread and I bought the sandwiches but I really wish that I stormed out. 

They should be thankful that I didn't tell all the white people in the line behind me what happened. I'm sure they would've all WALKED the HELL out. Which was what I should've done. Buhbye Saigon Sandwich. I don't care how delicious your sandwiches are, you are not getting my business. Who knows how else they violate health regulations when no one's watching. Gross.
author: Jenny T.

description:
If you're in the mood for a sandwich that's a little unique and can't go to ikes anymore give Saigon Sandwich a try. I'm not really a huge fan of vietnamese sandwiches, but this was a good one. The hubbs got me the chicken since i rarely do pork and it made for a perfect quick lunch. It's a really bready sandwich which normally i don't like, and this bread was pretty tough so you really had to bite and tear hard, but, it worked. The entire package made all the flavors work together. generous with the sandwich fillings so you don't feel gipped since there's so much bread. 
Not my favorite 7x7 list item, but glad I tried it.
author: Audrey V.

description:
the best in the world! better than any I've had in Vietnam even.
Lots of yummy juicy meat, well seasoned. 
generous portions. cheap!!
PLEASE DON'T CHANGE!
author: Xiu L.

description: Avoid this place at all cause! I came here because of all the great reviews. Ham sandwich and combo sandwiches were not edible! No white carrots and the ham was watery with nasty sauce. I would not recommend this place to anyone. The root beer can i got was filled with dirt and all the other soda cans were like that too. So I wonder how this place got a 96 score on health and safety inspection? Was it out of 1000 or the lower the number the cleanier it is!?! These pop cana were dirtier compared to cans ive seen in mexico.
author: Jason C.

description: I mean, god bless them. I'm so hooked on the tofu I eat it for breakfast. And I'm not even a vegetarian.
author: Smelly S.

description:
I'm trying to work through 7x7's Big Eat List.  Some of the picks seem a bit sketchy, but a friend suggested this spot and I'd driven past it a million times and was curious, what with the long lines and all.  So we went during the week, beat the line, ordered some sandwiches to go and ate them at work.  I admit, they are pretty tasty and the ingredients taste so fresh. I love the roasted pork with the carrots and jalapenos.  Simple but it packs a punch!

Tip:  Get there early to avoid the lines and bring back to your home or office.   Oh, and at about $3 each, I suggest you order TWO!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Just moved a month ago from Arizona to San Francisco.  Probably the most exciting aspect of moving here is the prospect of really good food, especially of the Asian persuasion.  The desert knows Mexican but not much else.  After a couple of weeks of trying different things out, I wanted to dedicate my inaugural review to what has been my favorite value of food quality and price - Saigon Sandwich.

A little whole in the wall on Larkin, this Banh Mi factory is a perfect mid day fix for anyone who likes:

Bread
Meat
Value

I recommend the pork, special combination or the chicken.  Each sandwich will run you between $3.25 and $3.75 and is worth it.
author: Jay B.

description: Big portions.  Cheap prices.  Can't ask for anything more besides a slightly less sketchy area and later hours.  But then you might not get big portions and cheap prices.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is fine.  I'm sure the $3.25 price point contributes to the review love on yelp.  The pork is pretty decent, but the sandwiches need more vegetable balance.  Pickled daikon would be a start.  More cilantro would be a cheaper fix.  The bread is very good, but there's too much of it relative to the quantity of sandwich filling.

If this is the best banh mi you've ever had, you're not looking hard enough.  When I was 12, the best rock concert I'd ever seen was the iteration of the Creedence Clearwater Revival that featured Ric Ocasek on lead guitar.
author: John B.

description:
Really cheap, really good, a must go if you're in the hood.  Just make sure you watch where you walk. You don't want to step on (human) feces on your walk over there.

Oh, and you should avoid going there during lunch hour.  The line gets really long.
author: Jose R.

description:
Once again, 5-Stars, because this is "as good as it gets" ~ as far as 'Vietnamese sandwich shops' go. Period.

(Literally) - A Hole in the Wall place. Don't have ANY expectations, beyond a great (Vietnamese) sandwich, at an unbelievably reasonable price . . . and (I would if I could) guarantee, you'll like it (if not love it).

Simple
author: Peter B.

description: I really wanted to like this place because it's cheap and everyone at school eats here.  My sandwich had great flavor but the chicken was scary.  It's like they grilled my friends sandwich, ran out of meat, and then scraped the grill for fatty meat bits they wouldn't serve anyone else.   Maybe I picked the wrong meat?  Bah, I wouldn't order chicken again but maybe something vegetarian.
author: Rayna A.

description: The fact that other banh mi  joints and food trucks have started charging $5-9 for lesser sandwiches makes Saigon Sandwiches all the more appetizing.
author: stuart l.

description:
Lookin for cheap n easy, me n my beau headed towards larkin.  

Thinkin the yelped stars and the line out the door was a good sign, I'm a bit tad dissapointed.  Yes it was under $5 but I was comparing the banh mi to saigon cuisine's @ the tanforan mall (yes, i said tanforan mall).

1) the roast chicken was saltier
2) the roll was harder
3) NO DAIKON?
4) there were pickled like kim chee onions in it

next time im hungry (coz this is filling), have cash only, want to wait 15 min, and already on foot (parking in the city is a b), i might come here again.  maybe.
author: Lady K.

description:
Blah blah blah, yes everyone and their momma knows this is THE BEST spot for banh mi in the city. So my long-overdue review probably isn't needed, but Saigon deserves another 5 star rating!! Love this spot, love the tiny hole-in-the-wall status, love love love.

Over the years my favorite has turned from the special combo to the TOFU banh mi - hella good. I'm not a vegetarian by any means, either.

What I don't love is the long lines to get my banh mi, but these little ladies are super FAST so the line always looks longer than it takes. Just be weary of the beggars who always camp outside this place. Give 'em some food if you can. They love the banh mi too.
author: Tay R.

description: I had the pork bahn mi and it was pretty awesome. The bread and pork was just right, veggies were super fresh, and the sauce that they used really blended everything together!
author: Melissa A.

description: My bikini waxer (what do you call them? hair removal specialist?) is Vietnamese. I asked her where her favorite bahn mi is and she said, "I only eat at Saigon Sandwich" And I have to agree with her. Best tofu bahn mi ever. It is messy, so get lots of napkins. Please be kind to the ladies. They are working at neck breaking speed and are on their feet all day. Have your order ready because they take orders in succession and make the sandwiches in a fell swoop. I also love the Vietnamese desserts. Since I'm taking classes closeby, I am planning on sampling a different dessert each week.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
Best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had (and I've had a lot)!

My favorites are the Tofu and Chicken sandwiches. Saigon Sandwich is never skimpy with the fillings...each sandwich is packed full with tofu/meat and pickled veggies. I've also tried some of their wrapped noodle/rice dishes and pork buns, but they do not compare to the yummy-ness of their bahn mi.

I've brought many of my friends here, and not one of them has been disappointed with the food :)
author: Stella L.

description: Amazing! Had the traditional pork banh mi, and it blew my mind! The bread was perfect, as well as the carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, and secret sauce. Tried to hit them up on New Years eve, but had to swing back through a few days later when they were open again. Worth the extra trip!
author: Brian S.

description:
My last thoughts before walking into Saigon Sandwich for the 1st time:

What am I doing driving through the Tenderloin?  I obviously have jumped the Yelp bandwagon w/ over a 1000 reviews.  How good can a $3 banh mi sandwich be?

I get out of my car quickly and walk in.  It was 230PM with no line.  I order my sandwich without peppers thinking the spice would be good enough (good call).  I watch the lady put on a plastic glove taking my cash, I have sandwich in hand, I get my change and split!

I walk out thinking: Wait a minute - how come the sandwich is so small?  Will this be enough for me and will it be satisfying?  Oh well, here it goes:

**CHOMP**

Delicious - I will come back for more.  Plenty more!

THE END
author: Janet H.

description:
With all the hype I decided to try it. I got a combo and it was packed with meat and veggies. The bread was good and just the right crispiness to it.
It was a good sandwich nothing great.  I had better banh mi during my travel trek in California. Today I will try Lee's.  I'm sure Saigon and Lee are the best in San Fran? Any take on that? Other suggestions?
author: Lana H.

description: Does it get any better than the Special Combination ($4) from Saigon? I think not.
author: Evan G.

description:
CASING THE JOINT: 
Entirely hole in the wall, it looks like the Saigon ladies are living out of a tiny delicious food closet. In the loin, usually with a line out the door during meal times. Pretty short wait regardless - no longer than 15--20 minutes. 

THE SCORE: 
I always get the pork saigon sandwich. $3 or so. I usually pick up a asian drink from the fridge or some new (or old favorite) dessert as well. Can't really go wrong here. 

THE GETAWAY: 
On my scooter, heading home to eat this $3 steal of a sando. Always satisfying, always ready for another one. I'll be back next time the Saigon itch strikes.
author: Eric C.

description:
really is the best banh mi i've ever had. i liked the chicken more than the meatball and the pork comes in last place.  

occasional add pate never hurt either.
author: J A.

description: I was craving a Vietnamese sandwich one sunny afternoon in sf so what do I do? Go on Yelp of course to find the best place to order one... and I found Saigon Sandwich! I was very excited from all the reviews I read "best Viet sandwich ever" yadayada yada.. Damn, on my way there I was thinking the whole time it better be worth it because I had to go through the Tenderlion... rough neighborhood O.o When I made it there I had high expectations so I orderd 2 combo's (both for myself), I got home... scarffed one down. A couple of hours later at work I felt sick to my stomach, and waalahh THREW UP. Apparently I must have the worst luck, because this probably is the only bad review you'll see about this place. Eat at your own risk!
author: Tip S.

description:
I don't know what the people at Saigon Sandwich do to make their sandwiches so delightful, but they need to keep doing whatever it is they do.  It is hands-down my favorite place to get cheap lunch in the Tenderloin (even if they did just raise the prices on me * sob*).  These sandwiches may seem small at first glance, but they are stuffed with so much awesome goodness that they fill you up pretty well.  I love love love love the roasted pork ($3.25).  It's so good. 

Saigon Sandwich is tiny.  And it's a tiny store in the Tenderloin, which generally isn't the area you twirl your fingers and stroll around (it's not that bad, but you know what I mean if you've ever been there).  I didn't realize where it was until a friend of mine actually had to point it out.  It's small and it's not the most spacious place on the inside either.  Whatever, though.  It's not a place to sit in and eat.  I've taken my sandwich down and eaten in front of City Hall and the Asian Art Museum before.  Both are interesting places to people watch. 

There's usually a line.  I stopped by around 11:30 to grab a sandwich and that was the first time I've been there without having to wait in a long line.  It was a good change of pace.  But if you insist on coming during the lunch rush, know there is going to be a line.

Oh and it's cash only.
author: Alea G.

description:
I think this is the tiniest eatery I've ever been to and they are darn good at making Vietnamese sandwiches and charging ridiculously low prices for them. 

I always get the combo (chicken, pork, pork meatloaf) w/o pate (I just don't eat pate) and it cost me a whopping $3.25. I love the bread- toasty, warm, chewy, crispy. It's not a huge sandwich but it will get you full. There is no indoor seating.

Tips
-Bring cash. 
-Best if eaten right away. 
-Lines can form very fast and very long. Either go early or call and place an order.
author: Eileen C.

description:
There are many Vietnamese sandwich places around this Tenderloin area, but Saigon Sandwich is my favorite! 

I'm simple, I love Banh Mi Cha, (fancy pork? i believe), ironic, there's nothing fancy about it! 
But I also love their other sandwiches.

The wait for lunch hour is okay, sometimes not too bad because the ladies are quick, getting orders in a row, at least 5 customers at one time!  The line sometimes looks intimidating though :)

Used to live in the area but now that I'm not, I try to stop by when I'm around the neighborhood. 


GREAT PLACE! Oh and lots of other snacks!
author: Karen P.

description:
Not bad... I got the pate and it tasted great.  Smooth, buttery, and melted in my mouth.  The price is decent.  The only thing I didn't appreciate was that the bread was a little too crunchy with no chewy center.  The bread actually scraped the roof of my mouth the first couple of bites... I hate that feeling!! 

Other than that, I would definitely go here again and order my pate banh mi and lychee juice.
author: Nicole G.

description:
$3.25 for an amazing sandwich! I get there and the lady takes about 7 orders at once, and then disappears to go work. About 10 minutes later, I receive my sandwich to go eat it back in my office. Little did I know, that this would be the best $3.25 I have spent in a long time. 

I ended up ordering 2, fearing that I would be hungry after 1. I was glad I did, but this is not to say that the sandwich wasn't filling. The great sandwich experience shouldn't just stop after 1 sandwich! So tasty, I say just go for 2!

Definitely worth the wait, and I say, 5 stars! great sandwich and a great price!
author: Jeff C.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up.

A while back (over 1.5 years ago) someone had told me of  Saigon Sandwich  saying that they had "bomb ass" Vietnamese sandwiches hat were better than Lee's Sandwiches down the street. I checked them out on Yelp and they had a surprising number of high ratings, so I was even more curious to check them out. Unfortunately, Lee's is first when coming from my apartment so I would always wind up there instead. Yesterday, however, I was walking back to my apartment from UN Plaza, so this time Saigon Sanwich would be first. I was in the mood for a Viet sandwich, so I decided this was the time to finally check them out.

Like other people have mentioned, there was a line out the door. But then again, the customer area in the store is tiny. About 5 people can fit inside at standing room.

There were 6 or 7 other people ahead of people; all but 2 had already ordered and were just waiting for their food. I ordered the Banh Mi Xiu Mai (meat ball sandwich), waited less than 10 min, and paid $3.25. I was going to also get a Viet ice coffee, but didn't see it on their limited menu which consisted of about 10 sandwiches and thats it. I never knew a Viet sandwich shop to not have Viet coffee, but everyone else was ordering only sandwiches, and Lee's is right down the street.

The Sandwich
The bread started off great. Thin, crispy crust and soft inside. But after a few chews, the bread was a bit too chewy and tough. Disappointing since it was almost perfect. It's not that bad though, it is certainly better than a lot of other places.

The meat was really good. Seasoned well, with a little kick. I wouldn't  say it's hot since I can eat pretty spicy foods, but you can definitely tell after a few bites that they have spices in there to add a little heat. And no, it wasn't from the jalapenos, because, come to think of it, I don't think my sandwich had jalapenos :(

The sandwich could have also had more  Chua (pickled carrot and daikon). Mine hardly had any and a Viet sandwich just isn't a Viet sandwich without  Chua. Anyone who thinks otherwise should probably just stick to Subway.

Conclusion
Saigon Sandwich does make a tasty sandwich despite those minor details I mentioned (I wouldn't have rounded up otherwise).

Would I go back? Maybe.

To me, their sandwiches aren't that much better than Lee's who are right down the street. They don't appear to have Viet coffee (though I could be wrong), but I've got to have a Viet iced coffee with my Viet sandwich. Plus Lee's has a lot of other goodies that I like. I know, it sounds like I'm advertising for Lee's, but really I'm just stating how they fit my needs a little better.

To whom would I recommend Saigon Sandwich?
If all you're loking to get is a sandwich or you don't mind making another trip to get more than a sandwich than by all means come to Saigon Sandwich.

Note: They do have various canned/bottled drinks and a few "homemade" Viet desserts. I don't know if they make the desserts or they get them from elsewhere.
author: Dennis Z.

description:
Super cheap and super yummy. Meat is delicious and the sauce is a great tangy sweet, AND they don't put too much mayo. One is enough to fill you up too!

Why not 5 stars? Although rare, I've had better banh mi (more toppings inside other than meat), it wasn't very spicy, and the actual place has virtually no seating space.
author: Roxane W.

description: I was attending a conference at the Hilton on O'Farrell and needed to run out for a quick lunch. Saigon Sandwich sounded like a perfect place, I hit it a little after the lunch hour (~2pm on a Saturday) and my sandwich came out really quickly. I went with the tofu banh mi. First off, the price was fantastic, $3.25 for a tofu banh mi. The sandwich was pretty good, it tasty fresh with generous portions of tofu. The mayo was a bit overpowering and I would've preferred the tofu to pack a little more of a punch. The veggies all tasted very fresh giving the banh mi a nice kick. Great stop, I'd definitely stop in again if I was near the area but wouldn't seek it out if I wasn't.
author: Stephen S.

description: I like this place, the best Vietnamese sandwiches in the tenderloin, way better then the big chain restaurant like the one thats 1block away. I don't no what it is but the sauce on the sandwich is awesome, I tried making it with mayo and other stuff but can't get the right taste, like there secret sauce. It gets packed during lunch time so I show up before. O ya and I like there white rice ball. It's stuffed with meat, chicken or pork with veggies.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Meh overrated.

I was excited to come here after reading so many good reviews of this place but in the end I was pretty disappointed.

I got the combination while my girlfriend got the roast chicken. The bread is rock hard it can break your teeth. For banh mi its really important to have really good french bread. You could break your teeth on this bread. The meats and veggies were delicious. Aside from the bad bread the sandwiches are average.

If you really want to experience superior banh mi I highly recommend Ba Le in Oakland. It is much cheaper there too.
author: David W.

description:
I've been a fan of vietnamese sandwiches (banh mi) since the late 80s so I know when I taste a good one.  Typically I find the grilled chicken sandwich pretty consistent the few places I go to buy from. The main difference being the texture of the bread. Personally I like it a little warm and very lightly crusted so I don't bruise my mouth when I eat it.  Some places, like Lee's, use a very crusty bread which I don't like.  Saigon's chicken banh mi was similar to other places I've tried but I like the softer texture of their bread.  The roasted pork was amazing though.  The pork was the best I've tasted in a sandwich anywhere including San Jose, where I consider the capital of vietnamese cuisine.  

Due to the always long line and  the fact that only the pork sandwich stood out I can only give this place a 4 star.
author: Kenbie L.

description: Cheap, tasty Vietnamese sandwiches. Not mind-blowing, but it's good--especially for SF. Grab a few for the road.
author: Thuan N.

description: Relatively speaking, this is probably the best banh mi you can get in SF. I guess they're okay for hipsters though.
author: Rich L.

description:
I have to say it is not the best bahn mi I have, but hey, too lazy to drive to inner richmond, but it is the best thing within the 3 mile radius in downtown.

The size is one the smaller side, and average $3-$4. Grilled chicken is pretty damn good at this little shop.
author: Alice C.

description:
Feel kinda bad leaving only two stars when it seems that everyone else LOVES this place...but hey, I'm only being honest.

Ventured over here after I drove up to Sing Sing for my fix and the door was closing at 3pm...nooooooooooo!  Since I didn't want the drive down here to be a lost cause...I drove along Larkin and had the option of three sandwich locations.  Since I was not going to Lee's (ew)...I decided to come here as I've heard good things.

Got the banh mi cha lua and an iced coffee.  Iced coffee was great...sandwich is another story.  It was a bit dry and had a weird sweet taste (probably from the thick brown sauce they put in it) - tasted like something you would find in a chinese pork bun.  IMO, when a sandwich has pate and pickled veggies in it...why would you throw in a sweet flavor?

Sing Sing's sandwiches are still my favorite...down the block on Eddy, left on Hyde.  TRUE hole in the wall good food, same prices...LOVE it.
author: Violet C.

description:
Summary thoughts - Wow, a lot of people have chimed in for such a small hole in the wall place.  Here's my summary eval:  The sandwiches are heavy versions of the ones you find in vietnam.  If you like the heartier gritty portions then you'll like this place and its prices.  If you are used to ones more like the ones in vietnam, then you will probably be expecting fresher ingredients and lighter use of mayo, pate, and the meats. 

I personally prefer this place's version because I am more of a carnivore, but definitely enjoyed the real thing when I was in Vietnam.  As others mention this is pretty much a small deli with other pre-made items (light cold noodle dishes, pork buns, etc).  Basically, it's a hearty meal for 2-3$ and a nice change of pace from western sandwiches.
author: Aaron W.

description:
After trying Baguette Express first I have to say I much prefer it to Saigon Sandwiches. BE is bright, clean, cheerful. SS is def not...she stuck my sandwich next to the sink by the soap. Yes I eat street food in Asia but at least don't do this when I'm watching.
But on to the important part - taste. The bread was not as fresh and the meat was mushy. She also ignored my request for no peppers. How I wished I had Baguette Express instead.
To be fair, its cheap and I could try again since its probabaly fresher at lunchtime (I went around 5) And hey, it beats out most other banh mi...esp in ny.
author: Lainy C.

description:
There's something magically satisfying about the crunchy-chewy-sweet-and-salty combination of the bahn mi here.  The tofu sandwich is every bit as overflowing as the meat versions, which cannot be taken for granted.  Half the fun of the excursion is trying some of the random goodies crammed into the tiny space here.  Last time I snagged some banana tapioca squares with coconut cream--other times my luck's been less good.

The conundrum: when the weather is nice, the line is ridiculously long, but the civic center lawn offers perfect picnicking grounds.  When the weather is lousy the lines are manageable, but where to devour your pile of wonderfulness?
author: Dana S.

description:
I've eaten here 3 times now, everytime its been awesome. The store front is very mom and pop, but the price makes it totally worth the trip. 

So far I've had the roast pork, pate, fanci pork and my wife had a roast chicken. Fanci pork is like a pressed lunch meat, but very good. The pate is like my jewish ma's chopped liver on a roll, delicous but its liver. The roast pork and chicken were very tasty, my wife enjoyed them both and she can be picky. 

I'm giving it 5 stars, if you are in the area and got no money id give it a try!
author: Steve S.

description:
$3.25 a sandwich...wat a steal!

Parking is pretty difficult as there is a bus stop right infront of the shop. So, I called in the order for pickup as I was leaving my  apt. My hubby waited in the car double parked for the time being as I jet in n' out w/ my sammys that were waiting for me.

Btw, another reason why I ordered takeoutt is because there is absolutely nowhere to sit in this shop.

I ordered one pork meatball sandwich and one pork&pate sandwich. I think I can do w/o the pate next time. Also,  note to self-don't forget to ask for extra cilantro. The bread was not hard like previous comments said. It was perfectly crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside.
author: Mina B.

description: mmmm. this place is a god-send.  I was directed here by Broke-Ass Stewart's blog.  I ordered the classic pulled-pork sandwich and it was incredible... nothing at all like I expected.  Fresh, spicy-sweet, overflowing with cilantro and the bread toasty and warm.  This is my new go-to sandwich spot.
author: Summer S.

description: $3.75 for most sandwiches with nice bread, a mixture of veggies and the main meat selection.  Great value for SF, but you have to endure waiting in line.  Most people order sandwiches for others - a great idea so you can alternate who stands in line.
author: John Y.

description:
I love bahn-mi sandwich. So, prior to my trip to SF, I did my research on Yelp for a good bahn-mi plc. I relied on the Yelpers on Saigon Sandwich. 

However, I was quite disappointed. The bread is half the size of what I have been used to in NYC. But I thought, as long as it's good, I don't care so much about the size. My boyfriend and I picked up 3 combo sandwiches before heading to the airport. One supposedly good bahn-mi didn't seem big enough for us. But I ended up having only a quarter of a sandwich and didn't touch the rest. I don't like the way the pork is cooked. I like BBQ pork in my bahn-mi. 

If this is the best bahn-mi in SF, I know now I do not have to look for a banh-mi when I am in SF.
author: EJ L.

description:
Even when money is tight I can always count on my favorite tofu sandwhich for $3.25 from this amazing hole in th wall. Don't fret if the line seems too long, those ladies are in there busting out those sandwhiches at warp speed.
DELICIOUS!!
author: Christine C.

description: If you're fiending for some banh mi, this is the place to go. Each sandwich is only a little over $3.00. They hella stuff it with meat and pickled vegetables. I'm not a huge fan of Vietnamese sandwiches because they make my hard palate hurt after I finish it, but when I want a meal quick and easy, this is where I come! There's always a huuuge line here during lunchtime, though.
author: Jamie C.

description:
It's odd that this simple $3.50 sandwich ranks as one of my favorite meals I've had in San Francisco so far. I've only been to about 20 places, but this is one I felt like telling the world immediately, even if it has 1000+ reviews. 

I ordered the roast pork banh mi. The first bite was bread, meat, and some amazing brown sauce. I was already excited by these three ingredients. But a few bites later I entered bliss. Veggies, the kinds I'm not too fond of (especially carrots) come together to make an unassumingly yummy sandwich. So simple, yet so perfect.

Sure the bread could be a little less rough, or it could use more meat, but to me, it was extremely satisfying and worth stopping by.
author: Rahil P.

description: This place IS all its cracked up to be!  The chicken and tofu ones are the ish.  The ladies making the banh mis look like my grandmother.  Good prices and great food!  Must go.
author: Joe L.

description:
This little shop serves the best banh mi I have ever tasted. I was introduced to Saigon Sandwich by a coworker at MUNI's Potrero shop (thanks, Kyle). He insisted that I order the "combo" and proceeded to call ahead for two of these combos. 

Combination of what, I have no idea, but this sandwich has everything in it, and it's ALL good. Meat (chicken?, pork?, beef?), carrots, liverwurst, vinegar sauce, and cilantro. I'm not a big fan of cilantro, but I can't imagine eating this sandwich without it.

The prices have gone up since the first time I was there but this sandwich is worth every penny. 

Get there as early as you can to avoid the crowds.
author: Rory O.

description:
Not sure what more there is to say.

The sandwiches are pretty great, although, I'm not sure 7x7 got it right in recommending the pork sandwich over the pate sandwich. I have a special place in my heart and stomach for pate.

At $3.25 per sandwich, Saigon Sandwich is expensive for Vietnamese sandwiches, but good job to them for making use of the reputation they've built to charge more. Finite output of sandwiches (there are only two ladies working the tiny counter here), huge demand, and thus, higher prices. Economics in action.
author: Cynthia T.

description: I came here today for the first time to try their sandwiches. I ordered one tofu sandwich and one fancy pork with pate sandwich. The sandwiches were $3.50 but the one with pate was $0.25 more. I really enjoyed the tofu sandwich although the sauce was kind of messy. The bread was not toasted which I didn't like because it made eating the sandwich kind of difficult. The fancy pork and pate I didn't like so much. I thought it would be good too but it wasn't. They put WAY too much pate and that just overpowers the whole sandwich. It felt like I had a lot of pate in my mouth. That's just wrong. The fancy pork wasn't great neither. I actually don't know if it was fresh or not because it didn't taste fresh. Anyways the tofu sandwich was great and the fancy pork and pate was not good. I think I will stick with the Irving place one.
author: Carmen L.

description: Everyone knows this is the spot.  Order, pay, step aside, wait.  Best banh mi in SF.
author: Hanah L.

description:
what can i say that has not yet been said.

Are they tasty? oh yes.
Are they cheap? only in value
Are they convenient? with bars, strip clubs and dance halls all around, oh so very yes. 

So stop in, but try a few types.  Ask the regulars on what to try and ask questions.  This will allow you to make a great choice.
author: Jai D.

description:
ok today was a super pig out day. first i had a big bowl of pho tai at bodega bistro across the street from saigon sandwiches and then i came straight here for a pate sandwich.  i was initially intrigued to come here because i saw a big line out the door as i went into bodega bistro for pho. AFTER i left bodega bistro I still saw a big line here and said to myself, i gots to see what this is all about! wow! the pate sandwich was really tasty. warm crusty french roll with carrots, cilantro, mayo, and meaty smooth pate. probably the best I have eaten in a long time.  for $3 including tax!
next time i will skip the pho and just come straight here.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I've heard so many rave reviews about their banh mi. I finally got a chance to go here the other day. I did my homework (Yelp reviews) before coming here so I knew what to get. 

I got one each of the roast chicken and roast pork. I ate it in the car on the way to an appointment. I had half of the chicken one first and it was good. I then had the roast pork and OMG!!!! It is the BEST banh mi I've ever had. The sauce from the pork mixed with the pate= orgasmic. Ok maybe that was a bit dramatic but you get my drift. 


They don't skimp on toppings. You get the right amount of pickled carrots and meat. I wish they put just a tiny bit more pate. 

I went back a few days later to buy 4 pork banh mis. She gave me 3 chickens and one pork. Needless to say I was a bit bummed. Also she was wearing a clear plastic glove on one hand and was touching money with it and wrapping up my banh mi. * sigh * If these pork banh mis weren't like crack to me, I'd be out the door. But I figured you gotta give up a lil' to get a lot. ;)  Yes I will still eat here.

There's like only a small table with two chairs so you can't really eat in here. 


I'm one to always start a line wherever I am so I never have to wait in line. Hahaha! Ok maybe there'd be one or two people ahead of me. But behind me is at least 5 people. I heard at lunctime, the line snakes around the block. I tried to call in my order but they didn't pick up the phone. 

FYI: these sandwiches MUST be eaten within the first maybe 3 hours. I waited longer and the bread was sooo hard to bite into. 

I love all their colorful drinks but too bad I don't know what most of them are. I did buy one. It was good. It was a bit on the sweet side and had a lot of fruits and too little milk. I got a tummy ache after wards and that was not good. I'm not saying the drink was bad. I'm just saying I have a very sensitive stomach. 

FYI: the pork banh mi comes with jalapenos. 

Will definitely come back for their pork banh mi. 

CASH only. 

I usually go before 11am so I get parking right in front. 

Just an FYI- there's a surveillance camera on you. So don't do anything embarrassing like I did. * whistles *
Best food that "tree fiddy" can buy. I stop by whenever possible for the best damn sandwich in town! I recommend the roast pork sandwich, and the sweet rice drinks in the cooler.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Okay, another review and then I need to study for my final!! =) 

Yes, I've reviewed this placed before and I'm doing it again. After they closed for remodeling all of the month of March, I've been coming here once or twice a week after work to order-up two sandwiches- one to eat now and the other for later or for lunch the next day =). My fav is the chicken, but I've tried the roast pork several times and love it too!! I've tried the combo and it's yummy too. I think I might have to stop by this place after I'm done studying =).
author: Neni E.

description: when my friend told me about this place, i was like pssssh...best banh mi?  im vietnamese...it takes alot to hold that title with me.  We just dropped off our car at the autobody place around the corner and walked by.  surprisingly there was hardly any line.  I walked in and decided to order 3 banh mi's and some banh bao's to go.  holy cow...i was totally not expecting this!  it was AMAZING!  my hubby tried to eat some of mines and i told him he better get his hands off unless he wanted to come back with nubs.  tons of yummy meat and OMG  pate heaven!!!!  when we pick up our car im getting 10 more.  that way hubs can have his own.  he said he only wanted a "bite" and when i got the banh mi back, half of it was gone!
author: Karisa L.

description:
Amazing deal. 3.25$ for a pretty big sandwich, AFTER tax. Wow! It's in a pretty sketch neighborhood, but I guess that can't be helped.

The sandwich was pretty good, too.
author: Grant M.

description: I was told this was the place to go for the best banh mi in the city and they were right! It was the best banh mi I've tasted! I had the roast pork and the meat was very juicy and tender compare to all the other places I had. Sucks that they close @ 5pm. I'd have to try to get off work early just to make it here in time. I'll definitely be going back to try the other sandwiches.
author: Thommy V.

description: this place is damn good, stumbled upon it by accident, line out the door at 11:30am = good sign. Got to get the Combo when you get a bahn mi and the combo did not disappoint. Roast Pork, liverwurst, ham and the pate is intense and delicious. The size of this sandwich is Medium, you could eat the whole thing and you will be very happy for $4.25.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This place is in the sketchiest part of the city but it's definitely the best Vietnamese sandwich in the city!  Subway and other Vietnamese sandwich places have nothing on this place.  It's so cheap and they put so much meat on every sandwich.  Usually I can finish the typical vietnamese sandwich, but I'm actually full after 3/4 of one of Saigon's.   


My favorite is the BBQ Chicken Sandwich here and I like it spicy.  They really stack the chicken and the bread is fresh.  YUM!!!


Quick tip - call in to order and pick up if you're going during lunch hour.  I've waited in line for 30 minutes for one of their sandwiches.  It's worth the wait, but if you're on the run, it's the best to pick up.
author: Isabella O.

description:
Hands down the best Banh mi I've had so far!!!! OMG!!!! Especially at $3.25 for a decently sized sandwich. Just amaaziiinng!!

I had the roast pork sandwich and it was divine!!! The pork was not dry at all; had just the right amount of pepper, cilantro, pickled daikon, carrots, mayonnaise, and pate; and the bread wasn't super hard to bite into.

Gaaahhhhhh!! I'm drooling just thinking about that sandwich.

Have it with some young coconut juice (with pulp) and you are SET. FOR. LIFE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Daniel L.

description:
would be 5 stars if not for the hard dry bread.

the sauce and flavor is top notch though.
a little pricey for vietnamese sandwiches ($3.25)

we got the roasted pork.
author: Addison P.

description:
YUMMY!

2 grilled pork sandwiches
1 chicken sandwich
1 Combo sandich

All consumed by me and my husband in one lunch hour.

So delicious and worth the hassle of finding parking!
author: Michelle Y.

description: Hands down BEST vietnamese sandwiches ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I waste more money on gas getting there than I do for the sandwiches I end up ordering. That's just how good it really is, I've tried Vietnamese sandwiches at other places and there not even close to being as fresh or juicy. Can't write this review anymore getting hungry
author: Mimi W.

description: Very good pork sandwich, although the problem was I ordered a tofu sandwich. I'm not a vegetarian and do eat pork sometimes. So I decided not to make the walk back to exchange it. She said tofu when my sandwich was ready, and it had a T on the wrapper, so I'm not sure what went wrong.
author: Karen J.

description:
So I've been back and I still keep to my 3 star review.  This time I asked for no mayo, but the problem with the sandwich is it's still on the sweet side.  The chicken is based in a sweet sauce and the pickled carrots are also sweet so the combination of both overpowers the sandwich.

However the chicken itself tastes like real homemade chicken drumsticks.  None of that rubbery stuff some places lists as meat.  But there was no pickled daikon in the sandwich, no cucumber, very little cilantro, and the bread very hard, like hurts-the-back-of-my-teeth hard. 

Overall, not a bad sandwich for $3.25, but I miss the salty sweet taste I get from other bahn mis.  This is one is just sweet.
author: C A.

description:
Shatangi is so pleased to have a regular lunch place.  I always get the same thing.  BBQ Pork, no mayo, extra jalapeños. It's the perfect amount of food for a great price.  Don't be deceived by the long line. It moves fast and the service is always efficient and pleasant.  Thank you ladies!!

Shatangi told you...
author: Njon W.

description: Better and cheaper than any Banh Mi that you've ever had.  Best cheap lunch spot in the city.  Just don't try to eat your sandwich there, they ain't got any room.
author: Kyle S.

description: Quality:price ratio off the charts. Fast and pleasant service. An oasis of affordability.
author: Jon V.

description:
They only understand "pork" or "chicken" so get the pork AND chicken. I asked for a knife and the woman responded with a really scared look. So be nice and don't ask for a knife.

My family and I wanted to just try the famous banh mi so we got one of each. A few bites later, I was direly holding onto my chicken, snapping at anyone who wanted an extra bite: "banh mi for only me!"

Saigon Sandwich is the only pure gem you'll find in the Tenderloin.
author: Hana J.

description:
SF's best Vietnamese baguette sandwiches for the buck... or rather 2 bucks. No longer do you have to go to San Jose to find a good Viet BBQ Pork sandwich. Sometimes there's a line out the door during the lunch hours, but it's worth fighting the small crowd of boat people for the Banh Mi Thit.

Gourmet taste at a ghetto price. Enjoy! ;-)
author: Be N.

description:
BEST VIETNAMESE MEATBALL SANDWICHES. EVER. I've never had a vietnamese meatball sandwich like theirs. Its oozing with flavor and juices. Man... writing this entry is already making me hungry. I think I'm about to take a little drive down to the TL to get me some!

All of their sandwiches are good IMO. Nothing has failed me here yet! THIS IS THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH PLACE IN SF. THE BEST.

And I wonder how they make money with their prices at around $3 or less. It's crazy!

This is one of the best hole in the wall sandwich places in the city, I swear!!
author: Andrew W.

description: My office had a secret Santa gift exchange set up for Christmas.  I'm one if those people who are extremely difficult to buy presents for so my unlucky but creative coworker decided to take me out on a fun let's-explore-the-neighborhood lunch date. The sandwich was one of the stops.  Best roast pork sandwich ever!  Toasty bread and juicy filling. I've gone back twice since our lunch date in January!
author: Lisa C.

description: Best place in San Francisco to get a Vietnamese Sandwich. The bread is always fresh and so good. Its a tiny place and there is usually a line all the way outside the door. I would go here over any Vietnamese sandwich place. There is a Lee sandwich the street which is huge but does not even compare to Saigon sandwich. The staff here is really nice and friendly. If i worked and lived near here i would go here almost everyday.
author: Anthony V.

description: I'm so sad I have not been able to eat you as much anymore. I had it recently and oh how I miss thee! :) I also bought this for a number of coworkers and they loved it! :)
author: Helen V.

description:
Just had a vietnamese sandwich from here for lunch. Great sandwich for ok prices. The lady that works there was mean tho. Sorry I wanted to pay for my friend's sandwich and it messed up your calculation for the total of my meal. :p

I'd be back here again to try the combination sandwich tho!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Came here on Sunday around noon.  The line was not too crazy and it moved pretty fast.  I got the grilled chicken sandwich.  It was pretty tasty.  The chicken was flavorful and moist.  All veggies were fresh and flavorful.  The only complain that I had was kinda thirty after I finished the sandwich... maybe from the sauce!!????
author: Liza T.

description:
Came here on a Saturday around lunchtime and yes, there was a line out the door as promised from other yelpers. 
This place is really small so don't be discouraged about the line being out the door. There isn't much room inside. 
Behind the counter are two cute older ladies, one making the sandwiches and the other collecting money. 

The sandwiches are a bit smaller than I'm used to. I like the pate so it's nice that they give you a healthy amount. We got the special combination which comes with everything. The whole thing was on the sweet side. That might have been because of the pate they use or something but it definitely needed more salty - more soy sauce would have been good.
author: Lucy S.

description:
Has anyone else noticed the insane amounts of saigon sandwich food porn on this page?  Incredible.

I got my first real gig in the city at Hyde Street Studio C about three years ago.  My first thought now working in the TL was, "Where the f*** in the world was I going to go for lunch.  (I like to keep my priorities in check).  My boss, let's just call him that for fun, nearly interrupted me in mid-sentence as I complained about all the money I would spend eating out every......"There's this awesome place that has $3 sandwiches,"  he blurted.  I became quiet and suspicious.  "Pssshh you must be talking about burger king or something", I whispered under my breath.  I though he was toying with me--I had just recently located from living in the sticks for almost four years.

Mr. Boss Man wasn't foolin'.  Though their price recently increased by a whopping 25 cents, everything he said about Saigon Sandwich was true:

1.  They rarely mess up your order despite how fast they crank them out, (they as in the two women that own and operate S.S).

2.  Cash Only.

3.  Efficient and pleasant service.

4.  Each sandwich comes with yummy pâté smeared on for your delight.

5. Bread made in house.  

6. No dine-in.

6. Excellent sandwich for its price.
author: Mennlay A.

description:
For 3.25 there is no better sandwich.  Excellent, fast, and satisfying.
The crunch of the fresh baguette is amazing.
author: Josepe M.

description:
I've only checked out this place 2 times. 

My first visit was sometime last year after hearing so much about it. The place is really small. You walk inside and then you order. That's why there's usually a line out the door. I tried their chicken sandwich, and it was OK. The only turn off about the sandwich is that their bread was a little bit hard, especially on the ends. 

The second time I went was today. I wanted to go last month, but they were closed for March. They definitely remodeled their Kitchen area. This time I had the Special Combination, which included Roast Pork and Pate. I think it was a better option then the chicken.

I'm not sure if their sandwiches are great, but I'd say they're good. I'd go every once in a while to try their other choices.
author: Matthew L.

description: Out of this world. Make sure you get napkins tho, you'll need them. FK I miss living near this place.
author: Mike T.

description: This is how Banh mi should be! The bread was crunchy from outside and soft inside. Pork was tender and moist. And there was right amount of Mayo and veggies. The ladies seemed pretty busy as its a small place and I've seen long lines here many times. But you will get a nice meal for under $5
author: Jam T.

description: Um lunch for under $5. YES. Love the combo banh mi. I usually go for lunch but I've never felt like the wait was atrocious. Don't except to eat there. Just grab your sandwich and head over by city hall to enjoy your lunch! CASH ONLY!
author: Janny N.

description:
Oh Saigon Sandwich, why can't I have you in CHICAGO??

My cousin brought me to this "hole in the wall" location in the Tenderloin which had a mini line formed already. The shop was not fancy at all. The wait was a little long. But when I bit into that abnormally shaped French bread with roasted pork, cilantro, peppers, mayo, and picked veggies, I knew it was THE ONE. The one banh mi I have been searching for my whole life. The bread was crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, the meat was tender and juicy, and the toppings just pulled everything together. I was a little disappointed that I had to share the meatball sandwich my cousin, but that was just as satisfying.

I hate to say it, but I left my banh mi heart in San Francisco.
author: Diana T.

description: Finally! A sandwich from Saigon Sandwich and it was AWESOME! I love how the sandwiches are stuffed with goodness and every bite is just a delicious delight! :D I got the special combination and it was soooooo gooood. There was plenty of meat, pate, and veggies! Although the sandwiches are stuffed, they are a bit short unfortunately. However, I would still recommend this place and will definitely be coming back! :D
author: Hwan L.

description:
These vegetarian tofu sandwiches haunt my dreams. The bread, the sweet tofu, the saucy mayonaise. It is like a hot stripper had a food baby and only charged 3 dollars. 

Saigon tofu sandwich+Mr.Browns coffee+some weird green dessert or imported packaged jack fruit snack=like maybe 6 bucks and more love for the city of San Francisco. We pay enough to live here, why not pay 3 bucks for a sandwich and feel better about the 500 parking tickets you pay every year?
author: Maria D.

description:
I must say that I love a good Banh Mi. In fact this was the first place I hit up in San Fran while there for a conference. The shop itself is a hole -- the place is small (no seating) and expect to wait in line for your sandwich. Not surprisingly, they also only take cash. Luckily, their sandwiches are dirt cheap (I think it was like $3.25).

My friend and I each had the Pork Banh Mi -- it seems to be the popular choice as literally everyone we heard order in front of and behind us ordered the same thing.

Overall, we both enjoyed our sandwiches, but they were by no means the best I've had. I'll start by saying that the flavor was spot on. The pork was tender and flavorful. They had all the right veggies on it, and the sauce was also quite tasty. In the end, not a single complaint there.

So why three stars then? For me, it came down to the bread. It was clearly nowhere near fresh -- it was super stale, hard as a rock, cut terribly, and the underside was completely cracked from one end to the other. Sauce was leaking out, and it was quite difficult to eat because of it. I hate taking a review down so much because of one flaw, but it was a big enough flaw to almost entirely detract from the experience.

Overall, great flavor to the sandwich -- in the right bread, this place would have be so much better. Don't know if I'd make a return visit the next time I'm in town.
author: Jeff L.

description: Ordering and waiting for your banh mi is confusing as hell, but the yumminess is worthwhile. And remember cash only. I had to spend an extra $2.50 at the ATM next door. Grrrr.
author: Ennie L.

description: Low prices give this place such an exceptional rating, as the sandwiches are just fine. I found the meat juicy and flavorful, but the bread harder than it should have been. If you're looking for a dirt cheap good sandwich come here, but for a mind blowing one go elsewhere.
author: Michael B.

description:
Good, cheap, and delicious!  Being the good Jew that I am, I recommend the roast pork sandwich all the way (don't even look at the fancy pork one), oh and the combo sando is pretty tastey as well, though you get less pork with that one :(.

Warning: Avoid this spot between 12-1, unless you don't mind waiting 25 minutes for your 3 dollar sando.
author: E-dough R.

description:
There are so many glowing reviews about this place that I almost didn't bother adding another one - 

I had the tofu sandwich and it was delicious. Good bread, good sauce (tasty but not too greasy), and a good portion size at a great price. Reviews of taste and flavor are always a matter of personal opinion so it's difficult to know how accurate a review will be for other people, but the price point at Saigon Sandwich makes me confident in the accuracy of five-star rating for everyone. It's $3.25, just go try it for yourself!
author: J C.

description:
I knew I had to try this place after seeing that it had over 2000 reviews and 4.5 stars.  It really is as good as everyone says it is!  I was a bit skeptical going there because being from L.A., there are TONS of Vietnamese sandwich places around so I've had my fair share of them.  After trying this place, I don't think I'll look at any other Vietnamese sandwich the same way again.

- There was virtually no line when I got there.  It was 11am.  Nice lady.  Got my sandwich in like 3 mins.

- I got the roast pork sandwich.  It was piled thick with meat and the regular vegetable condiments (cilantro, jalapeno, onions, shredded pickled carrots).  The meat is very flavorful and was not too fatty at all.  I love that they don't skimp on the meat!  But I had to take away one star because I asked for mine without mayo but the lady put it in anyway.  :/

-  Price is a bit more expensive as far as these sandwiches go.  I'm used to getting them for $2.50 but for the amount that you get, it's worth it.

- It's located in a sketchy neighborhood.  I had to walk from my hotel along Eddy St. to Larkin.  There were a lot of homeless people wandering around, some yelling out profanities.  If you had to walk there, I would suggest avoiding Eddy St. if possible and take Market and work your way up.  

- Con:  No place to sit and eat.  

All in all, it really IS the best Vietnamese sandwich I've tasted so far.  Highly recommended!
author: A.H. L.

description:
This is my favorite sandwich shop! I strongly criticize any other viet sandwich that isn't from this place. 
Banh mi thit was one of the things I grew up on. The pork is cooked so that's it's tender and has the right amount of seasonings. Their banh mi ga (chicken) is great too if you're not into pork. If you ask for the pickled veggies to be packed separately, they give you a lot more (you can save it to add to another meal). 
They also have other prepackaged viet meals. However, if you're going to Saigon Sandwich you're #1 reason for going has to be for their sandwiches! 
The place is a hole in the wall and you'll expect to walk by a few homeless folks loitering in the neighborhood (it is the Tenderloin), but their sandwiches are worth it!!

Overall,
Atmosphere- 3/10 (what do you expect from an Asian hole in the wall in the tenderloin!)
Service- 7.5/10 (quick and easy)
Food- 10/10
author: Kim Q.

description:
I work around the corner on Hyde and I can't get enough Saigon Sandwich. They closed for remodeling for all of March and I probably broke the bank eating other places last month.

Perfectly crusty bread, moist and sweet pork, and delightful veggies. All for $3.25.

Today is April 1st so I hope they're open!
author: Lindsay W.

description:
Tasty banh mi in the city - I'd come back here again for sure when I have a craving for roast pork + pate. The sandwich is packed with stuff - PACKED. Special combination included pretty much everything, at $3.75 a sandwich.

I don't think its the best banh mi in the bay area. South bay is where its at!! Thanh Huong all the way.
author: Carol L.

description: Absolutely delicious! My wife and I both had pork sandwiches, and they were phenomenal - good, moist meat topped with carrots, daikon, cilantro, and jalapeño. The line was out the door at lunchtime, but it moved pretty quickly. Very cramped with all the folks waiting for sandwiches.
author: Cody W.

description:
I had read about Vietnamese sandwiches awhile back and thought today would be a good day to check it out.  I don't have anything to compare this place to but the sandwiches were absolutely amazing.

They are made to order, the menu is small and they ask for your order while you're standing in line.  The two women making the sandwiches would put any short order cook to shame.  They churn out these tasty treats at a ridiculous pace.

I tried both the pork and chicken.  Hard to say which was better as they were both equally satisfying.  Go with another person and order different sandwiches to split.  Also, have a place in mind to eat them as there is no seating inside the tiny little closet that this restaurant occupies.
author: Robert B.

description: First off, fancy, schmancy bahn mi joints turn my stomach.  Give me the real deal.  Saigon sandwich, how do I love thee, let me count the ways.  Crunchy fresh bread and veggies, flavorful meat, pate on any sandwich (nc), haven't raised prices in conjunction with popularity that much and the best definition of a meatball sub ever.  This place is  truly a gem.  Loved it here even before there was a line.  Where else can you get a gourmet meal for $3.50?
author: tom j.

description:
Saigon Sandwich, what can I say about you that hasn't been said 1000's of times? Nothing really - only that it is an absolutely amazing and delicious sandwich. I get the roasted pork - definitely the way to go! My friend once tried the fanci pork, but didn't like it as much, so I would say go with the roasted pork. 

Here's the deal: go a bit earlier than 12 to beat the lines, don't be put off by the neighborhood, don't care that the store looks a little questionable, and be happy when a yummy meal only costs 3.25. ENJOY!
author: Ashley H.

description: My mommy would take me here for their chicken sandwiches. Every time I go here it brings back good memories of my mom. I miss her. But their Banh Mi are alway dope.
author: Lynn T.

description: I usually like this place but recently my visits have varied in customer care. I still think the sandwiches are delicious! Well, I should say all but the tofu are good. I like tofu and all but don't really like how we pay the same price for so little tofu. The ladies here can be nice....but they can also be very rude. I just went today for lunch and I can say I did not like how I was treated. Maybe it was because I went during rush hour? Maybe not. I just didn't like going there today.
author: Alex T.

description: Highly over-rated for yelpers. I am surprised that there was actually a line. I didn't want to believe it when I read about this place. The bread was kinda hard and dry. The roast pork and pate was really good inside, but I really couldn't get into it, especially when the bread is kinda tough. The service was eh...I didn't understand the lady, and with a long line, I wonder why they never bother to hire another person to work the line. I noticed that she handle someone's money and then touch the ingredients. Uh gross. I try to be an open-minded person, and hope to God I don't get food posioning, luckily I haven't. For a cheap sandwich, and don't mind the wait. Come here, otherwise go to Lee's, I think it's safer to eat there, cause the cashier isn't  the one making the sandwiches.
author: Jenny W.

description: Excellent Vietnamese sandwiches that covers most of the different varieties of fillings. The combo is jam packed with different meats and drips with good pork juices, very tender and moist!! Hummm, bite after bite and its less than $4 bucks!!!! That's why I've been here over 40 plus times!!! Fast and inexpensive!!!!
author: Wolfy W.

description:
Toasty baguette that was crispy on the outside but chewy and soft towards the center. I had a special combination sandwich not knowing what's inside but was looking forward to be surprised! Boy... it was fantastic. Special sauce (not mayo) slathered together with pate ham roasted meaty goodness- with abundance of pickled vege and pepper. It was perfect. Delicious. Cheap. and totally hit the spot.

The 1 star missing is the over all cleanliness of the store- I wish it could be less cluttered and when we walked in they were defrosting one of the refrigerator @ the front and the water was literally all over the floor. Also, the messy refrigeration display case had random pots and meats and stuff that I cant name. It did raise some health concerns on my mind. I seem to be doing fine right now but it would make me feel safer to see the food being prep from a clean area.
author: Amy Y.

description:
If this place hadn't been on 7x7's annual top 100 list, I don't think I would have ever come across it nor gone inside if I did. Situated in the Tenderloin, SS is the epitome of a hole-in-wall. When I first came here, the line was around 7 deep and I was already out of the door.

What they lack in decor and ambiance, they make up for it (and more) with their banh mi, Vietnamese sandwiches. Their meats, especially the meatball, are juicy and flavorful. I usually get that and sometimes their pork or combo. Their bread is hands down the best I've ever tasted from a banh mi shop. Sometimes, when bread has been sitting, it becomes stale, tough to chew, and rough on the roof of your mouth. This is not the case for SS, however, as their bread is perfectly toasted, flaky on the outside, and soft on the inside. 

My only gripe with SS, and the reason why I couldn't give it 5 stars, is that they are sometimes stingy with their meat and fill the sandwich with more of their pickled veggies, instead. Ah that reminds me, I think their veggies need more acid/vinegar, so I guess I have two gripes. Despite those two negatives, I think SS has one of the best banh mi's in SF/Oakland. I will definitely be back and next time, I'll try to see if they'll let me order it with double meat. Then, that will be close to banh mi perfection.
author: Alex C.

description: amazeballs. got the meatball sandwich for 3.75 great value and has a great kick from the fresh jalapenos.
author: Li L.

description:
Saigon Sandwich= effing awesome! Came  hear to hit the pork sandwich off my 7X7 List and was again, full and extremely happy. These little sandwiches are super tasty, got the pork and was able to eat a whole one solo and split another one with my sidekick Loren. Definitely want to come back and try the pork with pate and see how that is.

If you are in the 'Loin and can pop in, definitely try one of these tasty little suckers (at only $3.25 they are quite the bargain too). Tip: looked faster if you called in and picked up once you got there, our sammys took awhile for her to make along with everyone else who orders at once.

P.S Turtle Tower is right down the street, we also picked up some Pho to go and split to make the experience even better.
author: Sarah A.

description: Five stars for this quaint sandwich shop. A hidden gem... the bread was perfect- crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. I appreciate the appropriate use of cilantro. The flavors were very complimentary. All in all, the best bahn mi I've ever had. Folks were friendly and while seating is very limited, we made it work. I can't wait until my travels bring me back to San Francisco - this will be one of the first places I stop.
author: Krista H.

description:
SS's Banh Mi sandwiches were worth the effort.  I tried to go with a few friends yesterday, but discovered they only have 2 stools at a makeshift counter.  So we opted for Mangosteen next door - more on that next.  After a late night out, an early Sunday lunch at SS sounded perfect: simple and cheap ($3!!!), which was refreshing b/c last night's food and drink tabs were not.

For a post-Sat, we were surprisingly smart: two of us drove together, I got dropped off to order and the other circled the block fruitlessly looking for parking.  We brought 3 sandwiches back to the 3rd person who was a little hungover back at the apt.  Three of us split 3 sandwiches and therefore got to try at least 2 sandwiches each.  Smart sharing, huh?

Roast chix: solid.
Roast & steam pork: solid
Special combo: my 2 friends said the sauce was a tad better.

My only comment?  The bread is just a tad large and hard.
author: jerome c.

description: I got the roasted pork sandwich which means another check on the 7 by 7 list. Don't get me wrong, it's a good sandwich but I am not sure it is the best. I think I have been spoiled because of all the different places by where I live that sells Vietnamese sandwiches. It is a good bang for your buck but nothing special about it.
author: Eve C.

description: Wow the pork was amazing. Best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. Generous portions at a great price. I couldn't help but want seconds!
author: Helen L.

description:
Best Vietnamese sandwiches ever! My friends and I stopped here after the Giants won the world series and I was able to grab a sandwich for only $3.50! I needed to use my card and it was a $5 minimum so I grabbed some coconut dessert wrapped in a banana leaf too. Fast service, clean place, and fabulous food! 

If you ever decide to check this place out, try the #15 shredded chicken sandwich. Delish!
author: Teresa G.

description: I can't say I've done a tremendous amount of research on the matter, but at $3.50, this has to be dollar for dollar the best sandwich in the city. I recommend the pork, filling and ever so tasty.
author: Mark B.

description:
I was looking forward to going to Saigon for their famous banh mi sandwiches. I've had them elsewhere and enjoyed them very much, but had heard Saigon was "the best". 

Well...not for me. I didn't detect any fish sauce at all and was frankly grossed out by the overabundance of mayo. It was like a tube of lube with jalapenos on a pretty nice baguette. Ick.

I had a stomachache before I even finished half of it. Wow - just typing the phrase "jalapenos and mayo" gave me another flutter of stomach upset.

It looked nice and shiny in my trash can. 

Two stars for the nice baguette, cool collection of soft drinks and interesting packaged sweets.
author: wendella a.

description:
After a long day of perusing sex shops (for a gag gift for my friend, you perverts) and thrift stores, my companion and I were absolutely exhausted and dying of starvation.

A dilemma arose, however: we were broke spending our money on useless thrift store art and a fake anus molded from some no-name blond porn star.

WHAT SHALL WE DO??

Panic set in. My palms began sweating. My friend declared announced sadly that he had sharted. I comforted him with a pat on the shoulder (didn't want to get too close to him).

Luckily, I am a proud Android phone owner, pulled up the Yelp app and found this delicious hole in the wall delight.

$3 for a sandwich is beaten by, like, nothing outside of jack in the box. But these sandwiches are exponentially better, larger, and can (OMG!) be eaten sober. The roasted pork sandwich will definitely be consumed on a regular basis.
author: Victor B.

description:
I grew up on Vietnamese sandwiches by Little Saigon and let me tell you that the combo sandwich blows the other sandwiches out of the water.

Perhaps it's the pate... or perhaps it's the mayo... no, it's the bread...or..or...it could be so many different things, but together it's just plain deliciousness!  

If you want to give this place a try, I would recommend coming at off-peak hours (i.e. not lunch).  The line can get painful... unless you're a neighborhood V-Boy then you can just cut up to the front and grab a little piece of something.
author: Johnny C.

description: Oh Saigon Sandwich, how doth I love you...in innumerable ways.  On many a Monday morning schleping through the TL to work after a couple of days without street cleaning, you are the only thing that smells good.  You fill my still sleepy  nostrils with sweetness, eliciting salivation and joy.  If only I wasn't trying to give up bread...I'd eat you for lunch nearly everyday.  I eat meat, but the tofu sandwich is what I crave.  I have had so many great talks with  my best friend over a tofu sandwich bursting with cilantro and jalapenos...  a comfort food of sorts.  The women who work here have sandwich ordering and making down to a find art and function like a well greased machine.  Plus...price cannot be beat!  Yum.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I got the steamed pork & roasted pork combo sandwich and it was faaaaantastic!  I normally dislike sauces on my sandwich, but they put some sort of amazing sauce on there that gave it a tinge of sweet flavor.  

I think what put me over the edge and made this a 5-star sandwich was the bread!  Quizno's could learn a lesson or two from this place about toasting bread to perfection, because that was the case here.

They're a good size, and costing between $3.00-3.50, you can't afford NOT to.

There are also lots of Vietnamese snacks and drinks that you can get to accompany your sando, like sticky rice and flavored/seasoned peanuts.

The only reason why I didn't give this place 5 stars is because there is no place to sit down--it is literally a hole in the wall.  Given the shady locale, it's not like you can go across the street and sit down in a nice park and eat your sando in peace, exactly...

So expect to get your food on the go!
author: Alice C.

description:
Wow...what can I say except that I've lost all respect for most San Franciscan yelpers...unless I happened to have tried this place on the *worst day possible*.

Here's why the food fairies are dead:
(1) Wilted cilantro
(2) Cheap pate 
(3) Pickled veggies without the punch
(4) Bread was ok - nothing to rave about

In another words...4.5 stars? ARE YOU FREAKIN KIDDING ME? I was there for only two days, and depended on the good citizens of SF and yelp to guide me, and now I feel the bitter taste of grand disappointment.

The last time I visited San Francisco, 5 years ago, it was like foodie paradise - what happened? It seems like the evolution of modern cuisine in other cities like Seattle and even San Diego are surpassing it...

The only reason why I would come back to this place is to buy a sandwich and then proceed to throw it to the ground Napoleon Dynamite style.
author: Anh ..

description: ATTENTION VEGANS AND VEGETARIANS !!!!  THE SAUCE THEY USE IS CHICKEN BASED.  CONFIRMED!   Tofu is not marinated in any animal products.  So if you want a vegetarian sandwich, you have to order with no sauce.  You can ask for soy sauce if you want.  If vegan, ask for no sauce or mayonnaise.   Just for everyone's information.
author: Charlie S.

description:
BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES hands down in san francisco and possibly in the bay area.

awesome freakin prices for delicious meaty sammies! large selection of 
vietnamese sweets and asian snacks... i love saigon sandwiches!

help tip: call in your order and pick it up within 15 minutes! that way you won't have to stand in line and stand awkwardly in the compact waiting area while waiting for your sammie.
author: Alex C.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese Sandwich place in the City. So far! The taste of the pickled vegies are perfect, and the meat is very yummy too. They have a delicious tofu sandwich if you are into that. And Pork w/ pate for something a little more tasty/fattening :)

I'm not a big fan of their other stuff they offered...I bought some rice cake things and they were really dry. And I bought the bag of roasted chestnuts and me and my friend decided they tasted like ass. I also bought the cashew wafers and it wasn't too bad, but it wasn't amazing either. Stick with the sandwiches, I say, and if you do that you'll definitely experience 5 stars!
author: Xavier G.

description:
After a wild night and waking up on the street in the Tenderloin, I found myself at Saigon Sandwich. (Just kidden...I stopped by after a costco run.) Regardless...this place is good.
     Today, the baguette was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The roast pork and jambon gave two different variations of pork flavor. The pate spread on the baguette was a nice contrast to the well seasoned meat. The pickled carrots and fresh cilantro was a nice addition to all of the flavors.
     I REALLY want to give this place 5 stars, but there was a few small things that were missing. Although not a big deal, I did notice that there were no pickled daikon radish. There was also no head cheese offered. Overall, this place rocks!! You get an amazing sandwich for less than 4 bucks! I'll definitely be coming back...especially if I randomly find myself in the TL!
author: Siao W.

description:
You have no idea how long I've been craving a good Vietnamese sandwich.  So when I saw Saigon Sandwiches on The Big Eat SF list (#22), I jumped at the chance to cross this one off my list.

It's a tiny shop with two ladies working behind the counter, and you can tell that they know what they're doing.  There were a few people in the shop already, but they were served really quickly.

I got the roast pork sandwich (with no cilantro of course), and it was so good.  It's really flavorful, and I really liked that the pickled veggies were a bit spicy too. 

My friend and I had a bit of a brain fart when we ran out of the car with just our credit cards, and we found ourselves with only $1.50 in cash between the two of us after ordering the $3 sandwich.  Fail.

My friend ran back to the car to get some cash, but the woman at Saigon Sandwiches just gave me the sandwich and took what I had.  I still feel terrible, but they are so incredibly nice!

5 stars for the food, and 1 more if I could for unexpectedly great service!
author: Mee-Sun Y.

description:
I'm no expert on Vietnamese food, so I can't say whether Saigon's sandwiches are authentic or not, but frankly I don't really care. It's a great little hole-in-the-wall joint that I'm glad I finally checked out for myself. I work in the area, and I've heard countless times from my co-workers that this place had some good, cheap food. Guess I know now to trust them a little more.

When I first came here I thought it was odd that the place was so tiny. It's about the size of my living room, with the majority of the floorspace taken up by shelves containing stacks of assorted Asian snacks, cans of soda and energy drinks, and so on. There's barely enough standing room for ten people, let alone seating room for ... well, for ANYONE. Given that it's been pretty cold and rainy in the City lately, it was a bit of a hassle to have to get everything to go, but no big deal.

The ladies behind the counter aren't there to chit-chat. They ask what you want, make it, take your money, and that's all. In a way it's kind of nice; they're incredibly efficient at what they do, taking a group of orders at one time and churning out just as many sandwiches in a few minutes. Talk about fast service!

Price-wise, you can't complain. A single sandwich is no more than $3.50, and even though there aren't too many options, they're incredibly good, and make a good-sized meal with a small bag of chips and a drink. Personally I found the roast chicken to be quite tasty, but my friends have said good things about the pork varieties. Not sure about the tofu sandwich though. Considering you can't even get as good a meal at McDonalds without paying more, I'd say Saigon Sandwich is a bargain.

If you live or work in the area Saigon is definitely a great place to stop by on a somewhat daily basis. I hear it gets crowded during lunchtime (I've only been by around 2-3PM on weekdays), but with the speed of service it probably won't take very long to get your order. You won't be disappointed.
author: Will C.

description: Needed a quick lunch place before heading into the Orpheum. Asked Siri who sent us here and we had great sandwiches. The line was out the door, but that means 5 people in front of us. We were in and out in 5 minutes and took our sandwiches down to city hall to watch the tourist buses drive by while we ate.
author: Shirley F.
