description: This is the best meal and best deal I've had in San Francisco. Before you go pay $8.50 for a "sanitized" version at Out the Door or Bun Me, give this bunh mi a shot.  you may not get the swanky overproced atmosphere but the food is incredible. if you can't handle spicy, take off the green peppers.
author: Aubrey W.

description: Best bahn mi ever. Seriously. With about 4 other bahn mi places within blocks of each other, this place wins hands down. The bread is crispier and chewier, the special soy/mayo sauce is plentiful, the portions are generous, and all for less than $4! Normally I'm a huge pork fan but I have to say their chicken sandwich is best. It's super juicy and meaty with super extra 5-spice flavor. They love to load on the jalapeno and cilantro and carrots, too. This place is highly recommended, especially for the price and easy convenience!!!!!
author: Steenie K.

description:
So I came back to try the meatball and tofu banh mi and neither of those will bring the rating up.  The tofu has a sweet sauce that is ok for the first couple bites then becomes a soggy mess. The meatball which I'm pretty sure they call xiu mai was the sweet, peppery meatball they put in those Chinese steam white pork buns.  That was ok but not for me. 

I think my problem with American banh mi is that people think that if something tastes good with rice, over rice vermicelli (bun) or other noodles that it will taste good in a sandwich.  If I want a creative, overfilled, greasy sandwich, I'll go to Ike's. If I want a classic banh mi, I won't be going to Saigon sandwiches. And don't get me started on them heavy dense rolls they use.
author: Mimi L.

description: 4 star food, +1 for the price. Had a pork bahn mi and it was freaking delicious. And...at $3.50 a sandwich, too! What a bargain! Lines look intimidating but they clear out quickly since they're just putting the sandwiches together to order. Will definitely be back for more.
author: Sannie L.

description:
I had been trying to make a visit to this little shop for a long while now, based on mouthwatering reviews here and a little plug on the 7x7 list.  Had some time so I decided to make it my SF food tour day.  Little Star and Pearl's Deluxe Burgers, but Saigon Sandwiches first.

Very, very, very good for banh mi.... but not the best?  I found my sandwiches to be slightly too meaty, a little low on the veggies/fixins, and covered in mayo.  Perhaps it was a bad day, as I'm seeing some pictures here that have quite adequate amounts of veggies.  Oh, and I had to run back to ask them for jalapenos, since mine came with none.  Never had that one happen before.

The pate in my special combo was excellent.  Cilantro was exceptionally fresh, bread was crusty and soft inside.  Not too impressed by the fancy pork.  I'd even say that I prefer the artificially colored greatness that is Lee's cured pork and pork roll.  Though it was yummy, fast and cheap, that seems to be the M.O. for just about every banh mi venue in the Bay, so no extra stars for that.  If you're on the East side, try Banh Mi Ba Le in El Cerrito instead.
author: Virginia L.

description:
I had really high hopes for this place.  The sandwiches were decent but I just didn't love it.  Maybe I'm used to the ones from Little Paris in Chinatown.

I did think this place had leaner meat (for the roast pork) which I like since I always take out the fatty part, but it was too dry.  The bread was too dense and not as fluffy/light.  The size of the sandwich was much smaller than any other place I've had.  I liked the flavor of the condiments (carrots, cilantro, jalapenos).  I will say that the sandwich overall seemed "cleaner" in the execution than Little Paris.

I would give it a try again if I was in the area and would try something other than roast pork.
author: Irene C.

description:
BOMB

I've had banh mi in socal and love it there, but this place is definitely my #1 spot for banh mi in SF. The meat is hot and juicy, unlike the usual cold deli cuts you find at other vietnamese sandwich places. The size seems small, but definitely fills you up. The bread is not the traditional baguette bread which is perfectly fine for me. I find that sometimes the baguette bread is a little too crispy and it cuts up the inside of my mouth. Here, the bread is just crispy enough on the outside and soft and airy on the inside.

Definitely going to come back here.
author: Patrick P.

description: Get the special and be prepared to have the best vietnamese sandwich around. Love this place, just try to get there when they're actually open! TL hours!
author: Caroline D.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE.

Can I first just say how delicious this sandwich place is?! Omg, seriously, hole in the wall to the max. The ladies' behind the counter know how to make the perfect Banh Mi. 

I'm such a fan of Banh Mi's and honestly this place serves the tastiest Fancy Pork Banh Mi everrrrrrrrrr! The baguette is toasted to perfection, and the ingredients on the inside are all marinated with the perfect of all spices. Everything about the sandwich compliments the taste of what it should be. I love how full the sandwich is when you get it, usually some places only put a little bit of the meat, but boy oh boy, this place piles it on! Not to mention the flavorful carrots and radishes, that fight against the spiciness of the peppers, omgggg, so delishhhhhhh. 

One sandwich is all you need to experience the ultimate banh mi. That's all I have left to say. 

happy eating folks! :)
author: Liberty C.

description:
Damn.. I can truly say this  is a irreproachable joint!

I am located few doors down and I know this will be a weekly stop.

The bread is great and all the ingredients are perfectly marinated and flavored.

I got there around 12pm and there was a little line. I didn't have to wait long for my turn; thanks to incredible multitasking skills of the women working there. They took orders, made sandwiches, charged the clients without a register and chatting at the same time... and all that done so naturally.
author: Christian P.

description:
Sandwiches definitely lived up to the hype! I had the fanci pork which was mm mm goooood. A good sandwich starts with the bread and as soon as I smelled the rolls I knew I was in for a treat.  Meat was fresh, carrots were crispy, and the saucey thing was drooliscious.

Mind you they make the sandwiches from one order before even taking the next order, so if you are as unlucky as me to be in line behind three people who ordered like 10 sandwiches each, it can take a while. The place is a hole in the wall so waiting outside is a good idea, although it can be smelly and odd people wander around. 

BUT $3?!!? COME ON.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
I have to admit that the Banh Mi is tasty, bread is quite perfect and you can't beat the $3 price...
...but: 
- roast pork is too sweet
- carrots are on the soggy side
- combination pork was "wet", too wet....felt like eating cat chow

While eating I heard at least 5 people going for the chicken Banh Mi....we may have missed there.
author: Dario B.

description: This place is the jam. By fr the best Bahn Mi I've in the city, and definitely the cheapest ($3.50-$4.50 per sandwich). Even when there is a line out the door, I never wait for longer than a couple minutes. No frills, but when a sandwich is this good, you don't need 'em.
author: Brit F.

description:
Still m'fave. Hands down. Even if they did inflate the price AND shrink the sammich some. If you're open to boosting your cholesterol intake, I suggest asking for extra pate.

Both the sammiches and the iced coffee here kicks Lee*s Sandwiches in the arse!
author: BrasilPo P.

description: Vietnamese pork sandwich - SF's answer to Philly Cheesesteak. Hole in the wall, mom & pop shop that will fill your belly and put a smile on your face.
author: michael p.

description:
I never come to the Tenderloin. If Fresno is the armpit of California, then the Tenderloin is the ball sac of Satan. Every time I come here, I feel like I'm going to either: (1) contract gonorrhea just by breathing, (2) get my wallet jacked, or (3) step in a pile of human feces.

That said, Saigon Sandwiches is awesome! I came to the TL to get a quick haircut and run like a hurricane back to SOMA, but on the way back, I felt like a banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich) and what better place to get it than in Little Saigon? Quickly looked on Yelp (only for a few seconds, so as not to become a target to get my iPhone stolen by the crackhead pimp across the street), and I found this place. 

Now talk about finding a diamond in a shit bucket. Saigon Sandwiches had some damn good roasted pork banh mi. The place is a tiny indoor concession stand with a little old Vietnamese lady manning the sandwiches. It was damn tasty. Now, was it clean? Was it quality meats? I doubt it'll be winning any health inspection awards anytime soon. But for $3.00, it's probably better quality than McDonalds.

So yeah, I think this place is great for a quick banh mi pick-me-up. I made sure to tell them to double-bag my sandwich so as not to allow any chance of the chlamydia in the air to affect my sandwich.

Now, would I ever come back to the Tenderloin just for Saigon Sandwiches? HELLLLLLLLL NO. I wouldn't go to the Tenderloin to rescue my first-born son. BUT, if I were to ever to happen to be in the Tenderloin against my will, Saigon Sandwiches is definitely the place I'd go for a delicious Vietnamese sandwich.
author: Roy C.

description: Had the chicken and the special and both were pretty great. Not on a french bqguette, but the bread they used was acceptable. Crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. I do wish they packaged the veggies seperately so they don't get soggy if I decide to eat it later and it didn't come with soy sauce on the side, but hey, I'm asian...there's always soy sauce around the house. Will be back multiple times.
author: Alex L.

description: Absurdly delicious banh mi sandwiches for just over $3.  Called in an order for a party - you should probably call and confirm if you do because I think they forgot it - but it was a hit at the party.  REALLY wish it weren't in the Tenderloin, but I guess if it were in a better part of town, they wouldn't be so cheap and everyone would go.
author: B. Y.

description:
Awesome and cheap place for a good Vietnamese sandwich.

Both the roast pork and the roast chicken are worth it.  The Shiumai is decent as well but not as filling as the other two so you might not want to have the pork or chicken instead.

The wait are is definitely long if you get stuck here at the wrong time, but it's great if you go off rush and there's absolutely no wait.

They've also got a bunch of Vietnamese snacks which I've never tried, but they're great for some cheap eats.

They also close early and sometimes run out of the meats near the end of the day, so it's best not to go right when it's closing.
author: Jason K.

description:
Are you a fan of Vietnamese Sandwiches...maybe not. Either way you are going to love this place if you love eating good, cheap, and on the go food. 

$3 dollar sandwiches that will BLOW your mind if are tired of eating the same ole same ole Vietnamese Sandwich. This place does it right!

Grab yourself a nice cold drink, a couple sandwiches, and maybe some fresh mochi for later...kick back at your place, sit back and enjoy.
author: Nick C.

description:
Back In Bidness

Looks cleaner? and  Less cluttered.

2 sammiches = 7$

Albie Bock (get it?  ......Govenator)
author: Vance T.

description:
DELICIOUS and CHEAP BANH MI!!!

try the pork! it come with some amazing secret sauce that makes it soo much YUM!

their bread is crispy on the outside and soft/chewy in the middle..

word to the wise: CASH ONLY!!

im craving bahn mi again... crap!  -__-
author: Jeannette V.

description: Ok, but I rather eat at Lee's up the street. The problem was that the bread got really soggy a mere 30 minutes after I purchased it. I don't like how they mix siracha with mayo in the sandwich. Usually only mayo is used (well, where I've eaten viet sandwiches) and the heat comes from jalapenos. I think I like it like that and not how Saigon prepares them. The meat tasted too sweet or something strange...I know this place has a big following and that's great for them. However, I will be going to Lees.
author: Yva D.

description:
Lately I have been a bit of a snob about my vietnamese sandwiches cause I fell in love with the ones at Hoang Dat Cafe. I tell everybody to go to Hoang Dat because that's how much I love them and they are only a few blocks away from Saigon Sandwiches.

It had been awhile since I had been to Saigon Sandwiches, so I thought I would give it a try to see if it was the same/better/worse. 

I was actually pleasantly surprised. I got two sandwiches, the combination and the chicken. The flavor of the sandwiches are good and the meet they put in the combination sandwich is a little different than what I've had, but still good. I felt that the chicken sandwich was a bit on the sweeter side for my taste, but I still enjoyed it. The sandwiches were nice and warm and the peppers were especially hot, which made it even better. 

I felt that the bread was a bit chewy for me and therefore still prefer my sandwiches from Hoang Dat Cafe. 

Overall good sandwiches, but if I had to wait in line, then I would definitely go to Hoang Dat,
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Ummm, yeah, this was okay?  I didn't think it was amazing, but I did like the price - $4.25 for a sandwich and a soda.  I had the roast pork viet. sandwich.  

Spend a little more and get any sub at AK Subs.  No, it's not as close, and not as cheap, but wayyyyy better.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
A friend of mine recently asked me if I knew of any good cheap places to eat in San Fran. Just getting back from eating my way around the bay I had a list of places to give him. This was one of my favorites. Standing in line for 20 minutes to get a $3 pork Bahn Mi was worth every second and every bite. 

The sandwich was perfectly balanced. It was sweet, tangy, spicy, salty, and umami. $3 dollars that's it for a sandwich piled high with pork, shredded carrots, pickled onions, fresh cilantro. I would have paid double and would have been happy to wait another 20 minutes. I take that back I wouldn't have waited 40 minutes.
author: Jeffrey K.

description: $3.25 = huge, spicy, sweet, cilantro packed fried tofu on a fresh baguette. I'm going to get fat working around the corner from this place.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Best banh mi ever!  I tried the roast pork one, as well as the combination one and both were delicious.  For under $4 a pop, you can't really go wrong.  The place itself is definitely a hole in the wall, but they have a random assortment of Asian snacks such as prawn chips and those Hi Chew candies that are so tasty, so I like to stop in and get some random snacks.

My only problem with this place is that it is in the middle of the hood.  I would dare NOT venture here at night alone, and occasionally during the day get kind of freaked out.  There are tons of bums outside, one whom actually followed me to my car asking me to spare some change.  As long as they are harmless, I don't really mind but I think the area could be unsafe at night, especially for a small, young, unaccompanied female.  Consider yourselves warned ladies!
author: Maxine S.

description:
Ok. I've done 15 reviews in SF and have yet to give 5 stars to anything.

But this place is THE BOMB. Wow. Had a Bahn Mi just as they were closing tonight. Got the chicken, and wasn't expecting much really.

But this sandwich was effin tasty. I have no idea how they made it taste so good. Hands down the best food I've had in SF so far. (I'm here from NYC). That's saying a lot.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Saigon Sandwich en route to Bart en route to Airport =  :)

Best Vietnamese sandwich in town. Thankfully I live close by cuz there's no seating there.
author: Amber G.

description:
I wish they had a spot like this in San Jose. I've always wanted my Vietnamese sandwiches to be on the saucy side. I've had too many dry ones. Saigon Sandwiches definitely answered this problem. For $3 each, you can't beat this deal. They aren't shady with the meat either. 

Went on a Sunday afternoon and surprisingly the line was out the door. The lady is quick to take your order so be prepared. 

It's cash only and theres no where to sit down and eat.
author: Andrew C.

description:
You can't go wrong at this place!  I went with two friends and we were able to get 6 sandwiches and 3 sodas all for around $20.  Their sandwiches (had the tofu) changed my life...they really are that good.  My favorite part is the sliced jalapenos and sauce they put on them.  You can't eat at the shop but a short walk down the street is City Hall and it's many grassy parks.  

Careful, this place is addictive.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Had to try this place, having come across the hugely favorable Yelp reviews whilst searching out Vietnamese options across the city.

It's definitely worth trying, as it must be one of the best food deals in SF.  So why only three stars from me when so many others gave Saigon Sandwich four or five?  The sandwiches are freshly made and big-time bargains, but only folks who're a) very hungry AND b) nearly out of money AND c) refuse to prepare their own food at home, AND d) in the neighborhood are likely to find the Saigon Sandwiches experience so compelling that they become regulars.  I enjoyed my sandwich, but I can't say it crossed the "wow!" threshold.

In case you've never written a Yelp review, please know that *** is officially defined as "A-OK".  That is to say, in this case, I wouldn't discourage anyone from trying Saigon Sandwich.  Just attempting to be accurate and consistent in my ratings.

If you're hungry, low on funds, and in/near the 'Loin, this could be a good place to spend your last $3.50.
author: Francisco G.

description:
if i could eat more than one of thier sandwiches in one sitting i would, but alas it'd be too much.
Their chicken and pate is full of flavor.  Combination ham is all that i expected and more.  
I used to never like cilantro in my sandwiches but you can't have a vietnamese sandwich without everything in it.  Keep in mind, that they order in rounds here, so you'll wait in line, order in a group, and get your sandwhich in a group.  Be patient, it's worth the wait.
author: Susan Z.

description:
Don't try and strike up a conversation with the boss lady. She's there to make sandwiches in exchange for your moolah.

Boss Lady: [to me, practically screaming] HI HELLO. WHAT YOU WANT 

Me: A chicken and a pork sandwich!!

Boss Lady: [to police officer] HI HELLO WHAT YOU WANT

Po-po: pork sandwich

Boss Lady: [to unsuspecting out of towner hipster] HI HELLO WHAT YOU WANT

Out of town hipster: Hey, how you doin'? Wow....I can't decide! 

Boss Lady: (practically screaming) WHAT YOU WANT!! 

OFTH: Uh, (stumbling) uh, erk...sorry, oh chicken.

So, be prepared to 
1) verbalize your order at any second
2) fork out the right amount of money - 3 dollar bills ought to do it for one sandwich
3) do NOT engage in small talk (Hospitality is not included in the small price one pays for a sandwich)

The sandwiches are delicious and cheap. The sandwiches are worth making the journey to TL and possibly getting beat up.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Hands down the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever eaten.

Three dollars gets you a fantastic baguette topped with fresh cilantro, jalapeños, carrot, a small (read: perfect) dollop of sauce and - in my case - roast pork.

A compact, inexpensive, DELICIOUS meal that fits in the palm of your hand.

**Is there any better way to enjoy a stroll through this lovely, welcoming area of San Francisco than munching on a Viet sandwich and slugging Orangina?**

The shop also features numerous Asian snacks, drinks and seating for two very lucky or very lazy people.
author: Blake C.

description:
Very good. My only beef with this place, if any, is that the bread is too hard. Makes it difficult to speed eat it without chafing the roof of your mouth. And you might want to take out the peppers if u can't handle spicy. 
Very cheap and relatively quick as well. Nearly fast food fast.
author: Matthew T.

description: There's a lot of places to get vietnamese sandwiches. But this place tops it all! Its cheap, tasty, and the best viet sandwich u can get! Their menu is limited but i always go for the combo, which is about $3.75 and it has bbq pork and the other types of meat that usually come in the combo. If you go around lunch time, there's usually a line but its not too long of a wait. There's no place to sit so its just pick up your sandwiches and eat some place else. This place is a definitely a place you need to come back.
author: Anita W.

description:
My luv of the cheap, but yummy, Vietnamese sandwich started here years ago and I'm glad to see that people are still enjoying them.

Get one for lunch and one for later - you know you'll want another!

I like the spicy pork but haven't heard of a bad sammich from here before.
author: Mike J.

description:
I love the sandwiches here... much better than Lee's sandwiches at a cheaper price!  I love the bread and the mayo... my only request would be more cilantro and jalapenos.

Parking is not that difficult if you know the area... plenty of metered parking in the small side streets... i have never had a parking problem.

ps.. sometimes there could be a wait in line.. recently i waited 20 minutes
author: Jasen L.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for a while now after reading all the yelp reviews and finally the other day I went for it!  Yes, its in the Tenderloin, but its really not all that bad.  I was a bit nervous about the long line, but don't be fooled- it went really fast.  The lady's make several sandwiches at one time.

I decided to go with the tofu sandwich because of all the  reviews I had been reading and I was so satisfied when I finished it.  I have never had a Vietnamese sandwich before, so I cant really compare it to anything- hence the 4 stars.  However, the flavors of the sandwich were great- and for $3, what more could you ask for?

Yes, I would defiantly come here again and try another item but there could be a good chance I stick with the tofu because it was that good!
author: Cara D.

description:
This place is the thing I miss the most about San Francisco... $3.75 for a French baguette full of win...  they are simply amazing... so tasty... so very, very tasty... 

I tried the chicken (which was good), but my favorite is by far the pork... also had the banana sticky rice and spring rolls too, both of which were also really excellent...
author: Frank E.

description:
Excellent sandwiches.  Especially the pork meatball.  Good bread, decent amount of meat, and tasty pickled vegetables.

The line can get kind of long though so be prepared to wait 20 minutes or more if you get there at lunch time.

Good value as well for ~$3 each though they might jack up the prices after the current remodeling.  On the positive side, perhaps with the remodel, they can be more efficient and lines won't be as long.
author: Charles M.

description: I had to deduct a star from my previous review because of the piece of hair in my combo banh mi. I was careful to ensure it wasn't my own hair that fell as it was tucked into the meat and short hair about 4 inches long. I have long hair. I am disappointed by their sanitation and hope they start wearing some hair nets.
author: Peachie Y.

description:
I decided to give Saigon Sandwich a try today for breakfast and ordered the Vietnamese pork sandwich and a can of mr Brown ice coffee.

 there was only a short line in the morning, the sandwich was smaller than I expected and didnt have much pork, mostly fatty pieces with very little meat, Ive tasted better Viet sandwiches , they were average, nothing to brag about, this place is so tiny and only has room for two people to sit down by the window to eat, no restrooms, it's more of a order to go type sandwich shop not really set up for customers to sit down and eat a sandwich here. But the lady that makes the sandwiches is very fast!
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE...

I've been going to this place for years. My dad always orders over the phone and because we do that...we save a lot of time & get to cut the people in line.  The prices used to be cheaper, but rose to $3.

I always get the BBQ CHICKEN banh mi. so delicious, just as good the next day if you order more for lunch.  SIMPLY DELICIOUS and a MUST TRY if you're in the TL.  

Oh, I'm not too big of a fan of spicy and I MEAN their jalapenos are UBER SPICY. like burning in your tongue until i can drink half a cup of milk before it cools off.  So i like to hold the jalapenos (just FYI) for those who dont like spicy foods!

I also really LOVE their green cake. It's so fresh and delicious. drools* thinking about it really makes me want it now...their soy milk is also super fresh but not worth $2 a pop since you can get one of those half gallon ones from any super market for the same price :]

The ladies who work here work super fastttttt!!  And they can speak cantonese! YAY.
author: Steph L.

description:
This place is deadly serious.

$3 out the door for a tasty, delicious sandwich?
Seriously.

Jalapenos that will burn your lips like some sort of horrible STD if you're not careful?
Seriously.

One place to sit for one person... and it's a window seat?
So seriously.

Alright, this doesn't even sound like a positive review anymore.  But seriously, this was the first Vietnamese sandwich I ever had (I tried to pork, as it's the traditional choice... perhaps because it's the most awesome), and it knocked my socks off.  

If you don't know by now, a Vietnamese sandwich (here) consists of meat of choice, cilantro, shredded carrot, cucumber (unless I dreamt that), sliced jalapenos, mayo, and tasty-tasty magic sauce on a french roll.  If you order it without the tasty-tasty magic sauce, you're an asshole and you don't deserve to eat sandwiches.  Especially Vietnamese ones.  Go have another ham and cheese on white bread, you failure.
It was like Saigon Sandwiches was catering this party, but due to a scheduling conflict, the party had to be held in my mouth at the last minute, and a really large number of people were invited.  It seemed, literally, like everyone.

There can be a wait here around lunchtime, so come during an odd hour, such as 3pm, and you'll get a scrumptious delicacy within just a few minutes, for $3 even.  Shee-it, you might even be lucky enough to get "the seat".
author: Kyle O.

description:
Its ok...but not amazing.

Juicy roast pork. Bread was decent but nothing spectacular. Overall good but not awesome. Meat reminded me of chipotle a bit.

Sammich "leaks" a lot of juice so make sure that you keep it in the paper wrapper, otherwise you'll end up with a bunch of stains on your pants!  Not a great thing.

The bread really just wasn't there, the best part about the food here was that the sammy was STUFFED. Like you first see it and think...it's gonna be small...and then they pack that shit like a line worker packing a box full-o-fudge.
author: H B.

description:
I went to Saigon Sandwiches for lunch today and posted a pic of one of my sandwiches on my Facebook page. Within an hour I had 16 comments; here's a quick sample:

Mmmm! 
Yum!
Delcious!
I hate you
NOM (two times)
Phil, you should weigh 400 pounds
Sooooo good
Jealous

Six bucks for two delicious sandwiches and an afternoon's worth of entertainment? Damn straight.
author: phil h.

description:
This little grocery store has the best Viet sandwiches in the city.  The flavors are not toned down here.  I usually get the combination (with pate) or the roast pork sandwich.  The charshu (BBQ roast pork) are nicely marinaded and the cold cuts(mystery meat as my friend calls it) in the combination sandwich are flavorful.  Sandwiches come with pickled carrots and Daikon (radishes), Cilantro and Jalapenos.  

The market is definitely not attractive.  It's tiny, dark and outdated.  Sandwiches are cheap at ~$3.50 - $4 per sandwich, but my friends from South Bay complains that it's overpriced.  I guess it's only $2 to $3 around San Jose since they have a larger Vietnamese community.  

I've brought out-of-towners here who have never had a Vietnamese Sandwich before Saigon Market.  We usually end up with multiple return trips to Saigon.  A couple of them even said this was the best food experience while they visited SF!
author: Paul K.

description:
If your a fan of Banh Mi's then you have to try out Saigon Sandwiches. They are almost like my favorite banh mi spot in Oakland, Ba Le. But they use a different type of bread. They don't use the original Vietnamese small round baguettes. They use more of a mixed bread. The bread is great it taste like a mix of a ciabatta and a dutch crunch rolled into one. Real nice texture and has a great chewiness to it. 

I ordered the roast pork and i have to say that was a great sandwich. Everything about it from the pork to the pickled veggies. Tasted very fresh and the best part was they made it very fast. I walked in and made my order and they made it instantly. As soon as i turned around there were about 6 other people behind me, im glad i got mines before them. Im taking half a star off because they charge $3 dollars for a banh mi. And that is a dollar more then all the other spots. Three dollars is still cheap but i just paid $4 in toll.

4.5 Stars for Saigon Sandwiches in SF
author: Lux K.

description:
These $3.00 bites are awesome! The ingredients are fresh and the bread is fantastic, as for the meat (? its what I call mystery meat)... Although the chicken, pork and pate all looked the same, if you can get beyond looks they taste really good. 
For someone who lived off Subway- this is a nice change. 
Beware though- if you do call be prepared to be on hold for a long time. I called to place a large 30 sandwich order and had to put a coworker on the phone, no English!
author: Janell D.

description:
Avoiding the crowd and long lines for food at PRIDE, my friend and I trekked up the slight incline Larkin to visit the famous Saigon Sandwich! 
We were expecting a long line but there was only 3 people in front of us...SCORE! I ordered the chicken and my friend ordered the beef. The bread was crisp and the middle soft, the meat, perfectly marinated and the vegetables with a crunch! DELICIOUS! There was no place to really sit as this place is like a deli/store so we sat on the sidewalk devouring our sandwiches. 

What a perfect sandwich for a perfect sunny day in SF!!
author: Myron J.

description: very very good Vietnamese style sandwiches. I love this place. I always have the combination one. Good for togo
author: Suabot J.

description:
I've been here twice and each time it was okay. After reading the reviews, I'm frankly surprised that it has received such high ratings. Don't get me wrong, I really love hole in the wall places - but I cannot see their sandwiches being more than average.

Good amount of filler in the banh mi, but smaller torpedo (bread) than the normal sandwich. It also costs more dollars than the what I'm used to paying for a sandwich of this variety. I'm not completely in love with this place, but when I'm very hungry, in the area, and craving a banh mi, this is where I'd be.
author: Vicki L.

description: Probably my favorite grab-and-go lunch in the city: it's extremely cheap ($3.50!), quick enough, and the tastiest sandwich ever.  What could be better than roasted pork, pickled carrots and onions, fresh cilantro, jalapeno, magical sauces on crusty bread?  Might just go get one now...
author: Renée R.

description: Want a Bahn-mi with all the flavor at a good price? Other places come close, but there's a reason people use up a good portion of their lunch break to line up here...It's GOOOOD.
author: Orlando J.

description:
This place is like a little hole in the wall. They were slicing the pork right in front of us. We got the pork bahn mi (of course). And omg it was sooo good! and it was only like $4!! so cheap. The sauce they put in there with their pork makes it so juicy and flavorful and the pickled carrots and daikon radish and the cilantro topped it off. Also, the bread..oh the bread...it was crunchy and soft on the inside. Just like a vietnamese baguette should be. The perfect sandwich on the go.

PS. cash only!!!
author: Michelle V.

description:
If you're looking for a great Vietnamese sandwich, Saigon Sandwich is a sure bet in San Francisco.  There's generally a line so be prepared to wait for your sandwich as the two Vietnamese ladies behind the counter prepare your meal.

The sandwiches don't seem to be as large as the ones in SoCal, but don't let that fool you.  For $3 you get a sandwich stuffed with all of the normal goodies in perfect balance.  It may not seem like a lot, but it is definitely filling and fulfilling.  Don't expect to find much space to actually eat your sandwich.  This place is built for take-out in mind.

I'm a fan of hole in the wall places the provide quality food and Saigon Sandwich is definitely one such place.  Two thumbs up.
author: Kelvin V.

description:
"Bang me" once, you get my attention.

"Bang me" twice, you impress me.

"Bang me" three or more times with the same quality
and consistency, you put yourself on the map as...

DA best place in San Francisco to get Vietnamese "Banh Mi" (pronounced "Bang me" in English) sandwiches.  And for ONLY THREE BUCKS a pop, my favorites, after all these years, are still 1) the roast pork and 2) the special combo, which includes the pate spread (fancy word in french for liverwurst).

Even though SAIGON SANDWICHES is a hole in the wall, the patrons who line up are from bike messengers to office workers and from students to police officers.    

If you have never been here before, expect the wait to be 15 minutes or more.  Long line during lunch time and bumping elbows in small space. Two seats in the front (this is a CASH ONLY takeout place, like the old school Blondie's Pizza). 

The two Asian women operation is surprisingly efficient.  Quick service, unlike the post office!  They make the toasted sandwiches with fresh ingredients, like shredded carrots, jalapeno and cilantro.  

Tips:
* Call in advance for your order, so your wait time shrinks.
* Get one more sandwich to go.  Great snack for you or your friend.
* Ask to leave off the jalapeno peppers.  It may save you from burning your lips!

You simply the get the most "Bang me" for your BUCKS here!  I believe I am the 756th reviewer.
author: CT L.

description:
This is probably the best banh mi option in SF, but the ultimate best stuff is in the San Joe hood. 

The roasted pork sandwich definitely satisfies if I need a banh mi fix in the city.
author: Lisa H.

description:
My favorite traditional Vietnamese sandwich place in SF. People seem partial to the special pork, but I love their chicken sandwich. 

Their sandwiches used to cost $2.75, but then they raised it to $3.25. When I walked in and saw the price change, I was indignant--an almost 20% hike! Then I realized I was being a spoiled jerk. Saigon could triple their price and it would still be a better deal than those artisanal banh mi spots that like to call srirachi plus mayo 'spicy aoli.' So save your indignation for places like that, and reserve your appetite for Saigon Sandwiches.
author: Bradley T.

description: One of the best Vietnamese bbq chicken sandwiches (banh mi ga) I've had in recent memory. The line can grow quickly, even at odd times of the day, but it can also move relatively quickly as well depending on how many sandwiches the patrons in front of you order. The ladies behind the counter work so hard and so fast it's amazing. I think it literally only takes them about 30 seconds to make each sandwich. At only $3 it's easily one of the best sandwiches and budget meals you can find.
author: Erich D.

description:
Now I know why so many chefs eat here.
Lightest non-greasy roasted pork sandwich everrr.. With a lot of fresh veggies too. Tasty.
author: Melanie C.

description: The store is super small but I have to agree that sandwiches here are better then Lee sandwiches which is located near by.  Their bread is unique and they re-toast the bread before making, they stuff a lot of meat inside, you can feel the weigh of complete sandwich is heavy.  I don't like the special sandwich because of too much chicken, I like the Grill Pork and Sui Mai the most!  Recommend to order with vegetables on the side if you don't eat them right away.
author: Mit L.

description: I've tried the chicken, pork, and pate sandwiches and they are all consistently 3.5-star quality compared to what I'm used to in Atlanta. With the high ratings and the sandwiches being a dollar more ($3.50 each instead of $2.50), I really expected more. Also, if you come during an especially busy time, the lady making the sandwiches seems to stop caring about spreading out the sandwich filling evenly so you get a bunch of meat on one side and all the jalapenos on the other side. That said, I would still recommend this place as it's much better than most other banh mi places in town so go for it!
author: Amaryllia L.

description:
I'm not saying I don't think they're delicious nor am I saying I won't ever go there again but after seeing a cockroach stroll calmly across the tabletop, I can say I won't be back ANYTIME soon! 

My only other complaint would be the 87343487 times I've called in for a "meatball pork" only to discover a "BBQ pork" sandwich in my hand.  It can't be that difficult?  Right??

Other than that, for $3 a pop, it's pretty damn bomblicious.  

Oh yeah, their meatball pork sandwich (when they get it right) is REALLY, REALLY freakin gooood.  That, in itself, deserves 5 stars :)
author: Lisa W.

description: The roasted pork tastes like Chinese Chashu, which is awesome! The "special combination" is highly recommended as you can have several main ingredients rather than simply roasted pork in it.
author: Dihao Z.

description:
Gawd. Just do yourself a huge favor and order the roasted pork for $3.00. As a matter of fact, order 4. One for lunch, one for dinner, one for your significant other, and one for  lunch the next day..... That's what I did! These "BANG ME's" (Bahn Mi) are the BIZZZOOOMMBB!!!

I walked down 6 long SF downtown blocks to the Tenderloin to see what all the rave was about....and a female walking solo to through the Tenderloin is bold.....walking amidst the drunks, homeless beggers, hoes and their pimps, and the like...........but I just had to check it out and no one was gonna get in my way!

...and I'm sure as hell glad I did!!

Walking down Larkin St. from Geary St, I passed about 4 other Vietnamese sandwich spots that were empty....including Lee's (which was my favorite prior to visiting Saigon). When I approached Saigon, there was a line outside the door....so I knew I was definitely in for a treat!

Ugh....I'm already craving it again......
author: Kat M.

description:
Traditional Vietnamese sandwiches come no closer to the ones they have here.

Well, ok, by traditional I mean the kind that I used to eat out of my fraternity brother's refrigerator when his mom would make him these sandwiches... when he wasn't looking.

It comes with huge slices of hot peppers and my least favorite: cilantro clippings. But I still eat it. My jaw hurts from all the chewing of the bread.

I like. A lot, almost as much as I like Little Paris sandwiches.
author: Alfred Y.

description: banh mi doesnt get any better than this place. i have eaten here for over 20 years and it is still the same, except for the price. nothing compares to this place, especially the xi mai sandwiches. so awesome. parking is a bitch here though, but worth the effort and parking tickets. hell yeah
author: Ethyl M.

description:
Really small shop - really really small menu -- really really really good sandwiches. 

I don't think I could qualify to speak much on what makes a good French bread but damn - this shop's french bread has just the right crust/texture that my teeth like. Went back two days in a row and adding this to my quick to-go lunch spots in the area. 

Considering they have 5 or so items chalked on their menu, I was wondering what the fuss is all about. Things I noticed - the line that forms outside, on an average has people rolling out Tofu, roast chicken and pork to the lady behind the counter.  Vegetarian options other than Tofu - I think are limited. 

One bite into their version of a sandwich - french bread, roasted pork, cilantro, carrots, and their sauce  - and bang - you will be back. This would never be guessed on price-is-right.


The food's really good but had to drop a star for the  approach to the place.
author: Ajay J.

description:
TOP FIVE REASONS WHY I LOVE SAIGON SANDWICHES

5.  The two ladies manning the store.  They are really good at what they do (even if it consists of making sandwiches, wrapping them, calling out orders, and taking cash).  When lines are long (which is almost always), it's fun to watch them do their thing with such finesse and efficiency.

4.  Asian snack galore!  Calbee Shrimp Flavored Chips, "yupi" peanuts, Pretz, Hi-Chew gummies, Vietnamese pandan treats, and so much more!  They really pack this little store with tons of goodies -- their snacks are piled up against the wall.

3.  They sell banh lot (my favorite green worm-like and coconut dessert)!  Of all places in SF, I've only seen it sold at Little Paris in Chinatown and now here!

2.  The lady who's the cashier and also wraps the sandwiches knows all about hygiene.  You'll notice her putting on her plastic gloves to wrap the banh mi and she'll take them off when ringing you up.  And repeat.

1.  Their banh mi, duh.  Roast pork and combination are my favorite!
author: Diane L.

description: Saigon Sandwiches is what San Francisco is all about!!!  A little hole-in-the-wall place that has retail products stacked in the front window, and one person there to make cheap and fantastic sandwiches.  This place is completely void of any fancy decor... their creativity comes through in the tastebuds in your mouth.  They sell Vietnamese sandwiches, some homemade/cooked traditional snacks, and some pre-packed foods that are not in English.  I walk away happy from Saigon Sandwiches every single time.
author: Katie V.

description:
I am pleased to report that Saigon Sandwich popped my bahn mi cherry on Sunday. In a word, wow.

So, I've seen bahn mi everywhere, but most pictures and signs that are hung in windows, long faded by the sun, make it look less than appealing. Thus the reason for never trying it.

That was a stupid mistake. However, it was easily reconciled by trying Saigon Sandwich as my first. Yes, it's a sketchy neighborhood, and yes, there are some freaky Vietnamese snacks and desserts splayed out everywhere that I can't even begin to tell what food they were made from. But $4 for the best sandwich of my life makes me really not care about much else. Of course, I had two.

Run, do not walk, and enjoy spending the best $4 of your life.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Rivals Philly's Vietnamese Hoagies. Tofu was great, although friend reported her chicken Banh Mi was undercooked. So -- stick with the tofu as the safer choice, grab a drink, and find a place to sit down by the Civic Center. 

Service was curt, which is fine, but I asked for a receipt (from the pad that was right in front of me) + they refused. Nice... Anyway - good tofu banh mi, go in, order, get out, eat.
author: Andrew R.

description: Saigon Sandwich will always have a special place in my heart as that is where i had my first taste of Bahn Mi. Needless to say, i haven't had a comparable Bahn Mi since. They are simply perfection and at under $4 a pop, are the world's greatest bargain. I go for the roast pork every time.
author: Josh N.

description:
I've heard about this place, it's the Viet Sandwich Go-To place!

I went here this morning to pick up sandwiches for my BF, my PT and myself. It was around 10:30ish, and I didn't know I was so lucky until I left the place. It was pretty empty when I got in; the ladies were busy making sandwiches and I ordered. It took them a bit to get my sandwiches (Roast Chicken, Roast Pork and Fanci Pork) done, but they looked like they were prepping for the rush hour later on. When I left the place, the line of people extended all the way past the door. 

Each sandwich was $3.00 each, and the total bill with tax was $9.50. The sandwich itself is smaller than the ones I am used to eating, but nevertheless it was packed with hearty meats and fresh and radiantly-colored veggies. They don't skimp on the ingredients. The actual sandwiches that I tried ( R.Pork and F. Pork) were a good balance; the R Pork was flavorful, and the F. Pork was subtle and fresh. 

This isn't a place for you to sit and eat; it's really a grab-and-go. The little space is crammed with other products, like a sandwich place embedded in a Vietnamese grocery shop. Cute place really. 

The only thing is that I asked for the Pork sandwiches to be free of jalapenos (if you can't take spices, I suggest you ask them to leave it out when they make it), but my R Pork had a bit of jalapenos smushed inside. When I first took a bite, and I felt the spices running up my tongue, but since I didn't see the jalapenos, I thought it was the sauce! My BF said they probably put some in, forgot, and took them out, leaving some seeds there for the spicy taste. Most of the sandwich was good after that, until I go to the end and my mouth was on fire and I was tearing like a baby. I looked into the sandwich and saw a little piece of jalapeno, disguised as cilantro, sticking out of my sandwich! :(  It was so spicy I had to stop eating the sandwich and down a bottle of water. I really can't take some types of spicy foods. 

This place is worth a try though. Jam-Packed Ingredients onto a mini sandwich. Yum. 

Oh! This was my fault, but when I was looking up at the menu (it looked like they only had 6 things), I thought the menu was separated by sandwiches and entrees (it had this misleading block thing). Turns out the 2nd part of the menu were sandwiches too (special combo, etc). Don't make the same mistake I did!

Oh, oh! When one of the ladies were taking the rest of the orders, customers were making requests like "more sauce, more veggies, more meat," (all from one person, actually) etc, so I'm guessing you can sorta tailor your sandwich! Good to know! :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My mom's been bringing me to to Saigon Sandwiches since I was a tike (I'm 24 now.)  After all these years, this is still THE vietnamese sandwich shop to go to.  Before we go on long road trips, we come here and pack up bags and bags of sandwiches.  After, shopping in downtown or Chinatown, we stop by and load up on sandwiches on the way home.  On random days when I'm in a slump, I get a sandwich for lunch and I feel that much better.  It's a definitely a comfort food for me.

My favorite is the pork sandwich.  The sauce and the mayo combo is delicious.  The baguettes are always fresh.  The pickled carrots and cillantro are a must even though I'm not a fan of pickles.  And the whole thing is just 3 bucks!  I've also tried their meatball and chicken and combo and they're all also delicious but my fave will still always be pork.  Also, they sell a lot of Asian snacks and goodies along the counters.  That always gets to me when I smell fresh baked rice cake desserts.  I always have to buy something extra along with my sandwich!

It's definitely a hole in the wall type of establishment but the quality of the food is nothing of the sort.  The lines get RIDICULOUSLY long so if you're trying to get a sandwich for lunch, be ready to wait 20+ minutes.  It's true, there are only 2 ladies working their magic behind that tiny counter.  It's also best if you call in about half an hour to 45 minutes earlier than when you're expecting to pick up your order.  They're really just that busy because they're just that good!  I usually call in around 11 AM and then pick up around 11:30.

I love Saigon Sandwiches!
author: Ivy Z.

description:
yumyumyumyum. Saigon is sooooo delicious. I get the chicken, but of course the pork is good too. The sandwiches travel well - I kept them in my bag for a few hours and my excitable companions and I devoured them. I'm not giving full points because of the awkward ordering/waiting system. I suppose they can't do much better with the small space, but I'm especially prone to awkwardness, so there you have it.

Not much to say that hasn't been said - if you're in the area, go.
author: Miranda N.

description:
I was so excited for this place after seeing all the amazing reviews. While I loved the flavor of the pate, carrots, and spread, I was a little disappointed in the lack of flavor in the pork, the few sprigs of cilantro (which could have been chopped smaller for easier consumption), and the insanely rock-hard bread. The bread made the sandwich close to impossible for a small-mouthed person like me to eat! I couldn't even tell you how many little nibbles I had to hack away at that sandwich and how tired my jaw was at the end. And unlike Connie C., I did get plenty of battle scars in my mouth. 

The flavor was good, so I was still more satisfied than not, but the sandwich coupled with the weird customer service warranted Saigon Sandwich just 3 stars in my book. Maybe if I was a regular, I wouldn't mind their weird way of doing business, but for a first timer, I felt as lost and overwhelmed as I normally do in a WalMart. You go in (if there's room for you), and you just stand there until they look at you. Now, I understand they're busy fulfilling orders, but maybe a little instruction should be nice. For the first five minutes that I was ignored, I wasn't sure what to do. Finally, the cashier announced, "Next?" and I finally figured it out after watching the other customers shout out their orders. You give your order, she scribbles it down lightning-fast, calls for the next order, and fills up about 10 orders before giving it to the sandwich makers. I'm sure the sandwich makers heard the orders anyway, and with only about 6 things on their menu, it wasn't difficult for them to keep up. (Out of the 20 orders I witnessed, it didn't look like they messed any of them up. That was pretty impressive for having taken more than one order per minute.) Then the cashier starts bagging up the orders as they're made, announces the order, and you go get it and pay her. Cash only, and I have to say, at least they don't have the same person handling the food and the money (unlike other places, yeesh!). Also, it's to-go only, and the stone-hard bread makes it difficult to eat in your car without showering crumbs on yourself.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
HMMMMMM If your really hungry and can't wait give it a try not really the best one i have had I asked for no Coriander and the lady nodded and said yes and low and behold FRIGGEN full of the crap!

ounce bitten twice shy! I don't think I will be back unless the other half wants one she enjoyed it.
author: Mark H.

description: Extremely clean, good sandwiches with generous vegetable toppings.  I'm a fan of the chicken, tofu, and combination sandwiches.  One is enough for a meal, but the variety of flavors makes it difficult to resist buying more than one.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
It was lunch time and i just happened to be walking home..and there was NO LINE!!!!!!! YAY!  This made me very happy...kind of the same happy where you find a 20 in your pockets when you do laundry.

Still the best vietnamese sandwich i've had!!!!

Delicious, fresh, and cheap...

If you have never had one..go there today!
author: Ripley B.

description: I love this place.. Every time we stop at Turtle Tower, we walk past Lee's sandwiches and order from here. The mini baguettes are filled to the brim with meat, pickled veggies, cilantro. Almost all sandwiches are $3.75 and under. What a great tasty bargain!
author: Anne T.

description:
Best $3 Banh Mi I've ever had.

No doubt it's located down in the tenderloin, but when you're craving for their sandwiches location doesn't really matter.  Well maybe parking....

Just watch out for the line especially during lunch time.

Don't expect it to be a fancy sandwich store, it is def a no frills joint. What can I say, I love their sandwiches.  Plus they sell Vietnamese desserts and snacks as well.
author: Sophia S.

description:
Delicious Banh Mi for $3. How can you go wrong? Well, let's see. 

First of all, it's a shitty little hole-in-the-wall in the Loin. You gotta dodge the bums and junkies and other assorted shady characters while holding your breath to avoid inhaling the stench that permeates the whole area, all the while trying to avoid stepping on random mysterious messes on the sidewalk. 

Upon reaching the store, you squeeze your way through the 30 people waiting for their sandwiches in an area thats about 6' X 6', shout out your order, and proceed to wait 20-30 minutes for your sandwich.

I'm convinced that the reason they receive so many rave reviews is two-fold. First, it's CHEAP. You get a tasty sandwich for $3! Where else can you find such value? And second, after spending half an hour waiting for your sandwich, you have no choice but to convince yourself that it was fucking worth it. It's either that or feel like a fucking loser for wasting all that time.

Me? I felt like a fucking loser both times I visited there. Next time, I'm paying a whole $0.50-1.00 more at any number of places that sell equally tasty Vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Adrian L.

description: I've heard great things about this place. On some morning I decided to check it out. I was craving a Vietnamese sandwich and had never had one in SF before. The shop is super small but has so much character. I loved the woman behind the counter. She was so cute and reminded me of my mom. Inside there are snacks, drinks and Vietnamese desserts. I jumped at the opportunity to practice my Vietnamese with someone. I ordered the deluxe sandwich @ $3.75. Not bad. Cheaper than the ones in San Jose. The bread was crispy and so good. The deluxe includes roasted pork, steamed pork, and pate. Vietnamese sandwiches usually include the headcheese but this one did not. I give this place A for effort but the sandwiches do not compare to the ones I usually have in SJ.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I am in my late 20s and have been going to Saigon Sandwich since I was a teenager when my father first took me there when we lived in the TL.  I have loved the place for over a decade, constantly rave about it to all my friends, once brought over 100 sandwiches for a party, have spent thousands of dollars there (that is a lot of sandwichs at $3 a piece, and $2 in past years), and known and liked the ladies who work there/ own the place. 

That is why I am so sad that I just had a very bad experience there and will never go back.  I purchased 2 sandwiches and a drink which totaled $8.25 and I got $1.75 back for my ten bill.  Then as I waited for my final sandwich, I decided to grab that last pork bun and gave the woman my other ten bill; whereupon she gave me back $1.25.  I politely told her I think you are confused because I already paid for my sandwich with my other ten bill.  She said no.  I said "Why would I then have exactly $1.75 in my pocket?" (which had nothing else but my cell phone in it).  She said no.  I said "Think about it.  What I have in my purse equals $8.25 and I have $1.75 in my pocket."  She said no. 

It went on like this for a few more minutes.  I genuinely believe she believed she was right and was confused because it is a very busy store, all cash, no receipts ever given, and I had 2 ten bills.  I am just so disappointed that she just could not see the basic evidence in front of her and realize she was wrong; disappointed that I am a regular  customer for over a decade and she would think I would try to rip her off $8.25; disappointed in her forgetfulness and stubbornness.

I let the $8.25 go because a line was starting to form and I spend that much daily on my mandatory 2 lattes but I'm heartbroken...  I will never go back.  It's the principle of the matter: I was completely in the right and the basic facts in front of her demonstrated that.  I know they have a security camera and I hope they review it just so they know the truth themselves.
author: April K.

description: O-M-G the place makes the best banh mi sandwiches in sf. It's a little pricey but it's totally worth it. The line is long for a reason. It's because there sandwiches are so darn good.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Get the Roasted Pork or the Tofu....

The two ladies working are extremely quick; even with the line, it's not too long of a wait.

Bring cash.

Great place to bring a first date. (kidding)
author: Farbod D.

description:
I don't get it.

Maybe I went on a bad day? But my bread was hard and it was hella confusing placing an order.

Eh.. I like Irving Vietnamese Sandwiches better.
author: Heather W.

description:
As good as it gets.
I've had Bahn Mi all over North America.
Saigon Sandwich has the perfect combo for size, taste and price.
I personally liked the meatball pork sandwich the best.
author: Neil R.

description:
When the times get tough, the tough head to Saigon Sandwiches for one of the best deals in town.  For $3 you get a filling, delicious Vienamese banh (chicken and tofu were especially good).  The bread was fresh and soft, the meat/tofu warm and tasty and the veg filling crisp and tasty- what more could you ask for within that price range?  

The ladies are fast and efficient (the line of 10 plus out the door doesn't seem to phase them).  The other treats are worth exploring too- a rice and banana desert wrapped in saran wrap and resembling a enlongated twinkie was a fantastic find... explore on your own and be pleasantly surprised! (your wallet will like it too!).
author: Tracee E.

description: 5 stars! Convenient location near the downtown library. I can't speak for the meat as a vegetarian/vegan (although make sure to ask without mayo!). Whatever sauce they use on the tofu is fantastic! It is very spicy, but worth it, best Banh Mi I've had in the Bay Area yet! $3.50 for a sandwich.
author: Patrick D.

description:
I think their prices went up cuz its 3.50 now but its still HELLA GOOD. 

Lots of meat and pate and its warmmmm. 

but needs more veggies!
author: Amy S.

description:
You're just too good to be true
Can't take my hands off of you
You'd be like heaven to munch
I want to eat you so much
At long last love has arrived
And I thank God I'm alive
You're just too good to be true
Can't take my tongue off of you....

I need you banh mi and if it's quite alright
I need you banh mi to feed the hungry nights
I love you banh mi trust in me when I say, oh yay
Oh pretty banh mi don't let me down I pray
Oh pretty banh mi now that I found you stay
And let me love you, banh mi
Let me love you....

// Now that you've got that catchy song in your head (and I'm thinking about the version as performed by the late Heath Ledger in the seminal film, "10 Things I Hate About You"), I suggest you head on down to Saigon Sandwich whilst humming this tune and order yourself a sandwich. And enjoy.

Oh, my favorite is "cha lua." So... good....
author: Chung N.

description: cheap hole-in-the-wall with absolutely fantastic sandwiches. it's run by some cantonese/toisan people (who will be happy to hear you speak the language) but i don't think it compromises the authenticity. the bread is toasted really well so it's not a hard,crumbly mess and the sweet glaze on the banh mi is delicious.
author: Cailin H.

description: Yay! I'm a fan.
author: James G.

description:
Beware!!! It says they close at 6pm, but really it means if you're not there by around 5pm, you ain't getting no damn sandwich! I was busting my ass to get back into the city after getting stuck in some crap traffic getting off the Bay Bridge, and thought.. "PhEW! 5:15PM.. made good time!" (Since they "close" at 6pm.. Right?! RIGHT?!!!)

NO! I was wrong!!!!! I casually strolled in the door and naturally looked up at the sign.. and back down at the lady, and heard the worst words a girl could ever hear -- No, not "I think we should just be friends" or "It's me not you.." although this comes pretty close to meaning the same thing.. She said.. "no mo' sandwich!" 

I replied with, "OH NOOOOOOOOOOOOO!" literally.. just so she could hear the deep disappointment in my voice because I had that sandwich on my mind for the whole damn day.. The man in the store was holding his sandwich and headed out the door.. The last sandwich of the day. I died a little inside. 


The very next morning, I went in at 7am to purchase a sandwich for lunch.. Nobody puts baby in the corner..!
author: Donna H.

description:
My roast pork sandwich seemed really simple with sparse ingredients, but it was really full of flavor. Bonus: they serve it warm and toasted. 

I probably speak more Vietnamese than the ladies speak English, but they were incomprehensibly fast and plenty friendly. Good joint
author: Anton A.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwiches and prices in town!  Quite authentic, love the sauce they use in the pork sandwich.  Meats are tender, very tasty.  Best to go before 11am or after 2pm if you don't want to stand in a crazy line (especially when hungry).  When its hectic, the bread is not as warm as it could be, but that's understandable considering they don't have a lot of space for the toasters.  Enjoy, you won't have a better lunch or snack from under $4.00!  Booyah!
author: T G.

description:
I don't mean to go against the grain, but this place is easily comparable to Lee's, which is across the street. Though Lee's is a evil and greedy chain which hates kittens and is probably a natzi sympathizer these two places are pretty close in flavor:

Though I like the freshly baked bread at Lee's better, the meat and seasoning here won my heart. My only complaint is i've had some bone and really big pieces of fat in the chicken one before, which let's face it is ew. Also can't say it has much variety unless you are into headcheese, and I'll let you figure out what that is(p.s. it's not cheese).
author: Artur R.

description:
Absolutely worth all the hype.  Delicious sandwich, stuffed to the brim with fresh ingredients and such a steal at only $3!! Get the roasted pork sandwich! Line can get pretty long during lunch, but it's worth the wait. 

Only confusing this about this place is the line. You can never tell who's in line to order or who is waiting to pick up their order. Wish they had a separate and distinct order and pick up line.
author: Tina Y.

description: I had the pork and the chicken sandwiches this past weekend. The food is cheap, comes fast, and is real tasty. All you need is one sandwich. I tried to eat two and it was like the civil war (brain: yea, stomach: nay).
author: Phillip T.

description: I am hard to please but I can't say enough good things about these sandwiches.  Ridiculously amazing taste and dirt cheap.  They have ruined every other vietnamese sandwich, nothing compares.
author: Adriana P.

description:
I got a bahn mi here the other day, and realized the flavor was sorely lacking. Apart from a hefty spread of mayo, they were very light on the pickled daikon/carrots (which lacked sourness), cilantro and peppers. I ordered my usual special combo, and basically had a baguette with mayo, pate and meat. I swear I remember fried onions & Maggi being sprinkled on past bahn mis, but perhaps that was a dream.

For $3.50, it's cheap as heck, but I really expect consistency considering their reputation. I'll probably cut my visits to nil, after this experience.
author: Antoi C.

description:
This is the best banh mi I have had... surely blows Lee's out of the water. 

Nice crisp baguette
good amount of meat
*ask* for extra veggies
reasonably priced $3

This also happens to be the longest I have waited for one.  Be prepared for a bit of a wait time, sorry. They also carry miscellaneous Asian snacks that are just surrounding you as you wait in line.  If you really wanted... you could phone an order in, but would that be silly if I phoned in an order for only one or two sandwiches?  The sandwich was gone so fast you might have thought I inhaled it... 2 minute rule right? ;)
author: Steven T.

description: This place is amazing. It's all been written before, but I can't think of a better value in town. $3.50 gets you one of the best sandwiches around...I love the pork banh mi sandwich. I will return again and again.
author: Will A.

description: The best banh mi I've ever had. This is coming from a person who was born and lived in Vietnam for 9 years. Toe curlingly delicious.
author: nam t.

description:
I'm not religious but this 1 phrase has become my new prayer for the past 2 years. 

"1 Tofu, No Onion, No Pepper"

and all is well with the world.
author: Kevin M.

description: Finally found out what the "Hoopla" was all about with the Banh Mi sandwich was all about. I bought 4 of them 09/17/12 for my family members (here from the midwest) so that they could they try them for the first time. I thought that they were quite yummy, as did the rest of my family, but were somewhat sweeter and didn't have as much of a taste of the pate de foie gras that I remembered from a previous sampling I had elsewhere, so I was left a little disappointed. I'd still go back there again, but this time I think I'd try something else. They are very nice there and there prices are very reasonable..
author: Timothy L.

description: Got the roast pork sandwich for $3.25. The bread was toasted and not very flaky which was to my liking. The meat to veggie ratio was scewed to the veggies side but the veggies were delicious. If you dont like a spicy kick, ask for no jalapenos. The mayo tasted surprisingly good here and I did not get the runs after eating it. Overall a decent sandwich for the price and the best one in sf so far. If only it was closer to the sunset, I would go here more often.
author: Robert Y.

description: I might have had my expectations raised to the stars after seeing over 1800 reviews and 4.5 stars. There is absolutely nothing wrong with their banh mi's but I would hardly call their sandwiches memorable. Given that I only made one visit here to try their Roasted Pork sandwich, I may need a larger sample size to give a proper review. The pork lacked a bit of flavor but was not dry and the veggies were fresh. The bread was not bad, but I did like Fresh Brew Coffee's just a bit more as it was toasted better and the inside seemed more fresh.
author: Andrew L.

description: The ladies that work here are amazing. Barely any English, and the sandwiches are unreal.
author: Daniel F.

description: I lived right around the corner for 9 months, and would go at least twice a week. Walk in and yell "One Chicken" and watch as your sandwich is thrown together effortlessly. Be surprised to taste amazing flavors in what looked so simply prepared. For the price, this sandwich can not be beat.
author: William L.

description:
Its right down the street from Lee's Sandwiches and i would come here over Lee's any time. I would have never found this place if it hadn't been for yelp and all the great reviews. When you come in don't expect much cuz its literally a "hole in the wall". 

It was the best banh mi I've ever had. I had the combination and the meat ball with roast pork. I think the kickers with their sandwiches is that they have some sort of special sweet sauce on the meat and the bread is so good. Its the perfect baguette cuz its crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Both were really good. My friend got the roast pork with pate. They put too much pate so i would just stick with the regular orders. There was not as much cilantro and veggies as i would like, but it was good enough.
author: Bryant L.

description: Best Banh Mi I've had in the Bay Area!
author: Benjamin C.

description: All I can say is that eating this every day is possible. I'm proof.
author: Micah H.

description:
Woohoo! As good as it gets in SF :) 

My coworker has been talking about Saigon sandwiches for so long. I was reluctant to go because I grew up in San Jose, so I've been surrounded by Vietnamese sandwich shop, sorta like Starbucks, you're find a shop in every corner. 

I'm not really a huge fan of Vietnamese sandwich, but I'm always down to get one. It's just not something I would normally crave for I guess. 

So I finally went here today to find Che! I love Vietnamese dessert, but I didn't get any because our next destination was the Asian Art Museum. I'm pretty sure they do not allow food or drinks inside the museum, and I didn't want something sweet and liquid-y in my bag.  So we each got a sandwich because the thought of eating a Vietnamese sandwich while waiting in line sounds good :)

I ordered the Roast Pork and it was delish! It's better than the Vietnamese sandwich I've had in the Sunset. I'm not a fan of the carrots and radishes they normally put in Vietnamese sandwiches, but I didn't pick any out and left my sandwich as is. Sandwich was tasty, but I wish they added more cilantro and green pepper.

Overally, I think this place is really good compare to the Vietnamese sandwich shop I have been to around SF. I would definitely come back even if its in the TL.
author: Tina T.

description:
After hearing so much about this place, I had to try it for myself!  Literally a hole in the wall, I would never think to come here if it weren't for recommendations from family members and friends!

I got lucky that when I came here, there wasn't a line like what people had mentioned.  I ordered the chicken and the two different pork.  All with pate.  Went home and shared it with some people and we all agree it was pretty darn tasty!  It's really nothing I would have imagined it to be after seeing the place. 

With two little ladies taking orders and making the sandwiches, I must say for $3 a sandwich, it's not a bad deal at all!  Definitely not stingy on the portions and their pate is really delicious!  I do wish the peppers were spicy though!  But other than that, really good!
author: Natalie T.

description: My friends and I were walking around Civic Center Plaza during the Pride Parade last weekend and although there were many tempting food vendors within reach, we made our way to Saigon Sandwich. For only $3.25 per sandwich, we confidently felt like we had made the best possible lunch decision within walking distance. If ever I find myself in the area again, I'll order another roasted pork bahn mi, no doubt.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
These sandwiches are absolutely perfect. The only people for whom the sandwiches would not be perfect would be folks who really don't know the genre of food here.   the value is such a standout, that their modest shop, is really the one that every sandwich shop in the area tries to copy. No, they don't have pho.  No, they don't have regular roast beef. You probably don't want to get the special pork unless use advanced to the "next level" Vietnamese sandwiches.  

What should you get? You should either get the chicken or the pork. Do not make the mistake that everybody makes. They are not open for dinner, although they do stay open till 6pm most days so you can pick up a sandwich on the way home from the office. They are definitely a  lunchtime spot.
author: Jaime R.

description: Still the best and cheapest banh mi in the city.
author: Mike I.

description:
I wonder why I should bother writing a review for a place that already has over 1300 reviews, but since I and all of the people I work with eat a sandwich from Saigon at least twice a week, I have to write something.  

Excellent food, especially the special combo Bahn Mi.  Cheap, under $3.50 which is astonishing considering the quality.  convenient, right near work and Civic Center.

Why only four stars?  Despite the fact that these women are crazy fast, the lines are so long and so many people are ordering MULTIPLE sandwiches for everyone back at the office, it can take ages to order and go.
author: Denis P.

description: Hole-in-the-wall, cheap but delicious banh mi!  My family's been going here for years and we always get the bbq pork one.  They changed their menu a bit and did some construction to their place.  Although the sandwiches aren't as good as they use to be (or as big), and the price has gone up but the line to order has gone out the door, they're still worth it to try in San Francisco.
author: Reb R.

description:
I love how this place has 720 reviews and it's still sitting at 4.5 stars!  Well clearly, it rulzzzzzzzzzzzzz!

Ventured on over to the tenderloin today for lunch to pick up sandwiches for ourselves and a fellow co-worker.  We had to wait in line for about five minutes before actually ordering and then had to wait about 10 minutes while our 5 total sandwiches are made.  Their style is pretty cool as well.  They just yelled down the line asking for people's orders, which isn't too difficult considering there are only like 6 sandwich options total.  

I tried the:
Tofu
Roast pork (#22 on the 7x7 Big Eat list) 
Roast chicken

I'm having difficulty deciding which my favorite is because they were all beyond exceptional! I know they use a sh*t ton of mayonnaise and that sweet sauce that you find in many different Vietnamese restaurants. They also put on onions, julienned carrots, and a few greens. Personally, I liked the tofu the best!  

I will definitely be back, especially considering each sandwich was ONLY $3!!!! Yes, you read that correctly; $3!!! NO TAX EITHER. Amazing. I love the sh*t out of this place and can't wait to come back on a weekend.
author: Jenny W.

description: Go big or go home. $4.25 for the special combo. Cash only. Super. Simple. Sated.
author: Norman P.

description: Want a delicious Vietnamese sandwich for a cheap price ($3.25 cheap) and you're handing in the Tenderloin? Then try Saigon Sandwich. The options are limited: pork, chicken, or tofu, so have your act together when you get to the front of line. This isn't the type of place you should be wondering what to choose when the small Vietnamese lady says "Next!" Try and go before 11:45am or after 1:15pm to get the quickest service or be prepared to wait a while. And bring cash!
author: Rebecca D.

description: Do you think I can carry 10 greasy sandwiches by myself without a bag? Give me a damn bag! Idiots!
author: Billy N.

description:
I'm not sure what an authentic Vietnamese sandwich is supposed to taste like, but I like these. The ingredients are fresh and plentiful. The key to any great sandwich is the bread and they don't falter in this department. Sandwiches are pretty cheap for the quality, at $3 each. There's only about two seats in the joint, so it's more of a to-go spot.

There's a bunch of Vietnamese snacks, drinks, desserts, and other packaged goodies. I'm always puzzled about the wrapped up Vietnamese treats. Like, why not a sign?

As soon as I finished my sandwich I had regretted not buying another one for later.
author: Michael H.

description: This is only the 2nd time I've had a Vietnamese sandwich, so I'm not an expert but this was a damn good sandwich.  The meat was flavorful, piled high and the bread was fresh.  I am definitely coming back and this place is way cheaper than my normal $5 footlong.  I just have to figure out how to get to this place without running into all the crazy tenderloin crackheads and hobos.
author: michele k.

description:
The sandwiches here are good, but I wouldn't call it the best place in SF to get Banh Mi. The flavors of everything inside the sandwich are really excellent, but the bread was really hard. Not quite stale, but I really had to rip it apart with my teeth.

Additionally, this wouldn't be a place you would eat at, rather a place you would pick your food up at and then eat at a second location. There is one table, and the rest of the space is taken up by people waiting in (the sometimes extremely long) line. The atmosphere is impersonal and fast paced. Which I think is absolutely fine, especially in the city. But anyone who doesn't know what Bahn Mi is or wants to try it for the first time shouldn't come here.

The vegetable fillings are already put together in one container, so you probably couldn't ask for them to hold anything. Also, I saw some flies buzzing around the veggies when one of the workers wasn't looking. I know that they don't have the time to cover up the food because one customer comes in right after another, but this was slightly disconcerting to me.

The food here is very cheap, but you can find a cheap Vietnamese sandwich ANYWHERE. Especially in the neighborhood Saigon Sandwich is located.

In short, I really do like this place, and think they do a fine job. They cater to people who know exactly what they want, and have other places to go to eat it. But I'm really surprised at the popularity of this place. They don't -- in my opinion -- have the best tasting Bahn Mi in the city, and you can't even sit down to eat your food. Their lines can get very long, but they work very fast... But I would rather eat at a less popular place without a long line and with people spending more time putting my food together.
author: Trish B.

description:
HANDS DOWN---BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH I'VE EVER HAD!!!

this is probably my favorite food in san francisco. i used to think it was the savory crepes at Crepes a Go Go on 11th st...but whenever i sink my teeth into a juicy saigon sandwich i realize that i could eat one everyday for the rest of my life.

i've turned so many friends onto this place. many of these friends had never had a vietnamese sandwich, and many were never impressed with other vietnamese sandwiches they've had. i've also turned tons of meat-eaters (who are NOT into tofu) into the tofu vietnamese sandwich! my boyfriend for example does not like tofu one bit....but he won't order anything besides the tofu veggie sandwich here. their tofu is super juicy and marinated with great flavor, and the shredded vegetables pack a lot of punch as well. 

i've had vietnamese sandwiches at other places in Little Saigon and they just don't compare. their tofu is the best, their buns are warm and toasty (with the perfect crunch on the outside and the perfect soft warmth on the inside) and they are super fast and cheap!
author: katherine m.

description:
Vietnamese is one cuisine I'm definitely less enthusiastic about, but there's really no complaining over the roast pork banh mi at Saigon Sandwiches, where they nestle generous portions of tender, succulent roast pork with the standard accoutrements of julienned carrot and daikon, cilantro, and jalapeno into a crusty, spongy, soft mini-baguette. The sandwich offers the familiar sweet flavors of the banh mi, but knows to keep it to a minimum, of sorts. The savoriness of the feather-light yet substantial baguette really pulls its work in cutting this rich sweetness.

A submarine-shaped happiness awaits you in the Tenderloin, all for $3 a pop. Ask for extra jalapenos.
author: Nuri K.

description:
