I thought it would be like any other Vietnamese sandwich place, just like all them sandwich places spread around SJ (where I resort to for Vietnamese sandwiches). I was so wrong. This place has the best chicken sandwiches ever!!!

-Chicken sandwich: the bread is crispy and has weight to it (I hate some places where the bread is overly soft, too chewy, and consists of puffed air. You know what I mean?). The chicken is flavored well, not dry, butter and pickled carrots offset all the meat and bread. The sandwiches looked small, but they were heftily stuffed with meat/veggies. 
-Pork sandwich: The pork tasted/had a really porky smell. I didn't really like this one. The flavor was alright. I liked the chicken better. 

I'd frequent this place for the greatest chicken sandwich, but it's located in a not so great area. It's worth the trip though, you won't regret it! They also sell a variety of other Vietnamese desserts (coconut sticky rice, coookies, and other gooey goodies). 

P.S. They have a variety of drinks (fresh bottled soybean, tea, soda, etc) and che (Vietnamese soup desserts in cups). They also sell yan-yan and other snacks.
author: Tracy T.

description: While the meat was excellent in the sandwich, the actual size of it was way too small for the price. I'll stick with Lee's Sandwiches across the street.
author: Ron Z.

description:
Leave it to a rainy afternoon to not have a line out the door at Saigon.  Makes me a happy camper not having to wait to feed me.

$3 roasted pork banh mi, nice lady #1, not-so-nice lady #2, and a few minutes in the store left me with mixed feelings.  Maybe if lady #2 was nicer this would have been a five star review.

How do they cook the pork?  It's soooo good!
author: Jenny L.

description:
When I was working in the area I would eat here often.

There's really no place to sit there (with the exception of two cramped window seats), so be prepared to buy and go or stand there in the street eating, but the sandwiches are very good... especially the Tofu Sandwich!

I am a meat eater... but after trying their assortment, I would get that Tofu Sandwich almost every time!

(That photo of the roach in that person's sandwich creeps me out... luckily I've never found anything like that in my food!  YIKES!!)
author: Jason M.

description:
The first Vietnamese-American was elected to Congress in New Orleans this year. (High Five, Great Success)  If you can forgive the fact that he's a republican and he beat an incumbent who had $90,000 hidden in his freezer, it's still a landmark moment for my people.  Growing up, I never really believed the bull*&^% the teachers told me in school about becoming anything you wanted to be.  Well, now future immigrant or minority generations can at least have more faith in that belief. I salute you, Ahn "Joseph" Cao and Barack "Hussein" Obama. Please don't screw it up. By the way, I wanted to be a country western singer on tv when I grew up. Yeah, that didn't really work out for me...

Anyhoooo, to celebrate this historic moment for the Vietnamese people, I decided to visit Saigon Sandwiches in the Tenderloin.  $3.50 will get you the most delicious sandwich in the city. $3.50!!!!!! That is not a typo Yelp amigos.  This tiny Vietnamese lady makes your sandwich to order on a crusty baguette with fresh veggies and meat inside. I don't think she speaks a lick of english besides "thank you" and "come back again", but fuck man, she can make a sandwich like nobody's business. The lines that go around the corner of her tiny storefront is a testament to that.  

Trust me, it's worth  the wait. She is the living embodiment of the American dream. A woman who offers a great product for a reasonable price. If she was a few years younger, I think I would ask her out.  We'd go to a country western bar like the one in "Urban Cowboy" and sing Loretta Lynn songs. She would become smitten by my mastery of the mechanical bull, then we would lay by the fireplace nibbling on her Vietnamese sandwiches. Ahhhhh, but to dream...

What was I talking about again??? Oh, the sandwiches here are super good.  Tip her well.  Merry Christmas.

5 stars.
author: John T.

description:
So after two years of frequenting this place, I finally decided that I must write a review.  It is raved by some as the best Vietnamese sandwich in SF.  I think it is pretty good and the two ladies that work there are really nice.  However, I do miss only having to pay $1 for a Vietnamese sandwich in OC.  Taking into account that I am a long way from home, $3 for a delicious sandwich isn't so bad (especially since other Vietnamese sandwiches charge comparable prices).

My favorite is the Banh Mi Dac Biet (The Special) which includes pork, fanci pork, pate, and veggies.  A little rich for me with all the pate and mayo mixture.  I can only do these once in a while.
author: Bert N.

description: You've probably never had "the best banh mi" until you've been to Saigon Sandwich. I hadn't. This might be the only time you can change your life for only $3.50 (the sandwiches were only $3.25 a couple weeks ago).
author: NickJess S.

description:
This is a tiny hole-in-the-wall little place run by 2 ladies that is wildly crowded for lunch. You can tell this place is good by the line that goes out the door.

The chicken is tender and tasty, the bread is crusty and the special sauce seems like some sort of butter/soy sauce mix. The sandwiches come with cilantro and jalapeños. All for 3 bucks makes for a yummy lunch.
author: Chili B.

description: I love me some really good banh mi. The ladies at Saigon Sandwich do it right every time: lightly toasted warm bread to give it some crunch, a heap of roasted pork, a generous slather of secret mayo, and LOTS of pickled daikon-carrots, cilantro, and a sliver of jalapeno. Their shop layout makes more sense now and flows better with the counter facing out to the street, not like before when there would always be an awkward and crowded line along the side. Overall, an inexpensive and satisfyingly delicious banh mi experience.
author: Angie N.

description:
OK $3 for an AWESOME sandwich, doesn't get any better than this!
There are two women who run this joint and they are damn good at their job. They work as fast as they can to fill the orders that don't stop from about 1030 til about 230/3 in the afternoon. If you get there at the height of lunch you will wait but its oh so wroth the wait! I encourage you to try all the things that they have crammed on the counter. I recommend the coconut yellow custardy thing that they have along w/ the roast pork sandwich that looks just like the pictures. All of it is made in house with a little bit of love!
author: Kae w.

description:
Okay, I freely admit it, I'm a Vietnamese food snob.  If you grow up eating Vietnamese food at home, you have certain expectations.  I expect my banh mi to have well pickled julienned carrots & daikon (do chua), spicy jalapeños not bell pepper (yes, I've seen it before & it wasn't pretty), cucumber spears, cilantro, a smear of mayonnaise (preferably homemade) +/- pâté depending on what meat you put in it.  And NEVARRRR should a microwave enter into the picture!  (Oh the abominations I've been subject to!)

I can honestly say that their roast pork sandwich was the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had.  That's it.  The pickles were a smidge on the sweet side but otherwise nice & juicy & I love the fact that they give you a lot of pickles, not an anemic few strands & a ton of meat.  The flavors are balanced, sweet-sour veggies, crisp fresh veggies (cucumber & cilantro), plenty of spicy jalapeños (so if you don't like heat ask them to leave them out), traditional airy crispy Vietnamese baguette and then there's the meat.  The roast pork was so tender it fell apart in my mouth--savory, juicy, flavorful & not fatty at all.  Waaaaaahhh!  My mouth is filling up with saliva while writing this!

We smuggled 2 paper wrapped sammiches each the size of an adult guinea pig with a "glandular problem" on the plane with us & were nearly attacked by our fellow passengers.  Next time I'm in SF I'm going to go here as soon as I get off the plane & buy 3 to snarf on the plane on the way home but I'm not sharing!
author: Cam T.

description:
Ultimate bang for the buck

You will not get a cheaper and tastier sandwich in San Francisco (stick to the chicken or pork sandwiches)
author: T S.

description:
I woke up this morning after the excellent Yelp holiday party and elected to "work from home" today.  

But I've made an amazing discovery.  

Among it's other wondrous and magical properties, Saigon's Roast Pork Banh Mi is also an instant hangover cure.  I am eating one right now and the savory, sweet, crunchy, spicy, messy goodness is changing my whole outlook.
author: Jay Z.

description: Best Viet sandwich in the city handsdown! The bread is slightly crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. Meat is hooked up fat with the ends overloading out of the bread, not skimp like some places. The vegetables are fresh and crunchy and their special mayo sauce they use is smooth and tasty. I always order at least 2 sandwiches here, a roast pork and a pate. I used to like those lee's franchise spots back in the days, but there's no comparison once you tried Saigon. I could eat this allday everyday!
author: Patrick L.

description:
Wow, I'm glad I had my first Vietnamese sandwich here!  

My boyfriend thinks anyone who passes on the Special Combination sandwich is missing out.  He's been eating Vietnamese sandwiches for a long time, and this is his favorite to date.  I really enjoyed the roast pork, but I'm also less adventurous than he is.  We were both pleasantly surprised by how delicious the baguettes were.  I've not had a baguette this good anywhere.  

The only problem is that Saigon Sandwiches has ruined other sandwiches for me me forever.  Sorry Hoagie... sorry Muffuletta... sorry Panini, Po' Boy, and Reuben.   You're great and we've had great times, but you can't compete with a bahn mi from this place!
author: Christena T.

description:
A few days ago I received alarming news. A guy I work with that is allegedly well connected in the Vietnamese community told me that Saigon Sandwiches is in trouble. He said that even though it is acknowledged among people that know that Saigon Sandwiches has better food Lee's sandwiches a half block away is stealing all of their business by offering an open clean looking shop with plenty of seating.

I can't remember the first time I had a Saigon Sandwiches Sandwich but it couldn't have been before '88 and it couldn't have been after '92. The location and the hours are super inconvenient for me so I've been going rarely over the last ten years but when I heard they were in trouble I got over their as soon as I could. 

On my way home I drove by Lee's and it is everything that Saigon Sandwiches is not. My co-worker accurately described it as open and clean looking with plenty of seating. I can understand why someone would choose comfort but for my money Saigon Sandwiches is still the best based on having the best sandwiches.

This time the lady was so nice to me that I forgave them for being rude to me years ago and am giving up that last star.
author: Manny F.

description: Yummy, fresh sandwiches.  Pork and chicken are delicious.  $3.50 for nice size banh mi = good deal.  Try it!
author: D B.

description: Long lines usually mean a great meal, and this is no exception. For the price of $3.50, you get a fantastic sandwich, one of the best deals in San Francisco. I highly recommend the pork sandwich, spicy. Fresh and delicious, great baguette, nice meat.
author: Chuck B.

description:
I live in San Jose so there's a sandwich place on every corner. I do have to say, this was one of the best sandwiches I've had in a long time. 

The bread was perfectly soft and warm, I much prefer french rolls over baguettes that Lee's uses. Not much else to say, it's good and I'm a fan.
author: Jin S.

description:
About perfect dirt-cheap sandwich place.  

You stand in line, read the menu, pick your meat, get your food.  No options. Nothing fancy.  But a damn tasty, spicy, Vietnamese treat.

I'm an unadventurous, picky cad, so the missing 5th star is because the excellent roasted chicken was mostly dark meat and there really is no place to sit.  But, still... what a find!
author: Galen W.

description:
Someone call a rheumatologist, because this place is the joint!

Nestled in the heart of the dirty Tenderloin region of San Francisco is an even dirtier little sandwich shop that sells amazing football shaped sandwiches, the flavor of which is enough to quell any comer initially suspicious of the sanitariness of placing meat and sandwiches directly onto counter space.

The shop is run by two little old ladies who crank these babies out like a third-world shoe factory.  The line is long but somewhat efficient for a two-woman operation.  At three bucks a pop, this spot is well worth the jaunt from just about anywhere in the city.  Two+ sandwiches is recommended, depending on your appetite.  The pork and chicken are both tasty tasty.  The tofu sandwich seemed like a popular choice amongst my line-waiting peers.

The tenderlion is waiting.  Happy eating!
author: Alex C.

description:
Cheap sandwiches are good - sometimes there is mystery meat and odd textures, so I stick with the chicken....

Love, love, love the fresh veggies and cilantro - a great delicious little treat.
author: Erin M.

description:
The Veggie Vietnamese Sandwich (Bánh mì) is so good!
Sliced tofu, shredded carrots, cilantro, mint leaves, peppers, pickled radish and a sweet sauce in a crusty roll
$3.50

There is not really anywhere to sit so get it to go and let's have a picnic (just not in the Tenderloin please)!
author: Shannon Z.

description: SO FREAKING DELICIOUS! This place is in this little room that's can literally only fit 15 people at once. The selection of sandwiches is fairly a good amount and I love how they have a tofu/vegetarian sandwich, which was perfect because I am currently vegetarian for my religion. Anyways! The woman there will take about 2-6 orders at once and then you wait for your sandwiches to be made. It takes a while to get your order because this place is so small and there are only three women working there. One handling the orders and money, the other actually making the sandwiches, and the other making the bread or ingredients. I went during lunch hour so it was crazy busy. There were people going in and out of this place, so I knew this place must be amazing. I ordered the tofu sandwich and it was so good! They put in enough of the sauce so you get a good flavor and they give a good helping of the pickled stuff and cilantro. It was super filling by the time I finished it. I was full for hours. It is hands down so much better than any Vietnamese sandwiches I've had and I'm Vietnamese... I know my sandwiches. I would be down to eat here again the next time I go back up to SF.
author: Christine N.

description: Just as good as they were back in 2008. The combination is the perfect mix of smooth rich pate and other pork based products. Stuffed in the fresh baguette with crisp pickled veggies it was the perfect snack for under $4. No wonder these ladies churn out a million of these suckers. They are the perfect sandwich, but can be so messy! My car has crumbs all over the seat...still worth it though!
author: Stacy T.

description:
I have never really been a fan of Vietnamese sandwiches until two days ago. My boyfriend asked me to get him a sandwich from here and I said yes. Parking is horrible in this area so I went down and waited in a line that went out the door. So... if people are willing to wait in line for something it must mean that it's good!

I saw the menu and was surprised by the variety of sandwich options. This hole in the wall has a menu which consists strictly of the sandwich meat choices. Since I saw the roast chicken, I ordered one for myself minus the pate (well, cuz obviously I don't like weird exotic foods). To my surprise the sandwich was very tasty. Compared to the bland tasteless Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in the past, this by far has been the best. There was some kind of sauce on top of the chicken, which made the chicken moist and flavorful. I was also happy to have the pickled carrots, cilantro, a touch of mayo, and jalapenos to compliment the sandwich. Best ever!

I don't care if I have to stand in line for another one of these bad boys. It was so delish! This is definitely the only place I'll go when i crave a Vietnamese sandwich. The tapioca desserts and the bean drinks looked good, so next time I'll be sure to try one as well. 

5 stars for changing my mind about Vietnamese sandwiches! :)
author: Anne Y.

description: Omgosh.  Folks, it just does not get any better than this.  If you are a vegetarian or not, the tofu sandwiches are the MOST amazing thing I have ever ever eaten.  Tofu with sauce with crunch bread, jalapenos, carrots, cilantro, peanut sauces,,,ok I have to leave my house to get one....
author: M Mom M.

description: I think it's pretty good sandwich. You can't think the sandwich would be amazing, but their homemade butter they spread on the bread is creamy and tasty! Great place to grab a cheap meal. The sandwich is around $3.50. If you're in Little Saigon, then you must stop by. Small mom and pop's shop. It gets busy around lunch.
author: Cali H.

description: When I visit SF I literally by a bunch of these sandwiches before heading home to NJ before heading to the airport.  I double bag the bounty to keep the stank in until I am ready to devour these sandwiches.  Far better than Lee's but closes early.
author: Jon G.

description: Great food at a very reasonable price, sadly there is nowhere to sit. It was a little spicy, so you may want to get a drink with your sandwich.
author: Jonathon V.

description:
So while looking for some cheap food in SF I came across this place. 

It doesn't suck for sure. It's a decent sandwich with many different flavors, definitely an experience worth having for a sandwich. Go with the standard pork sandwich with everything. Try the different drinks in the fridge too.
author: John L.

description:
I was hooked the first time I tried the fancy pork sandwich. At $3 (not sure if this is still the right price?), it doesn't get much better... the fanciest pork in town, a French roll, pickled carrots and onions, parsley, and hot peppers -- awesome. 

If you're feeling adventuresome, I'd also recommend grabbing a few of the intriguing and unlabeled (in English, that is) items at the counter -- I've had some excellent egg dishes, pork buns, and desserts that I never would have known to ask for by name.
author: Tess W.

description: Best ever. Love this place, great deal $3.50, usually a line but well worth the wait, wish they were open later!
author: H C.

description: I think I'm in love with this place. I know people complain about the lines, but every time I've been here it's been hardly a wait. So far I've had the roasted chicken and the combination- both were spectacular. They have an amazing sauce that is totally addictive, and all the ingredients are really fresh, which they generously stuff into the sandwiches. At $3.50-$ 4.00 how can you go wrong?
author: NaNa M.

description: The tofu bahn mi seems to be getting greasier every time I go.  Still love the bread!
author: Negien M.

description: Cheapest and best Viet Sandwiches in SF. Next best thing to San Jose. Roast pork is the best here. Best bang for the buck in the TL
author: Allan A.

description:
Probably the best Viet sandwich I ever had.

There is actually about 3-4 Viet sandwich places on this block alone so I actually went and picked up one sandwich from each place and this is the one I liked the most.

The sandwich does seem to be a bit smaller then the others Viet sandwich shops but for only around $3 I can't really complain. 

Also, there selection of sandwiches is pretty limited if you compare it to Lee sandwiches.
author: Jasper L.

description:
I've been in the studio for 21 hours already this weekend. I'm start to go a little nuts. I mean, I've been drinking goddamn tap water from an old building in the Tenderloin for the past two days. But I guess stepping over passed out crack whores on your way to the studio makes you more "rock." 

Luckily, we are close to the best Vietnamese sandwich place in the city - Saigon Sandwiches. And for just under $3 a sandwich, you won't even mind standing in line next to a crate full of human shit, which is quite ingenious really because the plastic grid at the bottom prevents the splash-back that would otherwise occur had there been no crate. 

Add to that: running into your college friend's younger brother who tells you said college friend was recently hit by a drunk driver in an accident you later found out involved "a motorcycle chase and a collapsing building..."

The sandwiches are really good. My life is weird.
author: Keane L.

description:
all of the sandwiches they have are awesome.  if you're on a first date and you'd like to impress her, i'd splurge for the $2.75 specialty combo.  This sandwich has pate, a number of different kinds of meat, and this delicious, slightly sweet creamy mayonaise-type special sauce. i don't know exactly what it is, but it's good.  and they're big sandwiches too.  they fill you up just right for lunch. 

seriously, if i were allowed into the back and i found some old vietnamese guy in assless leather chaps and a cowboy hat and nothing else watching porn while simultaneously jerking himself and a billy goat off into a large vat marked "sandwich mayonaise", i would still continue to come here.  this  place is that good.  only i'd probably have to stop saying stuff like "mmmm..." or "oh that tastes so good" when slurping up the creamy white special sauce as it dribbles down the side of the sandwich.  and i would definitely have to stop saying things like "it's so big and fills me up just right!"
author: Sebastian N.

description:
You guys are all on crack!  Perhaps you are the people I had to step over to get in the door?  The only thing I could taste in my sandwich was the super sickly sweetness of the pickled veggies.  Oh yeah and the blood from my ripped open roof-of-mouth.  

It was the worst banh mi I've ever had and believe me, I've had plenty.  I would be tempted to call myself a connoisseur but I'm not a snob so I just won't.  Irving Café has the best in the city, FYI. 

When I feel like making the 8 block walk from my office to Little Saigon for a sammy, I always go to Baguette Express.  I KNEW I shouldn't have cheated on my Baguette Express but I trusted you, Yelp, because you've never let me down before.  How sadly misguided I was.  

I will never come back to stupid Saigon Sandwiches for the following reasons:
1) Baguette Express is way better and just a few doors up the street
2) The damage the bread did to my roof-of-mouth may require that I spend the rest of my days on a diet of milkshakes and baby food
3) I don't generally like dessert and that is what the sandwiches here taste like
4) It's stupid
author: Jen S.

description: These banh mi sandwiches are OUT OF THIS WORLD!! My eyes literally roll  to the back of my head each time I have one of their pork sandwiches. They are so so yummy.   Bread has the perfect crunch,  meat is moist, daikon and carrots are masterfully flavored, and the portions are so hearty. If you want to have the most magnificent authentic Vietnamese Banh Mi, this is THE place. I love love love Saigon Sandwich!
author: Isabella L.

description:
If you are not Vietnamese, avoid the "Fanci" pork.  No, it is not a nicer cut of meat.  It is some sort of pate, liverwurst concoction.  Funky.  

I'd stick to the more pedestrian grilled pork and chicken.
author: Monica L.

description:
Totally freaking delicious sandwich. 

Totally freaking delicious sandwich FOR THREE DOLLARS.

There was a line involved, but it was absolutely worth it. Plus, the line gave me time to admire the glove/money/vegetable application technique that the lady was rocking. She has MOVES.

I got the roasted pork because it's on the list of 100 things to try in SF before you die, but a whole gaggle of folks were ordering the meatball sandwich and at only $3, I figured it was worth the investment so I got me one of those too. Compared side by side I'd say that I liked the meatball one more, but I would have been perfectly happy with the roasted pork.

SO.GOOD. If you like Vietnamese sandwiches, I guess. Like, don't go monkeying around and trying to remove any of the ingredients (CILANTRO HATERS, I'M LOOKING AT YOU!).
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
I have braces and should not be eating Vietnamese sandwiches. Saigon Sandwiches makes me not really give a damn about that. If I get the sandwich early enough [they open at the buttcrack of dawn - read: 7am on weekends!], I can let the sandwich sit, and the bread will soften. It's cheap, and if I'm hungry, I can always get two for a little over $5... 

Of course, then I spend the rest of the afternoon in class wishing that I could have made a quick stop at the restroom to floss and brush... It takes a little time to get from Union Square to the TL and back AND to eat the sandwich on a sunny day in the middle of Union Square with braces [braces slow everything down]. 

There's nothing like tasting your lunch for several hours. Nothing! The spicy jalapenos, the cilantro, the roast pork, the carrots and pickles, the French bread slathered in sauce... [I hear the combo with the pate is even better!] 

Okay, you MIGHT get the same effect after you drink too much of anything bubbly after a meal and burp. Except it's still different. 

Nothing to chew on. 

I guess I'm just disgusting. :/
author: Tinna H.

description:
After my disastrous incident here with a hairy ball (ahem), I vowed never to return. 

But I was starving, broke, and Saigon Sandwiches is near my job, so I decided to give 'em a second chance. While I do think they're pretty good, I actually prefer Banh Mi Ba Le in Oakland better, mainly because of the bread. The rolls at Saigon Sandwiches are too big. It throws the filling-to-bread ratio off. 

Or maybe I'm just biased against them because the memory of hairy balls leaves a bad taste in my mouth (cough).
author: Jasmine W.

description:
We drove out to TL, parked our car next to a random bumm talking to himself,  hoped the car will still be intacted when we get back, walked half a block to this deli, only to stand in line for 15 mins while other random people spoke gibberish to me.

We ordered the combination with everything on it. It wasn't bad but it wasn't great either. I did think they put too much sweet sauce in it and I've never seen anyone put actual kraft mayo in a vietnamese sandwhich. 

I still think the best vietnamese sandwiches are found in oakland. Ba le or cam huong makes better ones!
author: Anna T.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and these sandwiches are nowhere near authentic tasting. Major disappointment! 

Been waiting to try this place. I ordered several to go, since my parents are visiting. Got home, bit into one, and was like eeewwwww...what the heck is this? It tasted as a sweet as a pb&j. 

If you're into sweet sandwiches, I'd say go here, but if you want something authentic, then try Lee's or Irving Street Cafe & Deli.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Crunch, crunch, munch! 

(Happy sigh) =) 

Just came back from Vietnam and had a craving for a banh mi. So 
where did I go? Saigon Sandwich! This place is no frills; they just make really good sandwiches! My favorite is the BBQ chicken banh mi. However, because of my craving, I ordered roast pork, BBQ chicken and the combo banh mi. 

(Crunch, munch) 

Need I say more? =)
author: Cris H.

description:
This closet-sized health-code failing dump is one of San Francisco's top three delis. I'm not joking. The sandwiches are f***ing great.

Banh mi, Vietnamese for sandwich, has been one of my diet staples since I was a kid. In San Francisco, there is really only one neighborhood where you can procure these delectable snacks: the Tenderloin, otherwise known as Little Saigon. According to a friend of mine, Saigon Sandwiches is known to be the best Vietnamese deli in the Tenderloin. The line out the door was my first indication that this might truly be the case.

Vietnamese sandwiches are the product of French imperialism and so it's no surprise that they're always on a baguette. The most traditional banh mi is the dac biet, or special, sandwich. Dac biet sandwiches are typically lined with mayonnaise and pate, and then stuffed with combination cold cuts (think Italian but add a Vietnamese flavor), julienned carrots, cucumber, pickled daikon, cilantro, and green chili peppers. A little soy sauce is sprinkled on top and voila! You have a pretty filling sandwich that will cost you around two bucks. Yes, you heard me right: two bucks. 

The dac biet sandwich at Saigon is my favorite. There's a generous dollop of pate (which I love), the bread is obviously fresh, and the toppings all bring me home to the combination of flavors I love so much. The chilies are a must, but be sure to instruct the sandwich maker to omit them if you are a wimp. 

I also had the barbequed pork sandwich which is also out of this world. The meat is marinated quite wonderfully. Other banh mi options include chicken, tofu (I've never in my life tried this version), and meatball pork. Are the sandwiches totally, totally authentic? Well, maybe the bread is a little plumper than those available in Vietnam but other than that, these sandwiches kick ass according to this Saigon-born chick.

It'll be hard, but branch out and try other goodies wrapped fresh daily on the cramped counter.
author: Baochi N.

description:
the best, i repeat, BEST, vietnamese sandwich i've ever had ever. (and i've ventured around quite a bit).

i get the roasted chicken sans patey, but with extra peppers. the bread is crunchy on the outside but soft on the inside-- just how i like it. and the chicken? incredibly flavorful. but i think the veggies are my favorite part of this beautiful sandwich-- the flavor of them compliment the roasted chicken in a way that leaves me craving this sandwich quite regularly. 

the place is pretty small, just big enough to fit a kitchen and a counter to place an order at. be prepared to walk out with your food in a plastic bag, looking for a place to sit-- i'd recommend the civic center plaza on a nice day. or the steps of the library nearby.
author: Muzna N.

description: Ok, ok, ok... where else can you go to get a pretty good made-to-order banh mi for about $3?  While it may not be truly authentic, it's darn close and tastes pretty darn good.  I've had the chicken, pork, and tofu -- I'm not much of a pate fan so I stay away from that one.  The three ladies that run the place are generally pretty efficient and work hard to keep the never ending line under control.  I wish they served cà phê sua dá but I guess it may not be worth their time because otherwise they probably would be selling it now.  They bring in pretty authentic Vietnamese desserts they have sitting on the counter that I typically get about 3-4 to take come and eat over the next few days.
author: Kent W.

description:
My search for the best Vietnamese sandwich in the Bay Area has officially reached its peak. The previous reviews kinda say it all, and at the risk of sounding like a cult-follower - Saigon offers up some of the most delicious pork on a bun in all of the Bay Area. And for a mere $3.00. I mean, it's practically FREE!

I've been here a few times now, always for the tried and true pork (though the chicken's not bad). The line is usually out the door around lunchtime during the week and weekends are packed too. I don't mind the wait and the service is incredible! I was short a few bucks once and the lady politely told me to just pay next time. So sweet!

The search will continue, but for now, I'm happy to say I've found my West Coast banh mi supplier. Damn skippy!!!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is probably the best banh mi I have ever had.
Its a whole in the wall but their samis are the best! The bread is crunchy, fresh, chewy. The meat and pork sami is so well seasoned, perfect amount of meat vs jalopeno/veggie combination. For $3 a very satisfying lunch! Sometimes the wait is long so call ahead and do a drive by.

Next time I will try their combo ham. YUM. I will never go to Lee's across the street again!
author: Petri Y.

description:
$2.75 for a sandwich? The first time I came here I thought that for $2.75 I should probably expect to get bread with mayonnaise on it...so I got 2. Well there's more than mayo on these sandwiches, cilantro, carrots and jalapenos with your choice of meat on a french roll. They're the Vietnamese equivalent to a burrito. They have what they call "fancy pork" which is just processed ham. I tend to stay away from that and go for the meat ball. More natural, you know.

It's pretty cramped in there so if you go around lunch you may be waiting outside. They also have pre packaged Vietnamese desserts from Hung Phat bakery around the corner. That's right, Hung Phat. It's OK, feel free to giggle.
author: Josua P.

description: Yes, it was yum.  You gotta know what you want, though.  The lady is like the "Vietnamese Sandwich Nazi".  She gives you the evil eye if you're not ready to order.  Indecisive?  Order the Roasted Pork.  Careful, you will find a few Jalapenos in there...make sure you tell them "No Jalapeno for you!"
author: Jennifer L.

description: Easy to miss as there is no sign for the little spot along Larkin Street.  But the roasted pork Vietnamese sandwich is outstanding and only $3.50!!  G
author: Chad S.

description:
#22 on the Big Eat SF list


Vietnamese sandwich... grabbed it to go, 3 bucks, and had a lot of hidden fiery peppers! 

pretty good, but pretty small for the price (the lady asked many times, "only one?" i guess regulars know to get more than one, but hey, it was to taste.
author: S V.

description:
It's 4pm on a Sunday afternoon. I decide to pick up a few sandwiches for me and my friend. 

Front of line: "I need 8 pork sandwiches"
Guy behind him: "What the fuck, I ain't waiting for this"
Guy turns around, "You need to chill out"
Guy screams, "Fuck this," and stammers out in a fit of rage.

Never a dull moment.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I didn't actually go to Saigon Sandwiches, but during my last SF mini vacation, my friends from Hawaii wanted Banh Mi. I guess they don't get Banh Mi as good as we do here. So the boys went to go pick up sandwiches, and brought them back to the girls. lol. 

I got the Tofu Banh Mi, which was really tasty! I really liked the fact that they used tofu skin, instead of the usual fried tofu that other vietnamese places use. The tofu skin makes the Banh Mi much tastier and juicier rather than just dry and blah.

Overall, great sandwiches and cool that we found it in SF. I probably won't go back only cause I never go all the way to SF for Banh Mi (we have great Banh Mi in the SouthBay), but I would recommend it if you are looking for it in the SF area.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
This place makes the best Vietnamese sandwiches in town! They are very filling, yet they are priced sooo looow. It's an incredible deal. I like the pork (siu mai) and the special sandwiches the most. This definitely beats Subway, Quizno's, Lee's Deli, etc etc etc!

I would definitely come back for more of their sandwiches!
author: Sam W.

description:
Have you noticed that most San Francisco foodies or food fans are self proclaimed experts on Asian cuisine? I'm one of them. Alongside that, as an actual Asian, there's that hidden snobbery that lurks beneath (or shows itself very obviously, whatever) when I talk to a non Asian who recommends a great dim sum place or a bakery with the best pork buns. I find that usually, upon checking out the aforementioned recommendation, my usual place is still better. Go me. Cue more foodie-ego inflation and smug city girl attitude.

So that's how I walked into my de-virginizing Saigon Sandwich experience. A little wary, more than a little arrogant, and definitely convinced that I smelled overrated all over the place (alongside the urine soaked streets outside). I've had my fair share of delicious banh mis - convinced that Irving Cafe & Deli was the best and that even if it wasn't, that SS wouldn't be *that* good. So there's always a line out the door - even on any obscure non-meal hour on a weekday. So it's been on some of the country's "best sandwiches" list and has almost 600 reviews on Yelp to date with an average of almost a full five stars. So freaking what! I'm Asian, man.

But then, I tried it . . . and now, disgruntled but without a doubt ready, I gotta say it: it's not overrated. At ALL. The bread is especially notable - deliciously solid and crunchy on the outside, fresh, chewy and heartily soft on the inside. Meats are marinated and flavorful as are the veggies. Pate is generous and freaking delicious. The two ladies behind the counter are impressive in memorizing orders and cranking out the rolled up bread-y, meat-y, tasty rolls of deliciousness (yes, I am very accurate AND descriptive).

So basically, everyone else was right.

Damn it. This kills my elitist facade.

It's okay, though. Totally, totally worth it.
author: Betty W.

description:
Yum.

They get the bread right.  And that's important to me.

So many Vietnamese sandwich places get all the ingredients right but the bread quality is lacking.

At Saigon, the sandwich bread has the right consisistency.  It possesses the perfect amount or resistance when you bite into it, and the flavor to match.

To make an analogy:

I never like pizza places that can't make a good standard pizza.  If the sauce, dough, and cheese ain't good, it doesn't matter to me what toppings you put on it.

If I'm going to eat a sandwich, the bread better be good.

At Saigon Sandwiches, the bread is good.

Bon appetit!
author: Justin C.

description:
Can one place be more polluted with good reviews then Saigon Sandwich, I grew up in the Tenderloin and Saigon Sandwich has always been a tourist attraction or for so called FOODIES people. 
EVERY THING here is NOT MADE HERE, credit goes to HUNG PHAT.
They make almost everything that Saigon Sandwich serve.
   
As I must reiterate to all y'all foodies folk  about the destination of that sandwich your holding from Saigon. Is in the trash can. 
  Lee's across the street serves the same stuff ..I would not doubt it if Lee's supplied some of the meats and sweets.
 Long live the authenic and true Sing Sing Sandwich.
author: John L.

description:
One of those "hole in the wall" joints that ain't a hole in the wall anymore. Sure it still looks unassuming, but if Esquire names you as one of the "Best Sandwiches in America" then you're no longer the cool secret place that's dingy but good and no one knows about it. There is something to be said if you need to step over bums and run past ugly hooker (dudes) to get in the store. Sorry to my second grade teacher, Mrs. Bullentini, for the run-on sentence and redundancy earlier, but I wasn't born in this country. 

Esquire Link (scroll down to the 4th entry): http://www.esquire.com/features/food-drink/sandwiches
author: Al L.

description:
I LOVE THEIR SANDWICHES!
Very nice owner with many other little dishes amongst the small store to purchase other foods like 3 color drink.

They have the best Vietnamese sandwiches in san francisco by far. 

Cheap and quick. 

Cops go there too and know the owner. If cops go, it must be good.
author: Tony C.

description: Very good Banh Mi!! Cheap, fast, easy, delicious. I've had better bread but everything else is superb!
author: Angie Q.

description:
It goes something like this..

You're walking two miles somewhere because you have no money to take the bus. It's disgustingly hot outside (at least for SF) and you're hungry because you've eaten the same shitty food for a week. 

You get to where you're going and you happen across a few dollars. What can you eat that's delicious for a few bucks? That doesn't even get you a glass of cranberry juice in some places.

Then you remember Saigon Sandwiches! You walk through the Tenderloin and it smells like excrement, except you aren't disgusted because all you can think is that even the bums are eating better than you are. You come across the Mecca that is Little Saigon. The line is an exceedingly long one as people ahead of you order 900 sandwiches each. But when you finally get you spicy, savory Roasted Pork sandwich it is all worth it.

Such are the simple needs of life.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Is everything Vietnamese this daaaammmmnnn good?  I would like for someone, anyone to try one of their sandwiches and complain.  

Recommend 2 sandwiches for 5 bucks.. yum yum eat em up!  Also, call in your order.. gets packed early.  Enough of this review... back to my sandwich!
author: Jamal G.

description:
This place is weird, in a good way. They have all Korean snacks, some that I have never ever seen before. A variety of Vietnamese desserts that are made in house and a very eclectic collection of yummy soft drinks and other asian drinks. But the star of this place is clearly the sandwiches. $2.95 for a delicious sandwich packed high with meat and veggies.

I went with the roasted chicken. The chicken was very soft and packed with flavor. The bread was moist and the veggies tart and spicy and just really good. 

Unni went for the combination. It looked great and was packed with a variety of meats. Next time I go, I'm getting that one. 

We picked up some cha gio too. They were good. Some coconut sweet cake thing. Some cookies and the red yellow and white viet dessert cup that was in the fridge. All were very good. And very cheap! 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Jen D.

description:
Hands down, best banh  mi I've had in my life.  Although it is smaller than my typical sandwich, it is filled with a good amount of meat and veggies in the not so-thick french roll (that's a plus).  This makes the overall sandwich well-balanced.  I usually go to Little Paris on Stockton.  In comparison with theirs, Saigon Sandwich tastes much better.  I usually get the chicken or combination sandwiches.  

My concerns about this place tho is: 
1) Cleanliness.  It's such a hole-in-a-wall.  But what place in Chinatown isn't the same.  I just hope that I don't find any extra items in my food....

2) Neighborhood...kinda tricky to get there when you're driving.  I usually park on Eddy St and pay fifteen minutes.  Yes, that's how long it takes to wait in line, put your order in, and then finally get it.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Tiny place, excellent sandwiches, odd hours. I drool when thinking about a combo sandwich dropping with fancy mayo and liver. SO TASTIES!

The only reason for pulling a star? They close at 5:45 and if you give them the sad puppy dog eyes at 5:46 they just shoot you down with a door slammed in your face.  :(  tear.
author: Chris Y.

description:
Thank God I've found this place.  My only option here is the Tofu Banh Mi, but that's okay, 'cause that's all I need.  And nowadays, I usually only have $2 in my pocket, anyway.  This is the restaurant for the broke & (un)employed.  

This place seems pretty popular, and it's easy to see why--a good sized sandwich for less than $3.  Who could pass that up?  Luckily, I've gone when there wasn't much of a line, and once, when there was no line at all!  This is definitely a take-out joint; other than a couple of chairs by the window, there is no seating.  Service has always been fairly quick, and even with the hustle and bustle I imagine these ladies are put through on a daily basis, I'm always given my sandwich with a friendly smile and a 'thank you.'
author: Marsha Z.

description: fast cheap and good.... waiting in the long line sucks but again worth the wait. I have only had the tofu sandwich since I am a non-meat eater.
author: Parichehr M.

description:
Tried the pork sandwich and the one with pate.  Personally, I didn't like the pate sandwich; there was so much of it and it had the consistency of baby poo.  The pork was good though.  The baguette is absolutely delicious - the perfect and simultaneous textures of soft and crunch.  

Watch out if you don't like cilantro though - they put practically an entire bushel of it on each sandwich.  The area is a bit sketch too - after getting our sandwiches, we were harassed by a local crackhead for the next two blocks.
author: Jenny R.

description:
If you're smart, you will know to come either before the crowd gets here, or after. If you come at the wrong time, you are sure to wait in a line that ends up out the door. It wont be long, since they are super quick in making your $3.00 sandwich, but I guarantee you will encounter some very strange people while waiting in line...

just a warning :)
author: M W.

description:
If you've been to Philedelphia and eaten at either of the original cheese steak places then you'll know what I mean. Hella pressure/frustration while ordering. Wizz with, with. etc. 

When the head lady screams "Hello"  you are supposed to order immediatly.

Being it was my first time instead of saying "Chicken, Pork or combo" I tried to ask her a question but just kept screaming "hello, hello, hello, hello". Finally I asked what the combination consisted of. She screamed "Combination" and they started to make my order. Now the regulars behind me  were starting to get restless. Then she screams "Hello" again at the next customer and continues down the line. Um........"Hello" I scream back at her.  She responds with "Hello". 

Its awesome when you can have one world conversations !!!

 So I yell "chicken". She yells "Chicken" and "Combo".  Eventually I ended up with just the chicken as planned.

This place is awesome. But remember only 4 words are allowed. 
"Chicken, pork, Combo or HELLO !!! All must be screamed

For your reading pleasure they exclusively carry the Epoch times. A newspaper entirely made up of AP and wire stories.
author: Joe G.

description:
And the Mystery Meat of the Day is... god I don't know what the f*ck it is but I'm sure they will be serving it here. 

Maybe I was eating dog, maybe it was cat, it definitely wasn't the chicken like I asked... and yeah, it wasn't even pork. 

I was so down to try it. Got excited when we decided to. Got some easy parking (it was Saturday). Service was pretty quick. It seemed semi-clean/clean enough. I was ready for a good sandwich, but damn if only I would have known what I was in for.

I guess if you don't mind eating with your eyes closed and can ignore having to chew on funky stuff you can handle their sandwiches because surprisingly, they tasted ok.

This place is way overrated by....
author: Lee M.

description:
February 9, 2009 @ 11:10 AM

Read my first review then replace:  Pork Sandwich with Tofu Sandwich.

Store was crowded today. I called in my order but it was not ready when I got there. It was not a problem because when I told her, she made my sandwich first before everyone else and was done in 2 minutes. I'm not kidding!!!

Filling, awesome, super-cheap lunch for $3.00!!!!

Will try the beef sandwich next time.
author: Leah E.

description:
Low on cash with a big appetite?  Saigon Sandwiches is your savior.  This place is a true hole-in-the-wall.  It's super tiny w/ window seating for two, not sparkling clean, a little dark, but you get cheap food that tastes awesome!

For exactly $3.25 you can get yourself a combination banh mi, which has a little bit of everything - pate, roast pork, chicken, carrots, cilantro, jalapeno, and mayo.  The ladies that work here totally stuff the sandwiches so it's sure to satisfy your hunger.  I have some trouble eating it because it's huge and the ingredients keep popping out everytime I take a bite - it took me 30 mins to finish eating it!  The sandwich was nice and warm and everything tasted so fresh, including the baguette.  =)

You can get a roast pork, chicken, pate, or vegetarian for only $2.75.  

Bring a little extra cash and you can treat yourself to a sweet drink/dessert.  They also sell prepackaged food items such as spring rolls and rice rolls for really cheap - under $5.  Other snack items are available such as chips, crackers, cookies, and other asian goodies!

If you come during the lunch hour, be patient as the line can get quite long.  The ladies usually take about 5 orders at a time, prepare them all, and then pass out each order - that's when you pay.  Make sure you know what you want to save some time.  They work quickly so you won't have to wait toooo long.

I love coming here when I'm too lazy to pack lunch!  =)
author: Cynthia H.

description:
I have a very long trial to sit through as a juror and I secretly don't think it sucks.  Why?  Well, I get to leave at 4:30 most days (other days... 2:00PM ;P ), I get mandatory 15 min breaks at least twice a day, the city pays me $17.50 each day (yeah, SF, you pay ME!), and I get 1 1/2 hr lunch breaks.  But mainly I'm excited to explore this area for cheap grub, especially the small little Vietnamese district along side Larkin St.

I've been told the best Vietnamese cuisine in the city is here and I've got a month to venture out and find them.  This is the ONLY way I'll walk around the TL freely, in the daytime when the crackheads are passed out in front of City Hall.

So I only really knew of one place... Lee's -- ugh, a big ol' chain.  So as I see the big giant Lee's sign about 2 blocks out, I see a huge line leading to what looked to be a phonebooth selling Bahn Mi's.  Hmm... the only advice I'll take from Rachel Ray is to get in the back of a very long line and you're guaranteed what you get will be good!  $2.75 for a regular ol' sandwich!  Can I get a Pho'ck Yeah?!

I got the roast pork and asked for an extra shmear of pate... mmm smooshed liver.  The line went fast and so did the orders!  My Bahn Mi came out to $3.25 (w/ the extra pate)...hmm, I'm pretty sure I can afford an extra $0.50 so no worries.

The bread was super fresh!!!  And just the way French folks know how to do it... crunchy, buttery outside and soft, pillowy inside.  The pork was not dried out at all, pate didn't have that cold refridgerated temp, and the pickled root vegs were juuuust right.  The only thing I detest is cilantro, which is a must in most Mi's, so I have to remember to ask them w/o that.  Plus, I have tendancies to trap every green object in between my chompers.  Mm hmm... part of the deforestation of the Amazon rainforest?  Yes, you can find them just to the right of my two front teef.  No idea how they got there... but they found their way in.

The Bahn Mi totally hit the spot and the portion was enough where I wasn't going to comatose out in court.  I've got evidence and witnesses to sift through... if it weren't for Roast Pork/Pate combo Mi, I might have convicted the wrong person!  Saigon Sandwich, you might have saved someone thousands of dollars!!!  And you still charge us under $5... Yay, you!
author: Chris T.

description: My man loves the banh mi's here.  The french bread they use here is great, better than alot of those banh mi knock off french bread places, it's kind of like the rolls you get at Tommy Joint's ( a little tough on the crust and you kind of have to pull it away from your mouth )....We tried many and this is his favorite, he once paid $278 bucks for a sandwich, lol, he parked his car outside in the bus stop, came out 5 minutes later, car was gone, tagged and towed....no joke, so better find a parking space....As for me, I prefer banh mi's from Boston, those are the best....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Saigon sandwich: $3.

Saigon sandwich plus toll and gas to get into the city:  $13.

Saigon sandwich plus round trip Bart fare: $15.

RAWR!!!  SF Bay area wins again.

It's such a good sandwich, though.
author: Quinn G.

description:
Hailed by many as the best Vietnamese sandwich shop in the city, I've been a long time member of the fan club myself. Even just passing by it makes me want to change whatever lunch/dinner plans I made so that I can shove my face into a Bahn Mi. 

My favorite here is the grilled pork, but the beau likes the combo. These sandwiches are bigger than what you usually get so it's a deal for the money that you are paying. They also sell other things in the store like snacks, sodas, and traditional desserts. No real places to sit so be prepared to take your food elsewhere to be consumed. Many times, the beau & I can't even make it to our "picnic destination" before we wolf it all down in the car. 

Once I called ahead to see what time they were closing. It turned out to be earlier than I could make it there, and I was feeling super bummed (because when I get a Bahn Mi craving, it's really no joke). Just as I was ready the hang up, the lady asked me if I would like to order ahead and pick it up from her AFTER CLOSING TIME! I mean, she wouldn't have been able to get any sort of payment from me. All she could get was a verbal promise that I would show up! She was definitely good for her words too because we definitely had a sandwich/money exchange later on that night through the metal gates. So so so awesome. I love her for that!!

In my cell phone are speed dial numbers for my parents, my beau, and my bff. Since that incident, Saigon Sandwiches has been added to the speed dial pad of necessary, very important numbers as well.
author: Rona J.

description: Their banh mi has a weird sweet sauce on it. Gross.
author: Kimling L.

description:
i was starvin marvin and i only found the banh mi's from saigon sandwiches to be ok.

first off, the bread is much too hard for sandwiches.  secondly, they need to put pate in all the sandwiches.  thirdly, the the meats are a bit on the salty side.

i'll stick to banh mi's from westminster.
author: Wilafur L.

description:
The "banh mi" sandwiches simply rock.  For $3 - 3.50 you can have a delicious mini baguette sandwich with a variety of meats, pate, jalapeno slices, picked daikon and carrots, cilantro, butter and soy sauce.

The the beginner I would suggest pork or chicken.  If you don't like cilantro or pickled daikon or carrots you can ask them to leave it out but the sandwiches are really not all that special without it.  

I'm a big fan of the meatball and the tofu.  The meatball is a Vietnamese style meatball that has a distinctively Asian flavor.  Very tender and savory.

The tofu is something special here because you hardly ever find good tofu sandwiches at other banh mi places.

The "sauce" is butter and light soy.
author: Calvin N.

description: I went the with my friends to buy their sandwich which it taste very good.  Their service is not really nice. I would come to buy it again.
author: Brian N.

description:
Thank you yelp, you saved me from going to Lee's Sandwich place across the street.  Otherwise I'll just be stuck eating their regular baguette pork sandwich instead of the wonderful fanci pork AND pate COMBO sandwich.  FOR 3 DOLLARS!  
  
Once it hits up lips...you just want more.....that pickled carrot and spicy jalapenos with the fanci pork and then the pate flavor just rushes in right behind them.  I know how Homer Simpson feels now when I watch him eat.  Hmmmmmmm......banh mi.

I suggest eating two banh mi's here (the regular bbq pork sandwich is also a winner).  You can't go wrong with this place.  Fill up so you have energy to run thru the Tenderloin down Ellis street and see people smoking crack pipes at 12 in the afternoon and drug dealers selling crack rocks for 14 dollars back to your hotel at union square.
author: Joe L.

description:
One cockroach isn't bad... I tell myself...

Plus, look, it's going *up* the wall, *away* from the food...

Hmmm, I think it looks full, it's holding its stomach... I think I saw it burp...

OK, OK, concentrate. Your sandwich is almost ready... Courage!

Ay! There's another one, following the first!

I look around, did anyone else see that? No, everyone is staring straight ahead...

Should I say something?

What am I crazy? I don't want to die in the tenderloin, not today anyway... Maybe I'll grab my sandwich and yell out "roach!" as I run out. Hmmm...

Pork! Extra Jalapenos!

Haha! I grab my sandwich, give the lady $2.50 and run out, forgetting to yell out "roach". Fend for yourselves people...

As I sit in my car (the sandwich never makes it very far), watching the drug dealers doing their dealing I think...

Jalapenos must be some kind of disinfectant, no?

Yes, yes, they are...

One star off for making me look inside my sandwich every time I bite into something crunchy and one off for sometimes not having the freshest bread...
author: Mister X.

description:
This is the only place where I treat my Dad to lunch.  $5 for the both of us, now that's a deal...and I am cheap. 

I got the fanci meatball with everything...carrots, jalapeos,cilantro...  It was delicious and very filling.  One is plenty, but because of the price I am always tempted to buy more.

Be prepared to wait in line.  Last time I was here we waited for a good 15 minutes but it was a nice day and definitely worth the wait.  

At all costs avoid going with crazy co-workers who tell your father about how they had their first kiss, etc. in high school at Disneyland.
author: Katherine C.

description:
White boy here who loves this place and has yet to forget that I can not have the peppers on my sandwich.

Saigon Sandwiches makes the best banh mi in San Francisco. I made the mistake a few weeks ago of getting one at Lee's and in learned just how much of a difference one can expect when ordering the same sandwich.


At Saigon you will get a sandwich with just the right amount of sauce so it is not dry, with pickled rather then just diced vegetables, on a roll you will savor rather then see shatter when you bite into it and meats you will swallow rather then spit out of your mouth.

Get you banh mi at Saigon and don't waste your time with the other shops.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Ok, so it's not the CLEANEST place I've ever been in.  And it's not in the BEST location.  And the women who work there don't speak the best ENGLISH.  And the parking is really HARD.  And the line can get REALLY long.  BUT, this is seriously one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. 

Warm, toasty french roll piled with sweet, spicy BBQ sliced pork, pickled carrots, mayonnaise, cilantro and jalapenos.  Yowsa.  Watch out for the slow burn.  It will get you.  

Don't waste your time on the Salad Rolls.  They taste like dirty lettuce.  If you are hungry shell out another $2 and get a second sandwich.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I'm usually not a fan of Vietnamese sandwiches, however, this place is definitely one of my favourites in the city.

The breads are fresh and soft and the meats are flavourful and tender; combined with the fact that they are only $3 each, there is really nothing more you can ask.

My favourites are pork and chicken.
author: Bill T.

description:
Oh, the sandwich of my people...I love the combination of meat, mayo, herbs, pickled veggies, jalapenos, and the warm, crispy empty carbs of your french baguette!  

I don't live or work anywhere near this place but I've made the trek and stood in the line for many, many years now.  Other Banh Mi shops have opened on the next block and they are bigger, cleaner, and even have pictures, but they do not compare to Saigon!  Yesterday, I parked on the block with the new shops, which were both pretty much empty, then I dodged needles and drunks on my way to Saigon, which had a line out the door, as per usual!  They're still the local favorite.

The bread and mayo definitely set this place ahead of the others, but for me it's also the people.  I always speak in Vietnamese (well, order in Vietnamese, which is what I do best!) to the two ladies who run (literally) this place, and although they're always crazy busy they are also kind, soft spoken, and always seem to recognize me even though I don't come too regularly.  I like the ladies and I love their sandwiches!  And you can too!
author: Nicole N.

description:
Besides watching the antics in the Tenderloin from my friends window, this spot was one of the highlights.

I remember my friend leading me to this quaint-looking asian market ion the outskirts of a part of the TL I affectionately monikered Little-Saigon. I remembered thinking that it semed more like a produce place then somewhere to grab some food.  I had my doubts as we left with our sandwiches.  I was factoring in the really inexpensive price, the location, and the place itself; and I may have been a little judgemental.  However, I was so wrong.

I remember coming back multiple times to grab a cheap and great bite to eat.  Love the sandwiches filled with a generous serving of deli meats.  I especially love the Pork and Pate sandwich the best: I love liver.  The bread is also crispy, and delicious.  Add in those pickled Vietnamese flavors; and you have a winning combo for about $3. How can you argue with that.

Delicious deli sandwiches with wonderfully crispy bread: All for cheap.
author: Satoru Y.

description: I never really like Vietnamese sandwiches until my friend introduce me to Saigon Sandwich. OMG! Their roasted pork is the best. I didn't expect much for a sandwich that was under $4. It's the best banh mi out there you can find. I also like their roasted chicken and you will not go wrong with ordering any meat for your banh mi. One thing I must say is that their sauce is delicious mixed in with cilantro, jalapeno, and pickled carrots. Yummy!
author: Elaine C.

description: Fancy Special Combination in a crispy, light baguette with extra meat paste is the big bomb....plus lower than $5...What a great deal!!!
author: Ryu K.

description: Great banh mi.  I usually get the tofu veg one, and it seems other yelpers are loving their meat options too.  The bun is just right, the pickled veggies are actually flavorful, the sauce isn't just hoisin or soy sauce like some other places are trying to cheat with.  The Vietnamese style desserts in a cup are yummy and made with coconut cream (the way they should be) and not dairy.  Prices are excellent.
author: Cando V.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches is around the corner from where I spent three sad years of existence.  I tried to learn to love the sandwich, but love is not about convenience.  Blood 'n BBQ do not mix.  I resorted to buying other snacks, keeping friends company as they queued up for the bad meat.

filling:  0
bread:  0 for being stale & for being sourdough (wtf??).  I hate these concessions to regionalism.
pickles, peppers, cilantro, etc:  0 for the BBQ sauce, oozing from the sandwich like an orange pus.
assembly:  0  
perks:  4 for the friendly customer service.  3 for their assorted snacks, peanut mochi, and grass jelly drinks.  If you're tempted to try out their pre-packaged food, stick with the Goi Cuon Chay (Fresh Salad Rolls with Tofu).  Their Goi Cuon Thit (Salad Rolls with Pork and Shrimp) tastes as scary as it smells.  It smells like catbox.
author: Tam N.

description:
If you don't mind waiting in line on the streets of the T.L for 20 minutes then this place is for you.  Did you know that Vietcong's diet consisted soley of these sandwiches?  No wonder we lost the war in 'Nam! 

The wait is worth the deliciousness and price (cheap!).  Overall, a place worth stopping at if you happen to be in the area.

Expect a line, a wait, and no place to sit.
author: Scott G.

description: Was in town for the weekend and found myself at Civic Center-time for some Vietnamese sandwiches!  Even though the chickens were up to 3.25 a piece I still bought 3-will serve me well on the drive back down to LA.  Delicious-comes with parsley, mayo, bell peppers, onions and carrots.  Definitely a gem.
author: Garrett T.

description:
The lines at the Slow Food Nation food stands at Civic Center were so long, I decided to head to this nearby place for a quick, inexpensive sandwich.  I ordered the tofu banh mi, which was ready within 10 minutes.  Overall, a great sandwich - the toasted French roll was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, filled with seasoned tofu, crisp slivers of carrots, cucumber, jalapeno and cilantro.  On the downside, my sandwich had a larger proportion of tofu to vegetables.  I love the veggie fillings, hot peppers and cilantro, so wish they had put more in there.   On the other hand, I noticed my friend's sandwich had a perfect ratio of ham/pate to vegetables.  
Good place to go for a banh mi fix, however my favorite in SF is still Cafe Dolci.
author: michele g.

description: Again, like Turtle Tower, I have been here before and was not impressed.  Due to the highly rated reviews I decided to see if they could change my opinion this time around, since I was in the area during lunch time.  There was a really long line and I was a bit confused with their ordering system, but found out soon enough.  There were two women working and they basically take about five people's orders at a time.  Then they quickly and quite efficiently make the sandwiches, coming back to the cash register only when all of those orders are finished.  After the transactions are completed, they jot down the next five (give or take) customers' orders and it continues.  I got the combo banh mi and it was good, but not mind blowing.  The bread was good, but the pate was creamy and tasted too much like liver.  Yuck.  I was really hoping that I'd love their banh mi too.
author: Sandy J.

description:
how is there a line here at 2:15pm? cause this place rocks.

there's a bunch of sandwich spots around this area, and i haven't tried them all, but this place delivers a great sandwich at a $3.00 price tag.

edit 06/30/2009 - apparently this place made playboy's top 10 sandwich spots in the usa... google it or whatever.
author: Ameer N.

description: One of the best banh mi's I've had..  Could be a really long wait though!
author: Derrick V.

description:
You know what...I love cheap food.   I even love crappy cheap food.

I can only spend so much on food when there's just so much booze to drink!  Seriously...I gotta prioritize my funds for the important stuff. 

There are a cajillion reviews for this place.  I have to say....it is some good shit. 

However...Wrap Delight is better.   Saigon doesn't put in cucumber in their sandwiches.  They have some pickled mix of onion and something red instead.  

Don't get me wrong...it's damn good. It's also damn cheap.   I can't hate on that but it's not my fave.

I'm hungry now.
author: Jay H.

description:
Update:  8/7/07:  I should have gotten THREE.  DEFINITELY get the roasted pork!

-----

I should have gotten TWO.
author: Natasha S.

description:
BEST BANH MI IN SAN FRANCISCO

Roast Pork Sandwich
The roast pork sandwich delicious.  I loved how all the flavors of roasted pork, pickled diakon and carrots, sliced jalapenos, cilantro sprigs, and secret sauce come together on a toasted baguette.A San Francisco classic!

Hey, even 7 x 7 Magazine agrees, they list this as one of the top 100 things to eat in San Francisco before you die.
author: Rob L.

description:
I discovered this place a year ago while working at the Culinary Academy on Polk St.   I don't know what to tell you, but their sandwiches are bomb-a** sh*t.  Their sandwiches have everything that anyone really needs--hearty meat, jalapenos, crunchy veggies, and some cream (fat).  

Watch out for the Meatball Pork--it's totally awesome! I just love how the flavored and hearty ground pork (not really a meatball) adds a peppery flavor to my sandwich.  No other Vietnamese sandwich comes close to Saigon Sandwiches.
author: Eric T.

description: It's okay. I still think top baguette and banh mi saigon in orange County is better. =D I had the pork roast here. It tastes good because they put a lot of mayo. Meat is alright. The bread is quite small but you would still get full.
author: James V.

description:
I was expecting so much more from this place. I think the ratings are so high because (1) choices are limited when it comes to Vietnamese sandwiches in this area, so beggars can't be choosers, and (2) people love hole-in-the-wall type joints that give them good value, which this place does because yes, the sandwich is very meaty and filling.

That being said, I think this place is good if you're looking for a filling, non-traditional sandwich, but not if you're looking for an authentic Vietnamese sandwich (which is what I was expecting and why I was disappointed). They don't have head cheese, and they overload on the pate and mayo. The "fancy pork" is some processed pork-like product with the texture of fish cake. The roast pork does have nice flavor -- smoky and meaty.

Overall, it was a heavy, somewhat bastardized version of what I'm used to in a Vietnamese sandwich that got a little icky towards the end because it was so meaty. I won't be returning.

P.S. I'm a huge fan of Huong Lan IV in Milpitas -- only $2.50 per sandwich and lots of options, including grilled pork for those who are grossed out by pate and head cheese. Delicious!
author: Veronica S.

description:
This is THEE place I think about when I'm in the TL and wanting a bite to eat for $3. I would rate this the #2 best viet sandwich shop in SF. Comes close to the one on Irving and 23rd.

My favorite vietnamese sandwich from here is their meatball sandwich. It's made just right. The only thing I wish for is bread that is right out of the oven. Sadly, they don't do this but for a place that doesn't have freshly baked bread, their bread is still pretty awesome. They don't cut their sandwiches in half like most other places but that's just a random thing I've noticed. No big deal.

Sometimes the lady asks if you want jalepinos on there but there are times where she has forgotten, so don't forget to say no to jalepinos if you're not a fan. I'm definitely not!
author: Heidi C.

description:
I give this place 2 1/2 stars. Why? 

I don't understand what the worship status is with their banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich). it was very sweet (a warning to diabetics!).

I grabbed one of the prepackaged little rice flour snacks off the counter and ordered a standard dac biet (special, combo) banh mi, and well, I didn't have any expectations even after the glowing reviews. better to be pleasantly surprised rather than let down, right? 

Here goes:
 
The bread was good. The inside of the sandwich however- it was missing the head cheese that I've gotten in all banh mi dac biet. No biggie, just a note. it appeared to be replaced with some fatty grilled pork. I'm not against fatty foods (I like my share of Southern and fried fare) but I don't like chunks of artery stoppers. The liver pate they used was very good though, it had a very fresh flavour. it also contained the standard pale pork meatloaf-type thing (I liken it to German leberkase).

Where oh where did my shredded daikon go? I neglected to look over the counter to see if they actually had any, but I was pretty confident they would have it- seems like a staple. I like pickled daikon. I felt a little gypped!

I asked for no cilantro. NO CILANTRO! Luckily I checked before taking my first bite or it would have ruined the entire sandwich for me- I removed two big sprigs of said offensive herb of evil (those wiley banh mi makers, I tell ya). I was standing there and the banh mi order taker told the maker three times, and she even nodded in acknowledgement! What the heck? 

the one thing that put me off was the sweetness of the entire sandwich. After about four bites I couldn't handle it anymore, and I set some soy sauce on it to try and bring it back to the savory side of things. it didn't seem to help and I didn't want my sandwich tasting of soy sauce, so I only managed about 3/4 of the way through before I just couldn't have any more of my sweet sandwich. What the heck was all the sugar about? 

The prepackaged thingy is called banh beo- little rice flour disks that are steamed until tender, topped with a cooked mung bean paste, ground dried shrimp and chopped green onions. This version also had some chopped bits of grilled pork and what I deciphered after some chewing was shredded pork skin. it was alright, but their fish sauce seemed a little sweet to me too. Am I becoming diabetic? 

Overall it was passable, but no matter how bad my banh mi craving is while in SF, I'm saving it for my two spots in Oakland where I get consistent savory goodness.

**2/12/07 update**
JR and I had the chicken banh mi the other day. He concurred that it had a sweet sauce on it (ok, so my taste buds are NOT going haywire!) and that he preferred the ones I get at the 'other' place. Not only that but the chicken here isn't grilled- it's just 'cooked' or even cut up! I had large sections of chicken that fell out of my sammich that were too big. The 'other' place actually grills their chicken.

I also picked up some banh cuon (rice rolls with ground pork & julienned wood ear fungus) and some banh beo. The banh cuon was very salty in comparison to the rest of their food- the most savory thing dare I say. The rice wrapping containing the filling was the wrong consistency and texture-it was more like a steamed Chinese rice roll you would get at a dim sum house- thick and opaque, not delicate and translucent. 

The Banh beo was a gloopy, greasy mess. Where did the grease come from? WTF. I have had many but never were there little pools of oil on the bottom of the container! And they were steamed, not fried so the grease really is a mystery. I understand a little is used to keep them from sticking together, but come on. They were so soggy they fell apart. 

I'm still staying away from this place so you guys can have my place in line. Try BC Deli or Cam Huong and tell me which one you like better.
author: Mortiche W.

description:
Good.  Hot or Not?  Hot.

Had the roast chicken sandwich.  Actually 1/3 of one split amongst two other friends.The French baguette was very soft..it actually didn't hurt the roof of my mouth!  Roast chicken was perfectly marinated, the special special mayo sauce was great and the fresh veggies made it all a killer combo.  And don't ask me want they put in that mayo sauce...I really don't want to know.

$3 for a sandwich isn't bad..considering you're in sf and subway is still charge for $5 dollar foot longs.  But you can always go cheaper.  I've had sandwiches for $2 before.  Although, the chicken chunks here were more bigger.
author: Yup S.

description:
Had the tofu sandwich here. They use thin slices of braised tofu - different and very good! Sauce is slightly thick and sweet (tasty, but I like the regular fish sauce), plenty of pickled veggies and onions. Bread is crunchy, but not too crunchy. I can see why everyone in line ordered two sandwiches!

Good Vietnamese tofu sandwich!
author: Evelyn G.

description:
I used to come here alot when I first moved to the city,  and  BOY did I love me my sammies here....Hundreds probably....Maybe more!
Until one day, after a couple of bites, I looked down and saw HALF of a dead cockroach...HALF!....*shudder*....So I had to break it off with them....It's not so bad that I have to cross the street when I see them....No....I just look longingly at them, think about the good times and keeping walking.....
author: Lara D.

description:
It was mostly a Bad Time, but at least one Good Thing came out of the French occupation of Indochina (I never saw Miss Saigon so I could be wrong, but I'm guessing on the whole Ho Chi Minh would have preferred to stay at home and that he only hit the Trail out of necessity).

That's the Banh Mi.

Needs no introduction nor yet another overwrought description of its one-of-a-kind flavor pattern, except to say S.S. has the best banh mi in town, still at the reasonable price of $3 per, and S.S. also has a vast array of other Southeast Asian delights like garlic peanuts, seaweed desserts, and the like.

Wonder if anything as good will come out of the Iraq War? Halal burgers, perhaps? Hmm.
author: Chris R.

description:
Everyone's said it already, but Banh Mi is great.  I write only to recommend that you accompany your sandwich with a ginger ale.  They have two kinds!  And they have diet.  Drink it with a straw.  No good reason, except that's how they do it in New York.

Also, don't ask to leave the peppers off, or anything off.  It's the combination that is so good.  Jalapenos alone:  too much.  In this sandwich?  Perfect.   It's a mistake to special order.

They also have wasabi peas (yum) and great spring rolls with shrimp.
author: Laurel B.

description:
OMG, I just realized I haven't written a review for this wonderful place that has the best vietnamese sandwiches ever.  I'm not the type that enjoys those hard crusted Baguette kinds from Lee's, so this place makes it all the better.  I get their combo for like $3 or something.

Just make sure you have patience to wait in line for this place during lunch hours because it gets long, but those two nice ladies in there are soooooo quick with the sandwiches, and they just come flying out like nothing.  love da carrots, the radishes, the perfect amount of mayo and the meat that comes in the combo!.  and all for under $3??
author: Vincent K.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches shoots straight up to the top of my cheap eats list.  Some people might think it's crazy that I should value a good Vietnamese sammiche so highly.  But banh mi is really important.  To my life.  MY LIFE.

I didn't believe my buddy when she told me there was an amazing banh mi place on Larkin (I'd become disillusioned and generally apathetic towards Vietnamese food in SF at this point), but Saigon Sandwiches is for real.  Loaded with super fresh and flavorful ingredients (they don't skimp on the pate, let me tell you), these sandwiches rival some of the banh mi I've had in the South Bay and in L.A..  They blow away the Vietnamese joints in Oakland Chinatown.  Which sucks for me because now I will be at work wondering what to eat, and I will just scoff disgustedly at the banh mi places around my office, knowing there is Saigon Sandwiches waiting for me at home.  *sigh*  

Special combo sandwiche... roasted pork sandwiche... mmm... *drool*
author: Diana Y.

description:
I love a good Vietnamese sandwich.

I'm a freak for spicy things - and while others take vitamins, I live off of Jalapenos and Serranos.  Yum.  I am a better person when I am fed my peppers.  It does wonders for my temper.  Even as a child, when I started acting up or throwing a hissy fit, mom would cook something that would perhaps kill some caucasian folks on the spot.  My mood would then improve.  Drastically.
 
So when one country decides to put Jalapenos inside a sandwich - - - I become a huge, huge fan.
 
For any of you who have not had a Vietnamese sandwich - - it's in a hoagie-type roll, contains marinated carrots, some other produce, JALAPENOS, mayo-type sauce, and some yummy meats.  I usually order this sandwich with Vietnamese cold cuts, but Saigon Sandwich didn't have them.  So I ordered the chicken.
 
Wowsies.... this stuff is good.  It tastes sort of like Teriyaki Chicken.... but not.  It's sweet, but not.  It's juicy but - - well, it's just juicy.  Yummy!
