Really good bread is served up here, and they have various other things laid out on the counter, for sale.  I skimmed over the packages and picked one to try.  I am still not sure what it was, but I can tell you - whatever it was, was not very good at all.  
Saigon Sandwiches - - - go with the name, get just the sandwiches.
 
Rob had the Pate Sandwich - - and that was also good.  But unless it is truly top quality pate - - pate always remidns me of Alpo.  No, I have never eaten Alpo, but if I had - I suspect it'd taste like this.  I, personally, would stick to the chicken or pork,
 
Saigon Sandwich is allegedly one of the most popular sandwich joints in the city.  I can see why.  This is good stuff.... and during the 10 minutes or so that I was there, people kept on pouring in to order. 
 
All that said - - I think I would opt to go to the typical Lee's Sandwiches over this, since #1, they have my coldcuts, and #2 for what this actually is - - it's cheaper there than at Saigon.  But even so - - it's STILL a bargain, and good, good food!
author: Grace K.

description:
I biked over to Saigon Sandwich for breakfast this morning, as the prospect of yet another bagel or pastry made me want to retch.  Lo and behold, they have breakfasty stuff!  I got what looked like a big steamed pork bun, but inside it also a cooked egg and some delicately flavored meat and spices.  Yum.  It was still warm and I wonder if it had been just baked?  

Though not exactly health-food, it wasn't as heavy as you might think.  I highly recommend giving it a try if you're there in the morning.

As for Banh Mi, I think the virtues of this sandwich are well known to all.  It almost makes the French colonial invasion of Vietnam seem worthwhile.  Well, ok, not really.
author: Amar P.

description:
$2 for a delicious Vietnamese tofu sandwich.... huh, where am I?  This doesn't feel like San Francisco!

I never would have discovered this gem in the wall if it wasn't for Yelp.  I've only had the "Chay" sandwich, since it's the only vegetarian option, but it is a masterpiece of a sandwich.  One sandwich is quite filling and enough for a meal.   It comes in a baguette with tofu (the tofu is a rolled-up sheet with a spongy texture), shredded carrots, onions, cilantro, and green chilli, and I believe mayo and some other sauces.  It's good stuff.  And the two Cantonese-speaking ladies behind the counter always provide fast and friendly service.
author: Dinesh M.

description:
Update: 
March 2008 Saigon fell in 1975, well....this Saigon's pork filling fell in quality...more like a HoChiMing faux pork filling...blech...$2.75..YUCK..
minus two stars
********************
One of the original Vietnamese bahn mi sandwich places thats up in the Tenderloin and just  continues to pack the people in during the week because it is close to the Law School, Federal Building and the State of Cal building.

Get the pork sandwich, custard pudding, soursop juice and it will still be under $5.00. 
It is about the size of walk in closet. After the 4th or 5th person in line it starts snaking out to the street onto Larkin.
author: miriam b.

description:
I grew up eating vietnamese sandwiches in San Jose, but never have I had one quite as delicious until I moved to the TL and started coming here.  The bread is ALWAYS perfect and they are definitely generous with the Pate.  I usually can't finish a sandwich this size, but for some reason, there's never a crumb left from here.  For $3.50 (for the special combo sandwich), its a economical, filling, and yummy lunch meal. 

They DO close early though, so expect to come here for lunch or early dinner.
author: Cindy K.

description:
Within the context of Banh Mi shops Saigon Sandwich is without a doubt 5 stars.  They've got the three things any Vietnamese sandwich shop should have - they're fast, cheap and a little bit dirty.  

Now most banh mi places have these three things, what sets Saigon Sandwiches apart?  The sandwiches are actually GOOD!  The bread is always fresh and the tofu seasoned well, a rarity for the oft overlooked banh mi chay.  (where are the buddhist monks in this town driving up demand for a quality veggie sandwich?)  The pickled veg is just the right mix of crunchy and tangy.  You won't wait for more than 10 minutes to eat and you can always grab a bag of wasabi dried peas (or sticky rice, or mung bean cakes, or spring rolls) if you can't make it that long without food.

Somehow the ladies that work there pump out hundreds of sandwiches without breaking a sweat.  Amazing.

Still have yet to find a better banh mi in SF...
author: Mat K.

description:
Ah...my love for Saigon Sandwiches has never been less than the first time when I had their vietnamese sandwiches.

I used to order the special combo where they seriously do not skimp on the meat, pate and the carrots. It was so delicious until once I decided to refrain from any red meat in my diet, the special combo was also eliminated...sad, and I wasn't too fond of their chicken sandwich.

Luckily, TOFU shows up on their menu and seriously, it is SOOOO good! Marinated tofu with veggies and jalapenos, I cannot ask for more. For $3.00 a pop and filling to the tummy, it keeps your wallet heavy while satisfied.

Only thing that might interfere being able to get my sandwich: the line. Depending on what time of the day although most of the time, there is a line outside of the door . But hey, it's worth the wait =).

Cash only. They do not take bills higher than $20.
author: Kim L.

description:
After all the rave reviews on Yelp for this place I finally got to try this place out.  My gf and I ordered (1) chicken and (1) pork sandwich.  They both come with the usual carrots, radishes, onions, and cilantro that most Vietnamese sandwiches are made with.  

The chicken sandwich tasted a lot better than the pork.  For $3 a sandwich, you can't go wrong here.

Make sure you keep one eye on where you parked your car because this place is located in the worst area in SF.
author: Danny P.

description:
When I say "ne'er again," I mean about two-and-a-half months later.

Better pork this time, but I've had leaner portions elsewhere.  Still, not bad for $3 even.

Some methhead tried to shoplift a soda while I was waiting in line, but was thwarted and duly derided by us paying patrons.
author: Daryl E.

description:
This has got to be one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. I got the roast pork and totally digged it. The bread was super fresh, crunch and soft. The pork wasn't fatty like I've had it some other places, and all the ingredients tasted fresh! I'm salivating just thinking about it right now. The bf and other friend got the pork and pâté and couldn't stop talking about how good it was. 

So we ended up getting these sandwiches before hitting up this clothing fashion show thing, and we decided just to eat outside of the Galleria where the show was at. We were all eating our sandwiches when all of a sudden this guy probably around his early twenties starts jocking us and goes... "dude is that from Saigon Sandwiches?!? oh mannn they're so good. I want one now". Please note that we were like 1.5 miles away from Saigon. That is just how popular and good this place is. This is definitely a must go for a quick meal in the city so you can maximize shopping time!
author: Gloria C.

description:
What else can I possibly say that hasn't been said before?  The banh mi here are the most kick-ass, stupendously delicious ones that I've had in a long while.  The two ladies making these sandwiches will stuff the hell out of fresh baguettes with the meat and the veggies (onion, carrot, daikon, jalapeno, and cilantro) and you end up with this little wax-paper bundle of love.  My brother got the roast pork and I got the roast chicken and we scarfed those babies down in about 5 minutes as soon as we got back to the car.  We were stuffed, but contemplated going back inside the place and splitting a combination sandwich.  Luckily (well, maybe not really) we came to our senses, although we should have gotten some to go since I'm totally craving one now.

-1 star because I asked for no cilantro on my sandwich and mine ended up stuffed with the most cilantro.  The sandwiches were also a tad sweet for my taste...next time, I'm gonna have to ask for extra jalapenos.

Overall, I'm in love with these sandwiches....delicious and cheap, cheap, cheap!
author: Angela H.

description: This may have been the best sandwich I've ever had in San Francisco. This place is very small - only two seats - and in a bit of a sketchy neighborhood, but the sandwiches are to die for! I recommend chicken/pate combo.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I was visiting SF and while wondering around the town, I got lost.  In fact, I was looking for one of the famouse food trucks that was supposed to be in the vicinity... then I came across this dinky little place.  I wouldn't have known that this was even a food joint, had it not been for a long line of people out the door!  It is my motto, never pass up a food joint with a long line of people.  So I got in line, without knowing what kind of food or 'stuff' they were selling.  This was the BEST decision I made in SF!  So the place turns out to be a dinky little Bhan Mi shop.  Again, without the long line of people out the door, I wouldn't have known that this was even a restaurant!  I was a bit confused on how to order or pay or get my food, so my place in line was sniped by a couple of sneaky old ladies, but a nice dude behind me told me what to do - I yelled out my order and stepped to the side and waited for my bahn mi to be assembled.  The place doesn't have a decent place to sit and eat... unless you want to be trempled by people waiting for their order.  So I took my sandwhich and headed out to a nearby park - ironically, they were having off-the-grid food truck gathering with the exact food truck I was looking for... go figure.  
Anyway, I dug into my grilled pork bhan mi... THE BEST EVERRRRR!!!!  Oh my goodness, they have perfected the french baguette!  Perfectly golden, crunch outside and airy, chewy and flavorful inside.  Pickeled veggeis, a bit of sriracha and grilled pork were absolutely perfect combination!  Literally, orgy of flavor and texture in my mouth!!!  All for less than four bucks, are you freakin' kidding me!!!???  A MUST!!!!
author: MJ L.

description:
Fantastic.  Great sandwich for $2.75.  This place got a write up in Esquire a few months ago and deservedly so.

When it gets busy, be prepared to wait, but not long.  They'll take the orders for the whole line and then bust the sandwiches out right quick.

I didn't have any problem with the attitude of the staff.  And if you're picky, you deserve some 'tude.  Eat it the way it's made or pick it off yourself.
author: Josh L.

description: Two ladies cranking out Vietnamese pork sandwiches. Store sells Vietnamese desserts, rolls, and drinks. Two seats at window, primarily for waiting customers not for snacking. Bread was stale, pork was average. The speed and price were sellers. Sandwich not so much.
author: Mairead R.

description: What? This is place is ridiculous! Delicious sandwiches at incredible prices. No wonder people are lined out the door . We've been back 2 times since we first visited two weeks ago.
author: Graeson N.

description:
ohhhh my god! the sandwhich here is so sloppy and nasty. The place is filthy and over rated.........this is not the best sndwhich place! i used to thihnk the sandwhiches were good here awhile back ago untill they got so sloppy with their sandwhiches. to tell u the truth it looks like a dog just went through ur sandwhich.  they use this very gewy sauce that tastes like melted down fat...........ewwww........grose!
pleaseeeee check out sing sing sndwhich shop..........deeelicious,
you will then know what a true authentic vietnamese sandwhich should taste like.
author: Sharon T.

description: Let's not kid around--these are the best in affordable, delicious sandwiches! The ordering process is a little confusing cuz everyone is just standing around and there's two little ladies behind the counter doing their business, making sandwiches like you're not even there but it's all worth it. They have other stuff too. None that I've tried because my mind is so set on those amazing sandwiches but I'm sure if it's there, it's delicious. The lines are super long and sometimes the wait is a bitch but to bite into that warm toasty french bread with some suspiciously delicious meatball pork and jalapeños? ALL worth it! and it's only THREE dollars a sandwich! Ain't nothing wrong with that.
author: Veronica L.

description: Sandwiches here are good but I wouldn't rave about it. I mean it's cheap and prolly the only viet sandwich place you get in the city. If you want really good viet sandwiches, go down to san jose.
author: Joyce B.

description:
On my way from BART to Van Ness, I couldn't resist taking a quick detour on Larkin to try a Bahn Mi from Saigon Sandwiches.

The chicken Bahn Mi was full of carrots, tons of cilantro and jalapenos. Unfortunately, the chicken was chunky (I like my Bahn Mi chicken shredded) and kind of fatty. I loved the sweet pickled flavor of the veggies. Some of the best I've had. I just wish the meat was a little better. 

I also bought a Banh Tet Chuoi (sticky rice with stuffed with banana) on impulse and it was perfectly sweet and balanced with banana flavor. I had never had one before and now I'm afraid I'm hooked. 

Saigon Sandwiches appears to be a well-oiled machine. I had my sandwich in hand in less than three minutes. Now that's fast food at its best!
author: Lee H.

description:
Thank you Yelpers for turning me on to a great sandwich. I just finished the BBQ Chicken (excellent) and am now eating a pork bun (not the best ever, but good) and washing it down with a soda, for less than $5. These ladies must be exhausted by the end of the day, they are so efficient and even friendly!
Thank you Yelp!

Update: 
So, this is my third trip there this week and I am polishing off my third sandwich in this sitting. I decided to try the Meatball, and I am seriously hooked.Thank god I am at home, because I literally licked the paper wrapper clean. 
I am an addict, going to the tenderloin every day for my fix.
author: Jason D.

description:
I'm totally lovin on this place

They're all super good, except for this mystery fish meat one don't get that one, but besides that it's so freaking good and so cheap.

I love that they're spicy, o those vietnamese people, who knew they kicked ass at making sandwiches and other warm foods.  I'm still unsure as to why the place is so cheap and why the sandwiches are so freaking good, but as long as that doesn't change you will see me there.  I only wish this place was open all day so I could get my dinner on there.
author: Chrammy D.

description: Thank you, Saigon Sandwich, for making the only really good bahn mi that I've ever had. I've certainly tried many others, and every single blessed time I'm just angry that it's not from Saigon Sandwich. I won't make that mistake ever again. xoxo
author: heather c.

description:
Bottom Line Up Front: The sandwiches are to die for. 

Meat: roasted pork, spot on. tender and moist

carrots and other veggies: crisp and fresh

sauce: tasty glue holding the thing together... helps the sammy melt in your mouth

bread: just enough crunch on the outside with the fresh softness on the inside.


If I was Vietnamese.. I could only hope my mom was a cool lil sandwich maker like the two lovely ladies working the counter when I arrived.
author: Drew F.

description: I love this place! The sandwiches are the best around, been coming here for 7 years. Whenever I get out of town visitors who want to do the tourist thing in the city, this is our first quick stop.  Sure, we can go take pictures of the civic center... It's my excuse to get my Banh Mi fix!
author: Jasmine T.

description: I'm not going to complain about a $3 sandwich, especially since I did enjoy the pate, pork and pickled veggies in it.  The bread didn't taste fresh but overall, it was good.  That wasn't a complaint.
author: Seong P.

description: If you want cheap, dirty but delicious...Saigon is your best bet. This little hole in the wall draws in quite a crowd because of its mega cheap $2.75 sandwiches. Good place to grab a quick to-go sandwich if you are on the run. Saigon Sandwiches I would say is a step above fast food but pretty much tastes like street food or the food you get from a food truck.
author: Debbie C.

description: WOW a Vietnamese sandwich still for $3.50?! I've tried many Vietnamese sandwiches around the Bay and Saigon is one of the best, but it still blows my mind that it's only $3.50. I consider this a very cheap price for something so scrumptious!
author: Philip T.

description:
I only had Lee's sandwiches for a Vietnamese sandwich and I thought that was good, but man, Saigon Sandwich is the best. I did not expect that. 

Seating: There are only a couple of chairs
Ambiance: A place for only a quick grab and go sandwich. I do not recommend this place for you to stay longer and chill with your friends. It gets stuffy inside. Also, the line can be long so have some time allowance to get your food. 
Price: Very reasonable, even cheaper than Lee's sandwiches
Taste: Did not disappoint. I love the Special Combination Sandwich. The proportion is big that after eating half of the sandwich, I was already full. 
Service: They were quick to ask who's next and always on the go to work on your sandwich.
author: Joann L.

description:
The people outside here are almost as spicy as the food inside. 

One gent was getting into a dispute with another gent. 
I think it was a debate over ethics in the modern world. 
Yes, I'm an optimist. 

In any case, the one gent settled it with the other gent, by yelling, to him YOU GO AHEAD CALL THE LAWMAN...then he turned to me, and screamed, YOU GO AHEAD AND CALL GOD.

I told him I left his number back at my hotel room
And he mumbled, "figures".

Ahh the city by the bay.
 
Go here. Get the pork. You know the drill. 
Ask 'em for it with a little extra juice. 
It really makes the sandwich kick into overdrive. 
As tender as the 'loin itself?
Not a chance.
author: D. R.

description:
More of a 2.50 stars, but anyways....

Finally got around to trying this place some friends have been raving about, and well, I was totally underwhelmed.  Aside from being cheap, I don't see what the big deal is.  I picked up two sandwiches (to try two different fillings) - the combo, and the BBQ pork.  Both were rather greasy, and the taste was, well, meh.  Sure they were stuffed quite full of...stuff, but that stuff was rather lacking in taste and texture (if you discount mush as a texture).  If your primary concern is a high food:dollar ratio, then I guess it's decent enough...though on the flip side, you could get a pound of steam table chow mein elsewhere for the cost of a sandwich.

I prefer the Bahn Mi at Little Paris (though admittedly I haven't been there for a few years - so they may have changed).
author: T C.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches owns Lee's
THE END. 
Plus, my mother knows people there so that works for me :P
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
Saigon Sandwich is pretty good, but I'm unclear if it lives up the the hype- despite what Mark Zuckerburg says.  http://www.facebook.com/q/Whats-a-good-banh-mi-place-in-or-near-Palo-Alto-CA/535301619147

For the money, it's a super good deal.  Although, I haven't really heard of Vietnamese sandwiches being more than $3.50.

I walked to Cupkates and picked up two awesome cupcakes and then stopped by S.S. to get two sandwiches.  (Awesome Friday lunch!)  I ordered the fanci pork and the roasted pork for a total of $6.50.  I could barely finish my second sandwich, which was a shame because I ate the fanci pork first and roasted pork was better in my opinion.  If you're in the area, I'd definitely stop by, but it wasn't worth walking a mile through the 'loin in my mind.  Next time I'm in the area, I'll probably try out Turtle Tower.
author: Cersei T.

description:
While i was attending Art Institute in the Civic center, i used to walk here at lunch and grab a couple sandwiches.

They were always fresh and tasted great, there was always a line, and it was always worth it.
author: N S.

description:
Cheap, modest portioned Vietnamese sandwiches, along with a lot of strange looking (to the western eye) Vietnamese (I assume) deserts and treats.  Located in quite the sketch neighborhood, in quite the hole in the wall.  

Quality of food is wonderful.  Something addicting and wonderful about these sandwiches.  They are filling and sized to perfection: if I'm not aching for extra food, or for my girlfriend, one sandwich is perfect, otherwise two does the trick (and at 6$ is still cheaper than all comparable large sandwiches I've seen these days).  

Adding to the experience is the Location.  Yes, I would say there is something about the sketch tenderloin location and hole in the wall ambiance which makes it an edgy, and an out of the ordinary, yet positive, experience.  Something exciting about plunging into the darkness, per say, to come out with a treasure such as one you'll find here. 

Cheap, tasty, not your average lunch.  Live on the wild side.  Oh and unfortunately its not quite a secret.  Best come after lunch hours during the week to get a short wait, or just hang out in line for about 15-20 min.  I do love businesses who give quality and don't steal an arm and a leg.
author: Alex L.

description:
WOW. Hands down the best bahn mi sandwiches I've had. I decided to "splurge" and get the most expensive sandwich - the special combination. It was somewhere in the $3 range, while their other sandwiches are in the $2 range. I know. I'm such a high roller.

The baguette was fresh and crusty with a generous amount of pate spread on the inside of the bread. A variety of meats, pickled carrots and daikon, and cilantro were stuffed into the sandwich. The flavors of the pate and the meats and the pickled stuff were all perfect. And it left me full for several hours (which is a big deal for me). 

My only complaint is that their iced coffee wasn't very good. But then again, Lee's Sandwiches is right across the street, so I can just hop on over to get the iced coffee there (I love their coffee, but I'm not a fan of their sandwiches). 

Yay for bahn mi!!!
author: Lisa M.

description: I love these Vietnamese sandwiches... or Bahn Mi.  My favorite is the meatball.  The bread is this great torpedo shaped french baguette. The bread is crusty and chewy and deliscious, especially when it soaks up the deliscious sauce they use.  Inside is the generous meatball filling, pickled carrots, jalapenos, cilantro, and ginger and I am sure I missed something.  They are a great deal at $3.50 a piece and one of my favorite things to eat in the city.
author: Shaun B.

description: Initial reaction to the sandwich was that it was smaller than the average banh mi you typically get but once you take a bit into it, it totally made up for it. The banh mi was packed full of flavor and the pate was very generous. Finished the sub and was full and satisfied. Will come back for sure. Can see why there was a lot of people there during lunch time. You actually see many different nationalities here, not just Vietnamese people. Glad to see that ;)
author: Alizze A.

description:
I'm eating a saigon sandwich as I'm typing. My brother picks up his girlfriend from work near Saigon Sandwich. I was craving my usual bbq pork with extra pate. The ladies are very generous with the pate.

This is the only place I eat my banh mi, since I was a kid.
author: Lola H.

description:
I was craving a vietnamese sando yesterday and decided to stroll down to the TL to pick one of these babies up. I ordered the usual, the chicken sandwich, never a disappointment.
For 3$ a sandwich you can't complain. It's filling, tasty and the roll is delish!
author: Kehaulani K.

description: Banh mi is delicious!! Not quite as good as the one I had in Chicago at Grahamwiches but definitely worth the walk from work for lunch. It cost me $4.75 for a chicken banh mi and a snapple. Deal!
author: Kate J.

description:
Legit Vietnamese sandwiches (usually!). But I don't know if a return any time soon is going to happen... 

Ordered a Chicken Banh Mi. There was a hair inside. It was not mine. It was literally stuck between the meat and the veggies, embedded into the sandwich. That made me sad. 

What the heck... it's just a single strand of hair! More protein! I will be going back... I just hope Saigon Sandwich and I can put all this hairy business behind us... 

Usually go for their Roasted Pork. A single sandwich for $3.25 is enough for a pretty filling meal. 
With their Tofu, it usually gets the bread soggy. I guess you just have to eat it a bit faster before it sogs up...
author: Kevin L.

description:
Taste - just aight I say. Yes I've tried them all and don't dislike any ingredients they use. The bread is really good too, but they just don't own it - know what i mean. If you add in the value - OK then you are talking about a much better situation. I have gone back for repeats and will continue to, but overall not a 5 star place in my book

Value = BIG / Taste = MED
author: Mike C.

description:
I'm a fat guy.

Therefore I was skeptical that two $2.50 sandwiches would fill me up.  And right now I'm stuffed from those delicious Saigon Sandwiches.

The bread is some of the best I've had in the bay.  I got standard chicken sandwiches which combined shredded carrots, fresh jalepeno's, cilantro, sweet and sour sauce and roast chicken.

They were really good and mixed some flavors that I've never really had together before.  It's not for the squeamish though; the meat was pretty fatty and grizzly.  I honestly would prefer a $3.50 sandwich with higher quality meat.

But that's just one white guy's opinion.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Thank you Yelp for directing me to this place. It is a true hole-in-the-wall; I couldn't find the location at first. 

For $3 you get a delicious choice of BBQ Pork, Beef, Chicken or Patte sandwich. There are other items on sale, but I don't remember the prices :p
This has to be one of the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had. The bread looked deceivingly hard but once you sunk your teeth into that delicious baguette, you were proven otherwise. The sauce they used on the BBQ was delicious and not too oily - nice. 

This truly was a two woman operation, one lady to heat up the sandwiches and another to stuff it and ring the customers up. They were super efficient; getting customers in and out in a blink - even when the line was out the door.
author: Danvin R.

description: The best tofu banh mi I've ever had for any price, let alone for under $4 in SF.
author: Allison D.

description:
With Saigon sandwich being less than a block away from Lee's, before having gone there I had always wondered how the two managed to stay successful. After visiting both, I now know why.

If you can muster the courage to brave the heart of the Tenderloin, fight your way, be it literally or figuratively, through the throngs of vagrants rattling their cups of change and Trannies itching to ask you if you'd like a hummer, then do it. Do it for justice. Do it for a Saigon. Do it for yourself. 

You will be hard pressed to find a better sandwich anywhere in the city, and this is coming from a guy who just gave a 4 star review to another sandwich shop down the block.

The store itself is cramped even when it isn't packed, which isn't often, but it's all worth it once you walk back out that door with a freshly made SAIGON.

The menu is relatively small, but trust me, you can't really go wrong with it. Unlike my routine at Lee's, which consists of chicken, when I trek to Saigon I always order the pork. IT IS SO FANTASTIC YOU WILL WONDER HOW THE HELL YOU EVER MANAGED TO LIVE WITHOUT IT.  Everything about it tastes fresh. The cilantro is some of the most flavorful I've had, the carrots are crisp, and the meat is tender and nomnom. It's filling to boot, which is a DAMN good deal for a sandwich that just cost you $2.75.

You're damn write I just wrote nom. I could have filled this whole review with nomnomnomnom and been satisfied, but added details and real words because I love you all. 

Go there. Get a sammich. Get some dried mango too. You won't regret it. With that first bite, it will be as if that bum you had to punch in the face for touching you when he asked for change never even existed.
author: Zack H.

description:
The sandwiches are as tasty as everyone has said. Nothing scary for those who may have gotten freaked out by some of the reviews. I too recommend the BBQ pork, since that's the only one I've tried thus far and it was excellent. I would describe it as a "mouth party".

The store is very small, crowded and if there's seating, I missed it. Maybe one table. Random stuff is pilled up high on the counters and there are things covering every shelf and surface. 

I found "Little Saigon" to have ample metered parking and the neighborhood wasn't scary during lunch time. Oh and yes, the sandwiches are dirt cheap. Enjoy.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I had no idea this place existed until my friend told me about it and we walked over to check it out.

We went around 2pm on a Friday and there was still a line! The lady who works there is very nice and is great at remembering orders.

The menu is limited but seriously, it doesn't matter. We had the roast pork sandwich and I must say, it was one of the best-tasting banh mi's I've ever had. WAY WAY WAYYYY better than Lee's Sandwiches. 

The pork tastes much more fresh. Yes, it is fatty (and I'm not a huge fan of fat =/) but I was able to pull out the fatty parts and it still tasted great. The sandwich was $3 and was smaller (shorter) than I expected, but by the time I finished the sandwich, I was full. All the other ingredients (carrots, cilantro, jalapeno peppers, white radish) were standard, but as everyone says, it's the sauce that is spread on the bread that makes it awesome.
I'm not sure exactly what the sauce is made out of, but it definitely makes this sandwich special!

The neighborhood is kinda sketch =/ but it's all good. 

Real foodies will trek for food, no matter the location!!
author: Jessica L.

description: I think I came on an 'off' day. The bread was hard as HECK(no joke)! I got the combo= $3.75. I had some for better quality at a cheaper price. The sandwich was really tasty, but too much mayo inside for me. My bf also got a tummy ache afterwards =( I still can't get over the fact of their hard bread though..
author: Vivian L.

description: I have been coming here since 1994, this is the best place in the bay hands down for a Vietnamese sandwich. I have tried them all, and they all are very delicious. I recommend getting the meatball sandwich it is to die for.
author: Foshow O.

description:
As good as it gets!  Can't go wrong with a great roasted pork sandwich for 3 bucks out the door!  Beats the "Five....Five....Five dollar foot long" at subway.  Although I do enjoy subway sandwiches too.  

The meat is tender and they don't skimp out on it.  The crunchy fresh french bread they use is delicious.  There is usually a wait, and it's not the nicest looking joint, but come on, you're there for the food!  All together, great place for a quick bite!
author: Chase F.

description:
i was flipping through the reviews to see how many vietnamese people were rating this place.  having vietnamese people for my "family-in-law" and being from socal~ i'm definitely spoiled with some types of viet foods.  banh mi is something i love and often crave.. so i was happy to know there was one near by where i work

came here with @donnaho's recommendation. 

easy to find.  look for the blue (graffitied) tarp and the long line running two stores down.  i was wondering why it was so slow but by the time i hit the door - i saw only two little vietnamese women working this tiny shop.  another 20 some of us crowded inside..

ordered banh mi ga (chicken) and tofu with pate.  I'm not a big fan of pate but since donna liked it - i thought why not. :)  haha .. they use the smaller and fatter rolls, but they were still yummy.  a little chewy but i think having it the lunch rush wave might have been part of the reason.  the pate wasn't the sausage-like/ cake pate i've seen at some other places.  it's thick, chunky and greasy (in a good way).  very strong flavor.. but i guess you have to be a fan of pate to enjoy it.

the chicken one was good.  they use a "special sauce" which is mayo based.. chicken was good.  they don't put enough veggies in my opinion but it's a goopy mess of yumminess in the end.

if i was ever craving banh mi.. i'd probably come here.. i did see some other ones near by that might be worth a shot.

if anything.. the sandwiches are hella cheap. :)  that bumped up to 4.  would come back (depending on the quality of the other ones near by.. have yet to try though) and probably recommend.  

ps:  you can call in your order ahead of time.  you still end up waiting a little but not as long as a walk in.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
This truly is as good as it gets.  If you want a quick bite, this is the place to go.  If you want a cheap meal, this is the place to go.  If you just want a delicious Vietnamese sandwich, this is the place to go.

When people say a restaurant is a hole in the wall, they have no idea what this can really mean until you get a sandwich here (remodeled and less so now).  Although there are two seats in the store front, this place is really only for take-out.  Their roasted pork sandwich is one of the best sandwiches, of any type, that I have ever had.  Don't be put off by the interior and you won't regret stopping in to this shop in little Saigon.

Overall, best sandwich in the city.  Just get a sandwich and tell me I'm wrong (they're only $3.25).
author: Thomas J.

description:
I'm a college student.

A hungry one. A broke one.

I also can't cook ... or grocery shop for that matter (I always seem to get run over by others and their shopping carts. LET ME WANDER AIMLESSLY THROUGH SAFEWAY WITHOUT GETTING HURT PLEASE!).

Anyway, I heard about this place through a friend and ended up heading down there after a particularly grueling hour at the gym.

Their BBQ pork sandwich was tasty enough for me to forget about my drill sergeant-esq aerobics instructor and the five million squats he made us do that morning. 

If you find yourself in between paychecks and in need of some sustenance, dig in between your couches and find $2.50 in change. The banh mi here will hit the spot.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Am I nuts, or are they almost giving away these sandwiches for $2.75. The last two times I went there, I had my car and parking was a peace of cake.  Ordering two combo sandwiches is the hallmark item to order here. 

If you do not like extermely hot .. i mean "burn your mouth and drink 1liter of milk", then forgo the jalepinos. 

The time I went, there was a homeless asking for money to buy a soda so I just bought her one to move her along... 

Good, cheap food, but you better keep your eyes out for other things.
author: Wilson L.

description:
I found this place accidentally, after the gym yesterday, and boy was I stoked!!
So far the best Chicken Bahn Mi I have had. The price is right too.
author: Karlee D.

description:
I know, I know, how much can one really expect from a sandwich that costs $2.75?  Maybe I'm crazy but I do at least expect the sandwich I ordered!

After having my co-worker rave about these amazing, cheap Vietnamese sandwiches, I gave in one day and headed over with her to grab some lunch.  (Side note: if you are a woman, do not go here alone unless it is between 12-1 so there are sure to be enough other suits around on lunch to keep the crackheads from seriously harassing you).

So, after having my "hot ass" only briefly acknowledged by crackheads, I head inside this place and tell the woman I would like the chicken sandwich.  My friend ordered the fancy pork and stressed NO CILANTRO (she hates the stuff).  

Well, after quickly dodging crackheads on our way back to a nice area to sit and eat, we unwrap our sandwiches and find, lo and behold, there is a fancy pork sandwich WITH cilantro and a TOFU sandwich without cilantro.  Wtf???? I mean, does "chicken" sound like "tofu"? I think not.  I ate the tofu sandwich anyways but it was NOT good.  Cold, bland tofu - yuck! I voiced my disapproval to my friend who jumped to Saigon Sandwiches' defense saying that "well, there was a decent line and she just made a mistake."

Ok, ok, I'll allow for a mistake, but....

Two weeks later, after agreeing to give the place another try, they totally f$%^ed up again!!  This time there was no one else in line and when I ordered my chicken and she ordered her fancy pork sans cilantro, we annoyingly pestered them to make sure she had the right thing.  I said "that's chicken, right?" like 4 times.  My friend said it maybe twice and thought my 4 times was a bit unnecessary until...

They gave my friend the TOFU instead of the Fancy pork this time WITH cilantro!  And for good measure, they even wrote "fancy pork" on the outside of the paper wrap!! 

I swear, they just want to get rid of that nasty tofu and bank on you not checking your sandwich until you are too far away from the place to want to make the trek again thru the crackheads to exchange!! 

And although I got my chicken this time, I was decidedly disappointed and actually fairly disgusted -- the chicken quality was nonexistant; cartilege-y, fatty, and generally gross.  

Two stars for the yummy bread though and if you are so lucky as to actually get the fancy pork, it is actually quite tasty.  But don't hold your breath, you'll probably end up with that nasty cold tofu.
author: Sonia F.

description:
Oh Saigon Sandwich, I fantasize about you when I need some spice in my life....mmmmm.....

The Scene
Well folks, it is the TL....so yes, hookers, druggies, pimps...you will gladly climb over them to get in the massive line for this hole in the wall sandwich joint. There is bar window seating....but really, you come here to take the sandwiches away with you (yes, "take away," not "take out"...because you really do want to take them away and enjoy them). 

The Food
Whether you order the chicken or pork, you will be in spicy sandwich heaven.  The rolls are crunchy, but not hard, the meat is always fresh, the cilantro is just picked, the carrot adds just enough tartness, onions are always amazing,  and the jalepeno is PERFECTION! YUM!

I was going to do one of those cute "this + this=priceless".....but, when a sandwich this good costs a mere $2.75.....no cutesiness needed
author: Bianca L.

description:
FREAKING THIS PLACE HAS THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES IN THE CITY.

I eat these two at a time.  I like the meatball and the bbq pork and the combination pork... LOVE IT.

line out the door.. no joke!

i'm all over that liver pate!! :)

I live across the city, so coming out here isn't easy.. the last time I came here, I bought 12 sandwiches 2 BBQ Chicken Rice Plates and 2 Spring Roll Packs.  I realize that I'm a big fat pig, but it was a cold winter.  a very cold winter.  I was stocking up on the goodness :)
author: Steph M.

description:
I love Vietnamese food. It's my favorite but, I've always had a hard time finding good Vietnamese sandwiches. It's not just the sandwich but also the location. I want the restaurant clean, I want reasonable parking,  I want my sandwich cheap and fast, and I want to see other interesting regional foods.

Saigon Sandwich fits my entire list of picky wants.

The location is seedy enough that I can find parking within a block but, not seedy enough that I wear my flak jacket with pepper spray weapons ready.  You can see where they prepare the food and it's always clean. I  love how you can see the crock-pot full of deliciousness that they probably set up every night so that we get perfectly succulent pork. I love that they stand by their pate enough that you can also buy it in a tin and take it home. I know I know... Pate in a tin?! Might as well eat cat food! But honestly, it's good stuff.  I also like being able try other regional foods.

To sum it up, this is my type of fast food. Why go to McDonald's to satisfy the urge for crunchy savory I'm-so-hungry-must-eat-now food? (Not that McD's satisfies anything other than a guilty conscious.) Saigon Sandwich is healthier, tastier, cheaper and better for the soul!
author: Paige B.

description: This is my first official Bahn Mi, so I don't have much to compare it to, but I really enjoyed this place! Fresh ingredients and a really great sandwich at a ridiculously cheap price (about $3).  Super small place, with a decent line around lunch time, but they are fast and efficient.  I will definitely go back!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Just as a side note.  The shop continues to kick major ass??  I have branched out and am now also get a 'pork' bun to go with my order.  They are awesome, yet somehow, I keep getting an egg in mine?  I have no idea how this keeps happening..

Not sure if I keep picking the lucky daily bun, but if you want a bun, make sure to ask what is in it, as I get pork and surprises!
author: Nicole F.

description:
Yesterday, on my way to get my $2.50 pork sandwich, I had an unfortunate encounter of the homeless crack-head variety.  I'm minding my own business, walking and talking on my phone and next thing I know, I hear someone groan "ummmmmm."

Standing next to me is a homeless crack-head, licking his chapped lips, groaning at me.  

HCH: ooooo baby.  Look at you.  I bet you have a great #$%$#^.
Me: :(
HCH: *drool, drool drool* Come here baby, I'm gonna #$##$ your @$#@#.
Me: !!!
HCH: I bet your @#$#@$ is real @#$# and I'm gonna @#$#@ your @#$#@ and you're gonna like it.
Me: *looking around for people other than HCH or store to duck into, none available*
HCH: I'm gonna @#$#@ and !@#$@#$ and @$##@$ your @#$@#$@ and !@$^#$%##$ ^#@$@% ^@#$%#$ ^@#$%#.

At this point HCH has been following me for two blocks and is approximately 6 inches away from me repeatedly licking his big chapped lips.  Finally Saigon Sandwich appears and I run inside.  HCH doesn't follow.  I am greeted by smiling sandwich maker and I begin to stop feeling violated.  

Five stars for cheap, tasty sandwich at unbelievably cheap price.  Minus one star for walking through the 'Loin and being verbally raped by HCH.  

Gas rating: 5
*shuddering* I have no words.  Only gas.
author: Soo C.

description: II did not know of Saigon Sandwich before the renovation, but it looks clean and I'm diggen it.  The cute little asian ladies work the lunch hour like it ain't no thang.  The food is warm, fresh, and so damn tasty.  Although, if you are a blonde or afraid of being asked for change every 8 seconds I would not recommend  the Tenderloin.  Best of all a great sandwich only costs $3.25!
author: Alec T.

description:
I'm not a Banh Mi expert but this place makes some awesome Sandwiches.

Everything about the Banh Mi is great, the meat is flavorful and the vegetables are fresh.  My favorite is the roast chicken but the roast pork is good too.  To top it off its $3.25 which is an incredible price considering its in the city (although to get to the place need to roll through the Tenderloin). 

While they are usually fast to make the sandwiches for you, i've heard this place gets a long line at times.  I've never had that issue since i usually go during the week before lunch time.

 If you are craving for a good sandwich and are in the area, definitely pick one up (or two if you are hungry).
author: Rohit N.

description: Mmm...best banh mi's in the city.  The combination and the meatball are my faves.  I think they need to expand their shop because the lines are always so ridiculously long.  Oh well...their sandwiches are worth the wait though ;D
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Yes... this place is easy on the pocket book... but then again, ALL Vietnamese sandwich places are.  If we are gonna start to haggle over +/- 50 cents, I'm going home.

This place is nothing special.  There is NO grilled pork here.  The closest thing was the Roasted pork, which is known elsewhere as BBQ Pork.  It's just the Char-Siu... Not bad, but definitely not special.

There were way too many carrots in the sandwich, the bun was not toasted all that much(still warm though)

All and all, I was not impressed.  Luckily I didn't have to go to the store myself, seeing as how many of the other reviewers rant on how ghetto the place is.

They also did not carry fried egg rolls (Vietnamese style, or otherwise)  Even good old Lee's has more then one type of these.

Look... I have been eating these sandwiches for close to 15 years.  I'm a huge fan, but Saigon left me disappointed.

I'm going back to Cam Huong in Oakland Chinatown... that place does it right!
author: Erich R.

description: I don't know how they do it but these are some serious banh mi! I spent $9.75 and walked away with an amazing lunch for my wife and myself, try the pork meatball. Also I havent been here in years and the place is definitely much cleaner than I remember it. I was a bit sketched out after my last trip there. Ladies here is a thought charge 4.25 instead of 3.25 and use the extra $1 so that they place is nice inside, although a part of me likes the whole in the wall vibe alot.
author: D M.

description:
***NEWSFLASH***  

I just discovered the pork meatball sandwich, after it was pointed out by a fellow Yelper, and DAMN is it good.  New favorite!



Previous Review:

The cost to pleasure ratio of this spot will blow your mind.  A mere $2.50 for a sandwich, with all the ingredients tasting perfectly fresh - most likely made that morning - the ingredients I mean, the sandwich is made before your eyes.  I like to get the roast chicken or roast pork (or both!) with extra greens, meaning more cilantro and jalapen~os.  The carrot salad that accompanies the sandwich is top notch, and the slathering of mayo-like sauce mingles so nicely with the bbq juices of the meats.  Damn they're so good.

They also offer several other Vietnamese street food style dishes, all wrapped up to go - fresh veggie rolls, pork/shrimp rolls, etc.  All good.  Tons of sweets as well.  Crazy shit really - you feel like you're in a little store in Vietnam.  It's fun to eat your grub at the window seats and watch/listen to all the folks strolling in from all walks of life.  A true melting pot of a store.  Killer food, the great equalizer.

The set up is essentially take-out - there are 3 or 4 seats in the window, but they're usually blocked by the line that forms out the door.  I try to avoid the place between 12:00 and 1:30 now as it's sort of a pain in the ass.  Leave it to Yelpers to have 232 freakin' reviews on this place already.  I certainly wasn't surprised to find it on Yelp, just a little shocked at the number of writeups - crazy!
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
Ever since I gave up eating meat a while back, I thought I was also giving up Vietnamese sandwiches. But, Saigon Sandwiches has an exceptional Tofu sandwich for only $3 (like the rest of their sandwiches). I've also had a dessert of theirs which is redbeans, some green jelly stuff and coconut milk. Its all delicious. The dessert is only $2.

All of my coworkers (who do eat meat) love the place too. We ordered 12-14 sandwiches to take back to the office the last time we went. Although the line is long during lunch, we called in our order and it was mostly ready when we got there. You still need to stand in the line, but, once you are in the front, your sandwich order should be ready. 

I absolutely love this place. Its an awesome deal!
author: Joan L.

description:
I am on the hunt for the authentic banh mi, the ones made with head cheese, cha lua and pate.  I haven't found them yet.

I wonder if this place gets high ratings because it's hip to like something in the Tenderloin.  

We ordered two sandwiches, the roast chicken and the special combination.  The combination sandwich was supposed to have roast pork, pate and cha lua.  There wasn't any roast pork in the sandwich; it was roast chicken.  Not the end of the world, but it wasn't pork.  I was already disappointed when I learned that don't even make sandwiches with head cheese.  Where's the authenticity in that?

My other issue is that the pickled vegetables consisted only of carrots.  What about daikon?  It's not an expensive vegetable and really adds to the whole sandwich flavorwise and texturewise.  

Lastly, there was a little too much bread.  I guess they're going for the more bang for your buck aspect.    

The search continues...
author: W M.

description: Great place for grabbing lunch or a snack to go. Their sandwiches are fresh, tasty, and affordable. The baguettes were especially top notch, firm and crispy yet chewy and soft. Although some reviewers have questioned the cleanliness, they should take into account that this is a hole in the wall Asian 'fast food' shop in the Tenderloin! Stories I've heard about what employees at Dominoes, Burger King, and the many other fast food chains do behind the counter are way more disgusting, you just don't get to witness it all. The fact that Saigon makes the sandwiches in front of you is a plus.
author: Merri K.

description:
ive eaten my fair share of vietnamese sandwiches from all over the bay area, and the one i had here is the best ive had so far.

i got the BBQ chicken sandwich - the chicken was tender and flavorful and i loved that the bread is toasted!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Honestly, I'm not going to write an extremely long review on this place. WHY? BECAUSE..... 

When I eat their sandwich, I am SPEECHLESSS!!!!!

FYI: I always get the chicken sandwich with pate and extra jalepenos. mmmm YUM... and the bread is to DIE for! 

Speaking of this sandwich makes me want to drive to SF for it and drive back down for school..

If you've never been here, you are CRAZY. Hurry up and GO!!!!!
author: Mai H.

description:
In order for me to enjoy something on its own merits, absolutely no research can be done beforehand. For example, the movie "Derailed" was utterly ruined because I read a single interview and inferred the entire plot from one question. 

Unfortunately, I researched this place.  Everyone raves about it and it took me 2 months to actually try it. So I'm salivating and expecting to maybe, just maybe, see heaven when I take a bite of this reputed amazing sandwich: meh. D'oh!

The price is cheap but a loaf of bread and meat isn't that much either. :::shrug::  It's just a sandwich to me. Bread, meat. Sigh, maybe I'm just not a sandwich type of girl.
author: Yan E.

description: Omg, the sandwiches are the bomb diggity! The tofu one is my favorite though with the jalapenos and the special sauce :)
author: Julie Z.

description: Oh my gawd!  This is one of the best deals in the city.  Cheap.  Fast.  Easy.  Filling.  Delicious!  Recommend the Xiu Mai (pork meatballs) Sandwich.  There may be a line, but it moves ridiculously fast.  Do it!
author: Lyz L.

description: No doubt the best vietnamese sandwich i've ever tried, I got a chicken sandwich, but the pork and one with pate (duck liver) was really goooood too! The meat was really tender and juicy, and the portion of vegetable in ratio to the meat was just right (that's important to me because i don't like it when the taste of veggies overcome the taste of meat) Service was really quick and i'm sure they make their sandwich fresh. I wouldda give them 3 stars for that, but the snacks variety was ridiculous!!! the che xung xa was sooo good, and they also sell other vietnamese dessert too, a must try in san francisco!
author: Lizi F.

description:
The hype, the buildup, and then the payoff.... 

Yes, Saigon Sandwiches are that good.

I ordered two sandwiches for myself because I know vietnamese sandwiches aren't the biggest.  Man, was I surprised when I opened my roasted chicken and pork meatball up.  Fat amounts of meat, carrots, cilantro, and some peppers in a toasted roll.

I love how the meat and vegetables are marinated.  Although I felt the chicken needed a little more kick with some salt, the meatball rocked.

I ripped through the chicken, then 3/4 through the meatball before puttering out.  I didn't want to put myself in a coma at work.  But that last piece made for a nice snack later on!

The line at Saigon stretches outside.  The lady at the counter takes orders going down the line like shes at Wall Street.  Call ahead and you can have your order ready when you arrive.

2 sandwiches x $2.75 = One happy hombre!
author: Sam T.

description:
cheap & deliciously filling? WOW

i am a fan.. My coworkers brought me back a pork vietnamese sandwich...and i devoured it.  The bun was crisp on the outside, filled with moist, hot deliciousness on the inside.  The carrots, radishes were pickled and warm, the pork was OH SO GOOD. it was still warm, and very moist, tender, flavorful. 

Sandwich doesn't look very big, but it's filled up with the good stuff, so you'll actually be full...i realized that other vietnamese places give you a big ass bun, but not much filling. 

i gave my coworker $5, she gave me a dollar in change.  

Fabulous.
author: Lulu C.

description:
Thank you Saigon Sandwiches for restoring my faith in Vietnamese food in the city. 

Since moving here from the South Bay, I've been disappointed time and time again. I've been boycotting any Vietnamese food in the city to wait til I visit my dear mother in San Jose to get my fix. But my Vietnamese food Nazi ways has gotten the best of me. My body and wallet are getting weak from a lack of fish sauce and MSG in my diet. 

Figured it's time to give Vietnamese food in the city another chance. Luckily I ended up here, a place that reminds me of downtown San Jose 15 years ago, when all the Banh Mi shops were located in filthy spaces the size of my room, with crowds of customers shouting orders to people behind the counter. I ordered in Vietnamese and was actually understood, instead of being met with the usual blank stare from most Chinese-run Viet joints in SF. It put me in such a good mood that I didn't care about the 3 old ladies who cut in front of me to order enough sandwiches to feed an entire apartment complex.

The sandwich: almost the way I like it. Maybe the pork could've been juicier, but so far it's the best in town. It had just the right amount of meat and vegetables and the pickled veggies weren't too sweet or sour. Also bought a roll of cha lua for $2.50, which should provide me with a week's worth of homemade Banh Mi Cha Lua. I'm gonna be hitting up this place every chance I get now.
author: Victoria N.

description: Really, best place for a cheap sandwich to go.
author: D. C.

description:
Hands down the best sandwich in SF and without a doubt the best sandwich I've ever had for its price. 

I've had every sandwich on the menu and absolutely love them all (especially the chicken) except the tofu, which is all right, just not that great. I've gone here dozens of times and it's always so incredibly good.

Just avoid it around 12-1:30 because the line is always absurdly long without fail.
author: Phatalie J.

description: I don't profess to be an expert but I've had Lee's, Thahn Huong and Dakao's and hand's down give me Saigon. They crank it out for two old ladies and have gotten a lot better with the young lady taking orders and running the cash register. As far as cleanliness it's alot better since the re-model. The health card score was a 95 last time I was there in July so hopefully that's a good sign. No matter I'd have to be in the death throes of food poisoning to stop coming here. Even at the recently inflated price of $3.25 it is the bomb.
author: David C.

description: Yummy Banh Mi. Cheap and fast. Don't let the line deter you, these ladies will move it along expeditiously. This is what a sandwhich shop should be.
author: Christian A.

description:
I'm no expert in Vietnamese sandwiches, but is paper all over the floor, boxes and debris everywhere, and a cooler stuffed so full it would take an excavating crew to get to the back part of the deal?  I didn't see any evidence of health risks but his is the most cluttered food service establishement I have seen to date in San Francisco.

Still, I can see why it's endearing if you like that sort of thing.  About average for taste, a bit cheaper than most ($2.25 for the sandwiches), very fast service, and the old ladies are friendly.  Plus, there's a lot of other pre-prepared stuff stacked on the counter you can buy.
author: Gil S.

description:
No ambiance, no eating space, cash only, not the safest neighborhood, long line usually, but INCREDIBLE SANDWICHES!!!   

I grew up with lunch from here, my dad when he had his office downtown would on occasion send someone to get us chicken sandwiches here........and between then and the last time that I went, in May 2006, the sandwiches have NOT changed, and the price has gone up only .25 in at least 12 years to the harsh price of $2.50!!

I re-stumbled upon it in May, when one day after a night of drinking, my friend was driving me back to my car, we passed it.  When I mentioned it, he said that he too loved it!  My amazement at the fact that someone else in this big city knew of my favorite divey Vietnamese Sandwich place!! After getting my car, I called my friend Leon to pick up his car, and on the way to getting his car, we stopped and had a sandwich, as he too had heard about the restaurant.  And that is how I was reunited with my Saigon Sandwich.   

I don't know about anything they have other than the sandwiches.........super moist roasted chicken on a french roll, with some sauce, and some random shredded carrots, cilantro, jalepeno and veggies that don't detract from the chicken, served toasted.  I don't have anything else to say other than the fact that there is a LINE out the door any weekday lunch hour should be testament enough for you to get one yourself SOON!
author: Denise B.

description: In the mood for some killer banh mis? This is the place. It's a little chaotic since you have to order first, then wait to pay once you get the food. Tends to get a little cramped since the place can only accommodate 6 people at a time. Usually a wait but definitely worth it! Love their pate.
author: Danny K.

description:
Oh Saigon Sandwiches, why do you taste so good?  That cilantro gives it the perfect zip.  The stir fry is sizzilin good.  The baguettes...nice and fresh...I feel guilty for saying this, but Saigon Sandwiches makes me think "maybe the French colonialization of VietNam was worth it?  Then I feel horrible.  But it's so good...and TWO BUCKS?!  For San Francisco, that's amazing.

Just don't look at the slimy stuff that's...all over the store.  And...uh...don't breathe.  You'll be fine.
author: Alyssa O.

description:
You know we're in a recession when banh mi at Saigon Sandwich have broken the $3.00 mark!

I feel like a grumpy old man... "Back in my day those sandwiches were only $2." 

Sigh...

Still 5 stars but not worth the wait if there's a long line (which is generally between noon and 1:30)... Lots of other passable good sandwich options in the vicinity.
author: Brian H.

description: The word spread in our office that someone was picking up the famous Saigon sandwiches for lunch. It quickly spread and  of course I jumped on it. I ordered the tofu one as I was on my trial vegetarian week. Who would have thought tofu bahn mi could be so heavenly. Juicy with just the amount of pickled veggies and jalapeño
author: Sam S.

description:
YUM YUM YUM!  Iwas introduced to this Vietnamese Bahn Mi (sandwich) place by a Vietnamese friend - that friendship may no longer exist, but good memories remain when I come to this place - I travel from San Mateo to get these sandwiches.  There is no replacement.

I love to pick one of everything on the counter while the ladies prepare my combo bahn mi - so delicious - we get like 2 days of food for about $30 - that's 2 lunches and 2 dinners.  amazing.  prepare to defend your place in line, some of the regulars can get a little pushy, but its part of the experience.  

say "cam ahn" when you leave - that's thank you in Vietnamese - they laugh when it comes out of this white girl's mouth but are happy too-
author: Michelle P.

description: Cheap, friendly, and not at all bad. However, really nothing mind-blowing. It's a solid staple, but overrated.
author: Sandra S.

description: There are 1257 review before me, but I am writing to confirm that the sandwiches here are SO delicious!  I was a naiive fan of Lees until I stepped foot into this tiny store.  So good. So good.
author: Jessica C.

description:
best, bahn mi xiu mai i have EVERRRRRRR had. honestly, it is like a MUST TRY.

they have since remodeled the place since my mom brought me here years and years ago, price has gone up a tad, but overall a good sandwich. i think the other special meat combo sandwich is good, but EVERYBODY who even walks in here must try the xiu mai. 

it doesnt sound very special, but this is the only place where they marinate their meat like this, thus the end product as the great tasting sandwich. looking at it it seems somewhat plain, and the sandwich doesnt seem all that big compared to a few other places, but i dont care if it costs 4 dollars i would still come back to buy it.

i was searching for the name of this place because i wanted some today and i always seem to get lost around there, all i remembered was that it was near a kfc in the tenderloin and i just circled around all the one way streets until i found it, so i might as well review it too.

parking is a b**ch, i double parked at the bus stop right in front and almost got a ticket numerous times lol, but yea i know, its my fault
author: Calvin T.

description:
I come here every now and then.

The sandwiches are pretty good, but like everyone, I compare it to other locations. Overall the taste is good. The roast pork sandwich with everything (mayo, pate, jalapenos, pickled carrots, parsley) always seems to satisfy me. Bread is toasted nicely while the meat is juicy (most times).

Nice cheap eat if you're in the area.
author: Tim S.

description:
In my dreams places like this one franchise and make the Ghetto'd poor healthy and safe from fast food.

It is  just a sandwich shop with lot's of other goodies on foam trays wrapped with clingwrap and imported sodas.

Affordable, friendly and abundant YEAH,
ad
author: Adam F.

description:
There's something about small hole in the wall places....you just know it's gotta be good....especially when the line is out the door.  You just know the place is good when the inside looks like a dog kennel....electrical wires running everywhere....patches of unpainted wall....small nooks and crannies that would make perfect homes for cockroaches and rats.

You just know...it's gotta be good!!

Especially when there's only 1 asian lady working behind the counter...making the sandwichs...and handling all the money...without a glove!!  Oh man....it's gotta be good......i'm drooling by this point.

And you know how else you know it's gotta be good??  When, despite all i've described: dirty store, run down, uncleaned in 5 years, lady handling money and making sandwichs at the same time, coughing, no gloves....despite all of these grade F health violations, there are white people waiting in line!!!  And the asian people are asking THEM if the sandwiches are good.

Oh man....i'm ready.

I ordered the roast chicken and the combo for myself, and another ham and pate combo for my friend.

MMM MMM MMM!!! Oh it was good!!!  The butter...the mayo....the pate....and you couldn't even taste the flavor of money!!  And all 3 for $8!!!
author: Tadd L.

description: I want you to take your hand and drag it between the seat cushions on your couch, now go look under the seat in the car; did you happen to scrape up $2.50?  Once you pick out the lint from your new wealth drag your broke ass down to Saigon Sandwiches and order a sandwich.  The place isn't clean, it isn't big, and they don't have a vast menu, but they make one hell of a sandwich.  I am envious of the people that have an office near by, this is the ultimate cheap and easy lunch.
author: Michael M.

description:
On my second date with my boyfriend (when they are still nice and sweet) he came over to my job during my lunch break and brought me a sandwich from Saigon. I was very skeptical. The wrapping did not convince me at first. But once I tried it... Wow! It was awesome. I remembered it being chicken. Uhmmm Chicken goodness.

I was hooked.

But then he took me to the establishment where the magic took place...
In the TL.

I was shocked. It's a hole in the whole. If you walk too fast you will miss it.

The best word to describe it: Sticky.
The floor is sticky. The chairs are sticky. The counter is sticky.

I'm not a neat freak, but this place could use a nice clean-up.

Until recently it would have gotten 5 stars, but...
Prepare yourselves for this horrifying tale:

My hubby and I visited Saigon (at my request). It was cold and raining.
I sat down (on the little sticky chair) and waited for my Meatball Goodness. When my hubby put it down on the little counter I couldn't help but smile (hello my darling!). But when I unwrapped my sandwich and searched for green peppers (I don't like them and my hubby orders it w/o them, but sometimes the little rascals manage just fine to get in there) I was shocked to see A HAIR! AHHHHH! It was very short, but a hair nonetheless. My hubby grabbed and threw it away as I stared horrified. An here is the moment of reassurance. When I know for sure how much he loves me and adores me: He took a bite of my sandwich where the hair was! I have to marry this man, I thought.

Anyhow, I'm forever scarred.

I do not know if I will be back after this.

It may take some time...

Meatball sandwich, I will forever miss you :**(
*************************************************************************
1/30/08

I'm happy to report that I've been back many times since and there were no hairs in my sandwich! Yay!

So glad I'm back. I love love LOVE my meatball sandwich!
author: Miss E.

description:
I have to say that I've had a sandwich here everyday for like a week so far. And I live down the peninsula. And I had to deal with crackheads hitting on me and one even telling me that he wanted to lick my toes (ewww). And I even bought a sandwich from Lee's across the street because I thought Saigon was closed and when I saw they were still open, I went in and bought a sandwich anyway, trying to hide my Lee's plastic bag. 

Yes, this place is just that damn good.

Eventually, if I keep on going here, I may get sick of it and just not want to go here for a while. 

I doubt that's going to happen....

FYI: they are open until 6pm Mon-Sat and until 5pm on Sundays!
author: Pippi L.

description:
*drool*

Meatball sandwich with extra pate

*slobber slobber*

All for under $3.00

*happy as a clam*
author: Deanna T.

description:
The place for Vietnamese sandwiches. This is it. 

A friend recommended this place to me recently after insisting it was the best around. Now, I love these sandwiches and was quite content settling for Lee's in various locations around the Yay Area.  But as I learned, Saigon Sandwiches takes it to another level entirely. 

Neighborhood is a little ratty. Like it matters though when your craving for banh mi burns like fire. Is it not worth sidestepping hobos and plugging your nose of fresh urine for an order of three $2 vietnamese sandwiches? I think so. How would I describe the decor...you feel like you're somewhere ordering SuperLotto tickets. The lady behind the counter is very sweet and a pro, even doing the glove-on-the-hand to take $$ move. God bless her. 

I love the pork + pate sandwiches. It is a genius combination. Apparently, there are lines out the door in peak times but when I went right at 5pm, it was just me.
author: Michael S.

description:
After hearing just about every member of my family rave about this spot, I was determined to give it a try. It's located in the Tenderloin District, so you'll have to pick your way past winos and panhandlers. It's TOTALLY WORTH IT. I ordered the pork sandwich with all the fixings. The bread was light, the pork was thin cut, moist, and very tasty. I loved the toppings - carrots in some sort of vinaigrette, fresh cilantro, and hot peppers. And that mayo mix...DELISH! I wish they had one of these in Boston!

Note: I'd recommend you take the sandwich to go. The shop itself is of the seedy-convenience-store variety.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
Wow.

I first had bahn mi thanks to my wife.  She is first generation Vietnamese from Garden Grove, CA.  I don't claim to be an expert on vietnamese food but let's say when we visit Mama Tran I get super excited despite the fact I have no idea what anyone is saying or what is going on half the time.  I'm there to eat.  Those are my credentials.

That being said this place has some really tasty sandwiches.  They have 5 items on the menu which is always a great sign to me... it means they do those things well.  The bread is great.  The french loafs have that great crusty outside but they aren't so hard they tear up the roof of your mouth.  I recommend the roast pork sandwich and the pate sandwich.  Better yet, I recommend the roast pork with pate on one sandwich.

Lunch time is super busy.  I recently learned you can call in your order.  After waiting in line for 30 minutes, it's worth the call.  It is in a dodgy part of town and the small galley kitchen these two old ladies work in isn't the cleanest or well lit but try it once and chances are you'll look past all this.
author: Henk V.

description:
This is probably the best Vietnamese sandwich shop in San Francisco. Don't mind that shop looks the storage room of abandon factory, the sandwiches are great. The sandwiches cost around $3.25 and is about half the size of Lee's Sandwiches across the street. 

If you're a first timer, I'd recommend the Meatball sandwich -- it's has a sweet pork flavor and is super juicy! If you're into dry-cut deli meats, I'd recommend the Special Combination sandwich.

Other quick tips: 
If you're driving here, there's usually metered parking spots available, but the shop is in one of the sketchy areas of Tenderloin. Also, it's cash-only and beware that during peak lunch hours the lines do get long and the two ladies that make the sandwiches can be slow, but it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Kao S.

description:
Cheap and tasty! I especially like their special which has a seasoned pate. Their bread is light and crusty. Yum!

Conclusion: YES!
author: Daniel K.

description:
Believe the hype!! One of the best sandwiches I have ever had, and for just $3... the absolute best deal in town. 

Went for the first time yesterday... I already want to go back for round 2. 

5 Stars
author: Blake W.

description:
Ok. 3 Stars. A solid 3. I would go 3.5 if I could. I mean, it's a good sandwich. It's cheap. It's fresh. And it's quick. Solid. The folks are friendly, and you can walk and sit in an approved area near a government building. Great lunch.

But c'mon people. A friend, who happens to be a reviewer here (you know who you are!) once told me this was the "best sandwich in the world that ANYone has ever had. Period".

For real? Honestly? Like I said, It's solid. GREAT value. But people: Perhaps, and I'm just guessing here, but perhaps, there's a little bit of excitement and assumed edginess in really really really liking the sandwiches from the hole-in-the-wall place? I like 'em. I dig 'em. But I sleep at night knowing that I will probably have a better sandwich at some point in my life. I hope I will...

Update: I didn't want to name names. I didn't want to stoop. I prefer, as those who know me (and know me they should) to remain in a neighborhood known as the "Moral Highground". Great views, ample parking, and a lightness of being that permeates the air. But Telstar L would not allow such sublime peace. No. To war he prefers. Yes, to war. So be it. Let me say this, during the waning hours of the ides of March. I propose to you all a question. In the purest sense of the term, could one sandwich truly be the pinnacle of the art? Could no other be expected to exceed it's sandwichosity (look it up) such that it remains in this day as the example for all others. Could any one Yelper be so ignorant as to ignore dozens of years of historical evidence to the contrary about such statements of fact (need we be reminded of the unfortunate words of a former head of the U.S. Patent Office)?

I should hope not. I should certainly hope not.
author: Jordan K.

description:
This place is solid. Let me clarify that I've only had the tofu sandwich, but it's really good. This place is also a bit sketchy, which adds some "secret hidden spot" appeal. The bread and veggies are fresh and those peppers they use keep me coming back. They also have every variety of mung bean product under the sun. Sweet! I picked up a bag of taro chips (potato need not fear this inferior root veggie) and some Nak Nak which describes itself as "choco tasty cream", and boy is it. My sandwich was only 2 bucks, no tax! Cant beat that.

Update: Just noticed today that some of the mung bean products are made by the Hung Phat Bakery. I wonder if this an Asian bakery or an African American one.

Update part 2: I no longer go here ever. Had a disturbing realization that the place just is not clean. Dirty prep area and handling everyybody's money and then making sandwiches without washing is  kind of gross.

Update 3: Increased rating back to 4 stars. They seem to have cleaned up the shop and food prep area substantially. Much appreciated.
author: Marky M.

description:
Yesyesyes on their tofu sandwich, just make sure to get it sans cilantro, that shit is nasty. 

They've got tons of weird asian stuff to eat too, I just don't know what most of it is. 

Most sandwiches are like $2.50 and they are big and good. The service is fast. I love this place.
author: Slasha S.

description:
This place has what you can Google as 'cheap eats'. The $3 pork sandwich is out of this world. Even less than what you pay for a large sandwich (burger) at McD, or JiB or BK. Amazing. And the Saigon Sandwiches taste tons better. Double tons better. 

I will be a repeat customer for sure. And by repeat I don't mean burping.
author: Heather O.

description:
Dear Nice little lady with short hair behind the counter of goods:

Thank you for your pleasant smile every time I walk in here.
Thank you for putting up with my indecisive self.

Nice Lady: Hi, what would you like?
Me: Hi, may I have a chicken, no wait, a steam pork and roast pork, no wait, a chicken, no I mean a siu mai sandwich please..
Nice Lady: Do you want jalapenos in it? 
Me: Why yes I would, I would indeed! How do you know I like it hot, hot, hot
Nice Lady just smiles

Well Nice Lady, that's why I love you..and your prices are always very reasonable! I just want to buy everything you have set out wrapped in plastic. Also the fridge full of viet desserts and the soy bean milk in the smaller case. I love your little establishment and hope to feed my future children with your food. Thanks!

P.S. 
I am sorry that I found out you had TIP jar so late in life. I will promise not to forget the jar next time.

Love,
H to the W
author: H To The W.

description:
This place have great sandwiches....all kind sweet deserts that I love.
It worth the wait.....if you you time that is.
Enjoy......
author: Kim L.

description: You know the place is good when you are still thinking about the delicious mouth watering viet sandwich you had and your 100 miles away. Well i got the chicken sandwich with peppers because i like spicy and it was incredible, the flavor, the texture, the crispy, and the tender. Sandwiches come in chicken pork and combination. they are i still believe $3.50 for one. But this has got to be the best place for viet sandwiches in the city because I tried other places and they do not even compare. Yummy food makes happy people. :)
author: Mindy X.

description:
Wearing my bullet proof vest and carrying an extra mag for my Glock, I ventured into the Tenderloin for one serious Banh Mi. 

Saigon Sandwiches is a solid Vietnamese Banh Mi shop cranking out tasty sandwiches of BBQ pork, chicken, meatballs, ...etc. The lady will usually ask you if you want spicy and if your answer is "yes" then you'll find a few slices of spicy chili peppers in your sandwiches. There are other prepackaged Vietnamese offerings from spring rolls to desserts near the window. " 

If you've ever felt liked you've been robbed at "Out the Door" for one of their Banh Mi sandwiches, then you'll truly appreciate your ability to stretch the dollar at this joint.
author: Dennis L.

description: I was super excited to get my hands on a banh mi. If you've read any of my other reviews, nyc does not have good viet sandwiches. Well when I walked in, I saw that they remodeled. Hm... the decor hasn't changed much but it sure looked a lot cleaner. I ordered the combo which is what I always get. At first bite I was confused. It's like the cleaned the place and cleaned out all the flavor too. I always said the dirtier, the better the food tastes. It's a real pity. 3000 miles for some dry pork pieces? What happened to the mystery meat (you know the pink one)? Sad to say but Saigon Sandwich is no longer my fav banh mi shop. I'm converting to the shop on Irving
author: Vanessa T.

description:
I Love you Saigon Sandwiches.

The one good thing that came out of the French "occupation" of Vietnam was the baguette, and maybe the coffee.  If you haven't had a Vietnamese sandwich (bunmi) go to Saigon sandwiches and get in line.  Get the fancy pork or chicken sandwich.  Who would have thought carrots and cillantro belong in a sandwich?
author: Nopadon W.

description:
Yelp rates 3 stars as A-OK- that's pretty much Saigon Sandwich.  

 I have a thing with people saying that Saigon sandwich is more Vietnamese or authentic than other sandwich places in the area, but folks, just because a place is dingy and small and mom and pop-ish doesn't mean its more authentic.  I've eaten at the all the other places people put down and they taste pretty authentic to me.  

Ironically, The hype probably is by people who prefer more "westernized" sandwiches. The bread is from wheat flour only, which is not what Vietnamese french bread is about .  filling is good, but veggies are stingy.  They seem to only do carrots and cilantro vs other places that will do carrots, daikon, cilantro, and cucumber.

pretty good sandwich, but don't believe the hype-  make your own decision!
author: T. N.

description:
Ive been to quit a few Vietnamese Sandwich shop and no one rivals this place for a vegetarian Vietnamese sammy. I haven't tried the meat or pate or other gross animal roll, but the vegetarian is the goodness that will get you to come back for more.

I have to stop by this place when Im in town no matter how long I stay. This is by far the best Vietnamese vegetarian sandwich shop in the west coast.
author: Siavash G.
