description: My family recently came to visit me from Ohio with an empty suitcase to fill with Vietnamese sandwiches from this place and steamed buns from Louie's dim sum in Chinatown. That's how good the sandwiches are at Saigon Sandwich!
author: Mimi K.

description: YUM - one of the best banh mi sandwiches I've had in SF!  It may be better than the sandwiches in LA! :)  Getting to Saigon Sandwich is probably not the safest but it sure has delicious Vietnamese sandwiches!!! The bread is just perfectly toasted and the chicken meat is super moist and warm...just fills my tummy with joy.  I don't recommend walking the streets around it alone...it's kinda scary. Oh and props to my fellow yelpers for recommending this place.
author: MyGirl L.

description: I found this tiny hole-in-the-wall while wandering back through the Asian Heritage street festival taking place.  I'm a huge fan of bahn mi, and there was a line out the door -- even with plenty of street vendors serving the festival -- so I figured that it must be good.  I got the combination sandwich with several meats and pate, the usual salad of carrots, cucumber, jalapeno slices and perhaps a bit of mayo and some other kind of sauce.  It was delicious and the taste made up for the fact that I had to wait about 15 min for it (busy day, and due to a lack of a number system I got skipped a few times).
author: Yea A.

description: eugh. Get in my belly, you delicious little sandwiches. Roast pork is my fave...next to the lady who says "next plz" at least 3x in a row.
author: Angela K.

description:
Best Banh Mi I've ever had. I used to get them on Clement because it's close to home, but now I'm finding I can't go because it's not as good as Saigon's. The chicken is a safe choice, but I think the pork is the best. Not fatty, perfectly seasoned/marinated/whatever. The dressing, mayo, cilantro, carrots, pickled radish...all of it is so amazingly perfect. I want one now.

Even though the sandwich tastes refreshing and light, it definitely fills you up, and it's a total steal at $3! Warning though: if you like being able to feel your lips, remove the jalapenos. Those suckers are hot! Even for this girl who loves her kimchee and Sriracha sauce.

I've never gone into the actual establishment, because I am a very lucky girl and my boss, who runs his second business near here, sometimes brings us lunch from here. He's also Vietnamese so I expect nothing but the best quality when he's in charge of our lunch order from here, and we are never disappointed.
author: Sachi T.

description:
one spot that i would give a limb for. not even joking. the tofu sandwiches (as i'm sure all of the sandwiches are) are amazing.  i can't even begin to describe how they good they are. there's a lee's right down the street, but don't sell yourself short. these are the best vietnamese sandwiches you will ever have, short of going to vietnam. i'm telling you.

i'm going to go right now actually.
author: Melinda J.

description: GODDAMN braces. I couldn't enjoy my sandwich cuz I just got my braces. However, i still found a way to devour these delicious little things. I loved the chicken one the best even tho i felt like it could've used more veggies. The bread was way too hard for my stupid teeth, but that's probably only because i'm totally teeth handicapped :(
author: Emily T.

description:
Doesn't the super long line during lunch speak for itself?  I would say this is one of the best places in SF to get a vietnamese sandwich (Banh MI)  I tried every sandwich they have and they're all so yummy! I'm salivating while just writing this review! I think this is what I'll have for lunch today!

FOOD - 5 YUMMO
SERVICE - 5 Very nice vietnamese ladies always very nice to me
DECOR - 3 it's a tiny hole in the wall sandwich shop but the food more then makes up for it!
author: Vince T.

description: I dont find this place good anymore.. They put too much liquid veggy  that causes the bread to be too soggy. Also the bread is too hard for my liking. I used to this place is good not anymore.
author: Aniko N.

description:
Tis a dilemma. What to rate something that does not exist at home? What  to rate something I've never had done right before? What if I later regret my superlative ratings due to a refinement of my currently-newbie banh mi tastes?

Oh efff that noise. 

SO we find Larkin and Eddy and park on the street. The neighborhood street people and junkies are just chillin in the daytime.  And I buy a bunch of chicken's and pork's and one special one for myself. The counter lady uses gloves to handle cash and then off them to make your sandwich. +1 for sure.

It was a religious experience, I swear up and down. The perfectly spiced tender meats, pate and sauces, pared with the ideal chew of the French bread.

Watch out for the chili's though, they're like fire and add just enough deadly heat one of the best sandwiches I've ever had, for less than $3 or not. May God help you if you happen to bite into the seeds. 

If you're ever, EVR in SF, do stop by and get a banh mi dac biet (special?) and watch your sandwich paradigms get smashed, one loving bite at a time. eff the rest in the Bay or Socal or Hawaii or whatever, this is the best.
author: Gary H.

description:
Consistently delicious and filling for less 4$. Canned beverage for $1. My go to banh mi spot. Saigon Sandwich can get a bit chaotic during lunch time so steadily advance towards the counter and know what you want before you get there. Line roughly forms down the middle of the entry, and people wait for their sandwiches along the sides of the entry. Bring cash and be ready to eat elsewhere as there are two cramped seats.

I usually get the meatball or roast pork. Go for the fancy pork if liver is your thing.
author: Adam K.

description:
Located only three clicks out of the 'Loin, this eatery receives six stars...as seven is not possible on Yelp.
Unbelievably tasty sandwiches. One fancy pork, one roasted pork, and one tofu, add a trio of mouth-watering Spring Rolls, two sodas, and the total came to 12 bucks. For those not OK with the spicy stuff, remember to request that the naplam-hot chilies be left off. The women working in the small, cluttered space, were all friendly and patient even though the line extended out the door. Definitely worth the wait. Count the hooker trannies as the walk by!
author: Mr. S.

description:
mmm...tofu.
I am a tofu addict.
I am a vegan protien junkie.

Saigon feeds my need, and for only two dolars.

Actually. $2.25, but that's a recent development. I think I can live with it.
author: Penelope C.

description:
Best $2.50 I ever spend on lunch. 

The ladies behind the counter are super nice too - when you know what you want when it's your turn. :)
author: Jill T.

description:
What you should expect if you have never been:

Cash only
No seating
Line out the door
DELICIOUS SANDWICH
CHEAP
selection of interesting and classic beverages
author: Joshua S.

description: Dirty! Dirty! Dirty!  I don't know how this place passes a health inspection.  It looks like nothing has been cleaned in years.  There is probably something living in that glass cooler.  Sandwich is poorly constructed, it looks like everything was jammed in the sandwich. The Vietnamese sandwich from Hoang Dat is so so much better!
author: Uy D.

description:
I've been hearing about this place for months and finally got a chance to try it for lunch last week.

My roast pork sandwich was delicious and at an amazing $3, the price cannot be beat for such a filling and relatively healthy lunch.

There was a long line just after 1 pm - but I dug the efficient system of two lines - one to order and one to pick up your sandwich as they were shelled out.
author: Abby W.

description: Best. Banh. Mi. Ever. Hilarious ordering system (which is also particularly effective) and the sandwiches are ridiculously good. One of the first places I ate when moving to SF.
author: Aaron A.

description: The pate was absolutely delicious.  But why do Saigon peepz feel the need to put sugar in everything? Would've been an even more excellent sammich had there not been sweet stuff.  Good breakfast/brunch option and is cheap.
author: Thanh P.

description:
Sweet Jesus, that was heavenly.

Pork,  cilantro, hot pepper, shredded carrots, pickled cucumber, mayo, and onion compactly nested in a toasted crispy bun.  

The pork is untrimmed, but you deal.  That's what makes it taste so magical.  

I recommend washing it down with a tall can of young coconut juice.  

There's also lots of packaged Korean junk food, but it's all in slightly sticky packaging --- fend for yourselves.
author: Katie T.

description: Overrated in my humble opinion.  The price is right, but when it comes to pork, you get what you pay for as Joe Gannon will tell you.  It had bubbles in it that made me think of eyeballs in my stomach after I inhaled the sandwich.  Kind of bossy around Saigon Sanwhich too.  They should watch Clean House too, the place is so cluttered.
author: Jack M.

description:
Holy Crap! These were so good! Don't be a fool just go to this place! 

I had the tofu sandwich my boyfriend had a chicken one. We both were completely blown away by how delicious and light these little gems of heaven were. Plus they were only $3 each! Why are you not there yet!?
author: M B.

description:
What to add?  Saigon sandwiches sets the standard by which all other Vietnamese sandwiches in the city are judged.  Top o' the heap.  Do yourself a favor and try the special combo.  

Special kudos to the ladies behind the counter for maintaining their smiles while making these masterpieces all day.
author: Michael W.

description:
If you were to look up "hole in the wall" in the San Francisco dictionary (what a good idea! someone should make one!), you'd find a picture and listing for this place.

I got two 3$ sandwiches because theet idea of spending 3$ on a meal in San Francisco just felt weird to me, but I could havea easily been filled up with one, and maybe next time i'll get a sandwich and one of the other items by the counter.

The sandwiches were ridiculous. So much delicious flavor.

Yes, there was a page full of healthcode posted righ ton the entrance, but it's part of the charm at a place like this.

Generally, the chain restaurants will fill you up for the cheapest, yet I often opt to pay a little more for the same amount of better quality food at an independent restaurant.

Yet this will fill you up with better food for less than Subway! I almost want to run into all of the Subways in the Tenderloin and yell at them to get the 3$ Saigon Sandwich than the 5$ footlong.
author: Mark A.

description: I'm biased since I live in Oakland where there's more than enough cheap Vietnamese delis so paying $3.50-$4/sandwich is actually expensive to me. But now I can see why there's a line out the door - the meat is good, they don't add mayonnaise (there's some pork gelatinous sauce they add instead), and although the sandwich is smallish and the bread isn't as crispy/soft, there's a lot more in there than you'd expect.
author: Leily P.

description:
These sandwiches are so chock full of fillings, its great authentic stuff.

While I've had better pate elsewhere, this place is the place to go for fantastic cheap sandwiches.

If theres a line, you yell out your order one after the next person and stand there until they call your sandwiches, and pay.
 
Recommended: Dac Biet sandwich and Chicken sandwich.

Heard the meatball is good, but I've never tried...i'm a creature of habit.
author: Momu T.

description:
I got reacquainted with this sandwich shop a few months ago when I moved back into San Francisco. The place hasn't changed, it still serves one of the best tasting Vietnamese sandwiches in the city for a messily $3 bucks!

The shop uses thick French loaves which are split, toasted, and then stuff with your choice of roast pork, tofu , meatball, chicken, jambon, or pate and also an assortment of pickled carrots, cilantro, jalapenos and some white vegetable that I don't know the name of (it doesn't matter because it doesn't deter from the flavour). 

I've had the roast pork, the chicken and the tofu, all of which were delicious, and, though, I absolutely loved the roast pork, I found a new favourite which is their tofu sandwich. The tofu is marinated and slightly crispy, but not watery! 

I also suggest you try the other items offered at the shop such as the Vietnamese peanuts, the pork buns, and the mini meals wrapped up in cellophane. The peanuts are coated in coconut and are addicting. The pork buns are not what you might expect. Instead of finding a red sweet sauce with BBQ pork inside, the Vietnamese bun has marinated pork with mushrooms, rice vermicelli, and half a hard boiled egg. The cellophane wrapped meals are just darn good. Be careful and try not to spill the fish sauce (provided in each wrapped meal) on you. Trust me on this.

The rest of the products are geared more towards a Vietnamese/Asian palate -my ex-husband (Vietnamese) loved all the jellied grass drinks, sweet coconut pastries, etc., but I did not.

Food is good, cheap, and fast.
author: Audrey S.

description: Absolutely amazing! Don't even think about, question, ponder it...just go...NOW!!!  We need a place like this in Boston.
author: Nate C.

description:
Excellent viet sandwiches!!!   The prices are still cheap/decent.  Tiny place on larkin, but very famous.  Lunch lines are out the door as ppl wait to get their orders ready (all the civic center workers). 

The 2 ladies behind the counters knows to take ur orders and money.  No talk nonsense.  Once in a while, you'll hear the 2 ladies yell at each other, arguing in vietnamese.  even in front of customers who probably have no idea what they're saying but are amused at the scene.  =P 

My fave is Siu Mai (no peppers)!!!  A must when you come here.  Serve quick when its still hot/warm.   Also they have alot of other small plates, desserts in the fridge, and can drinks.   

Only to-go, i think there's 2 stools by the window. but everyone comes in and takes it away.  My routine is my bf drives the car, then i get off and buys it as he double-parks or circles the block.
author: Ju D.

description: We walked to this place from Union Square, which was quite a walk but manageable.  The environment went from the nice and "clean" area of Union Square to more like New York City (we later found out we were in Little Saigon), but this made the trip even more interesting and fun. :)   Definitely not a restaurant, but a tiny store where you order bahn mi at the counter, then shuffle to a wall to make way for the next person ordering (the order/waiting area is probably 8 feet by 4 feet... small!).  The trip was worth it though, cause the bahn mi was delish and only about $3.50!  One sandwich was filling for me, but within a couple hours I definitely could've used another! Definitely recommend this place, and don't be alarmed by the journey to a delicious bahn mi!
author: Chich S.

description:
One of the best vietnamese sandwiches you will find.  I'm Vietnamese myself, and I grew up in little saigon in orange county, so I'm a pretty tough critic.  However, for the 2.50 price tag and the quality of sandwich they offer, you can't get a better deal anywhere else.  Guaranteed.

Plus the ladies who work there are simply lovely.
author: Khoa N.

description:
Today was the first of many weekend days spent at the library doing some homework. I had been meaning to come back here for a while now, so I decided to walk a few blocks and get myself a sandwich.

I was really amazed. I am used to the sandwiches from Latte Express on 5th and Mission. They are $3.95, small, but still tasty. But at Saigon Sandwiches for $2.50 you can get a tastier and MUCH larger sandwich. The meat definitely had more flavor. My only complaint is that it could have used more slaw.

I think I'll be back here several more times in the coming months for a library lunch break.
author: Stu M.

description:
Best banh mi on Larkin Street.  Actually, the only Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in San Francisco have only come from Larkin Street so perhaps these could possibly be the best in the city!

Don't be too psyched out by the long lines during lunch time.   I would say the longest I've waited was 15 minutes --- not too bad for the biggest, baddest, over-stuffed sandwich ever.  

I prefer the combo sandwiches --- nice mix of pickled carrots/daikon/peppers/meat/cilantro/and liver paste ---  Oh how I dig that liver paste!!

The trays of savory and sweet foods and the are pretty tasty and extremely cheap.
author: Guava C.

description: After 15 years of coming here, i will not come here anymore! the food is cheap, but its dirty! ate a chicken sandwich and my stomach has been ALL BAD for the past 3 days, OMG :( i will boycott this place until they clean it up. sad day :(
author: Q W.

description:
Honestly this place is small, dark, dirty, and packed. BUT I still love them soooooo much that no words can describe. I always come here when i get out of class in downtown. The line is always super loooooooooooooooooooooong! What i mean long is people would order like 20 sandwiches per person ( that's what holding up the line) but I got to say, people buy that much for a reason. 
The meatball sandwich is the best one to me. The flavor is very nicely done, you can taste the strong black pepper they use in it. The pickled carrots that comes with every sandwich is delicious too. Also the pork and tofu is popular. The combination pork is just OK, not much in it.
I waited 50mins for one sandwich last time I was there. It is just that good.
author: Sophie L.

description: I was so excited to be in San Francisco for a number of reasons while I attended a conference at the Moscone, but one main reason was the food options.  I've only ever had this kind of sandwich once before (in Brooklyn) and I was hooked!  So for that reason, I was glad to see that San Fran had options in the area.  Saigon Sandwich was on the top of the list, so naturally I hiked the 6 blocks from my hotel to check it out for dinner.  The place is in a sketchy part of town which is not big deal, but worth mentioning for those that feel uncomfortable in that setting.  The two ladies working were sweet as could be with big smiles and polite service.  As mentioned in other reviews, the service was very fast. BUT, when I got back to my hotel...  Well, you see where this is going.  I was soooo excited to tear into my sandwich, but damn I was disappointed.  The bread was hard (harder then a French roll should be), the all of the ingredients were cold and did not taste fresh at all.  To be honest, I stopped eating after a few bites just to hedge my chances against bad ingredients or food poisoning.  Now, as I mentioned, I've only ever had this kind of sandwich one other time, but let me tell you, it was amazingly good, bordering on religious.  Saigon Sandwich fell short.  Frown face.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Cheap. $3 dollar sandwiches, and maybe some more change if you want something other than standard. Be warned, this place gets crowded quick. Typically you have to wait in line to order, and when ordering, there is usually a line of 6 to 8 people waiting like you, for their order to be made. Expect to wait at least 15 minutes for your sandwich. However, for a simple $3 dollar meal, I think waiting 15 minutes won't kill me. 

I've finally tried them out today and got the fancy pork. Nice portions, and it's actually filling. I normally need to eat 2 sandwiches of the vietnamese variety to feel full, but this place only needs one to fill me up. No more McD's for me anymore!
author: Clinton L.

description: I don't know a more pleasurable way to spend $3.50 in San Francisco.  My favorite is meatball.
author: Robert R.

description: What is all the hype about? I grew up on Vietnamese sandwiches, having been born there and raised by a large extended family of Chinese/Cambodian/Vietnamese. Here are my major complaints: 1) the bread is a little too crunchy and small, 2) way too much carrot and no cucumbers, and (most importantly) 3) where is the true Vietnamese specialty (namely head cheese, steamed pork, and pâté). I guess if you don't know better a BBQ pork sandwich will do...unfortunately, I know better. I'll save my banh mi eating for my visits to San Jose.
author: Chanthi L.

description:
I tried this place today after a few hours in the Asian Art museum.  My friend Joshua wanted to check it out, and I'm glad I let him lead!

YUM!  The bread is exceptional, and perfectly crispy, not annoyingly flakey like you'll find at so many other Vietnamese sammy places.  The roast pork is great!  And the pickled veg on the sandwiches are a little sweet and tiny bit spicy.  

CHEEP!  I paid $3 for a good-sized delicious roast pork sandwich--it's no hoagie, but it's enough and YUMMY!  Add on a can of sweetened coffee drink for $1 and sit at the "counter" and watch the crazies go by.
author: Aimee B.

description:
I'll start by saying that I would give this place 3.5 stars.  The reason I rounded up was because this is the best Viet sandwich place in SF.  I generally get the roast pork sandwich.  The bread is absolutely perfect: crispy on the outside, chewy and warm on the inside.  The beef and veggies (carrots, pepper, cilantro, etc) are nicely marinated though a bit too sweet for me.  In comparison to other Viet sandwich places, it is a tad smaller and about 50 cents more expensive.  But it makes up for it with awesome bread and more effort that  you can taste with the meat and veg.

If I were to compare this only to other Viet sandwich places in the city, it is a solid 4 star.  A place like Lee's and others, the bread and meat are both so plain.  But compared to my fav sandwich place in the city, it falls just short in taste and filling which is why the rating fell a bit.

It does look like a hole in the wall but don't let that discourage you.  There are only 2 ladies working the long lines here, so be sure to have your order and cash ready.  They fulfill the orders in bulk, so basically, they go down the line, ask everyone up to the door what they want, then knock out the orders until they get to the next group to enter.

high turnover of food and seems clean enough
service is surprisingly quick considering the lines
parking is easy, metered
author: John D.

description:
Saigon sandwich shop apparently has no shortage of fans. Aside from the sandwiches,  I like to peruse the stray items wrapped in saran wrap on the counter, and sometimes just start noshing on some of that while i wait for the sandwich.

You can't beat the price, although atmosphere can be a bit lacking. Unless you like standing around a counter with a bunch of other hungry folks...

 I suggest one hop down Larkin a bit to Wrap Delight, which has similar snacks & sandwiches...plus is a little less cramped with some table seating, so you can get a vietnamese coffee with your meal. Wrap Delight also sell transit & parking meter cards...
author: Donny N.

description:
So gooood!  Working around Civic Center,  I was looking for a sandwich shop that was 1) within walking distance and 2) cheap.  It was a bit of a walk from Franklin and yes there was a line but it was absolutely worth it!  

The prices are shockingly low.  I didn't really believe in a time when $2.50 is barely the price of coffee, I could find a fully loaded sandwich.

My colleague and I both got the chicken. When he asked the woman behind the counter how big were the sandwiches, she looked right at me and said, "So two chicken? Next!" She knew her sandwiches would satisfy; she did not have time for his mundane questions. He feared the price equated to finger food.  We hurried back to our offices ecstatic about the purchases.  Unwrapping the sandwiches, back in the the air conditioned, florescent building  he suddenly realized the girth of what he held.  I realized after one jalapeno tingling bite that this sandwich was going down; no saving of leftovers, no wimping out.  Results:  1)money left in the wallet and 2) happy belly!
author: Ana d.

description:
When I don't feel like cooking, this is dinner.  Super cheap at $3 and even though the sandwiches are smaller than the ones you get at the Lee's across the street, they are the perfect size and are much tastier.  Not as many options either, but roast pork and roast chicken are really all I need.  Cash only.

Weeknights after work there usually isn't a line, but if you come at any time on the weekend, expect to wait about 20 minutes from start to finish.  Lots of interesting snack options to look at while you're waiting and it's always fun to watch the first-time visitors, their eyes gleaming with anticipation.  

The last time I went, I watched a teenaged girl muster up the courage to try a three colored-coconut drink.  After discovering how tasty it was, she passed it around to all her friends, who all purchased the same for themselves.

As far as the comments regarding gloves and money, I think the ladies do all the food work barehanded and put gloves on to take money and make change.  To be honest, I don't really care.  Too many people complain about stuff like that when they themselves don't even wash their hands properly after using the toilet or before they eat.
author: Allie R.

description:
Note to people who gave 2-3 star reviews: this is a ghetto-tastic, dirt-cheap joint. You're not eating upscale french food. Don't expect service with a smile, lavender-scented candles and cappuccino-brown walls. They call these places "hole in the wall" for a reason.

For what expectations you have, it's an awesome joint. At $2.50 per sandwich, you wonder how they make money. MMmm, so tasty. Gotta love the cilantro wedged in between the sliced carrots and the one-or-two peppers (could use a bit more kick). Sure you probably have a .25% chance of finding a rat's tail or a fly, but it comes with the territory, literally (Tenderloin isn't exactly the classy part of SF). 

If you do order though be sure to order by phone 30 minutes ahead. With the giant lines you're looking at a long wait if you do otherwise. The fact that there's a huge wait every lunch should tell you how great this place is. The spectacle of the contrast is humorous--you're in a slum-like neighborhood, and then you have a wall of urban professionals crowding around waiting for their orders.
author: Ak S.

description: The sandwiches are the bomb get extra pate. The bad no seating and cash only...
author: R C.

description: YESSS!!!! It's in the cuts of the tenderloin, but where else can you get a delicious (and in my opinion relatively healthy? maybe not) lunch for under $4! I highly recommend their roast pork, although their roast pork+steamed pork combination is fantastic as well. And someone please tell me what they put in that sauce because I could eat just the bread smothered in that sauce for days. The cashier is a sweetheart, and there is a plethora of other odd asian snacks inside. There's no seating in here, but civic center is just a few blocks away, and you definitely have a nice little picnic there... that is if your sandwich is still intact by the time you make it there.
author: Shawna C.

description: Last time I ate here several years ago the sandwiches cost $1.75. The sandwiches are good, but I'd rather just stay here in the East Bay where they are a lot cheaper.
author: James B.

description: This was one of the most epic sandwiches that I have ever had the pleasure of eating. So so yummy. Definitely worth the trip through the not so nice area of town. I grew up in the NYC area. There are some pretty wonderful places to find Banh Mi (at least there used to be - they seem to be disappearing), but this was wonderful. What a great afternoon treat!
author: Sarah B.

description: Haven't gone back in a long time since moving out of SF. But from what I can remember, they make some damn tasty sandwiches. I'm not sure if it's the bread, their secret sauce, or the fact that I had to wait in a line that stretches around the entire block to get my hands on one of these babies. Either way, I surely miss this place and haven't been able to find a comparable Vietnamese sandwich in the south bay.
author: Eric L.

description: I went back three more times and I've got to say, blame my beer soaked taste buds for the Pride day review. This is an excellent sandwich with fresh veggies, flavorful meat, and crispy bread. Now, please excuse me while I drown my sorrows with the fact that it's over 3,000 miles away from me.
author: Half P.

description:
So it's not the best food I've ever had but I'm giving it 4 stars for a couple reasons:

- it's good food in the Tenderloin
- crazy cheap

I usually get the fanci meatball sandwich without cilantro or jalapenos (just a personal preference).  It's a great sandwich for $2.50.  The ladies behind the counter can seriously turn out 20 sandwiches in 5 minutes.
author: Evan L.

description:
680 reviews. (I'm 681!) What more can really be said. I had a pretty good Banh Mi somewhere and my friends were like, dude you don't know what you're even talking about. Cut to this Saturday past. I ordered up 3. (Roast Pork, Fanci Pork and Pate. DEEEE LICIOUS.
(I didn't eat them all at once and of course the next day they aren't as good or as fresh, but they held up ok. )
I wish this place had BBQ pork too, but I'm gonna give them a pass. I need to try a special combination next.

Also, their grass jelly drinks are a great way to kill that Jalapeno heat.

Big propers to Marcus O. for setting me straight.
author: B S.

description:
THE best place for a vietnamese sandwich in san francisco, hands down! $3 for a deliciously huge and filled to the brim sandwich make for good times in my stomach. i always get the combination sandwich, they fill it nicely with pickled radishes and LOTS of pate YUM! 

my best friend loves that they have jackfruit chips for her to buy. and the little old ladies clearly know what they're doing and have it down pat.

oh saigon, i yearn for the nice sunny days when danny e and i would pick up sandwiches from you and then lie on the grass in dolores park blissfully not speaking as we were devouring our delicious sammies....
author: Melanie C.

description: Really good banh mi at a price you can't beat. It makes it worth the trip out to the TL. Different from what I'm used to, perhaps more authentic, but I still think Les Croisants takes the edge. Roasted pork + pate is the way to go.
author: Cristofer P.

description: Ordered 3 combinations to go and was so stoked to eat them the minute I got home. I started eating them, they tasted really good, but after half way I was overwhelmed by patte. There was just too much for my liking that I had to wipe some off! Otherwise it was a good banh mi.
author: Jackie M.

description:
This place sells some ONE THOUSAND SANDWICH A DAY, SEVEN DAYS WEEK.

This is how good are their sandwiches. 

They buy their bread from Bakers Of Paris in Brisbane, CA. 

Enjoy your sandwich and take some to go too. 

cabbieiam
author: Cabbie I.

description:
My friend brought me to this place for the first time when we were in high school. I'm in college now in a place far far away, and I still dream about the sandwiches here.

Delicious and cheap. Something about the meat (is it the juices?) makes the sandwich so much tastier than your standard banh mi. The materials are well-picked. I'm personally a favorite of the Combination since it gives that hodgepodge kind of taste that makes banh mi delicious in the first place. And, it only costs 3.75! If you're hungry (like I often am), grab an extra or two on the way out. You'll want it.
author: Oriana C.

description:
Totally the best deal in the city!

$2.50 a sandwich!!  My fav is the Roasted Chicken. Easy to eat on the go, or perfect to take for a short walk to civic center for a picnic. 

Sure it is small and shady looking at first, but once you walk in you find out that its all about the food!! Always some kind of fun treat to try!

Sometimes the line looks like but not an issue moves faster then you think. Kinda like the soup nazi, hahah dont be afraid those ladies are the sweetest!!
author: Danny B.

description:
I must have been living under a rock because I've never experienced a Vietnamese sandwich before coming here.  We went and stood in line in this tiny place.  I asked for the pork sandwich and it was amazing.  Every bite was a brand new discovery of wonderful flavors.
Looking forward to the next time.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
Cheap, Quick, and Bomb!  I love Saigon Sandwiches, especially their chicken!  Anyone who goes must try their green gelatin desert found in the drinks fridge section.  Sooo good!  

Highly recommended!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I've been here twice.  The first time I went during lunch and got the roast pork sandwich.  The bread was just the right temperature, the pork was cooked just right, and the toppings were fresh.  The second time I went was around 5pm and I ordered the "fanci pork."  I would advise against this "fanci pork" which was neither fanci nor pork.  As I tried to force feed this sandwich down my throat, I got the distinct impression that the sandwich has laid fallow for several hours prepped with mayo and other sauces that turn bad quickly.  This place has quick turnaround during lunch but seems pretty slow the rest of the day.  

I also tried one of the white round buns stuffed with rice noodles and meat.  It was average.  

In short, if you go, go during the lunch hour and get the roast pork.
author: David L.

description:
I've been a fan of Vietnamese sandwiches for many years.  I just went here for the first time and realized I've never really had a Vietnamese sandwich before.

Damn.

Best Vietnamese sandwich.  Ever.
author: Jason M.

description:
Walk an extra block down in the TL (they're cleaning it up, you won't get mugged) for a superior vegetarian sandwich to Lee's. (I still love Lee's smoothies--eat your heart out, Jamba).

The tofu is--dare I say--meaty. The veggies are fresh, and the jalapenos, though they aren't my thing, are good too. The baguette is perfect, not too soggy but not too dry.

It's hard to go anywhere in this city without paying a lot in this city for some item, but this place is the exception. The price is right--$3. You get plenty for your money, and you won't want a second--that would ruin the singularity of the sandwich.

So, close your laptop, hop on the bus (#31 or #19 are near, but it's close to downtown anyway) and go. You may have to wait but they are pretty efficient in my experience. Plus, what more do you expect for $3--to be acknowledged right away and charge it on your American Express card?
author: Luke J.

description:
Cheap eats - check
Fresh ingredients - check
Homecookin' - check

I love everything about Saigon Sandwiches. The women behind the counter make the best viatnamese sandwiches I have ever had. Plus, the give you the occasional attitude.

Five stars!
author: Yum N.

description: Forget Lee's..this is thee best banh mi I've ever had.  I've gotten it often when my co-workers pre-order and bring them to work.  I love the combination with pate or the chicken with pate.  I never realized how much I love pate until I came here.  The more, the better.  The place is tiny and there is always a line out the door.  But the ladies work quickly.  Since there is no place to sit, I love to take my sandwich and sit on the lawn at civic center on a sunny day :)
author: Kimba V.

description: LOVE this place. I've been coming back here for many years (getting close to 10).  I've had other Viet sandwiches in SF and the LA area but this is still the best and really cheap.  My favorite is the tofu (and I'm not a vegetarian)  soaked in a flavorful soy type sauce making it moist and complimenting the rest of the ingredients (all sandwiches have jalapenos, parsley,  carrots and white radish/daikon, and mayo unless you tell them otherwise). The place is really small so it's more of a take out place but they also sell other Vietnamese delicacies such as ham and desserts.  This is definitely a place you should try, it always keeps me coming back for more.
author: Jayme N.

description:
I've never had banh mi like these before. yummm...

previous reviewer was right, these are the 'traditional' sandwiches. The veggies aren't as 'tart' as I usually like them but dammnnnn they are good.  The bread is tasty and doesn't cut your gums ( oh yes, it's happened) and ooooooh the grilled pork. Try and avoid the lunchtime rush; It's a tease to wait in line so long.
author: l v.

description:
Bánh mì ........ Pronounced   BANG-ME !!
Is as good as it sounds.

It doesn't matter if you're doing one, the other, or both.
You WILL be moaning in pleasure.

Either way, be sure to stretch before partaking in serious Bánh mì action!
author: Mark B.

description: Like you need another person to tell you that this place is awesome, but I'll vouch for the pate and the tofu banh mi. I usually go during non-peak hours, and at 2pm, there usually isn't a line. The only thing that keeps this place from 5 stars is that the crust of the bread is usually a little hard, and it'll kind of scrape up the roof of your mouth.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Don't let the tiny, dingy interior of this Vietnamese Sandwich place fool you.  The food is delicious and very inexpensive.  The limiting reagent in many Vietnamese sandwiches has been, in my opinion, the quality of the bread.  This is not the case with this place - the bread here is fresh and crisp.  As a vegetarian, I only ever order the tofu but have heard fantastic things about the other sandwiches from my friends and colleagues.  The wait can be a little long (they tend to take a bunch of orders at a time and assemble all of those before they take another batch) but well worth it - just keep it in mind when you go for lunch on a weekday.  They also have a wide selection of southeast Asian desserts.  This place is a great way to buy food for a lot of people inexpensively (my husband has bought food for meetings with ~20 people) - just call ahead to place the order.

As a side-note, I once was drawn to the newer, shinier, and larger place across the street (Lee's... they have a more extensive menu as well) and found the food to be vastly inferior.  Stick to Saigon.
author: Kaman C.

description: the sandwiches are pretty good here. I think by far the best Vietnamese sandwiches I've had so far!!
author: parviz d.

description: Okay, this place is my favorite Banh Mi place in San Francisco. Super legit Vietnamese owner who makes authentic Banh Mi's at a super low price. 3.50 for a sammy with no tax? Yup. My boyfriend and I always come here when he has to get something downtown near Civic Center. The last time we went there, a homeless man asked to get a Banh Mi but only had a dollar and some spare change. The lady only took the dollar and gave him a whole sandwich. That was refreshing to see. I really like their roasted pork and roasted chicken banh mi's.  Very fast and efficient. Always a line when we come but worth the wait. I wish one was closer to me :(  My only small complaint would be that every time we ask for extra veggies ( no charge for that) they always load it up on my boyfriend's sandwich and I always get skimped. I will be brave and ask them for more veggies after our first request if I get jipped again. LOL
author: Linh V.

description: easily one of the best sandwiches in sf. The pork sandwich is my favorite, and you gotta make it spicy. Love this place
author: Jonah G.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches never disappoints me. I've been coming here since grade school and have always gotten their steampork-sandwiches-w/no- peppers-and-pls-cut-in-half-thanks.

They're always super busy during the mornings and lunchtimes, but at their prices, who can blame them?
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
The BEST Vietnamese sandwich in the city.

I'm eating one right now. Yum.
author: Peter C.

description:
Still the standard.  The bbq chicken is as good as ever, but the bbq pork has been slipping in my estimation.  Still the best bbq pork vietnamese sando out there, but it's not as good as the chicken.

For my money, it's best to buy the sandwich and then let it sit for 30-40 minutes to let the flavors blend together.  They're great to throw a couple in your backpack or whatever and go to a ball game.
author: Eric W.

description:
The best Vietnamese sandwiches in the city, imho.
I do eat meat, but can't get enough of their tofu sandwiches. I would have stayed veggie a lot longer if I had had such easy access to such amazing tofu sandwiches.
Sure, no atmosphere, always a line, etc. etc. But, d**m good sandwiches. And $3!
author: E C.

description:
It was a beautiful day in SF. Sunny and warm. Fogless. It was the perfect day to head to Golden Gate Park with a little picnic.

I had a choice between this sausage place at the Haight (I think) and Saigon Sandwiches. I choose Saigon Sandwiches because it's like $3 a sandwich. $3!!! And it's not a small sandwich. Plus it was good.

I had the Roasted Pork banh mi...it was still warm after we got to the park 30 minutes later. The french bread held the juices from the meat and pickles quite well. The jalapenos kicked it up a notch but it can be a bit spicy for some. 

$3...you just can't beat that! BTW, this is one of the rare things that is cheap, fast, and good!
author: J B.

description: I went to try this place out a few days ago.  When I thought sandwiches , I was thinking two slices of bread for $2.50.   They're like sub sandwiches... with delicious tender juicy meat.  My 2 friends that I went with both got seconds and thirds. The bread was a little bit hard, but overall , a really good sandwich worth the price.
author: Sindy W.

description: I stand corrected.  There are two small counter seats at the very front of the deli next to the refrigerators.  I'm sure if you get a seat there, you will see some very interesting things outside. I didn't notice them the first time around, but when I got there this morning at 10:30 to pick up five sandwiches for a gf and my family, I noticed the two seats.  Within seconds, three people appeared after me in line.  Impressive.
author: Christie X.

description: Not only the best banh mi but at the best price to boot. They pickle the veggies just right and use really good bread.
author: B B.

description:
This is a pretty good place for bahn mi. The sandwiches are still pretty cheap $2-3/sandwich and they have a good variety. Be prepared to wait in line if you go during lunch hour. 
I just wish there was daikon in the sandwich (the pickled carrot suffices) and maybe that their ingredients were fresher.
author: Anthony C.

description:
There are very few things I eat that I can apply the phrase, cream your culinary pants over. That phrase, coined by the hilarious Laura B, most definitely, completely and absolutely applies to these sandwiches. 

So I had a hearing at City Hall to attend, which happen to be on the same date as the ruling determining whether gay couples could resume marriage ceremonies (yay!). So the joint was mobbed, is what I'm saying. I go to my hearing and am super hungry at like 10 a.m. when it starts. EFF. Where am I going to find something to eat? My iphone is busted so I might as well have a soup can and 2 strings. I have no pocket Yelp, is what I'm saying here. 

Then I remember: the sandwich shop! Oh sweet mother of god, I will go there. It will be glorious. The hearing ends, I call my husband to confirm shop location, and off I go. I pass doorway after doorway smelling like a combo of fresh and stale pee. I see a line out the shop already. Fiddlesticks! The lady takes like 12 orders at a time. I ordered the simple roast pork. I wait in line, and of course OF COURSE a toothless meth addict kneels out front of the shop and begs for food and rants about how much life sucks because no one will allow her fucking rat (her words) into places. Like church. And restaurants. I eventually put my headphones on to drown her out. I then questioned my compassion as a fellow human. But I digress. 

Seriously 20 minutes go by, and I'm starting to wither I'm so freaking hungry. But voila! There's 12 sandwiches lined up in a row with pork and mayo in them. The other lady puts peppers, cilantro and carrots in there, wraps them up, and rings you up. $3.25. DUDE. Although the last time I was here it was $2.50 (2006). 

So I get the sandwich, and while I'm walking down Larkin, I bite into it. Friends, perhaps it's the fact I haven't had a French roll in 100 years because I've been trying to low-carbing it, but I literally thought I was going to pass out in ecstasy. It was perfectly toasted on the outside, soft on the inside. The bread alone was heaven. Then I got to the good stuff. I was literally making MM MMM MM sounds while I'm walking down Larkin Street. The pork so tender. The mayo so salty and perfectly juxtaposing the crisp cilantro. The sandwich is pretty big, and since I've recently employed the rule of eating until I'm 70-80% full, as opposed to the point of pants-splitting regret. So I put  of the sandwich away in my work bag for enjoyment later. During my BART ride back to the office, I'd periodically open my work bag, take a good whiff, and die just a little bit in pure food ecstasy. I get back to the office and tell my office mate: SMELL MY BRIEFCASE. NO, JUST DO IT. 

Mind-blowing sandwich. Wish I lived in the city still so I could have them more often.
author: H H.

description:
cheap. fast. delicious. 

but you have to get the combination, with the pate goodness!
author: Jane C.

description: The lines might be nuts, but the sandwiches are worth the wait!  I've searched high and low in SF for the best Vietnamese sandwiches and hands down this is the best.  Really good vegetarian sandwiches too.
author: Tammy R.

description: for some reason, the photo i added to this business site was flagged and removed.  for the record, the photo was of a sandwich that i purchased from this place which had a huge cockroach in it.  i am not here to defame or slander businesses on yelp, but i speak the truth of my experiences, services, products or food i receive and/or purchase.
author: Sheri N.

description:
I think it's impossible not to like this place. I went somehow at a non-busy time, and before I knew it, there was a line out the door! 

Such a good use for those silly $2 bills your grandma sends you on your birthday (oh, am I the only one who that happens to?)
author: Mike S.

description:
I cannot believe that I have not yet done a review of Saigon Sandwiches!

And why not now?  I should be working, I'm at home by myself, I took a nap and had coffee, so what the hell...I'm DOING IT!

Let's be creative and compose our review in list format.

Things to love about Saigon Sandwiches:
1) Delicious Sandwiches that I would be willing to pay way more than $2.50 for.
2) $2.50 sandwiches that are delicious (note, no.s 1 and 2 are slightly different).
3) Fast service even if the person in front of you orders 10 sandwiches
4) Prepacked vietnamese sweets and other completely foreign (to me) treats that are all less than $2 so I can pile them on and not care if the taste doesn't appeal to me.
5) Equal opportunity surliness - the lady who takes your order says "yeah yeah" to anyone who gives her lip - no matter what language they use to order.
6) Other patrons are friendly and will always tell you what something is if you ask them.
7) Pickled carrots!
8) DELICIOUS, FILLING SANDWICHES FOR TWO DOLLARS AND FIFTY CENTS!

Also, on a more personal note, 3 blocks away from my house so running down there at lunch is always an option...
author: Suze C.

description:
Mmmhahaha!  I like what Nigel had to say.  Ah, what the mind goes through when trying to express the most primative of responses.  Even my gentle cocker spaniel growls when I take that delicious bone away.  Okay, I'll stop there.  

This place is pretty good!  I even by-passed the new Lee's Sandwich accross the street to check it out.  I ordered the #1 dac biet and the #9 grilled chicken for my wife and me.  We liked it so much that we went back the next day to get more.  The only qualm I had was there was no crunchy head cheese.  I know, I know,  it sounds kinda raunchy, but that's what makes the dac biet sandwich dac biet (besides the pate)!  I give kudos on the wonderful baguettes and other ingrediants!

Warning:  watch out for pedestrians who fail to observe local street laws.  I almost hit a dude who walked a red light.  My wife scolded me for almost hitting him. ( What?!  Did you want me to hit him?  I saw the dude in time, didn't I?)  Anyways, when I found parking, I went to the shop and saw him complaining about the prices in Vietnamese.  He was thick headed and gave the owner a hard time.   He was such a tool!  I wanted to smack him but by the graces of god he finally removed himself from the establishment only to cause more traffic mayhem and marital strife.   

Oh, I highly recommend the chicken sandwiches #9!
author: John L.

description:
GABRIEL
You going to make it?

JERRY
(huffing)
Larkin's steep.

GABRIEL
For this sandwich, I'll risk you getting a heart-attack.

JERRY
I like my sandwiches like my women: crispy and toasty on the outside, spicy, with tender meat, on the inside.  Down-to-earth simple, but inexplicably, earth-shatteringly tasty.  And compact.  You got that part?

Gabriel and Jerry finally roll up to the small hole-in-the-wall with the blue awning.  Jerry leans over, catching his breath.

GABRIEL
(beat)
Yeah.  At least you'll like the sandwich.
author: T. F.

description:
I tried to order 5 sandwiches--2 pork, 3 chicken all without pate, but instead got 6--2 pork, 3 chicken, and 1 liver.  There were obviously some communication issues.  I specifically said that I didn't want pate in any of the sandwiches, but everytime i said "no pate" she just looked at me funny and repeated a variation back to me as a question, "no pad thai?"  
Yes i said, "no pate", and she says, "no bad ties?"
After three times of this, I started to crack up and she did too. While i was laughing at our apparent miscommunication, I think she was blatently laughing AT me. It wasn't the first time, nor will it be the last for that, I suspect.   

The sandwiches were top notch, although we threw the one with liver away.  I was hoping we would run into either a German or Vietnamese homeless person (no offense to the wired homeless who might be reading this, but who else would eat this?) on the way to the car, so we could give the sandwich away, but the homeless people of the city dodged a bullet that day.
author: R F.

description:
Hands down THE best Vietnamese sandwiches in the entire city! Cheap AND good food with good service! Sketchy neighborhood but well worth it, I'd trek a mile in the snow any day for one of these sandwiches!

I attend college at UCSC and so while I am away from home I have major Banh Mi cravings. As soon as I step foot back in the city I rush for Saigon Sandwich!

BBQ Chicken, Pate and Jalepenos please. Grab it to go. 

Lee's is a new addition nearby and is offering a little competition. This place beats a chain restaurant any day! Make the right choice and go to Saigon Sandwich instead! You won't be disappointed.
author: Tracy N.

description:
Best banh mi.  Be prepared to tell everyone else to shut up.  

Be prepared for more sweet barbeque pork per bite than any other banh mi in the city.  Believe me, I've tried them all.  

Be prepared to take it to go and eat standing up on the curb. 

Also be prepared to wipe your mouth and come right back inside for a second sandwich.
author: Sarah E.

description:
This place is so good, I've gotten all my pals addicted. I just wish they sold more of their noodle roll dishes and spring rolls. When I was in college, I used to buy a week's worth and haul them back to So Cal with me and pray no one discovered the delicious goods in fridge. 
What makes the banh mi so good here is the bread, which is Bakers of Paris. If you're buying a banh mi and they aren't using Bakers of Paris bread, steer CLEAR!. Plus, the have a nice mix of the vinegared carrots and jicama. It is affordable and quick (if there's no crazy long line).
author: P L.

description: I came here at the request of my friend before going out. My first impression upon arriving was a Soviet food line. But hey, the line was a good indication of the food they served. Inside, it reminded me of some of the shops in older buildings I encountered in Korea. The ladies working the kitchen and counter cranked out food in no time. I got a tofu sandwich, which was absolutely delicious. It was like a toasted mini-baguette and had fried tofu, chilies, carrots, cilantro and some tangy sauce on it. Next time I'm in the area I'll stop by and get another.
author: Robert L.

description:
Saigon = 4 stars

Lee's (across the street) = 1 star

Saigon Wins!!!

No competition...
author: L K.

description:
The most, the best, the greatest, forever! Vietnamese Subs ever!  mmmmm mmmm mmmm.  It is also wins for being the least awkward sandwich to eat due to the simplicity of the warm and crispy crust of the deeelicccious bread and the lack of weird long lettuce in your sub---carrots, coriander, spicy pepper, delicious, complete.  I got the fried tofu sub and it was perfect---my friends tried out all the varieties of chicken, fanci pork, regular pork, etc...and they were all lovely.  We ate them on the grass a block down at Civic Center Plaza to complete the excellency.  It's like p'oh on bread.

They also sell HELLO PANDA (those chocolate filled panda cookies) and Pocky at Saigon Sandwiches.

SketchY sandwich? Nay!
Perfect Vietnamese Sub!
Hello Panda? Yes!

DANK FACTOR: 10 out of 10
author: Caroline P.

description:
All I have had is the pork sandwich (banh mi) for $2.75, but it is DELICIOUS!  Just be sure to watch out for the green pepper slices if you aren't into spicy things... because I AM into spicy things and they are still nearly too hot for me.  This is one of my favorite sandwiches ever, not to mention the best deal in the city (even though the price actually used to be $2.50)!

On top of a delicious pork sandwich, who doesn't love going to the Loin for a meal?  After running some errands, I walked there from my bank in Russian Hill, and on the way, saw a couple of lovely trannies, a guy making himself sneeze by sticking a long stick up his nose (do you still say bless you when someone has induced their own sneeze?), and a crazy man carrying a large bucket of chicken yell and threaten someone who honked at him because he was crossing the street on a red light.  Where else can you get such a colorful experience?
author: Erin D.

description:
Yes I do agree that its dirty.
BUT! Its cheap and good sandwiches.
What more do you want!
I give 3 stars simply by the sanitation.
Shoot if I mistakenly ate a roach in my
sandwich then....Damn that roach tasted
Hella Good!
author: Nelson F.

description:
This place is so good it makes me want to "pork" the sandwiches with my yes-yes parts.

EDIT:  I have no idea why I posted that sentence as my review.  Sorry.  But, I remain true to my crass single-entendre:  This food will make you hot under the collar and will engorge your genitals with blood.  It's that good.
author: Eric P.

description:
Vietnamese sandwiches among other goodies this is the place to go. Not fast service but no because they not good, it's basically they are always busy and a 2 women operation. The line is actually always out the door. ETA for your order: 15 min. If you have spare time this is a decent place. Take it to go only. There are a couple of chairs within.  I don't think they have other bread choices so you will get the thick and crunchy bread.
Cash only.
author: Smooth R.

description:
Jared and the five dollar footlong can kiss my ass!!!!!!!!!!!! 

These sandwiches are beastly, and for $3 you feel like you stole from them.  I really have no idea how they can only charge $3 for this sandwich.  I dont know how to put in words how this sandwich tastes, but i will say if this sandwich took a dump it would look like something you get at subway, nuff said.

I also HATE all yelpers that can even give this place a bad review, you paid $3, there can be no complaining for $3...
author: christopher h.

description: I have been eating like a fat boy for years..lol This place by far is best Vietnamese sandwiches that I have eaten. The ladies who operate this place are friendly and quick. The best place for sandwiches!!
author: Leonardo X.

description:
I used to intern around the corner  over 10 years ago. 

Whenever I am in town, I resort to being my piggish-self and get the BBQ pork sandwich (no pun intended). I usually make room between breakfast and lunch because there's so much good food in SF. So my schedule is like this: breakfast, walk, coffee, walk, snack, walk,  lunch, etc... I even directed a Canadian couple taking a break near city hall to have lunch there. 

It's a pretty democratic place, if you have $2.75, you can have a piece of pork heaven! 10 years later, the prices haven't changed much. There are about close to 300 reviews on this place so read on....
author: Thao L.

description: Secret sauce always makes me happy. I don't know what's in there, but it makes the sandwiches worth the wait.
author: Kristina L.

description:
One of my good friends told me for the longest time that I have to try Saigon Sandwiches and when I finally did, I know why.  I mean, I've been a frequent eater of Vietnamese Sandwiches since I was a kid and have tried several places.  However, I can't eat any other Vietnamese sandwich without feeling like "what the hell am I eating this for"  

There is always a line and I am one of those people who hates lines but for my Vietnamese Sandwich fix, I really do not mind at all.  My wife knows, if I am willing to wait in line for something, then it MUST be GOOD...
author: Mark W.

description: Couldn't really write a review till i tried all of the sandwiches. In my opinion, the Chicken and the Tofu are the most tasty on the menu, it holds the flavor well and compliments the sauce (mayo and brown stuff) & the veggies perfect. Plus, it's 3.25.... I'm all about meals under $4. Best sandwiches in little saigon.
author: Ethan B.

description:
i'm not going to go all "best I've ever had" here but when you're craving some banh mi action - and you're in the city - you must roll through and get a couple and slap them in your purse/manbag. 

2 ladies rock the counter and crank out your $2-3 dollar sandwich quick - I don't actually even remember the price because it was so cheap. The sandwich isn't teeny weeny and it's not going to hold you back from going back to work either. 

Well-seasoned meat, nicely pickled veggies, good spread, toast baguette!! I'd come back again and stop through after going to any of the may ethnic restaurants on Larkin just so I could take one home to savor. Also, a great place to go if every else you want to go on this street is packed. 

Enjoy! Sidenote - if you're in NYC and want a banh mi, go to Baoguette for a contemporary spin on the banhmi that's honest to its ethnic roots and incredible. Saint Marks Place (between 2nd & 3rd Ave)
author: Jessica C.

description: For a banh mi place in San Francisco, it's reasonably priced, fresh, and pretty good. With Lee's Sandwiches a block away, there's a reason why so many people still wait in line for Saigon instead. Definitely a small local place with big flavor in each bite. The way they marinate their meat is a delight. The only thing I would change is putting the veges & jalapenos on the inside of the sandwich instead of on top of the meat.
author: Allen D.

description: Best sandwich. Get the meatball. Or the pork. Or the chicken. Hell, I bought 4 for $13. Yes it's that cheap and delicious. Go and thank me later
author: Jordan S.

description:
How does this place make any money? All the sandwiches are $2.50 and dayam...are they good! Definitely a gem for vietnamese sandwiches but located a bit in the hood. Stand in line, grab a coke out of the fridge, order a couple of pork sandwiches, and walk out happy. Although I've toured this neighborhood more than I would like to admit, there are many places to get a vietnamese sandwich but none that compare to Saigon. You'll get a warm, toasted soft roll with tender slices of pork, carrots, onions, and peppers. Get it spicy and be prepared to have your mouth on fire. 

If you're looking for a place to grab some quick sandwiches for cheap and you're not in the sunset or richmond for some real authentic asian cuisine, check out Saigon Sandwiches. Be sure to go early though, they close at 5pm or when they sell out of sandwiches.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Wow, this is the best vn sandwich I've ever tasted. Ever. 
And I really like that they use the softer rolls (I don't like the really crunchy kind). 

I don't know what they put in these things that's different than other VN sandwich shops, but it's some kind of secret sauce! Delicious magic secret sauce that makes the whole sandwich a spicy juicy delight!

Now, I cannot top one of the reviews here that has something to do with a donkey, but I *almost* agree with him that the even if there were a donkey involved, I would still eat the sandwich with all the same enjoyment. That is pretty wack.

This is the soundtrack of Saigon Sandwiches: 
"What you like? $2.50. What you like? $2.50. What you like? $2.50." Except $2.50 is pronounced like this: "too fipdee" else it ain't really Vietnamese enough. That one's for you Amy T. 
too fipdee....too fipdee....too fipdee
author: Thlel Yan D.

description:
I love eating Vietnamese sandwiches and this was not a disappointment.
I ordered the roast pork sandwich and the spring rolls.Compared to the sandwiches I've eaten elsewhere,  the roast pork sandwich had a generous amount of pork and the bread was very crunchy  just the way I like it. The spring roll was just okay.  The best part was the sandwiches are just $2.50.  Service is quick since they have some already made in the warming oven. Your best bet is to take it to go; since there is not much seating. They open at 6:30 A.M. if you want to pick up lunch before going to work. Parking was not difficult.
author: norine h.

description:
2.75 delicious sandwiches! This place is a total hole in the wall I would never have bothered with...but everyone at my work is addicted to these and I can see why. YAY! 

By the way I'm vegetarian, so I have only experienced the tofu sandwich, its magnificent !!!
author: Maryanne R.

description:
When i got there I was kinda surprised because there was a long ass line that wasn't moving, then I realized that they took a buttload of orders at once and they belt them out pretty damn quick.
Anywhoooo, I order the Ga and it's Ga-damn good! Only suggestion would be to use softer bread. I hate it when i'm eating a sandwich and it all squirts out of one side. It was spicy, cheap and quick...just like I like my women.  SNAP!
They have cherry 7up too, so I SHALL RETURN!
author: Nic K.

description: Go here until you get food poisoning. I know that sounds weird, but the sandwiches are really that good. I'll never return after my last visit, but I don't regret any of my prior visits.
author: Alfredo A.

description: Tried the Roast Pork (not bad, pretty good), The Special Combo (All kinds of meats, good) and the Meatball (outstandingly great!). A little bit of a line at 1:30pm on a Monday when I went in, but the lady took my order quickly and filled it fast. Cheap. Worth the wait, for sure.
author: Tyler H.

description: This place is awesome.  If you have to take a $20 cab to get here you will not be sorry.  Fresh bread, fresh ingredients all for less than $4.  How could you not think this is the best place in SF?
author: Patrick A.

description:
Best Vietnamese sandwiches i've ever had. It has the right balance of jalapeño, vinaigrette carrots, honey roasted meat and cilantro - and i know there must be mayonnaise in there somewhere (judging by the 10+ two gallon mayonnaise tubs on the back shelf). I typically go chicken or pork.

I'll come back to check the tofu soon.
author: Julien R.

description:
BOMB sandwiches...so good that i've paid a 250 dollar parking ticket (bus stop) to get one... ok not by choice but eff the DPT.

Try their "dac biet" (special" sandwich and you'll be a fan too.
It may be small and somewhat unorganized looking but those are the best kinda food places (as long as its clean though)
author: Dan N.

description: probably the best banh mi in the city. Allocate some time though because this place is slow and the lines long. I get the combo sandwich every time. They also sell a ton of asian snacks and drinks (fresh!).
author: Brandon O.

description:
You know when your friend is bitching and whining and being a little brat the whole time. And you know when you had an awesome time up until that point. You might have even been having one of those days that after a string of a couple of weeks of really shitty luck you feel like the celestial constellations might be finally turning around from "let's shit on Marko configuration". But than the mood is wrecked by the person tagging along with you. And just when you have had enough of it, you walk into heaven.
Two sandwiches, two old ladies making them, coconut black bean cake, some delicious green shit in a cup, you, heaven, I don't want to strangle people anymore.
After you wake up you realize that everything DID happen. And you are OK with that. Because now you know where the best Banh Mi sandwiches in San Francisco are.
author: Marko J.

description:
I have been eating banh mi my whole entire life. I used to think the only real good ones were found in a) Vietnam or b) Little Saigon in Orange County. Well, add Saigon Sandwiches to the list! This place is legit. 

Special combination (dac biet) is incredible. Tasty balance of meat, pork balogna (cha), pate,  and mayo all accented with not too pungent pickled carrots and daikon and cilantro and jalapenos! They really hook you up with lots of meat is higher quality than Lee's across the street (not too fatty). Bread is great quality, just enough crunch without tearing up the roof of your mouth. 

Tip: Try the tofu sandwich! It is amazing. Possibly even more flavor than any of the meat sandwiches! Wowzers.
author: Andrew D.

description:
This is the best cheap-eats place in the area.  The sandwiches are stacked.  This place is high value.

I recommend the chicken.  Ask for "no peppers" if you are faint of heart/stomach.

The sandwich artists are always nice and friendly every time I go there.  

HINT: Beat the lunch rush around 12, or call in your order (415) 474-5698 to expedite the process.  The line can get pretty long when the Feds take their lunch (the "soon to be old" Federal Bldg is located a block away).
author: James B.

description:
OH. MY. GOD. 

If you haven't been here yet, GO NOW! You have no reason not to (besides the ridiculously long lines and the slighty seedy neighborhood but we'll ignore that...) The Bahn Mi is cheap ($3 seems almost too good to be true!) and beyond delicious.

When I first moved to the city a friend told me about this place one night while we were out drinking. Even in my slightly intoxicated state I had enough sense to realize that when someone talks about a sandwich for 20+ minutes, it must be good. And oh is it ever...
author: Amanda R.

description: In case you haven't tried it yet, the bread is what sets this place apart.  This is not your normal, flaky and soft banh mi.  It is fresh, but has a little more toughness to it and is more crunchy on the outside.  It will fill you up and put you in a food coma ASAP.
author: Joey S.

description:
Love Letter to Saigon Sandwiches:

I remember in the hay days when I had to only contribute $1.25 to get taste of your delicious beauties.  You even had the promotion that if you buy  like 4 or 5 you get one Free.  Yeah, don't deny, I got that deal from you before.  Like I said this was like umm, maybe more  than 15 years ago.  I (and my classmates) would send someone that lives nearby to pick up the sandwiches and have it for school field trip lunches.  I guess you can say I grew up on you.

I love you dearly, but the lacking star, however, goes back to the bread.  I love all the flavor creations, be it roasted chicken/pork, meat ball, fancy pork, pate, combination (I had them All), and the way you marinated and cooked the meat is on the "money" with their sweet vinegar carrot-daikon-onion fixing, tag on some fresh cilantro, smear on some special pink sauce goodness, then kick it to me jalapeno slices--no wonder there's a line out the block for you (the sandwiches).  Scrumptious! I tell ya.  

Wrapped around your delicious filling goodness, please recognize that the Bread plays an important role as well.  I remember that they use to have nice crispy (lip cutting) light crusty bread and pillow soft chew inside...still talking about the bread, stay with me.  Yeah but the past few years, the bread hasn't been the same, kind of rough chewy crust, even stale tasting, can't hear that crunch sound that good baguette or french bread/roll makes.     

And it's only human nature that if you were given better before, I know better now how to compare.  Ok, you're not the best bread out there, but not the worst either.  You change, I gotta got try others to see if they are as good as you, but you know that it's what's inside of you that counts.

Sometimes I go astray, but I always come back for you.  Now earn that star and give me my crispy crunch sexy bread back.

Yours truly,
Good Bread Lover
author: Vanna S.

description:
Oh lord, words can not describe how much I love these sandwiches. At the height of my addiction I was eating 10 sandwiches a week. I had to cut down, but sandwiches like these you can't go cold turkey on.

Did I mention how the sandwiches are the exact opposite of cold turkey? The sandwiches here are cooked meats on deliciously baked mini-rolls. For you veggie heads out there they also have a fantastic tofu sandwich which is on par with any of their meatie goodness. 

To top it off, the sandwiches are ridiculously cheap. $2.75 a piece? How do they do it? Actually, scratch that, I don't want to know how they do it, I just want them to keep doing it!

Saigon Sandwiches loses a star because while the sandwiches are godly, everything else there is pretty second rate and the location isn't the peak of homeliness. Take your sandwiches to go, there's only two seats in the joint and sitting there will probably make you claustrophobic with the line out the door.
author: Robert P.

description: Cannot beat the prices, sometimes have to stand in line, but it is always worth the wait. My favorite is the meatball, can eat 3 no problem. The combination is very good also. I always by about 10 sandwich's and put some in the freezer for a fast snack at home.  You can try the rest but for the best go to Saigon.
author: Steve R.

description: Really bomb sandwiches, not really much of a store, but the sandwiches make up for it. The ladies are friendly and the snack variety is huge. What can I say, this is the best banh mi I've eaten so far. I've tried Banh Mi Ba Le (a very close 2nd place), Le Chevals (in Walnut Creek), Cam Huong (in Oakland), and Camille's (in Berkeley), and Saigon Sandwich is still the best!
author: Kevin L.

description:
LOVE AT FIRST BITE!!!!

I love Vietnamese Sandwiches because of this place. About 10 years ago when I was an intern working in the Civic Center Area my co-workers introduced me to this place. I had never been exposed to a Vietnamese Sandwich before, but was HOOKED when I first tried it. 


The office would then take turns making sandwich runs to this place. When someone found out they were gonna walk about 6 blocks away to get sandwiches from here everyone in the office eagerly wanted one.

Obviously if you haven't tried a sandwich like this the flavors are definitely different than Americanized sandwich shops. Soft and crisy french roll, grilled meat, Mayo, sweet sauce, sweet pickled carrots and onions,  and must not forget the cilantro...yummmm...ok it might not sound that appetizing...but it is freakin' awesome!!!!

Great sandwich place for reasonable prices. Lines were super long (especially since it's grown more and more popular) at lunch so it was best to come early or at an odd time of day to avoid the lunch rush.

I don't work in SF so I hardly am ever in the area...but if I did work around here I'd be eating here for lunch at least once a week! For now, I get my Vietnamese Sandwich fix at Dakao in downtown SJ, but still have yet to find better tasting Vietnamese sandwiches than these.

I highly recommend the roasted Chicken Sandwich!
author: Cathy D.

description:
Being the cheap-but amazingly flavorful-food whore...who knew??  I of course was up for a quick bahn mi...big ups to my iphone and yelp yet again!...
during halftime a couple weeks ago my friend and I needed a quick respite from R Bar and once again the demise of my beloved Jets (damn you Mangini/Favre.) A quick look on my yelp app and a brisk 7 minute walk and we were confusingly in a tiny convenience store with tiny smiling asian lady in front of us. Even after getting the pork bahn mi I was still a little perplexed; however, the five beers were telling my brain to shut and just eat while walking...such a good move. Bahn mi when not done right isn't anything special by any means...however, this was done miraculously. The mix of flavors, textured ingredients, easily consumable nature, and $3 price tag is dare I say a thing of beauty. 

Overall: Finally I am starting to see the payoff of all these "Asians" I keep hearing about in the area...This is fine example of a top notch snack/meal on the go if in the hood.

Value: For the price of one below average Subway sandwich you can get two flavorpacked vietnamese
author: Andrew K.

description:
Why? why are they so good? Its so simple, pork, carrots, cilantro, peppers, bread.  Yet it is so incredibly delicious.  And cheap! I cant even make my own lunch from home for less than $4! 
The line moves really fast but I am not a big fan of standing around that neighborhood.  This is a place to grab your sandwich and run away as fast as you can before the screaming crackhead gets hit by a car as he yells and darts in front of cars.  Yes, this is TL, home to Saigon Sandwiches: best sandwich this yelper has eaten...possibly ever?
author: Nilu r.

description: Best Banh Mi you will find in the bay area hands down! You can't go wrong, everything is sooo good depending what you're in the mood for that day. Fast turnover so you know everything is fresh. It must be the spot when so many people travel out of the way and stand in line just to get a sandwich. Plus everybody and their mama knows about this hole in the wall.
author: T L.

description: They have a new layout. Seems cleaner and is more efficient. They make the BEST Vietnamese sammies. Nom nom nom...
author: Stephen L.

description: I have to say, it's not bad.... but I still think Sing Sing's is better... it's the bread that is the determining factor for me. I love the combo meat sandwiches, but the crust of the bread has to be soft and doesn't fall apart. And this one isn't the best for me. It's really good... but not the best. It's cheap and I'd come here again if my favorite spot is sold out...
author: Kristina L.

description:
Wow, these are great Vietnamese sandwiches. I grew up in east side san jose, which is home to a large vietnamese population and hosts many vietnamese sandwich shops, so that is no empty praise. 

I love the barbeque pork sandwiches. At $3 a sandwich this is on par with the typical costs for vietnamese sandwiches, but is without peer in terms of quality.

Only problem is that it is hard to find parking around here. Oh well...my $70 dollar ticket was worth it.
author: Rondeep C.

description: Great tofu sandwiches.  Can be a long line around lunchtime (10:30-2), but for vegetarians it's well worth the wait!
author: Tim C.

description: I'm writing this review as I'm chewing down my last bit of my roast chicken bahn mi sandwich. Hands down, this was the best Vietnamese sandwich I have ever eaten. So good it makes you want to slap yo mama...then rush off to write a yelp review. Luckily I work only a couple blocks away, I'll be hitting up this place several times a week.
author: james m.

description: I know many things, but the thing I know best is food. I have been eating Vietnamese sandwiches since I've had teeth and I've tried them all around the bay area, in Southern Cali and in New York. Hands down, Saigon Sandwich has the best sandwiches available. From the slightly warmed french bread and just the right amount of mayo, to the tangy crispy julienned carrots and fresh cilantro and jalepeno. Not to mention the flavorful variety of meats. I could and would eat these everyday of my life if my fat didn't love storing in my body! You won't be disappointed and at $3 a piece, get them all!!!!!!!
author: Marilyn N.

description: Roast chicken bahn mi. $3.25! Cheapest and best lunch ever! Sweet and savory gravy sauce with chunks of roast chicken, cilantro, jalapeno, pickled radish and carrots...it was superb! This hole in the wall is authentic Vietnamese sandwiches and other deli stuff. Don't be scared, just try it!
author: N Justine K.

description: Yumyumyum. On good faith my bf said this place was better than Huong Lang in Sacramento so I tried it. And boy was he right! Everytime we come to the city I beg him to take me here but since he grew up eating here all the time he's very reluctant to take me :( I could live off eating a banh mi ga from here for lunch everyday.. If only I lived out there :(((
author: Tammy M.

description:
Returned to Saigon Sandwiches with my Mom, Aunt and Cousin-- I met them after they had morning tea in Ghirardelli Square, so this was very much the opposite of where they had just come from.  I wasn't ashamed though because I knew Saigon Sandwiches wouldn't let me down!  I was a little afraid the quality might not be so great given that it's the holiday time, but everything was excellent.

I was tempted to ding them one star on this follow up review for the lady giving me sort've a mean look after she misunderstood my order.  I didn't realize she had already taken my cousin's order so we duplicated one sandwich.  Not a problem though--I decided I might as well buy the extra sandwich which we gobbled up no problem.

Went to my usual place (in front of the Asian Art museum) to enjoy the sandwiches.  Not as sunny initially but then the sun came through!  Today the bread seemed extra fresh and my cousin from Boston agreed, (that the sandwiches were) "amazing".  I'm glad I was able to share this little gem with her!  Jen S, maybe you should give this place another try.  A one star rating is a little harsh...clearly the large number of reviews on this place can't be wrong!  :P
author: Christopher W.

description:
Ordered a Chicken Bahn Mi.  

I liked the bread at Lee's better.  I feel like Lee's have crunchier rolls.

But they do have more chicken in the sandwich at Lee's.

However, I didn't taste any pate spread I normally taste at other places, maybe it was absorbed by the doughy bread.
