Wasn't that great, but wasn't bad either...just taste like any other Vietnamese sandwiches I've had but with a tadbit more meat but not as much other ingredients (pate, no pickled daikon, etc).
author: e c.

description: It is totally worth a stroll through The Loin for this sandwich. The best sandy is worth getting shot for. Just kidding, kids (sort of). I'm no foodie, but the flavors that were dancing on me taste buds after one bite of the pork meatball transported me out of the hood and to a tropical island. Delicious! Plus, it's only $3.50!!!!!!! I'm buying a box cutter and going back tomorrow. Next time I'm trying the pork. Go get one. Oh, just kidding about the box cutter. Sort of.
author: Lianne S.

description: 1st time eating here. Purchased 2 pork sandwiches for my wife and I for $7! What a deal! I should have purchased an extra one for myself. The sandwich is so basic, yet full of flavor. I also like how the lady working behind the counter takes 10 orders at once and then cranks 'em out.
author: Mike V.

description: While, I did enjoy my $2.50 chicken sandwich here, the chicken was a bit mushy.  Quick service.  Good portion.  Nice crisp and hot jalepeno peppers.  I just don't think it's as good as the other place I get this item on Kearny, Latte Express.  Though this place is slightly cheaper and no sales tax.  But I wasn't wowed enough to go out of my way any time soon.  Also, at night, the after-effects of the excessive salt became aparent as I had to down a ton of water all night.  It's good to know, though, that the smack addicts have a good cheap meal option with this place existing as long as they decide to budget a little of their government check for food.
author: Marc S.

description: I love, love, LOVE this place. I love the su mai (meat ball), the best. It has a yummy sweet taste.  Too bad it's not close to my place cause I will buy it every week.
author: Mandy D.

description: My co-worker Pauline, showed me this place.  They have $3 Tofu sandwiches!  Yea, food for the vegetarian.  It tastes so juicy and soft.  They make their bread fresh.  Next time I'm going to get a dessert.  Tons of stuff you can pick from along the wall.  Drinks, snacks and so on.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Cheap and delicious!  

So much so that I'll overlook the cramped seating, long lines, and sometimes the lack of acknowledgment from the sandwich lady.
author: Dorothy N.

description: How can you not enjoy crack head watching while waiting in line to order? This is where I ate my very first Vietnamese sandwich, almost a year ago. The only Vietnamese sandwich better than this, for me, is at another hole in the wall restaurant in San Leandro. I get the combination pork and I die every time because the taste is so overwhelmingly delicious, then I come back to life to finish eating it. I'm sure people have had better sandwiches elsewhere but this little gem has my loyalty.
author: Heather M.

description: this is my first time having a banh mi sandwich.  It was soooo good.  The pork was perfectly marinated and melt in your mouth delicious.  The carrots were so crispy and gave the sandwich an extra crunchy texture.  the bread was so warm and crispy and soo good.  The best sandwich i've had in san francisco so far.  I highly recommend this sandwich shop, even though it feels like your'e walking through the ghetto just to get there.  Just put your blinders on and walk briskly through the streets and you'll be fine.  Please everyone, do yourselves a favor and try one of these sandwiches.  You will not be disappointed.
author: Juan A.

description: If you looking for a best sandwich in sf at a very reasonable price this is the place to go to. They have the best sandwich, I always get the grill chicken and can never get enough of it :)
author: Phuong N.

description: I will be the first to admit, the thought of one of these sandwiches initially didn't do anything for me. I work super close by this gem and hadn't ever tried their sandwiches. That is, until about a month ago when I was STARVING and BROKE. I was reading random reviews on Yelp when I found the reviews for Saigon Sandwiches. And it sounded HELLA good, so I decided to take a chance and try it. I am so glad I did. This is, hands down, one of the tastiest sandwiches I've ever eaten. I've never eaten bahn mi anywhere else, so I can't make a comparison. And I can only vouch for the Roast Pork (haven't tried chicken or fanci pork) But I am obsessed.
author: Elle F.

description:
yum yum cheap cheap yum yum 

Do not skip the fresh jalapeno on the sandwich, it's the seal on the deal.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Woah! This is definitely the best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had, and by far. Lee's doesn't even compare to this even one bit. My friends argue that Lee's has a better bread but for me it's actually better at Saigon. And no doubt about the ingredients inside, it's much much better at Saigon. 

I normally order the special combination which is the weird processed pork stuff, pate, and I think it might have bbq pork in there too. I always ask for extra jalapenos for extra kick. The pickled radish and carrot is so yummy. I've also had the bbq chicken sandwich which is just slightly less amazing but still awesome. It's cheap like 2.50-3 dollars per sandwich and it's big so you can eat half of one or one and take one for later. If you put it in the oven to reheat, the bread will still be crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside even the next day. 

Last time I took one and some beer to Dolores park during a nice day with friends. I'd recommend this to anyone!
author: Mastiff B.

description:
Crunchy, spicy, chewy. Packed.


I was eating my first VN sandwich with someone I didn't know very well & ended up with a variety of delicious ingredients stuck in my teeth & hanging out of my mouth.


THAT'S how good it was.


I'll go back for the Styrofoam-bottomed, saran-wrapped packages of spring rolls, imperial rolls, rice & delicious stuff.
author: Yasi S.

description:
Best 2 Buck Sandwich. Period.

Still it is a little ghetto and I wouldn't be surprised if vermin occupied the same space but it's good so I'd rather just pick up a sandwich and not think about the possible contents that could surface in that definition of a hole in the wall place!
author: Kat R.

description:
I tried Saigon again today for lunch. Instead of getting that greasy mess called a "Tofu Sandwich", I got the "Fancy Pork", which is really just cha lua (steamed pork).

Everything was perfection this time. More than enough fresh, crispy, pickled carrots. The bread was toasted nicely, not soggy or overly chewy like last time. The combination of mayo, salt, pepper, and cha lua was very reminiscent of my Vietnamese grandmother on Sunday afternoons :)
author: Michelle N.

description:
I love this place when i'm craving for viet sandwhiches.  they're not stingy about the stuff they put in your sandwhich and its sooo cheap too! but why did i gave them 4 stars?  Because i called in to place an order and whoever answered the phone gave me ATTITUDES!!! that's a bad sign!  Which is werid, because it never happened before (but then again, i havent been back for awhile)  Anyways, i got so mad i went to the one on Irving.  

They should fired that lady b/c one of my friends encountered a very similar experience (in person) and the sandwhiches weren't the same.. only a few slices of meat.  I guess it depends on who is working.. 

Where's that nice lady at??? (not to be mean, she's the chubbier one) Am i the only one+my friend having problems with this place??
author: Anna W.

description: upgrade to 4 stars.  here is the trick.  dont get mayo.  they tend to put heaps on the sandwhich, but if you leave it off, it is pretty good.  I am giving 4 stars because it is probably the best bahn mi I have had in the bay area so far.  I still would like the bread to be more fresh, but they toast it and without the gobs of mayo, you can actually enjoy the textural experience of the crunchy toasted bread.  Last time I wanted to give 3.5 stars but rounded down.  This time I still think it is a 3.5, but sans mayo, I will round up.
author: Scott C.

description:
oh man, I may venture to say, the best bahn-mi in san francisco.

sometimes there are lines but they move fast, and its worth it! Get more than one and heat it up later and its still good mmm
author: Noah P.

description: Its a small store and there always seems to be a line outside no matter what time.  Calling in your order helps.  Ive tried the chicken and roast pork but The COMBINATION is the way to go at a decent price - under $4.
author: she q.

description: As the whitest Jewish girl you've ever seen, you may wonder, what does SHE know about vietnamese sandwhiches....Well I  tknow o venture to the LOIN for this gem!
author: Lindsay G.

description:
There is a reason why this place always have a line.  From early morning, you'll see hords of people in chef's outfits from the nearby Culinary Academy buying sandwiches from here.  First impression ... if these future chefs like this place so much, it must be worth the wait.

The buns are toasted, the meats are always flavorful and juicy.  The sandwiches are not huge, but a pretty good portion for one meal for me.

I consider this place one of my favorite "hole in the wall" places for food.

Neighborhood's not the best, but not exactly the worst either.
author: Winnie C.

description:
uhhhh wtf happen to the sandwiches here. I mean its still good, but wtf... it's not as good as before. Seriously...... i was so disappointed this afternoon. 

But what the hey! It's only $2.50 cheap eats.. but just not as good. =( 

as Tuan D. said irving cafe and deli is still better!
author: Brian P.

description:
My friend and I went here to order some sandwiches to go and eat out in front of City Hall on one of the first clear and warm-ish days after that huge rainstorm last week.  It really hit the spot.  Filling yet light.  Every bite has a mix of sweet, savory, spicy, etc flavors.  I couldn't think of a better meal than a Vietnamese sandwich that day. And in reality, it's hard to think of too many other foods better than a Vietnamese sandwich...
...And they do them right at Saigon Sandwiches.

edit:
Today they accidentally gave me a chicken sandwich rather than tofu.  It took me a few minutes to get back and let them know about the mix up, but they were more than friendly about getting me the correct order and even adding a little extra tofu than normal in my sandwich. I have to give them props for that.
author: daniel m.

description:
Cheap.  $2.75 for a pork sandwich.

Long line out the door.  

Not a very clean place.

Good sandwich but not something I would get on a regular basis.
author: Marina T.

description:
This is my favorite Vietnamese Sandwich Shop! True, it's located in a sketchy neighborhood but the sandwich makes up for it. It's hard to find a delicious meal under $5 these days but this place is great!

I come here occasionally whenever I'm in the neighborhood. This time I got the Combination Vietnamese Sandwich for $3.75. If you enjoy more meat than vegetables(though it still has plenty of pickled veggies) then you should get this sandwich. It was good, but I've noticed many people ordering the Roast Pork Sandwich which I will definitely order next time around.

I will definitely come back, can't wait!
author: Michelle L.

description:
best vietnamese sandwich i've had...and for $3, how do you beat that! try the roast pork, it was amazzzzzing!

note: this is pretty much a take out place. there's only a small table for two off to the corner of this small shop.
author: Cindy H.

description: Pretty good authentic Vietnamese sandwiches.  I like their BBQ pork sandwich, along with that juicy meat, and super soft rolls, I can agree with the countless loyalist, that this is one of the best places in San Francisco to get a Vietnamese Sandwich.  Get there early during lunch times, with this economy the lines can get pretty long.
author: J Y.

description: No.  Too sweet and not enough chilies.  The bread was not the best either.  If I want a chicken banh mi I will go to Cafe Dolci or Irving Street Deli.
author: Bleep S.

description:
So, at the risk of sounding like a follower, I, too, love me some Saigon Sandwich action.  For $3 you get a delicious sandwich.  So delicious, in fact, your friend Brian will lie to you and tell you he wants to meet you for lunch, just so he can justify the Bart ride it takes to get him to Saigon Sandwiches.  :)

Go either before noon or after 12:30 and you won't get stuck in line.

Enjoy.
author: Melissa S.

description: If you're around the area and short of cash, need something good to eat, this is the place to go. Try the meatball sandwich. For $3.25, you can't beat it.
author: ben s.

description:
Finally checked out Saigon Sandwiches on an early Sunday afternoon.  Arrived to a line, but not out the door.  After ordering the roast pork sandwich and the Styrofoam tray of spring rolls, I took the two window seats with a friend.

Despite the not-so-faint smell of urine lingering in the air (source unknown: possibly a customer waiting in line), I really enjoyed the meal.  Now that's saying something about the sandwiches here.  The spring rolls didn't rise to level of the sandwich, and that might've had something to do with eating them at room temperature.

No digestive problems to speak of.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Leon R.

description:
This place has the best Vietnamese sandwiches in town!!  They are way better than ones from Little Paris which I grew up eating. The ones here are much more flavorful.  I ordered the chicken while the bf had the pork.  I took a bite of his and it was equally as good as mines.  We also had the spring rolls, only complaint was the sauce for the rolls was watered down..I like sauce to be thick and creamy.  

They run out of sandwiches pretty early so don't go there at 4pm expecting to get your bahn mi fix.  Believe me, I've been turned down several times.  For the prices, I don't know how they do it.  I suppose their rent may be cheap considering it's located in the Tenderloin.  So don't expect anything fancy about this place expect for good food at a cheap price.
author: hello k.

description:
Despite the bread being not quite up to Baguette Express' high standards, Saigon Sandwiches currently gets my vote for best Banh Mi in San Francisco.

Saigon Sandwiches easily has the tastiest Vietnamese Sandwich fillings in the city, especially the meatballs.

If a sandwich is equally about bread and filling, Saigon Sandwich is still the best in the city.
author: Suo L.

description:
It is 2007, I dare you to find a better sandwich for $2.50. Subway, whose sandwiches taste like they were made by robots even charges $2.99 for their daily special. Get the pork or the chicken, can definitely ask for it spicy. I work in Union Square and affordable lunch options include bringing food from home and not eating, so once I realized I can scoot over to the tenderloin lickety split, relief washed over me like a cool wave. 
g
ps. you can call in your order, if you are in a hurry!
author: Gabe b.

description:
Another surprising gem of  the tenderloin (well not so surprising if you see their lunch line or read yelp).  Saigon Sandwiches is a small shop that definitely is more than meets the eye.  While it's a little grungy and the seating area is only large enough for about three people, the food is excellent.  

The primary selling point is most certainly the price, for how little is paid you get a good size sandwich.  The large baguette roll is warm and fresh and theres is literally dressings falling out the sides.  While I'm sure theres not much else to be said that the over 400 reviews couldn't have expressed, this place will delight anybody and is one of the best deals in the city.  I would recommend that anybody visiting the city at least once check out Saigon Sandwiches.
author: Paige C.

description:
$2.75 for a warm, crusty french roll filled with your choice of roasted meat, pickled vegetables, fresh jalapeno, and cilantro? 

Hell yeah!

The BEST Vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Oh sweetness.  I've been kicking it at Baguette Express for the past 3 days.  I've read the reviews about this place and hauled ass to get a sandwich before work.
DUDES.
This place is amazing.  The little ladies are quick, the sandwiches are packed with goodies, and the prices are the same as Baguette Express ($3).  
The difference is, this place is yummier and the bread isn't as dry.  All in all, I'm a fan of both but would give a slight edge to SS.
author: Meh M.

description: I have been coming here since I was like 7 years old and this place has the best vietnamese sandwiches I have ever had. Good prices, great food. The place is small though, and you might have to wait a while if it's busy. It's totally worth it though. Lee's is across the street but theirs can't compare to this place!
author: Tiffany P.

description: Best sandwich place in the area, always a line through the door (but quick service) and verrrry affordable. Just be aware of the cash-only policy.
author: Jessica W.

description: I took everyone's advice and ordered the Special Combination & Pate... deelish! I went there Saturday around 10am and there was no line at all.
author: Teresa F.

description:
so i went here today to see what all the hype was about and all i have to say is meh.

i got the roast pork sandwich with extra pate and a combination which i've yet to eat (i'm putting that thru the next day test to see if it's still good tmrw).

bread: 3 stars. crispy in some parts, not so crunchy on others. for me a good banh mi has ALOT to do with how good the bread is and how crunchy it is after each bite and i have to say that Saigon Sandwiches was just avg for that.

roast pork: 3.5 stars. meat was tender and it wasn't tough to chew which is a good thing for me, but it was the taste. i like my roast pork a lil bit saltier.

pate: 4.5 stars. omg... sooooooooooo good!!!!! i haven't had a pate that was this good since i was 7 and that pate came from Banh Mi Saigon down in SoCal (which has gone down in quality since then). 

do chua: 5 stars. then again it's do chua so u can't go wrong with it in my opinion. 

so even tho they separated my do chua form my sandwiches like i wanted, i had really big expectations for them and i was a tad bit disappointed. so i'll have to give them 3. i would actually give them 3.5 stars but yelp doesn't allow for that. would i actually go out of my way to go here again and try another sandwich? yea why not? tho next time i'd prolly just get the pate. haha. :) i heart pate. MY all-time favorite banh mi place is still Banh Mi Che Cali down in So Cal btw Brookhurst & McFadden. That place consistently performs well with their banh mi thit nuong and their viet mayo. mmmm i drool thinking about those sandwiches.
author: Anne H.

description:
so i was skeptical at hearing how 'good' this place was...im from the southbay which has soooo many options for banh mi (my fave being huong lan in milpitas), that i didn't think that this was going to be nearly as good.  but upon finding the small store with a long line and two old ladies vigorously making sandwiches, my hopes shot up.

the banh mi here are GOOD.  probably the BEST ive had
the bread is very good.  crunchy on the outside, spongey on the inside.  its loaded with slightly pickled carrots.  
the meats are good.

i've had the banh mi ga (chicken) and the banh mi thit (pork) both are delcious, although id have to give the edge to the chicken sandwich

too bad they close at 6 or else i'd probly come here more often
author: Arthur T.

description:
Your sandwich is he best I ever I tried. Everyone go to Saigon Sandwichrestaurang. So, please go ahead try it i guarantee you will like it on your tongue.

4154006236
author: H. V.

description:
I was really looking forward to this sandwhich...so disappointed...to brave the trip thru the Tenderloin, when we found the place...I asked for roast chicken-and got chopped, pressed chicken lunchmeat...way too much salty meat to the itty bitty amount of veggies/cilantro/jalapenos, and no pickled ginger, no cucumber, no mint leaves? The bread was great...the pigeons appreciated the lunchmeat. Sorry guys...
and the price is 3.50 now.

Someone earlier asked about a Bahn Mi place in SJ...uh, you mean Huong Lan's??? real chicken, stuffed with veggies-carrot, daikon and cucumber, pickled ginger, cilantro LEAVES and mint leaves,
soooo good....so hungry.....and 2.50...
huge...
author: Juno R.

description: Hands down my favorite Banh Mi place because they give you some much pate - even though I bit into the plastic pate wrapping that got stuffed into the sandwhich the last time I was there - it's still the best Vietnamese sandwhich I've had
author: Nin J.

description: I'm just a yuppie gal from the peninsula - but I really, really love food. This was my first banh mi ever - so I'm no expert ,but I have to say: Ditto to all the other favorable reviews on Yelp. These sandwiches were awesome. Spicy, salty, tangy sweet in perfect balance with super-fresh toasted bread, crispy veggies and sweet succulent meat. I arrived at 11:35 and there was already a line. Beats a boring turkey deli sandwich any old day!
author: Cindy W.

description:
For SF it's a 5.  for LA it's a 4.  the bread and pork could be better.  but for all intents and purposes, this is the best place in SF.

its cheap, its good, and its usually fast unless you come during the lunch rush.  

come here.  it's good.  err don't come here, since that means it'll get more crowded.
author: Jason J.

description: Phenomenal Vietnamese sandwiches in the Loin area. Period. Can you believe that it can be had for less than $3.50?
author: G J J.

description:
For $12 my girlfriend picked up three delicious (2 fanci pork and 1 veggie) sandwich with two coconut waters. 

The bread was solid, ingredients were fresh and sauce was on point. For $12, what more can you ask for? 

I see some folks griping about this place not being up to par with "City's Best", but the truth is that you will not find a better specimen for the price. 

They will see my dollars again.
author: Dominico A.

description:
Doesn't matter if we don't know what fancy meat it. It's delicious.

Favorites:

Fancy-meat sandwich with spicy jalapenos
Three-colored coconut milk dessert drink to cool you off.
author: Will W.

description: By far my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place, EVER.  The insane price, the super speed, and the delicious pate sandwich makes me come here almost every weekend.  I'm glad they aren't right next to my house, otherwise I'd eat here every day.
author: Kryzak K.

description:
I am from NY and we have better bahn mi. Hands down.  

However, while I visit other parts of the country which are able to provide this tasty sandwich option, I have to respect and try it.  

Saigon Sandwich was relatively close by to our hotel, so I decided to take a long walk and pick up a couple of sandwiches.  This place is in the heart of Tenderloin, not the loveliest part of town to walk into for a lunch option, but during a business day, daytime, its ok.  The place is no nonsense: two ladies, making sandwiches at mach-1 speed.. almost.  While I waited, several orders of 6 or more sandwiches came in, all completed, wrapped, and ready to go, under 10 minutes!  But I arrived in the afternoon, no lunch hour traffic during my order....

I ordered their traditional and chicken bahn mi for comparison.  Both were tasty, not as spicy as we prefer.  Unlike other reviews, my order came with fresh, crispy bread. No complaints there.  Where I'd like to see some improvement is the sauce, its abit more bland than the East Coast best.  This could be a contender for the best West Coast bahn mi, as soon as they step up their spice level and sauce flavor game.

Let the competition begin, Saigon Sandwich ladies!
author: Yulia G.

description:
I've been to Vietnam twice and haven't found a Vietnamese sandwich better than the ones here.

Always a line out the door, and always delicious.
author: Angela G.

description:
Amazing! Every time! The perfect whole in the wall. 

Worth the wait. Get the special combination! 

I highly suggest getting 2 sandos because you're going to want another half immediately and then the remaining half is perfect for a snack later that day or the next.
author: Peter C.

description: Not really sure what all the fuss is about for this place.  Yeah, $3.75 is cheap for a sandwich, but I've had far better bahn mi then they serve here.  Had the pork sandwich.  Bread was too hard and the pork was dry and had no flavor.  Most likely will not return.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I loved it. I picked up two sandwiches and split them with my boyfriend. a great way to test the waters. 

i'll fully admit that i was a littl confused by the ordering process.. you get in line and wait for the clerk, she takes about 10 people's orders and then disappears to make the sandwiches. 3 minutes later, she reappears with 30 sandwiches and starts handing them out. (BRILLIANT) 

i'll probably try a different dessert the next time i go there - i tried something that resembled banana pudding, but more firm. can't say i'd have it again. 

the spring rolls looked excellent, too!
author: Heidi L.

description:
I never thought I liked banh mi sandwiches until I came to this place in the freakin' ghetto during my lunch hour.

For $2.75.. it can't be beat!  With a canned drink, it was a whopping $3.50.  My favorite is the chicken sandwich with extra peppers.  If you are a wimpy-wimp, omit the peppers cause they will put your mouth on fire.  I think I can eat this stuff every freakin' day of the week.. OMG.

Only bummer is that the line can be long at times.. but it's well worth the wait.  Some of the little items on the counter (wrapped) are worth trying.. like the fresh spring rolls with shrimp or the rice-"plates".  

FABOO!
author: Nancy H.

description:
Today, I stopped by Saigon Sandwiches and honestly can say I prefer Saigon more so than Little Paris. The bread was warm, the pork tender and moist with a light sweetness . My favorite part was the carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, mayo topping which really complimented the pork. I basically inhaled the sandwich while power walking my way home. By the time I reached my front door, all I had left was crumbs.

Since there are two other places that sell Vietnamese sandwiches within 2 block radius, I can only at this time give Saigon 4 Stars. I plan to check out Baguette Express and Lee's first and then do a more comprehensive taste test to determine which one has the winning BBQ pork sandwich. Bring on the pigs!
author: Sophie C.

description:
There are two ladies running the whole shop, at least when I was there...the wait was rather long, (I went during lunch), but this was hands down the best sandwich I've had for $2.50. 

Sidenote: I like that their french bread isn't super duper hard like other  places.
author: Emily A.

description:
God. seriously the best vietnamese sandwiches i've ever had. and the best part is that it's so cheap! yours for only 2 dollars or so. oh how that toasty bread hugs that carrot-onion mix, cilantro, peppers, sauce, and fancy pork, my fave! i grew up on these sandwiches and so this i believe will be a lifelong addiction.

however, i have no desire to know what that sauce is made of...
author: Faye P.

description:
Ahh yes, yet another Vietnamese sandwich shop to check off my list!

I was surprised by how small and unassuming this place is.  It looks more like a corner convenience store than a sandwich shop.  But decor aside, this place was packed at 3pm, not exactly the most popular meal time.

Got meself a roast pork sandwich.  Freshly toasted baguette, good amount of fillings, etc.  I thought the roast pork itself was ok, a bit lacking in flavor actually.  Same goes for the other fillers like the pickled carrots.

All in all, a solid Vietnamese sandwich.  Generous portions and tasty.  Def hits the spot.  Could be more flavorful though.
author: Adrian L.

description:
Their grilled chicken sandwiches are YUMMY!
Their sandwiches are very cheap ($3 to $3.5) too.

Understanding the menu is a bit challenging.  Ga is chicken and Thit is pork.
Also, they only have 2 seats at the entrance.  You either need to be very lucky to find a seat there or need to know where you'll be eating at.  This is not really the best neighborhood in downtown SF.
author: Durif M.

description:
............this place is most excellent. I always come here to satisfy my sometimes INSANE crave and urge to eat vietnamese sandwiches. Saigon sandwich is the shining light at the end of my tunnel, rock to my scissors, wind beneath my wings; not only do I look forward to it, it is my alpha, my fulfillment of hope as a beacon to my desires. Up until now, I nearly lost all hope in finding a FOOD worthy of 5 stars. Ran by 2 vietnamese women, this hole in the wall is somewhat hard to spot.. if you don't know where to look. I always come here to get either the Fanci Pork Sandwich or the Roast Chicken Sandwich. Both are good, but I prefer the roast chicken sandwich. The meat is very succulent and tender, rips right to the bite; it is juicy, and made perfectly with love from the dainty fingers of its maker. The hot pepper, cilantro, and other mini vegetables inside the sandwiches are very fresh, springy, and crunchy. The BEST part of this sandwich that deserves to be spotligtted is the bread. The bread is crunchy, yet soft. I don't know exactly how to put it, but the bread is very well balanced. It is crunchy, but not jagged crunchy, soft, but not in a damp way, and delicious, but not overpowering to the meat. The bread is very good. 

Waiting in line at this popular destination, and watching the sandwich chefs create magic and delight, I can tell lots of love and pride is put into each individual sandwich. Alongside this fact, the workers are quite sanitary, as they put on gloves to handle the exchange of money.. oh yah, speaking of money, the sandwiches are only 3 dollars............ need i say more?
author: simon k.

description: Really, what more is there to say?  Had the BBQ chicken... its was delish!  The chicken has great flavor (kind of like the 5 spice chicken) and there was a lot of it!  Plenty of veggies too... overall, an excellent sandwich at a great price!
author: Tom N.

description: The place is tiny but the sandwiches it produces are big. The menu is pretty simple and the price is unbeatable. A+
author: mc a.

description: DISAPPOINTMENT!!!!!! tried it for the first time to see what the fuss is all about... i ordered a special combo n all i see inside is a HUGE slab of messy pate oozing out of the bread and a couple of dried old cuts of cha lua... is that what they consider special?? there are no cucumbers or green onions or "special meats" inside.... I shall remain loyal to my favorite vietnamese sandwich place HOANG DAT CAFE!!!
author: Moesha N.

description: Just had a double steam and roast pork sandwich.  I love this place.  They are great.    There was even a line at 1:30pm today, when it only takes them two minutes to make these sandwiches.   Parking is not easy, but that the city. They are great when they are hot; they are still pretty good when it is cold. I usually try to eat it in the car, but then I get it all over the place.  I just have to find a good pit stop to hide and eat after I pick up those sandwiches.
author: Walter C.

description:
Well, the 755 reviews before me (I have not read them all) must be all the folks in line before me until I learned that you better be there by no later than 11:30 on a weekday and 10:30 on a weekend.

There's only one Vietnamese sandwich that's equal or better and it's in Orange County. It's called a "Long Sandwich" because it's on a Baguette that's long and thin. According to my many Viet friends down there it's the authentic one. 

I found another one on 6TH Avenue  between Clement & Geary but the bread is not as good...it's good but it's lots of white French bread.
I think it's called Little Vietnamese Sandwich Shop and indeed it's little but there are stools and a counter inside for about 6 people and a couple of tables outside for nice weather.
author: Lee S.

description: Mediocre at best, all it has going for it is the price. I'd much rather pay 75 cents extra and go to Irving Deli and Cafe, which not only has tastier sandwiches but better service.
author: Samu S.

description: While I heard sooo many raves about this place, I'll admit I was scared to trust the food quality based on the looks of this place. However, I finally gave it a whirl this weekend and I totally get what all the hype is about! I shared a pork meatball and a pate sandwich with my boyfriend. The pork meatball was absolutely delicious, and the bread is to die for!!! Where do they find such good bread??  I wasn't as big a fan of the pate but I don't like pate that much so i wouldn't read much into that. I will definitly be back for more pork meatball sandiches for sure. And at $4 a sandwich you can't go wrong!
author: Lindsay A.

description:
i crave the sandwiches here, especially the tofu sandwich.  tofu, you say?  tiffany eats tofu?  Yes, i do, because it's in a very tasty sauce and they give you enough to fill you up!

i used to eat the pate sandwich - just pate - but everytime i thought i was going to have a heart attack because they give you soooo much of it.

tip: call ahead and place your order (though they may mess it up), or go at a weird time (like, not noon).
author: Tiffany D.

description: Everyone knows about Saigon! Haven't you heard the hype?! Well, it's not my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place in the city, but I am a fan. I usually indulge in pork and pork product variations of Banh Mi. That's my ish and that's what I get everywhere else, sometimes because pork is the only thing on the menu. I can't say Saigon makes the best pork sandwiches though. Other than their "pate" sandwich, with mashed pork liver gushing out of every bite, I don't really care for the other pork items. I do appreciate the poultry and vegetarian options. I think I visit this place mostly for those options. The "roast chicken" is juicier than the "roast pork," surprisingly. The sauce is a little sweet but still delish! The "tofu" is wet and sloppy. I usually walk outta there immediately munching on my order, but I can't do that with the "tofu." That wet, sloppy, sticky sandwich requires a bib and a nearby sink! Flavor is on point though. Overall, I don't think it's the most authentic Banh Mi spot, but you will catch me in that ridiculous line every now and then. My white friends love it!
author: Helen L.

description:
Somehow, despite suggestions from trusted sources on all sides, I had never tried a Vietnamese sandwich until a few months back.  The inaugural sandwich was from an unmemorable place in Chinatown, and was not that exciting.

Saigon on the other hand, is everything that a sandwich should be. 

The pork is the way to go, I get mine without mayonnaise, and the $3 price tag seriously calls into question every other sandwich in one's life that has cost more and satisfied less.

Mm peppers.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Small clean sandwich shop with really authentic French influenced Vietnamese sandwiches.  Hit the spot today!
author: Jameson B.

description: One of the bEST Bahn Mi sandwiches I've had.
author: Stephanie N.

description: Best Banh Mi in SF...yes...BEST!  With $3 - $3.50 per sandwich average...can't beat that!
author: Patrick C.

description:
My favorite Viet Sandwich shop in the Bay!  The rest don't compare!
Everytime I walk out with my chicken sandwich, I head straight to my car and eat!  Yeah, I usually eat my sandwich while I'm driving because it's soo good!
author: Henri C.

description: My coworker said he was going to get some Vietnamese Sandwiches for lunch and if anybody wanted anything.  Being the super whiteboy that I am, I had never eaten a Vietnamese Sandwich before in my life.  I chose the chicken, and let me just say that this is honestly one of the best sandwiches, Vietnamese or otherwise, that I had ever tasted.  The chicken was moist and tender, the veggies were fresh, including the fresh Jalepenos, the bread was fresh, the pickled veggies were awesome, and all in all the sandwich was filling and delicious.  I can't wait to go to Saigon for myself and try the other items on the menu.
author: David M.

description: Drove all the way from San Diego just to check out this place. Even in the cold San Francisco weather, we waited about 10 minutes for the roasted pork sandwich. So worth it. I think the bread we had was a little on the hard side, but nonetheless the sandwich was the best vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. Ate the sandwich in the car because there was not much seating area in the tiny shop. I will definitely be back!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Having just relocated from the east coast, I was curious to find a great SF banh mi.  These sandwiches tend to be sweeter than I'm used to and I haven't found one with head cheese (my favorite part).  That being said, the toasted baguette is a great crusty counterpoint to the pate and various fillings.  The roast pork's sweet sauciness is nice contrasted with the heat of the jalapeno.  All in, a great start in the search for the best banh mi.  For those concerned about the neighborhood, the immediate area is fine. I feel perfectly safe.
author: Ed C.

description:
Excellent sandwiches-- archtypical banh mi.   

Have patience, this place's is no secret to the working lunch crowd.

A perfect takeaway lunch before hitting up the Asian Art Museum down the street.
author: E C.

description: I've never had banh mi before... but this was delish. We got a chicken and a pork banh mi and they were both great (I think the pork was slightly better). This place is really small... so don't expect to eat there. But it's so cheap! $3.25 for a sandwich is pretty awesome. I have to try more banh mi in order to properly rate this place, but hey, for now I say it's definitely worth a trip!
author: Melissa H.

description:
tofu + amazing bread + spicy cilantro goodness +$3 = best

damn the lines and damn the TL
author: Cori W.

description: I walked here for lunch today. There's always a line out the door, but it goes quickly 5 min tops.   It's a great small "hole in th wall" type of find.  The sandwiches all range between $3 to $3.50.  My personal favorite is the $3.50 combination.  The heated baguette has the perfect crunch to it.  I'm a stickler when it comes to finding the perfect baguetter.  I don't like mine too soggy nor too hard and crunchy .  My only wish is that there was indoor seating.  There are a 2-3 counter seats inside that's used more for waiting purposes. It's definitely more of a take-out sandwich stop.
author: Stacey L.

description:
BLAH!!  This place was not good.  I've had my fair share of Vietnamese sandwiches and this place is not good.  The pate is crappy, the bread is only so-so..  and the veggies are alright.

Perhaps I'm spoiled.  I've been to Vietnamese sandwich joints that bake their own bread, the veggies taste freshly pickled and they don't put some sweet teriyaki sauce on the sandwich.  They use Maggi!!  Much better.

This place gets a thumbs down from me.
author: Em M.

description:
Just returned from a trip to SF and had a great time eating around town.  Thanks to all for the reviews.  It made for a much better trip, better food and better finds - like Saigon Sandwiches.

I don't have much to add to all the creative and funny reviews that are already here other than we had great results getting a chicken, a pork, and a meatball for $8 bucks was a fantastic deal.  

We were really not sure what a combo was - combo of what?  There seemed to be some confusion even among the regulars as to what they were getting on the combo.  However for $2.50 who cares - jest get it and enjoy or if you're too full give it to the homeless drug addict yelling at the top of his lungs to nobody in particular - NOOOOO! NOOOOO!

Anyway, great spot that us out-of-towners would have never found or gone to without the reviews.
author: Mark M.

description:
Coming from San Jose, the Vietnamese capital of the Bay Area (and possibly the west coast), I know a banh mi sandwich.  I grew up eating them all the time.  And being Vietnamese myself, I think I know what a good Vietnamese sandwich should taste like.

And trust me, since moving to San Francisco, I have been searching for good Vietnamese food that can hold a candle to average restaurants in San Jose.  And as far as a good Vietnamese sandwich goes, this place meets that standard.
author: Phillip H.

description:
$2.50 is all it takes to get you full with a sandwich that was worth waiting 10+ minutes in line for.  This place is a sleeper.. It is located in one of the worst parts of the city.  Homeless people scattered along the road, daytime drunkards preaching about life, drug infested skeleton men(or were they women?).  Double parked UPS, Police, Best Buy trucks, FedEX, USPS, Firetrucks, US Military tanks, and even the USS Enterprise set the streetside wall to this place.  This shop is exactly one step in and the next step your out.  There is like romantic table for 2.. exactly 2 seats in the whole place. 

Jokes aside, I recommend the Xiu Mai (meatball pork) sandwich.. and be careful the sandwich can get really spicy =)  Definately a lunch break destination for budget oriented people =D
author: Benny S.

description:
Forget price. Forget atmosphere.  We're talking about Banh Mi.  It's always dirt cheap and fast. Always one of my favorite foods.

I knew Lee's Sandwiches years before moving to SF.  I love Lee's.  Yet, I wanted to cheat on Mr. and Mrs. Lee with the sandwiches at Saigon, just once.

The lowdown: Get the roast pork.  Go early when the bread is fresh.  And whatever you do, stay the hell away from the fancy pork.  It's mold injected pork meal with pockets of ground mystery meat.  Tasteless and cold, two things that any Banh Mi purist will agree violate the principles of proper Banh Mi design.

Minus one star for not offering barbeque red pork.  Minus one star for the terrible fancy pork.

On a positive note, I saw there is a Lee's across the street a block up. My basic rule of thumb is to count culture in your choice of restaurant.  Saigon had a strange mix of people from all over.  Very nice.  Lee's seemed to be catering mostly to the Little Saigon locals.

That being said, you might want to think twice about Saigon Sandwiches and give Lee's a try.  Though, on price alone, I'm still willing to give the Saigon pate a go.
author: Bartosz S.

description:
Roast pork Banh Mi! Roast pork Banh Mi!  It's always a good sign when a place sells one thing and little else and has people lined up out the door all day. And not just very misled tourists. Choice of meat, mayo, some brownish tangy sauce, cilantro, shredded carrot, jalepeno, on a warm french roll. I always try to grab one or two on the way to the beach.

I've seen some reviewers say there are better banh mi to be had nearby so I'll have to check them out. 5 stars until then.
author: Darren K.

description:
Today, is one of the rare days that SF is sunny. I decided to go to the SF public library but I wanted to grab a bite before i headed over there to study. I yelped vietnamese sandwiches because I was really craving them yesterday and I really wanted to try a new place. I found Saigon Sandwiches and I saw good reviews so I headed over there.

It was really hot and I was really hungry. Saigon Sandwiches HIT THE SPOT! OMG. I was full and it was just delicious. The chili caught me offguard and made my nose start running because it got spicy but I love spicy food so it was an extra kick! If you do not like spicy make sure to ask for no chili pepper. I got a roast pork and it was soooo good, especially sitting infront of the Asian Art Museum on a sunday day. I will definitely go here again. I was so close to going back and buying a fancy pork sandwich! RECOMMEND! BIG TIME!

AND CHEAP TOO! $2.75 for a VERY DELICIOUS SANDWICH!
author: Ricialg P.

description: Great sandwiches and for $3 (now).  I'm partial to the BBQ pork sandwich and while I order it with peppers, I pull them out.  Don't ask me why; it's just the thing I do.  I only go during the weekends since I don't work in this part of town, but it can be busy then too.  Try to go on off hours to avoid the line.  Contrary to others' experiences, I find the line moves slowly--but it's worth the wait.  While the place may seem a bit unclean, the health inspection report (for July 2008) gives them 82/100, which seems pretty good.
author: QuodE D.

description:
Saigon Sandwiches, a Vietnamese sandwich shop in the Tenderloin neighborhood, is a diamond in the rough.  For a mere $3, less than the price of a mediocre Starbucks latte, one can feast on a freshly prepared Bánh mì sandwich.  For two bucks more, throw in a side of sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves and a Thai Iced Coffee.

The first bite into a Bánh mì causes feelings of disbelief for the average sandwich eater - where are all these amazing flavors coming from?  The bread - soft on the inside and crusty on the outside - is stuffed with a mix of gently pickled, crunchy veggies, jalapeño peppers, cilantro, and marinated tofu or pork.  A sweet, vinegary sauce that lightly coats the veggies commingles perfectly with a thin schmear of mayonnaise and takes the cake for s[eat]ings' favorite [eat]ings, (isn't that cute?).  I've eaten Bánh mì before, but never as clean and delicious as Saigon Sandwiches'.   

For accuracy, I consulted Wikipedia to get the full history on Bánh mì.  "Bánh mì is a type of sandwich traditionally" made on a soft baguette "with thinly sliced pickled carrots, daikon, onions, cilantro, jalapeño peppers and meat or tofu. Popular bánh mì fillings include roasted or grilled pork, Vietnamese Ham, pâté, mayonnaise, chicken, and headcheese. Most Banh Mi sandwiches contain a Vietnamese mayonnaise-like spread that is a mixture of egg yolk, cooking oil/butter, and sometimes spices."  I knew all of this, but Wikipedia confirmed it for me.  They can do the research; I'll do the eating.
author: T. L.

description:
This place used to be one of my favorite hits when I lived in the tenderloin and I was affectionately referred to as "The Tenderlord". 
I had to wait to visit it again since it's been like 2 years just so I could make sure it was still that good.... 
Well ... IT IS! $3 for a little football bomb of a sandwich.
I love the simplicity of these sandwiches and they are so delicious.
Tip: buy a can of the Vietnamese coconut cream coated peanuts in the orange can ... they are a great snack to keep in your desk :)
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I believe this was the very first store I ate Viet sandwiches from as a kid.  It brings back so many memories here.

Every once in a while I will go back here since they have a different taste from a couple of its competitors up the street.

I really like their bbq chicken or just plain chicken, forgot.  Has a distinct taste you wont get at the other stores.  You can't really go wrong with their combo either.

I also like the authentic Viet snacks theyve been selling since I was a kid.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
these ladies work HARD for the money! 

my boyfriend & i found out about this place thanks to my neighbor. we were in a pretty long line as soon as we arrived, 10 - 15 people i'd say. 

so let me start off by saying that they have tons of asian goodies in here. things you can only really buy at asian supermarkets so that's definitely a plus. 

their sandwiches are BOMB. i got two and it was a damn good decision. i really love how they use raw jalapeno. i'm not sure what sauce they use but it's really good. the meat also has great flavor. 

my only complaint is that i wish this place was bigger. only three people can actually sit down to eat in here. 

this place has been around for a while.. an old teacher of mine went to hastings from 1991 - 1994 and he remembers this place being delicious and cheap. 

oh and this is an odd tip but trust me it will pay off: if you can, try to eat the sandwich upside down. i've learned from many crusty sandwiches that it will help (at least a little) the roof of your mouth from getting destroyed, lol.
author: Alyssa L.

description: This place is awesome. I eat here all the time and I've never gotten a bad sandwich here. It's crazy cheap too. Also, possibly the best tofu sandwich you can possibly get.
author: Arnold L.

description: This place is over rated! I love me some Vietnamese sammies, and am from San Jose where they make the best.. After reading all the rave reviews, I finally checked out this hole in the wall.. Unfortunatly I wasn't impressed. The bread was light but not crunchy and the filling of the sandwich was thin.. Not very filling at all.  Still on a quest to find the best Viet Sammie in SF..
author: Lily S.

description:
I took my cousin here after telling him that it is a "hidden" gem of the city. Upon arriving, there was a line out the door. Apparently, the Yelpers had tipped everyone off! People were ordering 10 sandos at a time, I had no idea what I was getting into (I had always had a friend pick it up). 

We went with the Combination and the Fancy Pork. The Combo is the way to go. Order  two, you can always save one for later....or for right after the first one.

I think I witnessed a drug deal on the corner, but what's reward without the risk?
author: Trevor F.

description:
I grew up with this place with the fancy pork sandwich.. oh its the bomb!
according to my parents its the realist thing to get to taste close to vietnams. first time i tried the tofu sandwich - it took awhile to get use to but i had one today..oh man.. i got my banh mi fix fixed! it kinda reminds me of inari (jap tofu pocket). i love the bread, the pate, everything but the cilantro haha not a clantro fan. this place is small...its take out alright. someone else got me the sandwich so i didnt see the remodel, will walk by soon coz im craving for another one.

before the remodel i had tofu sandwich for the 1st time and the lady who made our sandwiches was very inconsistent - iono was she new or what but that was the first time it just wasn't right...the amount of filling and sauce was inconsistent  - i think she was just sloppy coz there was so many ppl..it was only 6 ppl..we can all wait for a great sandwich. it tasted good though - it was just never that way before.

but im happy today and overall happy
suggest this to everyone
BEST EATS and BEST CHEAP EATS and BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICHES

oh. cash only.

i need to try the irving one to see what the big deal is. but they dont have tofu, only veg sandwich..sigh.. we'll see.
author: Janet W.

description: best damn viet nam samwich in da city Sucka!
author: Patrick S.

description: This place makes me wish I had a really hot, sexy, absolutely goddamned disgustingly-perfect-in-every-way boyfriend with a cool sense of style who could drive me to the TL in a preferably blue or black convertible on a sunny day to get roast pork bahn mi sandwiches from here, and then maybe we could take them to a park to eat them on top of a hill overlooking the city, and then afterwards we could drive around aimlessly listening to music and trying to make each other laugh, and maybe we could stop to make love on the side of the road, and then later at home we could fall asleep spooning in each others' arms and it wouldn't even matter if he snored or something. These are the kinds of totally unrealistic fantasies that this sandwich makes me think of because it's just that good and would fit right in with a perfect kind of day. My life will sadly never be that awesome, so I will settle for the sandwich as food is the only thing that will ever make me truly happy, right?
author: Joe T.

description: This place has the best vietnamese sandwiches in my opinion and I've eaten a lot of vietnamese sandwiches in the past. I personally think its the bread that makes the difference.  It may be a bit hard, but the quality of bread really gives the sandwich a whole new taste compared to the soft/dry bread of other places.  The women who work there are super fast.  I saw them make 20 sandwiches in 10 minutes to 8 customers.  Michael Scott would say "this is how business is done!"
author: Joseph C.

description:
So this was my first ever Bahn Mi experience and I'm 33, I know right,? disappointing.  
But man are these good.  I was in San Fran for the weekend, ate here Saturday for lunch got the roast pork and  some shrimp spring rolls.  So fresh, so good.  Here's what comes on your sandwich, pork, carrot, jalapeno, pickled onion, cilantro, and a lemony french mayo, all on the perfectly baked french roll.  
I went back on Monday to get some to-go back to Denver.  Because these sammies are warm, they tend to get a little saugy, but if you pop it in a toaster oven at 325, they get nice and crispy again.   
I brought home a roast pork, a special combination(roast pork, steamed pork, pork belly?, and pork pate)  Yeah Buddy!
I also got 2 Bahn Gio, which are the triangular banana leaves with a pork filled rice dumpling inside.  They are really tasty, kinda weird, but there is way more dumpling than pork.  Oh and cheap, cheap cheap!  2 sandwiches and 2 Bahn Gio for $10.
author: Matt P.

description: $3.25 for a big sandwich filled with meat, cilantro, mayo, pickled carrots, and some special sauce.  I really couldn't ask for more.  If the line is long, don't be deceived- they are assembly line geniuses here.  The lady takes everyone's order while another person begins making sandwiches, then they are ready to go as quickly as she can take the money.  Expect a 10 minute wait but sheesh- $3.25 for lunch!!  Yummmm roasted pork.
author: Luthien N.

description:
It's small and hectic in here; I ordered and waited off to the side of the counter patiently, admiring the bizarre drink selection ( Cactus soda?). Then some skank who ordered 2 people behind me stole my sandwich. They called "Tofu" and she, whom had been hovering right up against the counter in everyone in the line's way, snatched it up before I could claim it!  Clearly her lunch is so much more important than mine, I mean she's probably in law school down the street, and is just far more important than me in general. 

Anyways, I told myself I will not let that beeyotch who stole my Tofu  Banh Mi ruin my lunch. Two sandwich orders later I got my hands on it, scurried outside, and found a suitable (i.e. within a reasonably distal bum radius) place to enjoy it. The pressed tofu is superb, the mystery gravy/dressing is delicious, the veggies are crunchy and pickled, includes requisite cilantro and peppers, and of course the bread is perfectly crispy and flaky.
author: Civil D.

description: Not bad, a little chewy pork, not as good as some I've had in Virginia.
author: Nick R.

description: I've had better.  First time in SF. Will need to revisit after checking the competition.
author: Minotaur N.

description:
i grew up going to this place. its totally not like how it used to be. =/

on the plus side, they sell plenty of snacks and drinks. =)
author: Lisa N.

description: $3.25 for a sizable sandwich? That's better than most fast food places in the Bay Area.  I only knock off one star because the wait is terrible if you come by between 12-1 pm (and sometimes later if u're coming on a weekend).  The bread can be a little dry especially after the lunch rush, but the well-seasoned meat is more than worth it.
author: Koh K.

description: A great little sandwich shop that's makes delicious banh mi on the spot. The Vietnamese sandwich is packed with meat (I tried the roast chicken and roast pork) and garnished with fresh carrots, onions, peppers and cilantro in a fresh hoagie-like bun. Some of the veggies, like the carrots, needed to be more pickled and the meat needed more flavor (I preferred the chicken over the pork), but one can't complain much for its low price. Their front counter is piled high with snacks and sitting is limited to the windowsill.
author: Cliff W.

description: Coming from the san gabriel valley, i must say SF banh mi is a bit of a disappointment. Price was 4 bucks for a combination, it was alright. I think a little overpriced in comparison to other vietnamese sandwich spots down in the sgv, but saigon sandwich is a-ok like the rating suggests.
author: El D.

description: Best Roast Pork and Roast Chicken Vietnamese sandwiches in the city! I can't count how many I have had, but usually buy 2-4 each time I go. One to eat right away and a few for the fridge. Line gets really long at lunch time, but still worth the 20 minutes or so wait. Remember when they were just $2.50? 4 sandwiches for $10. Now I think they are around $3.50-$3.75. Still a bargain.
author: Jordan P.

description: Forget roast chicken, my new found love is roast pork!! Still one of the best banh mi out there for $3. =)
author: Alexander H.

description:
How could I have been on yelp and not written about Saigon Sandwiches!! 

I love this place!! their sandwiches are absolutely the best. dont be distracted by lee sandwiches couple blocks down or any other vietnamese sandwich place for that matter. this is the best. 

i'll admit i've strayed away a couple of times, but i've always come back to the original. u can't beat their crispy bread overstuffed with veggies and juicy bbq chicken...mmm...did i mention u can get this for under $3?! 

it's simply the best.

btw, don't be scared to try some of the desserts. my favorite is the one with the black eye beans and coconut milk. u have to mix it up before u eat it. it looks like mush, but its pretty sweet.
author: j t.

description:
Within my 1st week in SF, my good friend Bryan told me about this place that's a "hole in the wall" Vietnamese Sandwich place that everyone knows about...  

The ladies here have their system down:  cook the rolls, sauce them, and fill them with the goodness.  I love meat, but this place is also vegan friendly and you can't beat the $2.75 per sandwich!!

I recommend the meatball and/or the tofu.  Plus they have a myriad of other random impulsive snacking goods to consume as well.
author: Jake B.

description:
5 stars, what more can you ask for!
Perfectly done, i could eat here everyday!
damn this is good eatin'
author: Pug P.

description:
Amazing sandwich for any price ... but at $2.75, it's a steal.  My favorite's the pork, and I'd recommend trying whatever sandwich you order with everything on it EVEN IF you're a sandwich topping control freak because it's delicious, and you will truly miss out if you ask for no sauce or veggies.

To back up the deliciousness factor, boyfriend is half Viet, was raised on this food (sadly, I was not so fortunate, and grew up in a place where In-N-Out was the most exciting thing going on), and thinks this place is amazing.  I surprised him by bringing home lunch one day, and he was shocked.  One more point for me.

Line can be long, but when you're getting an amazing sandwich for under $3, who cares?  Also, the ladies behind the counter do a pretty great job of knocking out 10+ sandwiches in mere minutes for all the salivating patrons in line.

They also carry pork roll and a variety of Vietnamese snacks.  If you've got an extra couple bucks on you (let's say you walk in with a fiver on ya), I'd recommend trying the refrigerated drinks in the clear plastic glasses that look like they have beans or some sort of jelly-ish looking things in coconut milk.  Also delish.

Five stars on the great-find, hole-in-the-wall scale.  Four stars on the I-hate-walking-through-the-'Loin-at-certain-times-of-day/early-evening-just-to-get-here scale.
author: Kristen H.

description:
DAMN good vietnamese sandwiches ! I just hate the fact that they're in a not so wonderful area. The chicken sandwich and the fancy pork sandwich is my fave. the meatball is not bad either. I remember that the sandwiches use to be $2.50. But for the price of the sandwich its still good.  Worth waiting for when there is a line. Also some of the non sandwich dishes like the phan bell is good. 
Enjoy !
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I LOVE their chicken bahn mi! Flavorful chicken but not overly so (I find that most chicken banh mi are either over-seasoned or under-seasoned). Works perfectly with the pickled veggies. Word of warning to non-mayo lovers, the sandwich comes with mayo unless you tell the lady otherwise.

Yes, the price went up, but it's still only $3. Quite a find if you're looking for a cheap meal near the Civic Center. The lines can get pretty long during lunch, so prepare to wait or come early/late.
author: Jane K.

description:
They have the best Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever had!  Whenever I am in the area, I swing by to grab a few for lunch!  

Funny that Lee's just opened up down the block!  NO COMPARISON!

Don't forget to try their desserts too.. my favorite.. still don't know the name.. beans with white stuff on top!  YUM YUM!
author: Keith W.

description: Way better than Cafe Dolci's banh mi!  And who could beat these prices for a sandwich.  Loved the bread and sauce that they use, never dry or bland.  My favorite is the tofu sandwich and meatball!
author: Janelle D.

description: My parents opened Saigon Sandwiches in the late 80's and I remember making sandwiches there as a kid. It was quite an experience making hundreds of them in a day and pealing thousands of carrots, Daikons, & Jalapenos as a kid. My parents then sold off this place to my uncle. You would think I'd be sick of the food growing up with it and I've also had Vietnamese sandwiches EVERYWHERE but being non-bias, I still love eating there the most.
author: Eddie N.

description: This place has been here for many years, I used to buy a sandwich here every week when the sandwiches use to cost at $1.50...I havent ate their sandwiches for 2 year+ already and finally returning back to it, they surely lost their touch...I was disappointed with their service, regardless if they were busy or not, they werent able to get my order correct! Clearly I told them no onions, no peppers, and no cliantro, and still they put it in there, after having her confirming the order and reminding them several times...what happen if I had a food allergic reaction to it? would they be responsible for it? I asked for them to redo it and was ignored, I left there upset with the sandwiches...
author: Linh D.

description: Saigon Sandwhiches started my liking of Vietnamese sandwiches. I've tried other places, but hands down, this is the best I've ever had. It's much tastier than Lee's Sandwiches, which is down the street. Although their sandwiches are smaller compared to Lee's, they're much more packed with meat. And, I like my meat. (No pun intended, hahah.) It's a small sandwich shop that also sells Asian snacks that's ran by a very sweet, middle aged Vietnamese lady. I feel sorry for her sometimes, especially when the line is long 'cause she's the only one working most of the time. Give her a tip; she deserves it! Each time I pass through the TL, I try to make time to go to Saigon. I wish that they were opened later, they close at 6. :[ Be sure to have some cash in hand, they're cash only!
author: BrendaJoy G.

description:
Aesthetics are overrated when it comes to dining establishment.  I ultimately  have no concern for the ambiance of a restaurant as long as conditions don't cause me to become nauseous.  The service as well need not be stellar as long as I'm not made to feel like I'm unwanted.  Apathy's fine if the food can cover the spread.

  Saigon Sandwiches is an eating establishment that devotes so much of its focus on the food that everything else is a distant last.  It pays off.  The sandwiches here are the food of the gods that the gods feed to the heavenly livestock, and then butcher the livestock and eat the contents of the livestock's stomach first.  These are some dynamite sandwiches we're talking about.  They'll keep you coming back to this tiny place as often as you get the chance.

  This restaurant could set up shop at the gates of hell and I'd still brave the journey.  If I die, dear reader, and you catch wind of this news, tell them I want to be buried with a Saigon Sandwich (pate, preferably) and a bag of wasabi shrimp crackerchips.  And then shot into space.
author: Ignacio N.

description:
Whoa.  It's an experience because that area of the city is teaming with crack addicts, toothless meth zombies and plain old crazy people.  But once you prep to defend yourself and stand tough waiting in the line to get to the counter, the lady making the sandwiches takes about 7 orders at a time and whips through making them all with the extra-this and extra-that requests.
I was impressed and paid exact change as to not mess up her rhythm.
Then after getting back to the safety of our car and getting the heck out of there, we ate these tasty pork and pate sandwiches in a secret location.  Silently, we ate.  Tasty fresh French roll.  Spicy and tangy.  Roast pork goodness.
Sure, I'd definitely eat one of these sandwiches again, but I feel bad that businesses like this that are making quality sandwiches have to deal with this area of the Tenderloin's completely out of control scene.  
I'm not trying to make light or make jokes about this area of town or by any means make fun of the affected by the rampant drug use in the Tenderloin, but it is unsafe to walk around down there and I saw zero cop cars, but did see more than one street drug deal out in the open just circling while looking for parking.  Just a word of warning for those not prepared for city living.
author: Kev M.

description: Please, please, please bring back green onions on the sandwiches.  Don't  slack on this essential ingredient.  You'll regret it!
author: lavon t.

description: I really wanted to love you.  I went for years, being a devoted customer.  It all stopped one day, abruptly, sadly...when I found a roach in my sandwich.
author: Angela I.

description: Probably the best banh mi shop on this street!   For $3, I'll take 1 of each please.  It must be the meat and also the fresh crispy french baggette...I'm a fan!
author: Jeff H.

description:
Best sandwich you can get for $3.25 in the city, I would eat here everyday if I worked close by. They do take their time when making/serving- but still worth the wait.

Be warned about the 'combo' banh mi- it has 'not the world's finest' pate in it, and I've seen it catch people by surprise.

...now stop reading this review and go get me a sandwich
author: VL K.

description: Wow I think I found my lunch spot in SF. I love this stuff and can eat it forever. Lees eat your heart out!
author: Emmanuel C.

description: Pretty much the best sando in the world, not even taking price into consideration.
author: Jack S.

description: Used to come here often when I worked in the area years ago. Just dropped in this past Monday after I visited my mechanic down the street. Still as good as I remember it and cheap too.
author: Roman I.

description: 1 of the best viet sandwiches ever..pork and meat balls are so0o tasty and its cheapie!!!! as a long time customer since high school yr, i still drive out there to buy them..but the parking meter sux
author: alan l.

description: BOMB ASS SANDWICHES!!!! I came here by myself this morning to get a sandwich, ROAST PORK. all I gotta say is O M G, the rumors about this place and yelp reviews are so true. After I left the place, I went to pick up my sisters and went back to the sandwich shop so they can try it too! they said it was delicious! hah, I think this is my go to spot in S.F for vietnamese sandwiches!!!! =)
author: Thanh K.

description: Pretty good banh-mi served as efficiently as this tiny space allows. If you're in the 'hood, try one. Otherwise, meh....not a destination. Spice Kit on Howard is a lot better. And Out The Door also offers way more elevated banh-mi, at a slightly higher price and most importantly, in a more sanitary environment!
author: Sara K.

description: Best Sandwiches EVER!  I tried the roast pork and steamed pork last time and it was sooo good!  I think each sandwich has it's good things.  For example, the roast pork is very juicy and full of flavor.  The special combo has the paté, which I thought at first was something weird to have in a sandwich, but it turned out to be really delicious!
author: Monxi G.

description: This place is way overrated. The bread was hard, the sandwich was messy, the taste is just ok. I've had better.
author: zoey x.

description:
first, let me say, banh mi expert I am not, but I do love a good one when i find it. 

my friend and i trekked up to Saigon today for lunch and i had the roast pork. the pork has great flavor! their rolls are different but still tasty. i think there was almost a whole pepper on my sandwich which is a bit much for me, but I'll be damned if I'll be one of the people in line who tried to order veggies on the side or whatever specialized order you want. don't be fooled, this isn't a special order type of spot. 

i think I'll give it another try because for $3.00 its hard to beat. but I'm definitely interested in starting a quest to try as many of the banh mi shops in the TL as possible. recession proof lunch!
author: Annalea I.

description: Cheaper than the crack sold on the corner, but just as addicting.  They've been raising their prices regularly lately, but still affordable so you won't need to steal some yuppies iPhone to afford your habit.
author: Nosniv X.

description: It's damn good.  The way they prepare the pork shines.  The roll is good.  Not the best choice for bahn mi, but I'll take it.  It still doesn't compare to my place in Oaktown.  Where the hell are they preparing this meat?  That's the real secret I would like to know.  And how did they get signed off with the health department?
author: Amy H.

description: I haven't been back to this place since the last time i reviewed it, but have you guys checked out the photos of sandwiches? See the one with the cockroach swimming in the sandwich sauce? Gross! Glad I never became a regular! Instead, I bought all the ingredients of the tofu sandwich and have made my own. Maybe you'd like to try doing the same??? Yeah, try doing the same.
author: Angie B.

description:
I did a little mental exercise the other day and decided that the sandwiches would have to cost $7.00 or more before I'd reconsider going to Saigon Sandwich.  Since they cost $3.00, and these are really excellent Vietnamese sandwiches, this is the best buy in the City. 

They also have fun strange items to go with your sandwich, such as garlic peanuts, or candy! 

Be sure to remember that this location is on the edge of the 'loin.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Oh maaann, i dont know why i didn't review this place sooner.  

Anyways I will keep this short.  Saigon Sandwich shop is the best place to buy Vietnamese sandwiches in SF.  In fact, if you don't buy at least 3 sandwiches at a time, you're an idiot.  

The funny thing about this place is that there are Chinese ladies who are working there, not Vietnamese.  Yee boy, represent.

So stop going to Subway and buying crappy ham sandwiches for 5 bucks, when you can buy 2 vietnamese sandwiches for the price of one 5 dollar foot log of crap.

If you find yourself in the TL because you wanted to buy some crack, save some money and buy some sandwiches.  They're cheaper, they taste better, they're better for you, and they aren't illegal.  Win-win
author: SAS Z.

description: I love banh-mi, and Saigon Sandwich near Civic Center serves them up fresh daily. Toasted baguettes with a choice of delicious meats (like roast chicken or pork, meatballs, pate), pickled carrots and daikon, fresh cilantro, and healthy spread of mayo. A small handful of heaven for $3.25 a pop.
author: Joel A.

description: You see three ladies working away at those sandwiches like pros, like a factory line.  Chop, slap, stuff and wrap.  Like they've done it for years, and so, here is the verdict on Saigon.  My friend told me about this spot.  Saying it was the best around.  I ordered a pate and combo.  The buns were different than any other that I've had.  More fresh, crispy on the inside and out, and tasty too.  The pate is warm and they stuff it with a lot of the pickled carrots, making it a a full sub.  Take a bite and you'll be in lala land.  After one bite, I wanted to hurry up and chew and swallow so I can take the next bite right away.  I bought another one to eat a few days later and it wasn't as good then, so make sure to get it fresh.  The menu is limited but it's fine, keep it simple.  A lot of vegetarians came thru asking for the veggie one, so I should try that next time.  The line starts to get out the door at lunch time, so get there early or later if you can.  There is only minimal seating, like for 3 people there, so its really a to-go kind of spot.  I did try Lee's sandwiches too up the street and I would say they are comparable, but Saigon give you more bang for you buck.  More filling to the T, so try this hole in the wall spot and you won't regret it.  It is true, best Vietnamese sandwiches in the bay area for sure.
author: Janice F.

description: Try these sandwiches.  Like nothing you've ever had. Pork recommended.  Its a tiny shop with the line running out the door, but it moves fast and its worth a stop.
author: Doxie M.

description:
tofu sandwhich.
good, but a bit saucy.
author: Henry H.

description:
Oh, what a surprise!    YUM!  fun!  cheap!

So simple and delcious.  I tried the "special pork" and the "chicken" and loved both.  Crispy, fluffy bread; good meats and sauces; fresh greens and herbs.

Two of us ate sandwiches, had a few deserts, and sodas for only $12.

How can they do it?

the cheerful lady tried to talk me out of having the "special pork" but I really wanted to try it.  It was like sliced bratworst; very mild with good texture.  Give it a shot!
author: Greg H.

description:
$2 for the best pork-meatball banh mi in town.  Add 25 cents if you prefer chicken (really though, the meatball is the best, though they do offer sliced pork, and tofu too).  Honestly, I don't know what else there is for me to say...

Update: A friend of mine finally talked me into trying a tofu banh mi, which I had been resisting for some time.  I think it may be EVEN BETTER than my beloved banh mi xiu mai (meatball).  The lesson I'm taking from this is to be more trusting of my friends, for sure.
author: Matthew M.

description:
As a representative of the Vietnamese Sandwich shop this is a pretty great place. If you are expecting something else you will be unhappy.

They have Diet RC Cola.  They have $2.00 Sandwiches.  There is peanut sauce. They have a wide selection of Mochi.  They have fruit flavored beef jerky. They also have one hell of a line most days, but it moves fast.
author: Gustie L.

description:
GET THE COMBO! for $2.50, you get a sandwich stuffed with a combination of bbq pork and steamed pork, liver pate, fresh cilantro and jalapenos, pickled carrots, onions, and daikon, a little mayo and their secret bbq sauce.  I think it's the sauce that keeps everyone coming back.  Let's not forget the Baker's of Paris' rolls they use for the sandwiches....it's like heaven on a roll.

There's always a line and please please please call in advance if you got a big order, otherwise us people that just need 1-2 will hate you for it.
author: Billy T.

description:
Even with the recent price hike to $2.75, this has to be the best deal in the City! 

The Food:
Bahn Mi is a toasted French roll or baguette with pate, meat (chicken, pork, etc.) or tofu, seasoned with pickled vegetables, mayo, herbs and spices.  I agree with other yelpers that the jalapenos can be hot. I love them!  Some of the items on the counter (wrapped) are worth trying. I've had the fresh spring rolls with shrimp and a crazy tapioca pudding type thing in a cup. Both were very good.

Neighborhood:
This is in the tenderloin and you will know it when you visit. The place looks like a health code violation waiting to happen, but for me that just adds to the charm. There are a couple of stools but most take-out. Be ready to order or risk getting skipped over. The ladies behind the counter are a model of efficiency and they can pump out dozens of sandwiches while you wait. Bravo! I don't know how they remember all the orders but they have never messed mine up.
author: Alan L.

description:
In the comment below, Jordan K., a known communist, admits that he lacks the courage required to annoint the Bahn Mi from Saigon Sandwich Shop as the best sandwich in the world.  He confesses that he lies awake at night, imagining that he might one day taste a better sandwich.  My fellow citizens, know this: His quest will end in vain.  In fact, Jordan K. may well die quietly and alone, without ever having appreciated true perfection when it was served to him in an unassuming piece of white wax paper.

I do not say this lightly or without full consideration.  But I can say it unambiguously:

This is not only the best bahn mi Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had; it's the best sandwich I've ever had, at any price, anywhere, ever.  And I've had a lot of sandwiches.

Some might argue.  Some might quibble or disagree.  Fie on them.  I'll say it again: Best. Sandwich. EVAR.

PS: I most prefer the xiu mai (called Vietnamese meatball pork on the plastic menu sign).  Eat it and know greatness.
author: Telstar L.

description:
I'm going to keep this short and simple.  
This is my FIRST EVER 5-star rating on Yelp (I'm getting close to 30 reviews now).   Yes, it's that good.

Best Viet sandwich I've ever had (meatball pork).  I don't even like cliantro or hot peppers- that didn't bother me, I took some of it out and kept trucking along. Limited menu, so veggies will have to eat Tofu.  And good god. $2.50 for a sandwich?  is that even possible?  It's like a SF dream come true.

In the end, this is pretty much everything one could ever ask for in a "hole-in-the-wall" restaurant.  My roommate and I actually missed it as we drove through little saigon the first time since its so tiny.  I bought an extra chicken sandwich for lunch tomorrow, and even now, when I'm not even hungry, I'm having a hard time not reaching into the frig and downing it.  I'm already dreaming about when I can go back...
author: Ken S.

description:
Good, not great.  Love how crammed it is, love the candy and random groceries, love the shitty sign listing the sandwiches, how ridonk cheap it is, and how I got there right as the line started.  

Had the special combo.  The bread was fantastic, nice and soft but not too soft.  The meats were also tasty, but the flavor wasn't varied enough, felt like I was just tasting pork and pate and nothing else.  The pate is killer, though. 

WTF is with people coming here and ordering like 10 sandwiches at a time, though.  I mean, those ladies are really good at making a shitload of sandwiches at once, but come on there are people in line.
author: Keane N.

description:
I love this place b/c the sandwiches are delicious!  I mean it!  The chicken sandwich sans mayo is a must have!  The sandwich is served warm and they do not skimp on the chicken, carrots, onions, and cilantro.  

The service needs improvement, however the ladies who work behind the counter are sweet.
