Around noon, there is a long line that extends out the door and around the corner, which is crazy.  But it is worth the wait.
author: myiken n.

description: This may be the best sandwich I have ever had!! I never write reviews but I must say this place deserves it.  I will be coming back often and bringing others with me.
author: Nikki M.

description: Simply stated this place is the hands down winner of price to taste ratio of sandwich spots.  And I don't just mean Vietnamese ones.  What a tasty deal!
author: William J.

description: It was definitely good but it's hard for me to tell how it's that much better than anywhere else. I guess from now on when I want a Vietnamese sandwich I'll go there, but it didn't blow my mind or anytihng.
author: m t.

description:
I typically don't eat Vietnamese food. Actually, Vietnamese food is one of the last cuisines I'd choose to eat. So, I was actually upset that my friend took me there for lunch. 

For me to give this place a 4-star, you can tell how pleasantly surprised I was by this place.

Their Roasted Pork Sandwich is absolutely delicious!! Even though I don't eat carrots and I hate cilantro...everything together in one sandwich (the sweetness of the pork along with the carrots, jalapenos, pickled onions, cilantro, and a lemony french mayo all together on a french roll)...YUMMY!

With it only costing like $3.25...what more can you ask for?
author: Daphne L.

description:
Sai-gone-wrong Sandwich.  I'll tell you exactly why, too:

Girlfriend and I were hungry and figured Vietnamese sandwiches would be a great idea.  Quick and tasty food.  So while I was driving, she loaded up the Yelp app on my Android phone and found this place.  4.5 stars average from over 1000 reviews? The numbers were in our favor!

So.. why 2 stars?

1. Dry bread; not just dry, I mean rock hard.  Not only was the bread dry but it...
2. Cut the roof of my mouth.  So much that I could taste and feel blood.  What kind of fucking sandwich attacks the eater? Following which the...
3. Sandwich broke apart and dripped through the paper on my new 7 jeans.  
4. The ingredients inside the sandwiches (BBQ pork w/ pate and BBQ chicken) were actually good, so I can't fault them for that.
5. Sketchy neighborhood.  I think I counted about a dozen hobos, a few people that looked like they were smoking crack (literally) and the usual tranny hookers that loiter the streets in the TL.
6. Strange ass ordering process.  Do you wait in line, order and then wait in the same spot? Why did my sandwich take 10 times longer to make than the 6 people who were behind me and walked out with theirs?
7. Sandwiches are actually too small.  $3 at any other place gives you a large sandwich that's cut in half.

Yes the place is cheap, but, come on... you can get the exact same food elsewhere.   For instance: Y&Y on Clement and 6th Avenue, also Irving Cafe & Deli on Irving and 22nd.  Both places are much better than this place.  Both are in neighborhoods where a homeless tranny won't try to proposition you and you don't have to wait in line.
author: Serge S.

description:
I'm vietnamese and I have had many vietnamese sandwiches.  That being said, Saigon Sandwiches is top notch.  

And, the lady behind the counter was super sweet.
author: ms.maiplum t.

description: I just tried their vietnamese yogurt for the first time.  It's slightly sweet, mildly tart, light and  heavenly creamy.  Certainly different from american and greek yogurt.  Worth coming back for.
author: K C.

description: i guess west coast banh mi sandwich are more of the wet variety. i had the roast pork and it was juicy and well seasoned. The best part of the sandwich was not the meat or the vegetables but it was the bread. the bread is really good. i am not going to lie walking through the tenderloin district is a little sketch. next time i walk through this area i will be sure to bring a switch blade or something to protect myself. overall, good experience and good food.
author: Mike C.

description:
i tossed $3 on the counter and walked out with my sandwich to be hollered down by the lady behind the counter asking for 25 cents more.  

Apparently they just upped the price.
author: Walerz B.

description: Cannot believe how good the bahn mi was. Got a dac biet and it came on a crispy, warm but not very long baguette. The pate was luscious and oozing out. Other ingredients were well proportioned. Craving this sandwich right now. Also got the vietnamese green cake which was really good. It wasn't busy when I went, maybe 2 people in front of me and they seemed like regulars.
author: H. W.

description:
i'll start with -- it's $3.  that's already good.

this is my first vietnamese sandwich, so i can't judge it against others.  taste was nice -- kind of sweet, with a nice little pocket of jalapeño nestled in the middle.

i liked it.  it was good.  for the price, it was actually amazing.  i'm normally fairly generous with my stars, and the reason this didn't get five was because i certainly wasn't dazzled.  the reason it didn't get four, is because there was a piece of pork in my otherwise tofu sandwich.  good thing i am generally distrusting of public food establishments when i ask for something vegetarian.  i opened up my sandwich and scrutinized it.  "what's THAT?" i asked my boyfriend and friend who had both gotten the pork sandwiches....... "ummm, pork, dude," they replied.

SUPER close to my living quarters?  yes.
tasty sandwich?  yes.
SUPER cheap?  yes.
fast service?  yes.

so there you go.  it's definitely worth a try.  however, i will yelp around for other vietnamese sandwich joints before returning here.
author: Beccie F.

description: Good sandwiches, though the spread on their chicken sandwiches (bánh mì gà) is thick and a little too buttery/mayo-laden for my taste. I know many people prefer it this way so I can understand why Saigon Sandwiches gets a lot of five-star ratings. Baguette Express has a less heavy flavor that I prefer.
author: Tony L.

description:
So... I wasn't going to do this, but after a few weeks of the aftershock wearing off, I feel it's my duty to at least warn you all of possible similar tragedies happening to your sandwich.
I went to Saigon because of all of your rave reviews. I love vietnamese sandwiches, so I went and ordered two tofu, one with mayo for my roommate and mine without, and one roasted pork with pate (since everyone raved about it). Well, my roommate and I enjoyed our tofu sandwiches immensely. So much so, that later the same day I broke out the pate sandwich and took a bite. I looked at my sandwich and noticed a hair. No biggie, I mean, these sandwiches are good... I can deal with a hair. BUT, when I proceeded to pull it out, it wouldn't budge. So, naturally I opened the sandwich to remove the hair. What did I see? What was the problem. It was a whole entire hair ball the size of a quarter, bigger than the kind you get floating around your clothes in the dryer with your laundry. I was absolutely disgusted. I mean, think of how you feel when you find one hair? I really don't know how they missed it, I certainly couldn't miss it!!!! Anyway, I still gag a bit EVERY TIME I think about it. I went to Lee's and I have to say everything is much cleaner and sanitary there, and the veggie sandwich was damn good too. I forced myself to try Saigon again, even though my first experience was tragic. They were all out of sandwiches when I showed up at 5pm, but I went the following day and had a tofu. It was ok, but not as good as the first one. I don't think one will ever be as good as the first one because of the hair ball I found in my second one... it haunts me! lol

Seriously, stay away from the pate... god knows what else is in there.
author: Lauren M.

description: Great sandwiches and reasonably priced $3-$4. The place gets packed during lunch but worth the wait.
author: crystal e.

description: Yumminess! Very low key, the food is so worth it.
author: Huyen V.

description: When you want something quick and fast check this place out.... they have a great tofu sandwhich! Nothig like getting your grub on in the TL! Eddy, Yo!!!!
author: Joshua s.

description:
First, the sandwiches are phenominal beyond all possible explaination. (Although I'd watch out for the peppers) Second, they subsidize the normal selection of drinks and foods with some of the wierdest things imaginable. (Like Pennywort drink and these odd yogurt looking things) And finnally a good meal costs under four dollars. I will state that again simply because of its amazingness. It costs under four dollars for a complete meal. And once you are finished, you feel content. The sandwiches are actually very filling and the meats they use are perfect for the bread the veggies.

If you live in SF, or are just visiting, you need to go there. We should make these sandwiches a city, if not a national, icon.
author: Reverend D.

description:
The sandwiches are YUMMY and for under $3, you can't beat it.  
When I worked in the area, I would come and eat here at least once a week if not more, then I moved jobs and found it hard to get out here.  Now that I'm back in the area, I'm so happy to forget my lunch and go pick up a sandwich and some tasty desserts.
author: Chibinko -.

description:
One of the best Banh Mi places I've tried in the city. Can't hold a candle to my mother's but I haven't the 2G's to go visit and partake. I usually order the special combination with extra peppers. 

Make sure the ladies behind the counter don't rush you through your order and get it  right. Brusque is one way to describe the service.
author: Roy W.

description:
Okay, this is hands down my favorite Vietnamese sandwich shop. I love love love the meatball sandwich. The grilled pork and chicken are not too shabby either.

The bread is so fresh and lightly toasted. It's not hard and crusty like the bread you find at other places. The amount of mayo, carrots, cilantro and jalapenos are perfect. Be ware, sometimes those jalapenos bite back!!!

On any given day, I can pack away two, count them, TWO, meatball sandwiches. What can I say, I love these sandwiches. I think my boyfriend still can't believe this. :-)

This shop is not in the greatest part of the city, but who cares, they have the best Vietnamese sandwiches around.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Big, meaty sandwiches with enough pate and pickled veggies for street cred.  Not your traditional banh mi but then again your traditional banh mi isn't as tasty.  I like the chicken with pate and pork roll slices.  If you're going on a road trip, order the veggies on the side.  I see people coming out with bags of banh mi.

The owner and staff are OG.  

Saigon Sandwiches gets five stars (from a base of three) because it's the only place I'll go for banh mi.  I used to hate on it because the banh mi didn't look "traditional" but it all comes out the same hole anyways.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
First time here and there was already a line out the door.  It moves quickly just like the two Asian women barking Cantonese orders at each other.

Ordering is a breeze.  You have about five options on the menu and they are all $2.50.  Make the sandwich spicy if you like, pick a drink or any of the other items they have laying around and pay.  There is counter at the front of the store for about 3-4 people to sit.  It's my turn to order and the line is still out the door.  Where are all these people coming from?  Don't you know your in the loin?

I'd come here again, but you can get a similar mini sandwich at Lee's for $2.
author: Po L.

description:
Delicious, fast, and cheap!  The roast pork and tofu are amazing.  It's true what they say about the bread...fresh, French, and toasted to perfection.

The sweet little ladies crank them out and they're only $2.75...so,  it wouldn't hurt you to tip!
author: M M.

description:
If you look up hole in the wall.....you'll find a picture of Saigon Sandwiches. 
My bedroom is bigger than this place, but you know what? who give a f#ck 
If you want the best Vietnamese sandwich in the Bay Area...you'll go here 

If you go M-F 10-2 odds are there will be a line
author: Steve K.

description:
Best Viet sandwiches in the TL district. I love the BBQ chicken, have them add jalapenos and it's "oh so perfect". 

The place is quite small, and they move a little slow, but defintely worth the wait. 

They used to have a buy 5 get 1 free deal, but not sure if they still do that. Doesn't matter if it's free, i'll be back for more.
author: Jenny W.

description:
You know that when there is a line out the door in the Tenderloin, there must be something extra special about the place....and there was!

1)  Roasted Pork

2)  Roasted Chicken

Both of these sandwiches were equally good.  You can't go wrong with either of them.  I usually hate mayo on my sandwiches but for some reason, I'm pretty sure that these sandwiches were laced with crack.  Neither of these sandwiches had pate in them, but given the amazing yelp reviews, I'm going to opt for one with pate next time I go.  These sandwiches bursted at the seams with lots of filling and the bread - crispy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside - probably one of the best breads I've ever had.

There is a reason why people wait outside this unassuming hole-in-the-walling looking place...it's worth the wait!
author: Kristie G.

description:
stepped in, almost walked back out.  

"huh, where am i?"  nobody's here.  the tiny shop also looks like a back storage room of a restaurant.

but the two ladies working there kicked ass.  two mins after we ordered the chicken and the special combo, a line had formed, 10 deep.  wow.

bam!  excellent sandwiches!  i am now a fan of liver paste.
author: Ethan L.

description: I don't have to tell you the sandwiches are cheap and tasty at this establishment, because a gazillion other yelpers already did.  So why bore you?
author: Christina S.

description: I'd say that the Banh Mi here at Saigon is really just average.  I thought the baguette was a little difficult to eat (too crunchy and difficult to fit in my mouth), and they definitely skimped on the meat.  We ordered the roast chicken and the roast pork sandos ($3.25 each) and decided we've both had better, though it wasn't terrible.  What I did like about these Banh Mi was that they are spicier than normal, which is fabulous for me because I like it hot!  Will try other Vietnamese sandwich shops before coming back here.
author: Kira K.

description: Haven't had Vietnamese food before but this was one hell of a sandwich. Fresh carrots, cilantro, apple sweet sauce, cooked chicken on a fresh baked roll for $3.25......was amazing with a perfect blend of all the ingredients with just the right amount of temperature to give it a nice kick.
author: Pierce B.

description:
On this street, there are two Vietnamese sandwich (banh mi) places. I prefer one over the other. They are both located on Larkin near Eddy, about a block apart. Saigon Sandwich is at 560 Larkin while Baguette Express is at 668 Larkin.

So, what the hell's a banh mi? It combines a buttery French baguette with meat (usually barbecued), cilantro, pickled carrots, some spicy peppers, and sometimes mayonaisse. In other words, it combines the best of France with the SouthEast Asian melding of flavors: sweet, sour, salty, and spicy.

Baguette Express is clean, tidy and they have a machine that they can run some sugarcane through to get you your fix of sugarcane juice (haven't had it? then you haven't yet backpacked around South East Asia - you get addicted to this stuff there). It's slightly bigger than Saigon Sandwich and you can even sit down at a table or two. Saigon Sandwich is a small, cluttered little shop that has a lot more Vietnamese snacks to sell than Baguette Express. Both run around $2.50 per sandwich so it's probably the best deal in the entire city.

Baguette Express's bread has that difficult-to-get balance of crunchy-on-the-outside-soft-on-the-inside, while Saigon's is not as crunchy but still soft. The choice of meats are broader at Baguette Express and that's where Saigon Sandwich to me really shines. The meats there are just better - I think because they focus on fewer than Baguette Express. I compared a barbeque pork sandwich and a barbeque chicken sandwich from both places. I also felt that Saigon's balance of the sweet/spicy barbecue sauce, sweet/sour pickled carrots, spiciness of its peppers, cilantro, and mayo really balance well, while with Baguette Express the flavors were not as powerful.
author: Roy J.

description: This place is really good!!!! But it's not....special! I grew up in the suburbs of orange county but i definitely knew my way around little saigon...hello, first generation vietnamese here!!! that being said i think i know what would be considered "good banh mi" (look up anthony bourdain banh mi  on youtube for reference). this place, while charming, did not live up to my expectations. sure it's a great place to get cheap, good, banh mi, but i'm sure it's not the absolute best. i dunno norcal, if this is the best banh mi u got then...dang :/
author: Lea N.

description:
delicious banh mi at a bang for your buck, a mere 3 dollars a pop.

the roast pork was a bit strange tasting, so i'll stick with chicken next time. pate is also an addiitonal .25 cents.

tip: phone in your order and avoid the line!
author: Wendell M.

description: Very fast and great Banh Mi. My only little complaint is that the bread seemed a little doughy - meaning its a lot of bread. Would still recommend this place for VN sandwiches.
author: Kim V.

description: Every time I left my hotel, I could see a line stretching out the door of this little sandwich shop. By the third day, I was curious enough to go see what it was all about, and I do not regret that decision in the slightest. Amazing sandwich for the price. I wish I had checked it out earlier in the trip. One third the price and three times the flavor of some of the more unfortunate dining choices I made that week.
author: Eric F.

description: yes, the lines are crazy. but these sandwiches are amazing. the staff is efficient, and my combination banh mi was sooo flavorful. the bread was crispy but not hard. the pate was so good, too. seriously, you can't get a better meal under $5 in SF!
author: M J.

description: Roast Pork Banh Mi is fantastic. Simple, cheap, and fantastic.
author: Terry H.

description: Best Bahn Mi for the price in San Francisco! The fact that it's in a gritty neighborhood adds to the charm. My only wish is that there were more parks nearby as SS is pretty much take away only.
author: Denis L.

description:
everyone is right.  this place is awesome.
why haven't you tried this place yet?
oh and in case you're wondering, the veggie sandwich isn't vegan. they use meat broth to cook their tofu/soy thing. and use meat sauce for flavor. that's probably why it's so delicious. 
and i know most vegans who've tried and loved this place will try as hard as they can to forget that i just said that. i'm sorry. i really am. but some people would want to know. 
just do what i do, and pretend that you don't know.
author: Angela S.

description: I have never been more satisfied with a $3.25 purchase in my life.  I only tried the pork, but it didn't disappoint.  If you let it marinate in the wrap for awhile, it will get the bread to a consistency that simply melts when you eat it.  I suggest buying a few and saving half of them for dinner.  I am telling you, this place is worth finding no matter where you are in the city.  Notes about vagrants and pick pockets are not to be dismissed, but the benefits far outweigh the risks.
author: chris s.

description: holy shit best hole in the wall sandwich place EVER! DIRT CHEAP AND DELICIOUS! i took my friend here from out of town and she was blown away. if you like spicy food this is the place. every time i go i buy around 3 and freeze them bc their so cheap and in the TL....good cold
author: alexandria g.

description: These are not the type of Vietnamese sandwiches I'm used to eating.  None of the flavors I grew to expect were represented.  I ordered two sandwiches: the combination and the tofu.  The pickled vegetables were bland and there was not, to my knowledge or senses, any paté, cured pork cold cuts, or headcheese.  In essence, it was like a pork sandwich minus everything that would make it a Vietnamese sandwich, save for the cilantro and baguette.  Never mind the fact that the two Chinese ladies behind the counter are mean and impatient, and use the same gloves to prepare your food as they do to handle your money.  Never mind all that, really.  The only reason this place gets three stars is because the tofu sandwich tastes so damn good.
author: Jenn C.

description:
soooo worth the trip down into the tenderloin for a good deal like this! the sandwiches here are soo filling and tasty! 

The deserts in the refrigerator are also a must! There's this layered jello that's green and cocoa colored! it's DELICIOUS. Has a nice hint of coffee and subtle sweetness...I don't know what the name of it is, but it's soo good, and for $2.50 how can you go wrong?! 

and plus, If you're in a hurry a good tip would be to call in the order...that way you avoid the line! It does get pretty crowded around the lunch hour

FIVE stars, Vietnamese sandwiches in sf don't get better than this!
author: Jen L.

description: Best banh mi i have tasted in san francisco, and at $3 a pop, very little can beat. It is not the best I have EVER tasted in the Bay Area and for those new to SS, I advise you keep your expectation luke warm and you will be thrilled. The hours of operation are limited. The line is relatively long, especially at meal time, and if you have to park your car at a meter. The banh mi was slapped togther with little love. Where is the love?
author: Kent H Y.

description: the Banh mi was good! I would definitely come back. The Combination for 3.75 was definitely a mouthful.
author: Eric A.

description: Saigon Sandwich is a very close walk from my apartment. I stumbled upon this little hole in the wall one day and decided to give it a try. I was not dissapointed. Their bahn mi's deliver on almost every front. The cilantro is fresh, the pickled vegetables are sweet and bright and the meat is bursting with that salty, umami flavor we all love. My only problem with this sandwich is the bread. It is super crunchy almost to the point of being hard. It's not a petite sandwich either, so you really have to tear in to this thing with some aggression. Nevertheless, I can get past the texture of the bread because of how awesome the sandwich is overall. Just beware, the roof of your mouth might be a little sore after eating one of these beasts.
author: Eric M.

description: This place is the motherflippin bomb.  I just got back from Vietnam, and I swear none of the Banh Mi I had there was as good as Saigon Sandwich.  I love the mayo and the pork here.  Despite the line you can pretty much count on being there, I have rarely ever waited very long.  They can really crank them out.  Soooo good, and such a good price.  Saigon Sandwich rules!
author: Sean H.

description: Amazing vietnamese sandwich. I had their regular roast pork and the flavors were dead on. The bread was crunch and tasted fresh and the vegetables all provided a nice complement to the sandwich. Glad you made the choice to come to America.
author: Andrew H.

description: To me, this place defines how a Viet sandwich is made.  Price is right, its in the TL.
author: S F.

description:
I come here at least once a week for a sandwich and pork bun. The food is delicious and inexpensive. The service is quick and attentive. 

The only downside is that there is usually a long line during lunch. However, these ladies work really hard to get everyone's order straight and to get everyone out the door fast.
author: Sean K.

description:
Yes, it's actually that good.  Yes, it's worth braving the neighborhood and the panhandlers outside.  Yes, the most expensive item in the whole place is $3.  If they charged twice as much I'd probably still go.  This place almost makes makes me want to live in the loin.

Crusty, fresh baguette.  Ideal proportions of meat, toppings, and bread.  Fresh cilantro, never wilting or soggy.  Ample (but not overpowering) spread of tasty mayo.  

Meatball and special combination are my favorites.  Don't be afraid of the pate (yelp does not allow me to add the accent, but you can still say it in your head "patay") in the combo, it's worth the extra 50 cents.  Some of the packaged goodies on the counter are worth your time, some are not.  Same goes for the colorful drinks in the refrigerated case.  But it's more fun if i let you figure that out for yourself.  Go and discover.  Your mouth will love you.
author: Ben S.

description:
I like this place, but as DeShawn Stevenson would say, this place is overrated!  

Price is great and sandwiches are definitely tasty, but write-ups in Esquire?  Bread is sometimes too hard and the quality of the meat is not the highest.  The service is below average with long waits often.  

Also, I've had hair in my sandwiches here on multiple occasions.  I searched the Yelp reviews and there were 5 other reviews of people that found hair in their sandwiches also.  I know there are a lot of reviews and it may be a small percentage, but seriously how hard is it for them to put their hair back or whatever they do at the restaurants where the food doesn't come with hair in it.
author: Nick L.

description:
Get a sandwich (or 2... or 3) here. Drive, take a cab, bike, hitchhike... whatever it takes, but find a way to get here and buy a couple of sandwiches. 

If you're the fussy type, put your issues in the back of your mind (and don't look around too closely). Yes, the place is more than a little dicey, but OMGWTFBBQ!!! Eating one of their sammiches is truly a pleasure. Sometimes a little painful when you bite into a raw Jalapeno, but even that pain is tasty. The rolls are beyond perfect, the fillings amazing. Best Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had.

There're also piles of other prepared foods all over the counters and any available horizontal surfaces throughout the tiny shop. I would never even consider buying one of these unnaturally colored horrors (I'm sure they're delicious, but the sandwiches!!!).

If you just can't bring yourself to go there in person, hire or bribe someone to go fetch them for you. The sandwiches are so cheap that even paying for gas or delivery charges would be worth it.

Finally, when you're standing on line, pay attention. The lady will ask for your order, and you had better be prepared. How she keeps track of everyone's order is beyond me. I think there's some kind of funky magic going on here.
author: C F.

description:
I was very excited to try Saigon Sandwiches since I have been obsessed with Vietnamese sandwiches since I had one at "Out the Door."  

But I have to admit that I was a little disappointed with it.  Although the bread was crispy to perfection and the chicken was bathed in yummy Five Spice, all of the ingredients weren't consistent through out the sandwich.  Some bites included the spicy jalapeno and some left me with a giant stalk of cilantro in my mouth.  

I mean it was good for $3, but it wasn't as great as I had hoped.
author: melissa o.

description:
Almost anyone you talk to will tell you that Saigon Sandwiches has the best Vietnamese sandwiches in town.  They're selling them short, because these are probably the best sandwiches in town, period, regardless of ethnicity or genre.

The tofu is soft and flavorful, the chicken and pork both juicy and fresh, and the rolls they come on are always warm and crisp on the outside and soft and fluffy in the middle.  It's hardly a secret, if you go at lunchtime you can expect to wait in line a few minutes, but an awesome sandwich for $3 is worth it everytime.
author: Harrison A.

description:
mygod. 

yes this is hands down my favorite banh mi store.
dont come here often but family has always ordered from them since i was a kid. its a small cafe in the tendorloin/little saigon area. so kinda sketch. as well they have a competitor lee sandwiches up the block.

banh mi from chicken, meatballs and combo are probably my top 3.
meatballs would probably be my favorite since they dont have it at other stores. but each sandwich will have yummyass flavor.
author: Michael L.

description: The meat in the pork sandwich tasted like it was cooked a little beforehand as it was warmish not hot.  I still like this place.  It has cheap sandwiches with crunchy bread and the meat was seasoned nice.  The lady also makes it pretty fast.
author: Matthew P.

description: While looking at different apartments in the city, Saigon sandwich has been the greatest force gravitating me to stay in the tenderloin. This place is THE BEST! Who would've known that cilantro, pickled carrots, spicy peppers, mayo and pork is the perfect cure for a hangover? I'll tell you who: the nicest, most assertive, and most hard working-est Vietnamese women you will ever meet. I've been here hundreds of times, and though my zest for life often fades, the kind tone in the woman's voice when she says "thank you so much" does not. This is a shining beacon of hope in a world of shit. But the mayo tastes weird and there is always a line. :)
author: Ian T.

description: Hidden gem. These sandwiches are bomb-diggity. A 3 dollar extremely tasty sandwich and quick service make this a lunch destination I could hit up every day of the week.
author: Justin F.

description: This is a no frills type of place but the sandwiches are the best! I really like the chicken. The bread has the right chewiness factor and combined with the veggies, sauce and meat the taste is sublime.  Just go and get one! You won't regret it. They also have a tofu sandwich for those vegetarians out there.  There are random snack items near the register which you can buy to accompany your meal.
author: Ka C.

description: The Roast Chicken Bahn Mi was delicious and the sandwich size is perfect for lunch. Definitely going back here again.
author: Sahir S.

description: Really good banh mi sandwiches.  Not the best I've ever had.  They have a little more bread than I would like.  I would definitely come back though but I don't think I'd go out of my way to try it.
author: Mark K.

description: STUPID cheap, STUPID amazing; the Banh Mi form of the good a.k.a GOD is present in this place, and it will soon be present in your stomach. Enjoy!
author: Haz O.

description:
#22 of 100 on 7x7's The Big Eat SF 2009: Vietnamese roasted pork sandwich at Saigon Sandwich
http://bit.ly/1VmqYA

#22 of 100 on 7x7's The Big Eat SF 2010: Vietnamese roasted pork sandwich at Saigon Sandwich
http://bit.ly/a1POhh

This busy little shop serves an amazing Vietnamese pork sandwich - and for only $3. That might be a little more than what you could pay at another Vietnamese sandwich shop, but the taste more than makes up for it! The bread is nice and crisp, with delicious chewiness inside. The pork is incredible, with hot peppers, carrots, cilantro, and other fixins that make this an excellent sandwich.

Expect long-lines when going and be prepared with what you want to get when the lady shouts for your order. Take-out only, although there are two seats in the front.
author: Reid Y.

description: great for birthday dinners!!.. just playin' it's small as balls in here which was inconvenient for me because i needed time to kill and ended up eating the sandwich.. in my car. but nonetheless, i eat a lot of vietnamese sandwiches.. because they are fairly cheap and delicious. and these... are probably the best ones i've ever had. it's unfortunate i live in SD so i won't be here often but everytime i'm up here i'll make an attempt to stop by
author: Tyson T.

description: Chicken Sandwich - extra parsley and peppers! mmmh good! This is literally a hole in the wall - the store is long narrow and packed with people.  You scream your order from where you are standing and wait patiently for your sandwich to be made by the two women who work there.  Worth the wait - if you live in SF and you haven't had a sandwich from here you should be ashamed to call yourself a local.
author: Nicole C.

description: greatttttttt viet sandwhich! i genreally dont like viet sandwhiches but this place is amazing. very small, they run on a fast pace as they can have tons of customers any time of the day - know what you want to order when you go in.  i got the meatball sandwhich - great taste, a subtle heat from the black pepper mixed in with the delicious meatball flavor. an amazing tasting, very generously portioned, very filling sandwhich for 3.50? yay!!!!!
author: Vicky T.

description: Found this place on yelp.  So good. Every time I'm in San Fransisco, I gotta get my bann mi fix.  LA just doesn't cut it.... get the fanci pork with the works.  and for $3 you can't go wrong.
author: Kel J.

description: No matter how Americanized I am, I am a picky eater. I know my Asian foods because I grew up with it. My parents used to be chefs of a Vietnamese restaurant so whenever we would go out we would always critique the food. Is it too salty? Is it too sweet? Looks like its dripping with grease? Oh man the service here is horrible, I am going to under tip them so they can change their attitude! Either way, trying Vietnamese food in Portland, Beaverton, San Francisco, San Jose, Westminster and especially at home, I can say with confidence that Saigon sandwiches have the best banh mi xiu mai or meatball subs! Go ahead and try it... Compare it to Lee's Sandwiches and you will see the difference in quality and flavor... After trying it, the next time you think of Saigon sandwiches you will definitely drool!
author: Tony T.

description: Think this is another place where my wife and i disagree.  Got the tofu sandwich, and she got the roast pork.   The include long slices of fresh jalepenos in the sandwich, and it quickly got to be so much that she couldn't finish.  That was enough for her to not want to come back.  Myself, yeah, it was hot, but the tofu was pretty tasty.  I enjoyed it and would definitely come back.  Just make sure you know what you want before they ask you!  They're working hard, and working fast, and don't like it when people are wishy-washy.
author: Phil J.

description: This small mama shop is awesome. On a nice day out. I love to just walk over and grab a roast pork sandwich for 3 bucks. I've tried the combo one but still prefer the solely roast pork one. Beware of long line during lunch hours
author: Ernie P.

description:
it's by the dreaded tenderloin... whoa scary stuff...  but in all seriousness the place is great.  i was trying to hate on it when i came in.  didn't even give it a chance to be that good but damn....  it is really that good.  the bread is a bit different.  more of a kaiser roll than a straight baguette.  the toppings are on par with other places.  what really makes it though... the freakin butter sauce.  what ever the sauce is actually, it makes the sandwich.

recommendations: get extra pate on everything and anything
author: Tam T.

description: For $3 bucks you get a well flavored sandwich in beautiful baguettes with heaps of roasted meat, shredded vegetables and that vietnamese mayo thing, sweet, cinammony and light. I get mine with extra jalapeno and extra cilantro. I also happen to love the variety of bizarre Vietnamese dessert treats and buns and what not, as well as Asian snack foods from other countries for sale here. Unfortunately the lady who runs this place speaks ZERO English so I haven't been able to take advantage of much of the Vietnamese offerings (I am scared of not knowing what I'm eating).
author: Y K.

description: Two words.. Very delicious!! I hoped for the sandwich to be a little bigger, but it's still good! Highly recommended!
author: Antone A.

description: The roasted pork sandwiches are cheap and delicious, you owe it to yourself to try one. Much like the women behind the counter. Just kidding, the women behind the counter are high class. I generally will combo this with some of the best pho in the city across the street at Turtle Tower.
author: John S.

description: This is a picture of me after eating cilantro- http://www.yelp.com/user_photos?userid=5vd9a7Xx_LlFfVogN1UsJg&select=YVAQ5DiNZajxIbRGZboSfg Obviously, I'm allergic.  Yet I risk life and looks just to have one of these bad boys.  They're that good.
author: Lauren C.

description:
you know the place is good when there is a long line of hungry people (going out the door!) patiently waiting for their banh mi, as these two ladies take the orders and create these savory and filling sandwiches.

went here for the pers tyme. yes. pers tyme.  with berna and we both got the sfecial combo (with the pork and the beef, and the pate, and some other pork).  $3.50 is an awesome price for a huge sandwich that is so satisfying and filling at the same time.  I knew it was going to be special when I saw the simple white deli paper wrapper, reinforced with a single, blue rubberband.  http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/oN1O2sFnEglsrCPsGAklsQ/l
It was a delightful, little present!  

Each sandwich is packed with contrasting yet complementary flavors: the heat from the jalapeno, the sweet n' sourness from the pickled carrots, the savory sweetness from the meats.... so effin' tasty!  It is huge also.  I was so afraid my mouth was too small for the monstrosity of these flavor-packed sandwiches, but I am glad I managed to wrap my mouth around a sizeable portion to take my first bite.  It was nice.  I had to take a moment to breathe since I was getting full already after eating 2/3 of it, but was glad to finish the whole thing.  

Finishing up the whole thing was the only proper way of doing it.  It was too good to waste.

( | )
author: Grace M.

description: If you can brave the shady alleys and suspicious loiterers outside this unassuming shop in the Tenderloin, you're in for a treat. The bread for the sandwiches are baked right before your sandwich is made, and the result is fantastic: crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside. I had the pork sandwich, which was great. You can really taste every ingredient: the mild sweetness of the carrot, the tangy and slightly bitter lettuce... it just all comes together. If you don't like spicy food, ask them to leave out the jalapenos, which really give the sandwich an extra kick. Never mind the shady guy standing right outside, just take your sandwich and go.
author: Michael C.

description:
never really been a fan of banh mis. i guess you can say saigon sandwich has changed me. yeah, banh mis aren't too bad afterall. maybe all the ones i've had in the past (not very many) were just awful vietnamese sandwiches or something. i have to say, this place knows what they're doing. the flavor's perfect. took the first bite of my roasted pork sandwich and i thought to myself, omg.. it's just like eating pho, but on a sandwich! okay, that's totally not it, but i guess what i'm trying to say is, the flavors are so familar, that it's just yummy. 

overall, very good sandwiches. will definitely go back, only wish it wasn't so far away from my work place. cheap and delicious. a must try. :)
author: mai c.

description: Hole in the wall and the line can get pretty long, but the sandwiches are delicious and affordable. Only $3, but they pack on the meat, veggies and mayo. One of the best vietnamese sandwiches I've ever had.
author: Annie C.

description:
i had an excellent day. 

i spent it huffing and puffing up and down a steep mountainside with a good friend who is equally in love with food as i am, and we spent a lot of time between our heavy breathing talking about our favorite meals. 

he was recently introduced to the world of banh mis, and i couldn't help but express my love for saigon sandwiches. 

for a tiny little shop packed with asian snacks and pre-packaged meals, they also serve some of the best banh mis in SF. 

fresh and crisp french bread smothered in butter, mayonnaise and pate. cilantro, pickled carrots/daikon/onions, generous jalapeno slivers, and your choice of bbq pork/chicken, tofu, steamed pork or jambon.

the sandwich overflows with the ingredients, and is served warm. WARM!

so, like the little piggy that i am, before ordering my chicken noodle soup at hai ky mi gia, i stopped by the deli to buy a banh mi for a late, saturday night snack.
author: May T.

description: I don't understand all the hype about this place - it's not even authentic! My coworkers love this place. The sandwiches are mediocre at best - not worth the wait either.. Go to Sing Sing, it's way better.
author: C. T.

description: Saigon sandwiches is my last stop of things to do in Little Saigon before I go home. After eating at Turtle Tower (See previous review) I stop in here to grab two sandwiches. One for the ride home and one for later. If you are familiar with Vietnamese sandwiches then this is the ultimate spot. It's a sort of Viet Sandwich Mecca if you will. Of course everyone talks about the Banh Mi but I usually go for the combo. It's a difference of 50 cents!!! Cheap, delectable and filling this is the other hidden gem in the TL that is easy on the stomach and the wallet.
author: Jason C.

description: For $2.50 you can get a delicious warm French roll stuffed with shredded carrots, onions, cilantro, jalapeos and five-spice chicken.  What else is there to say?  Go!
author: Stacy R.

description: Best Vietnamese roasted pork sandwich in the city! It just sucks that I live so far otherwise I would have it often. So cheap and good... banh mi is so so good!!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
mmm. I can't say enough good things about Saigon Sandwich.  I get 5 sandwiches on Monday morning and store them in the fridge at work.  Once I am sufficiently hungry, I take one of these lovingly wrapped sandwiches and open it slowly... the condensation means the fridge is working.  Take half of the sandwich and place it into the microwave and set it to 45seconds.  Once it is done, let the sandwich sit for 1 minute.  Serve hot optionally with a cup of masala chai.

Vietnamese Foodgasm.
author: Anuj G.

description: Thank you Saigon for hiking your prices to $3 per sandwich.....oh that delicious, juicy pork meatball with fresh peppers and cilantro and crispy carrot.  Oh sorry, wet on a tangent.  So, yeah, thank you Saigon for raising your prices so I dont feel so freakin' guilty after tricking you into selling me a meal for less than I can make it for!
author: Mike H.

description: Most delicious banh mi I've ever had.  Roasted pork or roasted chicken, both stellar.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but these sandwiches actually make me feel like I WANT TO drive to the Tenderloin, circle for a parking spot, rustle around for coins to feed the meter, stand in line for 20 min. to get a sandwich, and watch some homelss woman pet her rats out in front.
author: Julie T.

description: Looking for the best Vietnamese sandwich ever? Well, you've found it here. I discovered this little gem in the Tenderloin while in law school right around the corner.  Not a hood you necessarily think of when you're looking for a good meal, but this place is definitely the exception. And the prices are almost unfairly cheap @ $3 for the best sandwich you can imagine. The bread is super fresh, and whatever's in that special sauce-yummmmmy!  I've made a special trip into the 'Loin on more than one occasion for one of these things. Trust me, you'll love it.
author: Natalie N.

description:
come rain or come shine, expect to wait in line.  

When I got out of the shop, as the rain was coming down a bit, there was a few people inside of Lee's (across the street) versus a line waiting in the rain for this joint.  You should know all the difference.
author: S S.

description: This place has been reviewed over a thousand times, so my review probably isn't necessary. I will just say that don't be intimidated by the line, it moves fast. The sandwiches are good and you can't beat the value. My only complaint is the sauce is a little to sweet for my taste.
author: jen w.

description:
Planned on getting a roasted pork sandwich from this place quite a while ago.  When I got there, I realized I had no cash 
(poor planning), but I asked around and found an atm nearby yay! I go back to the place and was a bit confused as to how the line works.  Apparently, they take about 5 people's orders, fulfills them, then they take the next 5 people's orders and so on.  Anyway, ordered the roasted pork sandwich.  Took it to my car, unwrapped it, took a bite, and cried a little because it was that good. THAT GOOD.  Saigon Sandwich, i will bbl.
author: Oli H.

description: Love this place! *Yummy* And props to the ladies who work there -- they are always so busy and really hustle to make the sandwiches for everyone.
author: C C.

description:
This place is one of my favorite little shops in all of SF. No matter which sandwich you try, they are all tasty and delicious. There are really no downsides about this place other then the awkward situation you might run into with the people in the streets. Wait time can vary since the line is usually out the door, but its still manageable. 
      For $3 and change.. I can eat this everyday. They're also pretty smart by placing all the impulse snacks right on the counter to entice you while you wait. I always get the crunchy shell peanuts which are very addicting. I dare say there are as many Banh Mi addicts due to Saigon Sandwich as there are crack and meth heads now in the TL!
author: JOHN N.

description: 3 bucks for an amazingly delicious sandwich.  I liked that they didn't skimp on the cilantro or the jalapenos (maybe too many jalapenos but I'd rather have too many and pick them out than not enough!).  I tried the roast pork and the tofu and they were both amazing.  It's definitely worth the sketchy walk and the wait in line, the line moves quickly thanks to the fast work of the 2 women at the counter and like I said, 3 bucks for an amazing & tasty sandwich can't be beat!
author: Suzanne V.

description: This place is the best V- sandwich in the bay area. Back in the days the sandwiches were $1.50 each. Now I believe they are $2.75 each.  I have tried many places in the Richmond district, sunset and even downtown but nothing can beat this place for the price and quality. When i go I usually by 10 sandwiches at a time. I usually order the bbq. pork or chicken. The sandwich comes with shredded carrots,peppers, radish strips and parsley on a warm baguette. I think what makes the sandwiches here is the special secret sauce (mayo) and the crispy bread.
author: Steve w.

description:
this will not be the best sandwich you ever have, but it sure is for 3 bucks. the line here can get pretty long since us yelp snobs know all about it. i'm pretty sure if you speak vietnamese, you can cut the line but maybe thats my imagination. my favorite is probably roast pork.
screw lee's sandwich, this is the best vietnamese sandwich you'll get in little saigon.
author: chris b.

description: Well I'll be the polemic element on Yelp by arguing that Saigon Sandwiches sucks.  I'm Vietnamese and I HEART Vietnamese sandwiches, in fact while I was living in Vietnam I ate one every day for breakfast.  In my humble opinion, Saigon Sandwiches overstuffs their rolls with pate and meats that is of low quality.  If you want better bread and a sandwich that doesn't drip pate out the other end as you try to take a bite go to Lee's down the street.  Lee's is also cleaner, newer and offers a better selection of Vietnamese snacks and goodies.
author: Amber L.

description:
Roll on down into the loin (tenderloin to your non locals a.k.a tender nob) and you can pick up a crazy snack at this hole in the wall establishment.  Order a sandwich and broaden your horizon as it looks like a salad in a sandwich, just roll with it, eat it and be happy. 

You can easily bide your time while they are making your lunch, looking over the plethora of  unusual food items being sold at the counter. What is the green concoction...no idea, is that a drink or a meal...no idea...oh lunch is ready, few dollars and out the door.  This rating is food only, as it is not a sit down establishment.
author: Niko P.

description: Great cheap Vietnamese Sandwiches. Lines normally out the door.
author: Johnson H.

description: Judging from the locals, it must be easy to get your hands on some crack in this neck of the woods which lends support to my theory that the sandwiches here are so good they must be made with small amounts of the addictive substance.  Don't get me wrong, you won't catch me offering sexual favors for one of their delicious meatball sandwiches but I will drive down there and step over all the man poo to get one.  Have one and you will too.
author: Tommy O.

description: I grew up eating banh mi for breakfast, lunch and dinner and while Saigon makes a decent one, it is by no means the best. Shows the hype machine does work. My aunt is actually related to the family who owns the joint. I need to remember to ask her what their profit margins are.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
5 stars for taste!  the wait though - it sucks.  even those these ladies totally crank out the sandwiches at light speed, it's no match for the phone and large to go orders, not to mention the line that grows exponentially as the lunch hour grows closer.

i have been eating these since a kid but this place is BY FAR the best.  i love that they're open as 6 am and that even though it looks not so big - the sammies here get you totally stuffed, and are totally stuffed w/ yummy goodness. cheap cheap eats w/ lots of meat and the right amount of pickled veggie fillers. - hmmm i wish i had one now.
author: Runt T.

description: Soooo, in my ever long quest to find the perfect Banh MI i had to try Saigon Sandwich. This place is legendary on yelp. Overall good stuff! As a lot of yelpers comment, its all about the bread and this place kills it in that department. Perfect texture and crunch without a flaky mess that you get at some places. The meat (i tried the pork, player) was thinly sliced which is what sets them apart from a lot of other Banh Mi places in the city (i personally like it a little thicker...so the 4 star rating.) Good stuff overall, there was a line so keep that in mind. Its close to city center and saw chris daley (board of supervisors) there too, kinda funny seeing him. Rumor has it that gavin likes this place...if thats what your into.
author: Lindonesia S.

description: OK I finally got myself to the TL to get me my sandwich. My friend recommended the meatball and holy crap it was good! I thought it was pate I was eating but it was the meatballs. So much flavor it was Ridick! So what other flavors are good? Can a longtime goer rate the best to the worst? Thanks
author: Karen T.

description: So, I really like their sandwiches but I don't go there anymore since I saw a little cockroach running across the floor. I'm surprised no one stepped on it given how packed they normally are.
author: Jordan W.

description:
what i didn't expect at the random hour of 4:15pm was a line that snaked out the door.  however it dissipated in a matter of minutes due to the efficiency of the ladies who were preparing the sanwiches.

who would've thought that for a mere $3, you could get an utterly satisfying, lip-smacking sandwich that is guaranteed to fill you up?

standing in line, i wasn't sure which type of pork to order; the roasted or fancy pork.  but being intrigued by the name, i decided to give my palate a treat with the fancy pork.  as she piled it into the sandwich though, i realized that wasn't quite what was I was expecting!  for those of you who don't know, they're thin slabs of cold pork which looks like it's been ground into a smooth paste and then sliced.  texturally and taste-wise, i thought it was similar to japanese fish cake!  so i ordered the roast pork too in case that was disappointing.

the fancy pork was fine, but i'd probably just stick to the roasted meats in the future.  it's slightly sweet and while firm, a tad spongy.

the roasted pork sandwich was yummy.  the thin slices of fatty roasted pork were generously layered into a french baguette, along with a smear of mayo and tangy-sweet onion & carrot slaw, punctuated by thin slices of jalapeno and tons of fresh cilantro.  i'm a carb lover (atkins be damned!) and the bread made the sandwich; it was crisp on the outside which gave a satisfying 'crunch' when bitten into, and nice and chewy on the inside.

were my lips greasy after i finished the crispy, savory Vietnamese torpedo?  heck yeah.  nothing a few napkins couldn't take care of.   but man, this was one of those meals that i wouldn't mind spending an hour on the elliptical for.

you can't get a better sandwich for $3!
author: Janet L.

description: The best vietnamese sandwich I have ever tasted in the bay area. If you go at lunch time there will be a long long line. My favorite is the combination and the pork sandwich with extra jalepeno's. I would recommend to call ahead before you go so you can skip the line and just tell them you called. the last time i called for my sandwiches, i was able to skip the line and go to the front and tell them I called and they had to ask me what I ordered and they made it right away. If you dont want to wait a long time for your sandwiches make sure to call.
author: Elina A.

description: Long lines, waiting, everyone in front of me is a hipster. Finally my turn, sandwiches go for about $3-$3.50. On my way out, line got even longer. There's something about the sandwiches, I think its the bread. It's not a typical french roll nor baguette.
author: Robin L.

description: Really good Vietnamese sandwiches.  Cheap.  I like the chickien. Not really any seats (assume take out), lines can get long.  Great value.
author: Peter A.

description: Banh mi perfection. Had the chicken for breakfast, the pork for lunch, and I could have had more but I was leaving town that day. I've been to the best banh mi places in NYC, and nothing compares. Num Pang perhaps, but it's more expensive than Saigon. This is the best cheap eat EVER.
author: Adam K.

description: oh man. you are hungry. you are near polk. you are almost broke. you just elbowed the 7 trannys off the stoop of this beat to shit walk-in to get a bite. and thats what you got....a bite of rank mayo and old carrots and bread that will cut your gums and some kind of meat. i usually like pork at these Vietnamese spots. fuck knows what i ate. i wish i knew so i could brag about whatever it may have been. probably street critter.
author: aidan m.

description: I know this has been ranked as the end-all and be-all of bani mi sandwiches in the Bay Area, but while waiting for my food I found myself staring at the ten gallon-sized containers of Kraft Mayonnaise on their counter and realizing that, while I do love mayo, even I have a natural limit, and their sandwiches take me to it. Take me beyond it. Add to that their room-temp meats and so-so bread, and it equals me moving on to warmer, fresher, slightly less mayo-ed banh mi.
author: Ian G.

description:
over 200 reviews so why read mine. not much i can say that others have not. but what the hell.

i got three sandwiches and cut them in half to share with my wife. roast chicken, roast pork, and pork meatball. pork meatball was my favorite. the others were a bit too fatty for me. but they cleaned up fine after i did some lipo on the meats.

the bread is very good with the carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, mayo topping it off. a lady behind me ordered a chicken banh mi made with all white meat chicken so that might alleviate the fatty problem i had. 

i will go back but the wait is a little long. i went at 2:30pm and waited about a half hour. not too bad and the two ladies work fast to move the line along. now i am going to have to find other great banh mi in the city without the wait. another search is on.
author: roger b.

description: A thousand voices can't be wrong.  Can't add much to the mob expect my experiences.  The bread is different but not in a bad way so I'm still searching for the ultimate banh mi.  However, the filling is second to none.  Great fresh ingredients and tasty meats in good quantities.  Pity it's off the beaten track for me.
author: Chris C.

description: Great $2 price for a cha lua (aka "special pork") banh mi, but very lackluster in key ways.  The bread's freshness and quality fell far short.  The creamy, tangy, sweet spread was flavorful, but it was a literal blob oozing out from the  interior bread crease.  A lighter amount and spreading it within the sandwich would have been much better.  Lastly, there were zero jalapenos to speak of, and I had asked for hot.  All in all, this banh mi was not for me.
author: M A N I K.

description: the best bahn mi in SF. hands down.
author: M K.

description: I love this place. Every time I go here I go on a spending spree. So many delights from my childhood. They have che, and all the sweets, and my favorite brand of beef jerky (not like that western crap that will demolish your intestines), cha lua, and oh yeah, sandwiches aka banh mi (which literally just means bread, btw). However, it's overpriced. Yes, 2.75 is cheap, but you SF ppl are getting hosed. 1.50 in Sunnyvale, and 1.00 in San Jose and LA. Usual Asian rules apply. Look for a high Asian quotient (AQ), and the dirtier, the better and more authentic. San Jose is much better (for once, and when it comes to all thing Viet, beats SF always), but for a cheap lunch, this is a good place. NB it closes at 5PM.
author: Hao L.

description: I got my first sandwich from here well over 15 years ago when it was $1.50.  What's crazy is that the prices has not changed a whole lot.  Still a bargain, and to this day, the best Vietnamese sandwiches made.  There's always a long line during lunch time for a reason.  The staff members there are always really nice, and they have other items as well.  If you have not tried it yet, go and check it out.  You might stumble upon something that you may really like.
author: Bernie C.

description:
"Me so hungry!"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t0oALRL7uyY

Sittin at the office with my stomach all hungry
So I got on yelp to find a new place to see
Picked up the telephone, then dialed the 7 digits
Said, yo, this Herm, baby! are you open with it?
I arrived at the shop, line outside the door
Having no idea of what the shop had in store
With little cash in my pocket, my stomach growling without warning
I was ready to devour a sando, cause me so hungry!

Oh, me so hungry, oh oh, me so hungry, oh me so hungry, me hungry long time!

Owners starts asking me "what do you want?"
I say give me a chicken sando, in a low polite grunt.
The owner says, you got it son, he could tell my hunger was bad
Like I haven't eaten, since I finished the Iliad.
I pay for my order, walk past all the people,
Get outside, my mouth was already lethal.
I tear open the wrapper, and get down on one knee,
And whisper to the sandwich, I'm so hungry!

Oh, me so hungry, oh oh, me so hungry, oh me so hungry, me hungry long time!

You can say I was hungry, even call me famished,
Cause in a matter of seconds, my sando just vanished.  
My hunger went away, it was too good to be true,
Is this what a $3 dollar sandwich is supposed to do?
As I walk back to my car, my composure back intact,
I yell out to the store, "Thanks guys, I'll be back!"
Thank you Saigon Sandwiches, you helped set me free,
For the next hour or so, I will no longer be hungry!
author: Herman N.

description:
This is my first review, and I'm giving it to these ladies at Saigon Sandwich.

The sandwiches are layered with various combination of meats, tofu, pickled vegetables, and other condiments. The bread has a nice crunchy crust and a soft chewy center.

They also carry a nice selection of side dishes and desserts as well. I highly recommend this my friends and neighbors of SF.
author: Cyrick H.

description: I live next door so I'm a bit biased but if I don't feel like cooking and am pretty broke then I can't go wrong with a Saigon Sandwich. There isn't much to them but at $3 a pop it's worth it. I recommend the roasted chicken and/or tofu sandwiches.
author: Franco A.

description: You got a jury duty summons for SF Superior at 400 McAllister or 450 Golden Gate District Ct?  Well, it's time to rejoice!  Because this nearby banh mi joint is the best to chase those civic duty blues.  Lines out the door cannot be wrong.  The bread isn't on the shelf long enough to go stale.  The pate version is unbelievable.  And you'll be back, jury duty or not.
author: K W.

description: WOW! This is the MEAT-iest Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. We tried the pork and the chicken sandwiches and both were amazingly laden with meat! 4" thick. The 8" or 10" french roll was fresh, stuffed with seasoned daikon and carrots and some sort of greenery, and jalapeno peppers. Watch out for the seeds. Made my lips numb. So good and so worth it at $2.75 a pop.
author: Cindy W.

description:
This place is pretty amazing.  Big menu, very cheap prices, and fast service.   You can get like a whole meal for just a few dollars- it's crazy.  

I had their spicy curry chicken & it was really good.  Very spicy- just how I like it ;).  The sandwiches are very good, as well.  I obviously haven't tried all of them though because there's like 7389339409 different ones to choose from.

Looking for a great variety of quality food that's very inexpensive?  Go here.
author: Blushed M.

description: How can you beat $2.75 vietnamese sandwiches? You cant! This place is a great hole in the wall place that gets TONS of business. I've personally waited like 20 min for a pork sandwich. I like the quality of their ingrediants and i am pleased the pork isnt all fat like some places are. This place rocks! Watch out tho - can be a very looooong line at lunch time.
author: Julie F.

description:
Simply the best Vietnamese sandwich in San Francisco!!!
The word is authentic!!!  If you want McD's style sandwich you can head over to lee's sandwich...
author: James H.

description: I am definitely a fan of both the BBQ chicken and pork. I tend to eat the chicken the most though. The meatball is pretty good as well, but I don't order it as often. I don't like the combo at all as it tastes horrible to me. Go to Sing Sing around the corner if you want a combo. So the bottom line is the sandwiches are great and is a great value, but the biggest drawback ( and why I wouldn't give this place a five) is the ridiculous line. Also don't even bother calling as they'll sometimes make your order then just give it out to the whoever is in line. Seems like they allow "regulars" to cut in as well which can add to your wait time. It you are not in a rush though, this place is definitely worth trying!
author: John C.

description: Ridiculously delicious sandos for $2.50 each.  Yesterday I ate two sandwiches for lunch - a roasted pork and a meatball.  I almost threw up afterwards, but it was totally worth it, I assure you.  That sketchy mayonnaise they use is like creamy crack, and if you want some real crack, I'm sure one of the friendly denizens of the neighborhood would be happy to help you out.
author: Alex P.

description: Very tasty Banh Mi! I've had this Vietnamese sandwich at many places and this place is on the top of the list.  This place is a teeny, dirty little hole-in-the-wall (-1 star) that's so typical Vietnamese-- packed with stuff and no room to sit.  Great for takeout, which is exactly what I did. I had the roast chicken, which had nice tender chunks of marinated chicken along with the standard fillings.  My friends had the combination.  I tried their jia (spelling?? meeting Vietnamese pudding desserts) which was eh-ok.  All together, I think 3 sandwiches + 2 "jia" and 1 banana-coconut-rice dessert role (surprisingly yummy) was ~$15.  For that price, I could eat like this everyday !!
author: Grace M.

description:
after moving to cali from seattle, i began to miss the good ol' banh mi's i would get in dt seattle...while living in la i satisfied my banh mi cravings with lee's sandwiches...but when my bf took me to saigon sandwich one day after eating chicken pho at turtle tower, i knew that lee's was def. overrated

you kno its good when theres a line on a saturday late morning...the place is small, but the bread is soft + the rest is fantabulouso! i always ask for extra jalapenos and cilantro b/c i like the extra kick...there is not one person who denies that saigon sandwich is their favorite banh mi place
author: Alice K.

description: I dunno. I mean, the sandwich was decent... but certainly nothing to rave about? I came here with moderately high expectations so I guess that was my problem. I was wierded out a bit at first when the vegetarians in front of me got pork instead of vegetarian as they had desired. The lady seemed really over-worked. I'll come back here and try it again, but I'd caution people not to expect a new miracle.
author: Sven S.

description: Just ignore your surroundings, because this is a five-star reason to go to a one-star part of town. It's difficult to say what's more phenomenal, the sandwiches or the price.  As long as you're in the neighborhood, buy several and stock up on lunch for the week . . . if they manage to last that long.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I don't really give 5/5s but this place deserves it.. It's got the best Vietnamese sandwiches in town although the place is kind of small with very limited seating.. The sandwiches are just that damn good.. Bread is baked perfectly and everything is prepared perfectly.. BBQ chicken and pork are the way to go 5/5
author: Mike L.

description: It's the best vietnamese sandwich place in the bay area.  I have been coming here the past 10 years.  My favorite sandwich is the combo special, then the meatball and roast pork come in 2nd and 3rd.  For those meat lovers this place is great.  The price has gone up over the years from $2.75 to $3.75 for a combo, but well worth it.
author: Steve L.

description: Great cheap lunch! There can be always a line, especially during lunch hours but I always ended up here during lunch when I went to school couple blocks away (CCA).. You know students like us need to live on cheap food since our tuition is THAT high! Anyways.. I love ,the Banh Mi Special Combination. All sorts of meats in a sandwich. Also should try their desserts that are on the counter and their Banh Bao. (Steamed buns) really delicious.
author: Juliane N.

description:
I haven't had Vietnamese sandwiches since I left SoCal about a year ago (Mr. Baguette being my favorite). It just occurred to me today as I was riding the shuttle through the TL that perhaps one of the little shops along Larkin might be worth checking out. A quick yelp search on my trusty blackberry suggested that Saigon Sandwich was the place to go. Around lunch time, there was a rather long line out the door of this unassuming little shop. 

Kenny: People in San Francisco are so obsessed with food they will wait in line if the food is worth it.
Me: Actually, they'll wait in line just because there is a line.

So, being the San Franciscans that we are, Kenny and I waited a good 15 minutes with high expectations for our potentially over hyped sandwiches. Our order was taken before we even reached the counter- Kenny going for the roast chicken and pork, while I stuck with the only vegetarian option on the menu, tofu. We waited a bit longer and finally the sandwiches were ready, and for the price ($2.75) the quantity is certainly not lacking. We sat down by the window to try our much awaited treats, while sipping on some very strange creamy-coconutty- tapioca and bean concoctions. The sandwiches were warm, the baguette slightly crispy (but not as good as at Mr. Baguette). The tofu was tasty, it is the kind of fried tofu that you find in inari sushi- fried, seasoned, and pressed into sheets. Also in the mix were an assortment of pickled vegetables- onions, carrots, and peppers. The pickles were not as sweet as at Mr Baguette, but the peppers were spicier. I tried Kenny's meat sandwiches but was not a fan. The roast chicken was mostly dark meat, and tasted too meaty for me. The pork was also a bit on the strong side. They serve the meat sandwiches with a generous dousing of gravy, which results in soggy bread if not eaten immediately. As for the drinks- the green and white coconut cream variety was not bad, tasted almost like melted ice cream with some green jelly chunks swimming about. The tapioca drink on the other hand (the one with the little balls that look like frog eggs) was definitely not my cup of tea. In summary, this is a cheap sandwich place which is definitely worth paying a visit to if you happen to be in the area and are not in a rush. However, I don't think it is as good as the other Vietnamese sandwiches I've had in SoCal.
author: Kate A.

description: This place is small! But their sandwiches are pretty good! They should put more stuff on it, like for pickled veggies, I love those. This place is more authentic then Little Paris! This place is straight up Vietnamese! Besides that it is in the Tenderloin. They have quite a good selection of   Vietnamese food.
author: Janet Z.

description: Before coming to saigon sandwiches i had never even tried a vietnamese sandwich. So i'm definitely glad i came here for my very first one! It was SO GOOD! the roll was crunchy yet not crumby and the pickled veggies were just right. I got the pork and i'm glad i did! My friend always get the tofu and surprisingly enough, it wasn't that bad! they have their own special sauce that makes it flavorful. I love that the prices as well. $3 for a sandwich??? Its great for poor college students like me! I just wish they stayed open later..you know, for those "i'm studying late and i'm getting kinda hungry" nights. Definitely coming back for more!
author: Suzan L.

description: I don't understand why people would give anything lower than 5 stars. They are awesome.
author: Gessa C.

description:
good sandwhiches. cheap as hell. i got the meat ball pork, and the roasted chicken sandwich. hell, at $2.50 a pop, why not splurge a little? i prefered the meat ball one over the roasted chicken. i'm pretty picky with my chicken meat and it was pretty fatty and it was dark meat - instead of white meat ... but that's just me. 

it'll probably be a while until the next time i go back - since it's kinda out of the way and they have weird hours. but i was glad i gave it a go.

oh yeah, next time i'll know to get my sandwiches without the peppers. that shit is hot!
author: James J.

description: Unbeatable delicious Vietnamese sandwiches for $2.75!  What a bargain! The owners are so generous and very kind. This past Sunday I was there, the line was long. But it goes quick. Yet there was homeless lady walk into the store ask for change. Of course, the owner was kind enough to giver her a buck. Because the owner was extremely handling orders. If isn't for the location, they will get five star from me.
author: Nancy T.

description: Just adding my two cents. The tastiness you get for what you pay - hard to find much better...! I drool sometimes when I think about those sandwiches...
author: Sophia L.

description:
I came to  this sandwich shop in search of a really really good Vietnamese bbq pork sandwich- and upon reading some of the yelp reviews- this one would be an idyllic place...
I ordered on the phone to go- a recommendation because the lines went out the door...after repetitive excercises on what I wanted- I finally got it all through- 1 bbq pork, 2 chicken and 1 pate... fo odo toto...YES!!!
No parking was available of course- so I jumped off the car and entered the door- "Yes Im here to pick up my order to go"...what odo? Ummm repeat selections again... Oh ok I make foyo...
To my amazement the lady did not wash her hand after handling money from the previous buyer???!!??!??  Everything was made in a  hurry- the veggies were stuffed right at the center- so you kind of had to spread it yourself...buns were barely lukewarm...
The Taste...
I just had a bite off each ;-)  my friends finished the rest...
Chicken was the best in my opinion...
BBQ pork- too sweet - steamed with bbq sauce...not for me...
Pate- also sweet...I dont want to sound so finicky but the cash register should not be in the prep area of sandwiches...
I dont think I'll be back :-(
author: Arissa C.

description: Do not go to this place unless you don't care about cleanliness.   The two old ladies behind the counter uses the same hand to touch money and then make your food.  It is so unsanitary there and they reuse the disposable glove again and again.  Their sandwiches taste the same as Lee's and Lee's is only 50 cents more. Seriously it is really dirty and my coworker and I will never go back there again.  Pay the extra 50 cents for clean food.  I promise you won't regret it!
author: Edith L.

description: Simple menu. Simply amazing bahn mi. Under $4. What more could one ask for?
author: Michael H.

description: pricey compared to milpitas.  nothing spectacular in the taste.
author: Cathy U.

description: Tasty cheap sandwiches. Crunchy bread, fresh veg and herbs, flavorful seasonings. The pork and chicken were a little on the dry side, but all the sauce and toppings compensated.
author: Jose R.

description:
I have to add my five stars to the hundreds here. Run, don't walk! This place is incredible -- a real neighborhood treasure. The line snaking out the door goes faster than you might think. Saigon Sandwich destroys the competition on this street with its warm crusty baguettes STUFFED with super-fresh ingredients.  I especially like the simplicity of the small menu. And the price! How much longer will we be able to get sandwiches this good for under $4.00? The women who do the work here have really earned their success. 

The best sandwiches of any kind in all San Francisco. No kidding. Five Stars!
author: Scotia W.

description: There should always be a Saigon Sandwich within a 20 minute walk of wherever I am.  I don't understand why there aren't more awesome Vietnamese sandwich spots.
author: Trevor S.

description: These are some of the better Vietnamese sandwiches in the city. Very cheap (you can get really full for $5) and generally fast (tip, know what you want when you get to the front of the line... I've been skipped for not having my act together). The tofu sandwich though is hit or miss. Sometimes it's delicious and sometimes the tofu is rubbery and gross. If you can avoid going right at the lunch hour peak (12-1) you will probably have a better experience and won't have to wait 20 mins for your sandwich.
author: Rebecca H.

description: $3.25 for a hot banh mi on a blustery sf afternoon. there's nothing better than a fresh baguette lightly dressed with mayo, carrot slices, cilantro, roast pork, and steamed pork to heat you up, especially when the banh mi is so damn tasty that you end up licking your fingers afterward to savor the flavor. these ladies are quick and efficient, and their banh mi are clearly top notch quality. cheap street eats really do no get any better than this.
author: Danny C.

description: Thanks to the great people of the Yelp community for introducing me to the world of Saigon Sandwich heaven and oh my goodness...all I can say is if I have to live in the TL, but live off Saigon Sandwiches then I would do it...this place is the bomb (do people still use this word, oh my gosh I'm so old school) anyway, I tried the pork sandwich edition and goodness gracious...let me tell you it is the best banh mi ever...Ever!!
author: murs.one ..

description:
Really more like 4.5 stars, darn the lack of increments. Was recommended to me by my very Vietnamese friend. She has yet to steer me wrong with their food.  
So, SO cheap, and so tasty. The sandwiches here are warm, taste of fresh ingredients, and the options, while limited, offer something for everybody. I have only had the chicken and various pork offerings, but they are consistent in their tastiness. While there is almost always a wait, the two ladies take orders and fill them with an efficiency rarely seen today in the business. How she remembers who got what is absolutely beyond me. 
My favorite moment that stems from this was when i picked up three sandwiches from here, and took them over to 1000 Van Ness to watch "Nacho Libre" with two of my male friends. I had two pork and one chicken one, and I swore up and down I asked for no peppers. I started in on mine, and both boys asked me for one. But two minutes after I heard the paper rustle in the unwrapping process, I thought they were going to cry from the heat. Both of them were sweating bullets from the first few bites into the sandwiches. The peppers are there, proceed with caution. 
So the neighborhood's a little sketch, but really, you are only going to spend 15, maybe 20 minutes tops waiting around, and the "local color" reminds me that i DO live in a city with depth. 
If you are feeling adventurous, try the various sweets in front of you, or the variety of drinks in the fridge. Their summer rolls are pretty good as well.
author: Jessica S.

description: Larkin, from Eddy on up, its turning into a Vietnamese Sandwich sideshow, with at least 4 Vietnamese sandwich shops within a two-block radius. Most recently another has popped up just across the street from Saigon (Lee's Sandwiches, a new chain with many other establishments in Bay Area cities like Fremont & San Jose) - MAKE NO MISTAKE, THEY CANNOT BEAT SAIGONS' SAMMYS! (yes that's baby talk for sandwiches) Yummier bread and more home-style meat @ Saigon plus that incredible butter-mayonnaise. Place also has a clean bill of heath review posted in plane view.
author: The Shmooze ..

description: If you want good, cheap eats, then this is the place to be.  The lines are long during lunch, but it's well worth the wait.  If you want to be adventurous then get a can of the grass jelly drink.
author: Jameson H.

description: My bf and I have never been disappointed by the sandwiches here. He calls it a sandwich sweatshop. When the lines get really long, they ask everyone in line what they want to order and pump it out all at once. Well worth the drive down to TL , then the drive around the block to look for parking(then eventually parking in the bus stop zone, due to no parking) and then waiting in line.
author: carebear l.

description: Just what a good Vietnamese sandwich shop should be.  Fresh bread, pork products, cheap and delicious.  That damn French bread always rips up the roof of my mouth, but it's so worth it.  Pleasure pain principle.
author: Corey V.

description: I love cilantro and let me just say, this place has the freshest cilantro, year-round!  The pork sandwich is amazing, made with delicious fresh bread, amazingly marinated pork, fresh cilantro, carrots and jalapenos.  I can't quite wrap my mind around all of the flavors, but together they meld into magical goodness.  Super cheap ($3!), super fast (even when crowded) and always consistently delicious.  Nowhere to eat inside - I like to just sit on the curb in front of the Phoenix hotel and watch the Tenderloin pass me by...  They also have lots of interesting saran-wrapped goodies on the counter.
