If you are feeling adventurous, try one on for size.  Will it be sweet?  Will it be savory?  Who knows!  I can't understand what she says they are made of?!?!?  Will it be good?  Yes, knowing Saigon Sandwiches, it probably will be good...
author: Cat P.

description: banh mi...vietnamese baguette "salad sandwiches"...under $three each....toasted warm thick "fat" baguette....choice of main meat...choice being banh mi xiu mai...lil' saucin' 'n' mayo.....fillin' of cilantro, carrots, onions 'n' fresh raw sliced jalepenos....warning: spicy hot hot hot hot~!~!!.....911 fire department burn....overall an excellent sandwich...wantin' for banh mi shop near home....also saigon providing korean snacks 'n' other small items to munch inside this miniture counter only shop....
author: Hen A.

description:
too many review on this joint so my tip is short.

ask for pork meatball (siu mai, i think) AND bbq chicken.

i ask for HALF of each on ONE sandwich!  cause really that's all i fit in my little belly even tho my eyes are too big.
author: Josie M.

description: Just had it for lunch.   Holy molie... what yummines in a perfectly crafted 8 inch bun!
author: Ivy S.

description: Tried the combination yesterday and have to say it lived up to the hype.  It's no foot long, yet a perfectly satisfying 8" or so.  For $3.50 you simply cannot go wrong!
author: Josh B.

description: Avoid coming here when the entire Federal Building is on lunch unless you can get yourself a 4 hour lunch break. The sandwiches here are like the best Phillie cheesesteaks except change the whiz for pickled carrots and the onions for cilantro and beef to pork and the seasoning to soy,fish sauce and the likes. Oh hell I'm ranting, I need to get myself a Saigon Sandwich, I'm outta here.
author: Brian J.

description: Good sandwich, wished the location was closer to the FiDi so that I could have it for lunch! I took BART from Montgomery just to see what the fuss was all about, and I agree, it's a yummy sandwich. However, with the $3 r/t BART ride, lunch came out to be $6. Not such a great deal for me after all. If I was in the area, I'd go again, but I wouldn't make a trip of it.
author: Ava C.

description: My god. This place makes me wish the communists won.
author: T.Z. R.

description: I live for the sandwiches, but the whole deal really must be experienced for full appreciation.  I love how she has "money gloves" and "sandwich gloves" and she is SO careful that ne'er the two shall meet.  I am frightened yet fascinated by the plastic wrapped pink, baby blue and green.....desserts? Dumplings? What in the hell? Are those sausages? Should I......would I..........could I?
author: David M.

description: Saigon's is fantastic.  The chicken sandwich with extra veggies is dirt cheap and super delicious.  Actually in terms of best sandwiches in the city, this is my other favorite place in the city next to Ike's.
author: C L.

description: Step off, don't come here, you are one more person in the way of getting me the best sandwich for your dollar in this town.  Really don't come here because I hate waiting for these tasty sandos!
author: Mickey D.

description: Stand in line.  Order.  Wait a few minutes.  Get sandwich.  Step over a bum and a crackwhore.  Find myself a nook where I won't get stabbed.  Enjoy the best Vietnamese pork sandwich the TL has to offer.
author: Yeeman N.

description: This is the best Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had. For a long time I went to the place close to my house and thought these things were mediocre. One day I wandered over here from work and was blow away. The bread is great quality and the chicken(which is all I've tried) has a perfect consistency and taste. The lady who makes the sandwiches is very friendly and they have a really eclectic choice of drinks. Worth the wait.
author: Max S.

description: It's my once a week lunch spot. Simply the best bahn mi sandwiches in San Francisco. The barbeque pork and chicken are mainstays, but you ought to try the tofu if you get a chance. It's fantastic!
author: Jim S.

description: The roasted pork sandwich is to die for! And it is only 3 bucks. Sure there is always a line and basically no seating and the interior is super dingy, but it adds to the charm of this establishment. I don't know if it is the cuts and quality of meats, or the wonderful french bread, or the other fixings, but Saigon Sandwich pumps out the best Vietnamese sandwich I have had in the city.
author: Nick H.

description: Where else in the city can you have a fresh, delicious lunch for $2.50?  You can't.  The vietnamese sandwiches in this teeny tiny place (probably  under 150 s.f.) are delicious.  They start with a french roll, add some pate, the meat of your choice, fresh cilantro and jalapenos.  Simple yet a great lunch.
author: Travis H.

description:
thee BEST banh mi anywhere.

i have had to stand in line 20 minutes just to get one of these heaven-on-a-bun sandwiches.  and i'd do it again.

oh yeah, and don't take it personal if the people seem rude.  it's not just you.  they're rude to everyone. lol
author: Ray R.

description: the banh mi is life changing! minus 1 star for the location and for the feces outside!
author: Val S.

description: After reading all the good review about this place, I finally decided to try it out.  I ordered the pork combo and I really didnt like it.  The bread was not toasted and they put sweet teriyaki sauce in the sandwich which made it really sweet.  I dont know..I dont think I will go there again.
author: Be. N.

description: It's the best banh mi in San Francisco.  It's the tastiest lunch under $3.50 that you can find.  And..... there are all sorts of tasty treats to tempt you at the counter while you're standing in line waiting for your sandwich.  I really like this place.
author: Juliana S.

description: Found this place on the 7x7 list of top 100 things to eat and drink in SF and this one definitely deserves 5 stars.  Super cheap and so tasty.  There is often a line out the door and you can tell that people travel from all over to grab a sando here.  Certainly worth the wait in line and the trip down to "Little Saigon".
author: Brian L.

description:
i'm vietnamese and banh mi is one of my favorites.  this is a great cheap place to eat in SF.  

Luckily I found a good place here in the Twin Cities, otherwise i'd be craving this place all the time.
author: Michael N.

description: all i'm saying is that if you're coming here from outta town...u best not take a wrong turn and end up in the heart of the 'loin. (the tenderloin for u outoftowners) bc if u do....you'll likely end up a) being hit up for some spare change b) being hit up for your wallet, phone and keys or c) stepping in human feces...btw- did i mention the sandwiches are great here?
author: aron w.

description: Great assortment of indonesian/malaysian snacks and pastries in saran wrap.  Also, they have against the wall crates of all my favorite sugary old soda brands my family used to buy like Shasta and Fanta, Hawaiian Punch, Hawaiian Sun, Tahitian Treat.  I used to come by here and wait in the forever line during business lunch hour when I was still in high school on summer break just waiting for an ice cold grape Shasta.  Oh but of course I must extol the virtues of their famed sandwiches.  Well?  What makes it Vietnamese?  Is it the chopped cilantro?  The chopped carrots, onions and fresh pepper slices?  Does the meat have to be siu mai or teriyaki bbq something or other?  Hey a cockroach just scrambled across my sneaker and into the wall (true story).  Who cares?  These sammiches are damn delicious!  Not to mention hot, cheap and filling.  Nasty sexy delicious.
author: Marjorie B.

description: After being spoiled with the banh mi in socal, it's taken some effort to find a good vietnamese joint that sells the good, cheap sandwiches that I crave. This place is one of the better ones I've had in the city. The bread is crunchy, the meat is tasty, the pickled veggies are excellent, and the spread is really good. They have the standard selection: grilled pork/chicken, fancy pork, meatball, combo, and tofu. That said, it's a little pricier than the $2 banh mi you can get across the street at Lee's, and the sandwiches are just average sized. They do have the whole sandwich production down to a science here, though, so service is pretty quick. I also like the fact that the woman actually put on a glove to handle money, so that actually ups my rating of this place. Also got a steamed bun and it was pretty good, with a half a hard boiled egg, some chinese sausage, and meat and veggie stuffing. This place will stay at the top of my list for banh mi in the city... for now.
author: Saunders C.

description: Great Vietnamese sandwiches - prob the best in SF.  The 2 ladies working there are nice and fast but this place is popular so the lines are always L-O-N-G.  But it's worth the wait.  Have in desperation tried other sandwich places in the city to avoid the line only to discover why everyone goes to SAIGON SANDWICH!
author: Lev E.

description: Before I left the city to move to Denver I made it my top priority to hit up Saigon Sandwiches.  I think I got 3 so I could try all the different fillings they had to offer and it cost me only $6.  Good stuff even better memories of my roommates and I chilling atop of Nob Hill while chomping on Vietnamese Sandwiches and me pounding a bottle of sake.  I've always wanted to go to the Gentleman's Club next-door (Pacific Union Club) but noshing on sandos while lying down in the grass probably didn't help my chances at all.
author: Shiho F.

description: the line here gets sooo long around lunch time. Im going to have to go out on a limb here and say that this place sucks (so go wait in line somewhere else so i can get my damn bomb-ass sandwich! lol). They give wayy too generous portions of meat to veges ratio in their sandwiches. what are they thinking? =D
author: Dave H.

description: Not good at all, bread is very hard and chewy . The Reviews for this Place Are Way Overrated. I don't think they toast the bread. They bread wasn't crispy like the review describe. Other places are much better than this place. I regret for rushing to taste the sandwich with a great expectation, and  turned out to be disappointment.
author: liana r.

description: So, honestly, i know this is the really well known place in little Saigon, but there are better places within two blocks that I find much tastier, not to mention cheaper and friendlier.  I don't hate this place, but out of the options in the loin its my third choice, the others just are sketchier looking and so less well advertised
author: Caleb R.

description: Super cheap, really good sandwiches. I had the BBQ chicken.
author: Joshua S.

description: I used to go here for lunch once a week.  The sandwiches are only $3 and are very filling.  I have tried the pork, the chicken, and the tofu and the tofu is actually my favorite.  The line can be out the door around lunch time, but the wait is definitely worth it! I have tried other Vietnamese sandwich places in the area and this one is by far the best.
author: Britany F.

description: THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH EVER!!! I always get the pork or the chicken. The flavor is soooo good. The meat is juicy, the bread is toasted, the veggies are plentiful, and--ooooh--the sandwich just melts in my mouth. Oh, and the price! The price cannot be beat: $2.50 for a mouthful of heaven! Yummm.... I'm salivating as I type this review.
author: Christina C.

description: I just moved onto Geary St. and one of the first things I thought of was how close I was to one of my favorite joints!  Saigon sandwiches never fails to please.  Come on are you serious?  ... $2.50-$3.00 for sandwiches as good as these is criminal!  But being a foodie, I'm hitting up all those Banh Mi sandwich spots just to come to my own final conclusions.  For now let's say the BBQ chicken is hands down one of the most flavorful sandwiches offered in SF, period!  I docked them 1 star, because nobody's perfect.
author: Holden A.

description: Bomb-ass banh mi thit with delicious carrots and cilantro for $2.75? Um, yes, I'll take it.
author: C P.

description:
so many reviews...... but this place is the yummiest for og vc sammies.
i get chicken -  no mayo - sometimes extra veggies.  he gets the pork.  we have had saigon many a time for our picnics - in the car, etc  and always makes for the best quick  lunch. i have had saigon many many  times and it always delivers.... yes,  the wait can get hairy at times and it seems like she may forget your order, but somehow...she never does. 
we heart your saigon.  dont go away. so cheap, so good and so delish!
author: Caroline S.

description: They have the best vietnamese sandwhiches in sf! Only other places thas has better sandwhiches in san jose! But 4 star for having great sandwhiches!
author: d n.

description: HANDS DOWN THE BEST VIETNAMESE SANDWICH (BANH MI) IN THE CITY. the ladies that work there are extremely nice and service is fast. the only bad thing i can say is there is no seating and the sandwiches can get sloppy (they drip alot of juices) but VERY TASTY! i come here almost once a week. i used to get meatball (xiu mai) now i get the tofu but pretty much all their sandwiches are great.
author: Sam L.

description: The BEST Vietnamese sandwich in SF!  I've tried the chicken, pork, meatball, combination, and tofu.  By far the meatball and combination are my favorites.  They don't skimp on the goodies.  I love that they stuff all their sandwiches w/ veggies.  There's always a line and you can even phone in your orders if you don't have time to wait.  You may question how the ordering process goes, but somehow they make it work.  Their sandwiches are the best and cheap.  For these reasons I don't mind trekking to the Tenderloin, circling for parking, and standing in line - it's worth it!
author: Meredith K.

description:
Not bad. I'm not much of a banh mi connoisseur, so I probably couldn't appreciate as much the caliber of the banh mi. The bread and sauces are definitely delicately prepared. The service is also pretty quick, which is great. 

I'd be curious to go back and try the pate and nothing beats $3 per sandwich in pricing!
author: Amy L.

description: Most Banh Mi sandwiches are sort of dry, but the ones at Saigon Sandwich are juicy and moist and the bread somehow remains crispy!  Yum Yum Yum.
author: Julie H.

description: The sandwiches here are 1) delicious and 2) cheap. You have your choice of several sorts of chicken and pork, and most interestingly Tofu. Yes, this shop is vegetarian friendly - and the tofu sandwich is incredibly delicious. If you are in the mood for Banh Mi, this is the shop you should go to, for sure.
author: neil c.

description: This is a great neighborhood Vietnamese sandwich place. I stop by here pretty often because it's cheap but good. There is almost always a line during the busy lunch hours. It's hard to say "NO" to the chicken sandwich. I usually try to get my co-workers to go pick up the sandwiches so I don't have to walk through the dingy streets.
author: Candace F.

description:
I love anything in a proper baguette... that includes Viet Sandwiches.  And as for locations in SF for these sandwiches, you wont get any better than this establishment.

Normally, I do not acknowledge things that are not usually fully cooked yet this place is different.  There is something within it that just tastes like perfection.

If I worked in the area, this would be my stop for lunch everyday despite it being crowded during the lunch rush.

Lastly, it is a great value for its price.
author: Michael C.

description:
MMm yummy yummy yummy! What else do you need to hear?

The line's kind of long and the service is slow, but everyone was waiting patiently, knowing that it would pay off in the end. Cheap sandwiches, lots of fillings. I got the special combo, which was a different taste in every bite. Their sandwiches are not as big as other places I've been to, and the bread not quite as flaky as I prefer (When you bite into a banh mi, the crust should shatter and fly everywhere like shrapnel. You should find crumbs inside your shirt at the end of the day). But that's just my taste. I've tried a couple of banh mi places in SF, and this one is the best so far, and the cheapest.
author: Tammy C.

description:
Order ahead. Cut in line and pick up sandwiches. Make sure to order more than one if you're eating alone (you'll regret it if you don't)

This place is pretty decent, not as good as Viet sandwiches from So Cal, however, but the best I've had in the City. Another perk is that the sandwiches are really cheap. $3 bucks for a sandwich is not bad at all for lunch. 

Also, the ladies behind the counter speak Vietnamese and Chinese. Don't ask them to include/exclude any times in English. Be a man and just do it yourself.

tl;dr
Pro - Siu Mai Sandwich; $3 for each sandwich
Con - Long ass line; ladies behind counter don't speak English
author: Danny N.

description: This place is great for a cheap (only $3.50!) and delicious banh mi sandwich. No seating available, just quick and easy sandwiches. You can't expect too much when you are paying less than $5 for lunch, so while this place definitely has a divey hole-in-the-wall feel, the banh mi is toasty and tasty, and served with a smile. This is hands down my go to spot in SF. Just be prepared to wait in line (it does move pretty quickly) during lunch time hours.
author: denise s.

description:
one word yall

bomb a$$ vietnamese sandwiches!!! haha you gotta try it
author: Sandy l.

description: Fantastic! Seriously for $2.50 or $2.75 you get a pretty big sandwich and i didn't feel like they skimped on the meat or veggies.  We tried the roast pork, and roast chicken sandwiches, both were delicious.  even after reading other Yelp reviews i found the lady behind the counter quite pleasant.  She takes 4-5 people's orders at a time so you have to wait a few minutes, but it's worth the wait! We took these to eat out in front of Union Square (I feel bad eating in front of all the homeless people waiting around in the Tenderloin)...Highly recommended place
author: Emiko M.

description: Very very good but they occasionally miss. I crave Bahn Mi sometimes and this place will do but I prefer Baguette Express up the street. They never seem to miss and are maybe a bit cleaner.
author: patrick g.

description: Really good for the price you pay.  My first impression was that you'd get a tiny sandwich for less than $3.  Boy was I wrong.  I had a hard time putting one down in one sitting, let alone two.  I decided to attack my left overs for the following day.  It was still good even as left overs.  I've tried their chicken and pork sandwiches which are really good.  Lot's of meat and very hearty.
author: R B.

description: This is a great little secret hidden hole-in-the-wall place to get food to go. There are all sorts of mysterious and interesting-looking foods wrapped in cellophane at the front counter, but I've never tried any of them. I'm all about the sandwiches. Pork is my favorite. Lots of hot peppers and cillantro, on these little rolls. Two is good for me, but most hungry men opt for three. Their fresh spring rolls are also nice. We usually order ahead, and then drive over -- metered parking is easy enough during the day. There's usually a line out the door, as most people don't call ahead -- and after five or ten minutes, I'm up at the counter and have my stuff, ready to jam it back to the office and share the goodies with the group. Highly recommended -- and best under-$5 lunch I can think of.
author: Zoe H.

description: mmmmmm..... soo good and sooo cheap. My boss ordered these for our lab one day at work, and I've returned a couple times for the tofu sandwiches. Good, quick, cheap. Do it!
author: Erin M.

description: I love you Saigon Sandwich.  I want to have your babies.  Lots of little sandwich shaped babies.  And they will be so delicious.  Tender little morsels.  But I digress.  The best two dollars I ever spent.  BBQ pork, carrot, onion cilantro, jalapeno, mayo, and magic Saigon sauce.  On a most wonderful baguette.  And such a clean, cute little place.  With clean, cute little workers.  I want to be one of them.  And provide the world with bahn mi love.
author: Coco D.

description:
why the hell is this place 4.5 stars? cmon guys, isnt it a bit dirty? i guess a little bit of dirt makes everything taste better. 

ok, when you're this close to the TL where you can get some REAL viet food, this place is just so-so. and the sandwiches here are not as good as those on irving street. and btw, $2.50 is actually up from their previous $2 charge. 

hence, a 2 to lower the average and bring some justice to the grading system.
author: Audacity L.

description:
updated (3/2/):
sucks they raised their prices by 50 cents!
but that still isn't gonna stop me from indulging here.. 
its just like those darn egg tarts at Golden Gate Bakery... the more popular they get, the price just keeps skyrocketing.

===========================
you really can't beat the price. its such a great lunch deal. there seriously is no where else you can find a delicious sandwich for $2.50. i can't stress it anymore than any other 300+ yelpers haven't already. every now and then i really do crave for a roast pork sanwich at saigon sandwiches. and every time i enjoy it just as much.
author: Sue Y.

description: I don't think a sandwich shop can get any smaller than Saigon Sandwiches, but out of all three shops in the two block radius, I have to say they have the best sandwiches.  I think the menu consists of only 5 types of sandwiches, but they are the 5 most common ones found in a bahn mi shop and they do do it the best.  It's a complete no frills and no gimmick shop that's mom and pop run, so go here for the best tasting sandwiches.
author: Ben M.

description: Used to eat their sandwiches ALL the time when i went to school near by.  They haven't lost their touch.  SOOO cheap and delicious!  yes!
author: Rachel P.

description: Great sandwich, great price, but the wait is brutal even off peak.  Still, they do their very best to keep things moving.  It's probably ideal to send a delegate (i.e. not me) for a team of people to make it worthwhile.
author: Leo C.

description: Bar none, the finest Vietnamese sandwich I've ever had. Get the tofu (or whatever your meat preference) and watch the disheveled drag queens stumble by from Polk St. during the lunchtime rush. Also, the sandwiches are $3, so you could probably get two if you were exceptionally hungry and/or wanted to share with the aforementioned disheveled drag queens (I won't judge you).
author: Andreas T.

description: Yeah it's a tad bit sketch in this hood. I came today after court and walked up Larkin. Thank goodness it was during the day and sunny. I ordered the combo sandwich with no onions, mayo or jalapenos. In fact I am eating it as I type this review. The bread was still hot when I got my sandwich and it just tastes damn good. And it is only $3.50! Totally affordable!
author: Natalie S.

description: It's true what they say. This is as good as it gets. I'm not the biggest meat eater around but I must say their pork sandwich is ahhmazing. It is the perfect size, not like those torpedo sized ones you find at Lee's. Their bread is just right, crunchy outside and soft inside. There isn't much seating inside (literally three chairs total) so we ate our sandwiches sitting on the sidewalk, which for some reason made it even tastier.
author: Nicole Y.

description: Best Meaty Vietnamese Sandwich in town for a low price! It's not just any typical Vietnamese Sandwiches around here...
author: Selina L.

description: REALLY good sandwiches for $2.50, and they probably merit five stars.  five stars, that is, assuming that they don't skip over your order so that everyone else who was behind you in line gets their orders first.  and then after 20 more minutes of waiting, you ask them about your sandwich, and the lady just tells you tersely that it's coming.  but it never does.  and then you leave cranky and unfulfilled and end up having to eat a $1.25 bag of salt and vinegar chips for lunch, which are not even salty and way too sweet.  but yeah.  REALLY good sandwiches otherwise.
author: Katherine K.

description: This place is hectic. This place is a hole in a wall. The workers are rude. BUT... the sandwiches fucking rock. Nowadays it's so hard to find good Vietnamese sandwiches with places like Lee's (sorry to anyone who likes Lee's... I guess I just have a thing against it since it's a chain). Their meats are top notch which make their sandwiches taste so good. Plus they're so cheap! People are literally tumbling out of the store. There's no order in the line and people just shout out their orders and somehow the women who work there get down all the orders. Man I want one right now T_T
author: Julie L.

description: These are some damn good sandwiches, and they are cheap!  Once upon a time our secretary and one of our beloved nursing assistants would trek to the loin for these delights.  Best deal EVA
author: Alison D.

description: This place was just OK. I've been there twice and had the roasted pork and the meatball sandwich. Long lines, quick service, very cheap, but I've had much better Vietnamese sandwiches (unfortunately outside SF) where the bread was a freshly baked baguette and the pickled vegetables were so much better.
author: Akasha A.

description: Good and cheap. My recommendations is the combination, they always pack the sandwiches with everything making them extremely fat.  The jalapenos are fresh, the meats are flavorful and the veggies are in generous portions.
author: mea f.

description: this place is a straight dark shady hole in the wall. seriously, i think only the front half was lit and the back half was dark and creepy. don't bother looking at anything else in the store. it all looks like it's been there long enough for the sun to fade it's packaging.  but the pork sandwich could quite possibly be the best vietnamese sandwich i've ever had.
author: Regina C.

description: Great sandwiches across the board.  Can't beat the price. Pate is a must.
author: Gary Y.

description: I walk here to eat lunch from work weekly and have not yet tired of the marvelous $2.25 sandwiches. There is always a line so bring a book.
author: Bonnie B.

description: I once bought two sandwiches: one grilled chicken and the other xiu mai (dim sum style pork dumplings), a drink, bag of chips, three spring rolls and this noodle thing for ten bucks! How do they afford to have such great food for such low prices? I don't know, maybe you could ask the line of people around the block. But you have to ask quickly because those two little Vietnamese ladies plow through that line like there's no tomorrow... and somehow they still have time to smile!
author: Sang N.

description:
bbq pork, the fresh yogurt in the little plastic cups, grass jelly drink, fried eggrolls, rice/noodle plates, wasabi shrimp chips, and the countless banana leaf wrapped bundles of savory AND sweet goodness.....  yummmmmmers.

they are open 7 days a week, from early morning to 530, prices havent changed in years, the ladies work so hard and the sammies are damn good!
author: Kimby T.

description: I love Saigon Sandwiches! We usually get the cha (or fanci pork - it cracks me up that the TL banh mi shops call cha "fanci pork" - in the east bay they don't call it that), a special combo, and the xiu mai. The xiu mai banh mi is the best in the area. The sauce is great!Sometimes, we get the some dessert too.  I love that the ladies take your orders in bulk and whip them out for 5 people at a time. I wish there was more room to sit down sometimes, but it doesn't take away from the charm of the place.
author: Annie Y.

description: I never had banh mi before Saigon Sandwiches.  I thought that the long lines and popularity of this place was attributed to the incredibly low price of $2.75 per sandwich.  But nooooo, the sandwiches are so awesome!  I recommend the roast pork or chicken, they have different sauces and their own charms.  I don't know where else, except maybe Southeast Asia, where you can get a fulfilling and delicious lunch for like $4 including drink!
author: Sunny C.

description: bun me some thit any day any night. DELICIOUS!
author: Rikki D.

description: This place is HELLA good. The sandwhich is to die far. Its pretty crowded in the inside and not really a place to sit but its good for to go. For people who think Little Paris sandwiches are good, you have no idea. This place also carry a variety of Vietnamese snacks. The prices are cheap for something that good. I've been eating here for a good number of years.
author: Audrey M.

description:
I should fear the contamination of seasoned tofu sandwiches since they use a meat slicer machine for slicing jalapenos but I always get 2. Otherwise, i would be highly disappointed after wolfing down the first sandwich. 

****please note: this place should be avoided if you are not ok with addictions.
author: Phi T.

description: Yum! So great, just wish there wasn't always a line. So it goes when it's good!
author: Lisa L.

description: I love this place. This is another one of those places the bread will cut the roof of you mouth just enough to let the flavor seep in  (see: Toaster Oven).  I love all their delicious treats and usually are delicious even though I don't what is in them.  I'm actually kind of a fronter bc I havn't even been in so long.  $2.75 for a sando. Amazing.
author: Megan M.

description: I stop by here on the weekends to get my fresh spring roll fix for $2.50 -- awesome!  Note:  The last three or so times I've stopped by after 2pm, they've been sold out of the spring rolls.
author: Shan K.

description: Just had their tofu sandwich today for the first time. For $6.00, it would be delicious and filling. But, since it's $2.00, it's amazing!
author: Josh E.

description: Are you a fan of hole in walls?  Vietnamese sandwhiches are done right, for under $3 easy.  There are almost absolutely no spots to sit around, so you better enjoy standing up ro sitting on a curve, otherwise great takeout for the office.  Call in advance! The spot is extremely small and tight, mostly stuff with other multiple asian delicacies, and the line gets ridiculously long at times.  Rest assured though, the small Vietnamese ladies working there are fast and efficient
author: Antonio C.

description: Craving a Vietnamese Sandwich? Saigon's the spot.  I haven't been here in years but it looks like nothing's changed.The pork bbq sandwiches are still goood like hell!! Prices have risen to a whopping $3.
author: Ramon L.

description: Best $2 sandwich I've ever had.  If it were $3, it would be the best $3 sandwich ever.  Maybe even $3.50....  Best $4 sandwich? ---now we're pushin it... but maybe.  Bottom line, order the pork meatball sandwich and you won't be sorry.  If you don't like it, don't come crying to me, because you only wasted $2.  Go back and try something else!
author: Val U.

description:
This place is dirt cheap. Piles of saran wrapped food stacked everywhere. There's like 3 chairs against the front window if you have to eat there (but take out sucks since nobody wants to smell pee while they eat), and if you are a clean freak, you will run away screaming into the night. Well, day, actually, since I don't think you want to be around there in the evening.

So, order your sandwich known as "banh mi" if you want to exhibit a modicum of culture (I always get the pork) and the little Asian lady will make it for you. There are peppers and onions so you'll probably won't want to go on a date with Gavin after eating there for lunch.

At TWO DOLLARS AND AND HALF, yes, $2.50 USD, it is unbeatable. Besides, get yourself a bottle of two buck chuck and you will be the cheapest date in the hood. Well, actually, considering the hood, you won't be.
author: Tracy Y.

description: $2.50 for the best ban mi you ever had. Every time I take someone to Saigon Sandwich they end up a convert. I left the city to work in San Mateo for about 8 months, and when I started working in SF again all my friends were like we have to go back there for lunch! Ok.
author: Mark M.

description:
I've had better Vietnamese sandwiches in the past (before they were marketed as Vietnamese, because they were eaten and made in ALL three former French Indochinese colonies; Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam).

I don't know why some yelpers claim that this sandwich shop doesn't serve the "traditional version."  Truth is, the sandwiches are technically considered "snack food" and even breakfast food.  If you travel to all three mainland Southeast Asian nations (Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos), you'll find almost EVERY different kinds of meats, including breakfast eggs!  However, the thing ALL sandwiches should have in common are the pickled daikon, carrots, cucumber, jalapenos, French baguette, pate, mayo, etc......

About Saigon Sandwich Shop:
-All sandwiches are consistent equal proportion of meat and veggies A+
-All the Sandwiches TASTE EXACTLY THE SAME! SO, not much variety unless you order a Pate only sandwich and sometimes the fancy pork.  Regardless if you order a meatball, chicken, pork, or combination, ALL the meat is flavored "sweetly/savory".   They're all very good, but my only complaint is that this is quite BORING.  If you're going to offer "different variety",  make sure they're truly "different" and tasty! Trust me, customers will appreciate this more!
author: NeverFoodFull F.

description: Maybe it's because I haven't eaten a vietnamese sandwich in a while, but i couldn't put it down once i started!  I had ordered the roast pork sandwich from them...i was about to order something else but i only had 3 dollars in my wallet.  oh no...i panicked...i don't have any loose change for tax.  but the lady turned to me and said it's only $3!!! nothing more!   Wuhuu!  Anyways, I ate about 2/3 of he sandwich, wrapped it up and went to get some water cuz the pepper residue was kinda hot.  came back and my friend had thrown it in the waste basket!  WTH!?!?  Since it was wrapped and there was only used mail and paper in there, I pulled it back out and devoured it...and no...i don't feel gross about it!  i have to say that the roast pork is sweet compared to the others that i've tried before.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: I love this place, and there's no better bargain in the city, but I just can't bring myself to give it that fifth star.  The service is pretty rough and sometimes I've had to wait upwards of 30 minutes for one sandwich.  Also, I'm kinda frightened by the extra large tubs of mayo that line the walls.  Couldn't you at least hide those below the counter???
author: Josh Z.

description: My dad's office is down the street so I get to come here....OFTEN. Aren't I lucky? :) This place is awesome. Before I would've given it 4 stars because all I got was the chicken sandwiches but now I am enamored with the combination. Patte, chicken, and sliced pork! Oh man. And I tried buying the patte they use, and everytime I go back I buy at least one of them to eat for myself. I love this place. I hate that so many people found out about this place but I'm very happy that these hard working women are getting a very good amount of business.
author: Calvin L.

description:
grilled chicken is my favorite,i love new baguettes they use now(paris bakery),go early to avoid lines
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YHwpQUdVoEg
author: Soupnazi B.

description: My favorite Vietnamese sandwich in the city! Get the bbq pork.
author: Christopher L.

description: I'm from San Jose, also known as Little Saigon, and have tried tons of Vietnamese sandwiches.  This place puts any bahn mi store in San Jose to shame.  Saigon Sandwiches meets In and Out Burger (minus the customer service and uniforms)  Know what you want to order because the line gets long and it moves quick.  The ladies behind the counter have no time for rookies and mean business.   Pretty straight forward menu with about 4 different meats to choose from.  I ordered the roast chicken and meatball and both were really good.  Meatball isn't usually something I order but I thought I give it a try and it did not disappoint.  Meats are flavorful and plentiful.  Saw a bunch of people order fried tofu sandwich and will definitely try that next time.
author: YumCha L.

description: The bbq chicken sandwich here is the best.  I gave it 4 stars because I only had to pull off a small amount of skin from the meat.  At $2.50, they make a tasty, cheap lunch if you are in the area.  I would probably get two cuz they are so damn tasty, and I have a pretty good appetite.  Ordering can be a bit chaotic, and it seems like there is only one staff who speaks english and I'm not sure she understood.  hell, maybe I should learn conversational vietnamese.  It's filled with mayo, chiles if you wish, cilantro.  I will be back.  I'm not a pork eater, but I've heard the pork ones are great too.
author: Emilio O.

description:
oh god, i was craving a vietnamese sandwich bad.... BAD. i just got back from my first visit to saigon sandwiches and hey... its pretty good. the rolls were nice and crunchy though i perfer the regular cut baguettes. i had the meatball which was nice, but felt that there needed to be a little more flavor - some extra sauce would have done it well. mark your calendars people, probably the only time youll hear me say that there was a bit too much meat... ever.

so i finished the meatball and thought about saving the chicken i had also bought... keep in mind one sandwich is plenty for a meal and i was quite satisfied, but starring down at the white paper wrapped and rubber banded roll... i held out for about 4 seconds before deciding to say F* it and i ate it on the go. the chicken was good but just a tad bland. after eating both those bad boys im sitting here writing my review trying not to fall into food comatose... $5 well spent. 

saigon sandwiches reminds me of vietnamese places i used to frequent with my parents when i was younger - sandwich shops, bakeries, grocery stores - but much, much smaller. seeing as how i havent had a vietnamese sandwich in about three months it was well worth it... and you know how i know? my hand still reak of pickled veggies and that makes me want to get off my ass and get another one.

so why only 3 stars? well, mainly because i gave lees sandwiches 4 stars and very few things make me want to sell myself on the street corner for a plane ticket home more then a lees sandwich.
author: N. B. K.

description: Tasty sandwiches for only $2.50.  I recommend the pate and roast pork combo.  A 9 year old took my order there this afternoon, it was pretty awesome, except he did not pass my no cilantro request on to the sandwich makers, damn child labor.   The great parts of these sandwiches are the perfect crusty French baguette, fresh jalapenos, tasty sauce, and crunchy carrots.
author: Katie M.

description: My sister put me on to this spot back int he 80's when the sandwiches were $1. It's still the same shop with great sandwiches. The line out side the door says enough. Sad to see the prices climb year after year but its all relative I guess, I mean where else can you grab lunch for under $3?
author: Gabriel C.

description: was a little skeptical when i first came here a couple years ago, but they have never failed to deliver delicious vietnamese sandwiches.  exceptional value for a quick and tasty meal.  it has been around for a while and agree with patrick g that the newer baguette express a block up provides a less ghetto experience.
author: Vic A.

description: Saigon Sandwiches makes the best Vietnamese sandwiches!  I have tried sandwiches from San Jose, Oakland and San Francisco and by far the ones at Saigon Sandwiches are the best!!!!  The meat is juicy, they put on just the right amount of sauce plus they add a lot of veggies.  The price is right too!  If you are ever in the TL, try them out!
author: Sooner S.

description:
$2.50 = a delicious pork sandwich from the loin.

this gem of a sandwich shop is hidden among the tenderloin's finest, but it's worth the trip.  the line was pretty long for a sunday morning,  but it's hard to complain when $2.50 gets you a full on tasty loinwich.  my buddies and i all ordered the same item and had three different experiences.  this doesn't speak much for the consistency of the menu items, but we were all happy with our purchases.

there are also chicken and steak sandwiches, as well as other desert items - all at absurdly low prices.  the service is relatively speedy and the people are great.  check this spot out if you're ever in the area.
author: a v.

description: This is my favorite banh mi in the area (or anywhere), the roast chicken is so damn good.  Would be 5 stars but because of the popularity it can take a really long time (today it took 20 minutes) to get your sandwich.  The popularity is well-deserved but usually I'll forego the best banh mi for a pretty good one nearby that I can get in 5 minutes.
author: Joseph N.

description: The banh mi to end all banh mi. I have tried both their veggie and chicken options and have not been disappointed. Beware the lines and the bums "decorating" the sidewalk outside with their fluids, don't let it deter you from Saigon's manna!
author: Megan W.

description:
Took the crowd sourced advice and hit this place today and I'm glad I did. Ordered the roast pork and I don't know if it's the BEST bahn mi i've had, but it's pretty damn good.  Top notch.  The spice/sweetness ratio is right on and the veggies inside were crunchy and fresh.  The bread stood out, crusty, but mostly soft (sometimes it's a bit too hard and can tear up the inside of my mouth).  

Like most b.m. shops, it's a dive, but the food turnover seems high, so I don't really get too concerned about getting sick or anything.  

Just in town for a couple of days and I'm definitely glad I made the trip to saigon sandwich.  My hotel's nearby, so it'll give me a chance to try the meatball.  Can't wait.

Oh, and being from the South, definitely appreciate the fact they have Vernors Ginger Ale.  So nice.
author: Eric S.

description: This is a fantastic sandwich and dirt cheap..3.50 for the pork and pate combo banh mi.  Though, you might get mugged by one of the local wobbling crazies.  It's probably for our safety that they close at 6pm  :-)
author: Jake H.

description: WOW!! Yummy and cheap!! Had the pork bahn mi. Delishious.... Hurry up and order, they get busy!
author: Chi chi R.

description: MMMMMM....they do not skim on the meats yo! I'm glad these Vietnamese banh mi's have finally caught on. I grew up on these back when you can get 2 for $1.... but Saigon Sandwiches definitely represents! The french bread is fresh and not a stale taste like some places. The reviews don't lie.
author: flo t.

description: The first time I came here, I did not know what to expect. I ordered the pork sandwich and devoured it! (Something I don't normally do) I've been hitting this place up on a regular basis, trying something new each time and LOVING the pork and chicken sandwiches.
author: Tera M.

description: I've been coming here before it was even known. The sandwiches are good and even with all their success, they DON'T skimp on their products, unlike many other places. If you've never had a Banh Mi aka. Vietnamese sandwich before, this is the ONLY place you should try in SF. You won't regret it.
author: Joseph N.

description: Tasty tasty! Hard to beat a vietnamese sandwich... def a bit dodgy of an area but well worth it!
author: Carolyn C.

description: There isn't much to say that hasn't been said already. I mean...4.5 stars on 700+ reviews...not much I can add. Except....anybody who says Sing Sing is better than here must be smokin something. I've tried many sandwiches in my day....nothing compares to Saigon. NOTHING. Me and Saigon go back...and it is still the #1 place to go for banh mi. LEGITTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT I think I'm going tomorrow!
author: David Y.

description: Best Vietnamese tofu sandwich!!!!!!! And only $3!!!!  I turned two veggies lovers on to this sandwich and they cant wait to go back!
author: Tara S.

description: This place makes a delicious Banh Mi (vietnamese for sandwich).  It's juicy, crunchy, and so flavorful.  I gave it 4 stars.  Missing 1 star because the price has gone up tremendously.  My mom use to come here and purchase in bulk.  They use to have deals such as buy 2 get 1 free, but that was way back in the days.  My favorite sandwich is the xie mai, combo, and cha.  I love adding pate in it.  Taste so much better.  The line gets a bit crazy.  It goes outside the door, but the service is really fast.  The lady takes down a bunch of orders at one time.  Makes that batch and that group of people leave.  There are usually only 2 workers there because the back counter will not fit more than 5.  The space is really small.  It's impossible to walk side by side.  Definitely worth the $3.  I've recommended this place to my coworkers and they are completely hooked.  They were fans of Little Paris Vietnamese Sandwich. ewww hate that place.
author: Mimi S.

description:
Checked out the pork sandwich, the pork is pretty fatty, they have more mayo (than I've noticed at other places), I held the chili. It was kinda bland, like a meat sandwich that just didn't really make me think of a banh mi 

Although you see them heat up the buns, they are not toasty or warm at all :-/ $2.50

Tha ladies work there speak Vietnamese and Cantonese. Things are a little bit on the slow side

I think for the area, which is pretty ghetto, I'd go back to Baguette Express about a block up

To try
- roast chicken
- someone recommended tofu.. for real?
author: xo x.

description: Still the best vietnamese sandwich from this hole in the wall.  For $2.50 a sandwich, you can definitely find that kind of change between the couch.  I always get the roast port with a heap of pate.  It tastes like iron in your mouth, but oh so good tho.....
author: Kenny Y.

description: This is a little hole in the wall that makes the best banh mi sandwiches, bar none.  For the price of $3.50, you just can't beat it.
author: Lisey W.

description: This is the best banh mi I've ever had. Nuff said.
author: Humaira M.

description: Oh hell yeah. There are so many times I am broke and hungry at work but I never need to worry because Saigon is right up the block. 2 pork sandwiches and a coconut drink and i'm good till dinner.
author: Robert H.

description: Absolutely, without a doubt, my favorite place in the entire world. Honestly, I could die tomorrow knowing that I have tasted perfection in the TL.
author: Lizzie N.

description: OK, maybe the pork meatball is now my favorite.
author: Jen D.

description: I have came to saigon for years and recently cleaned up the place and added ne hot tables to store the food. With these upgrades the prices has gone up to but it is still a great lunch and great price. The selection is not great but all of the sandwichs are great. The combos are great, it  has roast pork, steam pork and a big hunk of pate. It is a bargin  $3.75. The meat ball sandwich is full of flavor and it is only $3.25. Can't go wrong with saigon, just look at the line at lunch.
author: Bobby L.

description: Holy bahn mi batman!  There are about 234234098 curse words that want to come out of my mouth when I take a bit of a roast pork for $3 because it really just is THAT good. perfectly warm and toasty bun, a ::schmear:: of mayo, thinly sliced roast pork, pickled carrots, cilantro, and chilies.  Fast, CHEAP, delicious.  I can now die happy.
author: Vijay N.

description: BEST VALUE & SANDWICH.  I almost always come here for a sandwich whenever I am in San Francisco.  Not only are theirs the best, but they are also the best value!  The quality of the bread is fantastic; has a solid weight to it with a crisp crust. Previous reviewers are right in saying that they do not use your typical light small french baguette. It is definitely something slightly heartier.  I also appreciate that they will do a delicious pate and chicken combo, which is hard to find.
author: Burgundy I.

description:
Believe the hype.

Cheap sandwiches at 2-3 dollars a pop w/pickled veggies, nuclear peppers and fresh baguettes delivered daily.  

There's a lot of exotic meats and pork related sandwiches, but I try to shy away from those and get the chicken ones.   They're more to my palette and allow me to enjoy the sandwiches along with the powerful peppers!

this place looks like an abandoned deli, but it's actually alive and kicking!  They have lots of vietnamese desserts laying around wrapped in saran wrap, and a small deli case containing condiments they put into the sandwiches.   

You can get tapioca pearl desserts and a limited number of drinks.

BUT FORGET ALL OF THAT!

We are here for the sandwiches.   Little Lucca's in the best sandwich in terms of taste, quantity, texture etc.

Saigon sandwiches is the best value sandwich that packs a big punch.   

I live/work in San Mateo, and there have been many a time where my co-worker and I DROVE to San Francisco to pick up these sandwiches during our lunch hour because we just HAD to have them.

YOu won't be dissapointed.   I recommend getting them during the weekday because they get their fresh bread/meat deliveries then.  They are open on Sats, but tend to be leftovers from Friday.

If you can brave the crackheads, bad fast food places, and double parking...you'll enjoy this diamond in the rough sandwich place.
author: Michael L.

description: I went there on a Saturday. The lady was mopping the floor, when I and another customer walked in. The lady took the other customer's money, then proceeded to make the sandwich. Did she wash her hands or put on plastic gloves?  Nope.  I walked out.
author: Carol N.

description: I have loved this place for well over 6 years now.Even going in the opposite direction of anything I needed to do to make the journey.Like today for instance.If your looking for quaint ambiance and sophisticated refinery, you need to not go to this heavenly haven of flavor. If you happen to be on this sketchy block in the TL anytime between noon and 2pm there will be a very frightening line. All of those people making that mecca of a journey, just to shuffle in and shout their order in the tiny place with literally 2 seats,are without a doubt on to something. Aside from the fact that for $3.50 you will get a meal that will last well into dinner time, this is a culinary pearl in the rough. The vegetables are actually pickled on site. All of the proteins are slow roasted in heating bins. The gravy is not coming out of a can. This is the real thing, down to simmered juices and what I suspect is arrow root, to congeal but not diminish the integrity of the savory sauce. I will warn that if your a vegan it isn't an option. However, if you can handle a bit of chicken stock base, the Tofu sandwich is ideal.This place can get crowded,noisy,cramped,and make you yearn for an empty bus bench that doesn't smell like urine. However, once you unwrap that stiff paper package, a symphony of aroma will put you at ease. This sandwich hits every spot on a flavor palette that screams C-O-M-F-O-R-T. It's made of all those special blend of spices and ingredients that any food scientist worth his weight, will tell you set off all those happy little synapses,that just make you smile. Basically, look past the cover and just enjoy what they offer up. One damn good sandwich! In 6 years only once did I have a mediocre lunch.
author: Jaclyn O.

description: I'm lucky enough to be next door neighbors with this place and let me tell you its pretty nice. Being able to run downstairs and grab an authentic banh mi sandwich and some crab chips all for 4 dollars has pretty much taken over the way I eat lunch when I'm in the area. Their menu is small and simple so it can be a bit of a drag eating there a lot as I get tired of the same thing over and over. But lets face it, the sandwiches are delicious and only 2.50 so I'll keep coming back again and again!
author: Tommy P.

description:
I have been going to Saigon Sandwiches for the bulk of the four and a half years that I have lived in San Francisco.  They are a perfect option when you want to get something to eat on the cheap.  
The one drawback to Saigon Sandwiches can be THE LINE.  It can be a crush to get up to the counter.  Sometimes, even when the line is short, there will likely be someone in front of you who will have phoned in an order of 25 sandwiches.  
They recently raised prices a quarter, which may have taken them out of the running for the cheapest Bahn Mi in SF.  First, all of the meat sandwiches went up in price, while the tofu option remained at a low $2.   When I went back 2 weeks later, the tofu had kept pace with the other choices and made the jump to $2.25.  
If I wan't to sit at the small counter (seats 2 max), I can keep an eye out for the hated (the DPT), should one of those sneaky mother fuckers have it in mind that they want to issue me a ticket.  The sidewalk is for parking motorbikes, okay?
author: Eric T.

description: $3 sandwiches are perfect for lunch. There is always a long line during lunch and sometimes the orders become out of order. The roast pork and tofu sandwiches are my favorites.
author: Angela K.

description: Ive been coming here since i was a kid and still till this very day there's still a long line. I love how they're NOT shady with the meats and most of all its only $3 bucks in comparison to other places where they'll charge you $5 for a few slices of meat! :)
author: linda L.

description:
They got the daikon, the freaky desserts, and the unique drinks. This place is authentic. Don't be afraid by the slow moving line. The two kind ladies on the inside take about 7 orders at a time, make the sandwiches ring up the 7 and then move on. It is worth it. 

As others have said here, best to call in your order ahead of time.
author: Michael S.

description: Funny place. Good sandwich, nice people, cheap, love it!
author: R S.

description:
Seriously, what is all the hype about?
The pork--- AUGH.  Tasted like microwaved pork.
The bread---  been there twice, and still it isn't fresh.
And what the heck is the spread they put in there--- mayonnaise? gimme a break.
I can't believe it's getting all these great reviews.
author: V N.

description: This is the best bahn mi I've had... one of the sole reasons I risk my safety hittin' up the Tenderloin (I kid).  This place is usually line-out-the-door during lunch time, for good reason.  Chicken, pork, and pate are the standard varieties, and there's a bunch of other usual Vietnamese snacks and drinks there to round-off a bomb sando... just try not coming right at lunchtime!
author: Cooper S.

description: I would give it five stars, but I found a long, black hair in the middle of my sandwich.  I eat things that fall on the floor and street food in third-world countries though, so I'm not easily shaken.  I had the tofu sandwich and enjoyed every bite (once I pulled the hair out)!
author: ellyk E.

description: This place is awesome.  No other word will work, and this isn't just the ordinary awesome.  Rather it is the religious, awe inspiring almost religious awesome.  It's so good, so amazingly  good that i don't mind that there's only one veggie option.  And all this for $2.  Vietnamese food on a baguette doesn't seem like the most likely of all options, but it works.  In fact the combination is so good it almost makes up for the fact that it was the French occupation of Vietnam that lead up to the Vietnam War.  This place is a must, no ones life can possibly be complete before eating here.
author: Herbert S.

description: Still drooling after we got 27 of these delightful little torpedos for the office. I had the chicken with a mess of carrots, cilantro and extra jalapenos...hi, my lips are on fire...wanna smooch? YUM
author: Colleen B.

description: Cheap, delicious Vietnamese sandwiches (the bahn mi ga is the best).  It used to be 2 bucks for one of these things, but they may have bumped the prices up 50 cents since I last ate there; whatever the price, it won't break the bank.   I would have eaten here 3 times a week all through law school had I not discovered Wraps Delight, which is 2 blocks closer to Hastings and makes the same sandwiches for the same price.
author: Andrew E.

description: Wonderful sandwiches, yum yum yum......make sure to check for peppers those can getcha...
author: Marie B.

description: it been some time since I  had a good sandwich, On Monday around 11am I was walking down Larkin street to meet my friends on Mason Cafe, then I saw the Sign Saigon Sandwich and decided to walk in and try for the first time a Vietnamese sandwich. Only $3.00 for each sandwich! sounds like a bargin deal for me! The sandwich was delicious, yummy, fresh, hot, sweet and juicy - a perfect sandwich in the world!
author: Stephen W.

description: I haven't been here in awhile because i don't go around there anymore, but i remember back in the day i would come almost every morning for these delicious babies especially on my way to school, these are definitely my favorite Vietnamese sandwiches.
author: MichelleDylan K.

description: This place is tiny, there's no place to sit (2-3 stools), but as we sat in the car and ate our sandwiches, the line never stopped growing. It's pretty much a no nonsense vietnamese sandwich place. You can't beat $3 for a sandwich that is authentic and oh so good.
author: Julie C.

description: I've been hearing about this place for ages and decided to give it a try. I picked up their roast pork sandwich and it was pretty good. The pork had a nice flavor and they give you a ton of pickled veggies (do chua) that had a nice sweet and sour kick to them. I think the real stars of the sandwich were the bread which was soft on the inside and nice and crunchy on the outside and the spread (butter mayo) which was delicious and gave the sandwich that extra unctuous mouth feel that makes it taste and feel like a decadent delight. I still think San Jose sandwiches are better though but I do want to come back try the Cha Lua sandwich and the one with Pate. Plus the sandwiches are just $3 so I won't hate! Great bargain.
author: Cathy T.

description: This was a yummy treat. I went on Columbus Day, mid-afternoon, so metered parking was a breeze and there was only one person ahead of me. I'm vegetarian so could get only the tofu sandwich. They whipped two up in seconds, and I brought it home. Absolutely delicious. Fresh, crunch bread out the outside, soft dough on the inside. Wonderful crunch of pickled vegetables, some yummy sauce and hot peppers. And the tofu itself was very flavorful. Only $6 for two sandwiches! This was a steal. It just seems like a very crowded, not entirely clean place (sort of dark and dingy), so I docked it a star. Very sketchy neighborhood too. But the two ladies were very sweet.
author: Ice Cream Truck I.

description:
This is hands down the best Banh Mi in SF.  My favorite is the roasted pork.  If pate suits you, also heard this is a great add-on.

Toasty bread- check
Flavorful pork- check
Plenty of pickled veggies- check
Good amount of jalapenos- check

Avoid going on weekdays during lunch. CRAZY lines.
author: renee t.

description: Now that I'm away from the 'hood that used to be my office near Civic Center, there's not a lot of things that I miss about that neighborhood but one place I do miss is Saigon Sanwiches...I don't know what they put either it's the sauce in the meat or the way they toast the bread...these are some wham, bam, thank-you ma'm samwiches!  All for less than 3 bucks too...so you can have a $5 bill & still have change for the parking meter or the laudromat at the end of the day :-)   Fair warning b/c of the bargain there's a long line out the door during lunchtime but they serve you fast :-)
author: Elle F.

description: This has got to be THE BEST Vietnamese sandwich shop in San Francisco!!  Even though it is a little hole in the wall, everyone seems to know about it, as it is always packed!!  The meatball sandwich is the best sandwich there.
author: Ryan D.

description: This is the best $2.50 sandwich I've ever had, really there is no contest.  Carrots, sweet mayonaise, crunchy bread...not to mention chilis and cilantro.  I'm getting hungry just writing about it.  I've had both the roast chicken and the roast pork, I prefer the pork with extra chilis.  I've also had their fresh spring rolls.  Not the best fresh spring rolls I've had, but better than the fancy ones from Out the Door and at a fraction of the price (about $4 for 2).  It is definitely worth braving the Tenderloin to get a sandwich from Saigon.
author: Julie P.

description: the best banh mi i've had in SF.  can't give it 5 stars though because it doesn't top my fave place in Boston
author: Helen T.

description: This place is incredible.  The sandwiches are amazing and even more amazing is the price.  If you want a delicious Vietnamese sandwich that won't break (or even scratch) the bank - this is your spot.
author: Gabriel G.

description: My girlfriend and I decided one day to pick up some sandwiches from here and head to Dolores Park on a sunny day. For $13 we got 3 sandwiches, 2 drinks and a snack. We got 2 roast pork and 1 roast chicken, but they were both delicious. Everything in the sandwich tastes fresh and homemade, and for $3.25 each, it's cent-for-cent one of the best meals you can get in the city.
author: Theo T.

description: Grill Pork Sandwich is the best!! tons of good pork meat (not fatty like other places) very tasty for only $3 dolla holla!!
author: DVS A.

description:
Anytime I am in the area, I would stop by this place. You can get a nicely packed sandwich for a few dollars. I haven't been here in years so the prices probably went up. There's always a long line during lunch hour, which includes workers from city hall area, locals, and the law students.

Some of my friends always bash this place because it looks like crap and avoid eating there. This place really isn't for dining in, so just get your food and eat somewhere that looks nice and beautiful. From what I remember there is only 2-3 seats in front of the windows.

Update: Ok after the day I posted this review I was actually in the Tenderloin area so I stopped by. I decided to take one star off because I noticed the lady making sandwiches was also handling the cash as well. But hey it's the food industry, stuff like this is expected. Ever seen a waiter/watress put his thumb in your Pho soup when bringing it to your table?
author: G L.

description:
I am obviously reviewing a place that has a lot of reviews but this place is an instiution.

                         Saigon Sandwiches is the Jerusalem of all Banh mi/vietnamese sandwich joints.  Christians, Jews, Muslims, Buddhists, Hindus, heck even some Bahai"s come down to the loin for delicous , nutritious vietnamese sandwiches served by some of the nicest ladies in all of SF. The economic spectrum is broken down as financial district stock brokers wait in line with garden variety crack addicts(Actually I think some of the stock brokers kill 2 birds with one stone picking up crack and banh mi at the same time). The earth is fed and the ladies of saigon sandwiches do the commmunity a great service.............
author: Dan T.

description: A few weeks back I used the opportunity of the "get out of work early before Thanksgiving" half day to check out Saigon Sandwiches. It had been on the list for a while, but the line was always too long for the time I had for lunch. Not today, as I was one of a few people there. And like everyone says, it was super cheap, and it was good. Greasier than what I've found at other vietnamese spots, hence the average rating. Most people won't be disappointed. Did I mention super cheap?
author: Jason B.

description: Very nice baguettes crunchy on the outside and chewy in the inside. Te meat was quite tasty ( chicken and pork). Awesome variety in drink selection also!
author: Theo A.

description: i went there for the first time today and picked up 12 banh mi for a picnic......and i think i ate five of them!  (roast pork, tofu, roast chicken.....) all good......and good all day long. the bread is great........and the pickles...
author: hank h.

description: Coming here, we actually went to Lee's across the street since it was the familiar place to go in L.A.  This place takes the cake!  There is something magical that those 2 women behind the counter do that make these the best Vietnamese sandwiches that I've ever eaten!  The flavor is fantastic!  It doesn't matter whether you're getting chicken or pork either..  I got the pork while my gf got the chicken and we sampled each other's and both were amazing!  I think I am going to go today even though it's raining!  Regardless, they're so cheap!
author: Limzer L.

description: I really love a good sandwich.  That being said this place blows my mind!  $3 out the door for a tasty, quick Vietnamese sandwich can't be beat!  I have lived 3 blocks from this place for over a year and hate myself for only just trying it.  If you are in the area and have $3 cash (no tax) go here!  I had the roast pork.  It came with jalapenos, carrots, diakon (i think) and cilantro as well as some sort of sauce.
author: JOHN G.

description: For the win. It doesn't matter what you order here. It will be good. 'Nuff said.
author: Derrick L.

description: This is going to be simple and to the point, just like the sandwiches.  You cannot possibly get a better vietnamese sandwich in this city.  Absolutely perfect.  Amount of meat or tofu,  the pickled veg is delicious and crunchy and the perfect amount of spice from the peppers.  $3 bucks for a sandwich and i guarantee it will be the best 3 bucks you ever spent.  I applaud you for making me so happy everytime i go.
author: larry w.

description:
I checked out Saigon Sandwich 3 years ago when I first moved to SF.  I was in serious need of some good Vietnamese sandwiches and Yelp reviewers had given this place 4-5 stars and I was really excited to try it.  I remember the sandwich was pretty good, but the place looked so dirty, I couldn't bring myself to come back (especially when I saw the one-woman show handling cash and my sandwich).  

Fast forward to today.  Bf and I are in the tenderloin in search of a Vietnamese market for some spring roll wrappers and he wanted to go to Lee's for a quick lunch.  After 3-4 experiences at Lee's I wisely said, "I've always been really disappointed with everything I've ever gotten there.  Let's give Saigon Sandwiches another try."  I winced at the memory of how dirty it was, but that memory faded away as I approached the store front and saw that they had 3 people working the shop and they've re-organized the shop a little so it's more open in the back where they make the food.  The woman taking the order was a pleasant younger Vietnamese woman who ran a tight ship with the orders and handled all the cash.  One woman (the owner?) toasted the sandwiches, put on the mayo and the meat, and another woman was handled the veggies and wrapping.  I ordered two roast pork sandwiches and brought them home ten minutes later.  The sandwiches were even better than I remembered!  Moist and super flavorful!  I'm so glad they cleaned up the store and that I can return with a peace of mind.  I think this place will definitely be in my weekend rotation.
author: Trinh N.

description: I'm pretty selective when it comes to eating a right sandwich.  This place definitely has the best sandwiches in SF.  Watch out for the line during rush hours.  Make sure you place your order using the Vietnamese Style, just walk in and tell them what you want.   You don't need to wait for them to greet you or make eyes contact with you.
author: Viet T.

description:
I haven't been here in over a year since I live in Menlo Park and no longer work in SF, but I'm so happy that the sandwiches are just as tasty as I remembered.  I got the usual roast chicken and roast pork and ventured to try the fanci pork.  I had to share them with my husband and 2 young kids, it was definitely not enough food!  I didn't eat them right away but toasted them in the toaster oven a bit to crisp the bread up again.  The chicken and roast pork were flavorfully marinated with good amount of veggie topping.  The fanci pork was a nice change, very mild but still good.  And the prices haven't changed too much over time.  Just $3 for these delicious sandwiches, totally a great deal!

Go again?  Definitely be back any chance I get and certainly worth the drive from the peninsula!
author: J L.

description: Man, these ladies really get the line going fast. I was in and out of there in no time even though there were several people ahead of us. Delicious! I had their roasted pork and special combo. I also tried the roasted chicken. The combo was my favorite. I loved the cha and pate. It was the perfect amount of each along with the veggies. The only thing I minded were the huge chunks of jalepenos even though I love jalepenos. I just wish they were sliced a bit thinner. Next time I shall try the tofu with pate since it was mentioned so often.
author: Lee N.

description: Compared to other places, they really stuff their sandwiches. You get a lot for such a low price. I've only ever had the pate banh mi and it was good. I'm picky about the pate, the kind they have here is a little intense which means because they put so much stuff into the sandwich, it's a bit much. But I wouldn't say no to it if someone got me one.
author: cyndi L.

description: My mom turned us on to this place years ago. I was later  in Laos and ordered a sandwich -- it was identical in taste to that on Larkin Street. I was blown away. I must try the pate. My wife orders for me and she always gets the chicken or pork. I love the jalepenos they put in the sandwiches  but I take them out and munch on them as I go !  Great spot.
author: Don S.

description: worth the trip through the barrage of piss stinking bums and crack heads, only reason it gets 4 stars is cause ive had better in Texas. But they pwn in the city
author: Wei W.

description: Even with the slight price increase to $3 for the roast pork, I'm upgrading my review, the truth is the sandwiches there(regardless of price) are too good to slight with a three star review.
author: Michael P.

description: What a place!  Tell me where you can get a good meal for $2.00, or maybe $2.25.  Fantastic sandwich, even for a hole in the wall.  I have not ventured into the "special" meats, yet, but the pork and chicken are excellent with the carrots, cilantro and CHILE's!!  Makes me want to work for the government at Civic Center just to get my fill.  If you want Bhan Mi go no place else.
author: Michael M.

description: Why go anywhere else for sandwiches when you know where the best are at? Their banh bao (pork bun) is super good and I can stock up on fresh goi cuon (spring rolls) if I'm too lazy to make them myself. Sometimes I'll study at the main library just to reward myself with a $2 sandwich afterwards. They've got the goods.
author: Kim G.

description: Definitely authentic, Saigon Sandwiches taste like their straight from...well, Saigon. The bread is delicious and the vegetables are fresh. Great place to get an inexpensive and exotic lunch. The only thing that's a bit disconcerting are the health violations that are posted (all minor, but still a bit off putting).
author: Jessica S.

description: Proof that appearances can be deceiving. This Tenderloiin hole-in-the-wall is one of the best finds in the city. The $2 sandwiches are phenomenal and the spring rolls aren't too shabby either. Overlook the neighborhood and decor and enjoy a culinary treat.
author: Sig N.

description: I've been hearing about this place for years and finally had a chance to check it out this past weekend. If you dig Vietnamese sandwiches, this place is tops! The sandwiches are tasty and cheap, ranging from $2 to $2.25 each.  I opted for the bbq chicken. But the "fancy pork" sandwich is also a super yummy option (for those of you that eat pork). The sandwiches had great flavor. You can't beat that price short of staying home and pouring yourself a bowl of corn flakes.
author: Marie M.

description: The first time I came here I didn't go all the way with my sandwich... I only got meat and carrots.  So it's no wonder I didn't see what the big deal was, other than the price.  Today I sucked it up and got it done properly (even with the quarter increase in price, sigh).  I honestly hate cilantro, but it really does add that little je nais se quoi.  It was a pleasure to eat while I sat outside on this lovely day.
author: Nat K.

description: Grilled pork sandwich: Delicious.  Fresh veggies, a little creamy sauce, the perfect size for me (I prefer meals which meet one or two serving size needs of the day, not five) and the perfect price ($2.50).  I give this sandwich four stars because it was very tasty.  But since I prefer leaner meat, I don't think I'll be going there again.  I just couldn't work through it... too much chewing.  :(  Still... good sandwich.
author: Emily C.

description: This was my go to place for banh mi when I worked in the City.  It was really popular. Everytime I would go, there would be a line outside the door.  I guess it was because the sandwich cost $2.75.  You can't beat that for a cheap lunch.  I've had the chicken and the pork sandwich and both are really good.
author: Rowena D.

description: Normally $2 sandwiches would be a big warning sign of avoid at all cost, but not this place.  You seriously get some quality sandwiches for half the price of most cheap lunches in the city.  Ask for easy on the mayo because they put a lot.  Bring $10 and feed your family.
author: Jason A.

description: BEST sandwiches and shrimp rolls in the city! Super cheap! $2 for a sandwich and $2.75 for 3 huge shrimp rolls. My favorite sandwich is the bbq chicken. The french rolls are so fresh. The crust is crispy and the bread is so soft! Shrimp rolls are excellent! I can tons of them! Peanut sauce is perfect. Best healthy "fast" food!
author: Denise L.

description: After reading "Catfish and Mandala" (an awesome book), I've been craving Vietnamese food all week.  Not the over greased Tu Lan (which still has a place in my heart...literally), but just a good Vietnamese sandwich.  Unfortunately this place is only open during the day, and I can't get here easily from work (even though it's right on Eddy and Larken).  So I had to wait for Saturday to come. Sandwiches (roast chicken, pork, meatball pork) are $2.50, and if you want to splurge, the combination ones run $2.75.  The counter is packed with Vietnamese treats, including fresh spring rolls (3 rolls for $3).  Service was fantastic, but take it to go because they only have one table.
author: Mark D.

description: I wasn't sure if Saigon Sandwiches would live up to the hype, but it did. Hands down this place has the best banh mi I've ever had. And the sandwiches are only $2.50!  There is only a tiny alcove on the side of the restaurant with two stools, so you might find yourself eating in the street. Nonetheless, my pilgrimage here was worth it.
author: Evan K.

description: The banh mi ga (chicken sandwich) rocks. Best $2 lunch ever.
author: Richie K.

description:
I love their roast pork sandwiches. I go there after visiting the library back in the days. Now I only come here when I'm summoned for jury duty and get stuck at civic center for a while. It is worth the wait in line, if you're there during the busy hours. 

I don't go to Lee's Sandwiches because that place gave me diarrhea once. And once is enough.
author: bob k.

description: This place is a hole in the wall. It's the size of a closet. But the sandwiches are legit. The bread here is sweeter than most. They make sandwiches really fast because they have a long lines all the time. This place is really cheap and very good Sandwiches.
author: alfred k.

description: This place didnt seem particularly bad, its just that sandwiches werent any good. Maybe I should just say, that they werent for me.
author: Jeshua B.

description: the only thing more addicting than crack in the tenderloin are the 3 dollar sandwhiches from this place.
author: Viet N.

description: No. 1 Vietnamese sandwich in the city! Cheap and great eats!! Always a long line but so worthwhile!!
author: Yan M.

description: Cheap and delicious... that's all that matters. Great place for a quick lunch or even light dinner (if you feel like slumming it).
author: Bernie L.

description: God BLESS you, banh mi inventing person!  and god bless Saigon Sandwiches (aka that place with the blue awning) for making them close to my house!
author: Robyn C.

description: These Yelpers ain't lying - really delicious cheap sandwiches, spring rolls, and other goodies do not disappoint here at Saigon Sandwiches. They keep it real by putting a nice fresh hot pepper in there - yum! And gosh it is so darn cheap.
author: Sahra H.

description: They're damn fine sandwiches, and at $2.50 a pop, you are a sucker NOT to try them.  The perfect complement to a day at the Main Library.
author: Polly Enmity P.

description: Great vietnamese sandwiches. Cheap and delish. I'm not scared of hole in the wall places, unlike some of you babies. If it doesn't make you sick, then it's clean enough. Besides it's way cleaner than street food places in Vietnam. So if you're afraid of a little ghetto vibe stay away. That means the line is shorter for the rest of us.  Keep in mind this place is so f**kin busy that all their ingredients have to be made fresh daily.
author: Huy N.

description: When I go here, I feel like I am making the the most difficult decision in the world -- do I go for the BBQ pork, chicken, meatball, pate??? Ah, the price of the sandwiches are so cheap I can pick two -- and sometimes I do!! When it comes time for you to choose which sandwich to go for, you really can't make a bad decision here.  Go ahead order 'em all!!
author: Katie M.

description: Cant beat the price for sandwich. And it tastes good. Cant really add anything else that has not been said dozens of times by previous reviews.
author: Alfredo N.

description: I've been working in this area for a year and yet I haven't really yelped a lot of the restaurants here.  One.  They are mostly in Vietnamese so I don't remember their names.  Two.  I just forget about them.  That's really bad b/c the TL has the best deal of vietnamese food in the city!!  2.25 for a sandwich.  Where does $2 get us today?  Even MUNI is 1.50!!  Anyway, my favorite sandwich here is the pork meatball.  They stuff their sandwich w/ meat and their carrots is chopped up good so that they can stuff everything inside the sandwich.  They make their meats fresh so its always warm when you eat it.  Careful about the peppers b/c they can be spicy (but I'm known as a weaksauce, so others might find it not that spicy).  They also have individually wrapped goodies to sell and that goes for 2-3 bucks.  You cannot beat their deals.  I've tried the Lee's Sandwich and it does not compare!
author: AhLin C.
