description: It's 2.50 a sandwich and it's made really really fast but i'd have to give it 3 stars for the overall taste. The pate was tasting a little too sweet for me...hmm...maybe that was it.
author: Oanh N.

description: I give it four stars for a sandwich place, not a restaurant.  It's a hole in the wall, and has a very limited selection, but the quality of their sandwiches I've had is outstanding.  Very flavorful pork ball sandwich, roasted chicken sandwich, and sliced pork sandwich.  The bread quality is also very good. Price is also nice - just right. Four and a half stars.  Would be five if the selection were more extensive.
author: Gregory C.

description: Good. Fast. Cheap.  Okay, maybe it's not so fast when one comes during the lunch rush.  The sandwiches made by the elderly Vietnamese women kick butt! Perfect bread, exquisite toppings, and the right amount of meat.  I've eaten every sandwich here (not all at once, mind you) and would order any one of them again, especially with Pate'.  They have a selection of other things such as fresh pastries, drinks and YOGURT.  Mmmn.
author: Michael W.

description: BAM! Best deal in San Fran. These sandwiches are excellent. Fresh french bread packed with vietnamese goodness with some kick. The wait is worth it and wondering what is in the crazy authentic creations that line the shelves keeps you entertained.
author: M L.

description: The only thing have to add besides my five stars is this: they have Vernor's Ginger Ale, which is awesome and hard to find on this coast.
author: claire l.

description: For the love of God, I beg you guys to expand this place so I don't have to wait 15 minutes for my $3 Banh Mi! That being said, it really says a lot when there is such a long line of people WILLING to wait that long!
author: Tony L.

description: I am still in a daze of bliss after eating two of these bad boys over an hour ago. and it onlyy cost me 7 bucks. Go here. Now. Amazing. Meat was tender, bread was crunchy on the outside and soft as all hell on the inside, pickled veggies were crunchy, and marinade was divine.
author: Grant L.

description: The chicken sandwich was worth waiting in line for 15 minutes outside in the cold.  Brrr...
author: Ema S.

description: Fantastic!  Roast Pork is my fave, I hear the meatball is wonderful as well. Great bread, great veggies.  Cheap! $3.00. Can't go wrong there.  I agree calling in your order is a great idea. Everyone there seems to do it (except for me) and they are in and out much faster.  Far superior to Lee's.  Sometimes it's good to live in the 'Loin!
author: Tristan C.

description:
adore the tofu sandwich!  absolutely delish :)  usually tofu bahn mis use dried tofu and can be generally kinda cruddy.  but saigon sandwiches uses actual tofu and has great bread. 

i walked over from the farmer's market and got there around 11:30 on a sunday and to my surprise, no line!  well, there were 3 people in front of me, but that's practically no line for this place.  about 5 minutes later i was out the door and on my way with a line of 10 people behind me.  score!
author: Olivia T.

description: All of the  people from the Federal building go here for lunch, and for $3.00 you cannot blame them! my fav's are the tofu and the chicken. Good flavor, better price, excellant choice. it'a only open until about 3pm, which is fine because you don't want to be in that area any later anyway! i also reccomend the sweet rice that is availabel to the cashiers.
author: Young Urban Minority P.

description: UPDATE: roast chicken with pate is also an amazing option! still beware the peppers...=)
author: Nini G.

description: I found this place by the old "go where the people are" trick.  A line is almost always found outside this place.  They are very quick with the orders though and seem to be good about not touching food with the money hand.  Only a few places to sit which is why the 4 stars but so far the best Bahn Mi I have found in SF.  Worth the trip to the TL.
author: Fredricko B.

description: Saigon sandwich is seriously in my top 5 places to eat in the entire city! Any given day I would much rather get a 3.25 roast pork sandwich here than a 100 dollar meal at some fancy restaurant. Why? because these sandwiches are some of the most delicious things I have ever tasted! The combo of delicious port, crusty toasty bread, the sweetness of the carrots and the spicy peppers, PLUS the amazing magical mystery sauce they put on make for fireworks in my mouth! I force myself to only order one because I could definitely eat 2 or 3 in one sitting. Anytime I am anywhere near Saigon sandwich I make a point to stop in and grab a sandwich. Sure, you might get asked for change, or to buy someone a sandwich while standing in line outside the shop, but it's all part of the charm, and totally worth it for this sandwich!
author: Tara T.

description: Since they really only offer 3 sandwiches that are all GREAT, there is no complaint here. You'll see me standing in line with everybody else. Oh and they're only 3 bucks!! A steal.
author: Dave B.

description: It's worth the wait but usually it's fast. The pate and carrot dressing make the sandwich so tasty. The  bread is fresh and toasty.
author: Eric C.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of Vietnamese sandwiches but am now after having a banh mi xiu mai here.  It's a tiny little shop with only two ladies working there.  Despite how long the line becomes, they have no problem working at their own pace...but it's worth the wait.  

All sandwiches are $3 and there really isn't any seating available here so you're better off taking it to go.
author: t n.

description: Amazingly delicious.  What else is there to say?  You walk up to this Tenderloin shop (selling savory deliciousness in a not so savory part of town), see the ridiculous line out the door, and, for a fleeting moment, consider whether a Vietnamese sandwich is worth the wait.  Who the hell are you kidding? Of course it is!  The line actually moves faster than you would think, and while you are deciding which flavors to get, suddenly someone is barking at you to order (sometimes this happens when you're still a few places back in line, which, although confusing, is admittedly efficient).  You fork over your cash (do you even need to ask if a tiny Asian establishment will take plastic?), grab your toasty sandwiches, briefly consider but dismiss the possibility your food was made in less-than-sanitary conditions, and retreat to your sandwich-eating haven of choice.  I always get a pate sandwich and either a roast pork or chicken.  They are all lovely.... full of perfectly flavored meat, pickles, and a super spicy pepper.  For about an hour after consuming, I feel that I can die happy.  Then I want another one.
author: Megan S.

description:
Maybe the best sandwich you will ever eat. Delicious five spice chicken, crunchy roll, lovely picked vegetables and some jalapenos. Heaven on a bun. 

I added a three pack of shrimp rolls and a soursop (custard fruit) drink and was still only up to $5.75 and had enough food that dinner wasn't needed, and enough change from $6 to plug the meter while I got the food.

One of those places that makes living in SF worth it....and yes, they have a tofu sandiwch for our veggie friends!
author: Darien W.

description: It's simple: Best damn Vietnamese Sando this side of Saigon. Only in the heart of the Tenderloin will you find such a delectable delight. The go to is the roast pork sandwich. A tender array of pork placed in a supple french roll on a bed of cilantro, carrots and peppers. Each bite begs another and at the end of the sandwich, you will wish there where just one more. So buy lots, they are cheep!
author: Travis W.

description: The best goddamn Banh Mi in town, and believe you me, I've had a few.  At (the standard) $2.50 per (fancy meats extra), you can afford to buy lunch... and dinner... for yourself AND your friends.  Available sides come pre-packaged for your convenience: vietnamese spring rolls, red bean buns, mung bean pancakes, melon pancakes, tapioca/banana squares, and much more.  Not sure what it is?  Try it - if you dare!  Even if your mystery bakery item sucks, you'll have a kickass sandwich to fall back on.
author: Eclipse T.

description: Not bad, but not that great either.  The flavors were good overall and the sandwiches were inexpensive, but I really felt that the roll ruined it.  Like Sophia C. said, the bread was all wrong and I felt it really muffled the good flavors of the sandwich.  The shop was crowded and there is no room to eat inside to speak of and being in the tenderloin, there aren't any benches or anything nearby to enjoy your lunch on.  I don't like having to drag my food home, it bugs me.  Worth going to once or twice, or if you're in the area and hungry, but not worth going out of your way for.
author: Green T.

description: Hey wow this was amazing. I can't stop talking about the tender meat, fresh veggies, spicy jalepenos, and delicious baguette. also, while by no means a cleanly and welcoming place, it is more shabby and cluttered than revoltingly dirty, as some reviewers said. and only 2.50 and i was full!
author: Lisa M.

description: Best $3.50 sandwich in SF, if you don't mind stepping over passed out/crazy homeless folks (the neighborhood is sketch but it is the TL afterall) The pork meatball with jalapeno is the best. The women working the counter have seen it all, just patiently wait and they will ask you what you want. Grab a soda and some shrimp chips and youre in for a great lunch on the cheap.
author: James S.

description: My boyfriend rates these the absolute bestest Vietnamese sandwiches that he's ever had and I have to admit they're tasty... but they're just...  different from the Vietnamese sandwiches that I have come to know and love.  Nevertheless, I do heartily recommend the combination sandwich.
author: Jan C.

description: Nothing like it, if you haven't been.  I usally get two, they're only $2.50 each.  There's a whole load of other crap they sell there that looks questionable, but is probably good.
author: Evan A.

description: Tofu Vietnamese sandwich $2. Can't beat it! Prepare to wait in line since they are very popular. I hear the banana covered in sticky rice (wrapped in plastic) is very good but haven't tried it.
author: Amy E.

description: They have great Vietnamese sandwiches here at great prices! Everything in the menu is under 5 bucks! I love their combination with pate. It's so yummy and the meat juicy and filling. I just wish that their bread is crunchier and more baguette like.
author: Helen L.

description: The meat ball and the tofu sandwiches are my favorite.  If you plan to get a lot of them, it is better to call to order in advanced.
author: Lily K.

description:
a steal!!!!!  super cheap eats that gives you your bang for your buck!!!!  really good banh mi ga -- roast chicken vietnamese sandwich for $2.50!!!!!  roast chicken had good flavor, bread was perfectly soft on the inside & a bit crispy on the outside w/ great compliments of jalapenos, pickled carrots, cilantro & mayo.

went there for the 1st time yesterday.   tiny hole in the wall in the TL, with a tiny counter for 1 or tightly squeeze 2 people facing larkin st. got another small counter with other goodies:   spring rolls (also  a good deal $3.25 but eh, it was awright -- like the peanut dipping sauce  @ this 'lil deli on 6th & clement more but  forgot the name of the deli), vietnamese sweets & drinks.  

considering there was a line out the door with 8 people ahead of me, it didn't seem  to take that long -- less than 10 min.  two very busy & efficient women in the back making the sandwiches.  sandwiches are great to go.......for a picnic or to simply sit down in g.g. park & enjoy..........

UPDATE:  came here a couple of times within the past month.  think i'm over their sandwich, didn't taste too good............but when your broke & hungry, its still cheap eats..........
author: Cindi N.

description: OMG.  i dream about these sandwiches.  how can they still be $2-$3??!! i love that there is no inflation.  please, someone, tell the ladies that they should open a san diego location.  please, please, please!!!
author: becky k.

description: I've been to this shop a few times when I was visiting a friend of mine. I usually just go for the sandwiches and that's about it. It's a pretty decent price, around $2. The problem I find is that it is always crowded and waiting in line is a bore. The lines usually go out the door  and takes a really long time to get to the front. The shop is VERY crowded and cramped and you better make your decision fast or you're going to be hearing complaints from the people behind you. The sandwich was pretty good, except I'm not particularly fond of the dripping yellow sauce. Btw, the place isn't all that sanitary, but hey if you like the food, then I'm pretty sure you can get over it.
author: Jenny L.

description: You will never find a better sandwich for $2.50.  I've tried other Banh Mi but they never live up to this place.  I like the roast pork.  This place is the one thing I miss about working in the civic center area.
author: H Y.

description: This is my fave banh mi.  I always order the pork combo, but the tofu and chicken are also super tasty.
author: jane d.

description: Nothing like an excellent roast pork Vietnamese sandwich!  I love this place - it's totally authentic, cheap, fast, and tasty.
author: Jon A.

description:
Edit: 12/10/2009
This place has the best banh mi in SF, but damn there was a lot of mayo in the sandwich I got today. A LOT. The combination costs $3.50 now, which kind of sucks, but at least they still load up the sandwich with tons of stuff.
------------------------------------

Went here for the first time today and had an awesome combination sandwich. Price was a little steep at 3.25, nothing is ever as cheap as it used to be. Next time I'll ask them to leave the peppers out--those seeds had my mouth burning for a good half hour or so. I will be returning real soon, but next time there will hopefully not be a poor looking russian lady standing outside unable to speak english and seeming there to try to sell stuff and ask for money. minus 1 star for for the ghetto location.
author: Crystal L.

description: I will shove myself into this Banh Mi hole in the wall haven ANY time I'm around. Gotta try the pate next time. The roast pork banh mi is to die for. Service is top drawer and so friendly. It obviously wasn't decorated by your french-country loving mom but WTF the sandwiches are less than $3!!
author: Jeannie C.

description: I could eat the sandwiches at Saigon everyday until the end of time!  At first I only used to go to Lee's across the street, but I found heaven of Vietnamese sandwiches.  The tofu sandwich is juicy, soooo flavorful, and crispy.  My three favorite food traits!!  I try to go after the lunch hour rush, so I could walk right up to the kind ladies behind the counter and order my usual with extra peppers.  OHH!  They also have a deliciously decadent Vietnamese iced coffee  OMG!  It's like drinking a multiple orgasm in a cup ;).  I feel warm and wet just thinking about it.  OOPS!!  The snacks are various and are super yummy (soya peas ROCK!!).  GO NOW!!!  and say hi to me since I'll be there with or without YOU!!
author: Walter C.

description: The original Vietnamese sandwich shop in SF...oh how I miss working in this neighborhood (not really) just so I could eat cheap tasty sandwiches more often. I always get the BBQ pork and am never disappointed. I often try other odd snacks and goodies that catch my eye and am sometimes not thrilled.
author: Aimee G.

description: Even if it sucked, I would still go there for the price. But thankfully, I love their tofu sandwich. I don't know what is in that sweet sauce, but I think I'm in love. Only die-hard cilantro fans will be able to finish the whole sandwich without picking some sprigs off, but I try my hardest. Also, they have a nice drink and candy/snack selection!
author: Brittany L.

description: Hands down the best viet sandwiches ever! I will sneak out of work, drive for half an hour, and stand in line at this tiny hole in the wall to get myself one. Wish I had one right now =T
author: Mina T.

description:
This is the best Vietnamese sandwich I've had in the city! I used to walk by this place whenever I went to class at the Alliance Francaise. I was curious then, but I wasn't sure since it was just some random place I walked by a lot and it was across the street from Lee's, a place I'm familiar with. Anyway, after reading all the reviews and having massive cravings for Vietnamese sandwiches, I decided to give it a try.

I forgot the name of the sandwich I got, but it's one of the two pork ones. It's not the "fanci" pork, but the other one. I don't exactly know what the difference is, but I think the "fanci" pork is the one I'm used to. The one I had was really good, nevertheless. The bread was toasted just right and they weren't stingy with the vegetables and the meat. The pate also tasted right, unlike the one near my apartment that was dry and rather tasteless. What's the point of putting in tasteless pate?

I plan on returning more often and trying the other sandwiches. Oh, I'm excited! I want one now!
author: Aileen P.

description: Saigon is my favorite Vietnamese sandwich place in the city. Not only are the sandwiches super delicious, but cheap too! The chicken and the pork are always tender, and they never skimp on the carrots and onions. Also, try the coconut sticky rice, it's sooooo good!!
author: Kelly L.

description: It's the best place for Vietnamese sandwiches!!! Love their vegetable pickles and the bread is surprisingly soft! The area where it is in, not too great and It's a hole in the wall place, also at during lunch time, the line is sooo long! But, it's worth it!! Last time, I went around 2:45 pm, there was only 4 people, so I didn't mind to wait. Besides there are lot of Vietnamese goodies that you can munch while you wait for your delicious $3 sandwiches!!!
author: Daisy S.

description: I went here today for the first time today and just like all the reviewers are saying these sandwiches are BOMB. Ever since I moved to SF I could not find a good Viet sandwich place until this. Lee's sandwiches are decent so it's worth it to go a block away to get this. YOu know what they say about hole in the walls..this is a definition of one. I love that their menu is so easy and their sandwiches are so filling! I will definitely be coming here more often!
author: Nir B.

description: Got 2 dac biets today, and it is pretty good as usual. The line is as long as usual. Will be back pretty soon when I am feeling for a quick meal.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Ask for extra chili,peppers or whatever that green stuff is. I had the pork and chicken. F the mayo,who needs it. Lets keep it simple and tasty. I do think they asked if I wanted MAYO. there is another place close to goldengate st. it's not as good. Happy Saint Patricks day. KIss me. If you won't I won't wear green and you'l have to pinch me. i WENT BACK AND HAD A MEET BALL PORK! TALK ABOUT TH BOMB! LETS ADD ANOTHER STAR TO MAKE IT FIVE. i CAN'T WAIT TO TRY THERE SPICY PORK. AND I DON'T EAT PORK!
author: OSEPH E.

description: Cheap, tasty and different. The people who run it are so nice. I love the vegetable tofu sandwich, spicy.
author: James S.

description:
they are fast even when they are packed! (at Ike's I wait an hour and/or more for a sandwich... here I can be done in 2 minutes!) 

their tofu banh mi and yummy and soooo fucking cheap!
author: Maddy S.

description: I've always been a fan of Bunh mei, but unfortunately the only places I know of in the OC is Lee's Sandwiches...and that is very sad. Over the years, my boyf has introduced me to other places that serve these beauties- including one without any signs- just a hole in the wall (literally). This is another very famous hole-in-the-wall, rumored to be a favorite of THE Julia Child. On a very cold afternoon in SF, we made a quick stop for the chicken sandwich and the pork sandwich. Both were delicious...it's something about the sauce...sweet and tangy, not all mayo/buttery like Lee's. The bread was warm and crispy on the outside. The picked veges were great and the peppers were the perfect hotness- not overpowering. I did like the pork a little better than the chicken though. At $3 a sandwich, it seems like a fave of students (lots of students were there). No wonder Julia Child liked this place...yum.
author: yeana j.

description:
Hands down: one of the best sandwiches of my life. The pork is to die for--My mouth waters just thinking about them.  

I used to work in the Tendlerloin, and I was sad that I discovered this place soon before I moved. Now, when I visit I'll have one there and get a 2nd for the plane!
author: Amelia G.

description: A delicious tofu sandwich for $3! You can't beat it!! Just remember they're open 6am-6pm, so try and go early (sometimes I will walk by at 5:30 and they will be closing down). Totally worth every penny!
author: Anne A.

description: Really good vietnamese sandwiches, very very small shop but wow! This is the best one on the block too, don't bother with the other ones. They have good vietnamese snacks as well, very interesting tri-colored sweet rice. Yum!
author: Gina R.

description:
hands down the best viet sandwiches in the city. the bread comes out fresh and crisp. the sandwiches are JUICY,  the chicken- tender, the jalapenos aren't too overpowering and it's the perfect combo of ingredients. i've been eating vietnamese sandwiches since i was young and this is the best i've ever had!!!

great price and quick service considering the volume of people they get

don't be surprised if you find me driving across town for these babies!
author: Cee L.

description: yummy little sandwich at a reasonable price.  clearly a popular place as the line was out the door.  service was quick considering.
author: Kristen P.

description: being vietnamese i seriously thought people were HYPING this place wayyyy more than it needs to be. but when i ate here, i was like whoa dude it IS better!  the wait sucks during lunch time though.
author: H H.

description: This used to be our go-to banh mi place in SF. The bread was unbelievable -  crisp on the outside and fluffy in the middle. But what made the sandwich was the filling. Didn't matter if it's chicken, pork or pate, it's ALL good. We moved away to NY, and I couldn't quite find Vietnamese food that compared to what we used to get in the Bay Area. Fast forward three and half years later. We're out in SF for the holiday weekend. Lunchtime rolled around today and I thought, "What I wouldn't give for one of those sandwiches." All this time, and nothing's changed! Their sandwiches are just as good as I remember. I ordered the pork banh mi - juicy, tender pieces of pork, thin spicy slices of jalapeno, crunchy slivers of veggies, all drizzled with a special dressing and mayo, and stuffed inside one of the best french rolls I've had. This place did not disappoint. We treated a friend to a pork and pate banh mi, and she said it blew her usual banh mi out of the water. At $3 a pop, it's more than we used to pay (we were coming here when it was $2.25), but really it's still cheaper than anything. In a word: amazing! Come early if you're going for lunch - the civic center workers are all about this place and lines can get pretty long. If you do find yourself waiting, don't despair. it's totally worth your time.
author: Vania M.

description: I don't know what the fuss is about. I'm amazed how many people love this place.  I had the pork banh mi and it wasn't all that.  It was missing the daikon and something about  wasn't that great.  There seemed to be something missing.  I'd rather pay more and get something better.   I won't be coming back at all!
author: Sim T.

description:
Simply the best - taste, price, service, period.  Don't let the long lines fool you for this place.  It is a tiny place but very professional and believe me, the daily long lunch lines prove that the food is worth every minute - and cent.

By the way - little known secret - one of the best ice coffees here too!  Try it!
author: Antonio E.

description: Dirt cheap and tasty victuals. Could they really co-exist? Yes they can, and Yes they do.  Armed with as little as 12, count 'em, 12 quarters, you could chow down on a meat or meatless sandwich.  Served atop tasty french bread.  How do they do it?  All I know is that San Franciscans do, have it like that!! Twelve quarters and you're fed.   Bravo!!
author: brenda b.

description: I'll agree with many of the previous posters and say that this spot is, hands down, the best joint for banh mi in the city.  You've got to get the combo sandwich if you go and grub it while the contents are still warm, the veggies unwilted, and the roll still crispy crusted.  The only reason I give a mere three-stars is the fact that my tastebuds have been tainted by shops in San Jo, as well as in Westminster.  And the prices in those spots are much more reasonable.  Sigh, oh well.
author: Al K.

description: Wow.. $2.00 for a grilled chicken sandwich. Amazing!!! So my friend and I ventured here after our graduation rehearsal. We waited in line for a little bit and then ordered our sandwich from the small menu (I nearly tried the pate.. but didn't). There was tons of pre-packaged Vietnamese food on the counter and everywhere. TINY place. MMM then we got our sandwich and ate it in front of the Asian Art Museum, because the tiny store only has about three stools for seats. The sandwich had yummy chicken, FRESH FRESH cilantro my favorite!!, carrots, jalapenos, and yummy French bread. And some good kind of mayo sauce thing. YUM and CHEAP!! ch-chinggggg. The store also sells amazing coconut delights. I love the frozen young coconut juice. It has huge coconut pieces in it that you can stab with the little stabber pitchfork included with the cup. Also, they sell coconut mochi yumyumyum!!!!!!
author: O K.

description: Seriously - read the reviews below.  Phenomenal sandwiches at unheard of prices.  This place is what cult followings are made of.
author: Katie P.

description: This is one of the best deals in the area, and maybe even the city.  GO AND TRY IT!  The lines might be long, but the wait will be worth it.  (I like the roast chicken sandwich myself.)
author: Matt P.

description:
I've gotten sandwiches from here for years and hands down, they are the best for vietnamese sandwiches!  I haven't tasted a better one anywhere.  The key the fresh french bread they use, not the ones that crumples when you bite into it.

They tend to be very busy during the lunch hours, but I always call ahead to place the order and when you get there, it's ready and waiting.
author: Helen V.

description: This is one of those places I've wanted to keep all to myself, but the bbq pork is out of the bag so to speak. I always get the bbq pork sandwich. Succulent bbq pork, fresh bread, pickled veggies, secret sauce, mmmmmmmmm. I wish they still carried the orange pulp drinks, because now I have to go up the street and to the left for my drink. Also I get super pissed and throw a giant tantrum at the counter when they don't cut my sandwich in half, so ask beforehand. Jack fruit chips and those coconut cookies that look like maggots round out the sandwich nicely (with the pulpy drink from up the street.) Poolboy gets all the freaky rice balls that come from somewhere else, but he's like that. Bbq pork, bbq pork, bbq pork.
author: J. R.

description: Five stars for the god-like amazing sandwitches at only $2.50-$3 a pop.  Their big too!  The combination is the best with all the wonderful pate, tripe, head cheese, and pork that you can handle...the Jalapenos keep them spicy, the french bread is just crunchy enough without being too crunchy...it's such a cheap, wonderful, semi-healthy, and compact lunch option that it is unreal...I love the fact that this place is only 2 blocks from my house, but I hate the fact that they have such limited operating hours...The place by my house in northbeach was just as cheap and nearly as good, plus they were open until 3 am...I wish one of these TL banh mi places would jump on the late night bandwagon...besides that one minor caveat though, this place is the bees knees...
author: Francis K.

description: Crack for the budget-conscious. Cheap and dirty with a line out the door. This is all true. Simplicity, beauty and deliciousness is their pork sandwich.
author: Geof M.

description:
uh oh!!!!! here is a mean contender...it is so funny that these sammy shops are all on the same street...good...i love competition. once again......i applied my test. my metric system for vietnamese sammies is the banh mi thit nguoi. 

kinda like my mom's "good vietnamese restaurant test"....if the broth ain't right, don't waste another bite...she claims that if the most basic part of a soup.....broth is not flavorful, savory ,& light...chances are they can't do anything right.

the most basic & first flavors of the vietnamese sandwich offered  is the banh mi thit nguoi. 

well all i can say is this place out of the vietnamese gangsta sammy triad reigns supreme.  the taste was spot on and kept me wanting more. i can't wait to go back.

loved their selection of goodies there too.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: Today after leaving the courthouse and being excused from having to suffer jury duty, I got the craving for a Vietnamese sandwich. After doing much online research all things pointed to this place. The line was down the block, the sandwiches were dirt cheap at $2.75! I thought they would be tiny but the weren't. The problem was that the quality was mediocre at best. Worth the money but not the drive. PLUS-the lady handled my money AND my food. Gross. Not good in my book. I would eat there again if I happened to be close by and on a budget but I think I'll search elsewhere in the future.
author: Dave F.

description: Tiny store with a simple menu + barely comprehensible English from a little Vietnamese lady + cheap prices + line out the door + damn good sandwiches = 5 fuckin stars!
author: Rocky K.

description: After I saw all the reviews I had to go.  I had the pork.  Clean, straightforward ingredients. The only  complaint is that I thought the bread would be fresher.  I've had other bahn mi with super fresh bread that reminded me of being in France.  This bread seemed a bit more typical.  Maybe it's because I went on a Sunday.
author: Sonic D.

description: Their sandwiches are yummy and  cheap, but I don't recommend the pate :( be safe and get chicken or pork
author: Mila M.

description: I've been a customer of this restaurant for 10 years now, and I don't think I'll ever get tired of their sandwiches. Not only are they unique and tasty, but they are as cheap as they can get. A "can't stop eating sandwich" under $3.00? Where else can you find that! The only negative aspect of this restaurant are its long lines; the store is small and there are only three workers, but it is worth the wait!
author: Michelle L.

description: Man what else can i ask for?! Saigon Sandhwiches is cheap, fast, & plenty. A  college student's dream. i love the simple menu and i also really really  love the selection of junk foods they have in the counter. i feel like im in a asian food market check-out counter.
author: Jeorge J.

description: three words....THREE DOLLAR SANDWICHES...yea...vietnamese chicken with peppers and cilantro all between crispy bread...plus bao, a variety of snacks and coconut milk and grass jelly drinks.
author: Kat D.

description: Looking for a quick bite to eat go here. Just don't go here when its busy then youll have to go wait in line for like 45 minutes just to get a sandwich which taste pretty good but not worth the wait in my opinion( I only ate the chicken sandwich here).  Its a small place which little old asian lady's run which I think is pretty cool and they also carry asian sweets and snacks to go with your sandwhich if you like. I give it a luck 3 stars out of 5 for the price!
author: Daryl A.

description: I like this place a lot, it is the best place for Vietnamese sandwiches. Even tho the place is jam packed with all kinds of snacks and doesn't look that clean, the ingredients they use to make sandwiches look very fresh and yummy, and they do turn out very YUMMY. The ladies work in there are simply the best in the business, they your sandwiches right. Go try them.
author: Wes Z.

description: Simply AWESOME. These sandwiches are one of the best values in the city.  My favorite is the pate and bbq pork combo w/ extra cilantro and hot peppers.  However, you honestly can't go wrong with any of them since they keep their marvelous French rolls hot in a tiny oven all day long.
author: matthew w.

description: Tried this place for the first time today after I had found it while taking a stroll around my new hood.  I had the meatball and a coke and it was under $4 which is awesome.  The sandwich wasn't bad but it wasn't great either hence only 3 stars.  I will try it again sometime in the future but probably either when I can't afford anything else or I run out of other options.
author: Derek D.

description: One of the best Vietnamese sandwich places around. BB-Q Pork and lots of hot chili sauce. Sometimes they have Tapioca Pudding for $1.25 and that's great too.
author: Brian C.

description: You don't get any better value than this!  I've been craving some banh mi ever since moving up from Orange County (SF's banh mi doesn't compare to Little Saigon's, sorry).  I had heard great things about Saigon Sandwich, and it mostly lived up to my expectations.  It definitely wasn't as good as the banh mi I used to have, but to be fair, I wasn't a fake vegetarian before.  Pork or chicken probably would have been better than the tofu.  The tofu banh mi I had today was somewhat bland, and left me crying out for more flavor.  The last time I had it at Saigon Sandwich, it was much more impressive.  Both times though, the banh mi was warm but not hot.  I mean, they make it fresh, but it'll still not as hot as it should be.  Oh well, it's pretty damn good, not to mention ultra cheap, but could be better.
author: William C.

description: I haven't had a better vietnamese sandwich anywhere besides this place.  Plus it's super cheap for  lunch or dinner.  What more can you ask for.  I always order a few sandwiches for MYSELF when i come here.  =)
author: Kim N.

description: Delicious sandwiches.  I recommend the pork or the chicken.  The vegetarian options aren't that appealing here.  I sometimes worry about the cleanliness of this place, but I don't let my mind wander too far.  It would ruin the delicious experience that is the Saigon Sandwich.
author: Poker B.

description:
there's nothing i love more than walking down to saigon on a lovely sunny day and returning with a tasty yummy and cheap sandwich! so yummy i usually want two. though maybe i also want two because one doesn't exactly fill me up, but hey, at $2 a pop i'm more than happy to splurge for a second. more yummy for my taste buds anyway!

my only qualm is that i have more than once found meat in my tofu sandwich and in my mouth. this is why i say four stars, cause that shit grosses me out!
author: Tara A.

description: Just look at the line snaked out the door to know that the food is great.  Great tofu faux meat hoagie.
author: Julia H.

description: Another hole in the wall Bahn Mi place... I thought the meat quality was only so-so but what can you expect for the price?!  I like the fact that they have a bunch of other random snacks that you can buy so that bumps them up to four stars.  Otherwise, I think I would have just given them three.
author: Jason W.

description: Cheap sammiches that are actually, you know, tasty. It's a bit of a hike into the loin, and it's just far enough from my office to not want to go there all the time, but just close enough to be worth the trek.
author: Thom M.

description: If only the line weren't so long!!! As everyone says,  the sandwiches are incredible. You have to be prepared to wait with everyone else for these treats but it is well worth it. I used to come here a lot in high school and always got their chicken sandwich. Its the closest I've ever gotten in this country to bun like the ones I get in Paris in the Vietnamese immigrant communities.
author: Frances g.

description: The meatball sandwich only costs $3.00. I had an iced coffee and this jello-like green dessert called bun da lon - very exotic for the non-Vietnamese. One or two seats in the sandwich shop. It took 20 minutes to make a sandwich. The line is serious and quiet - watching intently at the friendly women make ordinary looking sandwiches stuffed with cilantro, pickled carrots and chinese radish, meat and some special sauce. Extra chili sauce will burn the lips.
author: Steve B.

description: The Vietnamese sandwiches here are pretty good & flavorful . The bread isn't the greatest though . Oh , and they sell some Asian snacks too as well as beverages .
author: Eileen L.

description: Wed, April 5 and still not open.   Boo-hoo.   I tried the new place on Fillmore Street.....twice the cost and NOT as good as Saigon Sandwich.
author: Alice L.

description: Other reviews have said it all. It's no secret that this place is a real gem. Go go go!
author: Will C.

description: 3$ sandwich! deal deal deal! it's a small lil store with not a lot of chairs, but hey their sandwich is delish delish! i got the roast pork today n omg it was soo good. i'm coming back for sure. also theres some snacks along the side n variety of drinks too. n lastly, the wait can be long, but it's worth the wait if u want some real sandwiches! Mmmm!!
author: Valerie N.

description: This place always produces the best sandwiches.  I'm not a sandwich person, but Saigon Sandwiches is the exception.  The sandwiches are best warm, so i'm usually done eating it by the time I reach the civic center bart.  The lines are long at lunch time, but the two ladies are quick to move the line along and the sandwiches never disappoint.   The chicken and pork are both very good.
author: Kristine W.

description: yum-o! nothing like a special combination sandwich and some fresh sweet soybean milk to start off your sunday morning! the combo of steamed and roast pork with pate was the best i've had in a while, hand down! also tried some of the roast chicken sandwich and the freshly made sweet rice wrapped banana dessert, which had just the right amount of sweetness! ah...
author: Andrey C.

description: Normally I would not write a review of a place that has over 1600 reviews already posted. What could I add that has not already been said? Well I am going to break my own rule and contribute some thoughts on Saigon Sandwich.   First the positives:  Cheap, generous and very tasty.  If you are looking for a sandwich that is big, very affordable and undeniably yummy this is for you.  The location is what it is. If you are not cool with the TL don't go there. My complaint, if it is a complaint, is that I was looking for a Bahn Mi and what  Saigon Sandwich serves is not like any Bahn Mi I have ever seen. Every other Bahn Mi, from Oakland to Austin and plenty of places in between was great because of the balance between the ingredients; not too many veggies relative to the meat and certainly not too much meat relative to the veggies. Even in the heart of central Texas, during the worst drought ever, the veggies were not over powered by the meat. At Saigon Sandwich, it is all about the meat. We tried the pork meatball, on the advice of a  regular, and the pork, which was shredded, not grilled, and from the moment they were handed to me I knew this was something else. They seemed to weigh as much as a big, tin foil wrapped burrito I remember from the old days at El Faro. They were greasy, sloppy and left me not feeling ready to continue our day long stroll thru the city on a perfect Indian summer afternoon.  The Times may call this the best Banh Mi in America but you can call me a non believer.
author: larry B.

description: Amazing sandwiches and so cheap.  If you don't like spicy make sure to ask for no peppers.  Take out only.
author: Claire W.

description: Tofu, tofu, tofu sandwich -- I dream of you.  Yum, yum, yum.  I've tried all the other veggie Vietnamese sandwiches in town and Saigon Sandwich is the BEST.  My only quibble is the sometimes excruciatingly long wait.  The ladies like to take a bunch of orders, make a bunch of sandwiches and make everyone wait instead of taking an order, making the sandwich, and then moving on to the next order.  But for $2 (Jesus, how do they make any money????), it's worth it.
author: Lesley G.

description: i absolutely love this place.  2.50 for hot, fresh, fast food.  Meatball is juicy.  Roast pork has a nice mix of fat and lean meat.  Nicely pickled veggies.  Get it spicy with a jalapeno.  Bread has that hard to find mix of crisp/crackly on the outside and soft on the inside.  The locale guarantees excitement.  Could you ask for anything more?  This is hands down my favorite sandwich shop in SF.
author: Mike C.

description:
tasty, fast, vegetarian, cheap.  

with a definitely delicious tofu option that's 2 dollars, cilantro, green chile peppers, and that sauce, saigon sandwich is one of the few places i return to time after time.  

on weekdays this joint gets crowded between 12:30 and 1, but otherwise the wait is not too long. oh- and the best part- take it to go and eat it in the park with a friend!
author: Sujata S.

description: I have never tried Vietnamese sandwiches until I visited the city and wanted to have a cheap lunch and decided to check this place based on the reviews here in Yelp.  I was blown away by how cheap the sandwich is and I figured I can afford to splurge by getting 2 sandwiches.  Wow, I cannot figure out what makes the sandwiches so good.  Is it the bread, the meat, the crispy vegetables?  I wish we have this in Vallejo.  This will be a favorite stop over every time I am around the area.  It's the best deal in town.
author: nikonuser p.

description: Great tasting Vietnamese sandwiches, best in the city and right up there with Cafe Dolci on Market St.  Both are tiny spots, usually with a line since the food is so good, but service is quick so you're usually not in line for too long.  Get there before the lunch rush!  BBQ pork sandwich definitely gets a thumbs up!
author: Redloci R.

description: I come here for the bbq chicken sandwich, but I leave with the tofu... every time. Some times 3x's a week. I leave a tip every time too, because seriously, if you are already getting a filling sandwich for about 3 bucks, you better tip, you cheap skate. Plus they lady with the wavy hair totally appreciates it. You can tell with the shocked smile she gives... it is all "FOR ME!?!?!" kind of expression. I wish I was Vietnamese and she was my aunt.... but I also wish the same for the little lady at Yamo... even if it is Burmese food... really? Burma? You are lucky I listen to NPR and I know its no longer Burma but Myanmar... get your updated and oppressed countries right Yelp!
author: danny e.

description: Great Vietnamese sandwiches. The carrots are sweet and crunchy and the bread is nice and toasty. Has a lot of different type of desert too. Try ordering in Vietnamese and ask for the "Dac Biet". They might laugh at you but you'll get a good sandwich not on the menu.
author: Michael L.

description: Excellent sandwiches and you cannot beat the price.  I've tried the chicken, pork, and pork meatball and the special but my favorite so far is the pork.  There is always a line and the people making the sandwiches are a bit like the soup nazi.. you need to keep it simple and don't ask for anything special or risk getting a dirty look.  The sandwiches are filling so plan on a nap after.
author: J J.

description: Ummmmm, yea. Roast Pork=Best Sandwich in the city.
author: Scott F.

description:
Great sandwiches... great price.. nuff said. 

For everyone who can't waiting 10/15 minutes at the peak of lunch hour - stop going the lines will be shorter for the rest of us.  If you go anytime other than 12-2 it takes a whopping 2 minutes.  Also, if you are in a rush, you can call ahead and skip the line - wow what a concept!
author: Alicia M.

description: Hands-down best (Flavor and Calorie) to Cost ratio in town!  There is often a long line at noon, so I usually pick mine up and off-hours.
author: Eric L.

description: Oh yeah, these little sandwiches will surprise you.  Great.  Loved the bread especially.
author: NB B.

description: i have loved every sandwich i have gotten here: fancy pork, chicken, meatball, roast pork. they were all amazing. unlike other banh mi places that fake it with mayo only, this place has got the pate! the bread is super crispy and yummy. and you can't beat the deal. must love spicy, cilantro, sweet carrots, meaty goodness, and all that jazz ... but if you didn't, then why go all the way to the tenderloin for vietnamese food? i crave this place. enjoy!
author: C A.

description:
my momma would always buy at least 5 of these sandwiches for the fam every time she's in the neighborhood.....

she would call us to ask if we want one......and bring them back because there is definitely no seating.

it's still good after all these years. go get your fix! pork. yum! chicken. yum! the dessert drinks are good too....not to mention cheaper than other places.
author: Alice T.

description:
My favorite drive by sandwich shop.  The neighborhood isn't the greatest as there's a lot of homeless ppl and other shady looking peeps around.  It's always packed and sandwich quality is pretty consistent.  I love how they toast the bread.  You get your money's worth with 3 bucks for a very good sandwich.

The only bad thing is that it closes early like around 5 pm but in that neighborhood I guess I would too.
author: Peter C.

description: Pork Bahn Mi is pretty good here, I order it with no mayo and no pate. Great sweet savory sauce but next time ill ask them to warm that sauce so its hot and not to drown the sandwich in it- it was dripping all over my chin like baby food. This is my new spot for Bahn Mi. The hole in the walls in the city alwatys get it right!
author: Nicole L.

description: Has anyone else gotten mild to moderate flu-like symptoms after eating here?  After five incidents, I stopped going.  I had been going here since the days when the sandwiches were $1.65.
author: Ex C.

description: Fantastic Vietnamese sandwich joint.  Their sandwiches have lots of tasty meat and veggies for less than $3 - who can ask for more.  Well, the bread could be a little flakier but I can't complain.  They have other items too which I see other people snatch up.  Go for the chicken, pork, or combination sandwiches.  You'll be back for sure.  (Call ahead for larger orders)
author: Ben K.

description:
The Vietnamese sandwiches here really are some of the best I've had.  
I highly recommend all the combo ones which include pate.  It's not super close to where I live, but I gladly drive out over there to pick them up when I'm in the mood for some pickle-y spicy yum.
author: Liz L.

description: Where else can you get a honkin' huge sandwhich for under $3??  This place is fantastic.  Non-touristy, not too busy, not fancy - just a good bite to eat.
author: D. L.

description:
Saigon Sandwich was selected as one of the best sandwiches in America by Esquire magazine.  http://www.esquire.com/features/food-drink/sandwiches 
See a video of the restaurant @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/01/15/vietnamese-saigon-sandwich/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: Best deal in town.  The tofu sandwich is so flavorful marinated with five spices, onions, and topped with cilantro.  And where else can you have lunch for $3?
author: Catherine A.

description: Great Vietnamese sandwich for $3.  Great selection of unidentifiable (to simple me)  side items.  A great lunch find near downtown.
author: bill k.

description: Oh, how I love these Vietnamese sandwiches. Cheap and oh so delicious. The wait is worth it! :)
author: Jennifer T.

description: why have i not had one of these things before...after moving to the TL I decided to try this place after overwhelming suggestion. Needless to say I was not disappointed, this lil shack of a store serves up some of the best damn sandwiches in life! I look forward to this place...miss it when its closed at only 6 pm :( I can't compare to other viet sandwich places but I can tell you its everything you want in a sandwich and then some...
author: Matt C.

description: I've seen people line up here at 8AM, and rightly so. Their Special Ham Banh Mi is one one of the most delicious sandwiches I've ever eaten and is only $3.75.
author: Jason B.

description: I 1259th agree that Saigon Sandwich is the best Vietnamese sandwich joint in SF.
author: M.A. L.

description:
Truly the best Vietnamese sandwiches around.  My favorite is the Xui Mai sandwich.  It has so much flavor and no where else makes it the same.  Yummy!  

My boyfriend loves the spring rolls.
author: Sally Trung N.

description: I love this place. The sandwiches here are the best. Where can you find a great sandwich for less than $3? I highly recommend this place over Lee's sandwiches, which is only a couple of blocks away.
author: J W.

description: I went there because of what Esquire said. I was not disappointed. Great sandwiches for a great price! The only problem is finding a place to sit so I ate my sandwich while walking.
author: Kevin C.

description: An absolutely tiny place, almost always a line. I get the tofu one, though I can't be sure it's vegetarian. I don't know what they put in the sauce, but it's gooooood. And only $2.25 for a whole freaking sandwich.
author: Erin S.

description:
They produce a gournet item at a rock bottom price. Their sandwiches are a symphony of ingredents that work together to culinarily sound out a masterpiece.

I usually have either the chicken or the roast pork. I personally stay away from pate because, though I like liver, the liver is a repository for whatever is in the environment.... enough said on that.

The portion of meat is ample for a sandwich currently costs $3.00. The ingredients: a warmed soft inside, cristy outside Bakers of Paris roll, mayonnaise, what they call chicken sauce (which I'd previously thought was hoisin), shreded marinated daikon & carrot, cilantro and fresh jalapeno.

I've been to the places down the street one block up. Lee's sandwiches are OK, good bread, sometimes, but not always OK meat, but it doesn't really have the flavor that Saigon Sandwiches has. Bagette express makes you ask special for the shredded arrots, the "bagette" has very little body, and the meat is rather elusive -- it's almost the sandwich that isn't there.

Stay with Saigon Sandwiches and HOPE that they  won't get pushed out by gentrification.
author: Martin F.

description: I haven't been here in a decade but I do remember their sandwiches were awesome.  I used to go there a lot for lunch a lot.  The chicken and meatball sandwiches were my favorites.  They also have a great variety of desserts, like 3 color drinks, sweet green rice (yeah, it sounds nasty, but taste great), coconut rice pudding, etc. like most Vietnamese restaurants.    The line gets long during lunch time...
author: Tom S.

description:
"tofu no pepper"

it's really hard to come up with a better way to spend $2.75. sure it's small, there are creepy TL people sitting around outside and the line can get pretty long but the sandwiches are just so good and the price is never out of any budget.

my only complaint is i regularly find little chunks of meat in my tofu sandwiches, but for being run by two little ladies and the amount of business they get, its an understandable mistake. i really really love this this place.
author: Derek Y.

description: These sandwiches are off the hook!!!!  Warm and crunchy on the outside and smacked with mayo,stuffed w/ whatever meat or tofu your heart desires, then a punch of fresh jalopenos and cilantro, and carrots to compliment the intense fusion of these different flavors and textures!! I've been coming here ever since my grandma would drag me along for her city wide excursions, still oh so good. But u better come correct when ordering, these ladies mean business when taking orders, they ain't got no patience fucking around w/ ur indecisive ass. they gots a system going, in which they take 10 or so orders and head to the back counter, and return in 3 minutes w/ your wonderful bundle of joy.
author: Nancy K.

description: Love it! The Vietnamese sandwich is genius. True, the roll could be fresher but come on it is $2.50. Do yourself a favor and get a sandwich here... come to think of it make it two.
author: Ben S.

description: tofu sandwich with cilantro please.  the bread is fresh and nicely toasted/warm.  the sauce with the tofu is delish!  ordering here is equivalent to seinfeld's soup nazi, the only difference is that you wont be denied sandwiches if you fudge up.  while waiting in line, you must be alert for when the lady is ready to take your order.  be very clear and precise with your order (i.e. TOFU) and then move to the side once your order has been taken.  no lallygagging.  get your money ready.  they increased their prices - so it's now $3 something for a sandwich.  beware of long lines during prime time lunch hours.
author: amee m.

description:
it's true, the price just went up...but at $3.50 this is still one of the cheapest and most deliciously filling meals you can get anywhere and seriously the best vietnamese sandwich i've ever had.

don't let the long lines or tiny ass shop dissuade you.
those ladies move fast.

i love you tofu sandwich.
author: Sean R.

description: When I tried this place for the first time in 2006, sandwiches were $2.50.  Now in 2010, sandwiches are $3.25.  Inflation sucks, but their sandwiches still rule.  The bread they use is what makes them so good.  I would eat these sandwiches every other day if I could.  I go with either grilled pork or grilled chicken.  This is definitely worth a lunch trek to the Tenderloin whenever I have a day off from work.  Good snack and drink variety too.
author: Alan C.

description: I can't just write a review about sandwich's without mentioning Saigon Sandwich. If you love or just like Vietnamese sandwich's this place will become the only place you will ever want one from ever again. I have lots of friends from SJ that would swear to me the best Viet sandwich's come from SJ and SF can't compare. So one of our cabin trips to Tahoe I buy a bunch of them and bring it up. They tried it and man never again will they claim SJ makes better Viet Sandwich's. Keep in mind these sandwich's where several hours old by this time but still amazing. I can just imagine if the had it fresh and warm they would have a mouth gasam haha. They use warm baguettes and they do not skimp on the the meat. My personal favorite is the combination. It has everything you could want especially lots of pate!!! They do get very very busy around lunch so you either get there early or call it in. Like i said in my previous sandwich review i don't give out 5 stars easily but a bomb sandwich for $3!!!!!!! how can I not.
author: mitchell l.

description: one of the tastier sandwiches i've had in a while. and for only $3? damn! i got the chicken, which had a sauce that was frigging yummy. im glad she forgot to put srirachi, like i had asked, because it might have detracted from the already great flavor. the jalepeno's gave it great spice anyways. the meat was room temperature and the bread was hard and toasty, but it made for an incredible combo. the lady making the sandwiches was sweet, like a grandma. i live just a few blocks away, so i will definately frequent this place. takeout only guys and gals
author: Andrew T.

description: Great cheep sandwich hole in the wall joint.  Makes me feel like I live in a real city.  Everyone should try it at least once.
author: Bronwyn B.

description: OMG I can't believe I don't have a review for Saigon Sandwiches yet!!!! I have been going here for years! Props to the two ladies behind the counter. They can make enough sandwiches to feed the whole city in a matter of minutes. Okay--so I'm exaggerating--but still, they can make them pretty darn fast. I have tried to come here at different lunch hours to beat the crowd (between 11-2) but the line is always long! Nevertheless, I still make the 35 minute drive to/from, wait in line for my banh mi. I've tried many many different Vietnamese sandwich shops but Saigon Sandwiches are the BEST! For a $3 sandwich-they sure pile on the meat! And if you order your sandwich and say Pate (ex. Chicken & Pate...or Pork & Pate) they will spread on extra pate! I swear! Try it. I always get the Combo Special ($3.50)--it has roasted pork and cold cut pork cake and of course--lots of pate! MmmMmm I go here at least once a week! Cheap, Delicious, and always hit the spot!
author: Kim D.

description: WOW! I didn't know there were that many people who knew about this spot. This is my neighborhood sandwich shop, and my favorite! I'm very satisfied to know that all of you can also appreciate a Bombass Banh Mi. Next time you check this place out, try the fresh soymilk. It is Delicious, and it washes down your sandwich perfectly.
author: KHiet H.

description: Great value, very tasty and very filling. I could not see eating 2 of these at once tho. $2.50 OTD is nice for the thin pocketed. This will be a regular spot for all that dare visit.
author: jerry m.

description: Best $2.75 you could ever spend on a sandwich! Must go when in or around the dicey tenderloin.
author: Jeff L.

description: #1 San Francisco treasure. I don't care how long I have to wait.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Wow, nice juicy sandwiches. You would think that for the prices they would cut on the filling but there is a lot of the meat and veggies. The coconut milk with jelly bean and tapioca is good but a lil too sweet for me. Next time I will try the coconut milk plain. 

They do not have much variety - juts one each of chicken, pork and tofu (don't remember what else there was on the menu). Great place to stop on your way to pick up a sandwich from when you are in a hurry.
author: sonali p.

description: One of the best Vietnamese sandwich places in the city. The sandwiches are not that large but are all heavily stuffed. Both the pork and chicken are marinated with lemongrass and spices, and therefore very aromatic and savory. The pork has the advantage of being thinly sliced while the chicken is chunky. But the "real deal" is the homemade meatball sandwich, very unique and bursting with flavors. All sandwiches are stuffed with shredded Vietnamese pickled radish/carrots and a few slices of hot pepper. You simply can't find anything better for $2.75!
author: D D.

description: i think everyone has already said what can be said about this place, i will add that when they "chicken sauce" they mean the chili sauce with a rooster on it, not to be confused with cock sauce, thats something else.
author: Jared Z.

description: this is the place to go tooooo on a budget or filfty rich! its a fulfilling! the sandwhich makes up for the long line during lunch and the clutter of snacks all around the counter! my favorite would be the bbq pork with pate paste! the only flaw would be that there cash only and they dont open late...this would be a great place to go to for a late night yumms!
author: Thaleda C.

description: vietnamese sandwiches are a part of my diet and in the whole city, this is one that i frequent and will drive out of my way to get to fulfill my craving. the line is always tremendously long and there are always only two women working behind the counter. you gotta give it to them though bc they be work fast and be power through their orders. i dont think there's anything i dont like about this place. my absolutely favorite is the fancy pork, but the siu mai, and the combos are always hits with my fam and friends and for the vegetarians, tofu sandwich. i wish i had some right now. dROOOOOL.
author: Jane T.

description: $3.25 for the best Vietnamese sandwich i've ever had. there will probably be a line at lunchtime, but i've never had to wait more than 15 minutes. there's a reason for the line. to-go only, a great lunch to enjoy in Civic Center park. i sometimes wake up in the middle of the night with cravings for a Saigon Sandwich.
author: Daryl F.

description: Love their sandwiches, when they get your order right that is. Tonight was the second time that we've ordered from Saigon Sandwiches after 5pm and the second time they got my order wrong. I ordered a tofu sandwich since I am a vegetarian. What I got instead was some white chicken looking slices with what looked like pork next to it. I've had the tofu sandwich at Saigon in the past and its great. So I'd love it, if I could get it when I order it.
author: Susan C.

description: The sandwiches here truly deserve 5 stars. They are filling and taste great, not to mention the awesome prices. I had to deduct 2 stars though. The first star was for the extremely slow service. Yes, they do make sandwiches really fast but who the hell are they for? You keep seeing them throwing them into white plastic bags but they aren't for the customers in line. I'm assuming they are orders but when you have a line of 6 people, shouldn't you be trying to make the 1-2 sandwiches most people are buying during lunch time so you can get the people in and out instead of the 25 someone is picking up later? The second star is for deliberately letting firemen, paramedics, and cops cut in line. They would take everyone's order but then make theirs first. I don't care who you are and what you do, you should have to wait in line like everyone else. That was extremely bad customer service and left a bad taste in my mouth...until I munched on my sandwich.
author: Diane M.

description: vietnamese chicken sandwich ....mmmmm .... now this is what i'm talking about!  excellent!  seriously.
author: Sarah K.

description: This place is damn good but vegetarians be ware.  I always order the tofu.  about 50 percent of the time I find some kind of meat scraps in the sandwich.  Today there was quite a bit of pork in it, about 1 tablespoon, which is sort of gross if you are vegetarian.
author: Tbone J.

description:
had a roasted pork banh mi (vietnamese sandwich) w/ jalapenos and really enjoyed it. it was delicious and MADE-TO-ORDER! thank you, yelp! i don't have to travel all the way to oakland anymore! 

i also ordered the roasted chicken, but i haven't eaten it yet. the 1st sandwich got me STUFFED! the true test: will it taste great after several hours??? i'll be sure to write a separate review ;)

i hear their prices have gone up from $3 to $3.25. the guy in line behind me kept whining the whole time about the increase, while his friend (or girlfriend) said nothing. considering this spot is in the city, $3.25 IS a good deal! 


DISLIKES: 
- no seating
- no free parking
- after handling cash using both her hands, the lady slipped on only ONE glove. MINUS 1-star!
author: Jennifer C.

description: i've been loving on these amazing sandwiches since 1997 and i'm thrilled theyre still in business and rocking! i found them when i was a broke ass 19 year old living in the TL and i continue to enjoy the authentic sandwiches and other vitenamese snacks they offer. consider as well, i have been to vietnam and the sandwiches here are better!
author: teala a.

description: i decided recently im goin to let people know about all the places in sf that are close to my heart lol ill proly keep a  couple secret but here i s aplace u should know about. if u dont go here and get a deliscous , inexpensive sandwich then u dont know nothing, this is a place wher u get 3 sandwiches! one to eat there and two to eat later ! ther the ish iv been goin ther for at least 9 yrs so i vouch
author: frank a.

description: Another good sandwich spot that you must try if you are in the tenderloin.   I love the pork meatball sandwich and the price is so shocking that I always have to buy two sandwiches and save one for the next day.  I would have to claim this spot the best Vietnamese sandwich spot in SF.   Lunchtime gets very busy and the line is usually out the door, but it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Bryan W.

description: about as hole in the wall as you can get--2 ladies cramped in a tiny space doing their best to dole out the sandwiches as fast as possible.  feels a bit like not sf for a moment.  ordered grilled pork and pate, is good.  right ratios, right flavors.  mesmerized by the colored drinks, tried a couple--mix of jelly, beans, and sweetness.  sandwiches are $3
author: Rob C.

description:
more like 3.5 stars.....you know when you have the day off and you have 1000 things you plan "to do" cos you want to maximize this rare occasion and  go do the all the things you think you wanna do but can't when you're stuck slavin' away for da man in some office/cubicle somewhere?  well, i think i got about .02% of those things done but after collecting up some books at borders and replacing that watch battery and cutting the never-ending search for the perfect handbag/tote short, i decided i'd FINALLY check out saigon sandwiches.  i'm sure i'm in the minority here and i'm sure there will be eyerolling, but i thought the sandwiches had great flavor but ultimately were just "ok."  maybe i was expecting more after it'd been played up for so many years.  figured i'd get a chicken and the traditional pork.  i loved the vinegary sweet carrot slaw and i'm a huge fan of cilantro and like the freshness they both added, but the pork tasted a little off to me.  a slight gaminess to it which is not common in lean pork.  the chicken one was much better in my opnion (i'm sure that will draw further eye rolling) but i guess what threw me off was the roll that is the foundation of this sandwich.  i love a crusty french bread as much as the next bakery/carb junkie, but i'd say these guys were more stale than crusty.  the roof of my mouth's all scraped up and nearly chipped a toof!

for $2.50 a pop, the price can't be beat.  i'll give it that.  i just don't know that i'd venture back out this way just for these sandwiches tho cos when i AM in the area it's usually to get loaded on booze or slurp up some pho.
author: Bird B.

description: I love you, saigon sandwich!  Yummy meatball sandwich for only $2.50!  You are a dive, but who cares!  When I took my evil ex there, he was frightened by the dirtiness and wouldn't eat there  That is how I finally learned how lame he was.  If a boy won't eat at Saigon Sandwich, I won't date him.
author: jessica d.

description: all these hipsters and transplants dont have a clue what they are talking about. how can this place be the best you have had? its turned into the burger king of vietnamese sandwiches. they just shove all ingredients into one messy pile. by the time you get home the sandwich is already half soggy due to the way they prepare the food. this place used to be way better back in the day im talking 20 plus years back before all the hipsters and yelp existed.. now it taste like crap. they keep raising the price and on top of that they always mess up your order.  years ago this was the place to get vietnamese sandwiches and no where in the enitre bay area could come close to this place. Now the quality of meat is horrible. The meatball, pork, and even chicken all dont taste the same at all as it used to be. They seem to be cutting corners now and buying lower quality meats to make a higher profit now.  if you gave this place a five star rating you must be trippin.  This place is not that good. not worth the wait and that is for sure. Sad to see one of the most famous sandwiches in the neighborhood i grew up in go down hill so fast. i will no longer support this store. instead i would rahter support l&g across the street. they taste and prepare their sandwiches almost like what saigon used to over 20 years back.
author: Art N.

description: saigon sammies..i'm in love. even though you messed up my order one time and put pork instead of tofu in my sammy, i am still a loyal customer/fan. just keep doing what you do sprinkling that crack on the warm toasted bread and i will always return with little hearts in my eyes.
author: Linda T.

description: I was in San Francisco on Spring Break last week, and had the fortune to pull over in little Saigon on the way to the airport.  As I was strolling down the street, three dudes walked by eating the most delicious looking banh-mi I'd ever seen.  When I asked where their sandwiches came from, they said "see the place with the line down the street? it's called Saigon Sandwich, and it's amazing!" -- Amazing it was. The line was deceptive, it moved a lot faster than one might expect, so don't let that dissuade you from stopping by. I had the roast pork banh mi, and it was truly a miracle on a bun.  There was just enough fresh jalapeno on the bun to create a warmth in your mouth, without overpowering those who are more faint-of-heart when it comes to spiciness. Also, although other banh mi I've had have mayo on the bun - the only fat on this bun seemed to be the juices from the delicious roast pork (and a yellow substance - possibly mustard?) - ensuring that it was both moist and flavorful.  The cilantro and shredded carrots added just the right amount of crunch and freshness. Yummmmm. If I could move to San Franscisco today, I'm pretty sure I'd rent a place down the street from Saigon Sandwich just so I could eat there on a daily basis.
author: Allison Z.

description:
for make up lovers, read my next review.

***

$2.75 for a vietnamese sandwich ain't that bad of a deal ... 

it was pretty good, but slightly sweet for my taste buds ... got the chicken, but it wasn't the chicken that was sweet, it was the onions mom... their chicken, on its own --- quite a juicy piece ... i actually like les crossaint wayy better ... but then again, saigon's cheaper ... and speakin of which, haven't explored san jo yet, so yea, in due time, ill make a trip down there ... *shrugs*

friendly and quick...

but not like OMG, i HAFTA come back. 

having to contemplate between saigon and lee's sandwiches across the street, first thing i did was yelp on my fone, and of course a)since saigon had more reviews, i assumed it was better, but whatevers, i stopped coming after reading yelp reviews ... and b)ive had lee's before and was willing to take a risk.

great place to stop by to pick up a few asian treats or two ... i was so tempted to get me their sae woo ggahng (shrimp chips)... a star for that, for having them korean treats.. =D

for the koreans, kno that song? it's ringing in my head now...the sae woo ggahng song? you know, it goes like ... "sohn ee ga yo sohn ee ga ... etc etc " LMAO~*
author: Jennifer S.

description: Anyone who doesn't give this place five stars should go back to walnut creek, the outer sunset or whereever it is you call home. The real deal here folks!
author: Jeff B.

description:
i've heard really good things about this place...i even risked my life walking through junkies and crackhead filled streets just to come here. 

well i finally went, stood in line and while i stood in line, i had a really good look around the place... well it looks as if it hasn't been cleaned in years... i see that they do not recognize the importance of good food safety practices and as my turn came up... i simply walked out.
 
so good luck to those of you who wish to dare.
author: melissa s.

description: CHEAP and DELICIOUS sammich. sometimes a long wait and theres a reason why. nothing much to say but get the sammich. theres a sauce on it thats sweet and good, im usually not a fan of sweet either. the jalapenios in it is golden.
author: Bobby J.

description: as i recently discovered, you can call ahead and order a LOT of sandwiches for a party (of deliciousness) - i asked for 35. they will label the sandwiches for you and pack the veggies separately so things don't get soggy and people can veggie-up their sandwiches however they want. perfect!
author: Angi C.

description:
i am very disappointed 
this is my first time in SF, and after reading the 5-stars good reviews, i decided to give it a try
i love Vietnamese sandwich, in fact, i can eat everyday without getting tired of it

i ordered pate sandwich, and my bf ordered a meatball sandwich 
it was good, but very disappointing because the sandwiches were not as good as we expected 
the bread is tough, and the onion thing with the sauce is completely overpowering the sandwich... it is like eating onion with the bread rather than a sandwich 

if you ever have a chance to come to Los Angeles, try Ba Le sandwich
that's what a Vietnamese sandwich should be .... rather than super-salty onion sauce with bread
author: Fiona L.

description: wascraving forthis sandwhich for at least 6months nowand finally wasable to pursue to go even in my busy schedule...but very dissappointed when i got there...close  after  work so just ate in a neighboring  cafe  lee's. Thier fresh roll was very hard  already   and their  vietnamese  pork bbqsandwich didn't  taste  so great..after aweekwentonasaturday, and there I  had my cravings fulfilled  t o eat at the best place  reviewed for  vietnamese  sandwich that was shared  by MW thebest !!!
author: cecille p.

description: Will turn a non-sandwich eater to a total believer. Great Vietnamese sandwiches for amazingly low prices. The line could get long around lunch time so you either would have to plan and go before the lunch rush or go mid-afternoon. Either way, you would love it! The peppers give it an extra nice kick to it if you like it spicy. You'd miss the place if you ween't paying attention unless you go around lunch time which is when they have an absolute long line. Bottom line. Very much worth it so try it!
author: Vincent L.

description: sorry, spencer but this place is way better than lee's.  best lunch ever man.
author: Markus B.

description: i wish i lived or worked closer to this place... or i wish they were located near where i live or work.  then i'd go here everyday.  talk about getting the best return for your money if you take into consideration the price and the level of deliciousness of the sandwich.
author: Christy I.

description: It was my husband's birthday yesterday, and of course he got to pick the restaurant. He has been researching Vietnamese sandwiches for around a month, and talking about this place non-stop, so it was a no brainer. We went around 5pm, as they close early and we were starving. The ambiance is that of a total dump. It looks like a seedy convenience store from the street. The owner is in the back toasting the French baguette rolls. The woman at the register assembles the sandwiches and very efficiently rings you up. The menu is small. Only around 6 or 7 kinds of sandwiches. They offer chicken, 2 kinds of pork, ham, pate, and tofu as the protein, and the veggies are pretty much what you get in a good fresh Vietnamese salad: a julienne carrot and daikon radish marinade with that nice sweet flavor. We got the special combination, which included roast pork, steamed pork, and pate. The first bite had my eyes sparkly wide and I was suffused with childish enthusiasm at the prospect of a whole sandwich full of bites ahead of me. The bread was warm and crisp, the flavors were a perfect marriage, WOW! I can see why they won the Citysearch best sandwich in SF award for 2008. There are two seats only, in the window. We sat there and watched a steady stream of patrons come and go...one with a giant bag full of sandwiches. The price ranges from $3 (most sandwiches) to $3.50 for the special combo we had. I woke up this morning feeling happy that now, every time I go to SF I can get take out. Mmmmmm good! Here I am a few months later. I have downgraded it from 5 to 3 stars. The reason is this. The last time I went there, a woman was sleeping with her cheek in her sandwich in the window. When the owner finally shooed her out, we had our sandwiches. Maybe it was partially the distustingness of the neighborhood, and the lady snoozing in the sandwich that got me, but it was certainly also the fact that some kind of chewy slimy things of an unidentifiable nature were in it. It still tasted great, but once I know my food is compromised, I can't feel the same way anymore.
author: Barbara S.

description: wow. 3 bucks for the best chicken sandwich in the city! i have nothing more to say. don't plan on sticking around to enjoy your food though, the area is about as sketchy as the TL can offer. get it to go and get out of that neighborhood quickly.
author: Jordan S.

description:
never had a vietnamese sandwich before...didnt know what to expect.  had jury duty for two weeks and this is one of the gems we discovered!  great tasting sandwich for $3.00!  it was sweet, and spicy with fresh ingredients.  the service is so-so but they are trying to get you in and out as quick as possible because the line is often out the door and there are like 3 seats inside.  while you are waiting in line there are a ton of packaged goods that peak your curiosity and that you have to take a chance on...since the translation is a bit tough when they are describing what it is.  i had the pork ban mi and it was delicious.  but they have a few more different kinds including one with pate and a veggie one too.
try it, and if you dont like it, it only cost you $3!
author: Rene V.

description: i don't have anything new to share, but for my money there isn't a better place in the city that can satisfy my hunger for under $5.
author: donald k.

description: this is one of those places where i scroll through to re-read my review and find that i haven't written one yet ... anyway, you already know, great sandwiches at a great price.  i especially like the chicken without peppers ... crispy roll fresh from the toaster with that sweet sandwich dressing.  so tasty.  too bad it's in a semi-semi-sketchy neighborhood.  and sometimes the wait can be 20 minutes.  but if you go around 2 or 3, you'll be out in 3 or 5 minutes flat!
author: spiff e.

description: damn good sandwich at a really good price.  only wish i lived or worked closer
author: Tony V.

description: This place is a glorified closet. The reason the line is often outside the door is b/c no more than three people can fit in the closet at any given time. Regardless you do not go to Saigon Sandwich for the ambiance. You go for the most authentic Vietnamese sandwiches in San Francisco. The menu offers a chicken, roast pork, or a meatball derivative sando.  Having had both the Chicken and Pork sando's each are outstanding. These people value every dollar you spend & go out of there way to insure you get a high-value / high-quality taste of Vietnam in every order. Go once and you will be back. Enjoy!
author: Tom B.

description:
