3 STARS only cuz i haven't yet seen the bugs & usually my bahn mi ga rocks well enough. the bugs:  i KNOW they lurk everywhere, there was a health inspector code notice hanging on the windows for ENDLESS. this document came down eventually, about a year or more ago. still, the verbiage (which i won't paraphrase for the sake of courtesy) was strong and detailed and all about dirt and bugs and stuff that can make a person real good and sick. 
ahem. i've eaten here at least a dozen times. i agree with a few others: WAY too many tiny flavor obliterating peppers, but i've learned that actually, the 'ladies' DO understand when you say 'just a little peppers' if you use a hand gesture = to 'teensy'. 
the buns might indeed have the potential to be crusty and baguette like, but in my visits, they have staled out by the time i'm there, post gym at late lunchtime. my fiance adores fast food, has very few compunctions about health protocols, and even he thinks there's something skevacious about the whole production line--the gloved hands doing everything from tossing garbage, handling money and prepping food....go on and google how fecal money is! its amazing any of us touch it. would you stick your finger in a bowling ball's holes and then lick it and swallow? same diff.
i know, i know.....our immune systems are strong enough to handle the onslaught of bacteria we unwittingly encounter each day....but is it too much to ask that this place tries alot harder to be hygienic and up to code? 
yes, i'll go back....but i always feel trepidation for a few hours after i've eaten there...wondering if i'll end up sick. 
i'm actually astonished at how many yelpers simply turn a blind eye to this aspect of Saigon Sandwiches.
author: mimsy b.

description: delish.  and gold stars to the women who work so hard to get these sandwiches out the door fast!  ;)  this is a no-nonsense banh mi shop.  you walk in, she asks you what you want, you just say pork, tofu, pate, or whatever kind of meat you want, and literally a few min later, there she is ready with your sandwich.  it's the best place to grab a quick bite of banh mi.  i had the tofu, and i think perhaps the fancy banh mi places have ruined me a bit, 'cuz well the tofu is actually kinda so-so here.  there's a banh mi place on clement that makes delish bbq tofu banh mi -- it's really tasty.  and then there are places that make lemongrass tofu banh mi -- those are really tasty too!  but unfortunately, this place doesn't marinate their tofu in anything (or at least it doesn't taste like they do), so the tofu bahn mi doesn't have as much flavor as i'd like.  however, because this place is in my hood, i'll def be back again and again.
author: Diane D.

description: Seriously tasty & juicy sandwiches for only $2.50! I don't know how they do it. Everything has already been said by other reviewers, and they are right. I open mine up and check for dead cockroaches before eating... so far so good.
author: M. W.

description: I don't have much to say other than what has been said, but this is a wonderful place despite its long lines.
author: Hannah B.

description: Now that I've moved from the city I crave these like no other.  I don't care if it's a sketchy neighborhood.  It's all good.
author: John W.

description: The best vietnamese sandwich in SF!!  They put plenty of everything in each crispy warm sandwich.  The price is right at $3.  This hole in the wall keeps it simple w/ only a few sandwiches on the menu.  I fell in love w/ this place instantly and will continue to go here as long as I'm still living in SF.
author: LT B.

description: the cleanliness of this place may be questionable but the tastiness of the tofu sandwich is not. and a little filth is probably good for your immunity. dont expect the employees to kiss your ass or even interact with you anymore than is necessary to tell you how much to pay, which is sort of refreshing.
author: Renee L.

description: Of all the Vietnamese sandwiches in the city, this one takes the cake by far.  Don't bother trying any in the financial district because they are all terrible!
author: Nick H.

description: I love Vietnamese sandwiches and I've eaten/tasted all the Vietnamese sandwiches within my residential zip code.  Finally I got to taste the highly reviewed sandwiches from "Saigon Sandwich"!  THIS is by far the BEST I've ever eaten:  generously stuffed with meats and vegetables at a wonderful price of $3-$3.50!
author: Nadine M.

description: I come here at least a couple times a week.  The sandwiches are awesome. There's usually a line around lunch time, but I guess that's to be expected when you can get a sandwich for $3.  My favorites are the chicken, the roast pork, and the meatball pork.
author: Suchil S.

description: excellent vietnamese sandwiches. i'd be here all the time but they're not open late and don't have very many vegetarian options.
author: Anthony K.

description: so much for so little.  almost too much.  i had to pull off carrots and cilantro just to get the sandwich in my mouth.  and i have a big mouth.  great value, but the stars get knocked down for cleanliness (which, i am told, is next to godliness).  but really?  2.50?  i can handle a little filth...
author: Samantha W.

description: I always get the BBQ Pork sandwich, no peppers please.  It is, by far, THEEEE best Vietnamese sandwich I have ever had.  Every time I go, it's freshly prepared, warm and delicious.  For $2.50 a pop, who can complain?!?  You can't help but fall in love with the food here.  If it were in a more convenient location for me, I'd probably make that my second home, for real.  You haven't had a taste of Little Saigon till you've gotten a sandwich from this place!
author: Dwigt K. S.

description: cheap,delicious food...very nice~
author: Bak M.

description: I love the roast pork banh mi -- you'd probably expect a $3 sandwich to be very unimpressive, but this tastes delicious.  Apparently, pork, carrots, cilantro, peppers and onions make a great combo.  Everyone should try this place at least once.
author: Luke P.

description: yeah, boy, two bucks, tofu saMMich. massive, massive little intestine rocket, for all those who willingly accept. i know i probably sacrificed my ever growing vegan agenda (what the hell was being spread on my nutrition-free bread loaf? mayo and sweet liver ovaltine? platinum flavor, my good people.) ALL ABOUT the cilantro, green pepper and pickled carrot chaser over the top. for this price, you should be inevitably snuffed for not getting lunch here if you are in the area ( go here before you go to new century, you cheeky pervs!) anyway, end of transmission. BAHN-MI-OH-MY!
author: Christopher J.

description: Soo good. Pork + Pate is already hard to beat, but Saigon Sandwiches just hits the perfect proportion of each on a crunchy baguette. The peppers + marinated carrots really add a nice kick.
author: Brian S.

description:
This is really one of the best "cheap eats" deals in the city.  A damn good and hearty sandwich for $2.50!  Its worth going through the scuzzy area of the Tenderloin.  Hell, if you're in the area for meth and vd and get hungry, then this is super convenient.
     My only problem with the place is based around a cultural difference.  If you are American you know to stand in a line.  Some foreign-born Asians (mostly older ones) are not familiar with this concept, so if some show up a line can easily turn into a clusterf**k and the line can get really tense.  It doesn't help that when an American points this out the offender pretends not to know English (or perhaps really doesn't).  I have been here a few times where it got pretty close to riot level.  And if you speak vietnamese you can usually shout something out to the women in the back and get your order first, even if you just showed up.  
     In short, if you are an American with a short fuse do not go here, but if you are patient you will be rewarded with cheap, tasty goodness.
author: Sean B.

description: This is definitely my FAVORITE place for Vietnamese sandwiches.  The line is CRAZY especially during lunch time, so try to get their early...around 10 AM to avoid having to squeeze your way in and out of the very tight-spaced store.  All their sandwiches are good, but I love the BBQ chicken and combination.
author: Amy T.

description: my favorite place for Viet sando. it is cheap and everything in there is good. we fed a small village of 9 for under $40.....beat that!
author: Katie K.

description: two fiddy but wurf fo foedy
author: Chester R.

description: their sandwich is like a piece of heaven. i would eat it everyday if i live next to it! i love the fancy pork or the pate sandwiches. it's also such a struggle to buy which one, so i usually ended up buying BOTH! it gets crowded during meal times (with good reasons!) and did i mention it's $2?!
author: Cindy L.

description: Wow, i'm amazed how popular this place has gotten. They've been in business at this little hole in the wall for over 20 years. My mom used to share recipes with the original owners who started this place. I have to agree with most reviewers that the banh mi's here are something special. you'll not find it like this anywhere else. Ususally in other vietnamese communitites in bay area/san jose, so cal, dont serve it this heartily. Its ususally offered a lower price and much lighter on the meats and sauce or no sauce at all and on a cheaper bread, not the crusty baguette. but then again, the prices for bahn mi's are ususually $1 or at the most, $2 elsewhere. Banh Mi's for $3 is unheard of, and most vietanmese banh mi goers will agree. But its definately worth a re-visit once in while. The sauce in the sandwiches here is like nothing else - thats what makes it so special and tastey. I'd give it one more star for perfect rating if the prices were more competitive.
author: Mai T.

description: oh man, I wish they would expand with a location in the mission... the trek out to the loin is still worth it though. freakin' tasty sandwiches, and sooo cheap! oh man... that pickled carrot is makin' me drool! Methinks I'll have to hop on over fer a banh mi for lunch today!
author: Jeremy H.

description: I swear this place has been around forever. I remember when I was a wee baby and my parents use to frequent this place a lot. Hence, my taste for a banh mi. This place is one of the OG places to me. Even though its super cramped and kinda grimy. They can whip it out like nothing even with just two people. They toast the bread just right and don't skimp out on the pickled carrots. Another thing they don't skimp out is the pork patty, my FAVORITE! For just a couple bucks you gotta try everything. They have the combo sandwich, the bbq pork, the bbq chicken, the ham sandwich. As you can see pork is the key meat. They have desserts in there too. Those are pretty good. Especially the green jelly thing. Grab an asian drink like chrysanthemum or coconut to go with it. It will make your experience different from just a soda. Word of advice...just let them add everything even the jalapenos. Take em out afterward if you can't eat stand it. The hint tasty of it is what you need.
author: Julie M.

description: mmm mmm mmm. i get the roast pork sandwiches, a bag of sweet seaweed and a can of grass jelly every time i come here. delicious meal and on the cheap.
author: yolanda f.

description: They have an excellent Combination Sandwich. Just call to order, they'll make it right away.
author: justin l.

description: My first time trying Viet Sandwiches here.  It's very small place compared to Little Paris.  But this store keeps it simple and they do a good job at it.  I ordered the combination and i split it with someone else that tried it for the first time and loved it. The sandwich roll wasn't hard and they had marinated sauce or something that goes great with the other stuff inside the sandwich.  Very good sandwich, very fast service at a good price.
author: Jason C.

description:
It was only a few months ago that I was exposed to the world of vietnamese sandwiches.  And since then, I have been on a manhunt for the best sandwich in the city, jumping out of cars in the TL and eating them with friends while stopped at red lights.  I still haven't tried every vietamese sandwich place in the city, but this place is good, very good.    Warning: this place is not clean.  But you have to ignore the dirt on the floor, the grease on the ceiling, and the fact that the same woman who takes your money is the one that makes your sandwiches without using gloves, because... the sandwiches are simply delish.  I went to pick up four sandwiches before meeting my friend for a movie at the metreon.  Why four?  Well, he wanted two, and I wanted one for dinner, and one to save for lunch the next day.  We had the combo, grilled chicken, and two grilled pork.  To be honest, I couldn't tell which one was the chicken or pork, and I tried them both, but they were both delish...nicely cooked with a hint of peppery flavor.  The pate was sweet and just enough, not too much or too little.  Most importantly, the bread was fresh and crispy, with a soft inside.  For $2.50 a sammy, that's not a bad deal at all.  

Picture this: sitting in Yerba Buena with four sandwiches, drinks purchased from your local walgreens, the sun is shining, and your friend is talking to you with a mouthful of pate and meat hanging from his mouth...nice.  

Note: the sandwiches do not keep well for a next-day meal.  Lesson learned: I should have just eaten both sandwiches like my friend.
author: Grace C.

description: Perfect for when you've already gone to Baguette Express (for their slightly better banh mi) the last three days in a row.
author: Fire P.

description: They have the best vietnamese sandwich I've ever had.  I've tried quite a few places before, but I find this the best so far!  I always get the combination with the pate.  They put in a good amount of meat and veggies, some other places you couldn't even see the meat... The sandwich is also very juicy fr the roast pork.  The roast pork is warm, not like some other places that will just put in cold pork, not roasted ones.  I'm hungry now.  They raised the price a few times the last few years, but still a good price for a sandwich.
author: Karen V.

description: The sammiches are just right and the sometimes-long line is addressed quickly as the orders are taken at least a few at a time. Efficient, cheap, and you can get dried jackfruit and coconut juice while you wait. The tofu Vietnamese sandwich is so delicious it tastes like faerie juice.
author: jane p.

description:
good
- great vietnamese sandwiches, and super cheap (I always get 2)
- fun watching 2 ladies making hundreds of sandwiches in a 3x5 space with nothing but a couple of knives and a toaster oven

bad
- line can get long, so call to order and then show up to pick up
- if it's too dirty for you, try Lee's across the street
author: Anthony W.

description: I've moved to Chicago and recently found a Vietnamese sandwich shop in my neighborhood....oh how I miss you Saigon!  Your sandwiches are divine.  They are petite and the bread is crusty! They have the perfect amount of filling (not too much not too little) and they are so fresh and delicious. Perfect little sandwich to ask your main gay to pick up before he meets you at the airport for an impromptu trip to Las Vegas. Big win all around.
author: kathy w.

description: i used to love coming here for the combo and meatball sandwich. before i wouldve given this 4-5 stars but after today when i came here to pick up lunch for my co-workers and i that i notice it was completely empty. i thought it was weird since theyre usually ALWAYS packed from morning to after lunch hours. i used to love the bread and everything about this place but today it wasnt great. the bread was hard and everything that was in it was skimped.  MEHH..maybe ill give this place another try in the future but as for now irving is still my favorite.
author: Tuan D.

description: The place is really small and crowded. But the sandwiches are good. There are two old ladies that make the sandwiches and take the orders. They lose a point for cleanliness.
author: Master C.

description: i grew up eating vietnamese sandwiches.. and when my favorite childhood spot closed up .. i couldn't find anywhere that could compete.. until about 4 years ago when i found this place.. love it..
author: Timothy W.

description: most bang for the buck.  there's this newer place just up the block on larkin (going north, on the right hand side), that i forget the name of that i think is better. but you really can't go wrong with this place.
author: Alan N.

description: best smurfin' vietnamese sandwich on the smurfin' planet.  love love love the combo.  coming in a distant second and third are mr. baquette and lee's sandwiches in socal.  although someone did mention someplace called top baquette (but since i haven't tried that yet)...
author: Bob C.

description: the best Vietnamese sandwich place in the city. hella cheap and hella good. the only thing parking stinks and you don't want to park far either b/c it's hella ghetto. what do you expect? it's in the heart of the tl. the tl ain't gonna stop me tho.
author: T V.

description: While they've raised their prices to a whopping $3.00 (formerly $2.50) this place still tops my experiences of Vietnamese sandwiches. I feel like one of the ladies makes my sandwiches a lot better than the other one but whatcha gonna do?
author: erik l.

description: ya.. you might have doubled your price over the last 2 years... but it's all good. it's a business for christ's sake! $3 for one of the top 20 sandwiches in the entire country (esquire mag?.. i think). you pleasure my palate.. and for that i am grateful. i will mos def be seeing you soon
author: geoffrey l.

description:
oh my god! the best sandwich you can buy for $2.75 =)
try the special combo....everything on a yummy french roll...love it...

(and if you are looking for a snack before the movies...this is within walking distance of the AMC on Van Ness)
author: Joy Y.

description: I am not used to writing reviews for places but felt I do this one.  Last time, I logged into my yelp, it gave me a list of reviews just written and the top review was for Saigon Sandwich on Larkin.  I had seen their name in yelp searches because it comes up way close to the top for having too many good reviews but always assumed they got lots of good reviews because they were cheap and people were being nice to grade them good all the time.  The first line of this review stated how delicious the roast pork sandwich has been, etc.  I decided to check it so I can check my own assumptions about their high score and if the food is really that good.  I did today and it turned out almost as I had expected.  The place is a small space with room for a few people to stand and maybe a couple to sit comfortably.  It is well-stocked and the two ladies behind the counter moved (almost ran) to do orders.  Every person in there was ordering multiple sandwiches ($3 for 90% of them) and once the line cleared, I was at counter when the tall fat guy in front of me ordered.  He wanted 3 pork sandwiches and went to sit.  He came back later to add a meatball also and his soda and they were all togo.  But he sat and started eating them there.  I ordered the world-famous roast pork togo and nothing else.  I expected it to be a typical Vietnamese sandwich and it was.  White roll with enough hot roast pork to make a medium size sandwich and the vegetables that make it Vietnamese.  I avoid white bread but the sandwich was good.  I wouldn't eat two nor would head here just for it.  I put it on my no-destination list.  Sometimes, a person has no specific destination and wander.  If someday I end up there this way, I have nothing against eating there but I don't know if it is worth going all the way there.  If a person eats more than one, he/she just gets a lot of bread.  Not??? I gave them 4 stars because they do a good job as a business start to finish but the food is not awesome.  Some simple sandwich places kick ass and I have to give them credit by holding one star here.  Try it.
author: Cush D.

description: This place lives up to the hype.  I just got back from there, and the pork sandwich was one of the best things I've ever eaten in my life.  There were about a million different flavors going on--they blended perfectly.  Next time I'm trying the meatball.  I still can't believe my sando was only $2.50!
author: C H.

description: My personal favorite is the "banh my ga pate" (the grilled chicken and pate sandwich). The sandwiches are better than those in Vietnam, and the fresh yogurt is on point. If you're still hungry, all the sticky dessert rices are pretty tasty. My heart goes out to this joint because it's run by the sweetest Vietnamese ladies, who can always recognize a regular.
author: Ali W.

description: This place is awesome. And for the price on what you get, what more can you ask for. I remember trying this place with my cousin's before picking up their Mom from work on a rainy, gloomy day. I got my usual whenever I order a vietnamese sandwich, the BBQ pork. I always get everything in it, but one thing I didn't know they put in here is Jalapeno peppers. I mean, I love spicy food, and jalapeno's included...but vietnamese jalapeno peppers are something else. For some reason, they are like on crack...they are so anti'd up in spice that in burns. When I bit into this sandwich, I was just glorified...bang for the buck, I love it! But as I bit into it and got to the Jalapeno's which I didn't know were in here...my tongue started to burn and my cousin who was driving was just laughing at me and his younger brother as we needed water...which we didn't have any and suffered through the agony of a burning tongue. Next time, I'll remember to NOT have Jalapeno's in mine, lol. Awesome and most likely the BEST Vietnamese sandwiches, must eat!
author: Sean E.

description: Pork Meatball, the best deal in town!!
author: edgar s.

description: gooood roast pork sandwich. $3 price tag. for once, both my tummy and my wallet are full.
author: Dana D.

description: Their sandwiches are awesome but the quality of the meat is up in the air.  They are pretty spicy but the pain is well worth it.  Definitely one of the best deals in town.  The cilantro is an awesome flavor addition.
author: Brooks O.

description: thinly sliced pork made this sandwich delicious...i went last sunday and there was a wait...two ladies with their toaster ovens made the sandwiches as fast as they could...one buy in front of me ordered enough for a 30 person pot luck!  definitely worth the price, but i'm not sure if it was worth the trek. i would never go to this area otherwise. lee's is just a block away and yummy smoothie drinks and other things.
author: Yummy E.

description: Definitely the best sandwiches in the area.  They were rated #1 sandwich in San Francisco for a reason.  The secret is in the bread and the sauce.  The bread is soft and doesn't scratch up the roof of your mouth.  The sauce gives the meat that perfect flavor.  The reason that Saigon is better than baguette express is that it actually fills you up.  Sorry baguette, the $.50 savings isn't enough to bring me back.  Saigon Sandwiches are the best!
author: Idin K.

description: Best sandwich spot in the city and BEST meatball sandwich in all of SF, SJ and SoCal!!!
author: Khoa N.

description: Best vietnamese sandwiches ive had. there are other vietnamese food and pastries there such as "banh bao" (pork bun). they stuff their sandwiches with lots of meat and condiments... 2.75 for a sandwich? cant beat that....
author: joseph t.

description: I've been ordering chicken sandwiches from here for awhile. It's best to order by phone if you know what you want. There's always a line of people whenever I go, so a call could cut them all. I hate waiting. I give the lady a dirty $2 and fifty cents, the same lady who makes the sandwiches has handled money. Does she wash her hands after? What can you expect for a cheap lunch. Sometimes the sandwich isn't as good as I anticipated, such as my bread not being so toasty or my chicken is not as warm. They're still on my list of places to grab a bite though, if I'm ever in the mood.
author: August S.

description: Totally loved this on the first visit - a revelation.  Loved it so much, grabbed two more on the way out of the city on departure day.  Roast pork, cilantro, pate, carrots, special sauce . . . just fabulous on the first visit.  Ruh roh . . . leaving the city run not so much.  Very "bready," much less fill in the sandwich and kinda soggy.  We were thrilled - one less can't-get-it-at-home culinary addiction to obsess on!
author: Eleanor S.

description: Definitely recommend this Vietnamese sandwich shop.  The place is tiny so go during off peak times.  The bread is crunchy with a chewy but not dense center.  The perfectly seasoned meats are balanced with fresh carrots, sauteed onions, cilantro, and hot pepper (optional).  I wish they would add slices of cucumber.   In addition to their delicious sandwiches, they offer snacks and take away meals.  Try the refrigerated jello.  They are made with thin layers of different flavors. So delicious.
author: Vivian T.

description: OMG! Best Sandwiches EVER!! Inflation hit, so they cost a whole $3.50. Long lines at lunch, but they move pretty fast. If you get there before 11 or after 130, it takes like 2 minutes. Lots of Asian snacky foods. They do sometimes put too much jalapenos, but meatball and chicken are my favorites. My Asian coworkers turned got me addicted to it. 1/2 a block down the hill from the "Little Saigon" archway.
author: Dave B.

description: This place has the best Vietnamese sandwiches in town.  There a bunch of them opening up, but none beats Saigon Sandwiches.  The bread is toasted and the meats are so savory that it makes your mouth water immediately.  Although it's in the TL, the place has charm.  It's a true hole in the wall opened by immigrants.  They open at 6am and close at 6pm.  They have 4 to 5 different choices of meats ranging from roast pork & chicken to a special combination.  This place gets a 5 stars especially since the sandwiches are only $3.
author: Hoang D.

description: Best Vietnamese sandwich place ever!!! a lot of condiments for a price that can't be beat...much better than Lee's Sandwiches (check out my review there).
author: J N.

description: Tried: wrap delight, lee's, baguette express, sing sing sandwich and saigon sandwich. Wow, 5 Banh Mi shops within a 3 block radius- and I'm sure I even missed a couple. Truly we are blessed in this city with such bounty of a cheap and truly brilliant sandwich. I don't know how I lived before I discovered Banh Mi. $2.50? I still feel like I'm getting away with something sometimes. So ok, so I love and praise all Banh Mi. That being said, out of the places I've tried I like Saigon the best (Wrap delight second). After sampling everything on the menu I have settled on the pork meatball sandwich, as it is more consistent than the roast pork or roast chicken, which are wonderful about 80% of the time, unless you get a mouth full of gristle. My vegetarian girlfriend prefers their more moist style of tofu to the dry shredded variety offered at wrap delight and baguette express. The special combination here is a bit overwhelming... if you're looking for that exotic combination of pates and various other meats that some say is the only TRUE vietnamese sandwich, I would recomment sing sing sandwich on hyde between eddy and ellis... they make a darn good one, (and it's the only kind of sandwich they make!!)  But really, for overall quality, consistency and cheapness you can't beat saigon sandwich. Thank you saigon sandwich, you've probably saved me enough change spent on lunch over the last 4 years to buy a new computer.
author: Dan W.

description: their tofu sandwiches are the best ever!!  even anthony bourdain loves saigon sandwich!
author: Chloe C.

description: $3 sandwiches that are GOOD.  This is quite posssibly the only Vietnamese sandwich spot that doesn't skimp on the ingredients.
author: Marvin W.

description: the sandwiches are really good.  line is pretty long.  the two ladies are really nice.  overall its way better than lee's sandwiches from across the street.
author: Tung T.

description: amazing! love the bread, roast pork, veggies and sauce!
author: Fat L.

description: i love this dirty hole in the wall!!!!!!! that's exactly what it looks like, but omg, their sandwiches.....SOME OF THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD. this is a hidden gem, i hope they stay around forever
author: P M.

description: after wasting a few hours of my life on jury duty, i decided to give this place a try since it's on the way home. there were no line when i got there which was just 11am. this place remind me of an old corner store feel. there were two ladies manning the store and making sandwiches. the menu from what i can see did not have much options but it's okay because with vietnamese sandwiches i always get combination. it had roasted pork, pate, carrots, pickled radish, and a couple of slice pork cake (minus jalapenos and cilantro). i have to admit i was a little disappointed with the size since i was accustomed to the little paris size. but after the first bite, OMG! it was a party of flavor in my mouth! it was greasy but it's soooooooooooo worth it! $3.50 a pop and made fresh in front of you i'm definitely coming back for more. beware lunch hours! they get busy really fast and expect a long line.
author: Lynn P.

description: there is nothing i can say about this place that hasn't been said before.  i had been meaning to go here for quite some time but it's kind of downhill from me and i hate walking uphill so that's why i hadn't gone here.  but as usual yelpers did not let me down.  i got the special combination "i think" it had pork cake pork and pate.  delicious.  and 3.25.  forget about it there is not a better cheaper place in the city hands down.
author: Anthony Y.

description: everything you've heard is true -- moist, creamy, cheap
author: Erica C.

description: i love the sandwiches here.. i think it's the mayo and the carrots.. my friends laugh at me when i say that, but it's true. i've been to other vietnamese sandwich places, but this place is it!! they're so juicy and yummy:) and the fact that their sandwiches are so cheap makes them, oh so irristable!! (however you spell that word.. )
author: Mari K.
